      • Blastomycosis dermatidis (RFs: lives in soil, most commonly found Great Lakes, Mississippi & Ohio river valleys, SE US; typically inhaled; hosts usually of normal health; Sites: lungs, skin if disseminated or as primary problem; Sx: many are asymptomatic; sometimes flu-like illness; others w/sub acute cough, fever, sob; skin nodules or ulcers) more from CDC
      • Coccidiomycosis (Etiology: south west US, higher risk if immune-compromised; Site: lung parenchyma and pleural space, joints, skin; Sx: sub-acute sob, cough, f, also arthritis, skin nodules, seeding of other sites) more from CDC
      • In compromised hosts, any severe systemic infxn (bacterial or fungal) can metastasize to skin
    • Rickettsial
      • Rocky Mtn Spotted Fever (Etiology: tick borne, incubation 2d to 2w; can occur in most states in US, Sx: f, c, ha, arthralgias, then generalized rash; can be severe/fatal) more from CDC
      • Typhus (various types) (Etiology: spread via flea, louse or tick, reservoirs often rodents squirrels; summer mos, incubation 1-2w, Central/South America, Asia, Central Africa, tropics; Sx: non-specific f, c, ha, malaise, myalgias; PE: non-specific mac-pap rash, sometimes adenopathy)
    • Spirochete
      • Secondary syphillis (Rfs: unprotected intercourse, men who have sex w/men, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's; Sx: secondary manifestations weeks after primary chancre heals; include: condyloma lata→ moist, frond-like growth in genital area; non-specific rash, w/predilection for palms, and soles, mucosal involvement, adenopathy, alopecia) more from CDC
      • Lyme (Rfs: hx living in area endemic w/Lyme→ Northeast, WI/MN, Northern Calif, occurs secondary to tick bite; Sx: bull's eye type rash→ erythema migrans, f, c, adenopathy, arthralgias; joint inflammation mos to yrs later, large joints, can wax/wane; PE: erythema migrans rash, joint pain, swelling, effusion) more from CDC
    • Parasitic
      • Cutaneous larva migrans (hookworm) (Etiology: typical hosts are cats and dogs; larvae shed in tool, enter humans thru bare feet; Sx: migrate thru the skin, causing itchiness and red lines; die after a few weeks w/resolution of sx)
      • Leishmaniasis (Kala Azar) (Etiology: spread by sand-fly bite, widespread throughout subtropics→ Africa, Central & South America, India, Mediterranean basin, Asia, Middle East; Sx/PE: cutaneous: papule→ nodule→ painless raised & indurated ulcers that don't heal over weeks to mos; visceral→ can be silent, or cause fevers, sweats, chills, wt loss, adnenopathy, organomegaly)
      • Lice (Sx: itching in hair, often occurs in outbreaks amongst kids; PE: can sometimes see moving lice on scalp; nits on hair shaft) more from CDC
      • Loa Loa (Etiology: from bite of deerfly; central and west Africa; Sx: diffue or local itching; transient, painless, red swellings; tendency for arms, legs, near joints; transient blurriness if crawl across eye; many are asx; takes mos after bite for sx to develop in those that get them; PE: transient, painless, red swelling; sometimes see worms moving under skin) more from CDC
      • Scabies (Sx: can be acute or chronic, intense itching→in particular at night, predilection for web spaces/hands/arms though can be anywhere, sometimes burrows visible, but often just papules and excoriations seen; spread person to person, including via sexual contact) more from CDC
      • Schistosomiasis (fluke) (Etiology: South America, Middle East, Caribbean, Africa: flukes, invade skin of swimmers, enter blood stream→ live in portal/mesenteric veins; Sx: itching and erruption during first few days @ site where enters skin; can cause portal htn after years; also f, c, abd pain, diarrhea; can live in bladder → SCC after years)
      • Strongyloidiasis (Etiology: warm/temperate regions including southeast US, tropics/subtropics including Asia/Southeast Asia; larvae enter thru feet/skin if walk barefoot in soil w/infected feces→ enter skin, where they can cause itching→ travel to lung→ penetrate alveoli and travel up trachea→ cough and then swallowed→ travel to and live in small intestine; Sx: most carry life-long w/o any sx; non-compromised hosts can have vague sx including cough, epigastic pain, weakness, watery diarrhea, itching, constipation; can cause life threatening hyper-infxn syndrome w/systemic symptoms if compromised from glucocorticoids, malignancy, HTLV-1 or organ transplant; PE: sometimes serpiginous red erruption from migrating larva under skin)

      HIV

      HIV can manifest in many ways. Below are common conditions (organized by organ system) associated w/this protean infection. Note that CD4 thresholds should be viewed as rough guidelines.

      Acute HIV Infxn

      • HIV (Etiology/Rfs: hiv risk factors→ men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; risks of unusual infection increase as CD4 declines; Sx: acute infection→ fever, chills, sweats, adenopathy, rash, pharyngitis; sometimes aseptic meningitis/encepahlitis; occur w/in 2-4 weeks exposure - then resolve; latency until later sx develop 6-10y after initial infxn if un-treated)

      IRIS

      • Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (RFs: low cd4, untreated or sub-optimally treated HIV, known or quiescent opportunistic infections (OIs), cancer (e.g. Kaposis) or autoimmune d/o: Etiology: reconstitution of immune system w/initiation of Anti-retroviral therapy→ profound inflammatory reaction as body responds to pathogen(s)/diseases; Sx: f, transient worsening of known infection/disease or unmasking of quiescent/unknown condition; specific sx based on the OI(s)/pathological condition and the anatomic site where focused; e.g: if pulmonary TB>worsening sob and hypoxia; if CNS crypto→ worsening meningitis; if CMV retinitis→ worsening visual sx, etc.; sx range from mild to severe; occurs within days to ~8 weeks of starting ARVs; then sx resolve & patient improves.)

      Neuro - Headache

      Could still be due to any of the problems that affect normal hosts.
      • Infection
        • Bacterial Meningitis (Etiology: inflammation of layers covering brain; Sx: photphobia, acute neck stiffness, headache, fever, confusion, and generalized illness; PE: f, + Kernigs (specific not sensitive)→ pain with passive knee extension when hip flexed to 90; + Brudzinski (specific not sensitive)→ hip and knee flexion occurs w/passive neck flexion; + jolt (sensitive not specific)→ worsening ha when patient rotates head back & forth; less common to have focal neurological findings and overall less impaired compared w/encephalitis)
        • Abscess (Etiology: reason for abscess → spread from adjacent site→ dental or sinuses, AVM, PFO, neurosurgery; organism based on underlying etiology: can be single, mixed; also consider nocardia; Sx: acute/subacute, headache, fever, loss of function based on location, progressive, delirium)
        • Toxoplasmosis (Etiology: typically causes mass lesion; less commonly encephalitis; Rfs: CD4 < 200; Sx: sub-acute, headache, confusion, fever, seizure, focal neuro deficits)
        • HSV (Etiology: causes encephalitis; Sx: fever, confusion, progressive over days to weeks)
        • VZV (Etiology: causes menongo-encephalitis; Sx: fever, confusion, rash, focal deficits including CN palseys)
        • CMV (Etiology: relatively rare cause encephalitis; RFs: CD4 < 50; Sx: progresses over days)
        • Cryptococcus (Rfs: CD4 < 50; Etiology: typically causes meningitis, less commonly cryptococcomas; often assoc w/increased ICP; Rfs: CD4 < 50; Sx: headache, fever, confusion; progresses over hours to days)
        • Cocci (Rfs: CD4 < 250; Sx: headache, neck pain, lethargy, living in endemic area &rarr Southwest)
        • TB (Etiology: can cause meningitis, tuberculomas or both; Rfs: TB elsewhere, CD4 < 350; Sx: fever, sweats, weight loss, confusion; focal deficits)
        • Syphilis (Rfs: can occur at any CD4 level, sexual exposure; Etiology/Sx/PE: primary, secondary and tertiary manifestations; primary infection causes painless genital ulcer → heals 4-6w; secondary manifestations weeks later non-specific rash, w/predilection for palms , and soles, condyloma around genital areas, mucous involvement, adenopathy; ha, photophobia, stiff neck w/syphillitic meningitis; tertiary manifestations yrs later affecting CNS→ numbness, weakness, balance problems, dementia; large blood vessels→ aortitis, aneurysm) more from CDC
      • Malignancy
        • Primary CNS Lymphoma (Etiology: typically B-cell; Rfs: CD4 < 50; Sx: sub-acute, lethargy, confusion, HA, focal deficits, seizure)
        • Systemic Lymphoma(Etiology: nhl, tends to be aggressive; Rfs: CD4 < 50; Sx: sub-acute, f, sweats, wt loss, confusion, focal deficits, seizure, adenopathy elsewhere, unexplained organogmegaly)

      Neuro - Other

      10-20% have neuro dysfxn as first manifestation HIV; 60% w/neuro dysfxn w/advanced dz.
      • AIDS Related Dementia (Etiology: related to toxic effect of HIV itself; tracks w/low CD4 count and high VL; RFs: not on HAART, high VL, low CD4; Sx: cognition→ inattention, reduced conentration, slowed processing; motor→ slowed movement, clumsiness, ataxia; behavior→ ranges from apathetic/dulled to aggitated; progressive over time to severe impairment and death; some component reversible w/rx HAART)
      • Delirium (Etiology: multi factorial; high risk if low CD4, as suseptible to many OIs and related organ dysfxn; also related to meds and other contributors as w/non-HIV patients)
      • Demyelinating polyneuropathy - CIDP or Guillain-Barre like
      • Mononeuritis multiplex (Etiology: can occur w/low or higher CD4; Sx: isolated or multifocal peripheral nerve or root dysfxn; asymmetric; motor and sensory; develops over weeks; in those w/higher CD4s often self-limited)
      • Myelopathy (Rfs: advanced/end stage; Sx: slowly progressive over mos, bilateral weakness, numbness and urinary dysfxn; specifics related to region of cord affected; PE: symmetirc spasticity, hyperreflexia, babinski, impaired sensation)
      • Myopathy (Etiology: rare; related to HIV or meds; Sx: progressive, proximal muscle weakness; sensory fxn preserved; sometimes muscle pain; PE: proximal muscle weakness, nl sensation and reflexes)
      • Peripheral Neuropathy (Sx: bilateral, tingling and pain; begins distal and moves prox; related to HIV virus and/or ARVs; PE: decreased peripheral sensation, loss of reflexes)
      • Progressive lumbrosacral polyradiculopathy (Etiology: uncommon, related to CMV or other pathogens; Sx: progressive B leg weakness, impaired sensation; develops over weeks, leads to paralysis, incontinence)
      • Progressive Multi-focal Leukoencephalopathy (PML) (Etiology: JC virus; RFs: CD4 < 100; Sx: lethargy, apathy, hallucinations, inattentiveness, perservation, & other manifestations of confusional state that's progressive over months, unrelenting→ leading to disability and death)
      • Seizures (Etiology: related to structural brain dz from infection or cancer; meds/drug of abuse/withdrawl; toxic-metabolic process; or could have unrelated szr d/o)
      • Stroke (Etiology: related to metabolic complications of meds, aging of patients w/HIV; Sx: similar to non-HIV patients - w/loss of fxn based on site of stroke)

      Skin and Mucous Membranes

      The following are skin disorders most commonly associated w/HIV. They tend to track w/CD4 counts, though it's important to recognize that patient's w/HIV can still suffer from disorders that occur in the general population.
    • Acute retroviral infection
      • Acute HIV (Rfs: men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/somone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; Sx/PE: throat pain and redness w/o exudate, fevers, chills, non-specific rash, adenopathy)
    • Bacterial
      • Bacillary angiomatosis (bartonella sp) (Site: skin; Rfs: occurs in HIV infected or otherwise compromised pts; Sx: fevers, sweats, wt loss; PE: nodules on skin, resemble Kaposis Sarcoma) more from CDC
      • Cellulitis (Rfs: common bacterial infxn w/HIV +; Etiology: strep, staph, mrsa; Sx/PE: acute, painful, redness, fever; most commonly strep, though can be staph as well; focal swelling if associated with skin abscess - tend to be staph)
      • Folliculitis (Etiology: acute inflammatory process that starts around hair follicle, typically bacterial (staph, pseudomonas w/hot tubs); Sx: acute, painful, red; PE: tender, erythematous pustules)
    • Fungal
      • Oral candidiasis (thrush) (Rfs: lower CD4 counts associated w/peristence and/or recurrence; PE: white discharge, bleeds when scraped)
      • Vaginal candidiasis (Rfs: lower CD4 counts associated w/peristence and/or recurrence; PE: cottage-cheese type discharge, itchy, bleeds when scraped)
      • Histoplasmosis (Sites; lungs, liver, spleen, mouth, systemic; Rfs: exposure to Mississippi & Ohio river valley, HIV+; Sx: can be asx/mild and resolve spont; often see x-ray evidence prior infection lung, spleen w/o known past infxn; cough, fever; can cause resp/systemic illness, oral ulcers in HIV+)
      • Blastomycosis dermatidis (RFs: lives in soil, most commonly found Great Lakes, Mississippi & Ohio river valleys, SE US; typically inhaled; hosts usually of normal health; Sites: lungs, skin if disseminated or as primary problem; Sx: many are asymptomatic; sometimes flu-like illness; others w/sub acute cough, fever, sob; skin nodules or ulcers) more from CDC
      • Coccidiomycosis (Etiology: south west US, higher risk if immune-compromised Site: lung parenchyma and pleural space, joints, skin; Sx: sub-acute sob, cough, f, also arthritis, skin nodules, seeding of other sites) more from CDC
    • Viral
      • Herpes Simplex Virus (Sx: acute, painful, vessicles; pain often present before lesions appear, regress spontaneously 1-3w; w/low CD4 counts, may recur or persist)
      • HIV related apthous ulcers (Rfs: men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/somone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, hx needle stick injury from infected person; PE: painful ulcer(s) w/surrounding erythema)
      • Herpes Zoster (Rfs: increased incidence and recurrence rates as CD4 drops; Sx: acute vessicular erruption, pain a few days prior to skin lesions, neuropathic/burning type pain, PE: vessicles in a dermatomal distribution) more from CDC
      • HPV (Rfs: Low CD4; Sx: painless growths, can be single/grouped/or in multiple clusters, painless, acquired via sexual contact, travel w/other STIs; PE: single or clustered growths) more from CDC
      • Molluscum Contagiosum (Etiology: w/CD4 < 200→ molluscum more numerous & less likely resolved spont; Sx: acute papular erruption, assoc w/viral infection; PE: papules) more from CDC
      • Varicella zoster (chicken pox) (Etiology: if first infxn, can be severe and disseminated w/HIV+; Sx: f, fatigue, ha, generalized vesicular erruption, can still get mild dz if vax, pneumonia in setting severe chicken pox or immunocomp) more from CDC
    • Spirochete
      • Syphilis (Rfs: men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/somone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's; PE: other findings assoc w/secondary syphillis including: non-specific rash, w/predilection for palms, and soles; hx painless genital ulcer from primary infxn)
    • Parasitic
      • Scabies (Rfs: lower CD4 assoc w/crusted (Norwegian)scabies; Sx: can be acute or chronic, intense itching→ in particular at night, predilection for web spaces/hands/arms though can be anywhere, sometimes burrows visible, but often just papules and excoriations seen; spread person to person, including via sexual contact) more from CDC
    • Cancer
      • Kaposis sarcoma (RFs: most commonly assoc w/advanced HIV, though can occur in elderly/others; Sx: purplish/red/brown nodules that can occur anywhere on skin; can affect any organ system including: intestines, liver, lung, etc→ sx related to degree of organ dysfxn; PE: purplish/red/brown nodules)
      • Non-Hodgkins (Etiology: 90% of lymphomas; many different types (B & T cell), significant variability in how aggressive they may be; Rfs: age > 60, hx hiv + confers markedly increased risk aggressive NHL; EBV→ Burkitts; h pylori→ stomach MALT; Sx: f, c, sweats, fatigue, wt loss; PE: progressive, painless, generalized adenopathy; splenomegaly; extra-nodal dz can involve almost any organ system)
      • Basal cell cancer (Etiology: more common w/HIV +; Rfs: chronic sun expossure, fair skin, prior bcc, immuncompromised; Sx: Non-healing, ulcerated, bleeding on a sun exposed region PE: rolled edges, growing, non-healing, central depression, pearly, w/telangiectasias)
      • Squamous cell cancer (Etiology: more common w/HIV +; Rfs: chronic sun expossure, fair skin, prior scc, immuncompromised; Sx: Non-healing, ulcerated, bleeding on a sun exposed region PE: non-healing, growing, crusted, firm, sun exposed areas)
    • Autoimmune, inflammatory d/o, or drug reactions
      • Atopic dermatitis/eczema (Rfs: CD4< 200; Sx: chronic, waxes/wanes, hands/arms/face, itchy; PE: cracked, sometime peeling, puritic, erythematous skin)
      • Seborrheic dermatitis (Etiology: often more pronounced and severe in setting HIV +; Sx: persistent/recurrent scaly, red patches, affecting face, scalp, behind ears, body folds; PE scaly, red, flaky)
      • Psoriasis (Etiology: often more pronounced and severe in setting CDS < 200; Sx: plaques and scale; predilection for knees, elbows, behind ears, umbillicus, gluteal cleft, hands PE: raised plaques & scale on ertheymatous base, pitting of nails) more from CDC
      • HIV Lipodystrophy (Etiology: assoc w/HAART; Sx: abnormal deposition of fat in abd, back of neck, breasts, trunk; loss of sub cu fat in face, extremities, buttocks; assoc w/insulin resistance)
      • Generalized allergic reaction (Etiology: more common w/HIV +; Sx: occurs w/in a week of exposure to a med, itchy, can be local or generalized, morbilliform (measels-like); PE: erythematous, macular, often areas of coalescence)

      SOB/Cough

      Etiology can still be any that affect HIV -; additional considerations based on degree of immune compromise
      • Infection
        • Bacterial pneumonia community acquired: pneumococcus, h influenza, legionella
        • Viral pneumonia - cmv, hsv, vzv
        • Fungi - Coccidimycosis (Rfs: CD4 < 250, living or visit to Southwest; Sx: cough, fever, sob)
        • Fungi - Histoplasmosis (Rfs: CD4 < 300; Sx: cough, sob, sweats; can have multiple other organ systems involved, including: liver, spleen, cns)
        • Fungi - Pneumocystis Jirovecii (Rfs: CD4 < 100 or untreated HIV; Sx: sub-acute, cough, sob, chest pain)
        • Fungi - Cryptococcus (neoformans) (Sites: cns, lungs, skin; Rfs: assoc w/immunocompromised, CD4 < 50 or untreated HIV; Sx: CNS disease→ sub-acute headache, fever, confusion; pulmonary→ subacute cough, sob, chest pain, f)
        • Fungi - Cryptococcus (gattii) (Sites: lungs, skin, cns; Rfs: found on West coast/Pacific Northwest; can cause pneumonia in normal hosts; can also infect those w/HIV and advance t-cell deficiencincy states; Sx: subacute cough, sob, chest pain, f; CNS sx of subacute confusion, ha)
        • Mycobacteria - TB (Rfs: can occur at any CD4, w/CD4 < 350→ extra-pulmonary TB increases; Sx: if > 350, similar sx to non-hiv +→ cough, fever, sweats, sob, hemoptysis)
        • Mycobacterium - MAC (Rfs: HIV + w/CD4 < 50 for disseminated dz; hx bronchietasis for lung sx; Sx: persistent/progressive cough, sputum, sob) more from CDC
      • Malignancy
        • Kaposis Sarcoma (Rfs: CD4 < 150, Sx: sob, cough, PE: KS elsewhere on body)
        • Lymphoma (Sx: sub-actue, f, sweats, wt loss, PE: adenopathy elsewhere, unexplained organogmegaly)

      Diarrhea

      Can still be any of the processes that affect normal hosts as above; also HIV meds; other infectious or malignancy related Etiologyogies increase as cd4 levels decline.
      • Infection
        • Isosporiasis (parasite) (Rfs: CD4 < 100 or untreated HIV, associated with drinking untreated water)
        • Giardia (protozoa) (Etiology: spread via poor hygiene, contaminated water, drinking from ponds/streams, anal intercourse; many infected are asx; Sx: incubation 1-3w; non-bloody watery/greasy/foul smelling diarrhea, gas, burping)
        • Cryptosporidium (parasite) (Rfs: CD4 < 100 or untreated HIV; Sx: acute or subacute profound diarrhea, abdominal cramps, fever, n, v)
        • Microsporidiosis (parasite) (Etiology/Rfs: associated with drinking untreated water, CD4 < 100 or untreated HIV; Sx: in addn to diarrhea, can affect other systems, causing→ keratitis, encephalitis, other)
        • Histoplasmosis (fungal)(Rfs: CD4 < 150; Sx: f, c, wt loss, abd pain; liver, spleen and lymph node involvement)
        • MAI (mycobacterial) (Rfs: CD4 < 50; Sx: diarrhea, n, v, abdominal pain, f, c, fatigue; can infect liver, spleen, lymph nodes, bone marrow, lung, pericardium→ causing adenopathy or organomegaly, anemia)
        • CMV (viral) (Rfs: CD 4 < 50; Sx: cramps, abd pain persistent diarrhea - sometimes w/blood, anorexia, wt loss, fatigue, cmv elsewhere→ retinitis)
      • Malignancy
        • Kaposis (Rfs: CD4 < 150, KS on skin or elsewhere on body)
        • Lymphoma (in partic NHL) (Sx: subacute, f, sweats, wt loss, adenopathy elsewhere, unexplained organogmegaly, focal cns sx)

      Infxns w/Generalized Sx F/C/S

      Serious infections from many pathogens (bacteria, viruses, spirochetes, rickettsia, fungi, parasites) can cause systemic sx of f, c, and/or sweats. The site of origin of the infection (e.g. lung, kidney, etc) usually identified by presence of focal sx occurring prior to or concurrent w/generalized sx. (e.g. cough, sob, sputum→ pneumonia). Infections can also start locally and spread to other sites, leading to focal findings distant from place of origin (e.g. staph endocarditis can lead to an epidural abscess). The infections below tend to cause systemic sx w/o necessarily having localizing sx/site of origin.

      Bacterial

      • Endocarditis (Rfs: prior endocarditis, unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart dz, prosthetic valve, acquired valvular heart dz (e.g. mitral prolapse w/regurg, aortic stenosis, rheumatic heart dz), IVDU, HIV, hemodialysis; Sx: f, c, sweats, sepsis, embolic events w/seeding and assoc sx; rapidity of clinical progression affected by organism and pt substrate; Etiology: 80% staph, strep; other less common organisms HACEK, Coxiella, T Whiplei, fungal; PE: fever, new or worse murmur, relatively rare skin findings include Janeway lesions→flat, painless, erythematous lesions on hands, and Osler's nodes→ painful nodules on fingers, findings associated w/seeding→ e.g. lbp or neuro findings from vertebral osteo, epidural abscess; focal neuro deficits from stroke or brain abscess) Duke criteria for endocarditis
      • Brucellosis (Brucella) (Sites: systemic; Etiology: ingestion of raw/uncooked dairy or handling infected animals; Rfs: veterinarians, meat packers, slaughter house workers, farmers; Middle East, Mediterranean, Mexico, Africa; Sx/PE: causes weeks/months of recurrent f, c, sweats, arthritis, adenopathy, orchitis, hepato-splenomegaly) more from CDC
      • Tularemia (Francisella tularensis) (Sites: skin, lymph nodes, lung; Etiology/Rfs: passed from dying wild animals to humans via ticks/insects, US Southeast and Rocky Mtns; Sx: f, c, ha, oral or skin ulcers, painful adenopathy, sob, cough, muscle aches) more from CDC
      • Neisseria meningitidis (Site: meninges, bacteremia; Rfs: often in outbreaks amongst young adults living in close quarters→ college dorms, barracks; unvaccinated; Sx: f, c, ha, n, v, sepsis; PE: very ill, ha, f, neck pain/stiffness, purpura) more from CDC
      • Typhoid fever (Salmonella typhi) (Site: small bowel, systemic infxn; Etiology: related to poor sanitation→ outbreaks, travel to endemic areas, spread by contaminated/unwashed food, poor sanitation, unclean water; gall bladder can act as reservoir; Rfs: from endemic area or travel; Sx/PE: relapsing daily fever x weeks, malaise, ha, chills, abd pain, diarrhea, maculop-pap rash→ rose spots, relative brady; aside from fever, sx quite variable)
      • Streptococcus Pneumoniae (pneumococcus)(Sites: pneumonia, upper respiratory infections, meningitis; bacteremia if severe; Rfs: s/p splenectomy or fxnl asplenia, eldery and very young, any chronic medical condition→ copd, liver or renal dz, chf, cancer, diabetes, HIV, or otherwise immunocompromised; also csf leaks, cochlear implants; decreased risk if vaccinated) more from CDC

      Viral

      • CMV (Sx/PE: retinitis/colitis/disseminated dz in patients w/HIV; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w, then f, c, malaise hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, fatigue x 4-6w; head/neck adenopathy & pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC
      • Chikungunya (RFs: travel to Carribean, mosquitoe bite; Sx: fever, symmetric arthralgia, inflammatory arthritis wrists, fingers, ankles; muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash; onset 3-7d after bite; usually last days to weeks, sometimes mos) more from CDC
      • Dengue (Etiology: spread by aedes aegypti mosquito; RFs: exposure in tropics, SE Asia, Carribean, South America; Sx: incubation 4-7d, abrupt onset high fever, aches, retro-orbital pain, bone/muscle/joint pain, often low back pain, maculo-pap rash; sx resolve in 3-4d; can recur) more from CDC
      • Ebola (Etiology: spread via close human contact, bats as reservoir; RFs: travel to West Africa or exposure to someone at risk, spread via contact w/body fluids of infected person; Sx: incubation of up to 3w; high fever, fatigue, aches→ 0-3d; epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, arthralgias, myalgias, sorethroat, chest pain, headaches, delirium, conjunctival injection→ 3-10d; severe illness, shock, GI hemorrhage or other complications, death or recovery→ 7-12d) more from CDC
      • EBV (mononucleosis) (Rfs: spread by direct contact→ kissing, shared drinking glasses, shared toothbrushes, etc; Sx: incubation 4-6w, prodrome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias, then f, sore throat; PE: maculo-pap rash after amox or other abx, head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly) more from CDC

      Retroviral

      • HIV (Etiology/Rfs: hiv risk factors→ men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; risks of unusual infection increase as CD4 declines; Sx: acute infection→ fever, chills, sweats, adenopathy, rash, pharyngitis w/in 2-4 weeks - then resolves; latency until sx develop 6-10y after initial infxn (if not treated) related to drop in CD4: generalized sx include f, c, cough, wt loss; other illnesses: mucosal candidiasis; fungal, mtb lung infection; persistent diarrhea; CNS toxo; non hodgkins lymphoma; kaposis sarcoma of skin, adenopathy, etc) more from CDC

      Spirochetes

      • Borrelia burgdorferi (lyme) (Etiology: tick borne, endemic area north east, upper mid west, tick contact x 24-48h; incubation days to weeks; Sx: rash, f, c, aches; then arthralgias, heart block, CNS involvement; later still arthritis; can co-infect w/organisms causing babesiosis and anaplasmosis; PE: erythema migrans bull's eye type rash, sometime inflammatory arthritis) more from CDC
      • Borrelia miyamotoi (Etiology: tick borne, endemic area north east, summer mos; Sx: f, c, headache, arthralgias, myalgias, malaise/fatigue; PE: often ill appearing, sometimes faint lacy rash) more from CDC
      • Borrelia - other sp (relapsing fever) (Etiology: tick borne, mountainous US→ West/Southwest, plateau of Mexico, South America; Sx: fever x ~3d→ then fever free x 1w→ then recurs; chills, ha, muscle aches, n, photophobia, joint aches, confusion; PE: non-specific; sometimes conj injection, confusion, mac-pap rash)
      • Leptospirosis (Etiology: contract via exposure to rodent/wild animal feces; incubation several weeks; Sx/PE: mild dz is self limited f, c, ha, n, v, muscle aches, conjunctival injection; severe dz with hepatic and renal involvement, pulmonary hemorrhage, and icterus) CDC

      Parasites

      • African Trypanosomiasis (t brucei sleeping sickness) (Etiology: Africa, from tsetse fly; Sx: f, c, HA, delirium, muscle and joint aches, death in mos if untreated; PE: chancre→ skin sore at bite site, adenopathy)
      • Babesiosis (B. microti - protozoa) (Etiology: tick born, endemic Northeast/Northern Mid-west US; can co-infect w/lyme and anaplasmosis; Sx: 1-4 w after infxn; subacute f, c, sweats, HA, muscle aches; in severe cases hemolytic anemia, kidney, liver injury, resp distress)
      • Leishmaniasis (Kala Azar) (Etiology: spread by sand-fly bite, widespread throughout subtropics→ Africa, Central & South America, India, Mediterranean basin, Asia, Middle East; Sx/PE: cutaneous: papule→ nodule→ painless raised & indurated ulcers that don't heal over weeks to mos; visceral→ can be silent, or cause fevers, sweats, chills, wt loss, adnenopathy, organomegaly)
      • Malaria (Etiology: spread by anopheles mosquito, tropical climates, in partic Southeast Asia, Africa; variants = P vivax, falciparum, ovale and malariae; Sx: incubation 1-4w; recurrent high fevers, C, HA; mild to life threatening (falciparum))
      • Strongyloidiasis (Etiology: warm/temperate regions including southeast US, tropics/subtropics including Asia/Southeast Asia; larvae enter thru feet/skin if walk barefoot in soil w/infected feces→ enter skin, where they can cause itching→ travel to lung→ penetrate alveoli and travel up trachea→ cough and then swallowed→ travel to and live in small intestine; Sx: most carry life-long w/o any sx; non-compromised hosts can have vague sx including cough, epigastic pain, weakness, watery diarrhea, itching, constipation; can cause life threatening hyper-infxn syndrome w/fever, chills, sweats, abd pain, sepsis if compromised from glucocorticoids, malignancy, HTLV-1 or organ transplant; PE: sometimes serpiginous red erruption from migrating larva under skin)
      • Toxoplasmosis (protozoa) (Etiology: carried in cat feces, healthy hosts not affected, in HIV + causes brain infection cd4 < 200; pregnant women can pass in utero→ congenital abnormalities; Sx: acute f, c, headache, delirium, szr, focal neuro deficits, eye pain and visual loss from retinal involvement)
      • W bancrofti (filariasis) (Rfs/Etiology; tropics/sub-tropics, spread by mosquitoes; Sx: most are asx and wont have sequelae; some will have acute f, c, adenopathy; filaria invade lymphatics, after years→ lymphedema from obstruction of channels; PE: in some, chronic lymphedema)

      Rickettsiae

      • Anaplasmosis (Etiology: tick born, incubation 1-2w, Midwest and Eastern US; can co-infect w/organisms causing Lyme and babesiosis; Sx: f, ha, n, v, myalgias; often causes BM suppression)
      • Coxiella Burnetti (Q fever) (Etiology: spread from cattle and sheep, incubation 5d-2w; Sx: fever, chills, severe ha, myalgias, malaise, cough, abd pain; many recover spont; can cause pneumonia, hepatitis, myocarditis)
      • Human ehrlichiosis (Etiology: tick borne, incubation 1-2w, endemic South Eastern, South Central and Eastern US; similar presentation to anaplasmosis; Sx: f, ha, n, v, myalgias; often causes BM suppression)
      • Rocky Mtn Spotted Fever (Etiology: tick borne, incubation 2d to 2w; can occur in most states in US, Sx: f, c, ha, arthralgias, then generalized rash; can be severe/fatal)
      • Typhus (various types) (Etiology: spread via flea, louse or tick, reservoirs often rodents squirrels; summer mos, incubation 1-2w, Central/South America, Asia, Central Africa, tropics; Sx: non-specific f, c, ha, malaise, myalgias; PE: non-specific mac-pap rash, sometimes adenopathy)
      • More on Rickettsiae from CDC

      Fungi

      Typically assoc w/compromised host.
      • Aspergillus (Sites: lungs, sinuses, Sx: cough/sob in compromised host→ tissue invasive or fungal ball; facial fullness/pain, nasal d/c→ invasive sinusitis in patients w/DM or otherwise compromised; recurrent wheezing in normal hosts→ ABPA)
      • Blastomycosis dermatidis (RFs: lives in soil, most commonly found Great Lakes, Mississippi & Ohio river valleys, SE US; typically inhaled; hosts usually of normal health; Sites: lungs, skin if disseminated or as primary problem; Sx: many are asymptomatic; sometimes flu-like illness; others w/sub acute cough, fever, sob; skin nodules or ulcers) more from CDC
      • Candida (Rfs: compromised host→ HIV, chemo, steroids, long term abx w/indwelling lines, TPN use, long ICU stays; Sx: fevers, systemic sx/sepsis)

      Mycobacteria

      • M Tuberculosis (MTB) (RFs: HIV +, ETOh, chronic kidney, liver, lung dz; dialysis, homeless, immunocompromised for other reason→ steroid, TNF inhibitors, other; though can occur in anyone, reactivating sometimes years after initial exposure; extra-pulm TB increases in HIV+ w/CD4 < 350; Sx: sub-acute, cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, sweats, fatigue; can also infect GI/GU tracts, pericardium, bones, cns, lymph nodes or become widely disseminated) more from CDC

      Non-Infectious: Malignancy

      Cancers cause fever as primary manifestation of malignancy or a result of infection→ induced immunocompromised state and/or chemotherpy. Malignancies most commonly linked to pimary fever listed below:

      Solid tumors

      • Renal cell (Rfs: smoking, obesity, family hx, male; avg age mid 60s; Sx: low back to lower abd/groin discomfort, wt loss, sweats, fever, flank pain, hematuria; PE: papable only if very advanced)
      • Liver (hepatocellular) (Rfs: chronic hepatitis for any reason→ viral, etoh, etc; Sx: RUQ/epigastric persistent/progressive discomfort discomfort, anorexia, weight loss; PE: palpable, firm liver if advanced)
      • Metastatic disease involving the liver - primary can be anywhere

      Liquid tumors

      Sx: fevers, chills, weight loss, adenopathy, decreased appetite; fatigue/low energy/chronically tired/SOB→ from anemia, mucocutaneous bleeding→ from low plt; impaired immunity, recurrent infections from→ low numbers or dysfunctional WBCs
      • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) (Etiology: monoclonal B cell d/o; Rfs: age > 60, male sl > female, agent orange exposure; Sx: often asx x years→ picked up on incidental labs; then fever, sweats, adenopathy, fatigue, wt loss, bleeding, infections; can transform into acute leukemia or lmphoma; can develop auto-immune hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia; PE: as progresses→ adenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly)
      • Chronic myelocytic leukemia (CML) (Etiology: associated w/9:22 chromosome translocation; Rfs: avg age 55-60, radiation, male sl > female; Sx: fatigue, abdominal fullness, f, weats, wt loss; WBCs elevated, often plt too; chronic phase x 3-5y; then accelerated phase w/blast crisis→ infection, bleeding; PE: often splenomegaly)
      • Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) (Etiology: most common acute leukemia in kids; in adults, represents 20% of acute leukemias; RFs: in adults→ male, hx prior radiation or chemo, > age 70, Down's syndrome; Sx: fatigue, sob, weakness, fever, sweats, easy bruising/bleeding; PE: palor, petechiae, echymoses; sometimes adenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)
      • Acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) (Etiology: most common adult acute leukemia; Rfs: male, age > 60, smoking, hx prior chemo or xrt; hx of myelofibrosis, essential thrombocythemia, polycythemia vera; Sx: fatigue, fever, dyspnea, easy bruising; PE: palor, echymoses, petechiae, musocal bleeding; sometimes adenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)
      • Other leukemias
      • Myelofibrosis (Etiology: sometimes have p vera, cml or ET first; Sx: generalized fatigue, night sweats, wt loss, fever; sob, doe→ from anemia; abd discomfort from hepato-splenomegaly→ sites of extra med hematopoeisis; PE: hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)

      Lymphoma

      General Sx: wt loss/decreased appetite sweats, fevers, chills, adenopathy, organomegaly, abdominal fullness; CNS involvement and sx w/NHL; skin involvement w/cutanous t-cell NHL
      • Hodgkins (Etiology: 10% of lymphomas; Rfs: age 15-40 & > 55, hiv +, EBV infection, fam hx; Sx: fever, sweats, wt loss, adenopathy; cough/sob if mediastinal invovlmenet; PE: painless, progressive adenopathy, in particular head/neck; sometimes splenomegaly, hepatomegaly)
      • Non-Hodgkins (Etiology: 90% of lymphomas; many different types (B & T cell), significant variability in how aggressive they may be; Rfs: age > 60, hx hiv + confers markedly increased risk aggressive NHL; EBV→ Burkitts; h pylori→ stomach MALT; Sx: f, c, sweats, fatigue, wt loss; PE: progressive, painless, generalized adenopathy; splenomegaly; extra-nodal dz can involve almost any organ system)

      Non-Infectious: Autoimmune/Rheum d/o

      Specific disorder based on other symptoms and findings - relatively uncommon (compared w/above)
      • Acute rheumatic fever (Sx: relatively uncommon, occurs 2-3w after strep pharyngitis, assoc w/fever, fatigue, acute/abrupt onset, migratory inflammatory arthritis of large joints typically; long term risk of mitral or aortic valve dz; PE: affected joint(s) are warm, red, pain w/movement)
      • Adult Still's Disease (Etiology: febrile illness of unknown etiology; Sx: f and other sx are persistent, sub-acute; evaluation of f does not reveal other etiology; also arhtritis & arthralgias of larger joints; salmon colored, maculo-pap non-puritic skin erruption; myalgias, adenopathy, sore throat, pericarditis and pleuritis; PE: erruption is light salmon colored mac/pap, pharyngitis, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy)
      • Cryogloblulinemia (Etiology: small-vessel vasculitis caused by antigen-antibody complex deposition; Type I monoclonal→ IgM or IgG, related to lymphoprolif d/o→ lymphoma, myeloma; Type II and III, mixed cryos IgM and IgG; related to Hep C (most common), SLE, RA, lymphoma, myeloma, hiv, hep b, other autoimmune; RFs: female > male, ages 40-50; Sx: subacute fatigue, weakness, muscle and joint aches, cough/sob if pulmonary involvement; confusion; symmetric or asymmetric often painful distal neuropathy, painful skin ulcers of extremities, purpuric papules; membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis; PE: palpable purpura of vasculitis, Raynauds, livedo reticularis, distal skin ulcers)
      • Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss) (Etiology: idiopathic d/o, small-to-medium vessel vasculitis; w/high levels circulating and tissue invasive eosinophils; Rfs: men=women, assoc also w/leukotriene antagonists; Sx: progressive, adult onset asthma, cough & wheezing, nasal stuffiness→ w/resp sx usually ~2-10 y prior to systemic sx assoc w/eosinophilic deposition in target organs and vasculitis; in these later phases→ systemic sx including: sob from parenchymal lung involvement; f, c, muscle aches; hematuria from renal involvement; heart failure, pericarditis and dysrhythmia w/cardiac involvement; peripheral neuropathy; PE: wheezing, skin findings of vasculitis: small, palapable purpura, don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; hematuria/renal involvement; unexplained peripheral neuropathy)
      • Familial Med Fevers (Rfs: Mediterranean descent→ Turkish, Jewish, Armenian, Arab, other; family hx; Sx: uncommon, associated w/cryptic abdominal pain, rash, arthritis, arthralgias, myalgias, recurrent fever)
      • Giant Cell Arteritis (Rfs: age > 50, often prior hx PMR; Sx fatigue, headache, joint aches, f, c, acute visual loss; PE: sometimes scalp or temp art tenderness, abnl optic nerve)
      • Granulomatosis with poyangiitis (Wegeners) (Etiology: small-to-medium vessel vasculitis; Sx: vasculitis→ recurrent/progressive nasal congestion, cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; PE: mucosal erythema, ulcer, nasal septum perf)
      • Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) (Etiology: uncontrolled activation of T Cells, w/inappropriate release of cytokines and macrophage activation; Rx directed at underlying cause; Rfs: triggered by lymphoma, leukemia, autoimmunes dz, infxns→ ebv, enterovirus, gastroenteritis, other; also a rare familial form; Sx: f that's unexplained, other related to the inciting process, increased ferretin, cytopenias, hyper-TGs; PE: f, splenomegaly)
      • Inflammatory bowel disease - Crohn's dz or UC (Sx: sub-acute, recurrent or chronic diarrhea; wt loss, bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, nocturnal diarrhea; systemic sx; presentation can also be fulminant)
      • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
      • Microscopic polyangitis (MPA) (Etiology: small vessel vasculitis; Sx: fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, sweats, wt loss; recurrent/progressive cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; less often nasal sx c/w GPA; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; skin ulcers; neuropathy; PE: palpable purpura, skin ulcer/necrosis)
      • Polyarteritis Nodosa (Etiology: medium-vessel-vasculitis; Rfs: 40s-50s, men>women, Hep B/C; Sx: more commonly subacute over mos f, s, malaise, wt loss, muscle/joint pain; multiple systems: arthritis, glomerulonephritis, peripheral nerve pain/dysfxn, skin w/ulcers, small, palapable purpura→ don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; abd pain, blood per rectum)
      • Polymyalgia Rheumatica (PMR) (Rfs: age > 50, Sx: subacute arthralgias affecting hips and shoulders, f, c, worse in AM; can't sleep secondary to inability to find comfortable position; PE: no findings of arthritis/synovitis on exam, no objective findings of weakness)
      • RA (Etiology: can cause interstitial lung dz, pleural inflammation, pulm vasc dz; meds for RA can have lung tox, also→ immunocomp→ infxn; Rfs: women > men; age 30-55; Sx: subacute (>6w), persistent/progressive joint pain, worse in AM due to gelling→ improves w/use, fatigue, tendency for bilateral involvement, commonly small and medium sized joints; nerve symptoms can be motor, sensory or from compression; PE: warmth, redness, spongy feeling from synovial inflam, pain w/squeezing of joints, effusion, abnormal appearing if longstanding, MCPs with chronic changes; extra articular findings: episcleritis, pleural/pericardial inflam, rheumatoid nodules) more from CDC
      • Serum sickness (Rfs: typically from rxn to abx, or secondary to viral infxn → e.g. acute hep b; Sx: acute, symetric, additive/migratory, polyarthritis; myalgias, fever, rash, onset days to weeks after exposure)
      • Takayasu's arteritis (Etiology: large vessel vasculitis, onset 10-30yo, Asian background, women > men; Sx: sub-acute and progressive, fevers, fatigue, wt loss, myalgias arthralgias; target organ sx based on affected vessels: abdominal aorta & branches→ abdominal pain, htn; thoracic aorta & branches→ chest pain, sob, tia/stroke; PE: loss of palpable pulses radial, carotid, lower extremity)
      • Vasculitis - other

      Non-Infectious: Endocrine

      • Menopause (Rfs: age ˜ 50; Sx: sweats but no fever, irregular menstruation)
      • Hyperthyroidism (Etiology: grave's disease, thyroiditis, multi-nodular or single toxic adenoma, exogenous thyroid hormone consumption; Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, sweating, wt loss, weakness; PE: fever, sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid→ nodules, pain or diffuse enlargement based on etiology, hyper-reflexia, moist skin)
      • Thyroid storm (Etiology: a profound thyrotoxic state, w/mortality 20-30%; Rfs: untreated or undiagnosed hyperthyroidism, often triggered by stress/infection or iodine admin from CT; Sx: acute, severe palpatations, sob/doe, tremor, abd discomfort, n, v, d, delirium; PE: ill appearing, fever, tachycardia, a fib, tremor, enlarged thyroid, abd discomfort, pulmonary edema/findings of chf, confusion)
      • Low testosterone (Sx: decreased libido, errectile dysfxn, generalized weakness, decreased muscle mass, depression)
        • Primary (Rf/Etiology: testicular hypofunction from: prior infection→ mumps; torsion/trauma/cancer/other reason for testicular death; past chemotherpay; genetic disorders→ hemochromatosis, prader-willi; PE: sometimes small or absent testes)
        • Secondary (Rf/Etiology: pituitary/hypothalamic dysfxn from: tumor, inflammatory processes, hypoperfusion; meds→ chronic narcotics, LHRH agonists for prostate ca; chronic diseases→ HIV, Dm, copd, chf, renal failure, cirrhosis)
      • Adrenal insufficiency (Sx: feeling poorly in general, n, v, orthostatic sx)
        • Primary (Etiology: problem at level of adrenal gland: autoimmune destruction → assoc w/DM 1, celiac dz; hemorrhage/infarct; infection → TB, HIV; infiltration w/tumor; PE: sometimes darkening of mucous membranes, skin folds, & pressure points)
        • Secondary (Etiology: problem at level of pituitary/hypothalamus → low acth; can be from surgery, tumor, hypoperfusion, auto-immune, trauma, meds→ chronic glucocorticoids)

      Non-Infectious: Meds

      Dx based on r/o other causes and temporal link between initiation med and fever onset
      • Malignant hyperthermia (Etiology: exposure to inhalational anesthetics or succinylcholine, typically in OR or w/in 24h; Sx: abrupt onset high fever, aggitation; PE: temp to 46c, Htn, tachycardia, tachypnea, ill appearing, diaphoretic, mottled skin, severe generalized rigidity, decreased reflexes)
      • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (Etiology: exposure to haldol, chlorpomazine, other typical or atypical neruoleptics; more common w/high dose or soon after rx/dose change, but also idiosyncratic→ occurring after years of rx; sx progress over several d; Sx: autonomic instability w/HTN, tachycardia, tachypnea, temp can be > 41.1c, pale, sweaty, fluctuating delirium→ aggitated or stupor/alert mutism to coma, cramps, generalized lead-pipe type muscular rigidity, decreased reflexes)
      • Cholinergic agents (Etiology: organophosphate insecticide overdose or exposure; Sx: sedation, confusion, sweating, shortness of breath; PE: salivation, wheezing, lacrimation, bronchorrea, emesis, diarrhea, urination)
      • Serotonin syndrome (Etiology: SSRIs, MAOIs, anti-epileptics, others; rapid onset sx ususally following rx initiation or dose change, though can occur if received rx w/in 5w; sometimes med combinations precipitate syndrome; intential overdose; Sx: aggiation/easily startled, sweating, shivering, diarrhea; PE: spectrum→ htn, tachycardia, tachypnea, hyperthermia to > 41c, flushed & sweaty skin, tremor, confusion/aggitation to coma, increased bowel sounds, clonus, muscular hyperactivity/stiffness, hyper-reflexia)
      • Many other meds - including broad range of abx

      Non-Infectious: Other

      • DVT/PE (RFs: immobility, trauma, known hypercoag state, past dvt/pe; Sx: acute, cough, SOB, pleuritic cp, hemoptysis; PE: tachycardia, tachypnea, often clear lungs; less commonly wheezing or findings of effusion; unexplained unilateral leg swelling; Well's Criteria for DVT; Well's Criteria for PE)

      Recent medical evaluations or treatments?

      • Patients sometimes neglect to mention evaln/rx by other MDs/Clinics, ERs, hospitals, etc

      Feeling well (or poorly) in general?

      • A possible non-specific indicator of problems

      More Info About General Symptoms:

      Comprehensive HPI and The rest of the history

      Back

      Eyes

      Comprehensive eye exam

      Chronic or past eye d/o?

      • glaucoma, macular degeneration, DM retinal disease, other

      Decline in vision/blurriness?

      Assessment of visual acuity

      Abrupt visual loss is a red flag for potentially serious underlying problems.

      Acute - Painless

      Lens

      • Profound hyperglycemia (Sx: blurriness due to lens edema, other sx DM→ polyuria, polydypsia, wt loss, fatigue)

      Vitreous

      • Vitreous hemorrhage (Rfs: often hx diabetes or trauma; Sx: acute, unilateral, degree of visual loss ranges blurry→ complete; PE: no red reflex, cant see retina)

      Retina & optic nerve

      • Retinal ischemia/stroke (Rfs: htn, dm, hyperlipidemia, known vascular dz, smoking, early fam hx; Sx: unilateral, like a "curtain dropping," field of visual loss based on distribution of artery occluded; PE: affected area retina may look paler)
      • Retinal vein occlusion (Rfs: htn, dm, hyperlipidemia, known vascular dz, smoking, early fam hx; Sx: unilateral, sudden visual loss; vision probs range from blurry to complete loss→ varies w/size of vein affected; PE: unilateral decrease in acuity, affected area of retina→ hemorrhage, edema, exudates, venous dilation)
      • Retinal hemorrhage (Rfs: associated w/DM neovascularization→ chronic poorly controlled DM, htn; Sx: unilateral visual loss or blurriness; PE: decrease in visual acuity, abnormal appearing retina)
      • Retinal detachment (Sx: unilateral, floaters, flashes; can occur post trauma or post surgery or spont; partial visual field loss that doesn't follow a pattern; can progress; PE: retina appears abnl)
      • Giant cell/temporal arteritis (Rfs: age > 50, F>M; 20% w/PMR will develop GCA; 50% w/GCA had PMR; Sx: f, ha, jaw claudication, wt loss, scalp pain, muscle aches typically x mos; visual loss abrupt, w/other sx typically first; PE: sometimes scalp/temp art tenderness, edematous optic nerve)
      • Retinal melanoma (Sx: typically slow onset blurriness; can be abrupt if associated w/bleeding; PE: decreased acuity, abnormal appearing retina)
      • Macular hemorrhage/edema (Sx: decreased central vision, unilateral; abnormal macula; PE: decreased acuity, abnormal appearing macula)
      • Retinal infection - often HIV or otherwise immuncomp - CMV, toxoplasmosis, endocarditis (PE: retinal exudates/cotton wool spots)
      • Diabetic &/or hypertensive retinopathy can cause acute sx when hemmorhage superimposed
      • Optic neuritis (Sx: acute, painful or painless, known MS, waxing and waning symptoms of sensory or motor loss, non-specific dizziness; PE: abnormal appearing optic nerve, sometime afferent pupil defect→ constricts when light shined in unaffected eye, but not to direct light)

      Brain

      • Stroke (Rfs: htn, dm, hyperlipidemia, known vascular dz, smoking, early fam hx, a fib; Sx: acute, loss of specific visual field→ based on area of occipital lobe affected; PE: visual field cut, other focal deficits)
      • Brain tumor (Sx: typically slow loss, w/specific visual field→ based on area of optic tract affected; bi-temporal if pituitary tumor→ optic chiasm pressure; rapid if bleeding/infarct superimposed; PE: visual field cut, other focal deficits)

      Acute - Painful

      Ext Struct/Globe

      • Orbital cellulitis (Rf: infected sinuses→ ethmoid; Sx: acute pain, worse w/eye movement, loss of vision; PE: diffuse redness, proptosis

      Cornea

      • Keratitis (Etiology: can be bacterial, viral→ hsv, vzv, fungal or parasitic→ onchocerciasis; also from trauma/fb, chemical exposure, or contact lens use; Sx: acute, painful, unilateral visual loss; PE: diffusely red, other findings of herpes zoster in v1 dermatome if that's the cause)
      • Corneal abrasion or ulcer (Sx: acute, painful, n, often related to local trauma/foreign body/corneal infection; visual loss, unilateral)

      Iris & Ant Chamb

      • Iritis/anterior uveitis (Etiology: assoc w/autoimmune dz→ ankylosing spond, sarcoid, reactive arthritis, behcet's dz, IBD; infxn→ HSV, secondary syphillis, VZV, TB; often idiopathic; Sx: acute pain, photophobia, impaired vision; PE: decreased acuity, irreg appearance of pupil, circumferential redness at cornea-sclera junction, sometimes layered pus in anterior chamber→ hypopyon; other systemic manifestations of the primary disease; can have pan-uveitis)
      • Acute angle closure glaucoma (Sx: acute, pain, n, v, ha, unilateral, visual loss; PE: globe feels hard, corneal clouding, mid-dilated & unreactive pupil)

      Vitreous, retina & optic nerve

      • Endopthalmitis (Rfs/Etiology: infection inside the eye, can be complication of trauma, cataract surgery, or seeding from systemic bacteremia; Sx: acute, pain w/any movement, f, loss of vision; PE: diffuse redness, layered pus in anterior chamber→ hypopyon)
      • Optic neuritis (Sx: acute, sometimes painful, known MS, waxing and waning symptoms of sensory or motor loss, non-specific dizziness; PE: abnormal appearing optic nerve, sometime afferent pupil defect→ constricts when light shined in unaffected eye, but not to direct light)
      • Posterior uveitis (Etiology: assoc w/autoimmune dz→ sarcoid, behcet's dz; malignancy→ lymphoma; infxn→ toxo, CMV, brucellosis, HSV, VZV, secondary syphillis, TB; often idiopathic; Sx: decreased vision, pain, photophobia; PE: decreased acuity, may not have external inflammatory findings unless pan-uveitis; other findings assoc w/underlying dz)

      Slow and Painless

      Cornea

      • Corneal scar (Etiology: s/p prior corneal injury; Sx: visual impairment in affected eye(s); may have hx antecedent injury/infection; PE: area of corneal opacification)
      • Degenerative corneal diseases (Etiology: rare disorders that are heritable or acquired; Sx: slowly progressive, bilateral vision impairment, can start soon after birth to teens/twenties)
      • Keratoconus (Etiology: uncommon, heritable or acquired, cornea becomes progressively abnly shaped→ affects ability to focus image; RFs: sometimes family hx; Sx: onset in 20s w/progression thru 60s, typically bilateral, blurriness, requiring frequent changes in eyeglass prescription)

      Iris & Ant Chamb

      • Glaucoma (open angle) (Rfs: age > 60, more common in AA; Sx: uni or bilateral, painless, slowly progressive visual probs; trouble seeing at night, problems w/peripheral vision, halos when look at lights)
      • Melanoma of iris (Sx: progressive interference w/vision, unilateral; PE: obvious dark tumor involving iris)

      Lens

      • Refractive errors: near or far sighted (Sx: bilateral, slowly progressive; PE: corrects w/pinhole testing)
      • Cataract (Rfs: rel common as age over 50; Sx: uni or bilateral, painless, no d/c, slow decline in vision; near vision worse than far, glare; PE: lose red reflex on exam)

      Retina & optic nerve

      • Macular degeneration (Sx: initially vague, decreased central vision in particular, uni or bilateral; PE: exudates, other abnl in macula)
      • Retinopathy from Diabetes (Rfs: long hx poorly controlled dm, often co-mingles w/diabetes; Sx: progressive visual loss, uni or bilateral, target organ damage elsewhere; PE: exudate, hemmorrhage, neovascularization)
      • Retinopathy from Hypertension (Rfs: long hx poorly controled htn, often co-mingles w/diabetes; Sx: progressive visual loss, uni or bilateral, target organ damage elsewhere; PE: flame hemmorrhages, exudates, a-v nicking, copper/silver wiring of arterioles)
      • Retinal melanoma (Sx: slowly progressive, blurriness)
      • Other retinal d/o (relatively uncommon)- retinitis pigmentosa, other
      • Meds (Rfs/Etiology: hx of taking a med that can cause visual loss→e.g. ethambutal; temporal connection between starting med and onset visual loss; lack of other explanation)
      • Toxoplasmosis (protozoa) (Etiology: carried in cat feces, healthy hosts not affected, in HIV + causes brain infection cd4 < 200; pregnant women can pass in utero→ congenital abnormalities; Sx: acute f, c, headache, delirium, szr, eye pain and visual loss from retinal involvement)
      • Chorioretinitis/posterior uveitis (Etiology: inflammation of choroid due to infxn or autoimmune process; Sx: subacute, painless, visual loss, floaters)

      Brain

      • Tumor (Sx: typically slow loss, w/specific visual field→ based on area of optic tract affected; bi-temporal if pituitary tumor→ optic chiasm pressure; rapid if bleeding/infarct superimposed; PE: field cut, other focal cns findings)

      Double vision?

      Assessment of extra-occular movements
      • Monocular (Sx: present with even one eye closed → refractive error, cataract or other local eye problem)
      • Binocular (Sx: resolves when one eye closed; present when look in direction of impaired movement, resolves when look in directions preserved movement; PE: exam to assess for level of dysfunction of CNs and/or extra-occular muscles that move eye→ loss of coordinated bilateral movement)
        • Stroke (affecting CNs 3, 4, or 6) (Rf: htn, dm, hyperlipidemia, a fib, fam hx, known vascular dz; Sx: acute, other neuro sx, unilateral)
        • Tumor (affecting CNs 3, 4, or 6) (Rf: known central nervous system tumor, PE: loss of other neuro fxn, impaired movement, as with this CN 6 palsey where eye cant look laterally; w/CN 3 involvement→ eye deviated down and out, pupil dilated, ptosis)
        • Infection or anything that increases ICP (Sx: HA, f, delirium, other neuro dxyfxn; CN 6 in particular at risk)
        • Aneurysm posterior communicating artery (as aneurysm grows→ compresses CN3→ also headache & sx sah; dilated pupil, ptosis, outward directed eye)
        • Myasthenia gravis (Etiol: autoimmune w/ab targeting ACh receptor; Rfs: 20-30 y female predom, 50-70y male; Sx: painless, subacute, progressive; worse w/repetitive movement, end of day; ocular sx→ double vision, eyelid weakness; other cranial nerve palsies; can also cause systemic weakness affecting neck, extremities, other muscles→ asymmetric and prox > distal fashion; PE: no atrophy, reflexes preserved, no sensory findings, ptosis, eye muscle weakness, weakness in other muscles→ worse w/use)
        • Muscle entrapment (Etiology: hx trauma; Sx: double vision when look in direction of impaired movement; PE: other signs of truam, impaired movement in a specific direction; e.g. w/orbital floor fx, trapped inferior rectus→ cant look down w/L eye)
        • Graves ophthalmopathy→ typically assoc w/hyperthyroidism (Etiology: impaired movement of eye due to hypertrophy of orbital tissues; Sx: proptosis, dry eyes, often other sx of increased thyroid: tachydardia, tremor, diarrhea, heat intolerance, etc; PE: bulging eyes, lids appear retracted, redness from conreal exposure, impaired movements)
        • Cavernous sinus thrombosis (Etiology: uncommon, assoc w/infection of teeth/sinuses that spreads, can affect CN 3, 4 or 6→ all travel thru sinus; Sx: acute, headache, double vision, szr; PE: proptosis, red eye, impaired extra-occular movement)
        • Guillain-Barre (Miller-Fisher variant) (Sx: ophthalmoplegia and ataxia, uncommon, accompanies other GBS sx, including: acute, bilateral numbness/tingling in legs, ascending pattern of weakness)
        • Wernicke's encephalopathy (Etiology: thiamine (B1) deficiency; Rfs: alcoholic, others w/severe nutritional deficiency; Sx: delirium, severe balance problems, occulomotor dysfxn leading to double vision or other occular disturbances; most patients wont have all 3 symptoms; resolve w/thiamine, occulmotor most quickly; untreated→ Korsakoff's dementia→ inability to form new memories; PE: profound confusion, crannial nerve palsey, severe ataxia→ often unable to stand, occulomotor dysfxn including cranial nerve palsey, vertical or horizontal nystagmus)

      Eye discharge?

      Observation of external structures
      • Viral connunctivitis (Etiology: adeno, other; Sx: acute, redness of conjunctiva, URI sx, watery discharge, no visual change, uni- or bilateral, gritty sensation; PE: diffuse redness, often clear d/c)
        • Adeno (Etiology/Site: cause of upper respiratory infxn→ common cold, conjunctivitis, otitis media; Sx: cough, nasal congestion, sore throat, ear pain, conjunctival inflamation; much less commonly pneumonia; PE: throat redness, conjunctivitis, anterior auricular adenopathy) more from CDC
        • Enterovirus (non-polio) (Etiology: passed fecal-oral, close contact, ingesting infected water; Site: brain→ meningitis & encephalitis, oral mucosa and skin→ hand/foot/mouth dz, heart→ myocarditis and pericarditis; conjunctiva→ conjunctivitits; upper resp tract; Sx: most have mild illness; w/more severe dz→ fever, ha, cough, runny nose, muscle aches, confusion) more from CDC
        • Measels (rubeola) (Etiology: spread thru resp droplets, highly contagious; Rfs: too young to be vaccinated (<1y), or never vaccinated; winter/spring in US; Sx: incubation 7-14d; cough, high f, malaise; rash 4-5d after sx onset; PE: conjunctivitis, runny nose, then white (Koplick's) spots on oral mucosa, then rash; complications include encephalitis, pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Bacterial conjunctivitis (Etiology: staph, h flu, strep, moraxella, neiserria; Sx: acute, red, opaque d/c, itchy/irritated, no visual change, uni- or bilateral; copious d/c if neisseria in partic; PE: diffuse redness of conjunctiva, pus)
        • Chlamydia trachomatis (trachoma) (Etiology: spread thru poor hand hygiene, sharing towels, or via flies, endemic in poor/developing countries, a leading cause blindness world-wide; Sx: chronic, purulent conjunctivitis, can lead to scarring of lid→ inward turned lashes→ scarring of cornea→ blindness) more from CDC
      • Allergic Conjunctivitis (Sx: itchy, watery d/c, chronic, no visual change, typically bilateral)
      • More on conjunctivitis from CDC

      Red Eye?

      Observation of external structures

      Painless

      • Conjunctivitis
        • Viral (Etiology: adeno, other; Sx: acute, redness of conjunctiva, URI sx, watery discharge, no visual change, uni- or bilateral, gritty sensation; PE: diffuse redness, often clear d/c)
        • Bacterial (Etiology: staph, h flu, strep; Sx: acute, red, opaque d/c, itchy/irritated, no visual change, uni- or bilateral; PE: diffuse redness of conjunctiva, pus)
        • Allergic (Sx: itchy, watery d/c, chronic, no visual change)
        • More on conjunctivitis from CDC
      • Blepharitis (Sx/Pe: redness along eye-lid margins, itchy, no visual loss)
      • Sub-conjunctival hemorrhage (Sx: no d/c, no pain, no visual sx, unilateral; PE: hemorrhage outside the iris)
      • Episcleritis (Etiology: often idiopathic/self limited; Sx: min or no pain, unilateral, no d/c, photophobia, or visual complaints; PE: acute redness of a focal region of sclera)
      • Ectropion (Etiology: inside of lower lid chronically exposed; Sx: dryness, no pain or visual loss, (PE: chronically exposed conjunctiva, redness, lower lid droops away from eye)
      • Dry eyes (Sx: chronic, mild redness, bilateral, itchy)
      • Sjogrens/SICCA (Rfs: women>>men; age typically >50, dry eyes and mouth; can affect multiple systems, including painful periph neuropathy; other systemic sx include arthralgias, arthritis, cutaneous vasculitis, other)

      Painful

      Pain is a red flag for serious underlying problems

      Ext Struct/Globe

      • Conjunctivitis
        • Bacterial (Sx: some hyperacute bacterial infections are painful and cause visual loss e.g. gc)
        • Viral→ Herpes (Sx: pain prior to erruption, vessicles, visual loss, unilateral)
      • Dacrocystitis (Rfs: much more common in children; Sx/PE: acute pain and redness over medial lower lid where tears drain, acute, no visual loss, unilateral)
      • Orbital cellulitis→ involves fat and muscles of orbital cavity (Sx: acute pain, f, worse w/eye movement, loss of vision; PE: redness and swelling of conjunctiva)
      • Scleritis (Etiology/Rfs: often assoc with auto-immune d/o→ e.g. RA/vasculitis; Sx: accompanied by severe/boring pain, no d/c, photophobia or visual loss; PE: acute redness of sclera, unilateral, usually focal)
      • Episcleritis (Etiology: often idiopathic/self limited; Sx: min or no pain, unilateral, no d/c, photophobia, or visual complaints; PE: acute redness of a focal region of sclera)
      • Entropion (Etiology: in-turned eyelashes; Sx: typically chronic irritation, blurring, redness; PE: lashes oriented so rubbing against eye)
      • Trauma, foreign body, chemical exposure: history should be suggestive

      Cornea

      • Keratitis (Rfs/Etiology: can be bacterial, viral→ hsv, vzv or fungal; also from trauma/fb, chemical exposure, or contact lens use; Sx: acute, painful, unilateral visual loss; PE: diffusely red, other findings of herpes zoster in v1 dermatome if that's the cause)
      • Corneal abrasion (Rfs/Etiology: related to local trauma/foreign body/contact lens use; Sx: acute, unilateral, painful, n, visual loss, unilateral)
      • Chlamydia trachomatis (trachoma) (Etiology: spread thru poor hand hygiene, sharing towels, or via flies, endemic in poor/developing countries, a leading cause blindness world-wide; Sx: chronic, purulent conjunctivitis, can lead to scarring of lid→ inward turned lashes→ scarring of cornea→ blindness) more from CDC
      • Sjogrens/SICCA (Rfs: women>>men; age typically >50, dry eyes and mouth; can affect multiple systems, including painful periph neuropathy; other systemic sx include arthralgias, arthritis, cutaneous vasculitis, other)

      Iris & Ant Chamb

      • Acute angle closure glaucoma (Sx: acute, pain, n, v, ha, unilateral, visual loss; PE: globe feels hard, corneal clouding, mid-dilated & unreactive pupil)
      • Iritis/anterior uveitis (Etiology: assoc w/autoimmune dz→ ankylosing spond, sarcoid, reactive arthritis, behcet's dz, IBD; infxn→ HSV, secondary syphillis, VZV, TB; often idiopathic; Sx: acute pain, photophobia, impaired vision; PE: decreased acuity, irreg appearance of pupil, circumferential redness at cornea-sclera junction, sometimes layered pus in anterior chamber→ hypopyon; other systemic manifestations of the primary disease; can have pan-uveitis)

      Vitreous & Int Struct

      • Endopthalmitis (Rfs/Etiology: infection inside the eye, can be complication of trauma, cataract surgery, or seeding from systemic bacteremia; Sx: acute, pain w/any movement, f, loss of vision; PE: diffuse redness, pus in anterior chamber)

      Discolored Sclera/Ext Abnl?

      Observation of external structures
      • Icterus (Sx: painless, bilateral, no visual symptoms; PE: yellowing of conjunctiva)
        • Hyperbilirubinemia from liver dz
        • hemolysis
      • Muddy brown sclera(Rfs: more common in blacks; Sx: painless, asx/no clinical sig, chronic, PE: brown patches on sclera)
      • Lid: hordeolum (stye) (Etiology: inflamation of eyelash follicles; Sx: acute over days, painful, swelling at lid margin, preserved vision; PE: focal, purulent, indurated area at lid margin; sometimes conunctival redness)
      • Lid: chalazion (Etiology: inflammation of meibomian gland; occurs deeper in lid c/w stye; Sx: acute over days, painful, red swelling in eyelid, preserved vision; PE: red, warm, focal bump on lid; sometimes conunctival redness; can evolved to rubbery non-inflammed nodule)
      • Pre-septal cellulitis (Sx: acute, red, painful skin, though eye itself w/o pain, preserved vision, full mobility; PE: red, edematous skin around eye)
      • Orbital cellulitis (Sx: acute, decreased vision, pain w/eye movement, head ache; PE: peri-orbital redness)
      • Pterygium (Rf/Etiology: age, sun exposure e.g. living in southwest US; Sx: slowly progressive, uni or bilateral, no sx unless crosses pupil→ interferes w/vision; PE: heaped up growth on conjunctiva)
      • Pinguecula (Sx: typically asx, raised conjunctival lesion, adjaccent to iris, doesnt cross the cornea, sometimes becomes inflamed; PE: raised, yellowish, globular)
      • Unilateral miosis and ptosis (Horner's synd) (Etiology: any process that interfers w/sympathetic chain: apical lung tumor, carotid dissection, idiopathic, other; Sx: unilateral sub-acute, drooping eye lid and small pupil noted; no visual probs, any sx related to primary problem; PE: lid covers more iris on affected side, pupil smaller, pupil reacts nly to light)

      More Info About Eye Disorders:
      NIH National Eye Institute, Comprehensive eye exam

      Back

      Head and Neck Disorders

      Comprehensive head and neck exam

      Chronic or past head and neck disorders?

      Hearing problems, head/neck malignancies; smoking, chewing tobacco or etoh (risk factors for malignancy); past head and neck surgeries, etc

      Sore Throat?

      Exam of the oral cavity

      Infection

      • Acute Pharyngitis
        • Bacterial
          • Grp A, Beta Hemolytic Strep (Sx: acute, fever, pain, absence of cough; PE: exudate & reddness, palpable LN, palatal petechiae) more from CDC
          • Other bacteria (Etiology: Strep Grp B and G)
          • Neisseria gonorrhea (Site: urethra, cervix, uterus, fallopian tubes, testes, pharynx, ano-rectal, joints; Sx: pharyngeal infection often asx, but can cause sore throat; Rfs: oral sexual activity; PE: penile d/c, cervical d/c, cervical pain and uterine pain if PID; pharyngeal inflammation & exudates; anorectal d/c; if disseminated→ pustules, infectious arthritis) more from CDC
          • Diptheria (Site: upper respiratory tract; Sx: cough, f, sore throat, uncommon now w/vax; PE: pseudo-membrane w/airway obstruction) more from CDC
        • Viral
          • EBV→ mono (Sx: acutely painful sore throat, fever→ sometimes prolonged, fatigue, doesn't respond to abx; PE: pharyngeal redness, exudate, and adenopathy; sometimes splenomegaly) more from CDC
          • Other viral (e.g. influenza) (Sx: abrupt onset, high fever, cough, myalgias; other viruses: rhino, adeno, others; PE: red posterior pharynx) More on upper respiratory infections CDC
      • Peri-tonsilar abscess (Sx: acute pain, worse then simple pharyngitis, localizes to one side, problems/pain swallowing, if severe→ airway compreomise; PE: focal swelling in tonsilar area, uvula deviated away)
      • Retro-pharyngeal abscess (Etiology: spread of infxn from adjacent space; Sx: f, c, acute, difficulty swallowing or handling secretions, difficulty speaking, sob; PE: sitting up, drooling, swelling in post pharynx, neck swelling, stridor)
      • Acute HIV (primary infxn) (Rfs: men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/somone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; Sx/PE: throat pain and redness w/o exudate, fevers, chills, non-specific rash, adenopathy)
      • Candida (Rfs: immuno-supressed→ chemo or hiv, abx exposure, steroids; PE: white exudate on mucosa, bleeds when scraped)
      • HSV (Sx: pain can precede appearance, worse if immunocmop, can be recurrent; PE: clear vessicles on red base, small ulcer after uncovered)
      • Epiglotitis (Sx: acute, f, can't swallow, sob, pain in anterior neck; PE: ill appearing, sitting upright, drooling, "hot potato" voice)
      • Lemierre's synd (septic thrombophlebitis of jugular vein) (Etiology: fusobacterium; Sx: starts as sore throat, may improve over few days, then worsens; pain also lateral neck, f, c, sweats, sob/cp if septic pulm emboli, severe illness; PE: febrile, pharyngeal inflamation, warmth and pain over lateral neck)
      • More on sore throats from CDC

      Inflam/Autoimmune

      • Apthous ulcer (Sx: acute, painful, self limited; Etiology: can be assoc w/viral infxn, meds, cancer, hiv, or idiopathic; PE: ulcer(s) with surrounding erythema)
      • Adult Still's Disease (Etiology: febrile illness of unknown etiology; Sx: f and other sx are persistent, sub-acute; evaluation of f does not reveal other etiology; also arhtritis & arthralgias of larger joints; salmon colored, maculo-pap non-puritic skin erruption; myalgias, adenopathy, sore throat, pericarditis and pleuritis; PE: erruption is light salmon colored mac/pap, pharyngitis, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy)
      • Other

      Other

      • Post-nasal drip (Sx: sensation of fluid dripping down throat, often worse lying down, anterior nasal drip as well, chronic cough)
      • Cancer (Rf: chewing or smoking tobacco, ETOH abuse, receptive oral sex→ HPV; Sx: progressive, non-healing or growing ulcer or mass; PE: ulcer, surrounding induration, growing mass, adenopathy)

      Oral ulcers or masses?

      Exam of the oral cavity

      Malignancy

      • Squamous cell (RFs: smoking, drinking, chewing tobacco; PE: slow growing, non-healing ulcer or mass of oral mucosa, edges indurated, lymph nodes firm, stuck to each other & underlying tissue, growing)

      Infection

      • Dental infection (Sx: acute pain, localized to affected tooth or adjacent tissue if spreading; PE: gingival swelling; pain reproduced when tooth is tapped)
      • Herpes Simplex Virus (Sx: acute, painful, vessicles; pain often present before lesions appear, regress spontaneously 1-3w)
      • Candida (thrush-related) (Rfs: immuno-supressed, abx exposure, steroids; PE: white discharge, bleeds when scraped)
      • Syphilis (Rfs: men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/somone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's; PE: other findings assoc w/secondary syphillis including: non-specific rash, w/predilection for palms, and soles; hx painless genital ulcer from primary infxn)
      • HIV related (Rfs: men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/somone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, hx needle stick injury from infected person; PE: painful ulcer(s) w/surrounding erythema)
      • Histoplasmosis (Sites; lungs, liver, spleen, mouth, systemic; Rfs: exposure to Mississippi & Ohio river valley, HIV+; Sx: can be asx/mild and resolve spont; often see x-ray evidence prior infection lung, spleen w/o known past infxn; cough, fever; can cause resp/systemic illness, oral ulcers in HIV+)
      • Ludwig's Angina (submandibular space infection) (Etiology: typically starts as dental infection, spreads to submandibular space; Sx: acute, neck/submandibular area pain and swelling in submandibular area, f, difficulty swallowing, drooling, airway compromise; PE: f, ill appearing, sitting up, foul breath, diffiuclty opening mouth, acute & painful submandibular swelling, indurated and red skin, sometimes co-existent dental infection)

      Inflam/Autoimmune

      • IBD related (Sx: sub-acute/chronic abd pain, wt loss, diarrhea, bloody stools)
      • Behcet's Dz (Etiology: rare autoimmune d/o; RFs: typically presents 20-30yo; Middle Eastern, Mediterranean or East Asian background; Sx: waxing/waning over weeks/months, painful ulcers in genital region and mouth; pain w/swallowing; fever; e nodosusm or other nodular skin lesions; pathergy→ papule/pustule in response to minor trauma; arthralgias; inflammatory arthritis in one/few med joints; eye sx from iritis; adenopathy; can have neuro involvement; can have arterial/venous thrombosis; PE: apthous ulcer(s) with surrounding erythema in mouth, pustule or ulcers in genital area; irreg appearance of pupil, circumferential redness at cornea-sclera junction, sometimes layered pus in anterior chamber→ hypopyon; inflammatory arthritis; adenopathy)
      • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
      • Pemphigus vulgaris (Etiology: idiopathic; Sx: oral blisters that unroof→ becoming ulcers; persistent over weeks/months; PE: can be accompanied by cutaneous blisters)
      • Apthous ulcer (Sx: acute, painful, self limited→ regress in 1-2w, can recur; Etiology: can be assoc w/viral ifxn, meds, cancer, hiv, or idiopathic; PE: ulcer(s) with surrounding erythema)

      Meds, Other

      • Medication related→ e.g. sulfa drugs, dilantin, chemotherapy
      • Other: Maxillary Torus→ hard palate(Sx: slow growing, can interfere w/dentures and chewing; PE: boney mass, on hard palate, non-tender, covered w/nl mucosa)

      External Mass/Adenopathy?

      Exam of the lymph nodes and thyroid

      LNs & Infxns

      • Malignancy
        • Squamous cell (RFs: smoking, drinking, chewing tobacco; PE: slow growing, non-healing ulcer or mass of oral mucosa, edges indurated, lymph nodes firm, stuck to each other & underlying tissue, growing)
        • Lymphoma (Sx: sweats, fever, wt loss; PE: diffuse LN enlargement, nodes non-tender, rubbery)
      • Infection
        • Bacterial
          • Staph (Sites: direct skin infection; Sx: fever, pain/swelling at primary as well as affected lymph nodes; PE: redness, warmth, induration, fluctuance)
          • Streptococcus: Group A (Sites: associated w/pharyngitis or direct infection of LN; PE: strep throat→ pharyngeal erythema, d/c, adenop, LNs warm, tender, enlarged) more from CDC
          • Primary dental or other oral infection (Etiology: adenopathy reflects local spread from primary site in mouth/teeth; PE: focus of infection identified in mouth; gingival swelling; pain reproduced when tooth is tapped, lymph nodes warm, tender, swollen)
          • Bartonella henslae (cat scratch) (Sites: skin and lymph nodes; Rfs/Etiology: caused by cat scratch; Sx: may see inflamation at innoculation site, then tender regional adenopathy w/in few weeks, fatigue, fever) more from CDC
          • Brucella (Sites: systemic; Etiology: ingestion of raw/uncooked dairy or handling infected animals; Rfs: veterinarians, meat packers, slaughter house workers, farmers; Middle East, Mediterranean, Mexico, Africa; Sx/PE: causes weeks/months of recurrent f, c, sweats, arthritis, adenopathy, orchitis, hepato-splenomegaly) more from CDC
          • Francisella tularensis (tularemia) (Sites: skin, lymph nodes; Etiology/Rfs: passed from dying wild animals to humans via ticks/insects, US Southeast and Rocky Mtns; Sx: f, c, ha, oral or skin ulcers, painful adenopathy, sob, muscle aches) more from CDC
          • Actinomyces (Sites: oral/neck/face, other organ systems Sx: slow growing abscess, often w/sinus tract development)
        • Viral and retroviral
