          • HIV (Etiology/Rfs: hiv risk factors→ men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; risks of unusual infection increase as CD4 declines; Sx: acute infection→ fever, chills, sweats, adenopathy, rash, pharyngitis w/in 2-4 weeks - then resolves; latency until sx develop 6-10y after initial infxn (if not treated) related to drop in CD4: generalized sx include f, c, cough, wt loss; other illnesses: mucosal candidiasis; fungal, mtb lung infection; persistent diarrhea; CNS toxo; non hodgkins lymphoma; kaposis sarcoma of skin, adenopathy, etc) more from CDC
          • CMV (Sx/PE: retinitis/colitis/disseminated dz in patients w/HIV; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w, then f, c, malaise hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, fatigue x 4-6w; head/neck adenopathy & pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC
          • EBV (mononucleosis) (Rfs: spread by direct contact→ kissing, shared drinking glasses, shared toothbrushes, etc; Sx: incubation 4-6w, prodrome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias, then f, sore thorat; PE: maculo-pap rash after amox or other abx, head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly) more from CDC
          • Herpes simplex oral infxn (Etiology: primary infxn sometimes assoc w/fever; Sites: oral; Rfs: passed by sexual or oral contact; Sx/PE: acute, painful, genital or oral area vesicles, inguinal adenopathy) more from CDC
          • Other viral resp infxn
        • Mycobacterial
          • M tuberculosis (MTB) (RFs: HIV +, steroids, chronic kidney, liver or lung dz; ivdu, from enedemic area, healthcare worker, otherwise immunocomp; extra-pulm TB increases in HIV+ w/CD4 < 350; Sx: sub-acute, cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, sweats, fatigue; can also infect GI/GU tracts; adenopathy most commonly head/neck→ scrofula) more from CDC
        • Fungal
          • Tinea capitis (Sx/PE: scaly, inflamed, raised, well defined patch(es) on scalp, associated w/focal hair loss, adenopathy occipital region of scalp)
        • Spirochete
          • Syphillis (Rfs: sexual exposure, Etiology/Sx/PE: primary, secondary and tertiary manifestations; primary infection causes painless genital ulcer, ~3w after exposure → heals 4-6w, regional adenopathy; secondary manifestations weeks to mos later w/non-specific rash, predilection for palms, and soles; condyloma around genital areas, mucous involvement, generalized adenopathy, f, sweats, eyes→ iritis/uveitis; tertiary manifestations yrs later affecting CNS→ numbness, weakness, balance problems, dementia; large blood vessels→ aortitis, aneurysm) More from CDC

      Skin cancer

      • Basal cell cancer (Rfs: chronic sun exposure, fair skin, prior bcc, immuncompromised; Sx: Non-healing, ulcerated, bleeding on a sun exposed region PE: telangiectasias, pearly w/rolled edges, growing, non-healing, central depression)
      • Squamous cell cancer (Rfs: chronic sun exposure, fair skin, prior scc, immuncompromised; Sx: Non-healing, ulcerated, bleeding on a sun exposed region PE: non-healing, growing, crusted, firm, sun exposed areas)
      • Melanoma (Rfs: fair skin, fair hair, prior melanoma, dysplastic moles, family hx, hx blistering sun burns, immunocompromised; PE: asymmetric, bleeds, irregular borders, non-homogeneous pigment, grows, doesn't heal)

      Benign growths

      • Lipoma (Sx: very slow growing, non-tender, often subtle, mass below the skin; PE: homogeneous, squishy feel on palpation, non-tender, no skin changes)
      • Epidermal cyst (slow growing, feel fluid filled on palpation, non-tender unless infected; PE: non-tender, small fluid filled cyst, when infected can increase rapidly in size, red tender)

      Thyroid/Parotid/Salivary

      • Thyroid (Etiology: goiter, cancer, thyroiditis; Sx: typically non-tender; if thyroiditis can be tender; can cause sob/doe if large and pushing on trachea→ rare; PE: mid-line enlargement)
      • Parotid (Sx: acute pain if infected or related to duct obstruction; cancer slowly progressive, can involve CN7→ peripheral palsy; PE: acute, tender, mass just anterior to the ears if infected; slowly progressive, firm, non-tender mass if malignant)
      • Submandibular salivary glands (Sx: typically non-teder and soft; acute pain and enlargement if obstructing stone; firm and slow enlargement if cancer (rare)

      Congenital abnormalities

      Uncommon conditions
      • Thyroglossal duct cyst (Etiology: remnant from thyroid migration from tongue to neck; Sx/PE: long standing, sometimes increase in size, midline, non-tender unless infected; move w/swallowing & sticking out tongue; anywhere from base of tongue to thyroid area)
      • Branchial cleft (Sx/PE: noted in childhood, non-tender mass, along front edege sternocleidomastoid or below clavicle; painful if become infected, can interfere w/breathing or swallowing if very large; sometimes drains mucous)

      Decreased hearing?

      Exam of the ears

      Conductive: outside→ CN 8

      • External canal obstruction:
        • Wax (Sx: slow, uni- or bilateral, painless; PE: wax visible in canal)
        • Bony growth (Sx: slow, uni- or bilateral, painless, hx extensive ocean swimming or surfing; PE: bony growth that narrows external canal)
        • Otitis externa (Sx: acute, painful; PE: d/c from external canal, swelling of affected area, pain on palpation of tragus)
      • Middle ear:
        • Tympanic membrane perforation (Etiology: infection, trauma; Sx: acute pain, discharge, decrease in hearing on affected side, can taste liquid dripping down throat if use topical ear drops, can hear air moving thru perf if pinch nose & valsalva; PE: perforation of TM)
        • Middle ear infection→ otitis media (Etiology: bacterial or viral; Sx: acute ear pain, muffled hearing, other uri sx→ cough, nasal congestion, fever; PE: evidence effusion behind ear drum; favoring bacterial→ drum red, opaque, bulging)
        • Cholesteatoma (Etiology: chronic build up of desquamated debris in middle ear; can occur secondary to trauma, infection, eustachian tube dysfxn; Sx: chronic hearing loss on affected side; PE: retracted drum, sometimes abnl visible behind TM)
        • Chronic middle ear effusion from eustachian tube dysxn (Sx/Etiology: inability of eustachian tube to equalize pressure→ chronic inflammation from allergies, rarely obstructing pharyngeal tumors; PE: evidence effusion behind ear drum)
        • Otosclerosis (Etiology: bony overgrowth affecting bones of middle ear; Sx: slow hearing loss, unti or bilateral)

      Sensori-Neural: CN8→ brain

      • Age related (presbycusis) (Rfs: age > 65; Sx: loss develops slowly, problems hearing conversations in partic if competing background noises, bilateral)
      • Chronic exposure to loud sounds(Rfs: hx recurrent exposure loud sounds thru work/habits/hobbies, lack of use ear protection; Sx: bilateral, chronic/progressive)
      • Acoustic neuritis (Sx: abrupt onset hearing loss, unilateral)
      • Ototoxic meds→ aminoglycosides, cisplatin
      • Menierres (Sx: sub-acute/chronic hearing loss accompanied by dizziness, tinnitus, waxes and wanes)
      • Trauma
      • Acoustic Neuroma (Sx: sub-acute and progressive, unilateral, sometimes assoc w/dizziness, tinnitus)
      • Multiple Sclerosis (Rfs: white>black, women>men, age onset <30; Sx: associated w/other patchy CNS sx: numbness, visual changes, balance problems, may wax and wane)
      • Stroke (RFs: Htn, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, smoking, known vascular dz; Sx: abrupt onset, unilateral, other assoc sx from local ischemia→ diplopia, facial weakness, dizziness, balance problems)

      Mixed sensori-neural/conductive

      • Combinations of the above

      Ear pain or discharge?

      Exam of the ears
      • Middle ear infection→ otitis media (Etiology: bacterial or viral; Sx: acute ear pain, muffled hearing, other uri sx→ cough, nasal congestion, fever; PE: evidence effusion behind ear drum; favoring bacterial→ drum red, opaque, bulging)
      • Tympanic membrane perforation (Etiology: infection, trauma; Sx: acute pain, discharge, decrease in hearing on affected side, can taste liquid dripping down throat if use topical ear drops, can hear air moving thru perf if pinch nose & valsalva; PE: perforation of TM)
      • Otitis externa (Sx: acute, painful, d/c; PE: d/c from external canal, swelling of affected area, pain on palpation of tragus)
      • Otitis externa maligna (Etiology: pseudomonal infxn assoc w/poorly controled diabetes; Sx: acute, painful, necrotizing infection of ear, cartilege; can spread to adbjacent bone, mastoids; brain; PE: febrile, ill, diffuse pain, edema, erythema of ear and sometimes adjacent tissues)
      • Ear cellulitis (Rfs: can start from otitis externa or trauma/injury to ear; Sx: acute swelling, pain of ear/surrounding skin, redness/edema of skin)
      • Mastoiditis (Rfs: a site of spread from complicated otitis media; Sx: acute pain, swelling of mastoid→ posterior and inferior to ear; PE: pain on palpation of mastoid, red, warm, induration)
      • Local skin cancer (Rfs: sun exposure Sx: slow growing, non-healing; PE: raised, sometimes ulcerated)
      • Polychondritis(Etiology: uncommmon auto-immune d/o affecting cartilage; Sx: subacute inflammation of cartilage; can also affect nose → stuffiness, epistaxis, d/c; trachea → stridor/sob, cough, wheezing; eyes, joints, kidneys, other)
      • Referred pain (Etiology: source of pain may be outside of ear, including: cervical spine, TMJ, cancer of the oropharynx, other)
      More on ear infxns from CDC

      Nasal d/c, congest, post nasal drip?

      Exam of the nose

      Infection - rhinosinusitis

      • Viral (Sx: acute, cough, colored d/c, self limited; PE: pain upon precussion of sinuses, post nasal drip evident on pharynx)
      • Bacterial (Sx: acute, cough, persistent, colored d/c, fever, tooth or facial pain; PE: pain upon precussion of sinuses, post nasal drip evident on pharynx, tooth pain if tapped, no transillumination)
      • Fungal (Etiology: mucor or aspergillous; overall uncommon; Sx: persistent facial pain, fever, congestion in compromised hosts→ older, diabetes; can lead to severe illness as these organisms are invasive)
      • More on sinus infxns from CDC

      Allergies

      • Allergic rhinitis (Sx: chronic, clear d/c, cough from post nasal drip; PE: clear nasal d/c, somtimes polyps)
      • Nasal polyps (Rfs: most commonly from allergies, cystic fibrosis much less common; Sx: chronic nasal obstruction, runny nose; PE: sometimes polyp visible on exam)

      Autoimmune/Inflam

      • Granulomatosis w/poyangiitis (Wegeners) (Etiology: idiopathic vasculitis Sx: recurrent/progressive nasal sx, cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as unusual→ rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; PE: mucosal erythema, ulcer, nasal septum perf)
      • Polychondritis (Sx: uncommon auto-immune d/o affecting cartilage; subacute inflammation of cartilage; can also affect nose→ stuffiness, epistaxis, d/c; trachea → stridor/sob, cough, wheezing; eyes, joints, kidneys, other)
      • Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss) (Etiology: idiopathic d/o, w/high levels circulating and tissue invasive eosinophils; Rfs: men=women, assoc also w/leukotriene antagonists; Sx: progressive, adult onset asthma, cough & wheezing, nasal stuffiness→ w/resp sx usually ~2-10 y prior to systemic sx assoc w/eosinophilic deposition in target organs and vasculitis; in these later phases→ systemic sx including: sob from parenchymal lung involvement; f, c, muscle aches; hematuria from renal involvement; heart failure, pericarditis and dysrhythmia w/cardiac involvement; peripheral neuropathy; PE: wheezing, skin findings of vasculitis: small, palapable purpura, dont blanch when compress them, can coalesce; hematuria/renal involvement; unexplained peripheral neuropathy)

      Meds/Toxins

        Meds/Toxins Rfs: chronic use topical vasocontrictors→ nasal congestion whenever stop using; cocaine→ nasal congestion, runny nose, PE: nasal bleeding, septal perforation

      Change in voice/hoarseness?

      • Vocal cord pathology
        • Cancer (Rfs: Smoking Sx: progressive, cough, hemoptysis, sob; PE: local adenopathy if spread)
        • Nodules/polyps (Sx: slow, worse w/talking, improves w/rest)
        • Infection (Sx: acute, pain w/talking, cough)
        • GERD (Rfs: assoc w/obesity, ETOH, smoking, caffine, chocolate, mint, increased BMI, age >50; Sx: chronic/recurrent burning type pain, often worse after meals, worse if lie down after eating, bad taste in mouth, radiates up from epigastrium, chronic cough)
      • Neurologic disorder
        • Weakness in phonation
          • Parkinson's dz (Rfs: age > 70; Sx: pill rolling tremor of hands, sometimes head bobbing tremor, difficulty starting and stopping movements, balance and gait problems, sometimes cognitive decline; PE: characteristic pill-rolling tremor, shuffling gait, masked facies, difficulty getting up and starting movement, difficulty turning)
        • Vocal cord paralysis from recurrent laryngeal nerve dysfunction (Sx: typically causes a breathy voice)
          • Cancer of: thyroid, larynx, mediastinum, other head/neck
          • Stroke
          • Other cause of cord paralysis
      • Overuse (Rfs: hx persistent speaking, loud voice, work related shouting, singing)

      Tooth pain or problems?

      • Dental infection (Sx: acute pain, localized to affected tooth; PE: gingival swelling; pain reproduced when tooth is tapped)
      • Cavity (Etiology: errosion thru enamel, typically on chewing surface, Sx: may be asx or can lead to tooh infection as above)
      • Broken teeth (Rfs: often assoc w/lack of access to dental care; Sx: acute or chronic; can lead to acute or chronic tooth infection w/local pain and swelling)
      • Gum disease (Etiology: chronic gum inflammation, usually related to poor brushing/hygiene, meds; Rfs: often assoc w/lack of access to dental care; Sx: can cause gum regression→ tooth exposure; leads to local infection, bleeding, tooth loss; PE: receding gums, exposed based of tooth or roots, bleeds easily)

      Sense of lump in throat?

      • GERD (Rfs: assoc w/obesity, ETOH, smoking, caffeine, chocolate, mint, increased BMI, age >50; Sx: chronic/recurrent burning type pain, often worse after meals, worse if lie down after eating, bad taste in mouth, radiates up from epigastrium, chronic cough)
      • Cancer (Rfs: hx smoking, etoh Sx: slowly progressive sx)
      • Psychogenic

      More Info About Head and Neck Disorders:
      NCI: Head and Neck Cancer, NIH: Hearing and Speech disorders, NIH Medline Plus: Ear, nose and throat disorders, Comprehensive head and neck exam

      Back

      Pulmonary

      Comprehensive pulmonary exam

      Chronic or past pulmonary disorders?

      • COPD, asthma, other

      Shortness of breath (SOB)?

      Pulmonary D/O

      Parench &/or Airways

      Pneumonia

      Common Sx: acute or sub-acute onset, cough, sob, doe, colored sputum production, fever, chest pain, cxr w/infiltrate; PE: rales, ronchi, wheezing or other findings on auscultation, dullness to percussion if pleural effusion or dense parenchymal involvement) Several scoring systems useful to gague severity: CURB 65 and PSI
    • Bacterial
      • Streptococcus Pneumoniae (pneumococcus) (Etiology: common cause of CAP; Sites: pneumonia, upper respiratory infections, meningitis; bacteremia if severe; Rfs: s/p splenectomy or fxnl asplenia, eldery and very young, any chronic medical condition→ copd, liver or renal dz, chf, cancer, diabetes, HIV, or otherwise immunocompromised; also csf leaks, cochlear implants; decreased risk if vaccinated; Sx: abrupt onset cough, sob, f, c, rusty-colored sputum prod) more from CDC
      • Haemophilus influenza (Etiology: common cause of CAP; Sites: upper and lower respiratory tract, cns; RFs: much less common since widespread use of vaccine; increased risk s/p splenectomy; Sites: pneumonia, otitis media, epiglottitis, meningitis) more from CDC
      • Mycoplasma pneumoniae (Etiology: common cause CAP; also upper resp tract infxn; Sx: acute f, c, cough, upper resp sx; not usually severe) more from CDC
      • Legionella (Etiology: common cause of CPA; Rfs: acquired via inhalation; grows in colonized water collection systems, cooling towers, nebs, whirlpools, etc; can be hospital acquired if water contaminated; Site: lung; Sx: acute cough, sputum, f, c, d, confusion) more from CDC
      • Moraxella (Etiology: common cause of CAP w/COPD; Sites: otitis media; bronchitis in copd exacerbation; lung; Sx: cough, sob, f, sputum)
      • Francisella tularensis (tularemia) (Etiology: uncommon cause CAP; Rfs: passed from dying wild animals to humans via ticks/insects, US Southeast and Rocky Mtns; Sites: skin, lymph nodes, lung; Sx: f, c, ha, oral or skin ulcers, painful adenopathy, sob, muscle aches) more from CDC
      • Yersinia pestis (plague) (Etiology: uncommon cause CAP; Site: respiratory tract; Rfs: passed from rodents to humans by fleas, direct contact w/feces, or respiratory droplets; Sx: rapid onset f, c, sepsis, pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Chlamydia pneumoniae (Etiology: uncommon cause of CAP; Site: upper resp tract and lung; Sx: sore throat, fever, non-productive cough) more from CDC
      • Chlamydia psittaci (psitacosis) (Etiology: uncommon cause CAP, spread by exposure to parrots & sometimes other birds; Site: lung; Sx: 1-2 week incubation; fever, cough, severe HA; other organ systems as well) more from CDC
      • Staph aureus: coag + (Etiology: uncommon cause CAP; pneumonia following viral infection; can be rapid and necrotizing)
      • Pertussis (Bordatella Pertussis) (Etiology: uncommon cause CAP; Site: upper airwary, rarely lung; Rfs: easily spread; vax of kids and re-vax of adults preventive; kids can have airway compromise due to small size; incubation avg 7-10d; Sx: catarrhal stage 1-2w→ cold sx, sometimes low grade T; then paroxysmal stage→ characteristic whooping cough, post-tussive vomiting; then convaslescent stage→ adults present w/persistent cough x 6-10 weeks) more from CDC
      • Nocardia (Etiology: uncommon cause CAP, lives in soil, inhaled or via open wound; Sites: lung, skin; Sx: subacute cough, f, abscess, cellulitis, lymphangitis if direct inoculation) more from CDC
      • Anthrax (Etiology: uncommon cause CAP; Rfs: acquired from animal exposure or biological weapon; Sx: inhalation: cough, f, c, pneumonia sepsis; cutaneous: ulcer to eshcar w/surrounding edema) more from CDC
      • Health care associated (Etiology/Rfs: hospitalized x2d within last 3m; also consider patients on HD, in NH, on recent IV abx; flora changes to gnr's, mrsa, other resistant bact; though could still be CAP organisms)
      • Aspiration (Etiology: can be acute, assoc w/altered consciousness/swallowing impairment; chronic/recurrent from persistent altered consciousness, swallowing dysfxn; severe GERD; can be inflammatory w/o infxn; Sx: acute or recurrent sob, doe, cough; PE: may have underlying cog or neuro impairment, may affect same lung area→ RML/RLL)
      • Post-obstructive (Etiology: pneumonia that occur behind a mass→ cancer or aspirated foreign body; Sx: often recurrent infection in same anatomic area, cough, f, sputum, sob; if cancer→ may have weight loss, hemoptyis; if aspirated foreign body→ hx altered consciousness, drug use, impaired swallowing)
      • More on pneumonia from CDC
    • Viral
      • Influenza (Etiology: common cause upper and lower respiratory infection; Rfs: seasonal in North America Oct to April, increase risk amongst old, young, pregnant, chronic lung disease, any chronic illness, no vaccination; Sx: abrupt onset of myalgias, arthralgias, fever, chills) more from CDC
      • RSV (Etiology: winter mos, typically affects infants and children, 4-6 d after exposure; Sx: cough, fever, runny nose, wheezing) more from CDC
      • Para-influenza (Etiology: upper resp infection/croup, tracheobronchitis, pneumonia; Sx: cough, fever, runny nose) more from CDC
      • Hanta (Etiology: rodent exposure, incubation 3-4d; Sx: f, myalgias, HA, n, v, abd pain; then rapidly progressive resp sx) more from CDC
      • Measels (rubeola) (Etiology: spread thru resp droplets, highly contagious; Rfs: too young to be vaccinated (<1y), or never vaccinated; winter/spring in US; Sx: incubation 7-14d; cough, high f, malaise; rash 4-5d after sx onset; PE: conjunctivitis, runny nose, then white (Koplick's) spots on oral mucosa, then rash; complications include encephalitis, pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Middle Eastern Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) (Etiology: coronavirus; Rfs: travel to or close contact in past 14d w/someone from Middle East; Sx: acute fever, cough, sob; sometimes n/v/d; can be rapidly progressive)
      • SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome) (Etiology: coronavirus; initial outbreak in China→ rapid spread/pandemic Sx: high fever, aches, sometimes cough; then pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Varicella zoster (chicken pox) (Rfs: rare in kids as vaccine preventable; Sx: f, fatigue, ha, generalized vesicular erruption, duration 5-10d, can still get mild dz if vax, pneumonia in setting severe chicken pox or immunocomp) CDC
    • Fungal
      • Aspergillus (Rfs: immunocompromised host and/or w/structual lung dz→ e.g. bronchiectasis; can be tissue invasive or chronic (e.g. fungal ball); Sx: can be indolent or acute; cough, sob, wt loss, cp, fatigue, hemoptysis) more from CDC
      • Blastomycosis dermatidis (RFs: lives in soil, most commonly found Great Lakes, Mississippi & Ohio river valleys, SE US; typically inhaled; hosts usually of normal health; Sites: lungs, skin if disseminated or as primary problem; Sx: many are asymptomatic; sometimes flu-like illness; others w/sub acute cough, fever, sob; skin nodules or ulcers) more from CDC
      • Coccidioidomycosis (valley fever) (Etiology: Southwest US, higher risk if immune-compromised Site: lung parenchyma and pleural space, joints, skin; Sx: sub-acute sob, cough, f, also arthritis, rash, skin nodules , seeding of other sites) more from CDC
      • Cryptococcus (gattii) (Sites: lungs, skin, cns; Rfs: found on West coast/Pacific Northwest; can cause pneumonia in normal hosts; can also infect those w/HIV and advance t-cell deficiencincy states; Sx: subacute cough, sob, chest pain, f; CNS sx of subacute confusion, ha)
      • Histoplasmosis (Sites: lungs, liver, spleen, systemic; Rfs: exposure to Mississippi & Ohio river valley, HIV+→ increased risk resp/systemic illness; Sx: can be asx/mild and resolve spont; often see x-ray evidence prior infection lung, spleen w/o known past infxn; cough, fever) more from CDC
      • Pneumocystis jerovecii (Sites: lung; Rfs: HIV + and cd4 < 200, prolonged steroid use; Sx: cough, f, sob pneumonia)
    • Mycobacterial
      • Tuberculosis (RFs: HIV +, immunocompromised for other reason, though can occur in anyone; extra-pulm TB increases in HIV+ w/CD4 < 350; Sx: sub-acute, cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, sweats, fatigue; can also infect GI/GU tracts, bone) more from CDC
      • Mycobacterial - MAC (Rfs: bronchietasis→ assoc w/copd, prior lung infxns, cystic fibrosis; Sx: acute infxn assoc w/persistent & progressive cough, sob, sputum; infxns recur) more from CDC
    • Parasites
      • Toxocariasis (aka visceral larva migrans or roundworm) (Etiology: definitive hosts are cats and dogs; humans ingest eggs from dirt→ eggs hatch in intestines→ larvae can travel to lungs, eyes, CNS, liver; Sx: many are asx; can cause cough, f, visual loss, hepatitis)
      • Ascariasis (Etiology: tropics/sub-tropics/SE US, eggs swallowed if contaminated soil ingested (e.g. human feces used as fertilizer)→ eggs hatch in intestines → larvae enter blood stream → migrate lungs → mature & coughed up → swallowed → mature in intestines; Sx: often asx; if heavy worm burden→ cough, f, sob, n, v, abd pain, impaired growth of children, sbo)
      • Strongyloidiasis (Etiology: warm/temperate regions including southeast US, tropics/subtropics including Asia/Southeast Asia; larvae enter thru feet/skin if walk barefoot in soil w/infected feces→ enter skin, where they can cause itching→ travel to lung→ penetrate alveoli and travel up trachea→ cough and then swallowed→ travel to and live in small intestine; Sx: most carry life-long w/o any sx; non-compromised hosts can have vague sx including cough, f, sob, epigastic pain, weakness, watery diarrhea, itching, constipation; can cause life threatening hyper-infxn syndrome w/systemic symptoms if compromised from glucocorticoids, malignancy, HTLV-1 or organ transplant; PE: sometimes serpiginous red erruption from migrating larva under skin)
        • CDC: parasites
    • Immunocompromised host
      • Chemotherapy w/neutropenia (increased risk pseudomonas, TB, fungal - though also can be typical bacterial pathogens)
      • HIV - see below" "SOB/Cough in HIV+"

      Bronchitis

      Sx: acute cough, colored sputum production, not seriously ill; SOB atypical→ only if chronically compromised→ copd, other; can lead to mucous plugging in chronically weak/ill; PE: ronchi on exam more from CDC

      Cancer

      Rfs: smoking and/or asbestos exposure; Sx: sub-acute sob, cough, wt loss, hemoptysis, chest pain, symptoms related to mets if advanced→ bone, brain, liver, paraneoplastic

      COPD

      Rfs: typically >20pky smoking Hx, second hand smoke exposure, consider alpha-1 antitrypsin if sx < 40y and no smoking hx; Sx: sob, doe, clear sputum unless infected; acute→ precipitated by infxn; can also cause chronic sob/wheezing; PE: wheezing on exam, may be barrel chested, can have diminished breath sounds) more from CDC

      Asthma

      Sx: recurrent bouts of wheezing, cough, clear or colored sputum; often viral or allergen as precipitant; often asx between episodes if well rx; childhood onset common→can outgrow it/persist/or develop later in life; PE: wheezing on exam, diminished or absent breath sounds an ominous finding in setting acute exacerbation more from CDC

      Interstitial lung disease (ILD)

      These are relatively uncommon, diffuse, inflammatory processes. Affect interstitium but often also alveoli and airways.
    • Idiopathic
      • Idiopathic fibrosis (Rfs: family hx, smoking, age> 60 Sx: sub-acute sob and doe, progressive dry cough; PE: characteristic dry crackles on exam)
      • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (Sx: Acute/sub-acute cough, sputum, sob, f; steroid responsive, often delays in dx as rx for copd/asthma)
      • Acute interstitial pneumonia (Sx: Acute onset sob, doe; diffuse lung involvement)
      • Multiple other rare sub-types, identified based on histological characteristics, imaging, and clinical findings - includes NSIP
    • Related to connective tissue d/o
      • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
      • RA (Etiology: can cause interstitial lung dz, pleural inflammation, pulm vasc dz; meds for RA can have lung tox, also→ immunocomp→ infxn; Rfs: women > men; age 30-55; Sx: subacute (>6w), persistent/progressive joint pain, worse in AM due to gelling→ improves w/use, fatigue, tendency for bilateral involvement, commonly small and medium sized joints; nerve symptoms can be motor, sensory or from compression; PE: warmth, redness, spongy feeling from synovial inflam, pain w/squeezing of joints, effusion, abnormal appearing if longstanding, MCPs with chronic changes; extra articular findings: episcleritis, pleural/pericardial inflam, rheumatoid nodules) more from CDC
      • Scleroderma (Rfs: age onset < 50, women > men; Sx: can be localized to skin or cause systemic dz; local disease causes focal skin thickening, skin pigmentation; greater involvement can include: GERD, skin tightening/thickened fingers, telangiectasias, raynauds→ finger hypoperfusion and pain in cold, calcium deposits in sub-cu; w/systemic sclerosis, wide spread dz affecting skin, lungs→ sob from pulm htn and interstitial lung dz; joints→ athralgias & myalgias; kidneys→ scleroderma crisis; pericardium→ pericarditis; gi→ GERD; PE: raynauds → fingers blanch/hurt when exposed to cold temp, skin thickening/tightness, hpyerpigmentation)
      • Mixed connective tissue d/o (Etiology: rare d/o, cross over between lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis; Sx: fatigue, muscle and joint aches, finger pain after exposure to cold, sob if pulm htn or ILD; PE: raynauds → fingers blanch/hurt when exposed to cold temp, sausage-type thickening of fingers, skin thickening/tightness)
      • Polymyositis (Rfs: male=female, adults; Sx: weakness more than pain, no numbness, proximal sx, arthralgias, myalgias; persistent cough, fever, sob; PE: progressive, proximal weakness, crackles on exam)
      • Dermatomyositis (Rfs: children and adults, male = female; Sx: weakness more than pain, no numbness, accompanied by rash, proximal sx, arthralgias, myalgias; persistent cough, fever, sob; PE: skin erruption in sun-exposed area, heliotropic rash around eyes, progressive proximal weakness, crackles on exam)
    • Related to systemic d/o
      • Sarcoid (Etiology: idiopathic systemic illness; Rfs: age usually <40, blacks >> other racial groups; Sx: recurrent/progressive cough, fever, fatigue, sob, wt loss, wheezing, joint pain, neuro sx, eye and skin complaints, chf from infiltrative cardiac dz, syncope/sudden death; often delays in dx as rx for asthma/other; PE: wheezing, other systemic findings including: uveitis, arthritis, erythema nodosum, purplish-skin plaques on face, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, CN7 palsey, CNS involvement, adnopathy, other organ infiltration)
    • Related to exposures
      • Asbestos associated (Etiology: exposure via work is ship yards, insulation on pipes/brakes, family member who worked w/asbestos; also causes mesothelioma and benign effusions; Sx: slowly progressive sob and doe; PE: dry crackles
      • Silicosis (Etiology: exposure thru foundry work, minining, sand blasting; Sx: slowly progressive doe/sob; assoc w/increased risk lung cancer and TB; PE: can have dry crackles)
      • Radiation associated (Etiology: known exposure of lung to xrt; Sx: progressive sob/doe, onset sx ~ 6m following exposure)
      • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (Etiology: secondary to exposures to many possible agents, including: mold, bird droppings, hay→ farmer's lung, other; Sx: acute/sub-acute or chronic; cough, wheezing, sob, f)
      • Berylliosis (RFs: exposure thru mining or working in industries that use beryllium; Sx: slowly progressive doe/sob. cough, f, wt loss; mos to decades betwn exposure and sx; PE: can have dry crackles, sometimes skin nodules)
    • Related to meds
      • Many meds can cause ILD (Etiology: develop sx and xray findings after exposure; common meds include amiodarone, bleomycin and other chemo agents, illicit drugs, talc, etc; dx made by linking sx to med exposure)

      Other inflammatory/infiltrative processes

      These are relatively uncommon
      • Granulomatosis with poyangiitis (Wegeners) (Sx: vasculitis→ recurrent/progressive nasal congestion, cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; neuropathic sx; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; PE: mucosal erythema, ulcer, nasal septum perf)
      • Goodpastures (Sx: persistent cough, sob, hemoptysis, concurrent acute kidney injury from glomerulonephritis)
      • Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss) (Etiology: idiopathic d/o, w/high levels circulating and tissue invasive eosinophils; Rfs: men=women, assoc also w/leukotriene antagonists; Sx: progressive, adult onset asthma, cough & wheezing, nasal stuffiness→ w/resp sx usually ~2-10 y prior to systemic sx assoc w/eosinophilic deposition in target organs and vasculitis; in these later phases→ systemic sx including: sob from parenchymal lung involvement; f, c, muscle aches; hematuria from renal involvement; heart failure, pericarditis and dysrhythmia w/cardiac involvement; peripheral neuropathy; PE: wheezing, skin findings of vasculitis: small, palapable purpura, dont blanch when compress them, can coalesce; hematuria/renal involvement; unexplained peripheral neuropathy)
      • Eosinophilic pna (Sx: f, cough, sputum; eos on labs, cxr w/peripheral infiltrates; acute and chronic forms; often mistaken for copd exacerbation if smoker or pna; often delays in dx as rx for copd/asthma/pneumonia)
      • Blood (Etiology: bleeding diathesis or other reason for bleeding into bronchi/alveoli or aspirating blood; vasculitides above; diffuse alveolar hemorrhage; Sx: cough, sob, hemoptysis)
      • ARDS (Etiology: initial pulmonary inflammatory process→ eg. bact or viral pna, with resultant secondary widespread pulmonary inflammation; other severe systemic illness; Sx: acute, rapidly progressive sob, f, sputum)

      Vascular Dz

      Emboli

        RFs for dvt/pulm embolus→ immobility, trauma, hypercoaguable state; Sx: acute or subacute if recurrent events, cough, SOB, pleuritic cp, hemoptysis; PE: tachycardia, tachypnea, often clear lungs; less commonly wheezing or findings of effusion; unexplained unilateral edema; Well's Criteria for DVT; Well's Criteria for PE More from CDC

      Idiopathic arterial pulmonary htn

        Rfs: women > men Sx: vague chest pain, subacute sob worse w/activity, dizziness with activity; PE: elevated jvp, edema, right ventricular heave, loud p2, rapid heart rate) more from CDC

      Other causes of pulmonary htn

      • Chronic/recurrent pulmonary emboli
      • COPD or chronic hypoxemia for any reason
      • Sleep apnea (Sx: snoring, obese, observed apnea, poorly rested in AM, daytime fatigue; PE: BMI > 30, OSA risk increased w/neck circumference >17 men, 16 women; osa risk increased if cant see back of throat)
      • Chronic, severe HF (Sx: orthopnea, PND, doe, sob; PE: lower extremity edema, + S3, elevated jvp, displaced pmi, rales on lung exam)
      • Congenital heart dz
      • Scleroderma (Rfs: age onset < 50, women > men; Sx: can be localized to skin or cause systemic dz; local disease causes focal skin thickening, skin pigmentation; greater involvement can include: GERD, skin tightening/thickened fingers, telangiectasias, raynauds→ finger hypoperfusion and pain in cold, calcium deposits in sub-cu; w/systemic sclerosis, wide spread dz affecting skin, lungs→ sob from pulm htn and interstitial lung dz; joints→ athralgias & myalgias; kidneys→ scleroderma crisis; pericardium→ pericarditis; gi→ GERD; PE: raynauds → fingers blanch/hurt when exposed to cold temp, skin thickening/tightness, hyperpigmentation)
      • Mixed connective tissue d/o (Etiology: rare d/o, cross over between lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis; Sx: fatigue, muscle and joint aches, finger pain after exposure to cold, sob if pulm htn; PE: raynauds → fingers blanch/hurt when exposed to cold temp, sausage-type thickening of fingers)
      • RA (Etiology: can cause interstitial lung dz, pleural inflammation, pulm vasc dz; meds for RA can have lung tox, also→ immunocomp→ infxn; Rfs: women > men, age onset 40-60, fam hx; Sx: fatigue, worse in am, sob, cough in patient w/known RA or findings suggestive PE: bilateral, symetric joint warmth, redness, pain, synovial thickening, typically affects MCPs hands, knees, other medium sized joints; less commonly skin nodules)
      • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
      • Hiv associated
      • Meds: e.g. fenfluramine, amphetamines

      Pulmonary AVM

        Etiology: most commonly assoc w/hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT; formerly Osler-Weber-Rendu) within lungs; also congenital, assoc w/cirrhosis→ hepato-pulm syndrome; or w/prior surgery/trauma; Sx: sob, doe; PE: findings associated w/advanced liver dz if related to cirrhosis; telangiectasis on nasal mucosa, lips, tongue and GI tract can cause bleeding in those areas)

      Pleural D/O

      Pleural Effusion

      Distinguish between exudative & transudative effusion by sampling fluid.
    • Tests to determine transudate v exudate
        • Tests include: appearance, LDH, TP, cell count, glucose, gram stain, culture, cytology. Light's criteria: Exudate if Pleural LDH/Serum LDH > .6, Pleural TP/Serum TP > .5, or pleural LDH > 2/3 nl.
    • Transudative effusion
      • CHF (C/V Rfs, orthopnea, sob, doe, pnd; PE: lower extremity edema , + S3, elevated jvp, displaced pmi, rales on lung exam)
      • Cirrhosis associated (Etiology: known portal hypertension from cirrhosis related to chronic liver dz; Sx: sob, doe PE: ascites, and findings suggestive pleural effusion)
      • Pulmonary emboli (exudate or transudate) (RFs for dvt/pulm embolous→ immobility, trauma, hypercoaguable state; Sx: acute or subacute if recurrent events, cough, SOB, pleuritic cp, hemoptysis; PE: unexplained unliateral edema; Well's Criteria for DVT; Well's Criteria for PE)
    • Exudative effusion
      • Cancer (Sx: SOB, sub-acute, cough, wt loss)
      • Infection: Para-pneumonic (Etiology: adjacent infection, but fluid not infected - aspiration to dx; Sx: acute, F, cough, sputum, SOB)
      • Infection: Empyema (Etiology: fluid infected - complication of pneumonia, lung surgery, trauma - aspiration to dx; bacterial, mycobacterial, viral; Sx: acute, F, cough, sputum, SOB)
      • Pulmonary emboli (exudate or transudate) (RFs for dvt/pulm embolus→ immobility, trauma, hypercoaguable state; Sx: acute or subacute if recurrent events, cough, SOB, pleuritic cp, hemoptysis; PE: unexplained unilateral edema; Well's Criteria for DVT; Well's Criteria for PE)
      • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
      • RA (Etiology: can cause interstitial lung dz, pleural inflammation, pulm vasc dz; meds for RA can have lung tox, also→ immunocomp→ infxn; Rfs: women > men; age 30-55; Sx: subacute (>6w), persistent/progressive joint pain, worse in AM due to gelling→ improves w/use, fatigue, tendency for bilateral involvement, commonly small and medium sized joints; nerve symptoms can be motor, sensory or from compression; PE: warmth, redness, spongy feeling from synovial inflam, pain w/squeezing of joints, effusion, abnormal appearing if longstanding, MCPs with chronic changes; extra articular findings: episcleritis, pleural/pericardial inflam, rheumatoid nodules) more from CDC
      • Lymphatic related→ chylous (usually exudate) (Etiology: injury to thoracic duct: trauma; Surgery→ manipulation in are near apex of lung; Cancer→ occluding lymphatics
      • Trauma (Etiology: event often obvious→ fall, blunt or penetrating trauma; other sign of injury present)

      Pneumothorax

      Sx: acute, SOB, pleuritic cp, PE: absent or diminished breath sounds, crepitus if air dissects into sub-cu tissues; if tension→ trachea deviated away, more likely hemodynamic compromise
      • Primary (Rfs: tall thin male, smoker)
      • Secondary (Rfs: trauma, chronic infection extending to pleura→ hiv, severe copd)

      Upper Airway D/O

      • Vocal cord dysfunction (Sx: inspiratory and expiratory wheezing, sudden onset/abrupt termination of attacks, no response to asthma rx, neck discomfort)
      • Tracheal obstruction (Sx: sob, doe, timing/onset of sx based on etiology below; PE: stridor→ inspiratory & expiratory wheeze loudest over trachea)
        • Tumor within airway (Sx: slowly progressive, hx smoking, cough, stridor or other exam findings)
        • Tumor/mass causing extrinsic compression (Etiology: thyromegaly, malignancy)
        • Foreign body (Etiology: known aspiration of or hx loss of consciousness, hx swallowing disorder, young children or adults w/cognitive/swallowing impairment Sx: acute, sob PE: resp distress, stridor)
        • Angioedema (histamine mediated) (Etiology: localized areas subcu swelling, response to a precipitant, including: meds, food, latex, insect bite/stings, other environmental triggers; Sx: acute, sob, edema, itching, flushing, abd pain; can be severe and life threatening due to airway issues; can occur w/anaphylactic rxns→ low bp w/systemic sx; PE: swelling of face & other body parts, edema often asymmetric and non-pitting, redness, stridor, wheezing, hives/urticaria)
        • Angioedema (bradykinin mediated) (Etiology: localized areas subcu swelling, response to a precipitant, including: meds, in particular ACE-I; can occur soon after initiation or later; Sx: acute, sob, edema, abd pain; typically no urticara or itching; can be severe and life threatening due to airway issues; can occur w/anaphylactic rxns→ low bp w/systemic sx; PE: swelling of face/head/larynx/tongue, stridor, resp distress)
        • Hereditary angioedema (Etiology: rare, related to C1 inhibitor deficiency, sometimes family hx similar events; requires rx directed at compliment cascade & its products; Sx: onset early age; often no trigger; sob, swelling, abd pain, no itching; can start in one area of body and spread; sx last several days; resolves in hours to days; can be life threatening due to airway issues; PE: swelling of face, tongue, stridor, resp distress; non-pitting edema of face/hands/legs/genitalia/other body parts; no urticaria)
      • Mucous plug (Sx: acute sob, doe; colored sputum if infected; Rfs: excess mucous production from chronic bronchitis, asthma, other; impaired ability to clear secretions from COPD, generalized weakness, altered mental status, other; PE: sob, sometimes wheezing if concomitant reactive airways dz, decreased breath sounds)
      • Other inflammatory or space occupying process of the neck that might compromise airway
      • Upper airway infection
        • Peri-tonsilar abscess (acute pain, worse then simple pharyngitis, localizes to one side, problems/pain swallowing, if severe→ airway compromise; PE: focal swelling in tonsilar area, uvula deviated away)
        • Epiglotitis (Sx: acute, f, can't swallow, sob, pain in anterior neck; Pe: ill appearing. sitting upright, drooling, "hot potato" voice)
        • Other infection of the mouth/neck that can compromise airway

      Chest wall/Diaphragm

      • Neuromuscular disease (Etiology: e.g. myasthenia, myopathy; Sx: progressive, generalized weakness, often worse w/repetitive use, double vision)
      • Phrenic nerve dysfxn (Etiology: damaged phrenic nerve from trauma, surgical injury; Neuro/Muscular d/o→ ALS, NMJ dz, cancer; idiopathic: Sx: Sob and DOE, worse lying down; if bilateral involvement→ worse sx than unilateral; PE: abdomen may move inward (paradoxically) w/inspiration, absence of diaphragmatic excursion on percussion, decreased breath sounds at base of affected lung)
      • Other CNS or PNS d/o: Guillain-Barre, ALS
      • Obesity (Etiology: abdominal and chest wall obesity impairs ability to fully inspire→ restrictive lung physiology; Sx: subacute/progressive doe, decline in exercise tolerance, sx correlate w/weight gain; PE: elevated BMI)
      • Chest wall or spine abnormality (Etiology: kyphosis, scoliosis, or other processes that inhibit respiratory mechanics: Sx: sob/doe that correlate w/progression of chest wall/spine dz; PE: evidence of spine or chest wall abnormality)

      SOB/Cough in HIV +

      Etiology can still be any that affect HIV -; additional considerations based on degree of immune compromise
      • Infection
        • Bacterial pneumonia community acquired: pneumococcus, h influenza, legionella
        • Viral pneumonia - cmv, hsv, vzv
        • Fungi - Coccidimycosis (Rfs: CD4 < 250, living or visit to Southwest; Sx: cough, fever, sob)
        • Fungi - Histoplasmosis (Rfs: CD4 < 300; Sx: cough, sob, sweats; can have multiple other organ systems involved, including: liver, spleen, cns)
        • Fungi - Pneumocystis Jirovecii (Rfs: CD4 < 100 or untreated HIV; Sx: sub-acute, cough, sob, chest pain)
        • Fungi - Cryptococcus (neoformans) (Sites: cns, lungs, skin; Rfs: assoc w/immunocompromised, CD4 < 50 or untreated HIV; Sx: CNS disease→ sub-acute headache, fever, confusion; pulmonary→ subacute cough, sob, chest pain, f)
        • Fungi - Cryptococcus (gattii) (Sites: lungs, skin, cns; Rfs: found on West coast/Pacific Northwest; can cause pneumonia in normal hosts; can also infect those w/HIV and advance t-cell deficiencincy states; Sx: subacute cough, sob, chest pain, f; CNS sx of subacute confusion, ha)
        • Mycobacteria - TB (Rfs: can occur at any CD4, w/CD4 < 350→ extra-pulmonary TB increases; Sx: if > 350, similar sx to non-hiv +→ cough, fever, sweats, sob, hemoptysis)
        • Mycobacterium - MAC (Rfs: HIV + w/CD4 < 50 for disseminated dz; hx bronchietasis for lung sx; Sx: persistent/progressive cough, sputum, sob) more from CDC
      • Malignancy
        • Kaposis Sarcoma (Rfs: CD4 < 150, Sx: sob, cough, PE: KS elsewhere on body)
        • Lymphoma (Sx: sub-actue, f, sweats, wt loss, PE: adenopathy elsewhere, unexplained organogmegaly)
      More on HIV from the CDC

      Cardiovascular

      HefRef

      Genl HF (Sx: orthopnea, PND, doe, sob; PE: lower extremity edema , + S3, elevated jvp, displaced pmi, rales on lung exam)

      CAD w/past MI

      • Most common cause HF w/reduced EF in US (Sx: Often past hx angina, MI, prior coronary interventions)

      Valvular Dz

      • Aortic stenosis (Etiology: most common Etiology adult calcific age >70; bicuspid age > 40; rheumatic heart disease Sx: initially asx, then can have SOB, syncope, chest pain, chf as stenosis worsens; PE: characterisitc systolic murmur, crescendo-descrendo, later peaking as progresses, other findings CHF)
      • Aortic regurgitation (Etiology: common Etiology include bicuspid valve, Marfans/connective tissue d/o, rheumatic heart dz, aortic root dil from htn; acute regurg from endocarditis or dissection; Sx: Chronic regurg leads to slow development sx; acute regurg→ acute sx PE: characteristic diastotic murmur, other findings CHF)
      • Mitral regurgitation (Etiology: chronic→ mitral valve prolapse, prior endocarditis, ring dilated from dilated LV, rheumatic heart dz, torn cordae; acute→ endocarditis, infarct; Sx: acute regurg→ acute sx CHF; chronic→ chronic CHF sx PE: holosytolic murmur, other findings CHF)
      • Sub-Aortic stenosis (Etiology: idiopathic, can present from kids to adults; Sx: initially asx, then chf develop as degree of obstruction worsens, also syncope; PE: systolic murmur; louder w/decreased preload)

      Meds or Toxins

      • Etiology: etoh, cocaine, crystal meth, anthracycline based chemo→ doxarubicin, cyclophasphamide, many others

      Rhythm related

      • Chronic svt w/poorly controlled ventricular response
      • Very frequent PVCs or runs of VT

      HTN related

      • Rfs: long standing htn that's not well controled, age > 50 and in partic > 75, dm, hyperlipidemia, obesity

      Idiopathic Dilated Cardiomyopathy

      • Etiology unknown

      Metabolic or response to unusual stresses

      • Profound hypothyroidism(Sx: wt gain, edema, dry skin, constipation, cold intolerance, depression/mood change, weakness, fatigue, coma; PE: often no findings aside from wt gain, sometimes decreased reflexes, edema, bradycardia)
      • Acromegaly (growth hormone excess) (Etiology: typically pituitary tumor, age ~40; Sx: increase in hat or shoe size as an adult, fatigue, weakness, joint pain, increased height, sweating & body odor, headache, visual loss afffecting temporal fields, infertility, menstrual irreg; PE: characteristic appearance of face w/prominent brow and jaw, enlarging hands, increasing shoe size, enlarging tongue)
      • Peri-Partum cardiomyopathy (Etiology: idiopathic; Rfs: most are w/in 1w post partum, though can present during last month of pregnancy to 5m post deliver; Sx: sob, doe, pnd, orthopnea)
      • Takotsubo (apical ballooning) (Etiology: following emotionally or physiologically stressful event; often transient w/full reocvery following supportive rx; Rfs: female> male, post menopausal; Sx: acute chest discomfort, sob, doe, syncope)
      • Hyperthyroidism (Etiology: grave's disease, thyroiditis, multi-nodular or single toxic adenoma, exogenous thyroid hormone consumption; Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, sweating, wt loss, weakness; PE: fever, sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid→ nodules, pain or diffuse enlargement based on etiology, hyper-reflexia, moist skin)
      • Thyroid storm (Etiology: a profound thyrotoxic state, w/mortality 20-30%; Rfs: untreated or undiagnosed hyperthyroidism, often triggered by stress/infection or iodine admin from CT; Sx: acute, severe palpatations, sob/doe, tremor, abd discomfort, n, v, d, delirium; PE: ill appearing, fever, tachycardia, a fib, tremor, enlarged thyroid, abd discomfort, pulmonary edema/findings of chf, confusion)
      • Pheochromocytoma (Etiology: inappropriate secretion of epi/norepi from adrenal medulla; rare condition; Sx: assoc w/findings related to abrupt, paroxysmal increase in sympathetic d/c; rarely causes cardiomyopathy; PE: elevated HR, BP, headache, sweating)

      Infxn Assoc (myocarditis)

      • Bacterial, viral, retroviral, spirochete (Etiology: HIV; viral myocarditis→ coxscakievirus, influenza, other; lyme; secondary to bacterial sepsis; Sx: typcially those of heart failure; also f, c, s and anything else specific to underlying pathogen; PE: t, elevated jvp, diplaced PMI, + s3, edema, other findings assoc w/primary infxn)
      • American Trypanosomiasis (chagas dz) - Parasite t cruzi (Etiology: Central and South America, via reduviid bug bite; incubation 1-2w; Sx: most have no acute sx; if acute sx present, can include→ f, c, sweats, malaise, ha, n, v, d x weeks; chronic sx in 20-30%, including: lower esophageal dysmotility; cardiomyopathy→ CHF, dysrhythmia; PE: rare acute findings: skin nodule at bite; eyelid edema)

      Restrictive or Infiltrative

        Processes that decrease ventricular compliance:
      • Amyloid associated (Etiology: systemic family of illness, protein can deposit in any organ; Sx: neuropathic→ pain or loss of fxn, carpal tunnel; autonomic dysfxn; renal dysfxn; cardiac msucle→ malignant dysrhytmias, chf; liver; GI tract; soft tissues, tongue; often delays in dx)
      • Sarcoid (Etiology: idiopathic systemic illness; Rfs: age usually <40, blacks >> other racial groups; Sx: recurrent/progressive cough, fever, fatigue, sob, wt loss, wheezing, joint pain, neuro sx, eye and skin complaints, chf from infiltrative cardiac dz, syncope/sudden death; often delays in dx as rx for asthma/other; PE: wheezing, other systemic findings including: uveitis, arthritis, erythema nodosum, purplish-skin plaques on face, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, CN7 palsey, CNS involvement, adnopathy, other organ infiltration)
      • Hemochromatosis (Rfs: age 30-40, Sx; SOB, DOE; chronic, progressive liver dz, ED and low libido, diabetes; PE: dark skin, small testes) More from CDC

      Hypertrophic

      • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (Etiology: idiopathic, can present from kids to adults; can have symmetric, focal or obstructive hypertrophy, Sx: initially asx, then chf develop as degree of obstruction worsens, also syncope or sudden death from spontaneous VT; PE: CHF findings, systolic murmur if obstructive which gets louder w/decreased preload)

      Autoimmune Related

      • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
      • Myocarditis - giant cell (Etiol: idiopathic; Sx: acute, rapid, severe and progressive CHF sx; often accompanied by ventricular dysrhythmias; high mortality; dx by endomyocardial bx and exclusion other etiol)

      HefPef

      Genl heart failure (Sx: orthopnea, PND, doe, sob; PE: lower extremity edema , + S3, elevated jvp, rales on lung exam)

      Chronic Htn

      • Rfs: long standing htn, age > 50 and in partic > 75, dm, hyperlipidemia, obesity; can also cause acute chf if true hypertensive emergency→ ~ >200/120 w/acute end organ dysfxn→ encepahlopathy, chf, renal dysfxn

      Valvular and other structural heart dz

      • Aortic stenosis (Etiology: most common adult calcific age >70; bicuspid age > 40; rheumatic heart disease; Sx: initially asx, then can have SOB, syncope, chest pain, chf as stenosis worsens; PE: characterisitc systolic murmur, crescendo-descrendo, later peaking as progresses, other findings CHF)
      • Aortic regurgitation(Etiology: include bicuspid valve, Marfans/connective tissue d/o, rheumatic heart dz, aortic root dil from htn; acute regurg from endocarditis or dissection; Sx: Chronic regurg leads to slow development sx; acute regurg→ acute sx PE: characteristic diasoltic murmur, other findings CHF)
      • Mitral regurgitation (Etiology: chronic→ mitral valve prolapse, prior endocarditis, ring dilataion from dilated LV, rheumatic heart dz; acute→ endocarditis, infarct; Sx: acute regurg→ acute sx CHF; chronic→ chronic CHF sx PE: holosytolic murmur, other findings CHF)
      • Mitral stenosis (Etiology: overall, very uncommon in US; related to rheumatic heart dz or congenital sx, can have regurg as well; Sx: asx initially, then CHF as progresses, worse if superimposed SVT, characteristic diastolic murmur, other findings CHF)
      • Pulmonary vein stenosis (Etiology: complication of ablation procedure for a fib)

      Infiltrative or Restrictive dz

        Processes that decrease ventricular compliance:
      • Amyloid associated (Etiology: systemic family of illness, protein can deposit in any organ; Sx: neuropathic→ pain or loss of fxn, carpal tunnel; autonomic dysfxn; renal dysfxn; cardiac msucle→ malignant dysrhytmias, chf; liver; GI tract; soft tissues, tongue; often delays in dx)
      • Sarcoid (Etiology: idiopathic systemic illness; Rfs: age usually <40, blacks >> other racial groups; Sx: recurrent/progressive cough, fever, fatigue, sob, wt loss, wheezing, joint pain, neuro sx, eye and skin complaints, chf from infiltrative cardiac dz, syncope/sudden death; often delays in dx as rx for asthma/other; PE: wheezing, other systemic findings including: uveitis, arthritis, erythema nodosum, purplish-skin plaques on face, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, CN7 palsey, CNS involvement, adnopathy, other organ infiltration)

      Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy

      • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (Etiology: idiopathic, can present from kids to adults; can have symmetric, focal or obstructive hypertrophy, Sx: initially asx, then chf develop as degree of obstruction worsens, also syncope or sudden death from spontaneous VT; PE: CHF findings, systolic murmur if obstructive which gets louder w/decreased preload)

      Coronary Artery Dz

      • CAD - where SOB is anginal equivalent (Rfs: other C/V RFs; Sx: pressure w/walking or other activity, radiation to L arm/neck/back, sweating, n, sx resolves w/rest)

      Rhythm Assoc

      • Too Fast: acute SVT (Sx: rapid heart rate, palpatations, doe; PE: rapid hr)
      • Too slow: bradycardia (Sx: fatigue, decreased exercise tolerance, CHF symptoms; PE: slow hr)

      Pericardial disease

      • Tamponade (Etiology: pericarditis from: cardiac surgery, infection→ viral, bacterial or TB; cancer related, metabolic d/c→ hypothyroid/renal failure, automimmune d/o, XRT assoc; med related, idiopathic, traumatic; Sx: doe, sob, cp, edema; PE: elevated jvp, soft heart sounds, elevated hr, low bp, pulsus paradoxus→ > 10 point drop in SBP w/inspiration, papated pulse volume can also vary w/respiration)
        • Rapid accumulation of fluid (Sx: rapid development of sob, doe, chest pain, other CHF-type sx, clinical decompensation)
        • Slow accumulation of fluid (Sx: better tolerated, slower development of sob, doe, feeling non-specifically poorly, chf-type sx)
      • Constrictive pericardial disease (Etiology: pericarditis for any reason that leads to scarring and loss of pericardial elasticity→ infection, surgery, autoimmune, idiopathic, etc; Sx: chronic/progressive sob, doe, other CHF-type sx, feeling poorly in general; PE: elevated jvp, lower extremity edema)

      High output HF

      • A-V fistula (Etiology: trauma, inflammation or surgery induced PE: might hear bruit over site)
      • Hyperthyroidism (Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, wt loss, weakness; PE: sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid, hyper-reflexia)
      • Anemia
      • Thiamine deficiency (Etiology: ETOH abuse Sx/PE: confusion, extremity numbness/difficulty walking)
      • Paget's disease (Rf: > 50 Sx: slowly progressive multi-site bone pain, leg bowing)

      Right to left shunt

      Uncommon disorders
      • Intracardiac - ASD or PFO (Etiology: congenital→ Sx: develop over years if large enough, sob, doe, paradoxical emboli, atrial dysrhythmias)
      • Intracardiac - VSD (Etiology: congenital→ Sx: develop over years if large enough, sob, doe, paradoxical emboli; rare complication post MI→ acute sob, decompensation PE: systolic murmur)
      • Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT; formerly Osler-Weber-Rendu) (Etiology: rare congential d/o, AVMs within lungs, nose, mouth, GI tract→ duod, stomach, colon; Sx: onset typically in teens, nose bleeds; cryptic GI bleeds/iron defic anemia, SOB, cryptic stroke or CNS abscess; PE: recurrent nose bleed, telangiectasis on nasal mucosa, lips, tongue)
      • Pulmonary AVM assoc w/liver dz (Etiology: assoc w/cirrhosis→ hepato-pulm syndrome; or w/prior surgery/trauma; Sx: sob, doe; PE: findings associated w/advanced liver dz)
      • AVM in any location - larger→ more sx (Etiology: congenital, post traumatic, post inflammatory, post surgical; audible bruit over large avm)

      Congenital Heart Dz

      These are uncommon diseases, typically picked up at birth or in early childhood. The list below is restricted to those congenital disorders which might escape early detection and manifest in adulthood. Congenital disorders identified and adressed during childhood are not discussed below. Care of these patients can be complicated and typically requires sub-specialty input. It's still helpful to know their hx, procedures done, past imaging, and current sx. More info about congenital heart dz from the AHA.
      • ASD (Etiology: congenital inter-atrial connection; first manifestation can be in adulthood if smaller, w/patholphysiology developing over time→ up to 30s or 40s; typically L to R shunting; Sx: slowly progressive doe, paradoxical emboli, atrial dysrhythmias, rarely platypnea-orthodexia→ Sob worse w/sitting up, relieved by lying down; PE: a fib, fixed & widely split S2, sometimes murmur from high flow across TV or PV, stroke if paradoxical embolous)
      • VSD (Etiology: inter-ventricular connection, most common congenital defect in kids; can manifest in adulthood if smaller w/patholphysiology developing over time, though this is unusual; typically L to R shunting; Sx: slowly progressive doe, paradoxical emboli, endocarditis; PE: systolic murmur along lower sternal border, sometimes murmur of AI, other findings CHF; findings of endocarditis if suggestive sx)
      • Coarctation of Aorta (Etiology: congenital narrowing of desending aorta; typically picked up in childhood but can manifest in adulthood, sometimes assoc w/bicuspid AS; Sx: develop over years, sob from chf, fatigue, nose bleeds, head ache, leg claudication, stroke or other assoc w/severe htn; PE: persistent unexplained htn, pulse volume difference btwn upper vs lower extremities, mumur AS if also bicuspid valve, chf findings if severe & prolonged)
      • Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) (Etiology: connection btwn aorta and pulm art which fails to close at birth; L to R shunting; can rarely manifest in adulthood if smaller, w/patholphysiology developing over time; can be assoc w/ASD or VSD; Sx: develop over years w/sob, doe; PE: continuous machine-like murmur at LUSB, findings pulm htn from Eisenmengers physiol)
      • Tetralolgy of Fallot (Etiology: congenital VSD, sub-pulmonary stenosis, aorta that over-rides the VSD, and RV hypertophy; results in cyanotic heart dz at young age; RF: Down's synd; Sx: very rare to present in adulthood in developed world; profound sob and DOE, endocarditis, paradoxical emboli→ cerebral abscess or stroke; PE: cyanosis, clubbing, systolic murmur along sternal border, other findings CHF; findings of endocarditis if clinical sx; findings polycythemia)

      Other Causes

      Non-hydrostatic pulmonary edema

      • Capillary leak into alveoli (Etiology: many possible causes, including: high altitude; brain trauma/insult; meds→ salicylate or narcotic overdose; ARDS; other)
      • Transfusion Associated Lung Injury (TRALI) (Etiology: related to the plasma component of transfusion; differentiate from Transfusion Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO)→ acute sob related to volume and oncotic load of blood products, patients w/RFs for diastolic HF; TACO and TRALI can overlap; Sx: for TRALI: w/in 6h receiving blood product, acute sob, can have fever; PE: f, sitting up, sob, tachycardiac, htn, elevated jvp, rales, edema)

      Anemia or Abnormally functioning hemoglobin

      • Anemia (Etiology: blood loss, production problems, lysis)
      • Abnormal hemoglobin (Etiology: disorders affecting loading/unloading of O2)
        • Methemoglobinemia (Etiology: hemoglobin changed to met-hgb form, which cant bind O2; Rfs: often from meds like dapsone, benzocaine spray; Sx: progressive sob, confusion, acidosis and target organ dysfxn→ more severe w/higher levels met-hgb; PE: tachypnea, tachycardia, O2 sat 85%, clear lungs, cyanosis)

      Deconditioning

      General inactivity, sedentary lifestyle, obesity, bed bound from illness, etc

      Volume overload for any reason

        CHF, advanced liver or kidney disease, etc

      Metabolic acidosis (w/resp compensation)

      Elevated resp rate, clear lungs on exam, other sx/findings as below related to underlying cause
    • Metabolic d/o
      • DKA or alcoholic ketoacidosis
      • Renal failure
      • Lactic acidosis (Etiology: hypotension, end organ hypo-perfusion, patient typically quite sick; meds including metformin in setting ckd)
    • Drug ingestions
      • Aspirin (Etiology: caused by unintentional over rx for pain or suicide attempt; Sx: ringing in ears, n, v, PE: delirium, rapid resp rate)
      • Isoniazid (Etiology: med used for treating TB other myobact infxn, consumed with intent to harm self; Sx: over dose causes confusion/lethargy/coma/szr/death)
      • Ethylene glycol (Etiology: used in anti-freeze; colorless, odorless and sweet tasting→ accidental ingestions in kids or purposeful in adults; Sx: lower dose similar to ethanol, higher dose n, v, confusion, kidney/liver dysfxn, death, tachypnea from metaolic acidosis, osmolar gap; PE: euphoria, aggitation, social disinhibition; severe cases w/respiratory depression to coma; ataxia, slurred speech)
      • Methanol (wood alcohol) (Etiology: contained in wind shield wiper fluid, anti-freeze, fuel additives, paint thinners; consumed inadvertently by child or w/intent to harm self/others, very toxic; Sx: initially can appear inebriated; n, v, confusion, resp depression, death; long term neruo deficits, blindness; osmolar gap and later met acidosis; PE: initially inebriated; later can have tachypnea from met acidosis, visual disturbance, then somnolence, multi-sytem failure)
      • Iron (Etiology: unintended OD in kids, or purposeful in adults Sx: n, v, abd pain, metabolic acidosis)

      Medications

      Amiodarone→ fibrosis, bleomycin→ fibrosis, other

      Panic attacks/anxiety d/o

      Initial eval directed towards ruling out physiologic etiology→ cardio, pulm, GI, other process w/sig morbidity/mortality
      • Panic d/o (Sx: sudden, repeated and unfounded attacks of fear; feeling out of control when attacks occur, focus on when next episode will occur, avoiance of places where anxiety attacks have occured in past, palpatations, sweeating, sob, dizziness, numbness, chest/abdominal pain, etc)

      Chest pain (CP)?

      Includes the range of symptoms from pressure, to pain, to vaguer discomofort.

      Primary Pulmonary D/O

      Pulmonary related CP tends to be worse w/inspiration (pleuritic), w/coughing, or associated w/sob
      • Pneumonia (Etiology: bacterial, viral, fungal, mycobacterial Sx: acute onset, cough, colored sputum production, fever, chest pain, cxr w/infiltrate; PE: tachycardia, tachypnea, often clear lungs; less commonly wheezing or findings of effusion; rales, ronchi, wheezing or other findings on auscultation, dullness to percussion if pleural effusion or dense parenchymal involvement) more from CDC
      • Cancer (Rfs: smoking and/or asbestos exposure; Sx: sub-acute, SOB, cough, wt loss, hemoptysis)
      • Pulmonary emboli (RFs for dvt/pulm embolous→ immobility, trauma, hypercoaguable state; Sx: acute or subactue if recurrent events, cough, SOB, pleuritic cp, hemoptysis; PE: tachycardia, tachypnea, often clear lungs; less commonly wheezing or findings of effusion; unexplained unliateral edema; Well's Criteria for DVT; Well's Criteria for PE) More from CDC
      • Pneumothorax (Sx: acute, SOB, pleuritic cp, PE: absent or diminished breath sounds, crepitus if air dissects into sub-cu tissues; if tension→ trachea deviated away, more likely hemodynamic compromise)
        • Primary (Rfs: tall thin male, smoker)
        • Secondary (Rfs: trauma, chronic infection extending to pleura→ hiv, severe copd)
      • Pleural processes - inflammatory more likely to cause CP, in particular when inhale. Often associated w/an effusion.
      • Tests to determine transudate v exudate
          • Tests include: appearance, LDH, TP, cell count, glucose, gram stain, culture, cytology. Light's criteria: Exudate if Pleural LDH/Serum LDH > .6, Pleural TP/Serum TP > .5, or pleural LDH > 2/3 nl.
        • Disorders assoc w/Transudative effusion
          • CHF (C/V Rfs, orthopnea, sob, doe, pnd; PE: lower extremity edema , + S3, elevated jvp, displaced pmi, rales on lung exam)
          • Cirrhosis associated (Etiology: known portal hypertension from cirrhosis related to chronic liver dz; Sx: sob, doe PE: ascites, and findings suggestive pleural effusion)
          • Pulmonary emboli (exudate or transudate) (RFs for dvt/pulm embolous→ immobility, trauma, hypercoaguable state; Sx: acute or subacute if recurrent events, cough, SOB, pleuritic cp, hemoptysis; PE: unexplained unilateral edema; Well's Criteria for DVT; Well's Criteria for PE)
        • Disorders assoc w/Exudative effusion
          • Cancer (Etiology: primary lung, mesothelioma, metastatic dz; Sx: sub-acute SOB, cough, chest pain, wt loss)
          • Infection: Para-pneumonic (Etiology: adjacent infection, but fluid not infected - aspiration to dx; Sx: acute, F, cough, sputum, SOB)
          • Infection: Empyema (Etiology: fluid infected - complication of pneumonia, lung surgery, trauma - aspiration to dx; bacterial, mycobacterial, viral; Sx: acute, F, cough, sputum, SOB)
          • Pulmonary emboli (exudate or transudate) (RFs for dvt/pulm embolus→ immobility, trauma, hypercoaguable state; Sx: acute or subacute if recurrent events, cough, SOB, pleuritic cp, hemoptysis; PE: unexplained unilateral edema; Well's Criteria for DVT; Well's Criteria for PE)
          • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
          • RA (Etiology: can cause interstitial lung dz, pleural inflammation, pulm vasc dz; meds for RA can have lung tox, also→ immunocomp→ infxn; Rfs: women > men; age 30-55; Sx: subacute (>6w), persistent/progressive joint pain, worse in AM due to gelling→ improves w/use, fatigue, tendency for bilateral involvement, commonly small and medium sized joints; nerve symptoms can be motor, sensory or from compression; PE: warmth, redness, spongy feeling from synovial inflam, pain w/squeezing of joints, effusion, abnormal appearing if longstanding, MCPs with chronic changes; extra articular findings: episcleritis, pleural/pericardial inflam, rheumatoid nodules) more from CDC
          • Lymphatic related→ chylous (usually exudate) (Etiology: injury to thoracic duct: trauma; Surgery→ manipulation in are near apex of lung; Cancer→ occluding lymphatics
          • Trauma (Etiology: event often obvious→ fall, blunt or penetrating trauma; other sign of injury present)

      Cardiovascular D/O

      Increased likelihood if + C/V RFs: smoking, diabetes, early family history, male, age >~ 50, HTN, hyperlipidemia, known cad or vascular dz elsewhere.

      Angina

      Central chest pressure secondary to coronary artery insufficiency; associated w/CV Rfs, sometimes radiates to L arm, L neck, back; PE: pale, sweaty, in pain, clutching chest
      • Stable angina (Sx: occur after a predictable amount of work, never at rest, not progressive, resolves when stops activity)
      • Unstable angina (Sx: occur at rest, progression or onset of symptoms such that occurring with less and less activity)
      • Myocardial infarction (Sx: acute chest pressure @ rest, can radiate to arm/neck back; often assoc n, v, sob, diaphoresis, feeling poorly; hx known cad or vascular RFs)
        • Plaque rupture (Etiology: sudden onset above sx→ ST elevation MI, NSTEMI or UNSA)
        • Demand ischemia (Etiology: sudden onset above sx, secondary to a physiologic stress applied to unchanged CAD; sources of stress include: tachycardia for any reason, incresaed catechols for any reason, anemia, hypoxemia, low BP, etc)

      Aortic Dissection or Aneurysm

      • Thoracic aorta dissection (Rfs: htn, dm, known atherosclerosis, smoking, hyperlipidemia, prior aneurysms, connective tissue dz; Sx: acute onset, tearing type CP, radiation to back, neck, to abd if dissection extends; stroke sx if involves carotids, sob if dissects to aortic valve/pericardium; angina if into coronaries; PE: sometimes asymetric pulse or bp, stroke if involves carotids, abd pain, arm/leg sx if decreased flow to limbs; loss or asymmetry of pulses)
      • Thoracic aorta aneurysm (Rfs: medial wall degeneration, Genetic→ Marfan's, other; Vasculitis→ Takayasus, GCA; post-aortic stenosis, dissection related; infection, trauma, htn, atherosclerosis; Sx: often asx or vague; cp, sob, upper back pain; compression of SVC, bronchi, or recurrent laryngeal n→ hoarseness; distal embolization; sudden collapse if rupture)

      Pericarditis

      Sx: sharp, acute, left sided chest pain, worse w/deep breath, worse lying down, better sitting up/leaning forward; PE: often pericardial friction rub present; if effusion→ may have decreased heart sounds; if tamponade→ elevated jvp, soft heart sounds, elevated hr, low bp, pulsus paradoxus
    • Infection assoc
      • Viral most common→ coxsackievirus, influenza, other (Etiology: antecedent respiratory viral; coxsackie, influenza, other; Sx: fever, cough, sweats)
      • TB or bacterial - less common c/w viral
      • Acute rheumatic fever (Sx: relatively uncommon, occurs 2-3w after strep pharyngitis, assoc w/fever, fatigue, acute/abrupt onset, migratory inflammatory arthritis of large joints typically; chest pain or sob related to pericarditis; long term risk of mitral or aortic valve dz; PE: affected joint(s) are warm, red, pain w/movement)
    • S/P MI, cardiac surgery, direct trauma
      • Post MI, can occur early or late
      • Post op from any cardiac surgery
    • Cancer or XRT related
      • Radiation involving mediastinum
      • Cancer metastatic or primarily involving mediastinal area - e.g. lung, breast, lymphoma, leukemia, melanoma
    • Metabolic d/o
      • Hypothyroidism (Sx: wt gain, edema, dry skin, constipation, cold intolerance, depression/mood change, weakness, fatigue; PE: often no findings aside from wt gain, sometimes decreased reflexes, edema, bradycardia)
      • Advanced kidney disease w/uremia
    • Connective tissue d/o or autoimmune
      • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
      • Scleroderma (Rfs: age onset < 50, women > men; Sx: can be localized to skin or cause systemic dz; local disease causes focal skin thickening; greater involvement can include: GERD, skin tightening/thickened fingers, telangiectasias, raynauds→ finger hypoperfusion and pain in cold, calcium deposits in sub-cu; w/systemic sclerosis, wide spread dz affecting skin, lungs→ sob from pulm htn and interstitial lung dz; joints→ athralgias & myalgias,; kidneys→ scleroderma crisis; pericardium→ pericarditis; gi→ GERD; PE: raynauds → fingers blanch/hurt when exposed to cold temp, skin thickening/tightness)
      • Mixed connective tissue d/o (Etiology: rare d/o, cross over between lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis; Sx: fatigue, muscle and joint aches, finger pain after exposure to cold; PE: raynauds → fingers blanch/hurt when exposed to cold temp, skin thickening/tightness)
      • RA (Rfs: women > men; age 30-55; Sx: subacute (>6w), persistent/progressive joint pain, worse in AM due to gelling→ improves w/use, fatigue, tendency for bilateral involvement, commonly small and medium sized joints; nerve symptoms can be motor, sensory or from compression; PE: warmth, redness, spongy feeling from synovial inflam, pain w/squeezing of joints, effusion, abnormal appearing if longstanding, MCPs with chronic changes; extra articular findings: episcleritis, pleural/pericardial inflam, rheumatoid nodules) more from CDC
      • Adult Still's Disease (Etiology: febrile illness of unknown etiology; Sx: f and other sx are persistent, sub-acute; evaluation of f does not reveal other etiology; also arhtritis & arthralgias of larger joints; salmon colored, maculo-pap non-puritic skin erruption; myalgias, adenopathy, sore throat, pericarditis and pleuritis; PE: erruption is light salmon colored mac/pap, pharyngitis, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy)
    • Medications
      • Hydralazine, procainamide, phenytoin, isoniazid, penicillins, others
    • Idiopathic
      • A common occurrence - often presumed post viral

      GI D/O

      Esophageal pain tends to be substernal, squeezing, related to food.
      • Esophagitis from GERD (Rfs: assoc w/obesity, ETOH, smoking, caffeine, chocolate, mint; increased BMI, age >50; Sx: chronic/recurrent burning type pain, often worse after meals, worse if lie down after eating, bad taste in mouth, radiates up from epigastrium)
      • Esophageal spasm (Sx: sudden onset, central squeezing pain, sometimes related to food or GERD sx; can remit spont or w/nitro; vascular etiologies typically r'd/out first)
      • Esophagitis from infection (Etiology: viral, fungal; Rfs: sometimes immuncompromised→ HIV+, chemotherapy; recent exposure to abx; Sx: acute/sub-acute sub-sternal pain, pain worse w/swallowing PE: hsv lesions or candida in mouth provide clue to what's affecting esophagus)
      • Pill induced esophagitis (Etiology: pain after ingesting pill not fully swallowed Sx: acute sub-sternal cp, worse w/swallowing)
      • Esophageal perforation→ mediastinitis (Etiology: reason for perforation include: repeated retching→Boerhaves, biopsy/procedure w/perforation, toxic ingestion→ lye/drain cleaner, foreign body; Sx: pain is severe and acute, w/assoc swallowing probs, ill appearance)

      MSK or Trauma

      • Muscle/bone/soft tissue injury/strain (Etiology: recent overuse, recent trauma, onset pain linked temporally; Sx: worse w/movement or use; PE: provocative testing clearly reproduces sx)
      • Cancer met to ribs/sternum (Rfs: cancer that mets to bone→ e.g. lung, prostate, breast, etc; Sx: progressive, unremitting bone pain; PE: pain on palpation over involved area, findings assoc w/primary cancer)
