      • Phrenic nerve dysfxn (Etiology: damaged phrenic nerve from trauma, surgical injury; Neuro/Muscular d/o→ ALS, NMJ dz, cancer; idiopathic: Sx: Sob and DOE, worse lying down; if bilateral involvement→ worse sx than unilateral; PE: abdomen may move inward (paradoxically) w/inspiration, absence of diaphragmatic excursion on percussion, decreased breath sounds at base of affected lung)
      • Other CNS or PNS d/o: Guillain-Barre, ALS
      • Obesity (Etiology: abdominal and chest wall obesity impairs ability to fully inspire→ restrictive lung physiology; Sx: subacute/progressive doe, decline in exercise tolerance, sx correlate w/weight gain; PE: elevated BMI)
      • Chest wall or spine abnormality (Etiology: kyphosis, scoliosis, or other processes that inhibit respiratory mechanics: Sx: sob/doe that correlate w/progression of chest wall/spine dz; PE: evidence of spine or chest wall abnormality)

      SOB/Cough in HIV +

      Etiology can still be any that affect HIV -; additional considerations based on degree of immune compromise
      • Infection
        • Bacterial pneumonia community acquired: pneumoccous, h influenza, legionella
        • Viral pneumonia - cmv, hsv, vzv
        • Fungi - Coccidimycosis (Rfs: CD4 < 250, living or visit to Southwest; Sx: cough, fever, sob, )
        • Fungi - Histoplasmosis (Rfs: CD4 < 300; Sx: cough, sob, sweats; can have multiple other organ systems involved, including: liver, spleen, cns)
        • Fungi - Pneumocystis Jirovecii (Rfs: CD4 < 100 or untreated HIV; Sx: sub-acute, cough, sob, chest pain)
        • Mycobacteria - TB (Rfs: can occur at any CD4, w/CD4 < 350→ extra-pulmonary TB increases; Sx: if > 350, similar sx to non-hiv +→ cough, fever, sweats, sob, hemoptysis)
        • Parasitic - Toxo Pneumonitis (Rfs: HIV+, CD4 < 100, less common than other pulmonary OIs; Sx: cough, fever, sob; clinically similar to PJP)
      • Malignancy
        • Kaposis Sarcoma (Rfs: CD4 < 150, Sx: sob, cough, PE: KS elsewhere on body)
        • Lymphoma (Sx: sub-actue, f, sweats, wt loss, PE: adenopathy elsewhere, unexplained organogmegaly)

      Other Causes

      Non-hydrostatic pulmonary edema

      • Capillary leak into alveoli (Etiology: many possible causes, including: high altitude; brain trauma/insult; meds→ salicylate or narcotic overdose; ARDS; other)
      • Transfusion Associated Lung Injury (TRALI) (Etiology: related to the plasma component of transfusion; differentiate from Transfusion Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO)→ acute sob related to volume and oncotic load of blood products, patients w/RFs for diastolic HF; TACO and TRALI can overlap; Sx: for TRALI: w/in 6h receiving blood product, acute sob, can have fever; PE: f, sitting up, sob, tachycardiac, htn, elevated jvp, rales, edema)

      Anemia or Abnl HgB

      • Anemia (Etiology: blood loss, production problems, lysis)
      • Abnormal hemoglobin (Etiology: disorders affecting loading/unloading of O2)
        • Methemoglobinemia (Etiology: hemoglobin changed to met-hgb form, which cant bind O2; Rfs: often from meds like dapsone, benzocaine spray; Sx: progressive sob, confusion, acidosis and target organ dysfxn→ more severe w/higher levels met-hgb; PE: tachypnea, tachycardia, O2 sat 85%, clear lungs, cyanosis)

      Deconditioning

      General inactivity, sedentary lifestyle, obesity, bed bound from illness, etc

      Volume overload for any reason

      CHF, advanced liver or kidney disease, etc

      Metabol Acidosis

      Elevated resp rate, clear lungs on exam, other sx/findings as below related to underlying cause
    • Metabolic d/o
      • DKA or alcoholic ketoacidosis
      • Renal failure
      • Lactic acidosis (Etiology: hypotension, end organ hypo-perfusion, patient typically quite sick; meds including metformin in setting ckd)
    • Drug ingestions
      • Aspirin (Etiology: caused by unintentional over rx for pain or suicide attempt; Sx: ringing in ears, n, v, PE: delirium, rapid resp rate)
      • Isoniazid (Etiology: med used for treating TB other myobact infxn, consumed with intent to harm self; Sx: over dose causes confusion/lethargy/coma/szr/death)
      • Ethylene glycol (Etiology: used in anti-freeze; colorless, odorless and sweet tasting→ accidental ingestions in kids or purposeful in adults; Sx: lower dose similar to ethanol, higher dose n, v, confusion, kidney/liver dysfxn, death, tachypnea from metaolic acidosis, osmolar gap; PE: euphoria, aggitation, social disinhibition; severe cases w/respiratory depression to coma; ataxia, slurred speech)
      • Methanol (wood alcohol) (Etiology: contained in wind shield wiper fluid, anti-freeze, fuel additives, paint thinners; consumed inadvertently by child or w/intent to harm self/others, very toxic; Sx: initially can appear inebriated; n, v, confusion, resp depression, death; long term neruo deficits, blindness; osmolar gap and later met acidosis; PE: initially inebriated; later can have tachypnea from met acidosis, visual disturbance, then somnolence, multi-sytem failure)
      • Iron (Etiology: unintended OD in kids, or purposeful in adults Sx: n, v, abd pain, metabolic acidosis)

      Medications

      Amiodarone→ fibrosis, bleomycin→ fibrosis, other

      Panic attacks/anxiety d/o

      Initial eval directed towards ruling out physiologic etiology→ cardio, pulm, GI, other process w/sig morbidity/mortality
      • Panic d/o (Sx: sudden, repeated and unfounded attacks of fear; feeling out of control when attacks occur, focus on when next episode will occur, avoiance of places where anxiety attacks have occured in past, palpatations, sweeating, sob, dizziness, numbness, chest/abdominal pain, etc)

      Orthopnea?

      • CHF (C/V RFs; Sx: PND, sob, doe; PE: lower extremity edema , + S3, elevated jvp, displaced pmi, rales on lung exam)
      • COPD (Rfs: smoking, typically > 20 pk yrs; Sx: acute or chronic, cough, sob, doe, wheezing)
      • The majority of acute or chronic lung dz assoc w/SOB will cause patients to sit up→ respiratory mechanics improved in this position

      Paroxysmal Nocturnal Dyspnea (PND)?

      • CHF (C/V RFs; Sx: orthopnea, sob, doe, PE: lower extremity edema , + S3, elevated jvp, displaced pmi, rales on lung exam)

      Edema?

      Lower extremity exam

      Bilateral

      Hydrostatic: Left sided HF

    • HF w/depressed EF
        • HF exam findings (Sx: C/V RFs, orthopnea, PND, sob, doe; PE: lower extremity edema , + S3, elevated jvp, displaced pmi, rales on lung exam)
        • CAD→ past MI - most common cause in US
        • Aortic stenosis (Etiology: most common sEtiology adult calcific age >70; bicuspid age > 40; rheumatic heart disease Sx: initially asx, then can have SOB, syncope, chest pain, chf as stenosis worsens; PE: characterisitc systolic murmur, crescendo-decrescendo, later peaking as progresses, other findings CHF)
        • Aortic regurgitation (Etiology: common Etiology include bicuspid valve, Marfans/connective tissue d/o, rheumatic heart dz, aortic root dil from htn; acute regurg from endocarditis or dissection; Sx: Chronic regurg leads to slow development sx; acute regurg→ acute sx PE: characteristic diastolic murmur, other findings CHF)
        • Mitral regurgitation (Etiology: chronic→ mitral valve prolapse, prior endocarditis, ring dilataion from dilated LV, rheumatic heart dz; acute→ endocarditis, infarct; Sx: acute regurg→ acute sx CHF; chronic→ chronic CHF sx PE: holosystolic murmur, other findings CHF)
        • Sub-Aortic stenosis (Etiology: idiopathic, can present from kids to adults; Sx: initially asx, then chf develop as degree of obstruction worsens, also syncope; systolic murmur; louder w/decreased preload)
        • Meds/toxins (Etiology: etoh, cocaine, anthracycline based chemo→ doxarubicin, cyclophasphamide, many others)
        • Chronic svt w/poorly controlled ventricular response
        • Long standing and poorly controlled HTN
        • Dilated cardiomyopathy (Etiology: idiopathic; Sx: chf-type)
        • Other metabolic or response to unusual stresses (Etiology: profound hypothyroidism; peri-partum; hyperthyroidism; secondary to sepsis; following a very stressful event→ Takotubo→ usually transient; Amyloid assoc)
        • Infection associated myocarditis (Etiology: HIV; post viral→ coxscakie, influenza, other; lyme; Chagas; other
        • Autoimmune associated (Etiology: related to Lupus, giant cell myocarditis, other)
    • HF w/preserved EF
        • HF exam findings(C/V RFs, orthopnea, PND, exam findings: lower extremity edema, + S3, elevated jvp, rales on lung exam)
        • Typically assoc with chronic poorly controlled htn (Rfs: long standing htn, age > 50 and in partic > 75, dm, hyperlipidemia, obesity)
        • Aortic stenosis (Etiology: most common sEtiology adult calcific age >70; bicuspid age > 40; rheumatic heart disease Sx: initially asx, then can have SOB, syncope, chest pain, chf as stenosis worsens; PE: characterisitc systolic murmur, crescendo-descrendo, later peaking as progresses, other findings CHF)
        • Aortic regurgitation(Etiology: common Etiology include bicuspid valve, Marfans/connective tissue d/o, rheumatic heart dz, aortic root dil from htn; acute regurg from endocarditis or dissection; Sx: Chronic regurg leads to slow development sx; acute regurg→ acute sx PE: characteristic diasoltic murmur, other findings CHF)
        • Mitral regurgitation (Etiology: chronic→ mitral valve prolapse, prior endocarditis, ring dilatation from dilated LV, rheumatic heart dz; acute→ endocarditis, inferior infarct, rupture chordae; Sx: acute regurg→ acute sx CHF; chronic→ chronic CHF sx PE: holosytolic murmur, other findings CHF)
        • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (Etiology: idiopathic, can present from kids to adults; can have symmetric, focal or obstructive hypertrophy, Sx: initially asx, then chf develop as degree of obstruction worsens, also syncope or sudden death from spontaneous VT; PE: CHF findings, systolic murmur if obstructive which gets louder w/decreased preload)
        • Mitral stenosis (Etiology: overall, very uncommon in US; related to rheumatic heart dz or congenital sx, can have regurg as well; Sx: asx initially, then CHF as progresses, worse if superimposed SVT, characteristic diastolic murmur, other findings CHF)
        • Pulmonary vein stenosis (Etiology: complication of ablation procedure for a fib)
    • Tamponade
        • Etiology: pericarditis from: cardiac surgery, infection→ viral, bacterial or TB; cancer related, metabolic d/c→ hypothyroid/renal failure, automimmune d/o, XRT assoc; med related, idiopathic, traumatic; Sx: doe, sob, cp, edema; PE: elevated jvp, soft heart sounds, elevated hr, low bp, pulsus paradoxus→ > 10 point drop in SBP w/inspiration, papated pulse volume can also vary w/respiration
      • Rapid accumulation of fluid (Sx: rapid development of sob, doe, chest pain, other CHF-type sx, clinical decompensation)
      • Slow accumulation of fluid (Sx: better tolderated, slower development of sob, doe, feeling non-specifically poorly, chf-type sx)
    • Constrictive Pericardial Dz
      • Pericarditis for any reason that leads to scarring and loss of pericardial elasticitiy (Sx: chronic/progressive sob, doe, other CHF-type sx, feeling poorly in general)
    • High Output HF
        • A-V fistula (Etiology: trauma, inflamation or surgery induced PE: might hear bruit over site)
        • Hyperthyroidism (Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, wt loss, weakness; PE: sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid, hyper-reflexia)
        • Anemia
        • Thiamine deficiency (Etiology: ETOH abuse Sx/PE: confusion, extremity numbness/difficulty walking)
        • Paget's disease (Rf: > 50 Sx: slowly progressive multi-site bone pain, leg bowing)
    • Rhythm Related
        • Too Fast: acute SVT (Sx: rapid heart rate, palpatations, doe)
        • Too slow: bradycardia (Sx: fatigue, decreased exercise tolerance, CHF symptoms)

      Hydrostatic: Right sided HF

      • Secondary to L sided HF
      • Pulmonary Emboli (RFs for dvt/pulm embolous→ immobility, trauma, hypercoaguable state; Sx: acute or subactue if recurrent events, cough, SOB, pleuritic cp, hemoptysis; PE: unexplained unliateral edema; Well's Criteria for DVT; Well's Criteria for PE)
      • Pulmonary HTN
        • Idiopathic pulmonary htn (Rfs: women > men Sx: vague chest pain, subacute sob worse w/activity, dizziness with activity; PE: elevated jvp, edema, right ventricular heave, loud p2, rapid heart rate)
        • Other causes of pulmonary htn (Etiology: sleep apnea, chf, chronic pulmonary emboli, HIV, connective tissue d/o if hx scleroderma or rheum arthritis; congenital heart disease)
      • R sided valvular heart dz
        • Primary Pulmonary stenosis or regurg → almost always congenital
        • Tricuspid regurg: Secondary process (Etiology: from L sided CHF, Pulm htn, etc)
        • Tricuspid regurg: Primary valvular abnl (Etiology: endocarditis; direct damage from trauma; assoc w/carcinoid)
        • Tricuspid stenosis (Etiology: very uncommon → congenital, tumor, carinoid)

      Hydrostatic: Portal Htn

      Etiology: prehepatic, hepatic and post hepatic; Rfs: hepatic inflam/fibrosis→ known liver disease from viral/etoh/other chronic hepatitis→ cirrhosis; Sx: abdominal swelling, sob PE: ascites, jaundice, icterus

      Hydrostatic: Venous Insufficiency

      Sx: chronic, better in AM, worse after standing/end of day, scaly and sometimes itchy; PE: bilateral, chronic bluish discoloration

      Hydrostatic: Immobility or Paralysis

      Lack of muscular pumping action, in particular if coupled w/dependent positioning of legs

      Hydrostatic: B DVT or IVC Obstruction

      Rfs/Etiology: uncommmon c/w unilateral; associated w/significant hypercoaguability

      Lymphatic Obstruction

      • Lymphatic injury (Etiology: lymph node dissection, trauma; PE Lymph edema, doughy, non-pitting)
      • Obstructing cancer
      • Idiopathic, prior bacterial infections, prior parasitic infection, obesity

      Low Oncotic Pressure

      • Advanced liver disease (Sx/Etiology: known liver disease from viral/etoh/other chronic hepatitis; w/decreased synthetic fxn and low albumin; Sx: lower extremity edema along w/ascites and other findings chronic liver dz; PE: leg edema, ascites, jaundice, icterus)
      • Malnutrition (Etiology: lack of access to calories, disadvantaged socio-economic status; resulting in low albumin; Sx: weakness, fatigue PE: muscle wasting→ temporal area in particular, )
      • Malabsorption w/in GI tract assoc w/chronic diarrhea - e.g. pancreatic insufficiency, short gut syndrome, Whipple's dz, other
      • Severe anemia - as hgb contributes to oncotic pressure of blood
      • Nephrotic Syndrome→ profound loss of protein in urine→ > 3.5g protein/d; also assoc w/decline in GFR, htn, hyperlipidemia & hypercoag; sometimes urine is frothy
        • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (Etiology: Primary FSGS→ most common cause idiopathic nephrotic syndrome→ 30-50% of cases, particularly common in black adults; Secondary FSGS→ Hiv, obesity, heroin, other; primary or secondary can progress to ESRD; Sx: edema, other can be related to primary process; PE: htn, edema)
        • Membranous nephropathy (Etiology/Rfs: accounts for ~30% of nephrotic syndrome in adults; age > 50; idiopathic though assoc w/Hep B or C, SLE, meds, malignancy; Sx: volume overload; PE: HTN, peripheral edema, sometimes periorbial and hand edema)
        • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (Etiology/Rfs: accounts for ~25-30% of neprhotic syndrome; mixed neprhritic/neprhrotic picture; assoc w/hep c, sbe/other systemic infxn, cancer, lupus, cryoglobulinemias, other: Sx: sometimes related to other/primary d/o; volume overload; PE: volume overalod, htn)
        • Minimal change glomerulopathy (Etiology: acounts for 70-90% of Nephrotic syndrome in kids; 10-15% in adults; idiopathic though assoc w/meds (lithium, nsaids), infxn (mono); malignancies (lymphoma); Sx: volume overload; PE: HTN, peripheral edema, sometimes periorbial and hand edema)
        • Diabetes (Etiology/Rfs: nephropathy secondary to chronic, poorly controled DM w/resultant glomerular disease; most common cause of nephropathy; assoc w/progression esrd; Sx: asssoc w/long standing DM including peripheral neurop, retinopathy, pad, cad; PE: htn, proliferative retinop, peripheral neurop, diminished pulses, lower extremity edema)
        • Other systemic disease that cause nephropathy: amyloidosis, multiple myeloma, HIV, hepatitis B

      General Volume Overload

      • Cirrhosis (Sx/PE assoc w/chronic liver dz→ hep C, ETOH)
      • Renal failure

      Inflammatory/Other

      • Bilateral cellulitis (Etiology: uncommon c/w unilateral; Sx: acute, red, fever, sometimes skin break as portal; PE: red and edematous)
      • Meds - in particular dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers
      • Hypothyroidism (Sx: wt gain, edema, dry skin, constipation, cold intolerance, depression/mood change, weakness, fatigue; PE: often no findings aside from wt gain, sometimes decreased reflexes, edema, bradycardia)

      Unilateral Edema

      Inflammatory

      • Cellulitis (Sx: acute redness, pain, fever; PE: red, tender, focal edema)
      • Necrotizing fasciitis (Etiology: relatively uncommon; assoc w/dm, impaired immunity or perfusion; typically polymicrobial: strep, staph, clostridium, other; Sx: acute pain, swelling, fever, toxic appearing, often rapidly progressive; PE: typically abnl vs consistent w/severe illness, skin findings sometimes subtle→ redness, bulla; more profound findings as dz progresses)
      • Diabetic muscular infarct (Etiology: related to small vessel infarct in leg → typically patient w/DM; Sx: acute pain, swelling; PE: non-specific→ may have redness; )
      • Trauma→ compartment syndrome (Etiology: significant LE trauma/crush injury → in partic to lower leg; Sx/PE: severe pain, swelling, numbness, weakness, decreased pulses)
      • Pyomyositis (Etiology: related to deep muscle infection w/seeding from direct trauma/injury or bacteremia; relatively uncommon, affecting compromised hosts→ DM, HIV; Sx: acute pain, swelling, fevers/systemic illness)
      • Gout or pseudogout (Sx: sometimes inflammation in foot or ankle can be so intense that diffuse edema develops; may have hx gout or pseudogout prior; PE: pain, warmth, redness, edema, decreased range of motion of involved joint)
      • Joint infection (Etiology:trauma w/direct path of infection into joint, or systemic seeding; Sx: infection w/in joint of foot or ankle can be so intense that causes diffuse edema; also fever and systemic sx; PE: fever, redness, edema, focused over dominantly affected joint, pain worse w/any movement)

      Hydrostatic

      • DVT (RFs: hypercoaguable state, immobility, trauma; Sx: acute swelling, localized discomfort; PE: unilateral edema otherwise unexplained, Well's Criteria to quantify liklihood)
      • Lymphatic obstruction
        • Lymphatic injury (Etiology: lymph node dissection, trauma; PE: Lymph edema, doughy, non-pitting)
        • Obstructing cancer (Sx: may relate to primary malignancy; PE: may have palpable inguinal nodes, Lymph edema, doughy, non-pitting)
        • Idiopathic, prior bacterial infections, prior parasitic infection, obesity
      • Massive DVT (phlegmasia cerulea dolens) (Etiology: unusual, massive proximal dvt, assoc w/hypercoag state; Sx: acute welling, pain, evidence arterial insufficiency/ischemia secondary to increased tissue pressure; PE: marked asymmetric edema, diminished pulses, delayed capillary refill, cool, dusky/bluish skin appearance)
      • Venous insufficiency (Etiology: sometimes hx saphenous vein harvest w/CABG or DVT; Sx: chronic edema, worse after standing, better in morning after lying; PE: chronic edema, dark/bluish skin discoloration))

      Ruptured Baker's cyst

        Sx: asx aside from edema, presence of cyst behind knee often not known prior

      Syncope or Pre-syncope?

      Determining etiology of a syncopal event challenging as often unwitnessed and hx vague

      Cardiovascular

      Cardiogenic syncope has high morbidity/mortality. Increased risk if hx: smoking, diabetes, early family history, male, age >~ 50, HTN, hyperlipidemia. Also increased liklihood if known cad, cardiomyopathy, depressed EF for any reason, vascular dz elsewhere. Findings suggestive of c/v syncope: facial lacerations, fx, other injury suggesting true & sudden LOC→ fall w/o protecting head. These findings suggest sudden decreased cerebral perfusion→ Etiologies of low BP.
        Sudden drop in BP→ decrease in cerebral perfusion; BP= COxSVR = HRxSVxSVR = HRxPLxInoxSVR (HR=Heart rate, SV=Stroke Volume, PL=Pre-Load, Ino=Inotropy, SVR=System Vasc Resist)
      Categories of C/V syncope:
    • Decreased Inotropy
      • Severe LV systolic dysfunction (Etiology: CAD w/known MIs, known or newly dx cardiomyopathy; impaired LVs are also the substrate for VT→ see below; PE: lower extremity edema , + S3, elevated jvp, displaced pmi, rales on lung exam)
      • Aortic stenosis (Etiology: age 30-50→ bicuspid; age >60→ senile calcific; Sx: takes years to become severe→ other sx of doe, sob progressive over years; PE: characteristic sytolic murmur, crescendo-decrescendo, later peaking→ more severe)
      • Sub-Aortic Stenosis (Sx: takes years to become severe, typically younger patients PE: characteristic murmur, louder w/less pre-load
    • Decreased pre-load
      • Hypovolemia for any reason (Etiology: bleeding, diarrhea, severe N/V; Sx provoked by standing, or present at baseline if volume loss severe; PE: elevated hr, low bp, +orthostatic vital sign changes)
      • Anemia for whatever reason (Etiology: in particular if occurs rapidly as w/blood loss→ hypovolemia)
      • Sudden hypoxemia for whatever reason (Etiology: such that blood reaching brain is O2 poor)
      • Other acute disruption in return of blood to heart (Etiology: tension pneumothroax, acute tamponade, pulmonary embolism, etc→ characteristic hx for each)
    • Bradycardia
        • Sx: fatigue, decrease exercise tolerance, CHF; if abrupt onset, then no antecedent sx
      • Primary conduction system problem → sick sinus syndrome, complete or high grade 2nd or 3rd degree AV nodal block
      • Secondary bradycardia (Etiology/Sx: ischemia→ assoc w/CP, exercise induced, known CAD; meds→ beta blockers, non-dihydro ccbs; hypoxemia for any reason)
    • Supraventricular tachycardia
      • SVT - a fib, a flutter, avnrt, WPW (Sx: rapid/irreg heart beat, palpatations; don't typically cause true syncope but rather light headedness and palpatation; syncope if also impaired LV fxn or hypovolemia)
    • Ventricular tach or V Fib
        • Highest risk for morbid/mortality:
      • Ventricular Tachycardia (VT) - Ischemic (Etiology: occurs in the setting of MI, assoc w/ischemic sx of chest pain, sob, diaphoresis; patient's w/CAD RFs
      • VT - Acquired structural heart abnormality (Etiology: in US, most typically from prior MI → depressed LV fxn, could also be from cardiomyopathy of other Etiology→ idiopathic, tox/met, viral, etc)
      • VT - Congenital or other structural heart dz (Etiology: RV dysplasia, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, dilated cardiomyopathy, or infiltrative dz→ amyloidosis, sarcoid)
      • VT - Congenital or other acquired pre-disposition (Etiology: long QT syndrome → congenital variant presents in younger patients, can have family hx sudden death; acquired long QT assoc w/many meds; also hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypocalcemia; Brugada syndrome, etc)
      • Ventricular fibrillation (Etiology/Sx: abrupt onset; can occur primarily→ w/acute MI or degeneration from VT; leads to death unless immediate defibrillation/cpr; occurs most commonly in those w/predisposition for VT→ see above)
    • Problems of low SVR
        • Problems of low SVR - Sx exacerbated by moving from lying/sitting to standing→ +orthostatic vital sign changes
      • Meds→ alpha blocking agents, other
      • Acquired conditions that lower SVR (sepsis, adrenal insufficiency, other - hx should be suggestive)
      • Anaphylaxis (Etiology: systemic response to a precipitant, including: meds, food, latex, insect bite/stings, other environmental triggers; Sx: acute, sob, doe, ill feeling, syncope/pre-syncope, n, v, abd pain, swelling, itching, angioedema, can be life threatening; PE: ill appearing, low bp/elevated hr, stridor, wheezing, hives, edema and redness of face and/or extremities)
      Recognize that combinations of above can contribute to sudden hypoperfusion - eg. mod AS + sudden volume loss from bleeding→ syncope

      Neurological

      • Neurocardiogenic/Vaso-vagal: inappropriate bradycardia and/or loss of periperhal tone (Etiology: provoked by fear, anxiety, pain prolonged standing, carotid stimulation, urination, cough; Rfs: often younger, low risk for c/v dz; Sx: feel suddenly sweaty, lightheaded/weak, blurry vision, warm prior to event; tends to recur in similar situations; recovery is usually rapid; sx may also abate if sit and/or lie down)
        • Situational→ assoc w/coughing, urination, defecation, pain, fear/anxiety/stressful events, prolonged standing
        • Cartoid hypersensitivity→ uncommon; sx provoked by pressue on carotid body in neck
      • Orthostatic hypotension from autonomic dysfxn (Etiology: failure to raise HR or peripheral tone w/standing, can be from long standing neuropathy from DM/other metabolic, intrinsic autonomic dz→ multi-system atrophy; Sx: more likely presyncope than syncope, recurrent/chronic w/positional changes; PE: impaired distal sensation, orthostatic blood pressure changes)
      • Multi-system atrophy (Rfs: age 50-60; Etiology: rare neurodegenerative d/o; progresses over 6-10 years; Sx: variability in presentaiton; initially autonomic dysfxn including orthostatic hypotension, if severe→ syncope/presyncope; urge incontinence, erectile dysfunction, other sexual dyxfxn; then parkisnonian features of slow movements, falls, rigidity, often aysmetric tremor, dysphonia dystonias; cerebellar dysfnx w/ataxia and dyscoordination; depression and anxiety; sob from stridor; PE: orhtostatic VS, abnormal posture, abnormal gait, cerebellar dysfxn→ action tremor, coordination problems, ataxic/wide-based gait, nystagumus)
      • Cerebral vascular disease affecting vertebral-basilar system (Etiology: vascular risk factors; Sx: in territory supplied by v-b system: sudden dizziness, double vision, swallowing/speech problems, nausea, vomiting)
      • Seizure d/o (Etiology: more likely if: known seizure d/o, known structural brain dz, Sx: witnessed szr w/post-ictal state, incontinence, tongue biting, injury from not protecting self if fall)
      • Acute intracranial process → blood, tumor, trauma

      Other

      • Hypoglycemia (Etiology: over treated dm, adrenal insuff, liver failure; Sx: sweaty, irritable, resolves w/glucose admin)
      • Drug overdose, e.g. heroin
      • Psychiatric d/o (Etiology: anxiety, panic, somatization - on detailed questioning, may not in fact have had true syncope - or claimed but not witnessed)

      Palpatations?

      Challenges: Patient frequently doesn't have sx at time presents to M.D.; includes range of sx including extra beats, extra awareness of particular beats, racing sensation, other.
      • Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) (Sx: transient or persistent sense of elevated heart rate or palpatations; some patients more bothered than others→ based on rate, chronicity, LV fxn, expected level of activity; range from palpatations to SOB to DOE to presyncope/syncope)
        • Atrial fibrillation (Etiology: HTN, ETOH abuse or w/drawl, stimulant abuse→ cocaine, systemic illness→ acute PE, CHF, pericarditis, valvular heart dz, systemic infxn, COPD exacerbation, hypoxemia, anemia, post-op; hyperthyroidism, sleep apnea; risk of stroke over 1y can be assessed w/CHADS2-VASc score, risk of bleeding w/HAS BLED score; PE: irreg irreg rhythm, rate varies based on a-v nodal conduction)
        • Atrial flutter (Etiology: HTN, ETOH abuse or w/drawl, stimulant abuse→ cocaine, systemic illness→ acute PE, CHF, pericarditis, valvular heart dz, systemic infxn, COPD exacerbation, hypoxemia, anemia, post-op; hyperthyroidism, sleep apnea; PE: can be regular, rate varies based on a-v nodal conduction)
        • A-V nodal re-entrant tachycardia (avnrt) (Etiology: idiopathic, PE: fast & regular)
        • Multi-focal atrial tachycardia (Etiology: most commonly assoc w/lung dz e.g. COPD PE: fast and irregular)
        • By-pass tract → WPW (RF/Etiology: idiopathic; can present in teens or older; PE can have very rapid rates)
      • Premature ventricular contractions (pvc) (Sx: awareness of extra beat, early beat, strong beat, often followed by a compensatory pause; no sob, no cp, no chf sx, no presyncope/syncope)
      • Premature atrial contractions (pac) (Sx: awareness of extra beat, early beat, strong beat; no sob, no cp, no chf sx, no presyncope/syncope)
      • Ventric tachycardia (vt) (Sx: red flags: syncope/presyncope, abrupt onset that results in fall w/injury, Hx CAD, Hx CHF)
      • Acute physiologic response (Etiology: fever, pain, hypovolemia, stress, hypoxemia from any cause, anemia, pulmonary embolism, etc)
      • Panic/anxiety d/o (Sx: anxiety, panic, depression, terror, multi-system concerns w/o organic disease)
      • Meds/toxins (Etiology: cocaine, caffeine, cigarettes, sympathomimetics, b-agonist inhalers, serotonin agents → aggitated delirium, neuromuscular hyperactivity, other)
      • Sudden Withdrawal of Meds/toxins (Etiology: abrupt cessation of beta-blockers or clonidine; ETOH or benzo cessation)
      • Other metabolic d/o
        • Hyperthyroidism (Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, wt loss, weakness, infetility, ED, menstrual irreg; PE: sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid, hyper-reflexia, moist skin)
        • Hypoglycemia (Sx: known DM & Rx w/meds, sweaty, irritable, resolves w/glucose admin)
        • Pheochromocytoma (Etiology: inappropriate secretion of epi/norepi from adrenal medulla; rare; Sx: assoc w/findings related to abrupt, paroxysmal increase in sympathetic d/c; rarely causes cardiomyopathy; PE: elevated HR, BP, headache, sweating)

      Calf or leg pain w/ambulation (claudication)?

      Lower extremity exam
      • Peripheral Arterial Disease: associated with typical vascular dz risk factors
        • Subacute/chronic (Etiology: from progressive athero; Sx: calf cramps/pain, worse w/activity, better w/rest, PE: feet progressively cool to touch, pale, hairless, diminished cap refill, ulcers, cool)
        • Acute (Etiology/Sx: sudden pain from abrupt arterial occlusion; emboli from a fib w/o warfarin, or ventricular thrombus if severe lv dysfxn; recent catheterization where plaque disrupted from aorta; thrombosis in situ; PE: pale, diminished pulses if proximal occulsion, blue/hypoperfused toes w/distal emboli, cool)
      • Spinal stenosis (Sx: chronic pain, radiates down back both legs, worse w/walking, better leaning forward)
      • Cramps - often non-specific (Etiology: hypokalemia, dehydration, hypocalcemia, idiopathic)

      Non-healing leg ulcers or wounds?

      Lower extremity exam
      • Peripheral Arterial Disease - PAD (Etiology: C/V RFs; Sx: progressive, better w/rest, better w/dangling legs, worse w/leg elevation; PE: lost of pulses, decreased cap refill, feet cool to touch, sometimes shallow ulcers first, deep ulcers/infxn/gangrene if advanced)
      • Diabetes (Etiology: a leading cause of PAD & neuropathy→ dual contributors to ulcers, visual impairment limits ability to identify early; PE: ulcers often at bottom of foot/places that are hard to see, can progress w/minimal pain, common cause of ostomyelitis, diminshed sensation on exam, often decreased pulses/findings of arterial insuffic as well)
      • Venous insufficiency ulcers (Sx: chronic swelling, worse at end of day; PE: chronic edema, dark discoloration of skin, ulcer w/prdilection for medial ankle)
      • Peripheral neuropathy for any reason (Sx: chronic numbness→ can lead to wounds that go unnoticed and grow; PE: neuropathic ulcer, which is often painless
      • Trauma
      • Infection (Etiology: staph or strep for typical single organism; polymycrobial and pseudomonas if DM; RFs: PAD, trauma/devitizilized tissue, DM, osteomyelitis or foreign body; Sx: redness, d/c, fever)
      • Compromised healing from: poor nutiritional state, chronic advanced illness (kidney, liver, hiv), meds (prednisone, chemotherapy)
      • Cancer
        • Basal cell cancer (Rfs: chronic sun exposure, fair skin, prior bcc, immuncompromised; Sx: Non-healing, ulcerated, bleeding on a sun exposed region PE: telangiectasias, pearly w/rolled edges, growing, non-healing, central depression)
        • Squamous cell cancer (Rfs: chronic sun exposure, fair skin, prior scc, immuncompromised; Sx: Non-healing, ulcerated, bleeding on a sun exposed region PE:non-healing, growing, crusted, firm, sun exposed areas)
        • Melanoma (Rfs: fair skin, fair hair, prior melanoma, dysplastic moles, family hx, hx blistering sun burns, immunocompromised; Sx/PE: asymmetric, bleeds, irregular borders, non-homogeneous pigment, grows, doesn't heal, reginal adenopathy if spread, sx related to mets to brain, lung, liver)
      • Vasculitis - relatively uncommon cause - Small or medium vessels
        • Buerger's Dz (thromboangiitis obliterans) (Sx: smoker, non-healing, painful ulcers of hands, feet; PE: progressive ulcers, can become gangresnous)
        • Pyoderma gangrenosa (Sx/Rfs: wounds associated w/IBD, cancer; wounds grow in unusual places and w/o clear explanation; non-responsive to typical wound care; PE: can be beefy red, sometimes surrounding erythema, sometimes eschar)
        • Polyarteritis Nodosa (Etiology: medium-vessel vasculitis; Rfs: 40s-50s, men>women, Hep B/C; Sx: more commonly subacute over mos f, s, malaise, wt loss, muscle/joint pain; multiple systems: arthritis, glomerulonephritis, peripheral nerve pain/dysfxn, abd pain; PE: skin w/ulcers, small, palapable purpura→ don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; abd pain, blood per rectum)
        • Medication or toxin induced (Rfs: levimasole→ used to cut cocaine; Sx: acute, painful distal extremities, in particular→ fingers, ears, nose; PE: decreased cap refill distally, swelling, pain, distal necrosis)
        • Granulomatosis with poyangiitis (GPA) (Etiology: small vessel vasculitis; Sx: fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, sweats, wt loss; recurrent/progressive nasal congestion, cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; skin ulcers; PE: mucosal erythema, ulcer, nasal septum perf, palpable purpura, skin ulcer/necrosis)
        • Microscopic polyangitis (MPA) (Etiology: small vessel vasculitis; Sx: fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, sweats, wt loss; recurrent/progressive cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; less often nasal sx c/w GPA; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; skin ulcers; neuropathy; PE: palpable purpura, skin ulcer/necrosis)
        • Cryogloblulinemia (Etiology: small-vessel vasculitis caused by antigen-antibody complex deposition; Type I monoclonal→ IgM or IgG, related to lymphoprolif d/o→ lymphoma, myeloma; Type II and III, mixed cryos IgM and IgG; related to Hep C (most common), SLE, RA, lymphoma, myeloma, hiv, hep b, other autoimmune; RFs: female > male, ages 40-50; Sx: subacute fatigue, weakness, muscle and joint aches, cough/sob if pulmonary involvement; confusion; symmetric or asymmetric often painful distal neuropathy, painful skin ulcers of extremities, purpuric papules; membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis; PE: palpable purpura of vasculitis, Raynauds, livedo reticularis, distal skin ulcers)
        • Other vasculitides - can be assoc w/cancer, other rheumatologic d/o

      More Info About Cardiovascular Disorders:
      National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute, Comprehensive cardiovascular exam

      Back

      Gastrointestinal

      Comprehensive GI exam

      Chronic or past GI disorders?

      • Ulcers, hepatitis, inflammatory bowel disease, cancer, irritable bowel syndrome, etc

      Heart burn/Sub-sternal pain?

      GI

      Esophageal related chest pain tends to be susternal, can radiate up toward mouth, squeezing quality, related to food.
      • GERD (Rfs: assoc w/obesity, ETOH, smoking, caffeine, chocolate, mint; Sx: chronic/recurrent burning type pain, often worse after meals, worse if lie down after eating, bad taste in mouth, radiates up from epigastrium)
      • Esophageal spasm (Sx: sudden onset, central squeezing pain, sometime related to food or GERD sx; can remit spont or w/nitro; vascular etiologies typically r'd/out first)
      • Esophagitis from infection (Etiology: viral, fungal; Rfs: sometimes immuncompromised→ HIV+, chemotherapy; recent exposure to abx; Sx: acute/sub-acute sub-sternal pain, pain worse w/swallowing; PE: hsv lesions or candida in mouth provide clue to what's affecting esophagus)
      • Pill induced esophagitis (Etiology: pain after ingesting pill not fully swallowed; Sx: acute sub-sternal cp, worse w/swallowing)
      • Esophageal perforation→ mediastinitis (Etiology: reason for perforation include: repeated retching→Boerhaves, biopsy/procedure w/perforation, toxic ingestion→ lye/drain cleaner, foreign body; Sx: pain is severe and acute, w/assoc swallowing probs, ill appearance)

      Cardiovascular D/O

      Increased likelihood if + C/V RFs: smoking, diabetes, early family history, male, age >~ 50, HTN, hyperlipidemia, known cad or vascular dz elsewhere

      Angina

      Central chest pressure secondary to coronary artery insufficiency; associated w/CV Rfs, sometimes radiates to L arm, L neck, back; PE: pale, sweaty, in pain, clutching chest
      • Stable angina (Sx: occurs after a predictable amount of work, never at rest, not progressive, resolves when stops activity)
      • Unstable angina (Sx: occurs at rest, progression or onset of symptoms such that occurring with less and less activity)
      • Myocardial infarction (Sx: acute chest pressure @ rest, can radiate to arm/neck back; often assoc n, v, sob, diaphoresis, feeling poorly; hx known cad or vascular RFs)
        • Plaque rupture (Etiology: abrupt vessel closure; Sx: sudden onset above sx→ ST elevation MI, NSTEMI or UNSA)
        • Demand ischemia (Etiology: sudden onset above sx, secondary to a physiologic stress applied to unchanged CAD; sources of stress include: tachycardia for any reason, incresaed catechols for any reason, anemia, hypoxemia, low BP, etc)

      Aortic Dissection or Aneurysm

      • Thoracic aorta dissection (Rfs: htn, dm, known atherosclerosis, smoking, hyperlipidemia, prior aneurysms, connective tissue dz; Sx: acute onset, tearing type CP, radiation to back, neck, to abd if dissection extends; stroke sx if involves carotids, sob if dissects to aortic valve/pericardium; angina if into coronaries; PE: sometimes asymetric pulse or bp, stroke if involves carotids, abd pain, arm/leg sx if decreased flow to limbs; loss or asymmetry of pulses)
      • Thoracic aorta aneurysm (Rfs: medial wall degeneration, Genetic→ Marfan's, other; Vasculitis→ Takayasus, GCA; post-aortic stenosis, dissection related; infection, trauma, htn, atherosclerosis; Sx: often asx or vague; cp, sob, upper back pain; compression of SVC, bronchi, or recurrent laryngeal n→ hoarseness; distal embolization; sudden collapse if rupture)

      Pericarditis

      Sx: sharp, acute, left sided chest pain, worse w/deep breath, worse lying down, better sitting up/leaning forward; PE: often pericardial friction rub present
    • Infection assoc
      • Viral most common→ coxsackievirus, influenza, other (Etiology: antecedent respiratory viral; coxsackie, influenza, other sx Sx: fever, cough, sweats)
      • TB or bacterial - less common c/w viral
      • Acute rheumatic fever (Sx: relatively uncommon, occurs 2-3w after strep pharyngitis, assoc w/fever, fatigue, acute/abrupt onset, migratory inflammatory arthritis of large joints typically; chest pain or sob related to pericarditis; long term risk of mitral or aortic valve dz; PE: affected joint(s) are warm, red, pain w/movement)
    • S/P MI, cardiac surgery, direct trauma
      • Post MI, can occur early or late
      • Post op from any cardiac surgery
    • Cancer or XRT related
      • Radiation involving mediastinum
      • Cancer metastatic or primarily involving mediastinal area - e.g. lung, breast, lymphoma, leukemia, melanoma
    • Metabolic d/o
      • Hypothyroidism (Sx: wt gain, edema, dry skin, constipation, cold intolerance, depression/mood change, weakness, fatigue; PE: often no findings aside from wt gain, sometimes decreased reflexes, edema, bradycardia)
      • Advanced kidney disease w/uremia
    • Connective tissue d/o related
      • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
      • Scleroderma (Rfs: age onset < 50, women > men; Sx: can be localized to skin or cause systemic dz; local disease causes focal skin thickening; greater involvement can include: GERD, skin tightening/thickened fingers, telangiectasias, raynauds→ finger hypoperfusion and pain in cold, calcium deposits in sub-cu; w/systemic sclerosis, wide spread dz affecting skin, lungs→ sob from pulm htn and interstitial lung dz; joints→ athralgias & myalgias,; kidneys→ scleroderma crisis; pericardium→ pericarditis; gi→ GERD; PE: raynauds → fingers blanch/hurt when exposed to cold temp, skin thickening/tightness)
      • Mixed connective tissue d/o (Etiology: rare d/o, cross over between lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis; Sx: fatigue, muscle and joint aches, finger pain after exposure to cold; PE: raynauds → fingers blanch/hurt when exposed to cold temp, sausage-type thickening of fingers, skin thickening/tightness)
      • RA (Rfs: women > men; age 30-55; Sx: subacute (>6w), persistent/progressive joint pain, worse in AM due to gelling→ improves w/use, fatigue, tendency for bilateral involvement, commonly small and medium sized joints; neuroapthic sx (pain or dysfxn); chest pain and SOB; PE: warmth, redness, spongy feeling from synovial inflam, pain w/squeezing of joints, effusion, abnormal appearing if longstanding, MCPs with chronic changes; extra articular findings: episcleritis, pleural/pericardial inflam, rheumatoid nodules) more from CDC
    • Medications
      • Hydralazine, procainamide, phenytoin, isoniazid, penicillins, others
    • Idiopathic
      • A common occurrence - often presumed post viral

      Primary Pulmonary D/O

      Pulmonary related CP tends to be w/inspiration (pleuritic), w/coughing, or associated w/sob
      • Pneumonia (Etiology: bacterial, viral, fungal, mycobacterial Sx: acute onset, cough, colored sputum production, fever, chest pain, cxr w/infiltrate; PE: rales, ronchi, wheezing or other findings on auscultation, dullness to percussion if pleural effusion or dense parenchymal involvement)
      • Cancer (Rfs: smoking and/or asbestos exposure; Sx: sub-acute, SOB, cough, wt loss, hemoptysis,)
      • Pulmonary emboli (RFs for dvt/pulm embolus→ immobility, trauma, hypercoagualbe state; Sx: acute or subacute if recurrent events, cough, SOB, pleuritic cp, hemoptysis; PE: unexplained unilateral edema; Well's Criteria for DVT; Well's Criteria for PE)
      • Pneumothorax (Sx: acute, SOB, pleuritic cp; PE: absent or diminished breath sounds, trachea deviated away if tension, crepitus if air dissects into sub-cu tissues)
        • Primary (Rfs: tall thin male, smoker)
        • Secondary (Rfs: trauma, chronic infection extending to pleura→ hiv, severe copd)

      MSK or Trauma

      • Muscle/bone/soft tissue injury/strain (Etiology: recent overuse, recent trauma, onset pain linked temporally Sx: worse w/movement or use; PE: provocative testing clearly reproduces sx)
      • Cancer met to ribs/sternum (Rfs: cancer that mets to bone→ e.g. lung, prostate, breast, etc; Sx: progressive, unremitting bone pain; PE: pain on palpation over involved area, findings assoc w/primary cancer)
      • Infection or other inflammatory process involving bones/soft tissue (Rfs: direct extension of infection or spread systemically; Sx: progressive pain, fever, chills; PE: fever, pain and inflammatory findings over affected areas)

      Neuropathic

      Neuropathic pain from zoster (Sx: burning, localized to dermatome, vesicular rash several days after pain onset; PE: dermatomal, vessicular erruption over chest area)

      Anxiety/panic disorder

      Initial eval directed towards ruling out physiologic etiology→ cardio, pulm, GI, other process w/sig morbidity/mortality
      • Panic d/o (Sx: sudden, repeated and unfounded attacks of fear; feeling out of control when attacks occur, focus on when next episode will occur, avoidance of places where anxiety attacks have occured in past, palpatations, sweating, sob, dizziness, numbness, chest/abdominal pain, etc)

      Acute RUQ or Epigastric Pain

      Stomach & esophagus

      • Ulcer - gastric or duodenal (Etiology: ETOH, h pylori, nsaid use; Sx: epigastric, acute or chronic; better or worse w/food, black stools)
      • Gastritis (Etiology: stress, ETOH, NSAIDs, h pylori; Sx: acute or chronic, epigastric pain, black stools, better or worse w/food)
      • Esophageal perforation (Sx/Etiology: severe acute chest or epigastric pain; must have reason for perforation include: repeated retching→Boerhaves, biopsy/procedure w/perforation, toxic ingestion→ lye/drain cleaner, foreign body; pain is severe, w/assoc swallowing probs, ill appearance)
      • Stomach perforation (Etiology: ulcer; less commonly cancer, foreign body; Sx: pain starts epigastic or local to affected bowel, then becomes generalized; n, v, f, sepsis)
      • Gastric cancer (Sx: typically sub-acute & progressive; epigastric area pain, anorexia, weight loss, persistent/progressive, n, v, early satiety)
      • Esophageal cancer (Sx: typically sub-acute and progressive swallowing probs more than pain, food gets stuck, may vomit to relieve obstruction, worse w/solids then liquids, pain, patient can often point to level of obstruction)

      Hepatobiliary

      • Hepatitis - Viral
        • A (acute) (Etiology/Rfs: spread fecal/oral/ingestion contaminated food, can be epidemic, incubation 2-4w; Sx: n, v, RUQ abd pain, puritis, dark urine, light colored stool, f, jaundice, icterus; sx generally resolve w/in 2-4w; PE: jaundice, icterus, RUQ pain, hepatomegaly)
        • B (acute) (RFs: spread via sexual contact, vertical, shared needles, needle sticks in health care workers, unscreened blood transfusion; Sx: many are asx; incuabtaion is 1-4m; acute infxn assoc w/n, v, jaundice; puritus, icterus, dark urine, light colored stool, malaise; typcially self limited, w/resoln sx 2-3m; 5% go on to chronic infxn, w/risk cirrhosis, spread to others, and hcc; PE: jaundice, icterus, RUQ pain, hepatomegaly)
        • C (rare cause of acute hep) (RFs: spread via needles, unscreened blood transfusion, cocaine inhaling tools, needle sticks in health care workers, vertical, sexual; 10-20% resolve spontaneously; long term risk cirrhosis and HCC w/chronic infxn; Sx: most w/acute hep C are asx; those w/sx have RUQ pain, f, malaiae, jaudice; PE: most have no findings in acute phase)
        • Hepatitis D (RFs: occurs as a co-infection w/hep b, uncommon in west, found in Mediterranean and Asian countries; spread via same mechanisms as hep b)
        • Hepatitis E (RFs: uncommon in western nations, though most common cause of acute hep in developing world, can be sporadic or epidemic, water born w/spread similar to hep a; Sx: incubation 3-8w, sx of malaise, n, jaundice x ~ 2w; usually self limited, rarely fulminant, rarely chronic)
          • More on viral hepatitis from CDC
        • CMV (Rfs; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; systemic infxn in HIV or otherwise compromised; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w, fatigue x 4-6w; Sx: f, c, malaise, RUQ pain; PE: epgiastric/RUQ pain, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC
        • EBV→ mononucleosis (Sx: incubation 4-6w, prodrome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias; then f, sore throat; PE: head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly) more from CDC
        • Herpes simplex (Etiology: disseminated HSV; Rfs: immunocompromised; Sx: abd pain, n, v, fever; sometimes typical skin lesions oral/genital; PE: sometimes vessicular lesions oral or genital regions)
        • Herpes zoster (Sx: burning type pain over RUQ area for several days prior to skin erruption; PE: dermatomal, vessicular erruption over abdominal dermatome)
      • Acute alcoholic hepatitis (Etiology: ongoing ingestion, superimposed on chronic liver dz; Sx: Acute RUQ pain, n, v, RUQ pain, jaundice, encephalopathy; PE: RUQ pain, jaundice, icterus, ascites, confusion)
      • Hepatitis: Toxins/Meds - prescribed or OD (Etiology: acetaminophen, INH, other)
      • Hepatitis: Autoimmune (Rfs: assoc w/IBD, RA, SLE, DM1; Sx: acute/sub-acute/chronic, fatigue, n, v, decreased appetite)
      • Hepatitis: Ischemic (Etiology: acutely ill, prolonged hypotension, atherosclerosis)
      • Acute Wilson's Dz (Rfs: age 20-40; Sx: jaundice, confusion, tremor, other neuro; sometimes autoimmune hemolysis accompanies; PE: jaundice, icterus, weakness, numbness, decreased coordination)
      • Liver abscess(Etiology: secondary to biliary obstruction complicated by infection; seeding from systemic bacteremia; also from parasites→ echinococcus, amebiasis; Sx: right upper quadrant pain, f, c)
      • Biliary colic (Etiology: gall stones; Sx: right upper quadrant pain, can radiate to back, often after meals, when present→ constant then abates spont, hx gall stones)
      • Choledocolithiasis (Sx: right upper quadrant pain, often after meals, when present→ constant then abates spont, hx gall stones; can cause jaudnice w/o other sx)
      • Cholecystitis (Etiology: obstructing gall stone; Sx: constant right/upper abd pain, can radiate to back, fever, nausea, hx gall stones; PE: pain in RUQ; palpating hand positioned below liver→ patient inspires→ pain increases when inflamed gall bladder contacts hand)
      • Cholangitis (Etiology: obstructed common bile duct from stone, cancer, stricture, other; Sx: right/upper abd pain, fever, nausea, jaundice, hx gall stones, often severe illness)
      • Liver cancer (Etiology: primary related to chronic hepatitis and cirrhosis; can also be mets; Sx: typically sub-acute, persistent/progressive RUQ area pain, anorexia, weight loss; PE: often firm, palapable liver; sometimes jaundice)
      • Biliary cancer (Sx: typically sub-acute persistent/progressive RUQ/epigastric pain, anorexia, weight loss, jaundice, ictreus, light colored stools; PE: jaundice, icterus, palpable gall bladder, firm liver if mets)

      Pancreatic

      • Pancreatitis (Etiology: ETOH abuse, gall stones, meds; less common anatomic→ divisum, post procedure, auto-immune, scorpion bites, trauma, hypertrigliceridemia; Sx: epigastric, constant, radiates to back, N, V; PE: epigastric pain on plapation)
      • Pancreatic pseudocyst (Etiology: assoc w/recurrent bouts of pancreatitis; Sx: epigastric pain, n, v→ similar to pancreatitis)
      • Pancreatic cancer (Etiology: typically primary to pancreas, can also be mets; Sx: typically subacute, progressive epigastric area pain, radiates to back, anorexia, weight loss, persistent/progressive, sometimes diarrhea; PE typically mass not present unless mets to liver; jaundice, icterus if biliary obstruction)

      Non-GI

      • MI (Sx: acute, N, V, SOB, CP, C/V RFs; PE: pale, sweaty, in pain, clutching chest)
      • Angina (Sx: activity induced discomfort, resolves w/rest, CP, C/V RFs)
      • Pneumonia (Sx: acute, sob, cough, colored sputum, fever, CP)
      • Herpes Zoster (Sx: acute vessicular erruption, pain a few days prior to skin lesions, neuropathic/burning type pain, PE: vessicles in a dermatomal distribution)
      • Pyelonephritis (Sx: typical sx low back/flank, sometimes perceived as towards LUQ or RUQ; fever, chills, dysuria, urinary freq; PE: f, +CVAT, pain on flank palpation)

      Acute LUQ Pain

      GI

      • Ulcers (Etiology: ETOH, h pylori, nsaid use; Sx: typically epigastric but can be towards LUQ, better or worse w/food, nsaid use, black stools, hematemesis)
      • Pancreatitis (Etiology: ETOH abuse, gall stones, meds; less common anatomic→ divisum, post procedure, auto-immune, scorpion bites, trauma; Sx: typically epigastric but can be towards LUQ, constant, radiates to back, n, v, ETOH abuse)
      • Pancreatic pseudocyst (Etiology: assoc w/recurrent bouts of pancreatitis; Sx: epigastric pain, n, v→ similar to pancreatitis; assoc w/recurrent bouts of pancreatitis)
      • Bowel/stomach perforation (Sx: acute, typically starts epigastic but can be towards LUQ→ then generalized; n, v, f, sepsis)

      Non-GI

      • Splenic Infarct (Sx/Rfs: acute, endocarditis or other source emboli; tumor that outgrows blood supply)
      • Splenic abscess (Sx/Rfs: pain, fever, endocarditis or other source infected emboli)
      • Sub-capsular splenic hematoma (Sx: acute, hx trauma affecting that area)
      • Leaking splenic art aneurysm (Etiology: uncommon, often aneurysm not known prior; Rfs: young, women > men; assoc w/preganancy; Sx: severe pain w/shock as lose blood)
      • Pneumonia (Sx: acute, sob, cough, sputum, fever, CP)
      • Herpes Zoster (Sx: acute vessicular erruption, pain a few days prior to skin lesions, neuropathic/burning type pain, PE: vessicles in a dermatomal distribution)
      • Pyelonephritis (Etiology: typically gnr, ascending from lower gu tract; Sx: typical sx low back/flank, sometimes perceived as towards LUQ or RUQ; fever, chills; dysuria, urinary freq if concomitant cystitis; PE: CVAT, pain on flank palpation)

      Acute Genl Pain

      Sometimes processes that typically cause generalized pain can be localized to the lower abdomen and vice versa

      GI

      Enteritis/Colitis

      • Bacterial enteritis (Etiology: salmonella, shigella, campy, yersinia, e coli 0157:H7; Sx: generalized crampy pain, acute, f, diarrhea, bloody stool, pain)
      • C dif colitis (Sx: generalized crampy abd pain, acute, diarrhea, blood in stool, cramps, fever, hx exposure to abx)
      • Viral gastroenteritis→ in particular Noro and Rota (Rfs: often epidemics; rota in particular amongst kids; Sx: generalized cramphy abd pain, acute n, v, diarrhea, fever)

      SB/LB Obstruction

      • Adhesions (Etiology/Rfs: hx prior abd surgery, hx intra-abd inflammatory process → infection, IBD; Sx: generalized abd, comes in waves, N, V, decreased flatus, abd distention; PE: distention, non-specific pain)
      • Cancer (Rfs: known cancer, no prior CRC screening; Sx: non-specific pain, wt loss, fatigue, other systemic sx, n, v, distension, decreased flatus; PE: distension, sometimes palpable mass, blood on rectal exam - occult or red if distal)
      • Hernia w/incarceration or strangulation (Rfs: prior surgery w/ventral hernia; inguinal or umbilical hernia; Sx: n, v, obvious trapped intestine/omentum thru fascial defect, distention, decreased flatus; PE: pain at site of incarceration, e.g: Umbo hernia)
      • Volvulous (Sx: geralized or LLQ→if involving sigmoid, n, v, decreased flatus)
      • Intussusception (Sx: generalized abd sx; acute, typically age < 2; in adults, bowel cancer can be lead point; n, v, distention, bloody mucous per rectum)

      Ileus/Other Motil d/o

      • Post laparotomy - after handling/manipulation intestines → resolves as patient recovers
      • Abdominal inflammatory process (Etiology: abscess, pancreatitis, other→ abates as primary process resolves
      • Ogilvie's Syndrome → colonic ileus secondary to infection/meds/'lyte disturbance/other problems (Sx: n, v, abd distension, decreased or absent passage gas/stool)

      Focal Bowel Infxn

      • Diverticulitis (Sx: left/lower abdomen, RLQ less commonly; fever, nausea)
      • Appendicitis (Sx: starts umbilicus → R lower quadrant, fever, nausea, anorexia; as w/peritonitis of any cause → patient lies still → movement increases pain)
      • Perforated viscous - stomach, small, gall bladder, appendix or large intestine (Sx: focal sx in that organ region→become generalized; from cancer, infection, ischemia, prolonged obstruction)

      Other Infxn/Inflam probs

      • Abscess (Etiology: contained collection from adjacent infection, perforated viscous, hematogenous seeding, other; Sx: f, c, focal pain over site abscess; PE: fever, focal pain, sometimes overlying induration, swelling)
      • Anastamotic leak (Sx: generalized abd sx, post-op, following operation w/bowel anastamosis)
      • Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis (Etiology: ascites, typically from advanced chronic liver disease; Sx: acute abd pain, confusion, fever, PE: generalized tenderness in patient with ascites)
      • Ulcerative colitis (Etiology: automimmune, genetic, environmentally triggered, other; affects colon, distal to prox; Rfs: Northen Europeans, North Americans; smoking and appendectomy protective; peak onset 15-30; Sx and PE: sub-acute, recurrent or chronic diarrhea; fatigue, wt loss, bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, nocturnal diarrhea, feeling poorly overall; spectrum from mild to severe; extra-GI: aphtous ulcers, erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosa, peripheral arthritis, ankylosing spond/sacroiliitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, eye sx→ episcleritis/scleritis/uveitis) More from CDC
      • Crohn's disease (Etiology: automimmune, genetic, environmentally triggered, other; transmural involvement; can affect anywhere in GI tract mouth-to-anus; Rfs: smoking and appendectomy increase risk; Northern Europeans and North Americans; peak onset 15-30; Sx: sub-acute, diarrhea→ though can be less prominent than w/UC, nocturnal diarrhea, sometimes bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, fever, abd pain, fatigue, wt loss, feeling poorly overall, fistulas, bowel obstruction, peri-rectal dz; spectrum of sx and findings; PE: sometimes abd mass; peri-rectal disease; extra-GI: aphtous ulcers, erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosa, peripheral arthritis, ankylosing spond/sacroiliitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, eye sx→ episcleritis/scleritis/uveitis) More from CDC

      Cancer

      • Sx/Etiology: more typically causes chronic sx - acute assoc w/obstruction→ LBO/SBO; capsular distention→ liver; infarct, perforation→ SB or LB

      Vascular

      • Acute mesenteric arterial ischemia (Rfs: Hx known atherosclerosis or Rfs, Rfs for embolic disease→ a fib, ventricular thrombus, acute low BP/low flow superimposed on atherosclerosis; Sx: progressive, severe generalized pain PE: few exam findings/pain out of proportion to findings; severe illness if progresses to necrosis)
      • Acute mesenteric venous ischemia (Etiology: less common than arterial ischemia; Rfs: hypercoaguable state→ factor 5 leiden defic, protein S/C/AT 3 defic, prothombin mutation, antiphoslipid antibody synd, parox noct hemoglobinuria; hx idipathic dvt/pe, malignancy, other inflam process; Sx: progressive, severe generalized pain; PE: few exam findings/pain out of proportion to findings; severe illness if progresses to necrosis)
      • Polyarteritis Nodosa (vasculitis) (Rfs: 40s-50s, men>women, Hep B/C; Sx: more commonly subacute over mos f, s, malaise, wt loss, muscle/joint pain; multiple systems: arthritis, glomerulonephritis, peripheral nerve pain/dysfxn, skin w/ulcers, small, palpable purpura→ don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; abd pain, blood per rectum)
      • Henoch-schoenlein purpura (vasculitis) (Sx: acute, n, v, sometimes bloody diarrhea, hematuria, renal impairment; PE: purpuric rash→ in partic abd, legs, buttocks; joint swelling and pain)
      • Colonic Ischemia (Rfs: known atherosclerosis or vascular risk factors, hypotension from other process superimposed on atherosclerosis, RFs for embolic events → a fib, ventricular thrombus; Sx: generalized abdominal pain, small amounts of bright red blood w/stool, diarrhea)
      • Abdominal aortic aneurysm (Rfs: known cardiovascular risk factors, in partic male, smoker, age > 60; Sx: upper abd/vague umbilical pain, radiating to back, profound hypotenision/other sx hypoperfusion if leaking/ruptured→ rapid demise if not identified/fixed)

      GU

      GU etiologies tend to have flank or low back pain, sometimes urinary sx as well.
      • Renal stones (Sx: acute colicky pain any where from flank→ groin, secondary to stone obstructing kidney or ureter; urinary frequency/urgency, hematuria, nausea, vomiting; patient cant sit still or find comfortable position)
      • Pyelonephritis (Sx:low back/flank pain on one side→ radiates toward lower abd; f, c, dysruia; PE; f, CVAT on exam)
      • Renal infarct (Sx: acute back/flank pain, n, v, hematuria; Etiology: source of emboli→ a fib, ventric thrombus; PE: very uncomfortable, pain on palpation)

      Other

      • DKA (Rfs: known DM, known poor control, acute other illness that is a precipitant; Sx: typically ill appearing, abnl vs, tachpneic)
      • Abd Wall (Etiology/Sx: injury, trauma, other; pain should localized to abd wall/superficial area)
      • Angioedema (Etiology: localized areas subcu swelling, response to a precipitant, including: meds, food, latex, insect bite/stings, other environmental triggers; Sx: acute, sob, edema, itching, abd pain; can be severe and life threatening due to airway issues; can occur w/anaphylactic rxns; PE: swelling of face & other body parts, redness, stridor, wheezing, hives/urticaria)
      • Herpes Zoster (Sx: burning type pain a few days prior to skin lesions, then acute vessicular erruption following a dermatome; PE: vessicles in a dermatomal distribution)
      • Sickle cell crisis (Rfs: known sickle cell dz, African-American descent; Sx: Acute generalized pain, can be precipitated by hypovolemia, hypoxemia or idiopathic)
      • Acute Intermitent Porphyria (Etiology: uncommon, inherited d/o; often triggered by starvation, etoh, smoking, infection, or meds; also cutaneous variants; Sx: episodic bouts of unexplained severe abd pain, agitation/confusion, n, v, limb pain, motor and sonsory neuropathy, seizure; PE: episodic htn, tachycardia, generalized muscle weakness, dark urine)
      • Familial Med Fevers (Rfs: Mediterranean descent→ Turkish, Jewish, Armenian, Arab, other; Sx: uncommon, associated w/cryptic abdominal pain, rash, arthritis, arthralgias, myalgias, recurrent fever)
      • Medications or toxins
        • Antibiotics, iron, glucophage etc (Sx: generalized, non-severe crmapy pain, sometimes diarrhea/constipation/flatus, onset times w/start of Rx)
        • Lead toxicity (Rfs: exposure via paint or work; Sx: abd pain, nausea, constipation, anemia, muscle and joint pain, confusion and cognitive problems, altered sense of tasted, peripheral motor neuropathy)

      Acute Lower Abd Pain

      Sometimes processes that typically cause lower abdominal pain can lead to more generalized abdominal symptoms and vice versa

      GI

      • Mechanical small or large bowel obstruction (Rfs: prior abd surgery, prior intra-abd infection; Sx: generalized abd, comes in waves, N, V, decreased flatus, abd distention)
      • Ventral hernia w/incarceration or strangulation (Sx/Etiology: n, v, obvious trapped intestine/omentum thru fascial defect, pain focused over site of problem; PE: pain and abnormality over area of fascial defect→ focused over umbillicus if umbo hernia)
      • Diverticulitis (Sx: left/lower abdomen, RLQ less commonly; fever, nausea, crampy abd pain, progressively worse over time; PE: pain in LLQ, can have focal peritoneal signs)
      • Appendicitis (Sx: starts umbilicus→ R lower quadrant, fever, nausea, anorexia, progressively worse over hours to days; w/peritoneal irritation, patient lies still→ movement increases pain; PE: pain over McBurneys point→ 1/3 from iliac crest to umbo; if peritonitis: shake tenderness, rebound, guarding, rigidity, + Rovsings→ pushing on LLQ and releasing causes RLQ pain; if retrocecal appendix→ psoas sign→ pain w/passive leg extension; if pelvic appendix→ obturator sign→ pain w/passive internal hip rotation)
      • Inguinal Hernia (Sx: inguinal area pain that's progressive/severe if incarcerated/strangulated; progressive sx, n, v, severe illness if unaddressed; PE: pain, swelling, sometimes inflammatory findings over inguinal canal)
      • Perforated viscous - appendix or large intestine (Etiology: cancer, infection, ischemia, prolonged obstruction; Sx: focal pain over affected area→ becomes generalized; PE: pain on palpation, peritorneal signs)
      • Volvulous (Sx: generalized or LLQ→ if involving sigmoid, n, v, decreased flatus; PE: pain and sometimes mass palpable over affected intestine)
      • Ulcerative colitis (Etiology: automimmune, genetic, environmentally triggered, other; affects colon, distal to prox; Rfs: Northen Europeans, North Americans; smoking and appendectomy protective; peak onset 15-30; Sx and PE: sub-acute, recurrent or chronic diarrhea; fatigue, wt loss, bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, nocturnal diarrhea, feeling poorly overall; spectrum from mild to severe; extra-GI: aphtous ulcers, erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosa, peripheral arthritis, ankylosing spond/sacroiliitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, eye sx→ episcleritis/scleritis/uveitis) More from CDC
      • Crohn's disease (Etiology: automimmune, genetic, environmentally triggered, other; transmural involvement; can affect anywhere in GI tract mouth-to-anus; Rfs: smoking and appendectomy increase risk; Northern Europeans and North Americans; peak onset 15-30; Sx: sub-acute, diarrhea→ though can be less prominent than w/UC, nocturnal diarrhea, sometimes bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, fever, abd pain, fatigue, wt loss, feeling poorly overall, fistulas, bowel obstruction, peri-rectal dz; spectrum of sx and findings; PE: sometimes abd mass; peri-rectal disease; extra-GI: aphtous ulcers, erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosa, peripheral arthritis, ankylosing spond/sacroiliitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, eye sx→ episcleritis/scleritis/uveitis) More from CDC
      • Cancer (Sx: more typically causes chronic sx - acute assoc w/obstruction→ LBO/SBO; capsular distention→ liver; infarct, perforation→SB or LB)

      Vascular

      • Acute mesenteric arterial ischemia (Rfs: Hx known atherosclerosis or Rfs, Rfs for embolic disease→ a fib, ventricular thrombus, acute low BP/low flow superimposed on atherosclerosis; Sx: progressive, severe generalized pain PE: few exam findings/pain out of proportion to findings; severe illness if progresses to necrosis)
      • Acute mesenteric venous ischemia (Etiology: less common than arterial ischemia; Rfs: hypercoaguable state→ factor 5 leiden defic, protein S/C/AT 3 defic, prothombin mutation, antiphoslipid antibody synd, parox noct hemoglobinuria; hx idipathic dvt/pe, malignancy, other inflam process; Sx: progressive, severe generalized pain; PE: few exam findings/pain out of proportion to findings; severe illness if progresses to necrosis)
      • Polyarteritis Nodosa (vasculitis) (Etiology: medium vessel vasculitis; Rfs: 40s-50s, men>women, Hep B/C; Sx: more commonly subacute over mos f, s, malaise, wt loss, muscle/joint pain; multiple systems: arthritis, glomerulonephritis, peripheral nerve pain/dysfxn, skin w/ulcers, small, palapable purpura→ don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; abd pain, blood per rectum)
      • Henoch-schoenlein purpura (vasculitis) (Etiology: small-vessel vasulitis; Sx: acute, n, v, sometimes bloody diarrhea, hematuria, renal impairment; PE: purpuric rash→ in partic abd, legs, buttocks; joint swelling and pain)
      • Colonic Ischemia (Rfs: known atherosclerosis or vascular risk factors, hypotension from other process superimposed on atherosclerosis, RFs for embolic events → a fib, ventricular thrombus; Sx: generalized abdominal pain, small amounts of bright red blood w/stool, diarrhea)
      • Abdominal aortic aneurysm (Rfs: known cardiovascular risk factors, in partic male, smoker, age > 60; Sx: upper abd/vague umbilical pain, radiating to back, profound hypotenision/other sx hypoperfusion if leaking/ruptured→ rapid demise if not identified/fixed)

      GU

      • Renal stones (Sx: acute colicky pain any where from flank→ groin, secondary to stone obstructing kidney or ureter; urinary frequency/urgency, hematuria, nausea, vomiting; patient cant sit still or find comfortable position)
      • Simple UTI - cystitis or prostatitis (Sx: acute, lower abd/pelvis pain, urinary frequency, urgency, no vaginal d/c if female, no other Sx; PE: sometimes supra-pubic area discomfort on palaption; prostate discomfort on palpation if prostatitis)
      • Testicular torsion (Sx: male w/acute, severe, unilateral pain in the scrotum, n, v; PE: painful testicle, sometimes lying higher in the scrotum than typical)
      • Testicular/epididymal infection ( Etiology: GNRs or gc/chlamydia if assoc w/sexually transmitted infxn; Sx: male w/ acute, unilateral, scrotal area pain, dysuria, frequency, fever; PE: painful, englarged testicle, sometimes hydrocele)
      • Pyelonephritis (Sx:low back/flank pain on one side→ radiates toward lower abd; f, c, dysruia; PE; f, CVAT on exam)
      • Renal infarct (Sx: acute back/flank pain, n, v, hematuria; Etiology: source of emboli→ a fib, ventric thrombus; PE: very uncomfortable, pain on palpation)
      • Cancer (Sx: typcially sub-acute, progressive; can cause acute pain if assoc w/infarct or bleeding)

      GYN

      Pregnancy related

      • Ectopic pregnancy (Etiology: past STI→ tubal scarring; Sx: acute lower abdominal/pelvic area pain, known pregnancy or could be initial presentation of pregnancy; )
      • Spontaneous abortion (Sx: acute, crampy, lower abdominal/pelvic area pain, known pregnancy, passage of clot thru vagina, sometimes fetus passed as well)
      • Placental abruption (Sx: acute, severe, lower abd/pelvic pain, during 2nd half of pregnancy, assoc w/vaginal bleeding)
      • Placenta previa (Sx: crampy, lower abdominal/pevlic area pain, during 2nd half of pregnancy, typically less painful than abruption)

      Pelvic Inflam Dz

        Etiology: progression of cervicitis from gc or chlamydia to involve uterus & fallopian tubes; Rfs: age < 25, hx sexual activity, hx STI, lower education level, multiple sex partners, new sex partner; Sx: acute lower abd/pelvic area pain, fever, malodorous smelling vaginal d/c; irreg vaginal bleeding; clinically more severe if tubo-ovarian abscess; PE: cervical d/c, cervical motion pain, uterine tenderness, pain on palpation adnexa more from CDC

      Ovarian Path

      • Cyst rupture (Sx: sub-acute lower abd/pelvic area pain, mid menstrual cycle)
      • Torsion (Sx: acute, severe lower abd/pelvic are pain, n, v)
      • Cancer (Sx: typcially sub-acute, progressive; can cause acute pain if assoc w/infarct or bleeding)

      Other

      • DKA (Rfs: knwon DM, known poor control, acute other illness that is a precipitant; Sx: typically ill appearing, abnl vs, tachypneic)
      • Abd Wall (Etiology/Sx: injury, trauma, other; pain should localized to abd wall/superficial area
      • Angioedema (Etiology: localized areas subcu swelling, response to a precipitant, including: meds, food, latex, insect bite/stings, other environmental triggers; Sx: acute, sob, edema, itching, abd pain; can be severe and life threatening due to airway issues; can occur w/anaphylactic rxns; PE: swelling of face & other body parts, redness, stridor, wheezing, hives/urticaria)
      • Herpes Zoster (acute vessicular erruption, pain a few days prior to skin lesions, neuropathic/burning type pain, PE: vessicles in a dermatomal distribution)
      • Acute Porphyria (Etiology: uncommon, inherited d/o; often triggered by starvation, etoh, smoking, infection, or meds; Sx: episodic bouts of severe abd pain, not otherwise explained, agitation, vomiting, limb pain, motor neuropathy; PE: tachycardia, weakness, episodic dark urine)
      • Familial Med Fever (Rfs: mediterranean descent→ Turkish, Jewish, Armenian, Arab, other; family hx; Sx: uncommon, associated w/cryptic abdominal pain, rash, arthritis, arthralgias, myalgias, recurrent fever)
      • Medications or toxins
        • Antibiotics, iron, glucophage etc (Sx: generalized, non-severe crmapy pain, sometimes diarrhea/constipation/flatus, onset times w/start of Rx)
        • Lead toxicity (Rfs: exposure via paint or work; Sx: abd pain, nausea, constipation, anemia, muscle and joint pain, confusion and cognitive problems, altered sense of tasted, peripheral motor and sensory neuropathy)

      Sub-acute/Chronic Upper Abd Pain

      Sometimes processes that typically cause upper abdominal pain can be localized to the lower abdomen and vice versa

      Esoph & Gastric D/O

      Benign

      • GERD (Rfs: assoc w/obesity, ETOH, smoking, caffeine, chocolate, mint; Sx: chronic/recurrent burning type pain, often worse after meals, worse if lie down after eating, bad taste in mouth, radiates up from epigastrium)
      • Ulcers - gastric or duodenal (Rfs: ETOH, nsaids, h pylori; Sx: epigastric, can radiate towards back, can be better or worse w/food, black stools, hematemesis, posterior duodeanl ulcers bleed, anterior duodenal ulcers can perforate)
      • Non-ulcer dyspepsia (epigastric, better or worse w/food; no red flags)
      • Bezoar (Etiology: build up of undigested material that fills stomach and cant be dissolved or passed along→ e.g. hair; fills up stomach/takes up space; early satiety; Sx: epigastric, slowly progressive leading to n, v, epigastric pain, wt loss)

      Malignant

      • Gastric cancer (Sx: epigastric area pain, anorexia, weight loss, persistent/progressive, n, v, early satiety)
      • Esophageal cancer (Sx: typically progressive swallowing probs more than pain, food gets stuck, may vomit to relieve obstruction, worse w/solids then liquids, pain, patient can often point to level of obstruction)

      Hepatobiliary

      Benign

      • Hepatitis - Viral
        • A (Sx: Typically causes acute sx - which can persist x weeks, then resolve completely)
        • B (Sx: Typically causes acute sx, which can take mos to resolve; chronic hep B doesn't typically cause sx unless/until cirrhosis or hcc develop)
        • C (Sx: Doesn't typically cause sx unless/until cirrhosis or HCC develops)
      • Post herpetic (Sx: burning type pain over RUQ area following shingles outbreak, can last mos)
      • Chronic alcoholic hepatitis (Etiology: ongoing ingestion, superimposed on chronic liver dz; Sx: RUQ pain, n, v, jaundice, encephalopathy; PE: RUQ pain, jaundice, icterus, ascites, confusion)
      • Autoimmune hepatitis (Rfs: assoc w/IBD, RA, SLE, DM1; Sx: acute/sub-acute/chronic, fatigue, n, v, decreased appetite)
      • Liver abscess (Etiology: secondary to biliary obstruction complicated by infection; seeding from bacteremia; also from parasites→ echinococcus, amebiasis; Sx: acute/sub-acute right upper quadrant pain, f, c)
      • Biliary colic (Sx: recurrent right upper quadrant pain, often after meals, when present→ constant then abates spont, hx gall stones)
      • Choledocolithiasis (Sx: recurrent right upper quadrant pain, often after meals, when present→ constant then abates spont, hx gall stones; can cause jaundice w/o other sx)

      Malignant

      • Liver cancer (Etiology: primary related to chronic hepatitis and cirrhosis; can also be mets; Sx: persistent/progressive RUQ area pain, anorexia, weight loss; PE: often firm, palapable liver; sometimes jaundice)
      • Biliary cancer (Sx: persistent/progressive RUQ/epigastric pain, anorexia, weight loss, jaundice, ictreus, light colored stools; PE: jaundice, icterus, palpable gall bladder, firm liver if mets)

      Pancreatic/Splenic d/o

      Benign

      • Chronic pancreatitis (Etiology: known hx recurrent pancreatitis, sometimes ongoing exposure to inciting agent→ e.g.ETOH; Sx: epigastric, can range from dull ache→ to boring, can radiate to back, sometimes worse w/food; wt loss, diarrhea)
      • Pancreatic pseudocyst (Sx: epigastric pain, n, v→ similar to pancreatitis; assoc w/recurrent bouts of pancreatitis)

      Malignant

      • Pancreatic cancer (Etiology: typically primary to pancreas, can also be mets; Sx: epigastric area pain, radiates to back, anorexia, weight loss, persistent/progressive, sometimes diarrhea; PE typically mass not present unless mets to liver; jaundice, icterus if biliary obstruction)
      • Infiltrative dz spleen→ typically from cancer(Sx: relatively uncommon, focused in LUQ, progressive, f, wt loss)

      Medications

      • Antibiotics, iron, glucophage etc (Sx: generalized, non-sevre crmapy pain, sometimes diarrhea/constipation/flatus, onset times w/start of Rx)

      Ventral hernia/Other mechanical d/o

        Sx: discomfort in area where intestines/omentum trapped in ventral defect; not severe nor assoc sx if no strangulation/obstruction/infarction

      Vascular

      • Mesenteric/small bowel ischemia (Sx: generalized abd/epigastric pain, known atherosclerosis or RFs, progressive/persistent pain after meals→ angina of the gut→ food avoidance→ weight loss)
      • Polyarteritis Nodosa (vasculitis) (Rfs: 40s-50s, men>women, Hep B/C; Sx: more commonly subacute over mos f, s, malaise, wt loss, muscle/joint pain; multiple systems: arthritis, glomerulonephritis, peripheral nerve pain/dysfxn, skin w/ulcers, small, palapable purpura→ don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; abd pain, blood per rectum)

      Fxnl disorder/IBS

        Sx: generalized/non-specific abd, no wt loss, not severe pain; no abd findings or other red flags; sometimes constipation or diarrhea predominant; sometimes mixed sx Rome criteria for functional bowel d/o

      Inflammatory Bowel Dz

      • Ulcerative colitis (Etiology: automimmune, genetic, environmentally triggered, other; affects colon, distal to prox; Rfs: Northen Europeans, North Americans; smoking and appendectomy protective; peak onset 15-30; Sx and PE: sub-acute, recurrent or chronic diarrhea; fatigue, wt loss, bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, nocturnal diarrhea, feeling poorly overall; spectrum from mild to severe; extra-GI: aphtous ulcers, erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosa, peripheral arthritis, ankylosing spond/sacroiliitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, eye sx→ episcleritis/scleritis/uveitis) More from CDC
