      • Crohn's disease (Etiology: automimmune, genetic, environmentally triggered, other; transmural involvement; can affect anywhere in GI tract mouth-to-anus; Rfs: smoking and appendectomy increase risk; Northern Europeans and North Americans; peak onset 15-30; Sx: sub-acute, diarrhea→ though can be less prominent than w/UC, nocturnal diarrhea, sometimes bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, fever, abd pain, fatigue, wt loss, feeling poorly overall, fistulas, bowel obstruction, peri-rectal dz; spectrum of sx and findings; PE: sometimes abd mass; peri-rectal disease; extra-GI: aphtous ulcers, erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosa, peripheral arthritis, ankylosing spond/sacroiliitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, eye sx→ episcleritis/scleritis/uveitis) More from CDC

      Parasitic infections

      • Ascariasis (Etiology: tropics/sub-tropics/SE US, eggs swallowed if contaminated soil ingested (e.g. human feces used as fertilizer)→ eggs hatch in intestines → larvae enter blood stream → migrate lungs → mature & coughed up → swallowed → mature in intestines; Sx: often asx; if heavy worm burden→ cough, fever, sob, n, v, abd pain, impaired growth of children, sbo)
      • Schistosomiasis (fluke) (Etiology: South America, Middle East, Caribbean, Africa: flukes, invade skin of swimmers, enter blood stream→ live in portal/mesenteric veins; Sx: can cause portal htn after years; also f, c, abd pain, diarrhea; can live in bladder → SCC after years)
      • Strongyloidiasis (Etiology: Asia/Southeast Asia, larvae enter thru feet/skin if walk barefoot in soil w/infected feces, live in small intestine; Sx: epigastic pain, weakness, watery diarrhea)
      • Trichuriasis (whipworm) (Etiology: eggs ingested, live in colon; Sx: w/light infxn→ asx; heavy burden→ abd pain, diarrhea, bloody stools, n, v, anemia)

      Sub-Acute/Chronic Low Abd Pain

      Sometimes processes that typically cause lower abdominal pain can lead to more generalized abdominal symptoms and vice versa

      GI

      Benign

      • Inguinal Hernia (Sx: chronic discomfort in inguinal area, not severe nor other sx if no incarcerated, strangulated, obstruction; PE: inguinal area bulge; tender, indurated and red if incarcerated/infarcted)
      • Ventral Hernia (Sx: discomfort in area where intestines/omentum trapped in ventral defect; not severe nor assoc sx if no strangulation, obstruction, infarction)
      • Functional disorder/IBS (Sx: generalized/non-specific abd, no wt loss, not severe pain; no abd findings or other red flags; sometimes constipation alt w/diarrhea) Rome criteria for functional bowel d/o
      • Inflammatory Bowel Disease(Sx: generalized abd sx; sub-acute, recurrent or chronic; wt loss, diarrhea, bloody stools, cramps, constipation; presentation can also be fulminant/severe if perforation, obstruction, profound inflammation) More from CDC

      Malignant

      • Colorectal (Rfs: no prior screening or screening > 10y ago, early family hx, polyposis syndromes, UC or colonic crohn's; Sx: anorexia, weight loss, vague pain, persistent/progressive, bloody stools, change in bowel habits, R sided→ fatigue from anemia, L sided→ obstructive sx)
      • Anal cancer (Rfs: squamous cell ca assoc w/HPV infection; Sx: anal pain, tenesmus, bleeding, pain, obstruction PE: palpable mass or diffuse tissue infiltration)
      • Lymphoma (Hodgkins and Non-Hodgkins)(Sx: wt loss/decreased appetite sweats, fevers, chills, adenopathy, organomegaly, abdominal fullness; CNS involvement and sx w/NHL; skin involvement w/cutanous t-cell NHL)
      • Metastatic disease to abdomen e.g. Lung - generalized abd

      Vascular

      • Mesenteric/small bowel ischemia (Sx: generalized abd/epigastric pain, known atherosclerosis or RFs, progressive/persistent pain after meals→ angina of the gut→ food avoidance→ weight loss)
      • Polyarteritis Nodosa (vasculitis) (Rfs: 40s-50s, men>women, Hep B/C; Sx: more commonly subacute over mos f, s, malaise, wt loss, muscle/joint pain; multiple systems: arthritis, glomerulonephritis, peripheral nerve pain/dysfxn, skin w/ulcers, small, palapable purpura→ don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; abd pain, blood per rectum)

      Gyn

      Benign

      • Endometriosis (Sx: dysmennhorea, irreg bleeding, pain w/intercourse, infertility, pain occurs mid-cycle, urinary or rectal sx if implantation in those areas)
      • Fibroids (Sx: vague lower abd discomfort - may vary w/size of fibroid, vaginal bleeding)
      • Pelvic adhesions (Sx: hx STIs/tubal scarring; hx pelvic area surgery/radiation; vague pelvic area pain; pain w/intercourse)
      • Ovulatory pain (mittleschmerz) (Sx: mid menstrual cycle, lasts 1-2 days, often on one side, recurrent)

      Malignant

      • Ovarian (Rfs: age > 50, fam hx breast/ovarian, nulliparity, obesity; Sx: vague, progressive, fullness/discomfort, increased girth if malignant ascites; PE: palpably enlarged ovary if large)
      • Uterine (Rfs: age >50, early menarche, late menopause, receiving unopposed estrogens, obesity; Sx vague lower abd discomfort, wt loss, progressive, vaginal bleeding; PE: enlarged uterus on exam)
      • Cervical (Rfs: smoking, early age first intercourse, multiple sexual partners, hx STIs, hx HPV, HIV; Sx: vague lower abd discomfort, vaginal bleeding, pain w/intercourse; PE: abnormal cervix on exam)
      • Vaginal (Rfs: age >50, DES exposure, HPV, smoking; Sx: lower abd/vaginal area pain, vaginal bleeding; PE: vaginal wall abnormality on exam)

      GU

      Benign

      • Interstitial cystitis (Sx: pelvic area, urinary frequency, urgency pain, chronicity, women > men, neg evidence infxn)
      • Chronic prostatitis (Sx: pelvic area pain, often past hx bacterial prostatitis; dysuria, frequency, urgency; if related to recurrent infxn→ culture + same organism as past; can also be w/o organisms)

      Malignant

      • Renal cell (Rfs: smoking, obesity, family hx, men > women, avg ages mid-60s; Sx: low back to lower abd/groin discomfort, wt loss, sweats, fever, flank pain, hematuria)
      • Bladder or other urothelial (Rfs: smoking hx; men > women, age > 50, anyline dye exposure→ TCC; chronic foley or schistosomiasis→ SCC; Sx: lower abd/pelvis discomfort, wt loss, hematuria/dysuria, urinary frequency/urgency, )
      • Prostate (Sx: asx early, can cause urgency, frequency, delayed emptying, hematuria; bone pain or lower abd pain if advanced disease w/mets)

      Dysphagia?

      Oropharyngeal D/O

      • Mechanical problems with chewing (Etiology: dental problems → prevent chewing and/or cause pain)
      • Sores/ulcers
        • Squamous cell cancer (RFs: smoking, etoh, chewing tobacco; PE: slow growing, non-healing ulcer or mass of oral mucosa, edges indurated, lymph nodes firm, stuck to each other & underlying tissue, growing)
        • Candida (Rfs: immuno-supressed→ chemo or hiv, abx exposure, steroids; PE: white discharge, bleeds when scraped)
        • Apthous ulcer (Sx: acute, painful, self limited; Etiology: can be assoc w/viral infxn, meds, cancer, hiv, or idiopathic; PE: ulcer(s) with surrounding erythema)
        • HSV (Sx: pain can precede appearance, worse if immunocmop, can be recurrent; PE: clear vessicles on red base, small ulcer after uncovered)
        • Bechets Dz (Etiology: autoimmune d/o assoc; Sx: waxing & waning sx; painful ulcers in genital region and mouth; eye sx from iritis; also multi-system/systemic sx from vasculitis, arthritis, GI and neuro involvement; PE: oral ulcers, genital ulcers, red painful eye w/irregular pupil)
        • Mucositis from chemotherapy
      • Neruological d/o
        • Stroke (Rfs: + vascular risk factors; Sx: problems w/initiating swallowing, other focal findings, hx aspiration)
        • Parkinsons (Rfs: age > 70; Sx: pill rolling tremor of hands, sometimes head bobbing tremor, difficulty starting and stopping movements, balance and gait problems, sometimes cognitive decline; PE: characteristic pill-rolling tremor, stooped forwards, shuffling gait, masked facies, difficulty getting up and starting movement, difficulty turning)
        • Botulism (Rfs: exposure to at risk food; Sx: acute onset→ 8-36h, afebrile, difficulty swallowing secretions, difficulty breathing or speaking, double vision, abdominal cramps, weakness/paralysis starts w/CNs→ spreads symmetrically to limbs)
        • Myasthenia gravis (Etiol: autoimmune w/ab targeting ACh receptor; Rfs: 20-30 y female predom, 50-70y male; Sx: painless, subacute, progressive; worse w/repetitive movement, end of day; ocular sx→ double vision, eyelid weakness; dysphagia, fatigue w/chewing; can also cause systemic weakness affecting neck, extremities, other muscles→ asymmetric and prox > distal fashion; PE: no atrophy, reflexes preserved, no sensory findings, ptosis, eye muscle weakness, weakness in other muscles→ worse w/use)
        • Tetanus (Etiology: Clostridium Tetani (GPR), exposure via contaminated wounds; toxin mediated; vaccination markedly decreases incidence dz w/50 cases/y US; Sx: ~1w incubation, increased tone in jaw muscles, dysphagia, diffuse musle pain/spasms, sweating, airway compromise; PE: fever, tachycardia, elevated bp, lock jaw, severe muscle spasm) more from CDC

      Esophageal D/O

      Cancer

      Progressive swallowing problems (Sx: food gets stuck, may vomit to relieve obstruction, worse w/solids then liquids, pain, over time worse w/ever smaller sized food)
      • Squamous cell (Etiology: Upper 2/3 of esophagus; RFs: associated with ETOH and smoking, age >50)
      • Adenocarcinoma (Etiology: Lower 1/3 of esophagus; RFs: associated with GERD→ Barret's, age > 50)

      Obstruction from benign causes

      • Zenker's diverticulum (Etiology: protrusion of portion posterior wall of esophagus thru weak area btwn cricopharyngeus and inferior contstrictor muscles; Sx: chronic, bad breath, sensation food stuck in throat/upper esoph, regurgitation undigested food)
      • Esophageal web or ring (Sx: chronic, non-or slowly progressive, sensation of food getting stuck → occurring more w/larger solids)
      • Esophageal stricture (Etiology: long hx gerd or hx caustic ingestion; Sx: sensation of food getting stuck → occurring more w/larger solids, can be progressive if related to chronic inflammatory process)

      Inflammatory

      • GERD esophagitis (Rfs: assoc w/obesity, ETOH, smoking, caffeine, chocolate, mint; Sx: chronic/recurrent burning type pain, often worse after meals, worse if lie down after eating, bad taste in mouth, radiates up from epigastrium, n, sometimes v)
      • Eosinophilic esophagitis (Sx: dysphagia, chest/upper abd pain, food impaction)
      • Pills (Sx: occur soon after incomplete swallowing of pill, patient can often point to spot along esophagus where pain is focused)

      Infection

      • Candidiasis (RFs: often compromised host→ cancer/chemo/hiv; PE: evidence candida in mouth)
      • HSV (RFs: often compromised host→ cancer, chemo, hiv; PE: HSV on exam)

      Dysmotility

      Equal difficulty w/swallowing solids and liquids.
      • Achalasia (Sx: progressive dysphagia, solids and liquids, regurgitation, GERD sx, food sticks lower area esophagus)
      • Esophageal spasm (Sx: acute, intermittent pain and difficulty w/swallowing)
      • Eosinophilic esophagitis (RFs: allergies, asthma; Sx: no pain, no response to PPI)
      • American Trypanosomiasis (chagas dz - t cruzi) (Etiology: Central and South America, via reduviid bug bite; incubation 1-2w; Sx: most have no acute sx; if acute sx present, can include→ f, c, sweats, malaise, ha, n, v, d x weeks; chronic sx in 20-30%, including: lower esophageal dysmotility; cardiomyopathy→ CHF, dysrhythmia; PE: rare acute findings: skin nodule at bite; eyelid edema)
      • Scleroderma (RFs: women > men, < 50, GERD, known disease, PE: skin tightening)
      • Tetanus (Etiology: Clostridium Tetani (GPR), exposure via contaminated wounds; toxin mediated; vaccination markedly decreases incidence dz w/50 cases/y US; Sx: ~1w incubation, increased tone in jaw muscles, dysphagia, diffuse musle pain/spasms, sweating, airway compromise; PE: fever, tachycardia, elevated bp, lock jaw, severe muscle spasm) more from CDC

      Neurological Disorders

      • Stroke (Rfs: + vascular risk factors; Sx: problems w/initiating swallowing, other focal findings, hx aspiration)
      • Parkinsons (Rfs: age > 70; Sx: pill rolling tremor of hands, sometimes head bobbing tremor, difficulty starting and stopping movements, balance and gait problems, sometimes cognitive decline; PE: characteristic pill-rolling tremor, stooped forwards, shuffling gait, masked facies, difficulty getting up and starting movement, difficulty turning)
      • Botulism (Rfs: exposure to at risk food; Sx: acute onset→ 8-36h, afebrile, difficulty swallowing secretions, difficulty breathing or speaking, double vision, abdominal cramps, weakness/paralysis starts w/CNs→ spreads symmetrically to limbs)
      • Myasthenia gravis (Etiol: autoimmune w/ab targeting ACh receptor; Rfs: 20-30 y female predom, 50-70y male; Sx: painless, subacute, progressive; worse w/repetitive movement, end of day; ocular sx→ double vision, eyelid weakness; dysphagia, fatigue w/chewing; can also cause systemic weakness affecting neck, extremities, other muscles→ asymmetric and prox > distal fashion; PE: no atrophy, reflexes preserved, no sensory findings, ptosis, eye muscle weakness, weakness in other muscles→ worse w/use)
      • Tetanus (Etiology: Clostridium Tetani (GPR), exposure via contaminated wounds; toxin mediated; vaccination markedly decreases incidence dz w/50 cases/y US; Sx: ~1w incubation, increased tone in jaw muscles, dysphagia, diffuse musle pain/spasms, sweating, airway compromise; PE: fever, tachycardia, elevated bp, lock jaw, severe muscle spasm) more from CDC

      Nausea or Vomiting?

      Esophageal d/o

      • Esophageal cancer (Sx: sub-acute, progressive dysphagia, food gets stuck, may vomit to relieve obstruction, worse w/solids then liquids, pain, patient can often point to level of obstruction)
      • GERD (Rfs: assoc w/obesity, ETOH, smoking, caffeine, chocolate, mint; Sx: chronic/recurrent burning type pain, often worse after meals, worse if lie down after eating, bad taste in mouth, radiates up from epigastrium, n, sometimes v)
      • Esophageal dysmotility (Sx: sub-acute/chronic, dysphagia solids and liquids, v when cant swallow food, GERD sx, food sticks lower area esophagus)

      Gastric d/o

      • Ulcer - gastric or duodenal (Rfs/Etiology: ETOH, h pylori, nsaid use; Sx: epigastric, better or worse w/food, black stools)
      • Gastritis (Rfs: stress, ETOH, NSAIDs, h pylori; Sx: epigastric pain, black stools, better or worse w/food)
      • Stomach cancer (Rfs: 50, smoking, ETOH abuse, h pylori→ MALT assoc; Sx: progressive feeling of fullness when eating ever smaller quantities of food→ early satiety, pain, bleeding)
      • Autonomic nerve dysfunction - e.g. w/DM (Etiology: long standing DM w/poor control; Sx: early satiety, chronic/progressive, neuropathic Sx elsewhere→ e.g. feet)
      • Bezoar (Etiology: build up of undigested material that fills stomach and cant be disolved or passed along→ e.g. hair; fills up stomach/takes up space; Sx: epigastric discomfort, slowly progressive leading to n, v, epigastric pain, wt loss)
      • Benign stricture (Etiology: chronic peptic ulcers; Sx: sub-acute, progressive, feeling full after eating small amounts, post prandial vomiting undigested contents, weight loss)

      Other GI d/o

      • Gastroenteritis (Sx: acute, generalized crampy abd pain, diarrhea, n, v)
      • Toxin-based food poisoning (Etiology: commonly staph; Sx: acute n, v w/in hours of eating affected food; others who ate same also ill)
      • Pancreatitis (Sx: acute epigastric pain, constant, radiates to back, N, V; Etiology: ETOH abuse, gall stones, meds; less common anatomic→ divisum, post procedure, auto-immune, scorpion bites, trauma)
      • Upper GI bleeding→ blood is a cathartic (Etiology: nsaids, h pylori, etoh, varices; Sx: acute n, vomiting of blood)
      • Acute hepatitis for any reason - ETOH, viral, other
      • Bowel obstruction - small or large bowel(Sx: acute, generalized abd pain, comes in waves, n, v, decreased flatus, abd distention)
      • GI malignancies - pancreatic, hepatic, biliary - sx are sub-acute and progressive
      • Ileus - post abdominal surgery, autonomic dysfxn, other - sx are acute

      Non-GI d/o

      • Meds - many - dx made on basis of temporal relationship, recognizing possible contribution
      • Toxins and drugs of abuse
        • ETOH - w/intoxication
        • Canabis hyperemesis syndrome (Sx: chronic maijuana use, improves w/showering or bathing in hot water, often delays in dx)
        • Other
      • Adrenal insufficiency (Sx: feeling poorly in general, n, v, orthostatic sx - can be primary or secondary)
      • Other metabolic d/o: liver and kidney dz, hypercalcemia, hypothyroidism, DKA
      • Pregnancy - in particular first trimester
      • Odors - primary or linked to prior unpleasant events (e.g. chemotherapy)
      • Acute, severe pain for any reason
      • Systemic malignancies
      • Generalized systemic infections
      • Generalized acute illness
      • Neurologic
        • Increased intracranial pressure (Etiology: HA, trauma, cancer, infection - w/appropriate accompanying hx)
        • Labrynthitis/vestibulitis (Etiology: often URI Sx prior; Sx: abrupt, worse w/ any head movement, self limited → lasts a few days)
        • Benign positional vertigo (Etiology: sometimes hx prior trauma; Sx: abrupt onset vertigo, worse w/any head movement→ roll over in bed, assoc n/v, episodes last 10-20 sec, no other neuro Sx, usually remits spontaneously; PE: sx provoked by Dix-Hallpike maneuver, associated rotational nystagmus toward affected side, treated w/canalith repositioning)
        • Brain stem ischemia (Rfs: htn, dm, hyperlipidemia, male, smoking, a fib; Sx: abrupt onset, dizziness, n, v, other focal neurological c/o in neighborhood → double vision, speech/swallowing probs, facial numbness, inability to walk)
        • Cerebellar stroke, hemmorhage (Rfs: htn, dm, hyperlipidemia, smoking, male; Sx: abrupt, often severe sx → cant walk, other focal cerebellar findings, n, v, dizziness)
      • Myocardial ischemia

      Abdominal Swelling?

      Ascites

      Significant fluid w/in the peritoneal cavity can cause a characteristic appearance of abdomen.
    • Fluid sample to determine if ascites from portal htn v other
        • Testing of ascitic fluid includes: appearance, culture, gram stain, cell count, LDH, albumin, T protein, glucose, cytology. Calculate SAAG (Serum Albumin - Ascites albumin Gradient), with > 1.1 indicating portal htn.

      Post-hepatic processes

      SAAG > 1.1
      • Hepatic vein thrombosis (Etiology: budd-chiari syndrome→ assoc w/hypercoaguable states; Rfs: age 30-40; Sx: RUQ pain, new ascites, jaundice, no findings chronic liver dz)
      • Severe R and L CHF - TP > 2.5
      • Constrictive pericardial disease→ sequelae of prior pericarditis - TP > 2.5
      • Tamponade→ often a sequelae of pericarditis - TP > 2.5

      Intra-hepatic processes

      Chronic processes that lead to fibrosis, typically from decades of inflammation, often associated w/findings of chronic liver dz; if hepatic encephalopathy, then confusion→ stupor; asterixis. SAAG > 1.1
      • ETOH Abuse (chronic→ cirrhosis)
      • Hepatitis C (chronic→ cirrhosis) (Etiology/Rfs: hx substance abuse/shared needles, transfusion prior to screening, shared inhalation instruments for cocaine; asx x decades until chronic liver inflam leads to fibrosis)
      • Hepatitis B (chronic→ cirrhosis) (Etiology/Rfs: transferred mother to child; also sexually, needles, blood; asx x decades until chronic liver inflam leads to fibrosis)
      • Fatty liver (chronic→ cirrhosis) (Etiology: chronic elevation in wt/BMI; asx x decades until chronic liver inflam leads to fibrosis)
      • Meds: Some are directly hepatotoxic→ e.g. acetamin, INH; other cause cholestasis→ e.g. steroids, OCPs; other have mixed tox→ e.g. ace-I, DPH
      • Infiltrative dz - e.g.sarcoid, lymphoma
      • Primary liver cancer (RF is chronic hepatitis of any etiology)
      • Metastases to liver from cancer elsewhere: colon, pancreas, lymphoma
      • Mixtures of the above d/o (Etiology: often a chronic hepatitis w/toxin superimposed)
      • Hemochromatosis (Rfs: age 30-40, Sx; chronic, progressive liver dz, ED and low libido, diabetes; PE: dark skin, small testes) More from CDC
      • Wilson's Dz (Rfs: age 20-40; Sx: progressive confusion, tremor, other neuro; PE: weakness, numbness, decreased coordination)
      • Alpha 1 anti-trypsin (Rfs: age 30-40; Sx: chronic progressive liver dz, co-existent COPD related sx→ in partic if no smoking hx)
      • Autoimmune hepatitis (Sx: acute/sub-acute/chronic, fatigue, n, v, decreased appetite; assoc w/IBD, RA, SLE, DM1)
      • Primary biliary cirrhosis (Etiology: assoc w/celiac dz and other autoimmune; Sx: fatigue, early on elevation in alk phos; cirrhosis→ portal htn → ascites a late finding)
      • Primary sclerosing cholangitis (Etiology: typically assoc w/IBD, ascites a late finding, cholestasis and extra-hep bil obstruction occur late as well; early-on assoc w/elevated alk phos)

      Pre-hepatic processes

      SAAG > 1.1
      • Portal vein thrombosis → assoc w/hypercoag state, inflammation, cancer
      • Portal vein obstruction from parasites→ schistosomiasis (Rfs: South America, Middle East, Carribbean, Africa: Etiology: flukes, invade skin of swimmers, enter blood stream→ live in portal/mesenteric veins→ can cause cirrhosis after years; can live in bladder → SCC after years; Sx: f, c, abd pain, diarrhea)

      Low oncotic pressure

      • Severe malnutrition
      • Advanced liver disease w/decreased synthetic function (Etiology: low albumin resultant from any of the chronic hepatic inflammatory disorders - co-mingles w/cirrhosis)
      • Protein losses thru urine (nephrotic syndrome) or GI tract - SAAG < 1.1

      Peritoneal/Other Inflam Process

      SAAG < 1.1
      • Malignancies that weep fluid and or produce mucin e.g. ovarian
      • Malignancies that block lymphtics e.g. ovarian
      • Chylous (Etiology: malignancies that obstruct lymphatics→ ovarian, lymphoma; filarial infection; trauma; other)
      • Pancreatitis (Etiology: ETOH abuse, gall stones, meds; less common anatomic→ divisum, post procedure, auto-immune, scorpion bites, trauma; Sx: epigastric, constant, radiates to back, N, V)
      • Blood (Etiology: trauma, malignancies→ liver or other intra-abd organ w/rupture of superficial lesion/errosion into blood vessel; portal htn & ruptured varices, infection→ peritoneal TB)
      • Serositis assoc w/lupus or inflammatory d/o - rare cause of ascites; should have other sx & manifestations
      • SBP - pre-existing ascites, w/bacterial infection superimposed (Sx: pain, confusion, worsening ascites)
      • TB (RFs: for TB→ exposure, travel, compromised; known TB elsewhere; Sx: chronic and progressive s, wt loss, fever)
      • Fungal (cocci, aspergillous, candida) (Etiology: rare problem often compromised host or those on peritoneal dialysis; Sx: often sub-acute, vague abd discomfort, increased girth)

      Gas

      • Non-specific bowel distension
      • Mechanical small or large bowel obstruction (Sx: generalized abd pain, comes in waves, n, v, decreased flatus, abd distention)
      • Ileus or parasympathetic dysfxn - post laparotomy, ogilvies, secondary to other intra-abd inflammatory process

      Organomegaly or Hernia

      • Liver, gall bladder, spleen, kidney, uterus (pregnant v other), bladder
      • Ventral hernia (Rfs: past surgery, Sx: may have discomfort from bulging thru defect; severe pain if incarceration/strangulation; PE: bulge thru scar line, increases w/straining )

      Jaundice?

      Jaundice may also be assoc with other findings of chronic liver dz

      Elevated unconjugated bilirubin

      • Over production of bilirubin
        • Hemolysis (Sx: sob, doe, fatigue & those related to specific etiology; PE: if severe hemolysis→ abnl VS, jaundice, scleral icterus, bilirubinuria if intravascular and sig d bili component; other sx related to specific Etiologyogy of hemolysis)
        • Reabsorption of large hematoma
      • Impaired conjugation
        • Gilbert's Dz (chronic, mild bili elevation, asx)

      Elevated conjugated bilirubin

      Cholestasis or Hep Inflam

      Infection

      • Hepatitis A (acute) (Etiology/Rfs: spread fecal/oral/ingestion contaminated food, can be epidemic, incubation 2-4w; Sx: n, v, RUQ abd pain, puritis, dark urine, light colored stool, f, jaundice, icterus; sx generally resolve w/in 2-4w; PE: jaundice, icterus, RUQ pain, hepatomegaly)
      • Hepatitis B (acute) (RFs: spread via sexual contact, vertical, shared needles, needle sticks in health care workers, unscreened blood transfusion; Sx: many are asx; incuabtaion is 1-4m; acute infxn assoc w/n, v, jaundice; puritus, icterus, dark urine, light colored stool, malaise; typcially self limited, w/resoln sx 2-3m; 5% go on to chronic infxn, w/risk cirrhosis, spread to others, and hcc; PE: jaundice, icterus, RUQ pain, hepatomegaly)
      • Hepatitis C (rare cause of acute hep) (RFs: spread via needles, unscreened blood transfusion, cocaine inhaling tools, needle sticks in health care workers, vertical, sexual; 10-20% resolve spontaneously; long term risk cirrhosis and HCC w/chronic infxn; Sx: most w/acute hep C are asx; those w/sx have RUQ pain, f, malaiae, jaudice; PE: most have no findings in acute phase)
      • Hepatitis D (RFs: occurs as a co-infection w/hep b, uncommon in west, found in Mediterranean and Asian countries; spread via same mechanisms as hep b)
      • Hepatitis E (RFs: uncommon in western nations, though most common cause of acute hep in developing world, can be sporadic or epidemic, water born w/spread similar to hep a; Sx: incubation 3-8w, sx of malaise, n, jaundice x ~ 2w; usually self limited, rarely fulminant, rarely chronic)
        • More on viral hepatitis from CDC
      • CMV (Rfs; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; systemic infxn in HIV or otherwise compromised; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w, fatigue x 4-6w; Sx: f, c, malaise, RUQ pain; PE: epgiastric/RUQ pain, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC
      • EBV→ mononucleosis (Sx: incubation 4-6w, prodrome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias; then f, sore throat; PE: head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly) more from CDC
      • Herpes simplex (Etiology: disseminated HSV; Rfs: immunocompromised; Sx: abd pain, n, v, fever; sometimes typical skin lesions oral/genital; PE: sometimes vessicular lesions oral or genital regions)
      • Herpes zoster (Sx: burning type pain over RUQ area for several days prior to skin erruption; PE: dermatomal, vessicular erruption over abdominal dermatome)
      • Bacterial abscess(Etiology: secondary to cholecystitis or cholangitis; seeding from systemic bacteremia; Sx: right upper quadrant pain, f, c)
      • Ascariasis (Etiology: tropics/sub-tropics/SE US, eggs swallowed if contaminated soil ingested (e.g. human feces used as fertilizer)→ eggs hatch in intestines → larvae enter blood stream → migrate lungs → mature & coughed up → swallowed → mature in intestines; Sx: often asx; if heavy worm burden→ cough, fever, sob, n, v, abd pain, impaired growth of children, sbo; can migrate to biliary tree and cause obstruction & related complications)
      • Echinococcus (tapeworm) (Etiology: main host is cattle and dogs; common in US and many other areas; eggs ingested by humans → travel to liver→ Sx: cysts form & can cause RUQ pain→ compress biliary tract → if rupture can cause anaphylaxis)
      • Entamoeba histolytica→ amebiasis (protozoa) (Etiology: acquired via unclean water/poor sanitation, also anal intercourse; Sx: only 10-20% develop sx; incubation 2-4w; abd pain, bloody diarreha; occas liver abscess)
      • Toxocariasis (aka visceral larva migrans or roundworm) (Etiology: definitive hosts are cats and dogs; humans ingest eggs from dirt→ eggs hatch in intestines→ larvae can travel to lungs, eyes, CNS, liver; Sx: many are asx; can cause cough, fever, visual loss, hepatitis)
      • Leptospirosis (Etiology: contract via exposure to rodent/wild animal feces; incubation several weeks; Sx/PE: mild dz is self limited f, c, ha, n, v, muscle aches, conjunctival injection; severe dz with hepatic and renal involvement, pulmonary hemorrhage, andicterus) CDC

      Meds/Toxins

      • ETOH Abuse (chronic) (Etiology: decades of abuse, though many still wont develop chronic liver dz; PE: other findings of chronic liver dz: ascites, gynecomastia, spider angioma, etc)
      • Acute alcoholic hepatitis (Etiology: ongoing ingestion etoh, often superimposed on chronic liver dz; Sx: acute RUQ pain, n, v, acute, jaundice, encephalopathy; PE: RUQ pain, jaundice, icterus, ascites, confusion)
      • Meds: Some are directly hepatotoxic → e.g. acetamin, INH; other cause cholestasis → e.g. steroids, OCPs; other have mixed tox → e.g. ace-I, DPH
      More on Hepatotoxins NIH: LiverTox

      Metabolic

      • Fatty liver (Etiology: chronic elevation in wt/BMI; asx x decades until chronic liver inflam leads to fibrosis; PE: other findings of chronic liver dz: ascites, gynecomastia, spider angioma, et)
      • Hemochromatosis (Rfs: age 30-40, Sx; chronic, progressive liver dz, ED and low libido, diabetes; PE: dark skin, small testes) More from CDC
      • Wilson's Dz (Rfs: age 20-40; Sx: progressive confusion, tremor, other neuro; PE: weakness, numbness, decreased coordination)
      • Alpha 1 anti-trypsin (Rfs: age 30-40; Sx: chronic progressive liver dz, co-existent COPD related sx→ in partic if no smoking hx)
      • Infiltrative dz - e.g. sarcoid, lymphoma, amyloid

      Autoimmune

      • Autoimmune hepatitis (Sx: acute/sub-acute/chronic, fatigue, n, v, decreased appetite; assoc w/IBD, RA, SLE, DM1)
      • Primary biliary cirrhosis (Etiology: assoc w/celiac dz and other autoimmune; Sx: fatigue, early on elevation in alk phos; cirrhosis→ portal htn → ascites a late finding)

      Malignancy

      • Primary liver (Rfs: chronic hepatitis for any reason→ viral, etoh, etc; Sx: RUQ/epigastric persistent/progressive discomfort, anorexia, weight loss; PE: palpable, firm liver)
      • Metastatic dz to liver e.g. colon, pancreatic, lymphoma

      Other

      • Hepatic failure from hypotension, sepsis, other - history should be suggestive
      • Pregnancy
      • Congestion from imparied venous drainage - typically also have ascites
        • Hepatic vein thrombosis (Etiology: budd-chiari syndrome→ assoc w/hypercoaguable states; Rfs: age 30-40; Sx: RUQ pain, new ascites, jaundice, variceal bleeding/other manifest of portal htn)
        • Severe R and L CHF
        • Constrictive pericardial disease→ sequelae of prior pericarditis
      Mixtures of the above d/o - often a chronic hepatitis w/acute process or toxin superimposed

      Post hepatic bil obstruction

      • Cancer
        • Pancreatic (Rfs: male, age > 50, chronic pancreatitis, smoking, family hx; Sx: persistent/progressive epigastric area pain radiating to back, anorexia, weight loss, sometimes diarrhea; PE: palpable mass from primary or met if advanced; jaundice if affecting head of pnacreas and obstructing CBD)
        • Biliary (Rfs: PSC, other chronic biliary inflammation; Sx: persistent/progressive RUQ/epigsatric discomfort, anorexia, weight loss, jaundice, ictreus, light colored stools)
      • Stones (Sx: can cause painless jaundice; also colic type pain, or infection)
      • Primary sclerosing cholangitis (Etiology: typically assoc w/IBD, ascites a late finding, cholestasis and extra-hep biliary obstruction occur late as well; early-on assoc w/elevated alk phos)
      • Parasites→ clonorchis (China, Viet Nam, Southeast Asia), ascariasis, echinococcus

      Over Prod of Bili

      • Hemolysis - if severe→ elevated direct and indirect bilirubin(Sx: sob, doe, fatigue & those related to specific etiology; PE: if severe hemolysis→ abnl VS, jaundice, scleral icterus, bilirubinuria if intravascular; other sx related to specific Etiologyogy of hemolysis)
      • Reabsorption of large hematoma - can have elevated direct and indirect bili

      Yellow skin w/o Liver Dz

      • Chronic renal disease
      • DM
      • Excessive beta-carotene ingestion - carrots, vitamins

      Vomiting Blood (hematemasis)?

      Brisk bleeding can occur from any etiology, in particular varices. Rapid losses result in vomiting blood or passing melena w/in hours. Also systemic sx & hemodynamic instability.

      Esophageal d/o

      • Esophagitis (Rfs: assoc w/obesity, ETOH, smoking, caffeine, chocolate, mint; Sx: GERD type→ burning type pain, often worse after meals, worse if lie down after eating, bad taste in mouth, radiates up from epigastrium)
      • Mallory-Weiss Tear (Etiology/Rfs: hx repeated retching)
      • Esophageal cancer or inflammation from other causes typically also have pain and dysphagia
      • Esophageal varices→ secondary to portal htn, whose causes include:
        • Post-hepatic processes→ hepatic vein thrombosis, severe R/L CHF, constrictive pericardial disease, restrictive cardiomypathy
        • Intrahepatic processes→ chronic hepatitis of any etiology including: viral, toxin, autoimmune, infiltrative, malignant; sometimes acute d/o if fulminant or superimposed on chronic
        • Pre-hepatic processes→ portal vein thrombosis, portal vein obstruction from parasites/other

      Gastric d/o

      • Ulcer - gastric or duodenal (Rfs/Etiology: ETOH, h pylori, nsaid use; Sx: epigastric, better or worse w/food, black stools)
      • Portal gastropathy→ secondary to portal htn
      • Gastritis (Rfs: stress, ETOH, NSAIDs, h pylori; Sx: epigastric pain, black stools, better or worse w/food)
      • Dieulafoys lesions→ sub-mucosal artery (Sx: sudden, brisk bleeding)
      • Stomach cancer (Rfs: 50, smoking, ETOH abuse, h pylori→ MALT assoc; Sx: sub-acute, feel full when eating ever smaller quantities of food, pain, bleeding)
      • Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT; formerly Osler-Weber-Rendu) (Etiology: rare congential d/o, AVMs within lungs, nose, mouth, GI tract→ duod, stomach, colon; Sx: onset typically in teens, nose bleeds; cryptic GI bleeds/iron defic anemia, SOB, cryptic stroke or CNS abscess; PE: recurrent nose bleed, telangiectasis on nasal mucosa, lips, tongue)

      Other

      • Swallowed blood from upper respiratory source→ nose bleed
      • Swallowed blood from oral bleeding site
      • Aorto-enteric fistula (Rfs: hx AAA graft; Sx: profound bleeding)
      • Meds can exacerbate any of above (warfarin, heparin, direct throbmin inhibitors, anti-plt agents, or anti-coagulant agents)
      • Contribution from primary bleeding disorder

      Black stools (melena)?

      Bleeding in upper GI tract

      Stool is typically tarry/sticky and has characteristic odor

      Esophageal

      • Esophagitis (Rfs: assoc w/obesity, ETOH, smoking, caffeine, chocolate, mint; Sx: GERD type→ burning type pain, often worse after meals, worse if lie down after eating, bad taste in mouth, radiates up from epigastrium)
      • Mallory-Weiss Tear (Etiology/Rfs: hx repeated retching)
      • Esophageal cancer or inflammation from other causes typically also have pain and dysphagia
      • Esophageal varices→ seconary to portal htn, whose causes include:
        • Post-hepatic processes→ hepatic vein thrombosis, severe R/L CHF, constrictive pericardial diease, restrictive cardiomypathy
        • Intrahepatic processes→ chronic hepatitis of any etiology including: viral, toxin, autoimmune, infiltrative, malignant; sometimes acute d/o if fulminant or superimposed on chronic
        • Pre-hepatic processes→ portal vein thrombosis, portal vein obstruction from parasites/other

      Gastric d/o

      • Ulcer - gastric or duodenal (Rfs/Etiology: ETOH, h pylori, nsaid use; Sx: epigastric, better or worse w/food, black stools)
      • Stomach cancer (Rfs: 50, smoking, ETOH abuse, h pylori→ MALT assoc; Sx: sub-acute, feel full when eating ever smaller quantities of food, pain, bleeding)
      • Gastritis (Rfs: stress, ETOH, NSAIDs, h pylori; Sx: epigastric pain, black stools, better or worse w/food)
      • Portal gastropathy→ secondary to portal htn
      • Dieulafoys lesions→ sub-mucosal artery (Sx: sudden, brisk bleeding)
      • Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT; formerly Osler-Weber-Rendu) (Etiology: rare congential d/o, AVMs within lungs, nose, mouth, GI tract→ duod, stomach, colon; Sx: onset typically in teens, nose bleeds; cryptic GI bleeds/iron defic anemia, SOB, cryptic stroke or CNS abscess; PE: recurrent nose bleed, telangiectasis on nasal mucosa, lips, tongue)

      Other sources of blood

      • Swallowed blood from upper respiratory source→ nose bleed
      • Swallowed blood from oral bleeding site
      • Aorto-enteric fistula (Rfs: hx AAA graft; Sx: profound bleeding)
      • Meds can exacerbate any of above (warfarin, heparin, direct throbmin inhibitors, anti-plt agents, or anti-coagulant agents)
      • Contribution from primary bleeding disorder

      Unrelated to Bleeding

      Stool is black - but usually not stick/tarry - and doesn't have characteristic odor assoc w/digested blood
      • Iron supplementation
      • Pepto Bismol

      Bloody stools?

      Distal disease more likely to cause obvious bleeding. Upper gi bleeding must be very brisk to cause gross blood in stool.

      Structural

      • Colonic AVM (Sx: typically small amounts blood, avm not visible on exam)
      • Colonic polyp (Sx: typically small amounts blood, polyp not visible on exam)
      • Diverticulum (Sx: acute, bright red blood, can be small or large amnts)
      • External hemorrhoid (Sx: painless bleeding, unless thrombosed; readily visible on exam; if thrombosed then acute pain PE: bluish venous structure in peri-rectal area; readly visible if thrombosed)
      • Internal hemorrhoid (Sx: painless bleeding, small or large amounts, recurrent; rare site of variceal bleeding from portal htn PE: not visible unless use anoscope or prolapsed; blood apparent on digital rectal if bleeding at time)
      • Fissure (Sx: acute, peri-rectal pain, worse w/bowel movement; PE: visible fissure in peri-rectal area, small amounts of blood w/bm)
      • Stercoral ulcer (Rfs/Etiology: older patient, immobile, related to hardened stool in low motility colon, dementia)
      • Rectal varices (Etiology: assoc w/portal htn; much less common than esophageal varices; Rf: any reason for portal htn→ pre, intra, or post-hepatic; Sx: related to chronic liver dz; profound bright red blood per rectum; PE: blood on digital exam, brisk bleeding, abnormal vital signs if sig bleeding)
      • Contribution from primary bleeding disorder
      • Colorectal cancer (adeno) (Rfs: no prior screening or screening > 10y ago, early family hx, polyposis syndromes, UC or colonic crohn's; Sx: anorexia, weight loss, vague pain, persistent/progressive, bloody stools, change in bowel habits, R sided→ fatigue from anemia, L sided→ obstructive sx; palpable if very distal)
      • Anal cancer (squamous cell) (Rfs: squamous cell ca around anus & assoc w/HPV infection, increased incidence w/anal intercourse, HIV, women, men who have sex w/men; Sx: anal pain, tenesmus, bleeding, pain, obstruction PE: palpable mass or diffuse tissue infiltration around anus)

      Inflammatory/Automimmune

      • Ulcerative colitis (Etiology: automimmune, genetic, environmentally triggered, other; affects colon, distal to prox; Rfs: Northen Europeans, North Americans; smoking and appendectomy protective; peak onset 15-30; Sx and PE: sub-acute, recurrent or chronic diarrhea; fatigue, wt loss, bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, nocturnal diarrhea, feeling poorly overall; spectrum from mild to severe; extra-GI: aphtous ulcers, erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosa, peripheral arthritis, ankylosing spond/sacroiliitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, eye sx→ episcleritis/scleritis/uveitis) More from CDC
      • Crohn's disease (Etiology: automimmune, genetic, environmentally triggered, other; transmural involvement; can affect anywhere in GI tract mouth-to-anus; Rfs: smoking and appendectomy increase risk; Northern Europeans and North Americans; peak onset 15-30; Sx: sub-acute, diarrhea→ though can be less prominent than w/UC, nocturnal diarrhea, sometimes bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, fever, abd pain, fatigue, wt loss, feeling poorly overall, fistulas, bowel obstruction, peri-rectal dz; spectrum of sx and findings; PE: sometimes abd mass; peri-rectal disease; extra-GI: aphtous ulcers, erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosa, peripheral arthritis, ankylosing spond/sacroiliitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, eye sx→ episcleritis/scleritis/uveitis) More from CDC
      • XRT induced (Rf/Etiology: hx radiation to lower abd/pv → e.g. prostate; Sx: small amounts of blood)
      • PAN (vasculitis) (Rfs: 40s-50s, men>women; Sx: subacute over mos f, s, malaise, wt loss, muscle/joint pain; multiple systems: arthritis, glomerulonephritis, peripheral nerve pain/dysfxn, skin w/ulcers, purpura; abd pain, blood per rectum)
      • Henoch-schoenlein purpura (vasculitis) (Sx: acute, n, v, sometimes bloody diarrhea, hematuria, renal impairment; PE: purpuric rash→ in partic abd, legs, buttocks; joint swelling and pain)
      • Medications (e.g. Ipilimumab) (Etiology: immune modulating cancer therapy) can cause colitis, as can other meds as well; Sx: dx based on recognizing connection between med & GI bleeding; brb per rectum, non-specific abd pain

      Infxn

      Bacterial

      • Salmonella (non-typhoidal) (Etiology: exposure from eggs, chicken, turtles; most recover in 4-7d; Site: small bowel; Sx: d, n, v, cramps, often w/bloody stools) more from CDC
      • Shigella (Etiology: spread person to person or from food; Site: small bowel; Sx: d, n, v, cramps, often w/bloody stools, typically self limited to 4-7d) more from CDC
      • Campylobacter (Etiology: spread thru contaminated food; Site: small bowel; Sx: d, n, v, cramps, often w/bloody stools, typically self limited to 1w) more from CDC
      • Yersinia enterocolitica (Etiology: spread via contaminated food; Site: small bowel; Sx: f, c, cramps, bloody diarrhea; typically self limited to 4-7d) more from CDC
      • C dif colitis (Etiology: hx exposure to abx or patients w/c dif; Sx: abd pain, diarrhea, blood in stool, cramps, fever) more from CDC
      • E Coli 0157:H7 (Etiology: Occurs in outbreaks, most get better in 5-7d; some can become very ill w/HUS; Sx: f, crampy abd pain, diarrhea, bloody stool) more from CDC

      Parasitic

      • Entamoeba histolytica→ amebiasis (protozoa) (Etiology: acquired via unclean water/poor sanitation, also anal intercourse; Sx: only 10-20% develop sx; incubation 2-4w; abd pain, bloody diarreha; occas liver abscess)
      • Necator americanus (hookworm) (Rfs/Etiology: common world-wide, enter thru feet/skin if walk barefoot in soil w/infected feces → bloodstream → lungs → swallowed → small intestines → blood loss; Sx: fatigue, d)
      • Trichuris (whipworm) (Sx/Etiology: eggs ingested, live in colon; light infxn → Sx: often asx; if heavy burden → abd pain, diarrhea, bloody stools, n, v, anemia)
      • Parasites: CDC

      Viral

      • CMV (RFs: IBD, immune modulating meds; Sx: f, crampy abd pain, bloody diarrhea)

      Bowel Ischemia

      Rfs: Hx known atherosclerosis or Rfs, Rfs for embolic disease→ a fib, ventricular thrombus, acute low BP/low flow superimposed on atherosclerosis; Sx: acute onset bleeding, pain

      Small bowel source

      Small bowel sources less common and harder to visualize on endoscopy.
      • Arterio-venous malformation (Rfs: age > 60, esrd, aortic stenosis, von-willebrand's dz; Sx: painless, bleed intermitently, no source seen on upper or lower endoscopy)
      • Small bowel polyps (Sx: related to familial polyposis syndromes, may have family hx gi malignancy)
      • Meckel's diverticulum (Etiology: ectopic stomach mucosa located in terminal ileum; Sx: can be asx, or cause, abdominal pain, gi bleeding, sbo)
      • Adenocarcinoma (Etiology: can be spontaneous, also assoc w/familial polyposis syndromes, duodenum is most common site; Sx: abd pain, wt loss, occult bleeding)
      • Lymphoma (Sx: sub-acute fever, sweats, abdominal pain, diarrhea, adenopathy elsewhere)
      • Metastatic dz (Sx: related to primary, mets to sb can cause pain, bleeding, obstruction)
      Meds can exacerbate any cause of lower GI bleeding: warfarin, heparin, direct throbmin inhibitors, anti-plt agents, or other anticoagulant agents.

      Constipation?

      • Functional
        • Low fiber diet
        • Irritable Bowel Syndrome (Sx: chronic, crampy pain, no wt loss, no blood in stool; no systemic Sx; can be constipation predominant, diarrhea predominant, or mixed) Rome criteria for functional bowel d/o
      • Obstruction
        • Distal colorectal (adeno) (Rfs: no prior screening or screening > 10y ago, early family hx, polyposis syndromes, UC or colonic crohn's; Sx: anorexia, weight loss, vague pain, persistent/progressive, bloody stools, change in bowel habits, L sided→ obstructive sx; palpable if very distal)
        • Anal cancer (squamous cell) (Rfs: squamous cell ca around anus & assoc w/HPV infection, increased incidence w/anal intercourse, HIV, women, men who have sex w/men; Sx: anal pain, tenesmus, bleeding, pain, obstruction PE: palpable mass or diffuse tissue infiltration around anus)
        • Stricture (Etiology/Rfs: prior surgery, IBD or other inflammatory process)
        • Fecal impaction (Etiology: low liquid intake, impaired awareness/cognition, chronic low motility)
      • Adhesions (Etiology: prior surgery, prior intra-abd infection; Sx: more typically causes acute obstruction, but in some cases can lead to chronic sx)
      • Ileus
        • Post laparotomy - after handling/manipulation instestines → resolves as patient recovers
        • Abdominal inflammatory process (Etiology: abscess, pancreatitis, other→ abates as primary process resolves)
        • Ogilvie's Syndrome → colonic ileus secondary to infection/meds/'lyte disturbance/other problems (Sx: n, v, abd distension, decreased or absent passage gas/stool)
      • Rectal disease causing pain w/defecation
        • Perianal fissure (Sx: Acute pain w/bowel movement, to extent that dont want to defecate, can be recurrent, sometime small amounts of bleeding; PE: visible fissure in peri-rectal area, pain on palpation)
        • Thrombosed external hemorrhoid (Sx: acute peri-rectal pain, sometimes small amount of bleeding; PE: thrombosed hemerrhoid readly visible)
        • Perirectal crohn's dz (Sx: known crohns, rectal bleeding, chronic abd pain, diarrhea, sometimes oral/eye/joint sx; PE: evidence of ulceration, sometimes abscess &/or fistulas in peri-rectal area)
        • Perirectal abscess (Sx: acute pain, peri-rectal swelling, fever; PE: fluctuant, tender, inflamed mass in peri-rectal area, fistula opening sometimes visible)
      • Metabolic/Endocrine
        • Hypothyroidism (Sx: wt gain, edema, dry skin, constipation, cold intolerance, depression/mood change, weakness, fatigue; PE: often no findings aside from wt gain, sometimes decreased reflexes, edema, bradycardia)
        • Hypercalcemia (Rfs/Etiology: known/suspected squamous cell ca, hyperparathyroidism; Sx: polyuria, constipation, confusion, bone pain)
        • Hypo/hyperkalemia (Etiology/Rfs: older, diuretic use, risk for low or high k)
        • Diabetes (Etiology: Neuropathy assoc; Sx: known dz, poor control→ polyuria, polydypsia, neuropathy)
      • Neurologic
        • Spinal cord problems (Etiology: trauma, infection, cancer affecting cord; Sx: urinary incontinence, lower extremity weakness, numbness)
        • Peripheral neuropathy
          • Poorly controlled dm
          • Other
      • Meds→ narcotics, anti-cholinergics

      Diarrhea?

      Acute (< 14d)

      Infection

    • Bacterial
      • Salmonella (non-typhoidal) (Site: small bowel; Rfs: exposure from eggs, chicken, turtles; incubation 12h-3d; most recover in 4-7d; Site: small bowel; Sx: d, n, v, cramps, often w/bloody stools; rarely can spread to distant sites in compromised hosts→ osteomyelitis, endovascular, other) more from CDC
      • Shigella (Etiology: spread person to person or from food; Site: small bowel; Sx: d, n, v, cramps, often w/bloody stools; avg incubation 3d; typically self limited to 4-7d) more from CDC
      • Campylobacter (Etiology: spread thru contaminated food; Site: small bowel; Sx: d, n, v, cramps, often w/bloody stools; incubation 2-5d; typically self limited to 1w) more from CDC
      • Yersinia enterocolitica (Etiology: spread via contaminated food; Site: small bowel; Sx: f, c, cramps, bloody diarrhea; incubation 4-7d; typically self limited to 4-7d) more from CDC
      • C dif colitis (Etiology: hx exposure to abx or patients w/c dif; toxin based; Sx: abd pain, diarrhea, blood in stool, cramps, fever) more from CDC
      • Traveler's diarrhea (Rfs/Etiology: diarrhea after travel to another country - central/south America, asia, africa; secondary to variety of enteric pathogens, from consuming undercooked food/poor hygiene in restaurants/untreated water; Sx: n, v, cramps, usually self limited) more from CDC
      • Staph toxin assoc diarrhea (Rfs/Etiology: secondary to eating contaminated food, occurs hours after consumption, other affected who ate similar; Sx: abrupt onset n, v, cramps, non-bloody d, self limited) more from CDC
      • C perfringens→ toxin based (Rfs/Etiology: secondary to eating contaminated food, occurs hours after consumption, other affected who ate similar, self limited; Sx: abrupt onset n, v, cramps, non-bloody d) more from CDC
      • E Coli 0157:H7 (Etiology: Occurs in outbreaks, most get better in 5-7d; some can become very ill w/HUS; Sx: F, crampy abd pain, diarrhea, bloody stool) more from CDC
      • Vibrio cholera (Etiology/Rfs: toxin mediated profound watery diarrhea, related to exposure to unclean water sources, often s/p natural disasters→ presents as epidemics; Site: small bowel; Sx: profound watery diarrhea; can lead to hypovoemic death in hours if severe) more from CDC
      • Vibrio vulnificus and parahemolytics (Rfs/Sites: causes bacteremia→ sepsis in hosts w/cirrhosis or otherwise compromised hosts, exposure via raw/under cooked shellfish; wound/skin infection if same hosts exposed via inoculation w/affected water→ walking in surf w/exposed wounds in endemic area; Sx: acute n, v, f, cramps, diarrhea; extremity pain and swelling if via wound) more from CDC
    • Viral
      • Rotavirus (Etiology/Rfs: common cause of acute enteritis in kids <5; vaccine preventable; Sx: abrupt onset n, v, f, diarrhea) more from CDC
      • Norovirus (Etiology/Rfs: common cause of acute enteritis in adults, daycare/hospitals/nursing homes; Sx: abrupt onset n, v, f, diarrhea) more from CDC
      • CMV (RFs: IBD, immune modulating meds; Sx: f, crampy abd pain, bloody diarrhea)
    • Parasites
      • Cryptosporidia (Rfs: young/old/immunocomp at greatest risk, spread fecal oral, assoc w/daycare center outbreaks; Sx: n, v, cramps, fever)
      • Giardia (protozoa) (Etiology: spread via poor hygiene, contaminated water, drinking from ponds/streams, anal intercourse; many infected are asx; Sx: incubation 1-3w; non-bloody watery/greasy/foul smelling diarrhea, gas, burping)
      • Entamoeba histolytica→ amebiasis (protozoa) (Etiology: acquired via unclean water/poor sanitation, also anal intercourse; Sx: only 10-20% develop sx; incubation 2-4w; abd pain, bloody diarrhea; occas liver abscess)
      • Parasites: CDC

      Inflammatory

      • Inflammatory Bowel Disease - Crohns or UC (Sx: Sub-acute, recurrent or chronic; wt loss, bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, nocturnal diarrhea; systemic; presentation can also be fulminant; Crohns can affect entire GI tract, UC colon only→ distal to prox) more from CDC
      • Microscopic colitis (Rfs: women > men, age >50; Sx: chronic diarrhea, blood w/mucous, wt loss)
      • XRT induced (Rfs: radiation to lower abd/pv→ e.g. prostate; Sx: small amounts of blood; rectal/abd pain, diarrhea, urgency)

      Other non GI

      • Hyperthyroidism (Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, wt loss, weakness, infetility, ED, menstrual irreg; PE: sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid, hyper-reflexia, moist skin)
      • Laxative, sorbitol, other meds abuse
      • Excessive caffeine intake, etc.
      • Niacin deificiency (Etiology: nutritional deficiency; Sx: chronic, prgressive, symmetric, erythematous erruption, puritic, can resemble sunburn, often V-area of neck, skin is often dry & rough appearing; diarrhea; irritability, anxiety, delusions, apathy; symmetric, painful peripheral sensory and motor neuropathy, arms and legs)

      Chronic

      Structural problems

      • Distal colorectal or anal malignancy (Sx: progressive, wt loss, pain, blood in stool, nocturnal diarrhea)
      • Benign stricture (Etiology: prior surgery, IBD or other inflammatory process)

      Inflammatory

      • Ulcerative colitis (Etiology: automimmune, genetic, environmentally triggered, other; affects colon, distal to prox; Rfs: Northen Europeans, North Americans; smoking and appendectomy protective; peak onset 15-30; Sx and PE: sub-acute, recurrent or chronic diarrhea; fatigue, wt loss, bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, nocturnal diarrhea, feeling poorly overall; spectrum from mild to severe; extra-GI: aphtous ulcers, erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosa, peripheral arthritis, ankylosing spond/sacroiliitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, eye sx→ episcleritis/scleritis/uveitis) More from CDC
      • Crohn's disease (Etiology: automimmune, genetic, environmentally triggered, other; transmural involvement; can affect anywhere in GI tract mouth-to-anus; Rfs: smoking and appendectomy increase risk; Northern Europeans and North Americans; peak onset 15-30; Sx: sub-acute, diarrhea→ though can be less prominent than w/UC, nocturnal diarrhea, sometimes bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, fever, abd pain, fatigue, wt loss, feeling poorly overall, fistulas, bowel obstruction, peri-rectal dz; spectrum of sx and findings; PE: sometimes abd mass; peri-rectal disease; extra-GI: aphtous ulcers, erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosa, peripheral arthritis, ankylosing spond/sacroiliitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, eye sx→ episcleritis/scleritis/uveitis) More from CDC
      • Microscopic colitis (Rfs: women > men, age >50; Sx: chronic diarrhea, blood w/mucous, wt loss)
      • XRT induced (Rfs: radiation to lower abd/pelvis→ e.g. prostate; Sx: small amounts of blood; rectal/abd pain, diarrhea, urgency)

      Infection

    • Bacterial
      • C dif colitis (Etiology: hx exposure to abx or patients w/c dif; Sx: typically acute abd pain, diarrhea, blood in stool, cramps, fever; sometimes chronic, recurrent or persistent) more from CDC
      • Bacterial & viral pathogens described under "acute diarrhea" rarely cause chronic sx
    • Parasites
      • Clonorchis (fluke) (Eiol: Asia/East Asia, humans infected by eating uncooked fish or contaminated water; live in bile ducts; Sx: can cause biliary obstruction → abd pain, wt loss, diarrhea, jaundice)
      • Cryptosporidia (Rfs: young/old/immunocomp at greatest risk, spread fecal oral, assoc w/daycare center outbreaks; Sx: n, v, d, cramps, fever)
      • Cyclospora (Etiology: most common in tropics/subtropics; outbreaks in US assoc w/contaminated produce; Sx: ~ 1w after exposure→ cramps, bloating, gas, diarrhea, wt loss; often self limited, though can recur)
      • Entamoeba histolytica→ amebiasis (protozoa) (Etiology: acquired via unclean water/poor sanitation, also anal intercourse; Sx: only 10-20% develop sx; incubation 2-4w; abd pain, bloody diarreha; occas liver abscess)
      • Giardia (protozoa) (Etiology: spread via poor hygiene, contaminated water, drinking from ponds/streams, anal intercourse; many infected are asx; Sx: incubation 1-3w; non-bloody watery/greasy/foul smelling diarrhea, gas, burping)
      • Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) (Etiology: found worldwide, common in children, situations w/poor sanitation; ingest eggs via contaminated water or hand to mouth; lives in the ileum Sx: cramps, diarrhea, n, v, wt loss)
      • Microsporidiosis (Etiology/Rfs: associated with drinking untreated water, CD4 < 100 or untreated HIV; Sx: in addn to diarrhea, can affect other systems, causing→ keratitis, encephalitis, other)
      • Necator americanus (hookworm) (Etiology: common world-wide, enter thru feet/skin if walk barefoot in soil w/infected feces→ bloodstream→ lungs→ swallowed→ small intestines Sx: of fatigue from blood loss→ anemia, d)
      • Schistosomiasis (fluke) (Etiology: South America, Middle East, Caribbean, Africa: flukes, invade skin of swimmers, enter blood stream→ live in portal/mesenteric veins; Sx: itching and erruption during first few days @ site where enters skin; can cause portal htn after years; also f, c, abd pain, diarrhea; can live in bladder → SCC after years)
      • Strongyloidiasis (Etiology: warm/temperate regions including southeast US, tropics/subtropics including Asia/Southeast Asia; larvae enter thru feet/skin if walk barefoot in soil w/infected feces→ enter skin, where they can cause itching→ travel to lung→ penetrate alveoli and travel up trachea→ cough and then swallowed→ travel to and live in small intestine; Sx: most carry life-long w/o any sx; non-compromised hosts can have vague sx including cough, epigastic pain, weakness, watery diarrhea, constipation; can cause life threatening hyper-infxn syndrome w/systemic symptoms if compromised from glucocorticoids, malignancy, HTLV-1 or organ transplant; PE: sometimes serpiginous red erruption from migrating larva under skin)
      • Trichinella (aka trichinosis) (Etiology: rare in US; from eating infected meat; Sx: abd pain, n, v, diarrhea; after 1-2w, muscle pain when migrate to muscles, rash, ha, n, v)
      • Trichuriass (whipworm) (Etiology: eggs ingested, live in colon; Sx: w/light infxn→ asx; heavy burden→ abd pain, diarrhea, bloody stools, n, v, anemia)
      • More on Parasites: CDC

      Malabsorptive D/O

      • Celiac disease (Sx: chronic bloating, gas, wt loss/inability to gain weight, fatigue, joint pain)
      • Pancreatic insufficiency (exocrine) (Etiology: chronic pancreatitis from any cause including: ETOH abuse or other chronic exposure to pancreatitis inducing toxins/process; Sx: diarrhea, wt loss, chronic upper abdominal pain, back pain, nausea)
      • Pancreatic cancer(Sx: anorexia, weight loss, epigastric pain radiating to back, persistent/progressive, sometimes diarrhea)
      • Lactose intolerance (Sx: n, bloating, gas, abd discomfort→ within 2 hours eating milk/milk products)
      • T Whipplei (Whipple's disease) (Etiology: possibly sewage, fecal oral spread; RFs: male>female, age 40-60; Sx: rare d/o, multipple chronic sx; wt loss, diarrhea, abd pain, fatigue; intermitent migratory arthritis that sometimes precedes GI sx x years, involves larger joints→ knees, wrists, ankles; f, adenopathy; broad range neuro sx→ cog impairment, uveitis, ha, supranuclear ophthalmoplegia, other; also skin, cardiac, pulmonary)
      • Small intestine bacterial overgrowth (Etiology: small bowel typically has few bacteria; processes that inhibit motility or create blind pouches promote sb bacterial growth; RFs: any surgery that creates blind limbs→ eg gastrectomy w/bil II; IBD; impaired intestinal motility for any reason, systemic sclerosis; decreased gastric acid; Sx: bloating, gas, steatorrhea, wt loss, non-specific abdominal discomfort; b12 and vit D deficiency)
      • Short gut after resection of large amount of small bowel (Etiology: Loss of absorptive surface area results in malabsorption, malnutrition and chronic diarrhea; can cause bacterial overgrowth; Rfs: extensive small bowel resection; Sx: diarrhea, malnutrition, wt loss, bloating, gas)
      • Mesenteric/small bowel ischemia (Sx: generalized abd/epigastric pain, known atherosclerosis or RFs, progressive/persistent pain after meals→ angina of the gut→ food avoidance→ weight loss, diarrhea)

      Irritable Bowel Syndrome/Functional

      Sx: chronic, no wt loss, crampy pain, no systemic sx, no blood, can be constipation or diarrhea predominant, or mixed Rome criteria for functional bowel d/o

      Other

      • Hyperthyroidism (Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, wt loss, weakness, infetility, ED, menstrual irreg; PE: sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid, hyper-reflexia, moist skin)
        • Graves Dz (Etiology: autoimmune; RFs: female > male, ages 40-60; most common cause of hyperthyroidism 50-80% of cases; Sx: as above; typically progressive over 2-3m; PE: diffusely enlarged thyroid, sometimes bruit; exopthalmous/ophthalmopathy in up to 25%; otherwise as above)
        • Painless thyroiditis (Etiology: autoimmune; Rfs: often post partum; Sx: as above, onset over < 3m)
        • Painful thyroiditis (Etiology: often post-viral; Sx: acute, painful thyroid and neck, fatigue; Sx: initially hyperthyroid ~6w, then hypothyroid ~4-6w; may return to euthyroid or remain hypo; PE: painful thryoid)
        • Toxic multi-nodular goiter (Etiology: often in regions of world that are iodine deficient; RFs: age > 50, women > men; Sx: as above, severity and timing onset vary; PE: palpable nodularity)
        • Toxic solitary adenoma (Etiology: idiopathic, single, hyperfunctioning nodule; Rfs> increasing age, women > men; PE: sometimes single palpable nodule)
        • Exogenous thyroid hormone consumption (Etiology: unintentional or intentional over rx in patient w/known hyperthyroidim; surreptitious use of thyroid hormone in someone w/o thyroid dz, perhaps to aid w/weight loss, other)
      • Laxative, sorbitol, other meds abuse
      • Excessive caffeine intake, etc.
      • Neuroendocrine tumors (Etiology: unusual tumors including: carcinoid, vip-oma, gastrinoma; Sx: wt loss, abd pain, flushing, diarrhea→ which can be profound, palpatations)

      Diarrhea in HIV +

      Can still be any of the processes that affect normal hosts as above; also HIV meds; other infectious or malignancy related Etiologyogies increase as cd4 levels decline:

      Infection

      • Parasite
        • Isosporiasis (Rfs: CD4 < 100 or untreated HIV, associated with drinking untreated water)
        • Giardia (protozoa) (Etiology: spread via poor hygiene, contaminated water, drinking from ponds/streams, anal intercourse; many infected are asx; Sx: incubation 1-3w; non-bloody watery/greasy/foul smelling diarrhea, gas, burping)
        • Cryptosporidium (Rfs: CD4 < 100 or untreated HIV; Sx: acute or subacute profound diarrhea, abdominal cramps, fever, n, v, )
        • Microsporidiosis (Etiology/Rfs: associated with drinking untreated water, CD4 < 100 or untreated HIV; Sx: in addn to diarrhea, can affect other systems, causing→ keratitis, encephalitis, other)
      • Fungal
        • Histoplasmosis (Rfs: CD4 < 150; Sx: f, c, wt loss, abd pain; liver, spleen and lymph node involvement)
      • Mycobacteria
        • MAI (Rfs: CD4 < 50; Sx: diarrhea, n, v, abdominal pain, f, c, fatigue; can infect liver, spleen, lymph nodes, bone marrow, lung, pericardium→ causing adenopathy or organomegaly, anemia)
      • Viral
        • CMV (Rfs: CD 4 < 50; Sx: cramps, abd pain persistent diarrhea - sometimes w/blood, anorexia, wt loss, fatigue, cmv elsewhere→ retinitis)

      Malignancy

      • Kaposis (Rfs: CD4 < 150, KS on skin or elsewhere on body)
      • Lymphoma (in partic NHL) (Sx: subacute, f, sweats, wt loss, adenopathy elsewhere, unexplained organogmegaly, focal cns sx)
      More on HIV from the CDC

      More Info About Gastrointestinal Disorders:
      National Digestive Diseases Clearinghouse, Comprehensive GI exam

      Back

      Genitourinary/Renal

      Comprehensive male genital/rectal exam

      Chronic or past GU disorders?

      • BPH, cancer, stones, intrinsic renal disease, erectile dysfxn, utis, etc

      Hematuria or oddly colored urine?

      GU cancer

        Gross, persistent hematuria coupled w/+ Rfs increases liklihood malignancy.
      • Urothelial malignancy of GU tract - bladder, ureters, renal pelvis (Rfs: persistent gross blood, age > 50, male, hx smoking→ transitional cell ca; squamous cell if chronic foley or hx shistosomiasis)
      • Renal cell (Rfs: smoking, obesity, family hx, male > female, avg ages mid 60s; Sx: low back to lower abd/groin discomfort, wt loss, sweats, fever, flank pain, hematuria; PE: papable only if very advanced)
      • Prostate cancer (Rfs: male, > 50, urgency; Sx: frequency, delayed emptying, hematuria; bone pain if mets)

      GU infxn

      • Cystitis (Etiology: typically gram negatives that enter bladder thru urethra; Rfs: stasis for any reason→ e.g. bph; foreign bodies→ stones or catheters; females→ short urethra, micro trauma from intercourse; Sx: acute, pain, frequency, urgency, often w/o fever; PE: sometimes supra-pubic discomfort w/palpation)
      • Prostatitis (Sx: acute, frequency, sometimes systemic sx; PE: prostate tender on exam)
      • Epididymo-orchitis (Sx: acute pain w/urination, frequency, urgency; Etiology: bacterial similar to UTI or gc/chlamydia; less common: TB, viral, med related; PE: swollen & tender epididymis and testis, doesn't transiluminate, urethral d/c if sti)

      Other benign GU probs

      • BPH (Rfs: male, >50; Sx: chronic, progressive, urgency, frequency, hesitancy, difficulty starting/stopping stream, incomplete emptying, decrease force, voiding again soon after urinate)
      • Stones (Etiology: 80% calcium oxalate from hypercalcuria which is usually idiopathic; others are: struvite→ infxn w/proteus, klebsiella; uric acid; cyctine rare; Sx: if stone obstructing kidney or ureter: acute colicky pain any where from flank → penis, urinary frequency/urgency, nausea, vomiting, patient cant sit still or find comfortable position; non-obstructing stones can cause painless hematuria)
      • Renal infarct (Etiology: a fib or other RFs for embolic event; hypercoag state; Sx: acute and severe flank/back pain, n, v, f; PE: pain on palpation)

      Glomerulonephritis

      Conditions that cause glomerulnephritis are typically associated w/systemic sx. They will also have abnormal urinalyses (in particular, red cell casts) and evidence of decline in GFR. The hematuria may be gorss or microscopic.
      • Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss) (Etiology: idiopathic d/o, small-to-medium vessel vasculitis; w/high levels circulating and tissue invasive eosinophils; Rfs: men=women, assoc also w/leukotriene antagonists; Sx: progressive, adult onset asthma, cough & wheezing, nasal stuffiness→ w/resp sx usually ~2-10 y prior to systemic sx assoc w/eosinophilic deposition in target organs and vasculitis; in these later phases→ systemic sx including: sob from parenchymal lung involvement; f, c, muscle aches; hematuria from renal involvement; heart failure, pericarditis and dysrhythmia w/cardiac involvement; peripheral neuropathy; PE: wheezing, skin findings of vasculitis: small, palapable purpura, don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; hematuria/renal involvement; unexplained peripheral neuropathy)
      • Goodpastures (Etiology: ab directed agnts basement membrane; Sx: f, sweats, cough, sob, hemoptysis and hematuria)
      • Granulomatosis with poyangiitis (Wegeners) (Etiology: small-to-medium vessel vasculitis; Sx: vasculitis→ recurrent/progressive nasal congestion, cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; peripheral nerve dysfxn; PE: mucosal erythema, ulcer, nasal septum perf, unexplained peripheral neuropathy)
      • Henoch-schoenlein purpura (vasculitis) (Etiology: small vessel vasculitis; Rfs: most common in kids, though can occur in adults; Sx: acute, n, v, sometimes bloody diarrhea, hematuria, renal impairment; PE: purpuric rash→ in partic abd, legs, buttocks; joint swelling and pain)
      • IgA Nephropathy (Etiology: ab-agn complex deposition; most common cause of glomerulonephritis world wide; Rf: male > female, male, young, Asian; Sx: gross hematuria, often at time of resp or gi infxn→ a period of IgA activation)
      • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
      • Microscopic polyangitis (MPA) (Etiology: small-vessel vasculitis; Sx: fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, sweats, wt loss; recurrent/progressive cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; less often nasal sx c/w GPA; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; skin ulcers; neuropathy; PE: palpable purpura, skin ulcer/necrosis)
      • Polyarteritis Nodosa (vasculitis) (Rfs: 40s-50s, men>women, Hep B/C; Sx: more commonly subacute over mos f, s, malaise, wt loss, muscle/joint pain; multiple systems: arthritis, glomerulonephritis, peripheral nerve pain/dysfxn, skin w/ulcers, small, palpable purpura→ don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; abd pain, blood per rectum)
      • Post-infectious glomerulonephritis (Etiology: most commonly post-streptococcal skin or pharyngenal infxn though can follow other bacterial or viral infxns; Rf: male > female, typical age 2-10; Sx: painless, onset 10-14 d after infxn, htn, fatigue, weakness, dark (coca-cola) colored urine; often lab evidence decline in GFR, proteinuria; most episodes resolve spontaneously)
      • Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (Etiology: an accelerated glomerulonephritis secondary to any of the following: Ab against basement membrane (e.g. Goodpastures), Immune complex deposition (e.g. lupus nephritis, IgA nephropathy) or ANCA+ vasculitis (e.g. granulomatosis w/polyangiitis); Sx: generalized fatigue, wt loss, dark urine, edema over weeks to mos; PE: htn, edema, gross hematuria)

      Non-GU causes

      • Contribution from primary bleeding disorder
      • Vaginal or lower GI source mistaken as hematuria
      • Myoglobin
        • Rhabdomyolysis (Etiology: muscle breakdown from: extreme muscle activity, trauma, prolonged immobility assoc w/loss of consciousness; Sx: muscle pain; PE: can be ill appearing; dark urine, decreased GFR on labs)
        • Rhabdomyolysis: meds→ statins
      • Bilirubinuria (Etiology: related to elevated levels of direct bilirubin, urine appears dark, typically associated with chronic liver inflammation/cholestasis→ w/findings of chronic liver dz; also w/processes that cause biliary tract obstruction, severe acute liver injury, or hemolysis)
      • Dehydration→ concentrated urine
      • Beet ingestion→ beeturia
      • Meds→ e.g. rifampin, pyridium

      Edema?

      Lower extremity exam

      Bilateral

      Nephrotic Syndrome

      Nephrotic Syndrome→ profound loss of protein in urine→ > 3.5g protein/d; also assoc w/decline in GFR, htn, hyperlipidemia & hypercoag; sometimes urine is frothy
      • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (Etiology: Primary FSGS→ most common cause idiopathic nephrotic syndrome→ 30-50% of cases, particularly common in black adults; Secondary FSGS→ Hiv, obesity, heroin, other; primary or secondary can progress to ESRD; Sx: edema, other can be related to primary process; PE: htn, edema)
      • Membranous nephropathy (Etiology/Rfs: accounts for ~30% of nephrotic syndrome in adults; age > 50; idiopathic though assoc w/Hep B or C, SLE, meds, malignancy; Sx: volume overload; PE: HTN, peripheral edema, sometimes periorbial and hand edema)
      • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (Etiology/Rfs: accounts for ~25-30% of neprhotic syndrome; mixed neprhritic/neprhrotic picture; assoc w/hep c, sbe/other systemic infxn, cancer, lupus, cryoglobulinemias, other: Sx: sometimes related to other/primary d/o; volume overload; PE: volume overalod, htn)
      • Minimal change glomerulopathy (Etiology: acounts for 70-90% of Nephrotic syndrome in kids; 10-15% in adults; idiopathic though assoc w/meds (lithium, nsaids), infxn (mono); malignancies (lymphoma); Sx: volume overload; PE: HTN, peripheral edema, sometimes periorbial and hand edema)
      • Diabetes (Etiology/Rfs: nephropathy secondary to chronic, poorly controled DM w/resultant glomerular disease; most common cause of nephropathy; assoc w/progression esrd; Sx: asssoc w/long standing DM including peripheral neurop, retinopathy, pad, cad; PE: htn, proliferative retinop, peripheral neurop, diminished pulses, lower extremity edema)
      • Other systemic disease that cause nephropathy: amyloidosis, multiple myeloma, HIV, hepatitis B

      Other low oncotic pressure

      • Advanced liver disease (Sx/Etiology: known liver disease from viral/etoh/other chronic hepatitis; w/decreased synthetic fxn and low albumin; Sx: lower extremity edema along w/ascites and other findings chronic liver dz; PE: leg edema, ascites, jaundice, icterus)
      • Malnutrition (Etiology: lack of access to calories, disadvantaged socio-economic status; resulting in low albumin; Sx: weakness, fatigue PE: muscle wasting→ temporal area in particular)
      • Malabsorption w/in GI tract assoc w/chronic diarrhea - e.g. pancreatic insufficiency, short gut syndrome, Whipple's dz, other
      • Severe anemia - as hgb contributes to oncotic pressure of blood

      Genl Vol Overload

      • Cirrhosis (Sx/PE assoc w/chronic liver dz→ hep C, ETOH)
      • Renal failure

      Left sided HF

    • HF w/depressed EF
        • HF exam findings (Sx: C/V RFs, orthopnea, PND, sob, doe; PE: lower extremity edema , + S3, elevated jvp, displaced pmi, rales on lung exam)
        • CAD→ past MI - most common cause in US
        • Aortic stenosis (Etiology: most common sEtiology adult calcific age >70; bicuspid age > 40; rheumatic heart disease Sx: initially asx, then can have SOB, syncope, chest pain, chf as stenosis worsens; PE: characterisitc systolic murmur, crescendo-decrescendo, later peaking as progresses, other findings CHF)
        • Aortic regurgitation (Etiology: common Etiology include bicuspid valve, Marfans/connective tissue d/o, rheumatic heart dz, aortic root dil from htn; acute regurg from endocarditis or dissection; Sx: Chronic regurg leads to slow development sx; acute regurg→ acute sx PE: characteristic diastolic murmur, other findings CHF)
        • Mitral regurgitation (Etiology: chronic→ mitral valve prolapse, prior endocarditis, ring dilataion from dilated LV, rheumatic heart dz; acute→ endocarditis, infarct; Sx: acute regurg→ acute sx CHF; chronic→ chronic CHF sx PE: holosystolic murmur, other findings CHF)
        • Sub-Aortic stenosis (Etiology: idiopathic, can present from kids to adults; Sx: initially asx, then chf develop as degree of obstruction worsens, also syncope; systolic murmur; louder w/decreased preload)
        • Meds/toxins (Etiology: etoh, cocaine, anthracycline based chemo→ doxarubicin, cyclophasphamide, many others)
        • Chronic svt w/poorly controlled ventricular response
        • Long standing and poorly controlled HTN
        • Dilated cardiomyopathy (Etiology: idiopathic; Sx: chf-type)
        • Other metabolic or response to unusual stresses (Etiology: profound hypothyroidism; peri-partum; hyperthyroidism; secondary to sepsis; following a very stressful event→ Takotubo→ usually transient; Amyloid assoc)
        • Infection associated myocarditis (Etiology: HIV; post viral→ coxscakie, influenza, other; lyme; Chagas; other
        • Autoimmune associated (Etiology: related to Lupus, giant cell myocarditis, other)
    • HF w/preserved EF
        • HF exam findings(C/V RFs, orthopnea, PND, exam findings: lower extremity edema, + S3, elevated jvp, rales on lung exam)
        • Typically assoc with chronic poorly controlled htn (Rfs: long standing htn, age > 50 and in partic > 75, dm, hyperlipidemia, obesity)
        • Aortic stenosis (Etiology: most common sEtiology adult calcific age >70; bicuspid age > 40; rheumatic heart disease Sx: initially asx, then can have SOB, syncope, chest pain, chf as stenosis worsens; PE: characterisitc systolic murmur, crescendo-descrendo, later peaking as progresses, other findings CHF)
        • Aortic regurgitation(Etiology: common Etiology include bicuspid valve, Marfans/connective tissue d/o, rheumatic heart dz, aortic root dil from htn; acute regurg from endocarditis or dissection; Sx: Chronic regurg leads to slow development sx; acute regurg→ acute sx PE: characteristic diasoltic murmur, other findings CHF)
        • Mitral regurgitation (Etiology: chronic→ mitral valve prolapse, prior endocarditis, ring dilatation from dilated LV, rheumatic heart dz; acute→ endocarditis, inferior infarct, rupture chordae; Sx: acute regurg→ acute sx CHF; chronic→ chronic CHF sx PE: holosytolic murmur, other findings CHF)
        • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (Etiology: idiopathic, can present from kids to adults; can have symmetric, focal or obstructive hypertrophy, Sx: initially asx, then chf develop as degree of obstruction worsens, also syncope or sudden death from spontaneous VT; PE: CHF findings, systolic murmur if obstructive which gets louder w/decreased preload)
        • Mitral stenosis (Etiology: overall, very uncommon in US; related to rheumatic heart dz or congenital sx, can have regurg as well; Sx: asx initially, then CHF as progresses, worse if superimposed SVT, characteristic diastolic murmur, other findings CHF)
        • Pulmonary vein stenosis (Etiology: complication of ablation procedure for a fib)
    • Tamponade
        • Etiology: post pericarditis from: cardiac surgery, infection→ TB or bacterial, cancer related, metabolic d/c→ hypothyroid/renal failure, automimmune d/o, XRT assoc; med related, idiopathic, traumatic; PE: elevated jvp, soft heart sounds, elevated hr, low bp, pulsus paradoxus
      • Rapid accumulation of fluid (Sx: rapid development of sob, doe, chest pain, other CHF-type sx, clinical decompensation)
      • Slow accumulation of fluid (Sx: better tolderated, slower development of sob, doe, feeling non-specifically poorly, chf-type sx)
    • Constrictive Pericardial Dz
      • Pericarditis for any reason that leads to scarring and loss of pericardial elasticitiy (Sx: chronic/progressive sob, doe, other CHF-type sx, feeling poorly in general)
    • High Output HF
        • A-V fistula (Etiology: trauma, inflamation or surgery induced PE: might hear bruit over site)
        • Hyperthyroidism (Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, wt loss, weakness; PE: sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid, hyper-reflexia)
