        • Anemia
        • Thiamine deficiency (Etiology: ETOH abuse Sx/PE: confusion, extremity numbness/difficulty walking)
        • Paget's disease (Rf: > 50 Sx: slowly progressive multi-site bone pain, leg bowing)
    • Rhythm Related
        • Too Fast: acute SVT (Sx: rapid heart rate, palpatations, doe)
        • Too slow: bradycardia (Sx: fatigue, decreased exercise tolerance, CHF symptoms)

      Right sided HF

      • Secondary to L sided HF
      • Pulmonary emboli (RFs for dvt/pulm embolous→ immobility, trauma, hypercoaguable state; Sx: acute or subactue if recurrent events, cough, SOB, pleuritic cp, hemoptysis; PE: unexplained unliateral edema; Well's Criteria for DVT; Well's Criteria for PE)
      • Pulmonary HTN
        • Idiopathic pulmonary htn (Rfs: women > men Sx: vague chest pain, subacute sob worse w/activity, dizziness with activity; PE: elevated jvp, edema, right ventricular heave, loud p2, rapid heart rate)
        • Other causes of pulmonary htn (Etiology: sleep apnea, chf, chronic pulmonary emboli, HIV, connective tissue d/o if hx scleroderma or rheum arthritis; congenital heart disease)
      • R sided valvular heart dz
        • Primary Pulmonary stenosis or regurg → almost always congenital
        • Tricuspid regurg: Secondary process (Etiology: from L sided CHF, Pulm htn, etc)
        • Tricuspid regurg: Primary valvular abnl (Etiology: endocarditis; direct damage from trauma; assoc w/carcinoid)
        • Tricuspid stenosis (Etiology: very uncommon → congenital, tumor, carinoid)

      Portal Htn

      Etiology: prehepatic, hepatic and post hepatic; Rfs: hepatic inflam/fibrosis→ known liver disease from viral/etoh/other chronic hepatitis→ cirrhosis; Sx: abdominal swelling, sob PE: ascites, jaundice, icterus

      Venous insufficiency

      Sx: chronic, better in AM, worse after standing/end of day, scaly and sometimes itchy; PE: bilateral, chronic bluish discoloration

      Immobility or Paralysis

      Lack of muscular pumping action, in particular if coupled w/dependent positioning of legs

      B DVT or IVC Obstruction

      Rfs/Etiology: uncommmon c/w unilateral; associated w/significant hypercoaguability

      Lymphatic Obstruction

      • Lymphatic injury (Etiology: lymph node dissection, trauma; PE Lymph edema, doughy, non-pitting)
      • Obstructing cancer
      • Idiopathic, prior bacterial infections, prior parasitic infection, obesity

      Inflammatory/Other

      • Bilateral cellulitis (Etiology: uncommon c/w unilateral; Sx: acute, red, fever, sometimes skin break as portal; PE: red and edematous)
      • Meds - in particular dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers
      • Hypothyroidism (Sx: wt gain, edema, dry skin, constipation, cold intolerance, depression/mood change, weakness, fatigue; PE: often no findings aside from wt gain, sometimes decreased reflexes, edema, bradycardia)

      Unilateral Edema

      Inflammatory

      • Cellulitis (Sx: acute redness, pain, fever; PE: red, tender, focal edema)
      • Necrotizing fasciitis (Etiology: relatively uncommon; assoc w/dm, impaired immunity or perfusion; typically polymicrobial: strep, staph, clostridium, other; Sx: acute pain, swelling, fever, toxic appearing, often rapidly progressive; PE: typically abnl vs consistent w/severe illness, skin findings sometimes subtle→ redness, bulla; more profound findings as dz progresses) LRINEC Score
      • Diabetic muscular infarct (Etiology: related to small vessel infarct in leg → typically patient w/DM; Sx: acute pain, swelling; PE: non-specific→ may have redness)
      • Trauma→ compartment syndrome (Etiology: significant LE trauma/crush injury → in partic to lower leg; Sx/PE: severe pain, swelling, numbness, weakness, decreased pulses)
      • Pyomyositis (Etiology: related to deep muscle infection w/seeding from direct trauma/injury or bacteremia; relatively uncommon, affecting compromised hosts→ DM, HIV; Sx: acute pain, swelling, fevers/systemic illness)
      • Gout or pseudogout (Sx: sometimes inflammation in foot or ankle can be so intense that diffuse edema develops; may have hx gout or pseudogout prior; PE: pain, warmth, redness, edema, decreased range of motion of involved joint)
      • Joint infection (Etiology:trauma w/direct path of infection into joint, or systemic seeding; Sx: infection w/in joint of foot or ankle can be so intense that causes diffuse edema; also fever and systemic sx; PE: fever, redness, edema, focused over dominantly affected joint, pain worse w/any movement)

      Hydrostatic

      • DVT (RFs: hypercoaguable state, immobility, trauma; Sx: acute swelling, localized discomfort; PE: unilateral edema otherwise unexplained, Well's Criteria to quantify liklihood)
      • Lymphatic obstruction
        • Lymphatic injury (Etiology: lymph node dissection, trauma; PE: Lymph edema, doughy, non-pitting)
        • Obstructing cancer (Sx: may relate to primary malignancy; PE: may have palpable inguinal nodes, Lymph edema, doughy, non-pitting)
        • Idiopathic, prior bacterial infections, prior parasitic infection, obesity
      • Massive DVT (phlegmasia cerulea dolens) (Etiology: unusual, massive proximal dvt, assoc w/hypercoag state; Sx: acute welling, pain, evidence arterial insufficiency/ischemia secondary to increased tissue pressure; PE: marked asymmetric edema, diminished pulses, delayed capillary refill, cool, dusky/bluish skin appearance)
      • Venous insufficiency (Etiology: sometimes hx saphenous vein harvest w/CABG or DVT; Sx: chronic edema, worse after standing, better in morning after lying; PE: chronic edema, dark/bluish skin discoloration))

      Ruptured Baker's cyst

        Sx: asx aside from edema, presence of cyst behind knee often not known prior

      Dysuria?

      Infection

      • Simple UTI/cystitis (Etiology: typically gram negatives that enter bladder thru urethra; Rfs: stasis for any reason→ e.g. bph; foreign bodies→ stones or catheters; females→ short urethra, micro trauma from intercourse; Sx: acute, pain, frequency, urgency, often w/o fever; PE: sometimes supra-pubic discomfort w/palpation)
      • Prostatitis (Etiology; GNRs; Sx: acute, frequency, sometimes systemic sx; can also be chronic or recurrent; PE: prostate tender on exam)
      • Epididymo-orchitis (Etiology: GNRs, chlamydia/GC if from STI; Sx: acute pain w/urination, frequency, urgency; Etiology: bacterial similar to UTI or gc/chlamydia; less common: TB, viral, med related; PE: swollen & tender epididymis and testis, doesn't transiluminate, urethral d/c if sti)
      • Pyelonephritis (Etiology: typically GNRs, from ascending urinary tract infxn; sometimes obstruction/anatomic predisposition; less common from hematogenous spread; Sx: acute low back/flank pain, f, c, n, v; dysuria, urinary frequency/urgency if concomitant cystitis; PE: f, cvat, flank pain on palpation)
      • Perinephric Abscess (Etiology: typically GNRs; complication of pyelonephritis; often assoc w/stones or obstruction for other reason; can also be from hematogenous spread; Sx: acute low back/flank pain, f, c, n, v; dysuria, urinary frequency/urgency if concomitant cystitis; PE: f, cvat, flank pain on palpation)
      • Urethritis→ gonorrhea, chlamydia (Rfs: + sexual active, hx past STI, Sx: urethral d/c, painful urination; in women, sometimes vaginal d/c; though many women w/chlamydia are asx; PE: urethral d/c; cervical d/c or pain on manipulation if concomitant cervicitis; look for findings from assoc STIs that travel w/GC & chlamydia but are otherwise asx→ e.g. ulcer from syphillis, condyloma from HPV, etc.)
      • TB (Sx: subacute/chronic dysuria, hematuria, neg evaln for bact infxn, RFs for TB→ HIV+, immunocomp, known TB elsewhere in body)

      Inflammatory

      • Interstitial cystitis (Etiology: idiopathic; Rfs; women > men; Sx: frequency, urgency pain, chronicity, neg evidence infxn; PE: cvat)
      • Urethral inflammation from unusual causes→ Bechet's, Reactive arthritis (Sx: persistent burning w/urination, neg evidence infxn; Bechet's→ waxing & waning sx; painful ulcers in genital region and mouth; eye sx from iritis; also multi-system/systemic sx from vasculitis, arthritis, GI and neuro involvement; Reactive→ LBP, heel pain, uveitis, joint pain)
      • External dysuria→ sx in women when urine contacts inflamed external genitalia (Sx: burning after urination has begun PE: secondary to vaginal inflammation for any reason→ fungal, viral, etc)

      Other

      • Other e.g. stones, malignancy

      Incontinence?

      Disorders of urine storage

      • Detrussor over activity (urge incontinence) (Etiology: typically idiopathic; rarely from neurodegenerative d/o w/autonmoic dysfxn→ e.g. multi-system atrophy; Sx idiopathic sudden urgency, need to void immediately, incont of moderate amounts of urine, day or night; less commonly→ UMN syndrome)
      • Detrussor under activity (overflow) (Etiology: nerve dysfxn w/impaired sensation or contraction of bladder→cauda equina, severe PN, other; Sx: impaired ability to sense bladder fullness, inability to empty; regular leakage small amounts urine; peripheral numbness, weakness; PE: decreased distal sensation, impaired strength, diminished reflexes, palpable bladder)

      D/O bladder outlet resistance

      • Increased resistance - overflow
        • BPH (Rfs: male, >50; Sx: chronic, progressive, urgency, frequency, hesitancy, difficulty starting/stopping stream, incomplete emptying, decrease force, voiding again soon after urinate; large prostate, rarely palpable bladder)
        • Urethral stricture (RFs: male, hx urethral trauma, hx gonorrhea, hx pelvic xrt, hx prostate surgery; ucommon in women due to short urethra unless hx urethritis or discrete trauma)
        • Prostate cancer (Rfs: male, > 50, fam hx; Sx: urgency, frequency, delayed emptying, hematuria→ if causing obstruction; bone pain if mets; PE: nodular/firm prostate)
      • Decreased resistance
        • Stress incontinence (Rfs: women >> men, age > 50, vaginal childbirth, Sx: worse w/cough/sneeze/sudden movement, small amounts, rarely at night; PE: incont may be reproduced if cough when in stirrups; sometimes prolapse bladder or uterus evident)
        • Complication of prostatectomy → damaged ext sphincter in men

      Mixed disorders

      • Urge incontinence coupled w/stress incontinence in women
      • Urge incontinence coupled w/increased resistance from BPH in men

      Lower urinary tract infxn

      • Either alone or coupled w/other processes

      Non-GU based d/o

      • Excess urine production → poorly controlled DM, diuretic use, hypercalcemia, diabetes insipidus (central or nephrogenic), CHF w/redistribution of volume at night
      • Meds can interfere w/ability to void: Anti-cholinergics, pseudophedrine, benzodiazepines, narcotics, other - in particular if superimposed on bph
      • Osteoarthritis or anything that impairs ability to get up and go to bathroom
      • Atrophic vaginitis in post-menopausal women
      • Among older patients in particular
        • Infection, delirium, immobility, meds, stool impaction, advanced dementia

      Irritative Sx: Freq? Urge? Noct?

      Irritative symptoms include: frequency, urgency and nocturia.

      Primary GU

      • BPH (Rfs: male, >50; Sx: chronic, progressive, urgency, frequency, hesitancy, difficulty starting/stopping stream, incomplete emptying, decrease force, voiding again soon after urinate)
      • Cystitis (Etiology: typically gram negatives that enter bladder thru urethra; Rfs: stasis for any reason→ e.g. bph; foreign bodies→ stones or catheters; females→ short urethra, micro trauma from intercourse; Sx: acute, pain, frequency, urgency, often w/o fever; PE: sometimes supra-pubic discomfort w/palpation)
      • Prostatitis (Etiology; GNRs; Sx: acute, frequency, sometimes systemic sx; can also be chronic or recurrent; PE: prostate tender on exam)
      • Epididymo-orchitis (Sx: acute pain w/urination, frequency, urgency; Etiology: bacterial similar to UTI or gc/chlamydia; less common: TB, viral, med related; PE: swollen & tender epididymis and testis, doesn't transiluminate, urethral d/c if sti)
      • Bladder cancer (Rfs: age > 50, male, hx smoking, anyline dye exposures→ TCC; chronic catheter or shistosomiasis→ SCC; Sx: persistent gross blood, urinary frequency, urgency)
      • Stone (Sx: low back→ groin pain, frequency, urgency, nausea, vomiting)
      • Strong and sudden bladder contraction→ detrussor over activity (Sx: sudden urges to urinate, quick onset, require voiding or incontinence will occur)
      • Prostate cancer (Rfs: male, > 50, fam hx; Sx: urgency, frequency, delayed emptying, hematuria; bone pain if mets; PE: nodular/firm prostate)
      • Interstitial cystitis (Sx: frequency, urgency pain, chronic, women > men, neg evidence infxn or other explanation)

      Non-GU

      • Poorly controlled diabetes
      • Loop diuretic use
      • CHF (C/V RFs htn, dm, cad, hyperlipidemia, fam hx; Sx: orthopnea, PND, nocturia related to volume distribution; PE: lower extremity edema, + S3, elevated jvp, displaced pmi, rales on lung exam)
      • Excessive ETOH and/or PM oral liquid intake
      • Psychogenic polydypsia
      • Inappropriate urine production→ diabetes insipidus (Etiology: centrally mediated: decreased ADH secretion→ s/p hypothalamus surgery, head trauma; nephrogenic: renal insensitivity to ADH→ from lithium or intrinsic renal d/o)
      • Inflammation adjacent to bladder (Etiology: inflammatory processes adjacent to bladder can cause urgency and frequency; include abd/pelvic abscess for any reason; Sx: acute frequency, urgency, fever; urine studies neg for infxn unless bowel to bladder fistula also present→ pneumaturia)

      Obstructive Sx: Incomplete emptying? Hesitancy? Decreased force of stream? Need to void soon after urinating?

      Obstructive symptoms include: Incomplete emptying, hesitancy, decreased force of stream, need to void soon after urinating.
      • BPH (Rfs: male, >50; Sx: chronic, progressive, urgency, frequency, hesitancy, difficulty starting/stopping stream, incomplete emptying, decrease force, voiding again soon after urinate; PE: large prostate, sometimes palpable bladder)
      • Decreased bladder contraction→ overflow incontinence (Etiology: peripheral neuropathy - sensory or motor; cauda equina syndrome from infection, tumor, fracture, posterior disc; PE: decreased distal sensation, impaired strength, diminished reflexes, palpable bladder)
      • Urethral stricture (RFs: male, hx urethral trauma, hx gonorrhea, hx pelvic xrt, Hx prostate surgery; uncommon in women due to short urethra, unless hx trauma or infection)
      • Prostate cancer (Rfs: male, > 50, fam hx; Sx: urgency, frequency, delayed emptying, hematuria; bone pain if mets; PE: nodular/firm prostate)
      • Phymosis (Etiology: scarring of foreskin so can't retract over glans, from recurrent balanitis, or failure to regularly retract; Rfs: male, uncircumcised; Sx: ballooning of urine under foreskin w/voiding, difficult & delayed urination, sometimes recurrent utis; PE: can't retract foreskin over glans)
      • Medications can interfere w/ability to void: Anti-cholinergics, pseudophedrine, benzodiazepines, narcotics, other - in particular if superimposed on bph

      Erectile Dysfunction (ED)?

      Sexually active w/people of same sex, opposite sex, both? What types of activity? Any areas of concern? These questions help define risks for particular problems. Hx of sexual activity should prompt discussion about screening for STIs.

      Problem with libido/lack of interest

      • Low testosterone (Sx: decreased libido, erectile dysfxn, generalized weakness, decreased muscle mass, depression)
        • Primary (Rf/Etiology: testicular hypofunction from: prior infection→ mumps; torsion/trauma/cancer/other reason for testicular death; past chemotherapy; genetic disorders→ prader-willi; PE: sometimes small or absent testes)
        • Secondary (Rf/Etiology: pituitary/hypothalamic dysfxn from: tumor, inflammatory processes, hypoperfusion; meds→ chronic narcotics, LHRH agonists for prostate ca; hemochromatosis; chronic diseases→ HIV, Dm, copd, chf, renal failure, cirrhosis)
      • Depression
      • Meds (many - in particular anti-depressants, anabolic steroid abuse)
      • Chronic medical conditions(renal & liver disease, anemia, hypothyroidism, etc)
      • Hx sexual abuse that interferes w/ability to achieve/maintain intimacy

      Probs get/maintain erection

      No AM erections, occurs w/all partners, + libido
      • In-flow probs→ Arterial disease (C/V RFs, known vasc dz; PE: sometimes diminished distal pulses, cool extremities, delayed cap refill, hairless)
      • Nerve dysfxn (Etiology: hx CNS or PNS d/o, dm; Sx: peripheral numbness or neuropathic pain; PE: impaired distal sensation)
      • Damage to nerves or arteries(pelvic trauma, radiation to pelvic area, etc)
      • Outflow problems(aberrant venous drainage that isn't closed off w/erections, typically idiopathic)
      • Low testosterone - see above
      • Meds (thiazide, bb, ccbs, many others → easiest to implicate when starting Rx has temporal relationship w/onset ED)
      • Structural probs w/cavernosa
        • Past trauma to cavernosa, past priapism
        • Inappropriate curvature from fibrosis→ Peironies dz (Sx: Curved & shortened penis w/erections, difficulty getting/maintaining errection, pain w/intercourse or inability to achieve penetration; PE: penis curved when errect, sometimes palpable plaques along cavernosa)

      Other problems

      • Hx musculoskeletal or neuro problems that interfere w/the mechanics of intimacy
      Problems associated w/low libido can co-mingle w/those causing inability to achieve or sustain erection. May help to obtain info about partner, ? if they have issues.

      Penile ulcer, mass, d/c, pain?

      Penile exam

      Ulcer

      Infection

      • Syphilis (Rfs: men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's; Sx: Painless ulcer following exposure, resolves spontaneously; PE: painless genital ulcer from primary infxn, later can have findings assoc w/secondary syphillis including: non-specific rash, w/predilection for palms, and soles, oral ulcers) more from CDC
      • Herpes simplex virus (Rfs: sexually active, past STIs, past HSV Sx: acute, painful, vesicles, recurrent, resolve spontaneously; PE: vessicle on a red base, ulcers when ruptures) more from CDC
      • Balanitis (Etiology: not typically an ulcer, but rather diffuse redness on head of penis, most commonly from fungal infection; Rfs: uncirc, poorly controlled dm, immunocop Sx: redness and sometimes white d/c head of penis, no urinary sx; PE: diffuse redness on head of penis)
      • Donavanosis→ granuloma inguinale (Rfs/Etiology: tropics & not in US unless travel, spread by direct sexual contact, incubation 1-3m, Rfs same as for HIV; Sx: papule to painless ulcer in genital area, beefy red/bleeds, develops over weeks, can be hard to distinguish from chancroid; PE: painless papule or ulcer in genital region, can be beefy/red and bleed)
      • Lymphogranuloma venereum (RFs/Etiology: caused by chlamydia trachomatis, spread by sexual contact, rare in US, incubation 1-3 weeks, RFs same as for HIV Sx: painless papule or ulcer on penis/vaginal/rectal area, then painful adenopathy; PE: painless ulcer or papule, painful adenopathy)
      • H ducreyi→ chancroid (Rfs/Etiology: Africa/Caribean & not in US unless travel, spread by direct sexual contact; RFs: same as for HIV, incubation 1d-2w Sx: papule to painless ulcer in genital area; PE: papule to painless ulcer in genital area, adenopathy)
      More on STIs from CDC

      Cancer

      • SCC (Etiology: Secondary to HPV; Sx: begins as painless nodule, grows slowly, then ulcerates, can bleed or become supra-infected; PE: painless nodule, then progresses to an ulcer, surrounding induration, inguinal adenopathy if metastatic; sometimes precursor lesion of carcinoma in situ; also concurrent or past HPV)
      • BCC, melanoma→ not common in genital area as not sun exposed (Sx/PE: slow growing, can be ulcerated, sometimes rolled edges; for melanoma→ pigmentation, asymmetric, irreg borders

      Autoimmune/other

      • Behcet's Dz (Etiology: rare autoimmune d/o; RFs: typically presents 20-30yo; Middle Eastern, Mediterranean or East Asian background; Sx: waxing/waning over weeks/months, painful ulcers in genital region and mouth; pain w/swallowing; fever; e nodosusm or other nodular skin lesions; pathergy→ papule/pustule in response to minor trauma; arthralgias; inflammatory arthritis in one/few med joints; eye sx from iritis; adenopathy; can have neuro involvement; can have arterial/venous thrombosis; PE: apthous ulcer(s) with surrounding erythema in mouth, pustule or ulcers in genital area; irreg appearance of pupil, circumferential redness at cornea-sclera junction, sometimes layered pus in anterior chamber→ hypopyon; inflammatory arthritis; adenopathy)
      • Local trauma to skin around penis

      Mass

      • Pearly penile papules (Etiology: benign growths; Sx: asx papules on the underside edge of head of penis, usually long standing but noticed by patient or partner→ concern re cancer, hpv, other)
      • SCC (Etiology: Secondary to HPV; Sx: Begins as painless nodule, grows slowly, then ulcerates, can bleed or become supra-infected PE: painless nodule, then progresses to an ulcer, surrounding induration, inguinal adenopathy if metastatic; sometimes precursor lesion of carcinoma in situ; also concurrent or past HPV)
      • BCC, melanoma
      • HPV (Sx/Rfs: painless growths, can be single/grouped/or in multiple clusters, painless, acquired via sexual contact, travel w/other STIs; PE: single or clustered growths) more from CDC
      • Bacillary angiomatosis (Etiology: bartonella infxn; Sx/RFs: occurs in HIV + or otherwise compromised hosts, painless; PE: nodules on skin, resembles Kaposi's sarcoma)
      • Condyloma lata (secondary syphillis) (Rfs: unprotected intercourse, men who have sex w/men, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's; Sx: secondary manifestations weeks after primary chancre heals; include: condyloma lata→ moist, frond-like growth in genital area; non-specific rash, w/predilection for palms, and soles, mucosal involvement, adenopathy, alopecia) more from CDC

      Penile d/c

      • Sexually transmitted infxn→ gonorrhea, chlamydia (Rfs: + sexual active, hx past STI, Sx: urethral d/c, painful urination; PE: urethral d/c; findings from assoc STIs→ ulcer from syphillis, condyloma from HPV, etc)

      Swelling or pain

      • Penile cellulitis (Etiology: rare, may have a portal of entry from trauma or ulcer; Sx: acute pain, redness, swelling, fever; PE: focal redness and induration)
      • Herpes simplex virus (Rfs: sexually active, past STIs, past HSV; Sx: acute, painful, vesicles, fever sometimes w/acute infxn; recurrent, resolve spontaneously; PE: vessicle on a red base, ulcers when ruptures, inguinal adenopathy w/acute infxn)
      • Penile and scrotal edema (generalized) (Etiology: total body volume overload for any reason, also lying for long periods so penis/scrotum dependent; Swelling may interfere w/ability to hold penis to urinate, no pain; PE: generalized penile or scrotal edema, no focal redness, no pain, evidence volume overload on rest of exam)
      • Paraphymosis (Etiology: foreskin gets trapped behind glans, resultant swelling makes it hard to replace it over head of penis; Sx: acute pain and swelling around head of penis; PE: pain and swelling of foreskin, which is trapped behind glans, glans may swell as well)

      Testicular/Scrotal pain or swelling?

      Testicular exam

      Testicular pathology

      • Epididymo-orchitis (Sx: acute pain w/urination, frequency, urgency; Etiology: bacterial similar to UTI or gc/chlamydia; less common: TB, viral, med related; PE: swollen & tender epididymis and testis, doesn't transiluminate, urethral d/c if sti)
      • Testicular torsion (Sx/Rf: acute pain, unilateral, severe Rf: typically age < 20, may have had similar events in past; PE: acutely tender and swollen testis, often higher than other side)
      • Torsion of testicular appendage (Sx/Rf: acute pain, unilateral, severe Rf: typically age < 20, may have had similar events in past; PE: acutely tender and swollen testis, with focus in one area→ site of appendage)
      • Cancer (Etiology: Seminoma v non-seminomatous, rarely lymphoma; Rf: undescended testicle, fam hx; typical age 15-30; 2nd peak >60 for seminomas; Sx: firm, usually painless, nodule or mass; PE: focal, firm nodules/enlargement, usually non-tender)
      • Hydrocele (Sx: typically painless swelling around testis, can be reactive→ infection, trauma, rarely cancer; often idiopathic; PE: tense, fluid filled collection discrete from testis that usually transilluminates)

      Scrotal pathology

      • Scrotal cellulitis (Etiology: break in skin from trauma, ulcer; Sx: Acute pain, redness, swelling, fever; PE: redness, induation, pain)
      • Scrotal abscess (Etiology: skin break/trauma; Sx: acute pain, swelling; PE: redness, pain, focal area of swelling and fluctuance)
      • Varicocele (Sx: chronic, non-tender, in cord structures above testicle, assoc w/infertility; PE: discrete collection of veins that accompany cord above testis, feels like "bag of worms")
      • Inguinal hernia (Sx: large hernia can extend into scrotum, chronic and progressive, uncomfortable as progresses, pain only if strangulation/infarct; PE: enlarged hemi-scrotum, can reduce manually, non-tender, testicles discrete and normal)
      • Scrotal edema (generalized) (Etiology: total body volume overload for any reason, also lying for long periods so scrotum dependent, swelling may interfere w/ability to hold penis to urinate, no pain, occurs over time; PE: generalized scrotal edema, no focal redness, no pain, evidence volume overload on rest of exam)
      • Necrotizing fasciitis (Fournier gangrene) (Etiology: severe, rare infection affecting scrotum/perineum; Rfs: immuncompromised hosts→ diabetes, immunosuppressive meds, vascular dz; Sx: acute, severe, rapidly progressive illness, pain and swelling in scrotum; PE: severe systemic illness, pain, edema, ertheyma, fluctuance, crepitus)

      Infertility (male)?

      • Infertility =s failure to conceive after 12m regular, unprotected intercourse; 6m if age > 35
      • F/U questions re infertility: (How long trying to conceive? how often intercourse? Past success? Prior evaluation? genl health, meds, surgeries, etc? partners health/issues→ infertility Etiology 1/3 male, 1/3 female, 1/3 mixed)
      • Etiologies
        • Quantity of sperm problem (Etiology: primary testicular problem, med effect, smoking, etoh, illicit drugs, anabolic steroid use, genetic, undescended testicle, varicocele, testicular failure, hypothalamic/pit causes)
        • Qualitative sperm problem (Etiology: impaired motility, can't penetrate egg or otherwise participate in fertilization→ meds, smoking/other toxins, anabolic steroid use, illicit drugs, etoh, varicocele, genetic, other)
        • Hx ejaculatory problems (Etiology: premature ejaculation; no/limited ejaculate→ meds, blocked vas deferens; retrograde ejaculation→ alpha blockers or other meds, s/p turp)
        • Hx erectile problems? If yes, see above under "erectile dysfunction"
        • Blocked sperm delivery system→ injury, surgery, infection affecting vas deferens
        • Partners health/issues (infertility Etiology 1/3 male, 1/3 female, 1/3 mixed)
        • Idiopathic

      More Info About GU and Renal Disorders:
      National Kidney and Urologic Diseases Clearinghouse, Comprehensive male genital/rectal exam

      Back

      Hematology/Oncology

      Chronic or past Heme/Onc disease?

      Hypercoaguable state? Bleeding disorder? Hemoglobin abnormalities? Adult cancers? Past chemotherapy or radiation? Childhood cancers→ if yes, then which and what rx? Childhood cancer carries risks for multiple adult problems: More info for cancer survivors from the NCI

      Cancer and blood disorders

      Solid tumors (primary)

      • Anal cancer (squamous cell) (Rfs: assoc w/HPV infection, increased incidence w/anal intercourse, HIV, women, men who have sex w/men; Sx: anal pain, tenesmus, bleeding, pain, obstruction PE: palpable mass or diffuse tissue infiltration around anus)
      • Biliary (cholangiocarcinoma) (Rfs: PSC, other chronic biliary inflammation; Sx: RUQ/epigsatric persistent/progressive discomfort, anorexia, weight loss, jaundice, ictreus, lighter color stools)
      • Bladder or other urothelial (transitional, squamous) (Rfs: smoking hx, male, age > 50, anyline dye exposure→ TCC; chronic foley or schistosomiasis→ SCC; Sx: lower abd/pelvis discomfort, wt loss, hematuria/dysuria, urinary frequency/urgency)
      • Bone - osteoscaroma (Etiology: uncommon; Sx: bone pain, fracture w/o mechanism, wt loss, feeling poorly)
      • Brain - can originate from any CNS tissues→ astrocytoma/glioblastoma, glioma, oligodendroglyoma, medulloblastoma, ependymoma, pituitary/hypothalamic, pinealoma, meningioma (benign) (Sx: progressive, head ache, seizures, feeling poorly, neuro deficits PE: weakness/loss of function, sensory deficits, behavioral changes, etc)
      • Breast (ductal, lobular) (Rfs: women>>>male, can occur any age, though typically > 50, other risk factors: early menarche, late menopause, never pregnant, family hx, past hx breast ca; Sx: patient notes breast mass, nipple retraction, bloody nipple d/c, skin changes; bone, brain lung, or other organ sx if present w/mets; PE: palpable disrete mass, bloody nipple d/c, nipple inversion, skin changes, axillary adenopathy)
      • Cervical (squamous, adeno) (Rfs: smoking, early age first intercourse, multiple sexual partners, hx STIs, hx HPV→ scc, HIV; Sx: vague lower abd discomfort, vaginal bleeding, pain w/intercourse; PE: abnormal cervix on exam)
      • Colorectal (adeno) (Rfs: no prior screening or screening > 10y ago, early family hx, polyposis syndromes, UC or colonic crohn's; Sx: anorexia, weight loss, vague pain, persistent/progressive, bloody stools, change in bowel habits, R sided→ fatigue from anemia, L sided→ obstructive sx; PE: palpable by digital exam if very distal; palpable on abdominal exam if very large or mets, gross blood or guaiac + on digital exam)
      • Esophageal (Sx: progressive swallowing problems, food gets stuck, worse w/solids then liquids, pain, patient can often point to level of obstruction)
        • Squamous Cell (Etiology: upper 2/3 of esophagus; Rfs: ETOH, smoking, age > 50)
        • Adenocarcinoma (Etiology: lower 1/3 of esophagus; Rfs: GERD → Barret's, age > 50)
      • Head and Neck (squamous) (Rfs: smoking, etoh, chewing tobacco, HPV infection; Etiology: typically squamous cell; Sx: present w/ulcers that don't heal in mouth, masses in mouth, difficulty swallowing, neck adenopathy PE: slow growing, non-healing ulcer or mass of oral mucosa, edges indurated, lymph nodes firm, stuck to each other & underlying tissue, growing)
      • Liver (hepatocellular) (Rfs: chronic hepatitis for any reason→ viral, etoh, etc; Sx: RUQ/epigastric persistent/progressive discomfort, anorexia, weight loss; PE: palpable, firm liver if advanced)
      • Lung (Sx: cough, sob/doe, chest pain, hemoptysis, hoarseness, wt loss, f, sweats; other organs if mets at presentation→ brain, liver PE: may have auscutatory findings if involves enough parenchyma, wheezing if affects large airway, findings assoc w/effusion if advanced)
        • Non-small cell (Rfs: more common, smoking assoc, asbestos exposure)
        • Small cell (Etiology: 10-15% of lung ca, more chemo responsive than non-small cell; RFs: smoking & asbestos exposure)
      • Melanoma (Rfs: fair skin, fair hair, prior melanoma, dysplastic moles, family hx, hx blistering sun burns, immunocompromised; Sx/PE: asymmetric, bleeds, irregular borders, non-homogeneous pigment, grows, doesn't heal, reginal adenopathy if spread, sx related to mets to brain, lung, liver)
      • Mesothelioma (Etiology: secondary to asbestos exposure from mining, work w/insulation→ pipes, brakes, ship building; or family exposed to clothing of those who worked direclty w/asbestos; Sx: causes pleural disease & effusion w/SOB, chest wall pain)
      • Metastatic disease→ almost any solid organ can have a met from cancer elsewhere
      • Ovarian (epithelial) (Rfs: age > 50, fam hx breast/ovarian, nulliparity, obesity; Sx: vague, progressive, abdominal/pelvic fullness/discomfort, constipation, bloating, anoexia, nausea increased girth if malignant ascites, irregular vaginal bleeding; PE: palpably enlarged ovary if advanced)
      • Pancreatic (adeno) (Rfs: male, age > 50, chronic pancreatitis, smoking, family hx; Sx: epigastric area, anorexia, weight loss, epigastric pain radiating to back, persistent/progressive, sometimes diarrhea; PE: palpable mass from primary or met if advanced; jaundice if affecting head of pnacreas and obstructing CBD)
      • Prostate (adeno) (Sx: asx early, can cause urgency, frequency, delayed emptying, hematuria; bone pain if mets; PE: nodular, firm prostate)
      • Renal cell (Rfs: smoking, obesity, family hx, male; avg age ~mid 60s; Sx: low back to lower abd/groin discomfort, wt loss, sweats, fever, flank pain, hematuria; PE: papable only if very advanced)
      • Sarcoma (soft tissue) (Etiology: uncommon; Sx: relatively uncommon malignancies, growing mass that arises from muscle/other tissue, other sx based on growth/interference w/adjacent structures)
      • Small bowel (adeno, lymphoma, carcinoid) (Etiology: less common than other GI tract malignancies; Sx: pain, bleeding, wt loss, obstruction; carcinoid→ diarrhea, episodic flushing, wheezing, hypotension)
      • Stomach (adeno, lymphoma) (Rfs: 50, smoking, ETOH abuse, h pylori→ MALT assoc; Sx: feel full when eating ever smaller quantities of food, pain, bleeding)
      • Testicular (seminomas, non-seminomas) (Rfs: typical age 15-30, undescended testicle; Sx: painless, progressive firm nodule; unexplained hydrocele; PE: firm testicle, discrete or diffuse)
      • Thyroid (papillary, follicular, medullary, anaplastic) (Rfs: hx radiation to head/neck, family hx; Sx: typically euthyroid; pt may note thyroid mass or adenopathy, sob or change in voice if spread; PE: thyroid nodules or enlargement; cervical adenopathy if spread)
      • Uterine (endometrial) (Rfs: older age, early menarche, late menoapause, receiving unopposed estrogens, obesity; Sx vague lower abd discomfort, wt loss, progressive, vaginal bleeding; PE: enlarged uterus on exam)
      • Vaginal (squamous) (Rfs: age >50, DES exposure, HPV, smoking; Sx: lower abd/vaginal area pain, vaginal bleeding; PE: vaginal wall abnormality on exam)
    • Other→ any solid structure can have a primary malignancy - though above are the most common

      • Leukemia

      General Sx: fevers, chills, weight loss, adenopathy, decreased appetite; fatigue/low energy/chronically tired/SOB→ from aneamia, mucocutaneous bleeding→ from low plt; impaired immunity, recurrent infections from→ low numbers or dysfunctional WBCs.
      • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) (Etiology: monoclonal B cell d/o; Rfs: age > 60, male sl > female, agent orange exposure; Sx: often asx x years→ picked up on incidental labs; then fever, sweats, adenopathy, fatigue, wt loss, bleeding, infections; can transform into acute leukemia or lmphoma; can develop auto-immune hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia; PE: as progresses→ adenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly)
      • Chronic myelocytic leukemia (CML) (Etiology: associated w/9:22 chromosome translocation; Rfs: avg age 55-60, radiation, male sl > female; Sx: fatigue, abdominal fullness, f, weats, wt loss; WBCs elevated, often plt too; chronic phase x 3-5y; then accelerated phase w/blast crisis→ infection, bleeding; PE: often splenomegaly)
      • Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) (Etiology: most common acute leukemia in kids; in adults, represents 20% of acute leukemias; RFs: in adults→ male, hx prior radiation or chemo, > age 70, Down's syndrome; Sx: fatigue, sob, weakness, fever, sweats, easy bruising/bleeding; PE: palor, petechiae, echymoses; sometimes adenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)
      • Acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) (Etiology: most common adult acute leukemia; Rfs: male, age > 60, smoking, hx prior chemo or xrt; hx of myelofibrosis, essential thrombocythemia, polycythemia vera; Sx: fatigue, fever, dyspnea, easy bruising; PE: palor, echymoses, petechiae, musocal bleeding; sometimes adenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)
      • Other leukemias

      Lymphoma

      General (Sx: wt loss/decreased appetite sweats, fevers, chills, adenopathy, organomegaly, abdominal fullness; CNS involvement and sx w/NHL; skin involvement w/cutaneous t-cell NHL; PE: generalized adenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, erythroderma,, sometimes focal neurological findings if CNS involvement)
      • Hodgkins (Etiology: 10% of lymphomas; Rfs: age 15-40 & > 55, hiv +, EBV infection, fam hx; Sx: fever, sweats, wt loss, adenopathy; cough/sob if mediastinal invovlmenet; PE: painless, progressive adenopathy, in particular head/neck; sometimes splenomegaly, hepatomegaly)
      • Non-Hodgkins (Etiology: 90% of lymphomas; many different types (B & T cell), significant variability in how aggressive they may be; Rfs: age > 60, hx hiv + confers markedly increased risk aggressive NHL; EBV→ Burkitts; h pylori→ stomach MALT; Sx: f, c, sweats, fatigue, wt loss; PE: progressive, painless, generalized adenopathy; splenomegaly; extra-nodal dz can involve almost any organ system)

      Multiple Myeloma

      • Rfs: age > 60; hx MGUS; Sx: fatigue, sob, wt loss, doe→ from anemia, renal involvement, hypercalcemia or combinations; bone pain from lytic lesions; infection

      Myeloproliferative d/o

      • Polycythemia vera (Etiology: primary bone marrow problem→ w/inappropriate RBC production; age onset typically > 50; Sx: hepatic vein or other venous clot in unusual location or otherwise unexplained; mi, stroke, tia, headache, mesenteric ischemia, other arterial insufficiency from sludging; itching exacerbated by hot shower; sometimes bleeding; often picked up incidentally on CBC; PE: ruddy complexion, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly)
      • Essential thrombocytosis (ET) (Sx: asx until platelets significantly elevated; then sx related to arterial or venous thrombotic events→ stroke, MI, dvt/pe; interestingly, some patients have increased risk bleeding)
      • Chronic myelocytic leukemia (CML) (Etiology: associated w/9:22 chromosome translocation; Rfs: avg age 55-60, radiation, male sl > female; Sx: fatigue, abdominal fullness, f, weats, wt loss; WBCs elevated, often plt too; chronic phase x 3-5y; then accelerated phase w/blast crisis→ infection, bleeding; PE: often splenomegaly)
      • Myelofibrosis (Etiology: sometimes have p vera, cml or ET first; Sx: generalized fatigue, night sweats, wt loss, fever; sob, doe→ from anemia; abd discomfort from hepato-splenomegaly→ sites of extra med hematopoeisis; PE: hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)

      Myelodysplastic Synd (MDS)

      • Rfs: Age > 60, a primary problem or secondary to chemotherapy or other d/o that can affect BM function; Sx: asx until anemia, low plt, or low wbc lead to sx→ fatigue, sob, doe, bleeding, infection; risk of transformation to AML

      Hemoglobinopathies

      • Thalassemia (Rfs/Etiology: mediterranean background, dx during childhood; Sx: failure to thrive) more from the CDC
      • Sickle cell (Rfs: black, family hx, identified in childhood; Sx: failure to thrive in childhood, recurrent bouts pain during crises) more from the CDC
      • Methemoglobinemia (Etiology: hemoglobin changed to met-hgb form, which cant bind O2; Rfs: often from meds like dapsone, benzocaine spray; Sx: progressive sob, confusion, acidosis and target organ dysfxn→ more severe w/higher levels met-hgb; PE: tachypnea, tachycardia, O2 sat 85%, clear lungs, cyanosis)

      Fevers, chills, sweats?

      Malignancy

      Cancers cause fever as primary manifestation of malignancy or a result of infection→ induced immunocompromised state and/or chemotherpy. Malignancies most commonly linked to pimary fever listed below:

      Solid tumors

      • Renal cell (Rfs: smoking, obesity, family hx; Sx: low back to lower abd/groin discomfort, wt loss, sweats, fever, flank pain, hematuria; PE: papable only if very advanced)
      • Liver (hepatocellular) (Rfs: chronic hepatitis for any reason→ viral, etoh, etc; Sx: RUQ/epigastric persistent/progressive discomfort discomfort, anorexia, weight loss; PE: palpable, firm liver if advanced)
      • Metastatic disease involving the liver - primary can be anywhere

      Liquid tumors

      Sx: fevers, chills, weight loss, adenopathy, decreased appetite; fatigue/low energy/chronically tired/SOB→ from aneamia, mucocutaneous bleeding→ from low plt; impaired immunity, recurrent infections from→ low numbers or dysfunctional WBCs
      • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) (Etiology: monoclonal B cell d/o; Rfs: age > 60, male sl > female, agent orange exposure; Sx: often asx x years→ picked up on incidental labs; then fever, sweats, adenopathy, fatigue, wt loss, bleeding, infections; can transform into acute leukemia or lmphoma; can develop auto-immune hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia; PE: as progresses→ adenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly)
      • Chronic myelocytic leukemia (CML) (Etiology: associated w/9:22 chromosome translocation; Rfs: avg age 55-60, radiation, male sl > female; Sx: fatigue, abdominal fullness, f, weats, wt loss; WBCs elevated, often plt too; chronic phase x 3-5y; then accelerated phase w/blast crisis→ infection, bleeding; PE: often splenomegaly)
      • Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) (Etiology: most common acute leukemia in kids; in adults, represents 20% of acute leukemias; RFs: in adults→ male, hx prior radiation or chemo, > age 70, Down's syndrome; Sx: fatigue, sob, weakness, fever, sweats, easy bruising/bleeding; PE: palor, petechiae, echymoses; sometimes adenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)
      • Acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) (Etiology: most common adult acute leukemia; Rfs: male, age > 60, smoking, hx prior chemo or xrt; hx of myelofibrosis, essential thrombocythemia, polycythemia vera; Sx: fatigue, fever, dyspnea, easy bruising; PE: palor, echymoses, petechiae, musocal bleeding; sometimes adenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)
      • Other leukemias
      • Myelofibrosis (Etiology: sometimes have p vera, cml or ET first; Sx: generalized fatigue, night sweats, wt loss, fever; sob, doe→ from anemia; abd discomfort from hepato-splenomegaly→ sites of extra med hematopoeisis; PE: hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)

      Lymphoma

      General comments (Sx: wt loss/decreased appetite sweats, fevers, chills, adenopathy, organomegaly, abdominal fullness; CNS involvement and sx w/NHL; skin involvement w/cutaneous t-cell NHL; PE: generalized adenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, erythroderma, sometimes focal neurological findings if CNS involvement)
      • Hodgkins (Etiology: 10% of lymphomas; Rfs: age 15-40 & > 55, hiv +, EBV infection, fam hx; Sx: fever, sweats, wt loss, adenopathy; cough/sob if mediastinal invovlmenet; PE: painless, progressive adenopathy, in particular head/neck; sometimes splenomegaly, hepatomegaly)
      • Non-Hodgkins (Etiology: 90% of lymphomas; many different types (B & T cell), significant variability in how aggressive they may be; Rfs: age > 60, hx hiv + confers markedly increased risk aggressive NHL; EBV→ Burkitts; h pylori→ stomach MALT; Sx: f, c, sweats, fatigue, wt loss; PE: progressive, painless, generalized adenopathy; splenomegaly; extra-nodal dz can involve almost any organ system)

      Autoimmune/Rheum d/o

      Specific disorder based on other symptoms and findings - relatively uncommon (compared w/above)
      • Adult Still's Disease (Etiology: febrile illness of unknown etiology; Sx: f and other sx are persistent, sub-acute; evaluation of f does not reveal other etiology; also arhtritis & arthralgias of larger joints; salmon colored, maculo-pap non-puritic skin erruption; myalgias, adenopathy, sore throat, pericarditis and pleuritis; PE: erruption is light salmon colored mac/pap, pharyngitis, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy)
      • Cryogloblulinemia (Etiology: small-vessel vasculitis caused by antigen-antibody complex deposition; Type I monoclonal→ IgM or IgG, related to lymphoprolif d/o→ lymphoma, myeloma; Type II and III, mixed cryos IgM and IgG; related to Hep C (most common), SLE, RA, lymphoma, myeloma, hiv, hep b, other autoimmune; RFs: female > male, ages 40-50; Sx: subacute fatigue, weakness, muscle and joint aches, cough/sob if pulmonary involvement; confusion; symmetric or asymmetric often painful distal neuropathy, painful skin ulcers of extremities, purpuric papules; membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis; PE: palpable purpura of vasculitis, Raynauds, livedo reticularis, distal skin ulcers)
      • Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss) (Etiology: idiopathic d/o, small-to-medium vessel vasculitis; w/high levels circulating and tissue invasive eosinophils; Rfs: men=women, assoc also w/leukotriene antagonists; Sx: progressive, adult onset asthma, cough & wheezing, nasal stuffiness→ w/resp sx usually ~2-10 y prior to systemic sx assoc w/eosinophilic deposition in target organs and vasculitis; in these later phases→ systemic sx including: sob from parenchymal lung involvement; f, c, muscle aches; hematuria from renal involvement; heart failure, pericarditis and dysrhythmia w/cardiac involvement; peripheral neuropathy; PE: wheezing, skin findings of vasculitis: small, palapable purpura, don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; hematuria/renal involvement; unexplained peripheral neuropathy)
      • Familial Med Fevers (Rfs: Mediterranean descent→ Turkish, Jewish, Armenian, Arab, other; family hx; Sx: uncommon, associated w/cryptic abdominal pain, rash, arthritis, arthralgias, myalgias, recurrent fever)
      • Giant Cell Arteritis (Rfs: age > 50, often prior hx PMR; Sx fatigue, headache, joint aches, f, c, acute visual loss; PE: sometimes scalp or temp art tenderness, abnl optic nerve)
      • Granulomatosis with poyangiitis (Wegeners) (Etiology: small-to-medium vessel vasculitis; Sx: vasculitis→ recurrent/progressive nasal congestion, cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; PE: mucosal erythema, ulcer, nasal septum perf)
      • Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) ()Etiology: uncontrolled activation of T Cells, w/inappropriate release of cytokines and macrophage activation; Rx directed at underlying cause; Rfs: triggered by lymphoma, leukemia, autoimmunes dz, infxns→ ebv, enterovirus, gastroenteritis, other; also a rare familial form; Sx: f that's unexplained, other related to the inciting process, increased ferretin, cytopenias, hyper-TGs; PE: f, splenomegaly)
      • Inflammatory bowel disease - Crohn's dz or UC (Sx: sub-acute, recurrent or chronic diarrhea; wt loss, bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, nocturnal diarrhea; systemic sx; presentation can also be fulminant)
      • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
      • Microscopic polyangitis (MPA) (Etiology: small vessel vasculitis; Sx: fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, sweats, wt loss; recurrent/progressive cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; less often nasal sx c/w GPA; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; skin ulcers; neuropathy; PE: palpable purpura, skin ulcer/necrosis)
      • Polyarteritis Nodosa (Etiology: medium-vessel-vasculitis; Rfs: 40s-50s, men>women, Hep B/C; Sx: more commonly subacute over mos f, s, malaise, wt loss, muscle/joint pain; multiple systems: arthritis, glomerulonephritis, peripheral nerve pain/dysfxn, skin w/ulcers, small, palapable purpura→ don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; abd pain, blood per rectum)
      • Polymyalgia Rheumatica (PMR) (Rfs: age > 50, Sx: subacute arthralgias affecting hips and shoulders, worse in AM, f, c; can't sleep secondary to inability to find comfortable position; PE: no findings of arthritis/synovitis on exam, no objective findings of weakness)
      • RA (Etiology: can cause interstitial lung dz, pleural inflammation, pulm vasc dz; meds for RA can have lung tox, also→ immunocomp→ infxn; Rfs: women > men; age 30-55; Sx: subacute (>6w), persistent/progressive joint pain, worse in AM due to gelling→ improves w/use, fatigue, tendency for bilateral involvement, commonly small and medium sized joints; nerve symptoms can be motor, sensory or from compression; PE: warmth, redness, spongy feeling from synovial inflam, pain w/squeezing of joints, effusion, abnormal appearing if longstanding, MCPs with chronic changes; extra articular findings: episcleritis, pleural/pericardial inflam, rheumatoid nodules) more from CDC
      • Serum sickness (Rfs: typically from rxn to abx, or secondary to viral infxn → e.g. acute hep b; Sx: acute, symetric, additive/migratory, polyarthritis; myalgias, fever, rash, onset days to weeks after exposure)
      • Takayasu's arteritis (Etiology: large vessel vasculitis, onset 10-30yo, Asian background, women > men; Sx: sub-acute and progressive, fevers, fatigue, wt loss, myalgias arthralgias; target organ sx based on affected vessels: abdominal aorta & branches→ abdominal pain, htn; thoracic aorta & branches→ chest pain, sob, tia/stroke; PE: loss of palpable pulses radial, carotid, lower extremity)
      • Vasculitis - other

      Endocrine

      • Menopause (Rfs: age ˜ 50; Sx: sweats but no fever, irregular menstruation)
      • Hyperthyroidism (Etiology: grave's disease, thyroiditis, multi-nodular or single toxic adenoma, exogenous thyroid hormone consumption; Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, sweating, wt loss, weakness; PE: fever, sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid→ nodules, pain or diffuse enlargement based on etiology, hyper-reflexia, moist skin)
      • Thyroid storm (Etiology: a profound thyrotoxic state, w/mortality 20-30%; Rfs: untreated or undiagnosed hyperthyroidism, often triggered by stress/infection or iodine admin from CT; Sx: acute, severe palpatations, sob/doe, tremor, abd discomfort, n, v, d, delirium; PE: ill appearing, fever, tachycardia, a fib, tremor, enlarged thyroid, abd discomfort, pulmonary edema/findings of chf, confusion)
      • Low testosterone (Sx: decreased libido, errectile dysfxn, generalized weakness, decreased muscle mass, depression)
        • Primary (Rf/Etiology: testicular hypofunction from: prior infection→ mumps; torsion/trauma/cancer/other reason for testicular death; past chemotherapy; genetic disorders→ prader-willi; PE: sometimes small or absent testes)
        • Secondary (Rf/Etiology: pituitary/hypothalamic dysfxn from: tumor, inflammatory processes, hypoperfusion; meds→ chronic narcotics, LHRH agonists for prostate ca; hemochromatosis; chronic diseases→ HIV, Dm, copd, chf, renal failure, cirrhosis)
      • Adrenal insufficiency (Sx: feeling poorly in general, n, v, orthostatic sx)
        • Primary (Etiology: problem at level of adrenal gland: autoimmune destruction → assoc w/DM 1, celiac dz; hemorrhage/infarct; infection → TB, HIV; infiltration w/tumor; PE: sometimes darkening of mucous memberanes, skin folds, & pressure points)
        • Secondary (Etiology: problem at level of pituitary/hypothalamus → low acth; can be from surgery, tumor, hypoperfusion, auto-immune, trauma, meds→ chronic glucocorticoids)

      Meds

      Dx based on r/o other causes and temporal link between initiation meds & fever onset
      • Malignant hyperthermia (Etiology: exposure to inhalational anesthetics or succinylcholine, typically in OR or w/in 24h; Sx: abrupt onset high fever, aggitation; PE: temp to 46c, Htn, tachycardia, tachypnea, ill appearing, diaphoretic, mottled skin, severe generalized rigidity, decreased reflexes)
      • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (Etiology: exposure to haldol, chlorpomazine, other typical or atypical neruoleptics; more common w/high dose or soon after rx/dose change, but also idiosyncratic→ occurring after years of rx; sx progress over several d; Sx: autonomic instability w/HTN, tachycardia, tachypnea, temp can be > 41.1c, pale, sweaty, fluctuating delirium→ aggitated or stupor/alert mutism to coma, cramps, generalized lead-pipe type muscular rigidity, decreased reflexes)
      • Cholinergic agents (Etiology: organophosphate insecticide overdose or exposure; Sx: sedation, confusion, sweating, shortness of breath; PE: salivation, wheezing, lacrimation, bronchorrea, emesis, diarrhea, urination)
      • Serotonin syndrome (Etiology: SSRIs, MAOIs, anti-epileptics, others; rapid onset sx ususally following rx initiation or dose change, though can occur if received rx w/in 5w; sometimes med combinations precipitate syndrome; intential overdose; Sx: aggiation/easily startled, sweating, shivering, diarrhea; PE: spectrum→ htn, tachycardia, tachypnea, hyperthermia to > 41c, flushed & sweaty skin, tremor, confusion/aggitation to coma, increased bowel sounds, clonus, muscular hyperactivity/stiffness, hyper-reflexia)
      • Many other meds - including broad range of abx

      Non-infxn: Other

      • DVT/PE (RFs: immobility, trauma, known hypercoag state, past dvt/pe; Sx/Pe: acute, cough, SOB, pleuritic, hemoptysis, unexplained unilateral leg swelling; Well's Criteria for DVT ; Well's Criteria for PE)

      Infectious pathogens

      Specific infections identified on basis of focality (i.e. patient complaints pointing to specific organ systems), risk factors, corollary sx and exam findings; labs/imaging help to pinpoint precise Etiologyogy and extent

      Bacteria

      Aerobes: GN

    • Gram negative rods
      • Acinetobacter (Site: wounds, urine, lung; Etiology: usually hospital acquired; not typically pathogenic for healthy hosts) more from CDC
      • Bacillary angiomatosis (bartonella sp) (Site: skin; Rfs: occurs in HIV infected or otherwise compromised pts; Sx/PE: nodules on skin, resemble Kaposis Sarcoma) more from CDC
      • Bartonella henslae (cat scratch) (Sites: skin and lymph nodes; Rfs/Etiology: caused by cat scratch; Sx: may see inflamation at innoculation site, then tender regional adenopathy w/in few weeks, fatigue, fever) more from CDC
      • Brucella (Sites: systemic; Etiology: ingestion of raw/uncooked dairy or handling infected animals; Rfs: veterinarians, meat packers, slaughter house workers, farmers; Middle East, Mediterranean, Mexico, Africa; Sx/PE: causes weeks/months of recurrent f, c, sweats, arthritis, adenopathy, orchitis, hepato-splenomegaly) more from CDC
      • Campylobacter (Site: small bowel; Etiology: spread thru contaminated food; Sx: d, n, v, cramps, often w/bloody stools; incubation 2-5d; typically self limited to 1w) more from CDC
      • Citrobacter (Site: urine most common; then biliary tree, peritoneum, respiratory, intravasc, other; Rfs/Etiology: often hospital acquired, compromised/ill host)
      • Donavanosis (granualoma inguinale) (Site: genital regions; Rfs: tropics & not in US unless travel, spread by direct sexual contact, can be hard to distinguish from chancroid, similar RFs for HIV; Sx/PE: incubation 1-3m, papule to painless ulcer in genital area, beefy red/bleeds, develops over weeks)
      • E coli (Sites: urinary tract, abdominal/pelvic/peri-rectal infection and abscess; O157:H7 causes enteritis and HUS) more from CDC
      • Eikenella (E Corrodens) (RFs: lives in human mouthrarr; assoc w/human bite; Sites: hands, arms or anyplace that bite occurs; rarely endocarditis→ HACEK organism; Sx: acute pain, redness, swelling, pain w/movement of fingers if tenosynovitis; subacute f, c if endocarditis; PE: wound where bite occurred, redness, warmth, fluctuance if abscess; persistent pain and drainage w/deeper infection of soft tissue or bone; streaky erythema w/lymphangitis; murmur if endocarditis)
      • Enterobacter (Sites: biliary tract, urinary tract, abdominal/pelvic/peri-rectal infection or abscesses; in hospitalized patients→ pneumonia, wound infection, uti)
      • Extended spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL) producing organisms (Sites: infects urine, wounds, other; RFs/Etiology: GNRs including enterobacter, e coli, klebsiella; an emerging hospital acquired infxn amongst those who are severely ill, having typically received abx prior)
      • Francisella tularensis (tularemia) (Sites: skin, lymph nodes; Etiology/Rfs: passed from dying wild animals to humans via ticks/insects, US Southeast and Rocky Mtns; Sx: f, c, ha, oral or skin ulcers, painful adenopathy, sob, muscle aches) more from CDC
      • H ducreyi (chancroid) (Site: genital region; Rfs: Africa/Caribean & not in US unless travel, spread by direct sexual contact, similar RFs for HIV; Sx/PE: incubation 1d-2w, papule to painless ulcer in genital area, adenopathy) more from CDC
      • Haemophilus influenza (Sites: upper and lower respiratory tract, cns; RFs: much less common since widespread use of vaccine; increased risk s/p splenectomy; Sites: pneumonia, otitis media, epiglottitis, meningitis) more from CDC
      • HACEK (Haemophilus, Actinobacillus, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, Kingella) organisms (Sites: systemic bacteremia→ endocarditis; Sx: typically sub-acute→ f, c, malaise x weeks)
      • Klebsiella (Sites: pneumonia, wound infection→ hospital acquired infections; Rfs: hospitalized patients, compromised hosts) more from CDC
      • Legionella (Site: community acquired pneumonia; Sx: acute cough, sputum, f, c) more from CDC
      • Morganella Morganii (Rf: debilitated/chronically ill patients, hospitalized, prior abx, urinary catheters; high rates resistance; Sites: urinary tract→ can form urinary stones, surgical sites, chronic wounds, intravascular, snake bites)
      • Pertussis (Site: upper airwary; Rfs/Etiology: easily spread; vax of kids and re-vax of adults preventive; kids can have airway compromise due to small size; Sx: characteristic whooping cough, adults present w/persistent cough x weeks) more from CDC
      • Pasturella (P multocida) (RFs: lives in mouths of dogs and cats→ assoc w/bites; Sites: hands, arms or anyplace that bite occurs; Sx: acute pain, redness, swelling, pain w/movement of fingers if tenosynovitis; PE: puncture wounds, redness, warmth, fluctuance if abscess; persistent pain and drainage w/deeper infection of soft tissue or bone; streaky erythema w/lymphangitis)
      • Proteus (Sites: common cause of urinary tract infection, can contribute to stone formation; wound infections in hospitalized patients)
      • Pseudomonas (Sites: lung; bacteremia in patients w/neutropenia, abdominal/pelvic abscesses, wound infection in patients w/DM; wound and urinary infections hospitalized or compromised pts; osteomyelitis; otitis externa in patients w/DM; Rfs: brochiectasis, cystic fibrosis, DM, chemotherapy w/neutropenia, chronic illness or otherwise compromised host)
      • Salmonella typhi (typhoid fever) (Site: small bowel, systemic infxn; Etiology: related to poor sanitation→ outbreaks, travel to endemic areas, spread by contaminated/unwashed food, poor sanitation, unclean water; gall bladder can act as reservoir; Rfs: from endemic area or travel; Sx/PE: relapsing daily fever x weeks, malaise, ha, chills, abd pain, diarrhea, maculop-pap rash→ rose spots, relative brady; aside from fever, sx quite variable)
      • Salmonella (non-typhoidal) (Site: small bowel; Rfs: exposure from eggs, chicken, turtles; most recover in 4-7d; Site: small bowel; Sx: d, n, v, cramps, often w/bloody stools; incubation 12h-3d; rarely can spread to distant sites in compromised hosts→ osteomyelitis, endovascular, other) more from CDC
      • Serratia (Sites: common cause of hospital acquired infections, compromised hosts: pneumonia, wound infection, uti)
      • Shigella (Site: small bowel; Etiology: spread person to person or from food; Site: small bowel; Sx: d, n, v, cramps, often w/bloody stools; avg incubation 3d; typically self limited to 4-7d) more from CDC
      • Vibrio cholera (Site: small bowel; Etiology/Rfs: toxin mediated profound watery diarrhea, related to exposure to unclean water sources, often s/p natural disasters→ presents as epidemics; Sx: profound watery diarrhea; can lead to hypovolemic death in hours if severe) more from CDC
      • Vibrio vulnificus and parahemolytics (Rfs/Sites: causes bacteremia→ sepsis in hosts w/cirrhosis or otherwise compromised hosts, exposure via raw/under cooked shellfish; wound/skin infection if same hosts exposed via inoculation w/affected water→ walking in surf w/exposed wounds in endemic area; Sx: acute n, v, f, cramps, diarrhea; extremity pain and swelling if via wound) more from CDC
      • Yersinia enterocolitica (Site: small bowel; Etiology: spread via contaminated food; Sx: f, c, cramps, bloody diarrhea; incubation 4-7d; typically self limited to 4-7d) more from CDC
      • Yersinia pestis (plague) (Site: respiratory tract; skin; Rf/Etiology: passed from rodents to humans by fleas, direct contact w/feces, or respiratory droplets; Sx: rapid onset f, c, sepsis, pneumonia; tdner aenopathy) more from CDC
    • Gram negative cocci
      • Neisseria meningitidis (Site: meninges, bacteremia; Rfs: often in outbreaks amongst young adults living in close quarters→ college dorms, barracks; unvaccinated; Sx: f, c, ha, n, v, sepsis; PE: very ill, ha, f, neck pain/stiffness, purpura) more from CDC
      • Neisseria gonorrhea (Site: urethra, cervix, uterus, fallopian tubes, testes; Rfs: sexual activity; PE: penile d/c, cervical d/c, cervical pain and uterine pain if PID; if disseminated→ pustules, infectious arthritis) more from CDC
      • Moraxella (Sites: otitis media; bronchitis in copd exacerbation; pneumonia in COPD; Sx: cough, sob, f, sputum)

      Aerobes: GP

    • Gram positive cocci
      • Staph aureus: coag + (Sites/Sx:: skin infection, abscess, wound infection; osteomyelitis via direct extension; arthritis; bacteremia, with seeding of abnormal or artificial valves, joints or devices; virulent w/rapid destruction valves/death w/in hours/days; toxic shock; pneumonia following viral infection; toxin based food poisoning→ n/v hours after exposure, others affected who ate same; PE: cellulitis→ redness, warmth, induration, skin abscess→ focal redness and fluctuance)
      • Staph aureus: coag - (Sites: skin infection, abscess, wound infection; bacteremia, w/seeding of abnormal or artificial valves, joints or devices; overall less virulent than coag +; PE: cellulitis, skin abscess)
      • Methicillin Resistant Saph Aureus (MRSA) (Sites: skin infection, abscess; bacteremia, w/seeding of abnormal or artificial valves, joints or devices, can be hospital or community acquired; healthcare assoc pna; PE: cellulitis, skin abscess) more from CDC
      • Streptococcus: Group A (Sites: cellulitis/lymphangitis; skin abscess; erysipelas; impetigo, throat infections→ acute pain, f, adenopathy; scarlet fever → high temp, rash, palatal petchiae, throat sx; necrotizing fasciits; PE: strep throat→ pharyngeal erythema, d/c, adenop, necrotizing fasciitis, red streaking from lymphangitis) more from CDC
      • Streptococcus: Group B (Sites: endometritis, meningitis, bacteremia, neonatal infection) more from CDC
      • Streptococcus: Group D→ enterococcus (Sites: urinary tract infection, pelvic/abd abscess, wound/other infxn in chronically ill/hospitalized patients)
      • Streptococcus Viridans (Etiology: mouth flora, bacteremia via dental procedure; Sites and Sx: endocarditis→ subacute w/sx f, c, malaise x weeks)
      • Streptococcus Pneumoniae (Sites: pneumonia, upper respiratory infections, meningitis; bacteremia if severe; Rfs: s/p splenectomy or fxnl asplenia, eldery and very young, any chronic medical condition→ copd, liver or renal dz, chf, cancer, diabetes, HIV, or otherwise immunocompromised; also csf leaks, cochlear implants; decreased risk if vaccinated) more from CDC
      • Vancomycin resistant eterococcus (VRE) (Sites and Rfs: hospital acquired infection, affecting those w/multi-system illness; can cause wound, urinary, respiratory infections) more from CDC
    • Gram positive rods
      • Anthrax (Etiology: acquired from animal exposure or biological weapon; Sx: inhalation: cough, f, c, pneumonia sepsis; cutaneous: ulcer to eshcar w/surrounding edema) more from CDC
      • Diptheria (Site: upper respiratory tract; Sx: cough, f, sore throat, uncommon now w/vax; PE: pseudo-membrane w/airway obstruction) more from CDC
      • Listeria (Site: bacteremia, CNS; Etiology: contaminated food; RFs: older persons, newborns, pregnant, immunocompromised; Sx: f, c, d, n, aches; ha, neck stiffness→ meningitis) more from CDC

      Anaerobes

      Anaerobes (GN or GP) (Often associated with mixed/complex infections/abscesses of abdomen, pelvis, lung, mouth)
      • Bacteroides fragilis (GNR) (Sites: along w/GNRs→ contributes to abdominal/pelvic, lung abscesses)
      • Clostridium Perfringes (GPR) (Etiology: most common cause food born diarrhea→ undercooked meat, other who ate same ill simultaneously, resolves in 24h; can contribute to nec fasciitis; Sx: cramps, diarrhea, 6-18h after ingestion, contribute to abd/pv abscess; NEC in neonates; PE: deep tissue infection from necrotizing faciitis) more from CDC
      • Clostridium Difficile (GPR) (Etiology: antibiotic associated colitis; toxin based; Rfs: can occur after any abx, also passed to patients in houspital via healthcare workers; Sx: cramps, diarrhea, severe pain and sepsis if advanced) more from CDC
      • Clostridium Tetani (GPR) (Etiology: exposure via contaminated wounds if unvax, Sx: 1w incubation,increased tone in jaw muscles, dysphagia, diffuse musle pain/spasms, airway compromise) more from CDC
      • Clostridium Botulinum (GPR) (Etiology: food/wound born toxin, black tar heroin; Sx: incubation 1-2d, rapid descending symmetric paralysis starting w/cranial nerves, dizziness, dry mouth, double vision, blurred vision, no sensory deficits, agitation, resp failure, death) more from CDC
      • Peptostreptococus (GPC) (Sites: lives in mouth, contributes to mixed oral/lung infxns/abscess)

      Other bacteria

      • Actinomyces (Sites: oral/neck/face, other organ systems Sx: slow growing abscess, often w/sinus tract development)
      • Chlamydia trachomatis (sti) (Sites: urethra, cervix, uterus, fallopian tubes, testes; Etiology: urethritis, epididymo-orchitis, cervicitis, PID; Sx: cervical or urethral d/c, vaginal bleeding; PID→ lower abd pain, f; women often asx; PE: cervicitis→ purulent cervical d/c, friable cervix; PID→ cervical d/c, cervical motion tenderness, adnexal pain, uterine pain; men→ urethral d/c, testicular/epididymal swelling & pain if testic involvement) more from CDC
      • Chlamydia trachomatis (lymphogranuloma venereum) (Site: Genital region; Etiology: spread by sexual contact, rare in US, Rfs: same as for HIV; Sx: incubation 1-3 weeks, painless papule or ulcer on penis/vagina/rectal area, then painful adenopathy) more from CDC
      • Chlamydia trachomatis (trachoma) (Site: eye; Etiology: spread thru poor hand hygiene, sharing towels, or via flies, endemic in poor/developing countries, a leading cause blindeness world-wide; Sx: chronic, purulent conjunctivitis, can lead to scarring of lid→ inward turned lashes→ scarring of cornea→ blindness) more from CDC
      • Chlamydia pneumoniae (Site: lung; Sx: fever, upper resp sx, non-productive cough) more from CDC
      • Chlamydia psittaci (psitacosis) (Site: lung; Etiology: spread by exposure to parrots & sometimes other birds Sx: 1-2 week incubation; fever, cough, severe HA; other organ systems as well) more from CDC
      • Mycoplasma pneumoniae (Etiology: common cause CAP; Sx: acute f, c, cough, upper resp sx; not usually severe) more from CDC
      • Nocardia (Sites: lung, skin; Etiology: lives in soil, inhaled or via open wound; Sx: subacute cough, f, abscess, cellulitis, lymphangitis if direct inoculation) more from CDC

      Viruses

    • Respiratory
      • Adeno (Etiology/Site: cause of upper respiratory infxn→ common cold, conjunctivitis, otitis media; Sx: cough, nasal congestion, sore throat, ear pain, conjunctival inflamation PE: throat redness, conjunctivitis, anterior auricular adenopathy) more from CDC
      • Enterovirus (non-polio) (Etiology: passed fecal-oral, close contact, ingesting infected water; Site: brain→ meningitis & encephalitis, oral mucosa and skin→ hand/foot/mouth dz, heart→ myocarditis and pericarditis; conjunctiva→ conjunctivitits; upper resp tract; Sx: most have mild illness; w/more severe dz→ fever, ha, cough, runny nose, muscle aches, confusion) more from CDC
      • Hanta (Etiology: rodent exposure, incubation 3-4d; Sx: f, myalgias, HA, n, v, abd pain; then rapidly progressive resp sx) more from CDC
      • Herpes simplex pneumonia (Etiology: can be primary or reactivation; Sites: typically oral, genital or cns; rarely pna; Rfs: passed by sexual or oral contact; Sx/PE: cough, sob, confusion, oral area vesicles)
      • Influenza (Etiology: common cause upper and lower respiratory infection; Rfs: seasonal in North America Oct to April, increase risk amongst old, young, pregnant, chronic lung disease, any chronic illness, no vaccination; Sx: abrupt onset of myalgias, arthralgias, fever, chills) more from CDC
      • Measels (rubeola) (Etiology: spread thru resp droplets, highly contagious; Rfs: too young to be vaccinated (<1y), or never vaccinated; winter/spring in US; Sx: incubation 7-14d; cough, high f, malaise; rash 4-5d after sx onset; PE: conjunctivitis, runny nose, then white (Koplick's) spots on oral mucosa, then rash; complications include encephalitis, pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Middle Eastern Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) (Etiology: coronavirus; Rfs: travel to or close contact in past 14d w/someone from Middle East; Sx: acute fever, cough, sob; sometimes n/v/d; can be rapidly progressive)
      • Para-influenza (Etiology: upper resp infection/croup, tracheobronchitis) more from CDC
      • Rhino (Etiology: cause of upper respiratory infxn→ common cold, typically self limited; Sx: cough, nasal congestion, sore throat) more from CDC
      • RSV (Sites: upper and lower resp tract→ croup, brochiolitis, pna; Rfs: winter mos, typically affects infants and children; in partic if premature or w/chronic lung or heart dz; Sx: cough, fever, sob) more from CDC
      • SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome) (Etiology: corna virus; initial outbreak in China→ rapid spread/pandemic Sx: high fever, aches, sometimes cough; then pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Varicella zoster (chicken pox) (Rfs: rare in kids as vaccine preventable; Sx: f, fatigue, ha, generalized vesicular erruption, duration 5-10d, can still get mild dz if vax, pneumonia in setting severe chicken pox or immunocomp) CDC
    • Liver
      • Hepatitis A (Etiology/Rfs: spread fecal/oral/ingestion contaminated food, can be epidemic, incubation 2-4w; Sx: n, v, RUQ abd pain, puritis, dark urine, light colored stool, f, jaundice, icterus; sx generally resolve w/in 2-4w; very rarely fulminant, not assoc w/chronic infxn; PE: jaundice, icterus, RUQ pain, hepatomegaly)
      • Hepatitis B (RFs: spread via sexual contact, vertical, shared needles, needle sticks in health care workers, unscreened blood transfusion; Sx: many are asx; incubataion is 1-4m; acute infxn assoc w/n, v, jaundice; puritus, icterus, dark urine, light colored stool, malaise; typically self limited, w/resoln sx 2-3m; 5% go on to chronic infxn, w/risk cirrhosis, spread to others, and hcc decades after initial infxn; PE: chronic infxn can lead to icterus, jaudice and other findings of chronic liver dz)
      • Hepatitis C (RFs: spread via needles, unscreened blood transfusion, shared cocaine inhaling tools, needle sticks in health care workers, vertical, sexual; 10-20% resolve spontaneously; long term risk cirrhosis and HCC w/chronic infxn; Sx: most w/acute hep C are asx; those w/sx have RUQ pain, f, malaise, jaudice; can have sx cirrhosis and hcc decades later; PE: most have no findings in acute phase; chronic infxn can lead to icterus, jaudice and other findings of chronic liver dz)
      • Hepatitis D (RFs: occurs as a co-infection w/hep b, uncommon in west, found in Mediterranean and Asian countries; spread via same mechanisms as hep b)
      • Hepatitis E (RFs: uncommon in western nations, though most common cause of acute hep in developing world, can be sporadic or epidemic, water born w/spread similar to hep a; Sx: incubation 3-8w, sx of malaise, n, jaundice x ~ 2w; usually self limited, rarely fulminant, rarely chronic)
        • More on viral hepatitis from CDC
      • EBV→ mononucleosis (Sx: incubation 4-6w, pro-drome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias; then f, sore throat; rash w/amox; PE: head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly) more from CDC
      • CMV (Etol/Rfs: retinitis/colitis/disseminated dz in patients w/HIV; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w; Sx: f, c, malaise hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, fatigue x 4-6w; head/neck adenopathy & pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC
    • Small bowel
      • Norovirus (Etiology/Rfs: common cause of acute enteritis in adults, daycare/hospitals/nursing homes; Sx: abrupt onset n, v, diarrhea, low grade f) more from CDC
      • Rotavirus (Etiology/Rfs: common cause of acute enteritis in kids <5; vaccine preventable; Sx: abrupt onset n, v, diarrhea, f) more from CDC
    • Neuro
      • Arbovirus (encephalitis) (Etiology: carried by mosquitos; cause an array of infections including equine, west nile, lacrosse, other; Sx: incubation 2d-2w; f, fatigue, HA, stiff neck, delirium) more from CDC
      • Enterovirus (non-polio) (Etiology: passed fecal-oral, close contact, ingesting infected water; Site: brain→ meningitis & encephalitis, oral mucosa and skin→ hand/foot/mouth dz, heart→ myocarditis and pericarditis; conjunctiva→ conjunctivitits; upper resp tract; Sx: most have mild illness; w/more severe dz→ fever, ha, cough, runny nose, muscle aches, confusion) more from CDC
      • Herpes simplex encephalitis (Etiology: can be primary or reactivation; RFs: passed by sexual or oral contact; Sx: acute, HA, delirium vesicles)
      • Measels (rubeola) (Etiology: spread thru resp droplets, highly contagious; Rfs: too young to be vaccinated (<1y), or never vaccinated; winter/spring in US; Sx: incubation 7-14d; cough, high f, malaise; rash 4-5d after sx onset; PE: conjunctivitis, runny nose, then white (Koplick's) spots on oral mucosa, then rash; complications include encephalitis, pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Polio - eradicated in US w/vaccine (Etiology: summer mos, most have no sx; Sx: fever, headache, stiff neck/back, limb pain→ a minority of these develop flacid paralysis of legs, respiratory muscles) more from CDC
      • Rabies (Etiology: bite from infected animal→ skunk, bat, squirrel, dog; incubation can be days to mos→ time to travel along pns to cns; Sx: f, ha, myalgias, arthralgias, hydrophobia, intermitent confusion/agitation, sensitivity to sound/light, pain at bite site, autonomic dysfxn; 20% w/progressive flaccid paralysis, starting near bite; sx onset to death avg 4d) more from CDC
      • West Nile (Etiology: incubation 2d-2w; summer/fall in North America; Sx: fever, muscle aches, confusion, ha, stiff neck, rash, confusion→ meningo-encephalitis) more from CDC
    • Associated w/derm manifestations
      • Coxsackievirus (enterovirus) (Etiology: myocarditis, pericarditis, erruption on palms/soles; Sx: w/cardiac involvement chest pain, sob; in kids f, malaise, vessicles in mouth and hands and soles) More from CDC
      • Herpes simplex oral/genital infxn (Etiology: primary infxn sometimes assoc w/fever; Sites: genital, oral; Rfs: passed by sexual or oral contact; Sx/PE: acute, painful, genital or oral area vesicles, adenopathy) more from CDC
      • HPV (Sites/Sx: painless growth in genital or rectal areas, spread sexually, years later causes cervical cancer, head/neck scc, penile scc; PE: clustered growths, genital warts, peri-anal warts) more from CDC
      • Parvo (Rfs: most common ages 5-19, Sx/PE: slapped cheek rash, also rash on arms, soles, palms; acute arthralgias/arthritis that can mimic RA; can cause acute hypoprolif anemia) CDC
      • Measels (rubeola) (Etiology: spread thru resp droplets, highly contagious; Rfs: too young to be vaccinated (<1y), or never vaccinated; winter/spring in US; Sx: incubation 7-14d; cough, high f, malaise; rash 4-5d after sx onset; PE: conjunctivitis, runny nose, then white (Koplick's) spots on oral mucosa, then rash; complications include encephalitis, pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Rubella (Rfs: uncommon w/vaccination; Sx: rash starts on face, fever, adenopathy; can be congenitally acquired)
      • Varicella zoster (chicken pox) (Rfs: rare in kids as vaccine preventable; Sx: f, fatigue, ha, generalized vesicular erruption, duration 5-10d, can still get mild dz if vax, pneumonia in setting severe chicken pox or immunocomp) CDC
    • Associated w/MSK manifestations
      • CMV (Sx/PE: retinitis/colitis/disseminated dz in patients w/HIV; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w, then f, c, malaise hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, fatigue x 4-6w; head/neck adenopathy & pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC
      • Chikungunya (RFs: travel to Carribean, mosquitoe bite; Sx: fever, symmetric arthralgia, inflammatory arthritis wrists, fingers, ankles; muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash; onset 3-7d after bite; usually last days to weeks, sometimes mos) more from CDC
      • Dengue (Etiology: spread by aedes aegypti mosquito; RFs: exposure in tropics, SE Asia, Carribean, South America; Sx: incubation 4-7d, abrupt onset high fever, aches, retro-orbital pain, bone/muscle/joint pain, often low back pain, maculo-pap rash; sx resolve in 3-4d; can recur) more from CDC
      • Ebola (Etiology: spread via close human contact, bats as reservoir; RFs: travel to West Africa or exposure to someone at risk, spread via contact w/body fluids of infected person; Sx: incubation of up to 3w; high fever, fatigue, aches→ 0-3d; epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, arthralgias, myalgias, sorethroat, chest pain, headaches, delirium, conjunctival injection→ 3-10d; severe illness, shock, GI hemorrhage or other complications, death or recovery→ 7-12d) more from CDC
