      • EBV (mononucleosis) (Rfs: spread by direct contact→ kissing, shared drinking glasses, shared toothbrushes, etc; Sx: incubation 4-6w, prodrome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias, then f, sore throat; PE: maculo-pap rash after amox or other abx, head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly) more from CDC
      • Enterovirus (non-polio) (Etiology: passed fecal-oral, close contact, ingesting infected water; Site: brain→ meningitis & encephalitis, oral mucosa and skin→ hand/foot/mouth dz, heart→ myocarditis and pericarditis; conjunctiva→ conjunctivitits; upper resp tract; Sx: most have mild illness; w/more severe dz→ fever, ha, cough, runny nose, muscle aches, confusion) more from CDC
      • Hep B (acute)(RFs: spread via sexual contact, vertical, shared needles, needle sticks in health care workers, unscreened blood transfusion; Sx: many are asx; incubation is 1-4m; acute infxn assoc w/n, v, jaundice; puritus, icterus, dark urine, light colored stool, malaise; typically self limited, w/resoln sx 2-3m; a minority develop symetric inflammatory arthritis of MCPs, PIP, knees, ankles; resoves in few weeks; PE: jaundice, icterus, RUQ pain, hepatomegaly, symetric inflammatory arthritis)
      • Influenza (Etiology: common cause upper and lower respiratory infection; Rfs: seasonal in North America Oct to April, increase risk amongst old, young, pregnant, chronic lung disease, any chronic illness, no vaccination; Sx: abrupt onset of myalgias, arthralgias, fever, chills) more from CDC
      • Parvo (Sx: acute, febrile illness in ages 5-19, runny nose, headache PE: skin erruption w/slapped cheek appearance, also rash on arms, soles, palms; sometimes symetric inflammatory arthritis can mimic RA; can cause acute hypoprolif anemia) more from CDC
      • West Nile (Etiology: incubation 2d-2w; summer/fall in North America; Site: brain→ meningitis & encephalitis; Sx: fever, muscle aches, confusion, ha, stiff neck, rash, confusion) more from CDC
    • Associated w/ f, c, aches, fatigue
      • Chikungunya (RFs: travel to Carribean, mosquitoe bite; Sx: fever, symmetric arthralgia, inflammatory arthritis wrists, fingers, ankles; muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash; onset 3-7d after bite; usually last days to weeks, sometimes mos) more from CDC
      • CMV (Sx/PE: retinitis/colitis/disseminated dz in patients w/HIV; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w, then f, c, malaise hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, fatigue x 4-6w; head/neck adenopathy & pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC
      • Dengue (Etiology: spread by aedes aegypti mosquito; RFs: exposure in tropics, SE Asia, Carribean, South America; Sx: incubation 4-7d, abrupt onset high fever, aches, retro-orbital pain, bone/muscle/joint pain, often low back pain, maculo-pap rash; sx resolve in 3-4d; can recur) more from CDC
      • Ebola (Etiology: spread via close human contact, bats as reservoir; RFs: travel to West Africa or exposure to someone at risk, spread via contact w/body fluids of infected person; Sx: incubation of up to 3w; high fever, fatigue, aches→ 0-3d; epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, arthralgias, myalgias, sorethroat, chest pain, headaches, delirium, conjunctival injection→ 3-10d; severe illness, shock, GI hemorrhage or other complications, death or recovery→ 7-12d) more from CDC
      • EBV (mononucleosis) (Rfs: spread by direct contact→ kissing, shared drinking glasses, shared toothbrushes, etc; Sx: incubation 4-6w, prodrome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias, then f, sore throat; PE: maculo-pap rash after amox or other abx, head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly) more from CDC
    • Associated w/parotid, testicular, cardiac involvement
      • Coxsackievirus (Sites: myocarditis, pericarditis, palms/soles; Sx: w/cardiac involvement chest pain, sob; in kids f, malaise, vessicles in mouth and hands and soles) More from CDC
      • Mumps (Etiology: uncommon w/vaccination; Sx: f, myalgia, malaise, affects B parotids and testicles) More from CDC

      Systemic fungal

      • Aspergillus (Rfs: lung dz assoc w/immunocompromised host and/or w/structual lung dz→ e.g. bronchiectasis; Sites: lungs→ can be tissue invasive or chronic (e.g. fungal ball); sinuses, skin, other; Sx: can be indolent or acute; cough, sob, wt loss, cp, fatigue, hemoptysis; facial fullness/pain, nasal d/c→ invasive sinusitis in patients w/DM or otherwise compromised; recurrent wheezing in normal hosts→ ABPA)
      • Blastomycosis (Rfs: lives in soil; Sx: many normal hosts wont develop infxn, more likely if compromised; inhaled→ sub-acute cough, f, sob; up to 15 w after exposure)
      • Candida (Rfs: compromised host→ HIV, chemo, steroids, long term abx w/indwelling lines, TPN use, long ICU stays; Sx: fevers, sytemic sx/sepsis)
      • Coccidioidomycosis (Etiology: south west US, higher risk if immune-compromised Site: lung parenchyma and pleural space, joints, skin; Sx: sub-acute sob also arthritis, PE: inflammatory arthritis, skin nodules, seeding of other sites)
      • Histoplasmosis (Sites; lungs, liver, spleen, mouth, systemic; Rfs: exposure to Mississippi & Ohio river valley, HIV+; Sx: can be asx/mild and resolve spont; often see x-ray evidence prior infection lung, spleen w/o known past infxn; cough, fever; can cause resp/systemic illness, oral ulcers in HIV+)
      • Mucor (Sites: lung→ pneumonia, sinuses→ invasive sinusitis; Rf: DM or otherwise compromised; PE: cough, fever, HA, sinus pain)
      • Pneumocystis jerovecii (Sites: lung; Rfs: HIV + and cd4 < 200, prolonged steroid use; Sx: cough, f, sob pneumonia)
      • Cryptococcus (Rfs: immunocompromised, CD4 < 50 or untreated HIV; Sx/PE: sub-acute headache, fever, confusion, adenopathy)
      • More on fungi from CDC

      Mycobacteria

      • M tuberculosis (MTB) (RFs: HIV +, steroids, chronic kidney, liver or lung dz; ivdu, from enedemic area, healthcare worker, otherwise immunocomp; extra-pulm TB increases in HIV+ w/CD4 < 350; Sx: sub-acute, cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, sweats, fatigue; can also infect GI/GU tracts; adenopathy) more from CDC
      • Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC)(Rfs: HIV + for diarrhea, bronchiectasis for lung sx; Sx: diarrhea in HIV +; persistent/progressive lung infection in patients with bronchiectasis) more from CDC
      • Mycobacterium avium intracellulare (MAI) (Rfs: HIV +, CD4 < 50; Sx: diarrhea, n, v, abdominal pain, f, c, fatigue; can infect liver, spleen, lymph nodes, bone marrow, lung, pericardium→ causing adenopathy or organomegaly, anemia)

      Retrovirus (HIV)

      • HIV (Etiology/Rfs: hiv risk factors→ men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; risks of unusual infection increase as CD4 declines; Sx: acute infection→ fever, chills, sweats, adenopathy, rash, pharyngitis w/in 2-4 weeks - then resolves; latency until sx develop 6-10y after initial infxn (if not treated) related to drop in CD4: generalized sx include f, c, cough, wt loss; other illnesses: mucosal candidiasis; fungal, mtb lung infection; persistent diarrhea; CNS toxo; non hodgkins lymphoma; kaposis sarcoma of skin, adenopathy, etc) more from CDC

      Spirochetes

      • Borrelia burgdorferi (lyme) (Etiology: tick borne, endemic area north east, upper mid west, tick contact x 24-48h; incubation days to weeks; Sx: rash, f, c, aches; then arthralgias, heart block, CNS involvement; later still arthritis; can co-infect w/organisms causing babesiosis and anaplasmosis) more from CDC
      • Borrelia miyamotoi (Etiology: tick borne, endemic area north east, summer mos; Sx: f, c, headache, arthralgias, myalgias, malaise/fatigue; PE: often ill appearing, sometimes faint lacy rash) more from CDC
      • Borrelia - other sp (relapsing fever) (Etiology: tick borne, mountainous US→ West/Southwest, plateau of Mexico, South America; fever x ~3d→ then fever free x 1w→ then recurs; chills, ha, muscle aches, n, photophobia, joint aches, confusion; PE: non-specific; sometimes conj injection, confusion, mac-pap rash)
      • Leptospirosis (Etiology: contract via exposure to rodent/wild animal feces; incubation period several weeks; Sx/PE: mild dz is self limited f, c, ha, n, v, muscle aches, conjunctival injection; severe dz with hepatic and renal involvement, icterus) CDC
      • Syphillis (Rfs: sexual exposure, Etiology/Sx/PE: primary, secondary and tertiary manifestations; primary infection causes painless genital ulcer, ~3w after exposure → heals 4-6w, regional adenopathy; secondary manifestations weeks to mos later w/non-specific rash, predilection for palms, and soles; condyloma around genital areas, mucous involvement, generalized adenopathy, f, sweats, eyes→ iritis/uveitis; tertiary manifestations yrs later affecting CNS→ numbness, weakness, balance problems, dementia; large blood vessels→ aortitis, aneurysm) More from CDC

      Rickettsiae

      Obligate intracellular gram negative bacteria which are spread by tick, mite, flea, louse, or chiggers.
      • Anaplasmosis (Etiology: tick born, incubation 1-2w, Midwest and Eastern US; can co-infect w/organisms causing Lyme and basesiosis; Sx: f, ha, n, v, myalgias; often causes BM suppression)
      • Human ehrlichiosis (Etiology: tick borne, incubation 1-2w, endemic South Eastern, South Central and Eastern US; similar presentation to anaplasmosis; Sx: f, ha, n, v, myalgias; often causes BM suppression)
      • Rocky Mtn Spotted Fever (Etiology: tick borne, incubation 2d to 2w; can occur in most states in US, Sx: f, c, ha, arthralgias, then generalized rash - though not always, can be severe/fatal)
      • Coxiella Burnetti (Q fever: Rickettsia-like) (Etiology: spread from cattle and sheep, incubation 5d-2w; Sx: fever, chills, severe ha, myalgias, malaise, cough, abd pain; many recover spont; can cause pneumonia, hepatitis, myocarditis)
      • Typhus (various types) (Etiology: spread via flea, louse or tick, reservoirs often rodents squirrels; summer mos, incubation 1-2w, Central/South America, Asia, Central Africa, tropics; Sx: non-specific f, c, ha, malaise, myalgias; PE: non-specific mac-pap rash, sometimes adenopathy)
      • More on Rickettsiae from CDC

      Parasites

      An organism that lives on or in host and gets its food from or @ expense of its host. Liklihood of infection linked to geographic exposure(s).
    • Associated w/diarrhea or other intestinal sx
      • American Trypanosomiasis (chagas dz - t cruzi) (Etiology: Central and South America, via reduviid bug bite; incubation 1-2w; Sx: most have no acute sx; if acute sx present, can include→ f, c, sweats, malaise, ha, n, v, d x weeks; chronic sx in 20-30%, including: lower esophageal dysmotility; cardiomyopathy→ CHF, dysrhythmia; PE: rare acute findings: skin nodule at bite; eyelid edema)
      • Cryptosporidia (Rfs: young/old/immunocomp at greatest risk, spread fecal oral, assoc w/daycare center outbreaks; Sx: n, v, diarrhea, cramps, fever)
      • Entamoeba histolytica→ amebiasis (protozoa) (Etiology: acquired via unclean water/poor sanitation, also anal intercourse; Sx: only 10-20% develop sx; incubation 2-4w; abd pain, bloody diarreha; occas liver abscess)
      • Schistosomiasis (fluke) (Etiology: South America, Middle East, Caribbean, Africa: flukes, invade skin of swimmers, enter blood stream→ live in portal/mesenteric veins; Sx: can cause cirrhosis after years; also f, c, abd pain, diarrhea; can live in bladder → SCC after years)
      • Trichinella (roundworm) (Etiology: rare in US; from eating infected meat; Sx: abd pain, n, v, diarrhea; after 1-2w, f, muscle pain when migrate to muscles, rash, ha, n, v, itching)
    • Assoc w/hepato-biliary sx
      • Ascariasis (Etiology: tropics/sub-tropics/SE US, eggs swallowed if contaminated soil ingested (e.g. human feces used as fertilizer)→ eggs hatch in intestines → larvae enter blood stream → migrate lungs → mature & coughed up → swallowed → mature in intestines; Sx: often asx; if heavy worm burden→ cough, fever, sob, n, v, abd pain, impaired growth of children, sbo; can migrate to biliary tree and cause obstruction & related complications)
      • Entamoeba histolytica→ amebiasis (protozoa) (Etiology: acquired via unclean water/poor sanitation, also anal intercourse; Sx: only 10-20% develop sx; incubation 2-4w; abd pain, bloody diarreha; occas liver abscess)
      • Echinococcus (tapeworm) (Etiology: main host is cattle and dogs; common in US and many other areas; eggs ingested by humans → travel to liver→ Sx: cysts form & can cause RUQ pain→ compress biliary tract → if rupture can cause anaphylaxis)
      • Schistosomiasis (fluke) (Etiology: South America, Middle East, Caribbean, Africa: flukes, invade skin of swimmers, enter blood stream→ live in portal/mesenteric veins; Sx: can cause cirrhosis after years; also f, c, abd pain, diarrhea; can live in bladder → SCC after years)
    • Assoc w/respiratory sx
      • Toxocariasis (aka visceral larva migrans or roundworm) (Etiology: definitive hosts are cats and dogs; humans ingest eggs from dirt→ eggs hatch in intestines→ larvae can travel to lungs, eyes, CNS, liver; Sx: many are asx; can cause cough, f, visual loss, hepatitis)
      • Ascariasis (Etiology: tropics/sub-tropics/SE US, eggs swallowed if contaminated soil ingested (e.g. human feces used as fertilizer)→ eggs hatch in intestines → larvae enter blood stream → migrate lungs → mature & coughed up → swallowed → mature in intestines; Sx: often asx; if heavy worm burden→ cough, f, sob, n, v, abd pain, impaired growth of children, sbo)
      • Strongyloidiasis (Etiology: warm/temperate regions including southeast US, tropics/subtropics including Asia/Southeast Asia; larvae enter thru feet/skin if walk barefoot in soil w/infected feces→ enter skin, where they can cause itching→ travel to lung→ penetrate alveoli and travel up trachea→ cough and then swallowed→ travel to and live in small intestine; Sx: most carry life-long w/o any sx; non-compromised hosts can have vague sx including cough, f, sob, epigastic pain, weakness, watery diarrhea, itching, constipation; can cause life threatening hyper-infxn syndrome w/systemic symptoms if compromised from glucocorticoids, malignancy, HTLV-1 or organ transplant; PE: sometimes serpiginous red erruption from migrating larva under skin)
    • Assoc w/cardiac sx
      • American Trypanosomiasis (chagas dz - t cruzi) (Etiology: Central and South America, via reduviid bug bite; incubation 1-2w; Sx: most have no acute sx; if acute sx present, can include→ f, c, sweats, malaise, ha, n, v, d x weeks; chronic sx in 20-30%, including: lower esophageal dysmotility; cardiomyopathy→ CHF, dysrhythmia; PE: rare acute findings: skin nodule at bite; eyelid edema)
    • Assoc w/ f, c, sweats
      • B. microti→ babesiosis (protozoa) (Etiology: tick born, endemic Northeast/Norhtern Mid-west US; can co-infect w/lyme and anaplasmosis; Sx: 1-4 w after infxn; subacute f, c, sweats, HA, muscle aches; in severe cases hemolytic anemia, kidney, liver injury, resp distress)
      • African Trypanosomiasis (t brucei sleeping sickness) (Etiology: Africa, from tsetse fly; Sx: f, c, HA, delirium, muscle and joint aches, death in mos if untreated; PE: chancre→ skin sore at bite site, adenopathy)
      • Malaria (Etiology: spread by anopheles mosquito, tropical climates, in partic Southeast Asia, Africa; variants = P vivax, falciparum, ovale and malariae; Sx: incubation 1-4w; recurrent high fevers, C, HA; mild to life threatening (falciparum))
      • Toxoplasmosis (protozoa) (Etiology: carried in cat feces, healthy hosts not affected, in HIV + causes brain infection cd4 < 200; pregnant women can pass in utero→ congenital abnormalities; Sx: acute f, c, headache, delirium, szr, eye pain and visual loss from retinal involvement)
      • W bancrofti (filariasis) (Rfs/Etiology; tropics/sub-tropics, spread by mosquitoes; Sx: most are asx and wont have sequelae; some will have acute f, c, adenopathy; filaria invade lymphatis, after years→ lymphedema from obstruction of channels; PE: in some, chronic lymphedema)
    • Assoc w/neuro & muscle sx
      • Malaria (Etiology: spread by anopheles mosquito, tropical climates, in partic Southeast Asia, Africa; variants = P vivax, falciparum, ovale and malariae; incubation 1-4w; Sx: recurrent high fevers, C, HA; mild to life threatening (falciparum))
      • Toxoplasmosis (protozoa) (Etiology: carried in cat feces, healthy hosts not affected, in HIV + causes brain infection cd4 < 200; pregnant women can pass in utero→ congenital abnormalities; Sx: acute f, c, headache, delirium, szr)
      • Trichinella (roundworm) (Etiology: rare in US; from eating infected meat; Sx: abd pain, n, v, diarrhea; after 1-2w, f, muscle pain when migrate to muscles, rash, ha, n, v, itching)
    • Assoc w/eye sx
      • Toxoplasmosis (protozoa) (Etiology: carried in cat feces, healthy hosts not affected, in HIV + causes brain infection cd4 < 200; pregnant women can pass in utero→ congenital abnormalities; Sx: acute f, c, headache, delirium, szr, eye pain and visual loss from retinal involvement)
    • Assoc w/lymph edema
      • W bancrofti (filariasis) (Rfs/Etiology; tropics/sub-tropics, spread by mosquitoes; Sx: most are asx and wont have sequelae; some will have acute f, c, adenopathy; filaria invade lymphatis, after years→ lymphedema from obstruction of channels; PE: in some, chronic lymphedema)
    • Assoc w/cutaneous sx
      • Leishmaniasis (Etiology: spread by sand-fly bite, subtropics; Sx/PE: cutaneous→ sores/ulcers; visceral→ can be silent, or cause fevers, sweats, chills, wt loss, adnenopathy, organomegaly)
      CDC: parasites

      Infxn by Organ System

      Eye

      Ext Struct

      • Blepharitis (Sx/Pe: redness along eye-lid margins, itchy, no visual loss)
      • Hordeolum (stye) (Sx: acute/sub-acute, discomfort, preserved vision; PE: red bump, focal redness)
      • Dacrocystitis (Rfs: much more common in children; Sx/PE: acute pain and redness over medial lower lid where tears drain, acute, no visual loss, unilateral)

      Globe/Peri-globe

      • Orbital cellulitis (Rf: infected sinuses→ ethmoid; Sx: acute pain, worse w/eye movement, loss of vision; PE: diffuse redness, proptosis)
      • Pre-septal cellulitis (Sx: acute, red, painful skin, though eye itself w/o pain, preserved vision, full mobility; PE: red, edematous skin around eye)

      Conjunctiva

      • Viral (Genl) (Etiology: adeno, other; Sx: acute, redness of conjunctiva, URI sx, watery discharge, no visual change, uni- or bilateral, gritty sensation; PE: diffuse redness, often clear d/c)
      • Adenoviru (Etiology/Site: cause of upper respiratory infxn→ common cold, conjunctivitis, otitis media; Sx: cough, nasal congestion, sore throat, ear pain, conjunctival inflamation; much less commonly pneumonia; PE: throat redness, conjunctivitis, anterior auricular adenopathy) more from CDC
      • Enterovirus (non-polio) (Etiology: passed fecal-oral, close contact, ingesting infected water; Site: brain→ meningitis & encephalitis, oral mucosa and skin→ hand/foot/mouth dz, heart→ myocarditis and pericarditis; conjunctiva→ conjunctivitits; upper resp tract; Sx: most have mild illness; w/more severe dz→ fever, ha, cough, runny nose, muscle aches, confusion) more from CDC
      • Measels Virus (rubeola) (Etiology: spread thru resp droplets, highly contagious; Rfs: too young to be vaccinated (<1y), or never vaccinated; winter/spring in US; Sx: incubation 7-14d; cough, high f, malaise; rash 4-5d after sx onset; PE: conjunctivitis, runny nose, then white (Koplick's) spots on oral mucosa, then rash; complications include encephalitis, pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Bacterial (Genl) (Etiology: staph, h flu, strep, moraxella, neiserria; Sx: acute, red, opaque d/c, itchy/irritated, no visual change, uni- or bilateral; copious d/c if neisseria in partic; PE: diffuse redness of conjunctiva, pus)
        • Chlamydia trachomatis (trachoma) (Etiology: spread thru poor hand hygiene, sharing towels, or via flies, endemic in poor/developing countries, a leading cause blindness world-wide; Sx: chronic, purulent conjunctivitis, can lead to scarring of lid→ inward turned lashes→ scarring of cornea→ blindness) more from CDC
      • More on conjunctivitis from CDC

      Cornea/Ant&Post Chambers

      • Keratitis (Etiology: can be bacterial, viral→ hsv, vzv, fungal or parasitic→ onchocerciasis; also from trauma/fb, chemical exposure, or contact lens use; Sx: acute, painful, unilateral visual loss; PE: diffusely red, other findings of herpes zoster in v1 dermatome if that's the cause)
        • Onchocerciasis (worm - river blindness) (Etiology: causes river blindness, Africa/Central & South America; worm spread by black fly bite; Sx: conjunctivits/keratitis→ vision loss, skin nodules)
      • Endopthalmitis (Rfs/Etiology: infection inside the eye, can be complication of trauma, cataract surgery, or seeding from systemic bacteremia; Sx: acute, pain w/any movement, f, loss of vision; PE: diffuse redness, pus in anterior chamber)
      • Iritis/anterior uveitis (Etiology: assoc w/autoimmune dz→ ankylosing spond, sarcoid, reactive arthritis, behcet's dz, IBD; infxn→ HSV, secondary syphillis, VZV, TB; often idiopathic; Sx: acute pain, photophobia, impaired vision; PE: decreased acuity, irreg appearance of pupil, circumferential redness at cornea-sclera junction, sometimes layered pus in anterior chamber→ hypopyon; other systemic manifestations of the primary disease; can have pan-uveitis)
      • Posterior uveitis (Etiology: assoc w/autoimmune dz→ sarcoid, behcet's dz; malignancy→ lymphoma; infxn→ toxo, CMV, brucellosis, HSV, VZV, secondary syphillis, TB; often idiopathic; Sx: decreased vision, pain, photophobia; PE: decreased acuity, may not have external inflammatory findings unless pan-uveitis; other findings assoc w/underlying dz)

      Retina

      • Retinal infection - often HIV or otherwise immuncomp - CMV, toxoplasmosis, endocarditis (PE: retinal exudates/cotton wool spots)
      • Toxocariasis (parasite - aka visceral larva migrans or roundworm) (Etiology: definitive hosts are cats and dogs; humans ingest eggs from dirt→ eggs hatch in intestines→ larvae can travel to lungs, eyes, CNS, liver; Sx: many are asx; can cause cough, fever, visual loss, hepatitis)
      • Toxoplasmosis (protozoa) (Etiology: carried in cat feces, healthy hosts not affected, in HIV + causes brain infection cd4 < 200; pregnant women can pass in utero→ congenital abnormalities; Sx: acute f, c, headache, delirium, szr, eye pain and visual loss from retinal involvement)
      • CMV (virus) (Sx/PE: retinitis, colitis, disseminated dz in patients w/HIV; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w, then f, c, malaise hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, fatigue x 4-6w; head/neck adenopathy & pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC

      Head and Neck

      Mouth/Throat/Neck

      • Acute Pharyngitis
        • Grp A, Beta Hemolytic Strep (bacterial) (Sx: acute, fever, pain, absence of cough; PE: exudate & reddness, palpable LN, palatal petechiae) more from CDC
        • Other bacteria (Etiology: Strep Grp B and G)
        • Neisseria gonorrhea (bacterial) (Site: urethra, cervix, uterus, fallopian tubes, testes, pharynx, ano-rectal, joints; Sx: pharyngeal infection often asx, but can cause sore throat; Rfs: oral sexual activity; PE: penile d/c, cervical d/c, cervical pain and uterine pain if PID; pharyngeal inflammation & exudates; anorectal d/c; if disseminated→ pustules, infectious arthritis) more from CDC
        • Diptheria (bacterial) (Site: upper respiratory tract; Sx: cough, f, sore throat, uncommon now w/vax; PE: pseudo-membrane w/airway obstruction) more from CDC
        • EBV→ mono (viral) (Sx: acutely painful sore throat, fever→ sometimes prolonged, fatigue, doesn't respond to abx; PE: pharyngeal redness, exudate, and adenopathy; sometimes splenomegaly) more from CDC
        • Other viral (e.g. influenza) (Sx: abrupt onset, high fever, cough, myalgias; other viruses: rhino, adeno, others; PE: red posterior pharynx) More on upper respiratory infections CDC
      • Peri-tonsilar abscess (Sx: acute pain, worse then simple pharyngitis, localizes to one side, problems/pain swallowing, if severe→ airway compreomise; PE: focal swelling in tonsilar area, uvula deviated away)
      • Retro-pharyngeal abscess (Etiology: spread of infxn from adjacent space; Sx: f, c, acute, difficulty swallowing or handling secretions, difficulty speaking, sob; PE: sitting up, drooling, swelling in post pharynx, neck swelling, stridor)
      • Acute HIV (primary infxn) (Rfs: men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/somone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; Sx/PE: throat pain and redness w/o exudate, fevers, chills, non-specific rash, adenopathy)
      • Candida (Rfs: immuno-supressed→ chemo or hiv, abx exposure, steroids; PE: white exudate on mucosa, bleeds when scraped)
      • HSV (Sx: pain can precede appearance, worse if immunocmop, can be recurrent; PE: clear vessicles on red base, small ulcer after uncovered)
      • Epiglotitis (Sx: acute, f, can't swallow, sob, pain in anterior neck; PE: ill appearing, sitting upright, drooling, "hot potato" voice)
      • Lemierre's synd (septic thrombophlebitis of jugular vein) (Etiology: fusobacterium; Sx: starts as sore throat, may improve over few days, then worsens; pain also lateral neck, f, c, sweats, sob/cp if septic pulm emboli, severe illness; PE: febrile, pharyngeal inflamation, warmth and pain over lateral neck)
      • More on sore throats from CDC
      • Dental infection (Sx: acute pain, localized to affected tooth or adjacent tissue if spreading; PE: gingival swelling; pain reproduced when tooth is tapped)
      • Syphilis (Rfs: men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/somone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's; PE: other findings assoc w/secondary syphillis including: non-specific rash, w/predilection for palms, and soles; hx painless genital ulcer from primary infxn)
      • Histoplasmosis (Sites; lungs, liver, spleen, mouth, systemic; Rfs: exposure to Mississippi & Ohio river valley, HIV+; Sx: can be asx/mild and resolve spont; often see x-ray evidence prior infection lung, spleen w/o known past infxn; cough, fever; can cause resp/systemic illness, oral ulcers in HIV+)
      • Ludwig's Angina (submandibular space infection) (Etiology: typically starts as dental infection, spreads to submandibular space; Sx: acute, neck/submandibular area pain and swelling in submandibular area, f, difficulty swallowing, drooling, airway compromise; PE: f, ill appearing, sitting up, foul breath, diffiuclty opening mouth, acute & painful submandibular swelling, indurated and red skin, sometimes co-existent dental infection)

      Adenop (Infxn)

      Bacterial, viral, retroviral, mycobacterial, fungal & spirochetes
      • Staph (Sites: direct skin infection; Sx: fever, pain/swelling at primary as well as affected lymph nodes; PE: redness, warmth, induration, fluctuance)
      • Streptococcus: Group A (Sites: associated w/pharyngitis or direct infection of LN; PE: strep throat→ pharyngeal erythema, d/c, adenop, LNs warm, tender, enlarged) more from CDC
      • Primary dental or other oral infection (Etiology: adenopathy reflects local spread from primary site in mouth/teeth; PE: focus of infection identified in mouth; lymph nodes warm, tender, swollen)
      • Bartonella henslae (cat scratch) (Sites: skin and lymph nodes; Rfs/Etiology: caused by cat scratch; Sx: may see inflamation at innoculation site, then tender regional adenopathy w/in few weeks, fatigue, fever) more from CDC
      • Brucella (Sites: systemic; Etiology: ingestion of raw/uncooked dairy or handling infected animals; Rfs: veterinarians, meat packers, slaughter house workers, farmers; Middle East, Mediterranean, Mexico, Africa; Sx/PE: causes weeks/months of recurrent f, c, sweats, arthritis, adenopathy, orchitis, hepato-splenomegaly) more from CDC
      • Francisella tularensis (tularemia) (Sites: skin, lymph nodes; Etiology/Rfs: passed from dying wild animals to humans via ticks/insects, US Southeast and Rocky Mtns; Sx: f, c, ha, oral or skin ulcers, painful adenopathy, sob, muscle aches) more from CDC
      • HIV (Etiology/Rfs: hiv risk factors→ men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; risks of unusual infection increase as CD4 declines; Sx: acute infection→ fever, chills, sweats, adenopathy, rash, pharyngitis w/in 2-4 weeks - then resolves; latency until sx develop 6-10y after initial infxn (if not treated) related to drop in CD4: generalized sx include f, c, cough, wt loss; other illnesses: mucosal candidiasis; fungal, mtb lung infection; persistent diarrhea; CNS toxo; non hodgkins lymphoma; kaposis sarcoma of skin, adenopathy, etc) more from CDC
      • CMV (Sx/PE: retinitis, colitis, disseminated dz in patients w/HIV; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w, then f, c, malaise hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, fatigue x 4-6w; head/neck adenopathy & pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC
      • EBV (mononucleosis) (Rfs: spread by direct contact→ kissing, shared drinking glasses, shared toothbrushes, etc; Sx: incubation 4-6w, prodrome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias, then f, sore thorat; PE: maculo-pap rash after amox or other abx, head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly) more from CDC
      • Herpes simplex oral infxn (Etiology: primary infxn sometimes assoc w/fever; Sites: oral; Rfs: passed by sexual or oral contact; Sx/PE: acute, painful, genital or oral area vesicles, inguinal adenopathy) more from CDC
      • Other viral resp infxn
      • M tuberculosis (MTB) (RFs: HIV +, steroids, chronic kidney, liver or lung dz; ivdu, from enedemic area, healthcare worker, otherwise immunocomp; extra-pulm TB increases in HIV+ w/CD4 < 350; Sx: sub-acute, cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, sweats, fatigue; can also infect GI/GU tracts; adenopathy most commonly head/neck→ scrofula) more from CDC
      • Tinea capitis (Sx/PE: scaly, inflamed, raised, well defined patch(es) on scalp, associated w/focal hair loss, adenopathy occipital region of scalp)
      • Syphillis (Rfs: sexual exposure, Etiology/Sx/PE: primary, secondary and tertiary manifestations; primary infection causes painless genital ulcer, ~3w after exposure → heals 4-6w, regional adenopathy; secondary manifestations weeks to mos later w/non-specific rash, predilection for palms, and soles; condyloma around genital areas, mucous involvement, generalized adenopathy, f, sweats, eyes→ iritis/uveitis; tertiary manifestations yrs later affecting CNS→ numbness, weakness, balance problems, dementia; large blood vessels→ aortitis, aneurysm) More from CDC

      Ear related

      • Middle ear infection→ otitis media (Etiology: bacterial or viral; Sx: acute ear pain, muffled hearing, other uri sx→ cough, nasal congestion, fever; PE: evidence effusion behind ear drum; favoring bacterial→ drum red, opaque, bulging)
      • OM associated perforation (Sx: pain may lessen after perf, discharge, decrease in hearing on affected side, can taste liquid dripping down throat if use topical ear drops, can hear air moving thru perf if pinch nose & valsalva; PE: perforation of TM)
      • Otitis externa (Sx: acute, painful, d/c; PE: d/c from external canal, swelling of affected area, pain on palpation of tragus)
      • Otitis externa maligna (Etiology: pseudomonal infxn assoc w/poorly controled diabetes; Sx: acute, painful, necrotizing infection of ear, cartilege; can spread to adbjacent bone, mastoids; brain; PE: febrile, ill, diffuse pain, edema, erythema of ear and sometimes adjacent tissues)
      • Ear cellulitis (Rfs: can start from otitis externa or trauma/injury to ear; Sx: acute swelling, pain of ear/surrounding skin, redness/edema of skin)
      • Mastoiditis (Rfs: a site of spread from complicated otitis media; Sx: acute pain, swelling of mastoid→ posterior and inferior to ear; PE: pain on palpation of mastoid, red, warm, induration)

      Nose & Sinuses

      • Viral (Sx: acute, cough, colored d/c, self limited; PE: pain upon precussion of sinuses, post nasal drip evident on pharynx)
      • Bacterial (Sx: acute, cough, persistent, colored d/c, fever, tooth or facial pain; PE: pain upon precussion of sinuses, post nasal drip evident on pharynx, tooth pain if tapped, no transillumination)
      • Fungal (Etiology: mucor or aspergillous; overall uncommon; Sx: persistent facial pain, fever, congestion in compromised hosts→ older, diabetes; can lead to severe illness as these organisms are invasive)
      • More on sinus infxns from CDC

      Pulmonary

      Upper airway

      • Peri-tonsilar abscess (acute pain, worse then simple pharyngitis, localizes to one side, problems/pain swallowing, if severe→ airway compromise; PE: focal swelling in tonsilar area, uvula deviated away)
      • Epiglotitis (Sx: acute, f, can't swallow, sob, pain in anterior neck; Pe: ill appearing. sitting upright, drooling, "hot potato" voice)
      • Pertussis (Bordatella Pertussis) (Etiology: bacterial; Site: upper airwary; Rfs/Etiology: easily spread; vax of kids and re-vax of adults preventive; kids can have airway compromise due to small size; incubation avg 7-10d; Sx: catarrhal stage 1-2w→ cold sx, sometimes low grade T; then paroxysmal stage→ characteristic whooping cough, post-tussive vomiting; then convaslescent stage→ adults present w/persistent cough x 6-10 weeks) more from CDC
      • Other infection of the mouth/neck that can compromise airway

      Pneumonia

      Pneumonia (Common Sx: acute or sub-acute onset, cough, sob, doe, colored sputum production, fever, chest pain, cxr w/infiltrate; PE: rales, ronchi, wheezing or other findings on auscultation, dullness to percussion if pleural effusion or dense parenchymal involvement) Several scoring systems useful to gague severity: CURB 65 and PSI
    • Bacterial
      • Streptococcus Pneumoniae (pneumococcus) (Etiology: common cause of CAP; Sites: pneumonia, upper respiratory infections, meningitis; bacteremia if severe; Rfs: s/p splenectomy or fxnl asplenia, eldery and very young, any chronic medical condition→ copd, liver or renal dz, chf, cancer, diabetes, HIV, or otherwise immunocompromised; also csf leaks, cochlear implants; decreased risk if vaccinated; Sx: abrupt onset cough, sob, f, c, rusty-colored sputum prod) more from CDC
      • Haemophilus influenza (Etiology: common cause of CAP; Sites: upper and lower respiratory tract, cns; RFs: much less common since widespread use of vaccine; increased risk s/p splenectomy; Sites: pneumonia, otitis media, epiglottitis, meningitis) more from CDC
      • Mycoplasma pneumoniae (Etiology: common cause CAP; also upper resp tract infxn; Sx: acute f, c, cough, upper resp sx; not usually severe) more from CDC
      • Legionella (Etiology: common cause of CPA; Rfs: acquired via inhalation; grows in colonized water collection systems, cooling towers, nebs, whirlpools, etc; can be hospital acquired if water contaminated; Site: lung; Sx: acute cough, sputum, f, c, d, confusion) more from CDC
      • Moraxella (Etiology: common cause of CAP w/COPD; Sites: otitis media; conjunctiva; bronchitis in copd exacerbation; lung; Sx: cough, sob, f, sputum)
      • Francisella tularensis (tularemia) (Etiology: uncommon cause CAP, inhaled w/incubation 2-6d; Rfs: passed from dying wild animals to humans via ticks/insects, US Southeast and Rocky Mtns; Sites: skin, lymph nodes, lung→ inhaled w/incucation 2-6d, uncommon cause pna; Sx: f, c, ha, oral or skin ulcers, painful adenopathy, cough, sob, muscle aches) more from CDC
      • Yersinia pestis (plague) (Etiology: uncommon cause CAP; Site: respiratory tract; Rfs: passed from rodents to humans by fleas, direct contact w/feces, or respiratory droplets; Sx: rapid onset f, c, sepsis, pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Chlamydia pneumoniae (Etiology: uncommon cause of CAP; Site: upper resp tract and lung; Sx: sore throat, fever, non-productive cough) more from CDC
      • Chlamydia psittaci (psitacosis) (Etiology: uncommon cause CAP, spread by exposure to parrots & sometimes other birds; Site: lung; Sx: 1-2 week incubation; fever, cough, severe HA; other organ systems as well) more from CDC
      • Staph aureus: coag + (Etiology: uncommon cause CAP; pneumonia following viral infection; can be rapid and necrotizing)
      • Pertussis (Bordatella Pertussis) (Etiology: uncommon cause CAP; Site: upper airwary, rarely lung; Rfs: easily spread; vax of kids and re-vax of adults preventive; kids can have airway compromise due to small size; incubation avg 7-10d; Sx: catarrhal stage 1-2w→ cold sx, sometimes low grade T; then paroxysmal stage→ characteristic whooping cough, post-tussive vomiting; then convaslescent stage→ adults present w/persistent cough x 6-10 weeks) more from CDC
      • Nocardia (Etiology: uncommon cause CAP, lives in soil, inhaled or via open wound; Rfs: glucocorticoid use or otherwise immunocomp; Sites: lung which can spread to CNS, skin; Sx: subacute cough, sob, f, abscess, cellulitis, lymphangitis if direct inoculation, adenopathy, confusion, focal neuro findings) more from CDC
      • Anthrax (Etiology: uncommon cause CAP; Rfs: acquired from animal exposure or biological weapon; Sx: inhalation: cough, f, c, pneumonia sepsis; cutaneous: ulcer to eshcar w/surrounding edema) more from CDC
      • Health care associated (Etiology/Rfs: hospitalized x2d within last 3m; also consider patients on HD, in NH, on recent IV abx; flora changes to gnr's, mrsa, other resistant bact; though could still be CAP organisms)
      • Aspiration (Etiology: can be acute, assoc w/altered consciousness, swallowing impairment; chronic/recurrent from persistent altered consciousness, swallowing dysfxn; severe GERD; can be inflammatory w/o infxn; Sx: acute or recurrent sob, doe, cough; PE: may have underlying cog or neuro impairment, may affect same lung area→ RML/RLL)
      • Post-obstructive (Etiology: pneumonia that occur behind a mass→ cancer or aspirated foreign body; Sx: often recurrent infection in same anatomic area, cough, f, sputum, sob; if cancer→ may have weight loss, hemoptyis; if aspirated foreign body→ hx altered consciousness, drug use, impaired swallowing)
      • More on pneumonia from CDC
    • Viral
      • Influenza (Etiology: common cause upper and lower respiratory infection; Rfs: seasonal in North America Oct to April, increase risk amongst old, young, pregnant, chronic lung disease, any chronic illness, no vaccination; Sx: abrupt onset of myalgias, arthralgias, fever, chills) more from CDC
      • RSV (Etiology: winter mos, typically affects infants and children, 4-6 d after exposure; Sx: cough, fever, runny nose, wheezing) more from CDC
      • Para-influenza (Etiology: upper resp infection/croup, tracheobronchitis, pneumonia; Sx: cough, fever, runny nose) more from CDC
      • Hanta (Etiology: rodent exposure, incubation 3-4d; Sx: f, myalgias, HA, n, v, abd pain; then rapidly progressive resp sx) more from CDC
      • Measels (rubeola) (Etiology: spread thru resp droplets, highly contagious; Rfs: too young to be vaccinated (<1y), or never vaccinated; winter/spring in US; Sx: incubation 7-14d; cough, high f, malaise; rash 4-5d after sx onset; PE: conjunctivitis, runny nose, then white (Koplick's) spots on oral mucosa, then rash; complications include encephalitis, pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Middle Eastern Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) (Etiology: coronavirus; Rfs: travel to or close contact in past 14d w/someone from Middle East; Sx: acute fever, cough, sob; sometimes n/v/d; can be rapidly progressive)
      • SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome) (Etiology: coronavirus; initial outbreak in China→ rapid spread/pandemic Sx: high fever, aches, sometimes cough; then pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Varicella zoster (chicken pox) (Rfs: rare in kids as vaccine preventable; Sx: f, fatigue, ha, generalized vesicular erruption, duration 5-10d, can still get mild dz if vax, pneumonia in setting severe chicken pox or immunocomp) CDC
    • Fungal
      • Aspergillus (Rfs: immunocompromised host and/or w/structual lung dz→ e.g. bronchiectasis; can be tissue invasive or chronic (e.g. fungal ball); Sx: can be indolent or acute; cough, sob, wt loss, cp, fatigue, hemoptysis) more from CDC
      • Blastomycosis dermatidis (RFs: lives in soil, most commonly found Great Lakes, Mississippi & Ohio river valleys, SE US; typically inhaled; hosts usually of normal health; Sites: lungs, skin if disseminated or as primary problem; Sx: many are asymptomatic; sometimes flu-like illness; others w/sub acute cough, fever, sob; skin nodules or ulcers) more from CDC
      • Coccidioidomycosis (valley fever) (Etiology: Southwest US, higher risk if immune-compromised Site: lung parenchyma and pleural space, joints, skin; Sx: sub-acute sob, cough, f, also arthritis, rash, skin nodules , seeding of other sites) more from CDC
      • Cryptococcus (gattii) (Sites: lungs, skin, cns; Rfs: found on West coast/Pacific Northwest; can cause pneumonia in normal hosts; can also infect those w/HIV and advance t-cell deficiencincy states; Sx: subacute cough, sob, chest pain, f; CNS sx of subacute confusion, ha)
      • Histoplasmosis (Sites: lungs, liver, spleen, systemic; Rfs: exposure to Mississippi & Ohio river valley, HIV+→ increased risk resp/systemic illness; Sx: can be asx/mild and resolve spont; often see x-ray evidence prior infection lung, spleen w/o known past infxn; cough, fever) more from CDC
      • Mucor (Sites: lung→ pneumonia, sinuses→ invasive sinusitis; Rf: DM or otherwise compromised; PE: cough, fever, HA, sinus pain)
      • Pneumocystis jerovecii (Sites: lung; Rfs: HIV + and cd4 < 200, prolonged steroid use; Sx: cough, f, sob pneumonia)
    • Mycobacterial
      • Tuberculosis (RFs: HIV +, immunocompromised for other reason, though can occur in anyone; extra-pulm TB increases in HIV+ w/CD4 < 350; Sx: sub-acute, cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, sweats, fatigue; can also infect GI/GU tracts, bone) more from CDC
      • Mycobacterial - MAC (Rfs: bronchietasis→ assoc w/copd, prior lung infxns, cystic fibrosis; Sx: acute infxn assoc w/persistent & progressive cough, sob, sputum; infxns recur) more from CDC
    • Parasitic
      • Toxocariasis (aka visceral larva migrans or roundworm) (Etiology: definitive hosts are cats and dogs; humans ingest eggs from dirt→ eggs hatch in intestines→ larvae can travel to lungs, eyes, CNS, liver; Sx: many are asx; can cause cough, f, visual loss, hepatitis)
      • Ascariasis (Etiology: tropics/sub-tropics/SE US, eggs swallowed if contaminated soil ingested (e.g. human feces used as fertilizer)→ eggs hatch in intestines → larvae enter blood stream → migrate lungs → mature & coughed up → swallowed → mature in intestines; Sx: often asx; if heavy worm burden→ cough, f, sob, n, v, abd pain, impaired growth of children, sbo)
      • Strongyloidiasis (Etiology: warm/temperate regions including southeast US, tropics/subtropics including Asia/Southeast Asia; larvae enter thru feet/skin if walk barefoot in soil w/infected feces→ enter skin, where they can cause itching→ travel to lung→ penetrate alveoli and travel up trachea→ cough and then swallowed→ travel to and live in small intestine; Sx: most carry life-long w/o any sx; non-compromised hosts can have vague sx including cough, f, sob, epigastic pain, weakness, watery diarrhea, itching, constipation; can cause life threatening hyper-infxn syndrome w/systemic symptoms if compromised from glucocorticoids, malignancy, HTLV-1 or organ transplant; PE: sometimes serpiginous red erruption from migrating larva under skin)
        • CDC: parasites

      Bronchitis

      • Bronchitis Sx: acute cough, colored sputum production, not seriously ill; SOB atypical→ only if chronically compromised→ copd, other; can lead to mucous plugging in chronically weak/ill; PE: ronchi on exam more from CDC

      Bronchiectasis Assoc

      • Bronchiectasis (Etiology: focal or diffuse lung damage that creates dilated areas that dont clear secretions well; Rfs: COPD, known bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis, prior lung infxn; Sx: fever, cough, sputum, SOB)

      Pleural

      • Empyema (Etiology: fluid infected - complication of pneumonia, lung surgery, trauma - aspiration to dx; bacterial, mycobacterial, viral; Sx: acute, F, cough, chest pain, sputum, SOB)

      Cardiovascular

      Myocarditis

      • Bacterial, viral, retroviral, spirochete (Etiology: HIV; viral myocarditis→ coxscakievirus, influenza, other; lyme; secondary to bacterial sepsis; Sx: typcially those of heart failure; also f, c, s and anything else specific to underlying pathogen; PE: t, elevated jvp, diplaced PMI, + s3, edema, other findings assoc w/primary infxn)
      • American Trypanosomiasis (chagas dz) - Parasite t cruzi (Etiology: Central and South America, via reduviid bug bite; incubation 1-2w; Sx: most have no acute sx; if acute sx present, can include→ f, c, sweats, malaise, ha, n, v, d x weeks; chronic sx in 20-30%, including: lower esophageal dysmotility; cardiomyopathy→ CHF, dysrhythmia; PE: rare acute findings: skin nodule at bite; eyelid edema)

      Pericarditis

      • Viral most common→ coxsackievirus, influenza, other (Genl) (Etiology: antecedent respiratory viral; coxsackie, influenza, other; Sx: fever, cough, sweats)
      • Coxsackievirus (enterovirus) (Etiology: myocarditis, pericarditis, erruption on palms/soles; Sx: w/cardiac involvement chest pain, sob; in kids f, malaise, vessicles in mouth and hands and soles) More from CDC
      • Influenza (Etiology: common cause upper and lower respiratory infection; Rfs: seasonal in North America Oct to April, increase risk amongst old, young, pregnant, chronic lung disease, any chronic illness, no vaccination; Sx: abrupt onset of myalgias, arthralgias, fever, chills) more from CDC
      • Bacterial - less common c/w viral - assoc w/direct extension, trauma, bacteremia
      • Tuberculosis (RFs: HIV +, immunocompromised for other reason, though can occur in anyone; extra-pulm TB increases in HIV+ w/CD4 < 350; Sx: sub-acute, cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, sweats, fatigue; can also infect GI/GU tracts, bone) more from CDC
      • Acute rheumatic fever (Sx: relatively uncommon, occurs 2-3w after strep pharyngitis, assoc w/fever, fatigue, acute/abrupt onset, migratory inflammatory arthritis of large joints typically; chest pain or sob related to pericarditis; long term risk of mitral or aortic valve dz; PE: affected joint(s) are warm, red, pain w/movement)

      Endocarditis

      • Endocarditis (Rfs: prior endocarditis, unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart dz, prosthetic valve, acquired valvular heart dz (e.g. mitral prolapse w/regurg, aortic stenosis, rheumatic heart dz), IVDU, HIV, hemodialysis; Sx: f, c, sweats, sepsis, embolic events w/seeding and assoc sx; rapidity of clinical progression affected by organism and pt substrate; Etiology: 80% staph, strep; other less common organisms HACEK, Coxiella, T Whiplei, fungal; PE: fever, new or worse murmur, relatively rare skin findings include Janeway lesions→flat, painless, erythematous lesions on hands, and Osler's nodes→ painful nodules on fingers, findings associated w/seeding→ e.g. lbp or neuro findings from vertebral osteo, epidural abscess; focal neuro deficits from stroke or brain abscess) Duke criteria for endocarditis

      Gastrointestinal

      Esophagitis

      • Esophagitis from infection (Etiology: viral, fungal; Rfs: sometimes immuncompromised→ HIV+, chemotherapy; recent exposure to abx; Sx: acute/sub-acute sub-sternal pain, pain worse w/swallowing; PE: hsv lesions or candida in mouth provide clue to what's affecting esophagus)
      • Esophageal perforation w/mediastinitis (Sx/Etiology: severe acute chest or epigastric pain; must have reason for perforation include: repeated retching→Boerhaves, biopsy/procedure w/perforation, toxic ingestion→ lye/drain cleaner, foreign body; pain is severe, w/assoc swallowing probs, ill appearance)

      Gastritis

      • H Plyori induced ulcer (Sx: acute or chronic, epigastric pain, black stools, better or worse w/food)

      Viral Hepatitis

      • A (acute) (Etiology/Rfs: spread fecal/oral/ingestion contaminated food, can be epidemic, incubation 2-4w; Sx: n, v, RUQ abd pain, puritis, dark urine, light colored stool, f, jaundice, icterus; sx generally resolve w/in 2-4w; PE: jaundice, icterus, RUQ pain, hepatomegaly)
      • B (acute) (RFs: spread via sexual contact, vertical, shared needles, needle sticks in health care workers, unscreened blood transfusion; Sx: many are asx; incuabtaion is 1-4m; acute infxn assoc w/n, v, jaundice; puritus, icterus, dark urine, light colored stool, malaise; typcially self limited, w/resoln sx 2-3m; 5% go on to chronic infxn, w/risk cirrhosis, spread to others, and hcc; PE: jaundice, icterus, RUQ pain, hepatomegaly)
      • C (rare cause of acute hep) (RFs: spread via needles, unscreened blood transfusion, cocaine inhaling tools, needle sticks in health care workers, vertical, sexual; 10-20% resolve spontaneously; long term risk cirrhosis and HCC w/chronic infxn; Sx: most w/acute hep C are asx; those w/sx have RUQ pain, f, malaiae, jaudice; PE: most have no findings in acute phase)
      • Hepatitis D (RFs: occurs as a co-infection w/hep b, uncommon in west, found in Mediterranean and Asian countries; spread via same mechanisms as hep b)
      • Hepatitis E (RFs: uncommon in western nations, though most common cause of acute hep in developing world, can be sporadic or epidemic, water born w/spread similar to hep a; Sx: incubation 3-8w, sx of malaise, n, jaundice x ~ 2w; usually self limited, rarely fulminant, rarely chronic)
        • More on viral hepatitis from CDC
      • CMV (Rfs; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; systemic infxn in HIV or otherwise compromised; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w, fatigue x 4-6w; Sx: f, c, malaise, RUQ pain; PE: epgiastric/RUQ pain, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC
      • EBV→ mononucleosis (Sx: incubation 4-6w, prodrome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias; then f, sore throat; PE: head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly) more from CDC
      • Herpes simplex (Etiology: disseminated HSV; Rfs: immunocompromised; Sx: abd pain, n, v, fever; sometimes typical skin lesions oral/genital; PE: sometimes vessicular lesions oral or genital regions)
      • Herpes zoster (Sx: burning type pain over RUQ area for several days prior to skin erruption; PE: dermatomal, vessicular erruption over abdominal dermatome)

      Hep (bacterial)

      • Bacterial abscess(Etiology: secondary to biliary obstruction complicated by infection; seeding from systemic bacteremia; Sx: right upper quadrant pain, f, c)

      Hep (parasitic)

      • Ascariasis (Etiology: tropics/sub-tropics/SE US, eggs swallowed if contaminated soil ingested (e.g. human feces used as fertilizer)→ eggs hatch in intestines → larvae enter blood stream → migrate lungs → mature & coughed up → swallowed → mature in intestines; Sx: often asx; if heavy worm burden→ cough, fever, sob, n, v, abd pain, impaired growth of children, sbo; can migrate to biliary tree and cause obstruction & related complications)
      • Echinococcus (tapeworm) (Etiology: main host is cattle and dogs; common in US and many other areas; eggs ingested by humans → travel to liver→ Sx: cysts form & can cause RUQ pain→ compress biliary tract → if rupture can cause anaphylaxis)
      • Entamoeba histolytica→ amebiasis (protozoa) (Etiology: acquired via unclean water/poor sanitation, also anal intercourse; Sx: only 10-20% develop sx; incubation 2-4w; abd pain, bloody diarreha; occas liver abscess)
      • Toxocariasis (aka visceral larva migrans or roundworm) (Etiology: definitive hosts are cats and dogs; humans ingest eggs from dirt→ eggs hatch in intestines→ larvae can travel to lungs, eyes, CNS, liver; Sx: many are asx; can cause cough, fever, visual loss, hepatitis)

      Hep (spirochete)

      • Leptospirosis (Etiology: contract via exposure to rodent/wild animal feces; incubation several weeks; Sx/PE: mild dz is self limited f, c, ha, n, v, muscle aches, conjunctival injection; severe dz with hepatic and renal involvement, pulmonary hemorrhage, andicterus) CDC

      GB & Bil

      • Cholecystitis (Etiology: typcially obstructing gall stone; GNRs or GPCs; Sx: constant right/upper abd pain, can radiate to back, fever, nausea, hx gall stones; PE: pain in RUQ; palpating hand positioned below liver→ patient inspires→ pain increases when inflamed gall bladder contacts hand)
      • Cholangitis (bact) (Etiology: obstructed common bile duct from stone, cancer, stricture, other; GNRs or GPCs; Sx: right/upper abd pain, fever, nausea, jaundice, hx gall stones, often severe illness)
      • Ascariasis (worm) (Etiology: tropics/sub-tropics/SE US, eggs swallowed if contaminated soil ingested (e.g. human feces used as fertilizer)→ eggs hatch in intestines → larvae enter blood stream → migrate lungs → mature & coughed up → swallowed → mature in intestines; Sx: often asx; if heavy worm burden→ cough, fever, sob, n, v, abd pain, impaired growth of children, sbo; can migrate to biliary tree and cause obstruction & related complications)
      • Echinococcus (tapeworm) (Etiology: main host is cattle and dogs; common in US and many other areas; eggs ingested by humans → travel to liver→ Sx: cysts form & can cause RUQ pain→ compress biliary tract → if rupture can cause anaphylaxis)
      • Clonorchis (fluke) (Eiol: Asia/Sast Asia, humans infected by eating uncooked fish or contaminated water; live in bile ducts; Sx: can cause biliary obstruction → abd pain, wt loss, diarrhea, jaundice)

      Panc/Splenic

      • Pancreatitis w/superimposed infection(Etiology: ETOH abuse, gall stones, meds; less common anatomic→ divisum, post procedure, auto-immune, scorpion bites, trauma, hypertrigliceridemia; infection secondary to hematogenous seeding, post ERCP or other procedure; Sx: f, c, epigastric pain, constant, radiates to back, N, V; PE: epigastric pain on plapation)
      • Pancreatic pseudocyst (infected) (Etiology: pseudocyst assoc w/recurrent bouts of pancreatitis; infection secondary to hematogenous seeding, post ERCP or other procedure; Sx: f, c, epigastric pain, n, v→ similar to pancreatitis)
      • Splenic abscess (Sx/Rfs: pain, fever, endocarditis or other source infected emboli)

      Peritonitis

      • Diverticulitis (Sx: left/lower abdomen, RLQ less commonly; fever, nausea, crampy abd pain, progressively worse over time; PE: pain in LLQ, can have focal peritoneal signs)
      • Appendicitis (Sx: starts umbilicus→ R lower quadrant, fever, nausea, anorexia, progressively worse over hours to days; w/peritoneal irritation, patient lies still→ movement increases pain; PE: pain over McBurneys point→ 1/3 from iliac crest to umbo; if peritonitis: shake tenderness, rebound, guarding, rigidity, + Rovsings→ pushing on LLQ and releasing causes RLQ pain; if retrocecal appendix→ psoas sign→ pain w/passive leg extension; if pelvic appendix→ obturator sign→ pain w/passive internal hip rotation)
      • Perforated viscous - gall bladder, stomach, small or large intestine (Etiology: cancer, infection, ischemia, prolonged obstruction→ hernia, volvulous, intussuception, etc; Sx: focal pain over affected area→ becomes generalized; PE: pain on palpation, peritorneal signs)
      • Abscess (Etiology: contained collection from adjacent infection, perforated viscous, hematogenous seeding, other; Sx: f, c, focal pain over site abscess; PE: fever, focal pain, sometimes overlying induration, swelling)
      • Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis (Etiology: ascites, typically from advanced chronic liver disease; Sx: acute abd pain, confusion, fever, PE: generalized tenderness in patient with ascites)
      • Peritoniits from MTB, fungi (Etiology: rare problem often compromised host or those on peritoneal dialysis, other TB Rfs→ exposure, travel, compromised; known TB elsewhere; Sx: chronic and progressive f, s, sub-acute abd pain, increased girth, wt loss)

      Diarrhea (<14d)

    • Bacterial
      • Salmonella (non-typhoidal) (Site: small bowel; Rfs: exposure from eggs, chicken, turtles; incubation 12h-3d; most recover in 4-7d; Site: small bowel; Sx: d, n, v, cramps, often w/bloody stools; rarely can spread to distant sites in compromised hosts→ osteomyelitis, endovascular, other) more from CDC
      • Shigella (Etiology: spread person to person or from food; Site: small bowel; Sx: d, n, v, cramps, often w/bloody stools; avg incubation 3d; typically self limited to 4-7d) more from CDC
      • Campylobacter (Etiology: spread thru contaminated food; Site: small bowel; Sx: d, n, v, cramps, often w/bloody stools; incubation 2-5d; typically self limited to 1w) more from CDC
      • Yersinia enterocolitica (Etiology: spread via contaminated food; Site: small bowel; Sx: f, c, cramps, bloody diarrhea; incubation 4-7d; typically self limited to 4-7d) more from CDC
      • C dif colitis (Etiology: hx exposure to abx or patients w/c dif; toxin based; Sx: abd pain, diarrhea, blood in stool, cramps, fever) more from CDC
      • Traveler's diarrhea (Rfs/Etiology: diarrhea after travel to another country - central/south America, asia, africa; secondary to variety of enteric pathogens, from consuming undercooked food/poor hygiene in restaurants/untreated water; Sx: n, v, cramps, usually self limited) more from CDC
      • Staph toxin assoc diarrhea (Rfs/Etiology: secondary to eating contaminated food, occurs hours after consumption, other affected who ate similar; Sx: abrupt onset n, v, cramps, non-bloody d, self limited) more from CDC
      • C perfringens→ toxin based (Rfs/Etiology: secondary to eating contaminated food, occurs hours after consumption, other affected who ate similar, self limited; Sx: abrupt onset n, v, cramps, non-bloody d) more from CDC
      • E Coli 0157:H7 (Etiology: Occurs in outbreaks, most get better in 5-7d; some can become very ill w/HUS; Sx: F, crampy abd pain, diarrhea, bloody stool) more from CDC
      • Vibrio cholera (Etiology/Rfs: toxin mediated profound watery diarrhea, related to exposure to unclean water sources, often s/p natural disasters→ presents as epidemics; Site: small bowel; Sx: profound watery diarrhea; can lead to hypovoemic death in hours if severe) more from CDC
      • Vibrio vulnificus and parahemolytics (Rfs/Sites: causes bacteremia→ sepsis in hosts w/cirrhosis or otherwise compromised hosts, exposure via raw/under cooked shellfish; wound/skin infection if same hosts exposed via inoculation w/affected water→ walking in surf w/exposed wounds in endemic area; Sx: acute n, v, f, cramps, diarrhea; extremity pain and swelling if via wound) more from CDC
    • Viral
      • Rotavirus (Etiology/Rfs: common cause of acute enteritis in kids <5; vaccine preventable; Sx: abrupt onset n, v, f, diarrhea) more from CDC
      • Norovirus (Etiology/Rfs: common cause of acute enteritis in adults, daycare/hospitals/nursing homes; Sx: abrupt onset n, v, f, diarrhea) more from CDC
      • CMV (RFs: IBD, immune modulating meds; Sx: f, crampy abd pain, bloody diarrhea)
    • Parasitic
      • Cryptosporidia (Rfs: young, old, immunocomp at greatest risk, spread fecal oral, assoc w/daycare center outbreaks; Sx: n, v, cramps, fever)
      • Giardia (protozoa) (Etiology: spread via poor hygiene, contaminated water, drinking from ponds/streams, anal intercourse; many infected are asx; Sx: incubation 1-3w; non-bloody watery/greasy/foul smelling diarrhea, gas, burping)
      • Entamoeba histolytica→ amebiasis (protozoa) (Etiology: acquired via unclean water/poor sanitation, also anal intercourse; Sx: only 10-20% develop sx; incubation 2-4w; abd pain, bloody diarrhea; occas liver abscess)
      • Parasites: CDC

      Diarrhea (Chronic)

    • Bacterial
      • C dif colitis (Etiology: hx exposure to abx or patients w/c dif; Sx: typically acute abd pain, diarrhea, blood in stool, cramps, fever; sometimes chronic, recurrent or persistent) more from CDC
      • Bacterial & viral pathogens described under "acute diarrhea" rarely cause chronic sx
    • Parasitic
      • Ascariasis (Etiology: tropics/sub-tropics/SE US, eggs swallowed if contaminated soil ingested (e.g. human feces used as fertilizer)→ eggs hatch in intestines → larvae enter blood stream → migrate lungs → mature & coughed up → swallowed → mature in intestines; can migrate to biliary tree; Sx: often asx; if heavy worm burden→ cough, fever, sob, n, v, d, abd pain, jaundice, impaired growth of children, sbo)
      • Clonorchis (fluke) (Eiol: Asia/East Asia, humans infected by eating uncooked fish or contaminated water; live in bile ducts; Sx: can cause biliary obstruction → abd pain, wt loss, diarrhea, jaundice)
      • Cryptosporidia (Rfs: young, old, immunocomp at greatest risk, spread fecal oral, assoc w/daycare center outbreaks; typcially self limited; Sx: n, v, d, cramps, fever, wt loss if severe)
      • Cyclospora (Etiology: most common in tropics/subtropics; outbreaks in US assoc w/contaminated produce; Sx: ~ 1w after exposure→ cramps, bloating, gas, diarrhea, wt loss; often self limited, though can recur)
      • Entamoeba histolytica→ amebiasis (protozoa) (Etiology: acquired via unclean water/poor sanitation, also anal intercourse; Sx: only 10-20% develop sx; incubation 2-4w; abd pain, bloody diarreha; occas liver abscess)
      • Giardia (protozoa) (Etiology: spread via poor hygiene, contaminated water, drinking from ponds/streams, anal intercourse; many infected are asx; Sx: incubation 1-3w; non-bloody watery/greasy/foul smelling diarrhea, gas, burping, wt loss)
      • Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) (Etiology: found worldwide, common in children, situations w/poor sanitation; ingest eggs via contaminated water or hand to mouth; lives in the ileum Sx: cramps, diarrhea, n, v, wt loss)
      • Microsporidiosis (Etiology/Rfs: associated with drinking untreated water, CD4 < 100 or untreated HIV; Sx: in addn to diarrhea, can affect other systems, causing→ keratitis, encephalitis, other)
      • Necator americanus (hookworm) (Etiology: common world-wide, enter thru feet/skin if walk barefoot in soil w/infected feces→ bloodstream→ lungs→ swallowed→ small intestines Sx: of fatigue from blood loss→ anemia, d)
      • Schistosomiasis (fluke) (Etiology: South America, Middle East, Caribbean, Africa: flukes, invade skin of swimmers, enter blood stream→ live in portal/mesenteric veins; Sx: itching and erruption during first few days @ site where enters skin; can cause portal htn after years; also f, c, abd pain, diarrhea; can live in bladder → SCC after years)
      • Strongyloidiasis (Etiology: warm/temperate regions including southeast US, tropics/subtropics including Asia/Southeast Asia; larvae enter thru feet/skin if walk barefoot in soil w/infected feces→ enter skin, where they can cause itching→ travel to lung→ penetrate alveoli and travel up trachea→ cough and then swallowed→ travel to and live in small intestine; Sx: most carry life-long w/o any sx; non-compromised hosts can have vague sx including cough, epigastic pain, weakness, watery diarrhea, constipation; can cause life threatening hyper-infxn syndrome w/systemic symptoms if compromised from glucocorticoids, malignancy, HTLV-1 or organ transplant; PE: sometimes serpiginous red erruption from migrating larva under skin)
      • Trichinella (aka trichinosis) (Etiology: rare in US; from eating infected meat; Sx: abd pain, n, v, diarrhea; after 1-2w, muscle pain when migrate to muscles, rash, ha, n, v)
      • Trichuriass (whipworm) (Etiology: eggs ingested, live in colon; Sx: w/light infxn→ asx; heavy burden→ abd pain, diarrhea, bloody stools, n, v, anemia)
      • More on Parasites: CDC

      Other Parasitic

      • Enterobiasis (pinworm) (Etiology: fecal oral, common in kids, Sx: nocturnal peri-anal itching)
      • Taenia Saginata (beef tape worm) (Etiology: eating raw or undercooked beef; Sx: most are asymptomatic; sometimes bloating, nausea, wt loss; perianal discomfort from passing proglottids in stool→ some times visible)

      Genito-Urinary

      Lower Tract

      • Simple UTI/cystitis (Etiology: typically gram negatives that enter bladder thru urethra; Rfs: stasis for any reason→ e.g. bph; foreign bodies→ stones or catheters; females→ short urethra, micro trauma from intercourse; Sx: acute, pain, frequency, urgency, often w/o fever; PE: sometimes supra-pubic discomfort w/palpation)
      • Prostatitis (Etiology; GNRs; Sx: acute, frequency, sometimes systemic sx; can also be chronic or recurrent; PE: prostate tender on exam)
      • Epididymo-orchitis (Etiology: GNRs, chlamydia/GC if from STI; Sx: acute pain w/urination, frequency, urgency; Etiology: bacterial similar to UTI or gc/chlamydia; less common: TB, viral, med related; PE: swollen & tender epididymis and testis, doesn't transiluminate, urethral d/c if sti)
      • Urethritis→ gonorrhea, chlamydia (Rfs: + sexual active, hx past STI, Sx: urethral d/c, painful urination; in women, sometimes vaginal d/c; though many women w/chlamydia are asx; PE: urethral d/c; cervical d/c or pain on manipulation if concomitant cervicitis; look for findings from assoc STIs that travel w/GC & chlamydia but are otherwise asx→ e.g. ulcer from syphillis, condyloma from HPV, etc.)
      • TB (Sx: subacute/chronic dysuria, hematuria, neg evaln for bact infxn, RFs for TB→ HIV+, immunocomp, known TB elsewhere in body)

      Upper Tract

      • Pyelonephritis (Etiology: typically GNRs, from ascending urinary tract infxn; sometimes obstruction/anatomic predisposition; less common from hematogenous spread; Sx: acute low back/flank pain, f, c, n, v; dysuria, urinary frequency/urgency if concomitant cystitis; PE: f, cvat, flank pain on palpation)
      • Perinephric Abscess (Etiology: typically GNRs; complication of pyelonephritis; often assoc w/stones or obstruction for other reason; can also be from hematogenous spread; Sx: acute low back/flank pain, f, c, n, v; dysuria, urinary frequency/urgency if concomitant cystitis; PE: f, cvat, flank pain on palpation)

      Ulcers

      • Syphilis (Rfs: men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's; Sx: Painless ulcer following exposure, resolves spontaneously; PE: painless genital ulcer from primary infxn, later can have findings assoc w/secondary syphillis including: non-specific rash, w/predilection for palms , and soles, oral ulcers) more from CDC
      • Herpes simplex virus (Rfs: sexually active, past STIs, past HSV Sx: acute, painful, vesicles, recurrent, resolve spontaneously; PE: vessicle on a red base, ulcers when ruptures) more from CDC
      • Balanitis (Etiology: not typically an ulcer, but rather diffuse redness on head of penis, most commonly from fungal infection; Rfs: uncirc, poorly controlled dm, immunocop Sx: redness and sometimes white d/c head of penis, no urinary sx; PE: diffuse redness on head of penis)
      • Donavanosis→ granuloma inguinale (Rfs/Etiology: tropics & not in US unless travel, spread by direct sexual contact, incubation 1-3m, Rfs same as for HIV; Sx: papule to painless ulcer in genital area, beefy red/bleeds, develops over weeks, can be hard to distinguish from chancroid; PE: painless papule or ulcer in genital region, can be beefy/red and bleed)
      • Lymphogranuloma venereum (RFs/Etiology: caused by chlamydia trachomatis, spread by sexual contact, rare in US, incubation 1-3 weeks, RFs same as for HIV Sx: painless papule or ulcer on penis/vaginal/rectal area, then painful adenopathy; PE: painless ulcer or papule, painful adenopathy)
      • H ducreyi→ chancroid (Rfs/Etiology: Africa/Caribean & not in US unless travel, spread by direct sexual contact; RFs: same as for HIV, incubation 1d-2w Sx: papule to painless ulcer in genital area; PE: papule to painless ulcer in genital area, adenopathy)

      Masses/Other Infxn

      • HPV (Sx/Rfs: painless growths, can be single/grouped/or in multiple clusters, painless, acquired via sexual contact, travel w/other STIs; PE: single or clustered growths) more from CDC
      • Bacillary angiomatosis (Etiology: bartonella infxn; Sx/RFs: occurs in HIV + or otherwise compromised hosts, painless; PE: nodules on skin, resembles Kaposi's sarcoma)
      • Condyloma lata (secondary syphillis) (Rfs: unprotected intercourse, men who have sex w/men, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's; Sx: secondary manifestations weeks after primary chancre heals; include: condyloma lata→ moist, frond-like growth in genital area; non-specific rash, w/predilection for palms, and soles, mucosal involvement, adenopathy, alopecia) more from CDC
      • Infected Bartholin's cyst (Sx: discrete swelling in labia; when infected→ acute pain, swelling, redness, sometimes spontaneous d/c; PE: swelling in labia @ 5 and 7 o'clock positions; when infected→ pain, redness, fluctuance)
      • Scrotal cellulitis (Etiology: break in skin from trauma, ulcer; Sx: Acute pain, redness, swelling, fever; PE: redness, induation, pain)
      • Scrotal abscess (Etiology: skin break/trauma; Sx: acute pain, swelling; PE: redness, pain, focal area of swelling and fluctuance)
      • Necrotizing fasciitis (Fournier gangrene) (Etiology: severe, rare infection affecting scrotum/perineum; Rfs: immuncompromised hosts→ diabetes, immunosuppressive meds, vascular dz; Sx: acute, severe, rapidly progressive illness, pain and swelling in scrotum; PE: severe systemic illness, pain, edema, ertheyma, fluctuance, crepitus)

      GYN

      Vaginitis

      • Bacterial vaginosis (Rfs: sexual activity, new partners; though can also get w/o sexual activity; Sx: malodorous d/c, assoc w/dyspareunia; PE: thin, grayish d/c)
      • Fungal vaginitis (Etiology: recurrent infection should prompt screen for dm, hiv; Sx: itchy, soreness, pain w/intercourse; PE: white/cottage cheese consistency d/c)
      • Trichomonas (parasite) (Etiology: spread thru sexual contact; Sx: itchy, malodorous, pain w/intercourse; PE: yellow/green, frothy d/c, cervix with "strawberry" appearance)

      Cervicitis/PID

      • Cervicitis: STI (Etiology: chlamaydia and gonorrhea, infxn limited to cervix; Rfs: hx sexually active, prior STI; Sx: purulent discharge from cervix→ vagina, vaginal bleeding, burning w/urination; PE: discharge from cervix, redness around os, bleeds easily)
      • Pelvic inflammatory disease: STI (Etiology: progression of cervicitis from gc or chlamydia to involve uterus & fallopian tubes; Rfs: age < 25, hx sexual activity, hx STI, lower education level, multiple sex partners, new sex partner; Sx: acute lower abd/pelvic area pain, fever, malodorous smelling vaginal d/c; irreg vaginal bleeding; clinically more severe if tubo-ovarian abscess; PE: cervical d/c, cervical motion pain, uterine tenderness, pain on palpation adnexa)
      • Tubo-ovarian abscess: STI (Etiology: complication of PID; Sx: acute lower abd pain, fever, vaginal discharge; PE: fever, discharge from cervix, cervical motion pain, adnexal pain, adnexal mass)
      More on STIs from CDC

      Endometritis

      • Endometritis (Etiology: bacterial infection of uterine lining; RFs: non-pregnant from ascending STI as part of PID spectrum, post uterine procedure→ d&c, hysteroscopy, or miscarriage; post-partum from bacteria introduced at time delivery vaginally or c-section; Sx: lower abd pain, f, s, d/c; PE: elevated temp, lower abd/uterine tenderness, cervical d/c)

      Mastitis

      • Mastitis→ post partum (Sx: acute, painful, warm, red; PE: breast warmth, redness, fluctuance if abscess)

      Vag Ulcer/Mass

      • Syphilis (Rfs: unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's; Sx: Painless ulcer following exposure, resolves spontaneously; Pe: painless genital ulcer from primary infxn, later can have findings assoc w/secondary syphillis including: non-specific rash, w/predilection for palms, and soles, oral ulcers)
      • Herpes simplex virus (Rfs: sexually active, past STIs, past HSV; Sx: acute, painful, vesicles, sometimes fever w/acute infxn; can be recurrent, resolve spontaneously, sometimes urinary retention; PE: vessicles on a red base, ulcers when ruptures, inguinal adenopathy w/acute infxn)
      • Donavanosis (granualoma inguinale) (Rfs/Etiology: tropics & not in US unless travel, spread by direct sexual contact, incubation 1-3m; Rfs: same as for HIV; Sx: papule to painless ulcer in genital area, beefy red/bleeds, develops over weeks, can be hard to distinguish from chancroid; PE: painless papule or ulcer in genital region, can be beefy/red and bleed)
      • Lymphogranuloma venereum (RFs/Etiology: caused by chlamydia trachomatis, spread by sexual contact, rare in US, incubation 1-3 weeks, RFs same as for HIV; Sx: painless papule or ulcer on vagina/rectal area, then painful adenopathy; PE: painless ulcer or papule, painful adenopthy)
      • H ducreyi (chancroid) (Rfs/Etiology: Africa/Caribean & not in US unless travel, spread by direct sexual contact, RFs same as for HIV, incubation 1d-2w; Sx: papule to painless ulcer in genital area; PE: papule to painless ulcer in genital area, adenopathy)
      • Infected Bartholin's cyst (Sx: acute pain, swelling, redness, of labia, sometimes spontaneous d/c; PE: swelling in labia @ 5 and 7 o'clock positions; pain, redness, fluctuance)
      • HPV (Sx/Rfs: painless growths, can be single/grouped/or in multiple clusters, painless, acquired via sexual contact, travel w/other STIs; PE: single or clustered growths) more from CDC
      • Bacillary angiomatosis (Sx/RFs: occurs in HIV + or otherwise compromised hosts, painless, PE: nodules on skin, resembles Kaposi's sarcoma)
      • Condyloma lata (secondary syphillis) (Rfs: unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's; Sx: secondary manifestations weeks after primary chancre heals; include: condyloma lata→ moist, frond-like growth in genital area; non-specific rash, w/predilection for palms, and soles, mucosal involvement, adenopathy, alopecia) more from CDC
      More on STIs from CDC

      Heme-Onc

      Lymph Nodes

      The most common infections w/a tendency to involve lymph nodes (anywhere in the body) are described below.
    • Bacterial
        • Affected lymph nodes are typically those closest to primary infection, increase rapidly in size, are warm and tender. Fluctuant if necrosis and abscess.
      • Staph aureus (Sites: skin infection, abscess, wound infection; osteomyelitis via direct extension; arthritis; bacteremia; Sx: fever, pain/swelling at primary as well as affected, lymph nodes; PE: cellulitis→ redness, warmth, induration, skin abscess→ focal redness and fluctuance)
      • Streptococcus: Group A (Sites: cellulitis/lymphangitis; skin abscess; erysipelas; impetigo, throat infections→ acute pain, f, adenopathy; scarlet fever → high temp, rash, palatal petchiae, throat sx; necrotizing fasciits; PE: strep throat→ pharyngeal erythema, d/c, adenop, necrotizing fasciitis, red streaking from lymphangitis) more from CDC
      • Chlamydia trachomatis (lymphogranuloma venereum) (Site: Genital region; Etiology: spread by sexual contact, rare in US, Rfs: same as for HIV; Sx: incubation 1-3 weeks, painless papule or ulcer on penis/vagina/rectal area, then painful inguinal adenopathy) more from CDC
      • Yersinia pestis (plague) (Site: respiratory tract; skin; Rf/Etiology: passed from rodents to humans by fleas, direct contact w/feces, or respiratory droplets; Sx: rapid onset f, c, sepsis, pneumonia; erythema, edema, tender aenopathy) more from CDC
      • Bartonella henslae (cat scratch) (Sites: skin and lymph nodes; Rfs/Etiology: caused by cat scratch; Sx: may see inflamation at innoculation site, then tender regional adenopathy w/in few weeks, fatigue, fever) more from CDC
      • Brucella (Sites: systemic; Etiology: ingestion of raw/uncooked dairy or handling infected animals; Rfs: veterinarians, meat packers, slaughter house workers, farmers; Middle East, Mediterranean, Mexico, Africa; Sx/PE: causes weeks/months of recurrent f, c, sweats, arthritis, adenopathy, orchitis, hepato-splenomegaly) more from CDC
      • Nocardia (Rfs: glucocorticoid use or otherwise immunocomp; Etiology: uncommon cause CAP, lives in soil, inhaled or via open wound; Sites: lung which can spread to CNS, skin; Sx: subacute cough, sob, f, abscess, cellulitis, lymphangitis if direct inoculation, adenopathy, confusion) more from CDC
      • Francisella tularensis (tularemia) (Sites: skin, lymph nodes; Etiology/Rfs: passed from dying wild animals to humans via ticks/insects, US Southeast and Rocky Mtns; Sx: f, c, ha, oral or skin ulcers, painful adenopathy, sob, muscle aches) more from CDC
      • H ducreyi (chancroid) (Site: genital region; Rfs: Africa/Caribean & not in US unless travel, spread by direct sexual contact, similar RFs for HIV; Sx/PE: incubation 1d-2w, papule to painless ulcer in genital area, inguinal adenopathy) more from CDC
    • Viral and Retroviral
      • HIV (Etiology/Rfs: hiv risk factors→ men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; risks of unusual infection increase as CD4 declines; Sx: acute infection→ fever, chills, sweats, adenopathy, rash, pharyngitis w/in 2-4 weeks - then resolves; latency until sx develop 6-10y after initial infxn (if not treated) related to drop in CD4: generalized sx include f, c, cough, wt loss; other illnesses: mucosal candidiasis; fungal, mtb lung infection; persistent diarrhea; CNS toxo; non hodgkins lymphoma; kaposis sarcoma of skin, adenopathy, etc) more from CDC
      • CMV (Sx/PE: retinitis, colitis, disseminated dz in patients w/HIV; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w, then f, c, malaise hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, fatigue x 4-6w; head/neck adenopathy & pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC
      • EBV (mononucleosis) (Rfs: spread by direct contact→ kissing, shared drinking glasses, shared toothbrushes, etc; Sx: incubation 4-6w, prodrome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias, then f, sore thorat; PE: maculo-pap rash after amox or other abx, head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly) more from CDC
      • Herpes simplex oral/genital infxn (Etiology: primary infxn sometimes assoc w/fever; Sites: genital, oral; Rfs: passed by sexual or oral contact; Sx/PE: acute, painful, genital or oral area vesicles, inguinal adenopathy) more from CDC
    • Fungal
