      • Platelet dysfxn→ von Willebrand disease (Etiology: variable severity, family hx may be unknown; Sx: spontaneous mucocutanous bleeding → gums, nosebleeds, GI tract; excessive bleeding during/after surgical procedures, trauma, dental extraction, w/menstruation PE: petechiae, spontaneous ecchymoses or after minor trauma) more from CDC
      • Hemophilia (Etiology: factor deficienty state, typically factors 8 or 9; often family hx; Sx: bleeding problems noted from birth or early life; spontaneous hemarthroses, spontaneos intra-muscular bleeding or hematomas, excessive post-traumatic bleeding, excessive bleeding w/any challenge to hemostasis) more from CDC

      Adenopathy?

      Palpable pathologic lymph nodes are most often appreciated in the head/neck, axialla, or inguinal regions. Lymph nodes of concern are typcially > 1cm and enlarging/changing. Many lympoh node group (intra-abd, retroperit, throacic) are not accesible on exam.

      Cancer

      • Leukemia (Etiology: CLL in partic; also AML, ALL; adenopathy less common w/CML; Sx: fever, sweats, wt loss, fatigue, sob, bruising; PE: pale, adenopathy, sometimes hepato-splenomegaly)
      • Lymphoma (Sx: wt loss/decreased appetite sweats, fevers, chills, adenopathy, organomegaly, abdominal fullness; CNS involvement and sx w/NHL; skin involvement w/cutaneous t-cell NHL; PE: generalized adenopathy; mutiple, somewhat rubbery, stuck together; hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, erythroderma,, sometimes focal neurological findings if CNS involvement)
        • Hodgkins (Etiology: 10% of lymphomas; Rfs: age 15-40 & > 55, hiv +, EBV infection, fam hx; Sx: fever, sweats, wt loss, adenopathy; cough/sob if mediastinal invovlmenet; PE: painless, progressive adenopathy, in particular head/neck; sometimes splenomegaly, hepatomegaly)
        • Non-Hodgkins (Etiology: 90% of lymphomas; many different types (B & T cell), significant variability in how aggressive they may be; Rfs: age > 60, hx hiv + confers markedly increased risk aggressive NHL; EBV→ Burkitts; h pylori→ stomach MALT; Sx: f, c, sweats, fatigue, wt loss; PE: progressive, painless, generalized adenopathy; splenomegaly; extra-nodal dz can involve almost any organ system)
      • Solid tumors: Any can involve lymph nodes. Typically firm, stuck together, and growing. Often follow anatomic drainage patterns. A few common cancers:
        • Breast: first site of spread is often ipsilateral axilla.
        • Head and Neck squamous cell: first spreads to ipsilateral lymph nodes of neck.
        • Thyroid: first spreads to ipsilateral lymph nodes of neck.
        • Melanoma: first spread can be to nearest lymph nodes; though as progresses, can present anywhere.
        • Less common: supraclaviular nodes from advanced upper abdominal cancer; peri-umbillical from advanced intra-abdominal cancer.
      • Castleman's disease (Etiology: uncommon, lymphoma-like malignancy; Sx: fevers, chills, sweats, wt loss; PE: local or generalized adenonathy)

      Infection

      Bacterial

      Affected lymph nodes are typically those closest to primary infection, increase rapidly in size, are warm and tender. Fluctuant if necrosis and abscess.
      • Staph aureus (Sites: skin infection, abscess, wound infection; osteomyelitis via direct extension; arthritis; bacteremia; Sx: fever, pain/swelling at primary as well as affected, lymph nodes; PE: cellulitis→ redness, warmth, induration, skin abscess→ focal redness and fluctuance)
      • Streptococcus: Group A (Sites: cellulitis/lymphangitis; skin abscess; erysipelas; impetigo, throat infections→ acute pain, f, adenopathy; scarlet fever → high temp, rash, palatal petchiae, throat sx; necrotizing fasciits; PE: strep throat→ pharyngeal erythema, d/c, adenop, necrotizing fasciitis, red streaking from lymphangitis) more from CDC
      • Chlamydia trachomatis (lymphogranuloma venereum) (Site: Genital region; Etiology: spread by sexual contact, rare in US, Rfs: same as for HIV; Sx: incubation 1-3 weeks, painless papule or ulcer on penis/vagina/rectal area, then painful inguinal adenopathy) more from CDC
      • Yersinia pestis (plague) (Site: respiratory tract; skin; Rf/Etiology: passed from rodents to humans by fleas, direct contact w/feces, or respiratory droplets; Sx: rapid onset f, c, sepsis, pneumonia; erythema, edema, tender aenopathy) more from CDC
      • Bartonella henslae (cat scratch) (Sites: skin and lymph nodes; Rfs/Etiology: caused by cat scratch; Sx: may see inflamation at innoculation site, then tender regional adenopathy w/in few weeks, fatigue, fever) more from CDC
      • Brucella (Sites: systemic; Etiology: ingestion of raw/uncooked dairy or handling infected animals; Rfs: veterinarians, meat packers, slaughter house workers, farmers; Middle East, Mediterranean, Mexico, Africa; Sx/PE: causes weeks/months of recurrent f, c, sweats, arthritis, adenopathy, orchitis, hepato-splenomegaly) more from CDC
      • Nocardia (Sites: lung, skin; Etiology: lives in soil, inhaled or via open wound; Sx: subacute cough, f, abscess, cellulitis, lymphangitis if direct inoculation) more from CDC
      • Francisella tularensis (tularemia) (Sites: skin, lymph nodes; Etiology/Rfs: passed from dying wild animals to humans via ticks/insects, US Southeast and Rocky Mtns; Sx: f, c, ha, oral or skin ulcers, painful adenopathy, sob, muscle aches) more from CDC
      • H ducreyi (chancroid) (Site: genital region; Rfs: Africa/Caribean & not in US unless travel, spread by direct sexual contact, similar RFs for HIV; Sx/PE: incubation 1d-2w, papule to painless ulcer in genital area, inguinal adenopathy) more from CDC

      Spirochetes

      • Syphillis (Rfs: sexual exposure, Etiology/Sx/PE: primary, secondary and tertiary manifestations; primary infection causes painless genital ulcer, ~3w after exposure → heals 4-6w, regional adenopathy; secondary manifestations weeks to mos later w/non-specific rash, predilection for palms, and soles; condyloma around genital areas, mucous involvement, generalized adenopathy, f, sweats, eyes→ iritis/uveitis; tertiary manifestations yrs later affecting CNS→ numbness, weakness, balance problems, dementia; large blood vessels→ aortitis, aneurysm) More from CDC

      Viral and Retroviral

      • HIV (Etiology/Rfs: hiv risk factors→ men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; risks of unusual infection increase as CD4 declines; Sx: acute infection→ fever, chills, sweats, adenopathy, rash, pharyngitis w/in 2-4 weeks - then resolves; latency until sx develop 6-10y after initial infxn (if not treated) related to drop in CD4: generalized sx include f, c, cough, wt loss; other illnesses: mucosal candidiasis; fungal, mtb lung infection; persistent diarrhea; CNS toxo; non hodgkins lymphoma; kaposis sarcoma of skin, adenopathy, etc) more from CDC
      • CMV (Sx/PE: retinitis/colitis/disseminated dz in patients w/HIV; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w, then f, c, malaise hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, fatigue x 4-6w; head/neck adenopathy & pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC
      • EBV (mononucleosis) (Rfs: spread by direct contact→ kissing, shared drinking glasses, shared toothbrushes, etc; Sx: incubation 4-6w, prodrome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias, then f, sore thorat; PE: maculo-pap rash after amox or other abx, head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly) more from CDC
      • Herpes simplex oral/genital infxn (Etiology: primary infxn sometimes assoc w/fever; Sites: genital, oral; Rfs: passed by sexual or oral contact; Sx/PE: acute, painful, genital or oral area vesicles, inguinal adenopathy) more from CDC

      Fungal

      • Coccidioidomycosis (Etiology: south west US, higher risk if immune-compromised; Site: lung parenchyma and pleural space, joints, skin, lymph nodes; Sx: sub-acute sob also arthritis, PE: inflammatory arthritis, skin nodules, seeding of other sites)
      • Histoplasmosis (Sites; lungs, liver, spleen, mouth, lymph nodes, systemic; Rfs: exposure to Mississippi & Ohio river valley, HIV+; Sx: can be asx/mild and resolve spont; often see x-ray evidence prior infection lung, spleen w/o known past infxn; cough, fever; can cause resp/systemic illness, oral ulcers in HIV+)
      • Sporothrichosis (Rfs: lives in soil, infection via cut when handling dirt, vegetation; Sx: painless skin nodule at site of innoculation; develops over 1 to 12 weeks; increases in size and can ulcerate; sometimes local adenpathy)
      • More on fungi from CDC

      Mycobacterial

      • M tuberculosis (MTB) (RFs: HIV +, steroids, chronic kidney, liver or lung dz; ivdu, from enedemic area, healthcare worker, otherwise immunocomp; extra-pulm TB increases in HIV+ w/CD4 < 350; Sx: sub-acute, cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, sweats, fatigue; can also infect GI/GU tracts; adenopathy most commonly head/neck) more from CDC

      Parasites

      • Leishmaniasis (Kala Azar) (Etiology: spread by sand-fly bite, widespread throughout subtropics→ Africa, Central & South America, India, Mediterranean basin, Asia, Middle East; Sx/PE: cutaneous: papule→ nodule→ painless raised & indurated ulcers that don't heal over weeks to mos; visceral→ can be silent, or cause fevers, sweats, chills, wt loss, adnenopathy, organomegaly)
      • W bancrofti (filariasis) (Rfs/Etiology; tropics/sub-tropics, spread by mosquitoes; Sx: most are asx and wont have sequelae; some will have acute f, c, adenopathy; filaria invade lymphatics, after years→ lymphedema from obstruction of channels; PE: in some, chronic lymphedema)

      Autoimmune/Rheum D/O

      • Adult Still's Disease (Etiology: febrile illness of unknown etiology; Sx: f and other sx are persistent, sub-acute; evaluation of f does not reveal other etiology; also arhtritis & arthralgias of larger joints; salmon colored, maculo-pap non-puritic skin erruption; myalgias, adenopathy, sore throat, pericarditis and pleuritis; PE: erruption is light salmon colored mac/pap, pharyngitis, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy)
      • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
      • Sarcoid (Etiology: idiopathic systemic illness; Rfs: age usually <40, blacks >> other racial groups; Sx: recurrent/progressive cough, fever, fatigue, sob, wt loss, wheezing, joint pain, neuro sx, eye and skin complaints, chf from infiltrative cardiac dz, syncope/sudden death; often delays in dx as rx for asthma/other; PE: wheezing, other systemic findings including: uveitis, arthritis, erythema nodosum, purplish-skin plaques/nodules on face, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, CN7 palsey, CNS & PNS involvement, adnopathy, other organ infiltration)
      • Serum sickness (Rfs: typically from rxn to abx, or secondary to viral infxn → e.g. acute hep b; Sx: acute, symetric, additive/migratory, polyarthritis; myalgias, fever, rash, adenopathy, onset days to weeks after exposure)

      Hypercoaguability?

      DVT

      Hx DVTs, Pulmonary emboli; more info from CDC
      • Acquired states that promote clotting
        • Malignancy→ in particular mucin secreting adenocarcinomas, nhl, aml, others
        • Immobility, w/risk increasing based on degree: prolonged sitting→ long car ride, plane ride to bed bound
        • Trauma/vascular injury, surgery
        • Chronic vascular catheters
        • Chronic inflammatory conditions→ Inflammatory bowel disease, lupus, Behcet's dz, etc
        • Smoking
        • Meds→ e.g. estrogen
        • Heparin induced throbocytopenia (HIT) (Sx: 50% decline in plt w/in 5-10 d rx, either first time or re-exposure to heparin; leads to venous and arterial thrombotic events)
        • Essential thrombocytosis (ET) (Sx: asx until platelets significantly elevated; then sx related to thrombotic events→ stroke, heart attack, dvt/pe; some patients have increased risk bleeding)
        • Excessive erythrocytosis (too many RBCs) (Etiology: primary bone marrow problem→ polycythemia vera; secondary process→ testosterone supplementation, renal/liver/splenic cancer, inappropriate use of epo, chronic hypxemia, osa; Sx: hepatic vein or other venous clot in unusual location or otherwise unexplained; mi, stroke, tia, headache, mesenteric ischemia, other arterial insufficiency from sludging; itching exacerbated by hot shower; sometimes bleeding; PE: ruddy complexion, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly)
        • Hyperhomocystinemia
        • Nephrotic syndrome - increased risk in particular for renal vein thrombosis and DVT
        • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) (Etiology: unusual d/o, avg age onset 30s, acquired rbc membrane prob that increases susceptibility to compliment; Sx: spontaneous venous thrombosis→ portal, hepatic, mesenteric and extremity veins; episodic intravascular hemolysis, in partic following infxn, w/assoc sob, doe, fatigue; decreased production all cell lines)
        • Pregnancy - w/hypercoag state extending ~6w post partum
      • Hereditary states
        • Protein S, Protein C, AT3 deficiency states; factor 5 leiden resistance, prothrombin mutation, anti-phospholipid antibodies
      • Often Venous Thrombo-Embolic Dz (VTE) is caused by multiple factors - e.g. hereditary predisposition + a "second hit" like immobility

      Arterial events

      Hx early/unexplained arterial thrombo-embolic events or events in unusual distributions
      • Anti-phospholipid anti-body syndrome
      • Essential thrombocytosis (ET) (Sx: asx until platelets significantly elevated; then sx related to thrombotic events→ stroke, heart attack, dvt/pe; some patients have increased risk bleeding)
      • Excessive erythrocytosis (too many RBCs) (Etiology: primary bone marrow problem→ polycythemia vera; secondary process→ testosterone supplementation, renal/liver/splenic cancer, inappropriate use of epo, chronic hypxemia, osa; Sx: hepatic vein or other venous clot in unusual location or otherwise unexplained; mi, stroke, tia, headache, mesenteric ischemia, other arterial insufficiency from sludging; itching exacerbated by hot shower; sometimes bleeding; PE: ruddy complexion, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly)
      • Heparin induced throbocytopenia (HIT) (Sx: 50% decline in plt w/in 5-10 d rx, either first time or re-exposure to heparin; leads to venous and arterial thrombotic events)
      • Endothelial damage from trauma, surgery, xrt, cocaine
      • Hyperhomocystinemia
      • Pregnancy - w/hypercoag state extending ~6w post partum
      • Often idiopathic or assumed related to traditional RFs of: HTN, hyperlipidemia, smoking, early family hx, diabetes

      Anemia

      Hemoglobin measurement needed to Dx anemia - but such a common problem that DDx provided below. Sx: weakness, fatigue, sob, doe. Degree of sx based on acuity of anemia, other co-morbid dz processes, genl activity level.

      Decreased RBC production

    • Bone marrow production problem - acquired
      • Myelodysplastic syndrome (Rfs: Age > 60, a primary problem or secondary to chemotherapy or other d/o that can affect BM function; Sx: asx until anemia, low plt, or low wbc lead to sx→ fatigue, sob, doe, bleeding, infection; risk of transformation to AML)
      • Aplastic anemia (Etiology: Secondary→ meds, infection, xrt, other; all cell lines decreased; Sx: sob, fatigue from anemia; recurrent infections from low wbc; bleeding from low plt)
      • Hematologic malignancy e.g. leukemia, lymphoma, multiple myeloma, myeloproliferative disorders (Sx: wt loss, f, chills, sweats, bleeding, other cell lines affected)
    • Bone marrow production problem - hereditary
      • Thalassemia (Rfs/Etiology: mediterranean background, dx during childhood; Sx: failure to thrive) more from the CDC
      • Sickle cell (Rfs: black, family hx, identified in childhood; Sx: failure to thrive in childhood, recurrent bouts pain during crises) more from the CDC
      • Aplastic anemia (Etiology: primary→ related to a number of inherited conditions; all cell lines decreased; Sx: sob, fatigue from anemia; recurrent infections from low wbc; bleeding from low plt)
    • Secondary bone marrow production problem
      • Chronic kidney disease→ low epo
      • Chronic liver disease
      • Chronic inflammatory process of any sort→ anemia of chronic disease
      • Low testosterone in men (Sx: low libido, ED, decreased energy, non-specific weakness/fatigue, depression)
      • Hypothyroidism (Sx: wt gain, edema, dry skin, constipation, cold intolerance, depression/mood change, weakness, fatigue; PE: often no findings aside from wt gain, sometimes decreased reflexes, edema, bradycardia)
      • ETOH abuse
      • B12 deficiency (Etiology: perinicious anemia, s/p gastrectomy, crohn's dz, rarely diet related; Sx: progressive, legs more common then arms, can be painful, impaired dorsal columns function, gait problems, tongue can be smooth and swollen if severe, s/s anemia if severe, rarely confusion)
      • Folate deficiency
      • Meds e.g. chemotherapeutic agents and many others
      • Iron deficiency - Primary (Etiology: lack of access to iron is unusual, unless extreme diet→ vegan)
      • Iron deficiency - Secondary (Etiology: blood loss→ see below; malabsorption of iron for any reason→ gastric surgery, gastric by-pass, celiac dz, IBD, elevated gastric pH from h2 blockers or PPIs, etc.)

      Blood loss

      Slow losses (compensated) tend to cause vague symptoms of fatigue and dyspnea. Rapid losses (uncompensated) tend to cause abnormal vitals signs and are often visible (e.g. throwing up blood or passing blood per rectum). Internal sources of bleeding (intra-abdominal, retroperitoneal, thoracic) aren't directly visible but hx often suggestive.
    • Bleeding in upper GI tract
        • Stool is typically tarry/sticky and has characteristic odor
      • Ulcer - gastric or duodenal (Rfs/Etiology: ETOH, h pylori, nsaid use; Sx: epigastric, better or worse w/food, black stools)
      • Esophageal varices→ seconary to portal htn, whose causes include:
        • Post-hepatic processes→ hepatic vein thrombosis, severe R/L CHF, constrictive pericardial diease, restrictive cardiomypathy
        • Intrahepatic processes→ chronic hepatitis of any etiology including: viral, toxin, autoimmune, infiltrative, malignant; sometimes acute d/o if fulminant or superimposed on chronic
        • Pre-hepatic processes→ portal vein thrombosis, portal vein obstruction from parasites/other
      • Stomach cancer (Rfs: 50, smoking, ETOH abuse, h pylori→ MALT assoc; Sx: sub-acute, feel full when eating ever smaller quantities of food, pain, bleeding)
      • Gastritis (Rfs: stress, ETOH, NSAIDs, h pylori; Sx: epigastric pain, black stools, better or worse w/food)
      • Esophagitis (Rfs: assoc w/obesity, ETOH, smoking, caffine, chocolate, mint; Sx: GERD type→ burning type pain, often worse after meals, worse if lie down after eating, bad taste in mouth, radiates up from epigastrium)
      • Swallowed blood from upper respiratory source→ nose bleed
      • Swallowed blood from oral bleeding site
      • Mallory Weiss Tear (Etiology/Rfs: hx repeateed retching)
      • Dieulafoys lesions→ sub-mucosal artery (Sx: sudden, brisk bleeding)
      • Aorto-enteric fistula (Rfs: hx AAA graft; Sx: profound bleeding)
      • Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT; formerly Osler-Weber-Rendu) (Etiology: rare congential d/o, AVMs within lungs, nose, mouth, GI tract→ duod, stomach, colon; Sx: onset typically in teens, nose bleeds; cryptic GI bleeds/iron defic anemia, SOB, cryptic stroke or CNS abscess; PE: recurrent nose bleed, telangiectasis on nasal mucosa, lips, tongue)
    • Bleeding in colon - structural
      • Colonic AVM (Sx: typically small amounts blood, avm not visible on exam)
      • Colonic polyp (Sx: typically small amounts blood, polyp no visible on exam)
      • Diverticulum (Sx: acute, bright red blood, can be small or large amnts)
      • External hemorrhoid (Sx: painless bleeding, unless thrombosed; readily visible on exam; if thrombosed then acute pain PE: bluish venous structure in peri-rectal area; readly visible if thrombosed)
      • Internal hemorrhoid (Sx: painless bleeding, small or large amounts, recurrent; rare site of variceal bleeding from portal htn PE: not visible unless use anoscope or prolapsed; blood apparent on digital rectal if bleeding at time)
      • Stercoral ulcer (Rfs/Etiology: older patient, immobile, related to hardened stool in low motility colon, dementia)
      • Contribution from primary bleeding disorder
      • Rectal varices (Etiology: assoc w/portal htn; much less common than esophageal varices; Rf: any reason for portal htn→ pre, intra, or post-hepatic; Sx: related to chronic liver dz; profound bright red blood per rectum; PE: blood on digital exam, brisk bleeding, abnormal vital signs
      • Colorectal cancer (adeno) (Rfs: no prior screening or screening > 10y ago, early family hx, polyposis syndromes, UC or colonic crohn's; Sx: anorexia, weight loss, vague pain, persistent/progressive, bloody stools, change in bowel habits, R sided→ fatigue from anemia, L sided→ obstructive sx; palpable if very distal)
      • Anal cancer (squamous cell) (Rfs: squamous cell ca around anus & assoc w/HPV infection, increased incidence w/anal intercourse, HIV, women, men who have sex w/men; Sx: anal pain, tenesmus, bleeding, pain, obstruction PE: palpable mass or diffuse tissue infiltration around anus)
    • Bleeding in colon - inflammatory/infxn
      • Ulcerative colitis (Etiology: automimmune, genetic, environmentally triggered, other; affects colon, distal to prox; Rfs: Northen Europeans, North Americans; smoking and appendectomy protective; peak onset 15-30; Sx and PE: sub-acute, recurrent or chronic diarrhea; fatigue, wt loss, bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, nocturnal diarrhea, feeling poorly overall; spectrum from mild to severe; extra-GI: aphtous ulcers, erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosa, peripheral arthritis, ankylosing spond/sacroiliitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, eye sx→ episcleritis/scleritis/uveitis) More from CDC
      • Crohn's disease (Etiology: automimmune, genetic, environmentally triggered, other; transmural involvement; can affect anywhere in GI tract mouth-to-anus; Rfs: smoking and appendectomy increase risk; Northern Europeans and North Americans; peak onset 15-30; Sx: sub-acute, diarrhea→ though can be less prominent than w/UC, nocturnal diarrhea, sometimes bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, fever, abd pain, fatigue, wt loss, feeling poorly overall, fistulas, bowel obstruction, peri-rectal dz; spectrum of sx and findings; PE: sometimes abd mass; peri-rectal disease; extra-GI: aphtous ulcers, erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosa, peripheral arthritis, ankylosing spond/sacroiliitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, eye sx→ episcleritis/scleritis/uveitis) More from CDC
      • XRT induced (Rf/Etiology: hx radiation to lower abd/pv → e.g. prostate; Sx: small amounts of blood)
      • Bacterial enteritis can cause acute, self limited bleeding - not typical to lead to anemia
      • Parasites → Entamoeba Hyst (Rfs: unclean water/poor santiation, also via anal intercourse; Sx: diarrhea, abd pain, 2-4w incubation)
      • Parasites→Necator americanus (hookworm) (Rfs/Etiology: common world-wide, enter thru feet/skin if walk barefoot in soil w/infected feces → bloodstream → lungs → swallowed → small intestines → blood loss; Sx: fatigue, d)
      • Parasites→ Trichuris (whipworm) (Sx/Etiology: eggs ingested, live in colon; light infxn → Sx: often asx; if heavy burden → abd pain, diarrhea, bloody stools, n, v, anemia)
      • HIV + (chronic, atypical infxns → CMV, HSV; Kaposis; can also be bacterial)
      • Medications (e.g. Ipilimumab) (Etiology: immune modulating cancer therapy) can cause colitis, as can other meds as well; Sx: dx based on recognizing connection between med & GI bleeding; brb per rectum, non-specific abd pain)
    • Ischemia
      • RFs/Etiology: hx vascular disease and RFs, hx hypoperfusion→ hypotension for any reason; Sx: acute onset bleeding, pain
    • Small bowel bleeding
      • Arterio-venous malformation (Rfs: age > 60, esrd, aortic stenosis, von-willebrand's dz; Sx: painless, bleed intermitently, no source seen on upper or lower endoscopy)
      • Small bowel polyps (Sx: related to familial polyposis syndromes, may have family hx gi malignancy)
      • Meckel's diverticulum (Etiology: ectopic stomach mucosa located in terminal ileum; Sx: can be asx, or cause, abdominal pain, gi bleeding, sbo)
      • Crohn's disease (Etiology: automimmune, genetic, environmentally triggered, other; transmural involvement; can affect anywhere in GI tract mouth-to-anus; Rfs: smoking and appendectomy increase risk; Northern Europeans and North Americans; peak onset 15-30; Sx: sub-acute, diarrhea→ though can be less prominent than w/UC, nocturnal diarrhea, sometimes bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, fever, abd pain, fatigue, wt loss, feeling poorly overall, fistulas, bowel obstruction, peri-rectal dz; spectrum of sx and findings; PE: sometimes abd mass; peri-rectal disease; extra-GI: aphtous ulcers, erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosa, peripheral arthritis, ankylosing spond/sacroiliitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, eye sx→ episcleritis/scleritis/uveitis) More from CDC
      • Adenocarcinoma (Etiology: can be spontaneous, also assoc w/familial polyposis syndromes, duodenum is most common site; Sx: abd pain, wt loss, occult bleeding)
      • Lymphoma (Sx: sub-acute fever, sweats, abdominal pain, diarrhea, adenopathy elsewhere)
      • Metastatic dz (Sx: related to primary, mets to sb can cause pain, bleeding, obstruction
    • Trauma & phlebotomy
      • Trauma (Etiology: typically obvious - blood can escape externally or collect in body spaces → chest, abd, retroperit, thigh)
      • Phlebotomy (Etiology: chronic blood donation or recurrent phlebotomy in hospitalized patients)
    • GU or GYN losses
      • GU (Etiology: unusual to lose a lot of blood in urine unless very obvious)
      • GYN (Etiology: vaginal bleeding from heavy menses, polyps, fibroids, cancer)

      Hemolysis

      Genl Sx: sob, doe, fatigue & those related to specific etiology; PE: if severe hemolysis→ abnl VS, jaundice, scleral icterus, bilirubinuria if intravascular; other sx related to specific Etiologyogy of hemolysis
    • Acquired d/o of RBC membrane
        • Hemolysis is intra-vascular
      • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) (Etiology: unusual d/o, avg age onset 30s, hemolysis due to increased susceptibility to compliment; Sx: spontaneous venous thrombosis→ portal, hepatic, mesenteric and extremity veins; episodic hemolysis, in partic after infxn, w/assoc sob, doe, fatigue; decreased production all cell lines)
    • Inherited d/o: Abnormal RBCs
        • Hemolysis is largely extra-vascular
      • Spherocytosis (Etiology: RBC membrane defect; Sx: those assoc w/anemia, splenomegaly and jaundice; spectrum of severity; neonate to adulthood)
      • Thalassemia (Rfs/Etiology: hemoglobin defect, Mediterranean background, dx during childhood; Sx: failure to thrive)
      • Sickle cell (Rfs/Etiology: hemoglobin defect, black, family hx, identified in childhood; Sx: failure to thrive, recurrent bouts pain during crises)
      • G6PD Defic (Rfs/Etiology: enzyme defect, Mediter, Asian, African, Middle Eastern background; Sx: typically asx until presented w/acute oxidative stress→ infection, meds, fava beans → acute hemolysis → resolves when stress removed)
    • Secondary Hemolytic anemias: RBCs normal
        • Hemolysis is intra or extra-vascular
      • Autoimmune (Etiology: primary/idiopathic or secondary to: connective tissue d/o→ e.g. lupus, RA; infection→ viral, mycoplasma; malignancy→ e.g. CLL; meds→ e.g. penicillins or cephalosporins)
      • Transfusion rxn (occurs following blood transfusion)
      • Selected infections e.g. malaria, babesiosis
      • Hypersplenism (Sx: splenic enlargement for any reason can cause hemolysis → exaggeration of spleens nl fxn; causes include infection, cancer, infiltrative; often also assoc w/low plt and wbcs)
      • Severe malfunction of mechanical heart valve (Sx: accompanied by sx chf/other to suggest valve not opening/closing normally; nl fxning prostheses cause low level, asx hemolysis)
      • Microangiopathic
        • DIC (Etiology: secondary to a precipitant, including → systemic infxn, cancer, trauma, other serious event)
        • HUS-TTP (Etiology/Rfs: HUS→ kids, TTP→ adults; Sx: acute to weeks, n, v, weakness, sometimes abd pain, sometimes diarrhea; sometimes szr, confusion or intermitent neuro deficits; assoc w/anemia, acute kidney injury; secondary to an inciting event, including meds → e.g clopidogrel, infection→ e.g. e coli 0157h7, cancer, etc.)
      Contribution from bleeding d/o - acquired or congenital - can contribute to any of above

      More Info About Oncology and Hematology Related Disorders:
      National Hematologic Diseases, National Cancer Institute and National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute

      Back

      OB/Gyn/Breast

      Chronic or past disease?

      • Infertility, endometriosis, infection, cancer, etc

      Vaginal bleeding?

    • Normal menstruation: Occurs every ~28d, usually w/predictable duration & quantity of bleeding; Avg age menarche US:12-13 ; Avg age menopause US: 51.
    • Quantify excessive bleeding by number of pads change over 24h, degree to which they're saturated, clots observed, etc.

      • Non-Structural causes

      • Perimenopausal (Etiology: anovulatory; Rfs: age 40-50; Sx: hot flashes, irritability, no other abd/pevlvic sx, increase duration between periods, variable length periods)
      • Perimenarche (Etiology: anovulatory, relted to immature pituitary-hypothalamic-ovarian axis; Rfs: age 12-16; Sx: new onset periods, duration and frequency of periods irregular)
      • Polycystic ovarian synd (Etiology: anovulatory; Sx: irregular menstrual intervals, less frequent than monthly, bleeding can be heavy; diabetes, infertility; PE: obesity, hirsutism, acanthosis nigricans)
      • Stress, extreme exercise, extreme wt loss/eating d/o (Etiology: anovulatory, related to loss of GnRH pulsatility from hypothalmus; Sx: loss of periods, skipped periods, lighter and/or shorter duration of bleeding when they occur)
      • Medical conditions
        • Advanced, chronic medical disorders - e.g. kidney dz, poorly controled diabetes, liver dz (Etiology: anovulatory from loss of GnRH pulsatility at level hypothalamus; other causes r'd/out; Sx: loss of periods, missed periods, irregular bleeding)
        • Hypothyroidism (Sx: wt gain, edema, dry skin, constipation, cold intolerance, depression/mood change, weakness, fatigue, loss of periods, missed periods, irregular bleeding; PE: often no findings aside from wt gain, sometimes decreased reflexes, edema, bradycardia)
        • Hyperthyroidism (Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, wt loss, weakness, loss of periods, missed periods, irregular bleeding; PE: sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid, hyper-reflexia)
        • Hyperprolactinemia (Etology: anovulatory, related to pituitary prolactinoma or meds that cause increase prolactin levels→ antipsychotics, many others; Sx: irregular periods, galatorrhea, head aches, infertility)
        • Meds (Etology: many meds including antiepileptics can cause hyperandrogenism, wt gain→ disrupt pit-hypthal axis→ annovulatory irregular bleeding)
      • Coagulopathy related - ovulatory→ menstruation occurs at regular intervals, but is prolonged and heavy
        • Primary bleeding d/o - e.g. von willebrand's, low or dysfuctional plts, etc - prolonged bleeding after min trauma or surgery/dental procedures; spontanenous gum bleeding, nose bleeds, bruising, family hx
        • Meds affecting coagulation can exacerbate bleeding (anti-plt agents→aspirin, clopidogrel, nsaids; anti-coagulants→ warfarin, heparin, direct thrombin inhibitors, etc)
      • Infection related
        • Cervicitis/PID (Rfs: sexually active, Hx STIs; Sx: spotting/small amounts of blood, acute, vaginal d/c, lower abd pain; PE: cervical d/c, cervical inflammation, pain on manipulation of cervix)
        • More from the CDC

      Structural:Cancers

      • Endometrial cancer (Rfs: age > 50, early menarche, late menopause, receiving unopposed estrogens, obesity; Sx vague lower abd discomfort, wt loss, progressive, irregular vaginal bleeding, bleeding starting after menopause; PE: enlarged uterus on exam)
      • Cervical cancer (Rfs: smoking, early age first intercourse, multiple sexual partners, hx STIs, hx HPV, HIV; Sx: vague lower abd discomfort, vaginal bleeding and/or pain w/intercourse; PE: abnormal appearing cervix)
      • Ovarian cancer (Rfs: age > 50, fam hx breast/ovarian, nulliparity, obesity; Sx: vague, progressive, fullness/discomfort, irregular bleeding, increased girth if malignant ascites; PE: sometimes palpably enlarged ovary on exam)
      • Vaginal cancer (Rfs: age >50, DES exposure, HPV, smoking; Sx: lower abd/vaginal area pain, irregular vaginal bleeding, pain and/or bleeding w/intercourse; PE: abnormality along vaginal wall)
      • Vulvar cancer (Etiology: least common of gyn malignancies; affects labia; Rfs: associated w/HPV infxn; age > 50, smoking; Sx/PE: progressive mass or ulcer on labia, itching, bleeding, pain w/intercourse)
      • More on GYN cancers from CDC

      Structural Causes - other

      These etiologies are mostly associated w/ovulatory bleeding.
      • Fibroids (leiomyoma) or polyps (Rfs: common (70-80%) age > 50, black > white; Sx: severe sx in 15-30% of those w/fibroids, heavy/prolonged bleeding during menstruation, fertility problems, lower abd pressue/pain)
      • Polyps (uterine, endocervical) (Rfs: age, obesity, tamoxifen use; heavy/prolonged bleeding during menstruation, bleeding between periods, fertility problems)
      • Endometrial hyperplasia (Rfs: similar to those for endometrial cancer→ age > 50, early menarche, late menopause, receiving unopposed estrogens, obesity; concern that they can co-exist; age; Sx: post-menopausal bleeding)
      • Adenomyosis (Etiology: endometrial tissue that develops w/in myometrium; Rfs: age > 40, prior pregnancy; Sx: excessive bleeding w/periods; pelvic discomfort w/periods)
      • IUD or birth control meds - in partic when first started (Sx: small amounts of blood, irregular/between periods)
      • Retained tampon, trauma, foreign body

      Pregnancy related

      • Ectopic pregnancy (Rfs: sexually active, past STI; Sx: first trimester, known pregnancy, acute lower abdominal pain)
      • Spontaneous abortion (Sx: 1st or 2nd tirmester, known pregnancy, crampy pain, clots, PE: blood, clots, cervix may be visibly open with tissue extruding)
      • Placenta previa (Sx: 3rd trimester, cramps, bleeding is often painless)
      • Placental abruption (Sx: third trimester, bleeding with cramping/frequent contractions, may see fetal heart rate changes/decelerations)
      • Molar pregnancy (Sx: 1st to early 2nd trimester, bleeding can be heavy, passage of tissue clusters, classic u/s appearance, may have n/v/tachy/sx hyperthyroid)

      Pelvic Pain?

      Acute

      OB/GYN Etiology

    • Pregnancy related
      • Ectopic pregnancy (Etiology: past STI→ tubal scarring; Sx: acute lower abdominal/pelvic area pain, known pregnancy or could be initial presentation of pregnancy)
      • Spontaneous abortion (Sx: acute, crampy, lower abdominal/pelvic area pain, known pregnancy, passage of clot thru vagina, sometimes fetus passed as well)
      • Placental abruption (Sx: acute, severe, lower abd/pelvic pain, during 2nd half of pregnancy, assoc w/vaginal bleeding)
      • Placenta previa (Sx: crampy, lower abdominal/pevlic area pain, during 2nd half of pregnancy, typically less painful than abruption)
    • Infection
      • Pelvic inflammatory disease (Etiology: progression of cervicitis from gc or chlamydia to involve uterus & fallopian tubes; Rfs: age < 25, hx sexual activity, hx STI, lower education level, multiple sex partners, new sex partner; Sx: acute lower abd/pelvic area pain, fever, malodorous smelling vaginal d/c; irreg vaginal bleeding; clinically more severe if tubo-ovarian abscess; PE: cervical d/c, cervical motion pain, uterine tenderness, pain on palpation adnexa)
      • More from the CDC
    • Ovarian pathology
      • Cyst rupture/hemorrhage (Sx: mid menstrual cycle, acute, unilateral or pelvic, can have GI/GU sx as well, can occur following activity→ sexual or other, sx assoc w/hypovoemia if sig blood loss)
      • Torsion (Sx: acute, severe lower abd/pelvic area pain, n, v)

      GU

      • Simple UTI (Sx: acute, frequency, urgency, no vaginal d/c, no other sx; PE: sometimes supra-pubic discomfort)
      • Pyelonephritis (Sx: fever, chills, lower abd/low back pain, n , v, systemic sx; PE: febrile, costo-vert angle tenderness)
      • Stones (Sx: acute onset, colicky pain, radiates from flank to pelvis; if in bladder, pain focused in pelvis)

      GI

      • Bacterial enteritis (Sx: generalized crampy pain, acute, f, diarrhea, bloody stool)
      • Bowel obstruction - small or large bowel obstruction (Sx: generalized abd, comes in waves, n, v, decreased flatus, abd distension; PE: distended, generalized discomfort)
      • Ileus or parasympathic dysfxn
      • Diverticulitis (Sx: left/lower abdomen, RLQ less commonly, fever, nausea; PE: pain localized to RLQ, guarding, rebound & other signs peritonitis)
      • Appendicitis (Sx: starts umbilicus → R lower quadrant, fever, nausea, anorexia; as w/peritonitis of any cause → patient lies still → movement increases pain; PE: RLQ pain, rebound, guarding, other signs peritonitis)
      • Inguinal or femoral hernia (Sx: discomfort in inguinal area, severity based on durations incarceration &/or if infarct; PE: inguinal area bulge; painful, indurated and red as progresses)
      • Volvulous (Sx: geralized or LLQ→ if involving sigmoid, n, v, decreased flatus; PE: pain over area of volvulous, sometimes mass, can progress to peritonitis)
      • Intussusception (Sx: generalized abd sx; acute, typically age < 2; in adults, bowel cancer can be lead point; n, v, distention, bloody mucous per rectum)
      • IBD (Sx: more typically a chronic syndrome of recurrent pain, wt loss, diarrhea, BRBPR, other systemic sx) more from CDC
      • Distal colorectal cancer (Sx: more typically causes chronic sx - acute assoc w/obstruction→ LBO/SBO; rectal bleeding, vague pelvic pain; very advanced cancer can present w/perforation→ peritonitis)

      Vascular

      • Mesenteric/small bowel ischemia (Rfs/Etiology: known atherosclerosis or risk factors, known risk factors for embolic disease→ a fib, ventricular thrombus, acute low BP superimposed on atherosclerosis; Sx: persistent/progressive generalized pain; PE: few exam findings/or pain out of proportion to findings, ultimately peritonitis w/prolonged ischemia or infarct)
      • Colonic Ischemia (Rfs: known atherosclerosis or RFs, hypotension from other process superimposed on atherosclerosis, RFs for embolic events→ a fib, ventricular thrombus; Sx: generalized abdominal pain, small amounts of bright red blood w/stool, diarrhea)

      Sub-acute/chronic

      GYN

    • Benign
      • Endometriosis (Sx: dysmennhorea, irreg bleeding, pain w/intercourse, infertility, pain occurs mid-cycle, urinary or rectal sx if implantation in those areas)
      • Fibroids (Sx: vague lower abd disocmort - may vary w/size of fibroid, vaginal bleeding)
      • Pelvic adhesions (Rfs: STIs/tubal scarring; hx pelic area surgery/radiation; Sx: vague pelvic area pain; pain w/intercourse)
      • Ovulatory pain (mittleschmerz) (Sx: mid menstrual cycle, lasts 1-2 days, often on one side, recurrent)
    • Malignant
      • Ovarian cancer (Rfs: age > 50, fam hx breast/ovarian, nulliparity, obesity; Sx: vague, progressive, fullness/discomfort, irregular bleeding, increased girth if malignant ascites; PE: sometimes palpably enlarged ovary on exam)
      • Uterine cancer (Rfs: older age, early menarche, late menoapause, receiving unopposed estrogens, obesity; Sx vague lower abd discomfort, wt loss, progressive, vaginal bleeding; PE: enlarged uterus on exam)
      • Cervical cancer (Rfs: smoking, early age first intercourse, multiple sexual partners, hx STIs, hx HPV, HIV; Sx: vague lower abd discomfort, vaginal bleeding, pain w/intercourse; PE: abnormal appearing cervix)
      • Vaginal cancer (Rfs: age >50, DES exposure, HPV, smoking; Sx: lower abd/vaginal area pain, vaginal bleeding; PE: vaginal wall growth or abnormality)
      • Vulvar cancer (Etiology: least common of gyn malignancies; affects labia; Rfs: associated w/HPV infxn; Sx/PE: progressive mass or ulcer on labia, itching, bleeding, pain w/intercourse
      • More on GYN cancers from CDC

      GU

    • Benign
      • Interstitial cystitis (Rfs: women > men; Sx: urinary frequency, urgency pain, chronicity, neg evidence infxn)
    • Malignant
      • Renal cell (Rfs: smoking, obesity, family hx; Sx: low back to lower abd/groin discomfort, wt loss, sweats, fever, flank pain, hematuria)
      • Bladder or other urothelial (Rfs: smoking hx, age > 50, anyline dye exposure→ TCC; chronic foley or schistosomiasis→ SCC; Sx: lower abd/pelvis discomfort, wt loss, hematuria/dysuria, urinary frequency/urgency)

      GI

    • Benign
      • Inguinal or femoral hernia (Sx: chronic discomfort in inguinal area, not severe nor other sx if noy incarcerated, strangulated, or obstructed; PE: inguinal area bulge; tender, indurated and red if incarcerated/infarct)
      • Ventral Hernia (Sx: discomfort in area where intestines/omentum trapped in ventral defect; not severe nor assoc sx if no strangulation, obstruction, infarction)
      • Functional disorder/IBS (Sx: generalized/non-specific abd, no wt loss, not severe pain; no abd findings or other red flags; sometimes constipation alt w/diarrhea) Rome criteria for functional bowel d/o
      • Inflammatory Bowel Disease(Sx: generalized abd sx; sub-acute, recurrent or chronic; wt loss, diarrhea, bloody stools, cramps, constipation; presentation can also be fulminant/severe if perforation, obstruction, profound inflammation)
    • Malignant
      • Colorectal (Rfs: no prior screening or screening > 10y ago, early family hx, polyposis syndromes, UC or colonic crohn's; Sx: anorexia, weight loss, vague pain, persistent/progressive, bloody stools, change in bowel habits, R sided→ fatigue from anemia, L sided→ obstructive sx)
      • Anal cancer (Rfs: squamous cell ca assoc w/HPV infection; Sx: anal pain, tenesmus, bleeding, pain, obstruction PE: palpable mass or diffuse tissue infiltration)
      • Lymphoma (Hodgkins and Non-Hodgkins) (Sx: wt loss/decreased appetite sweats, fevers, chills, adenopathy, organomegaly, abdominal fullness; CNS involvement and sx w/NHL; skin involvement w/cutanous t-cell NHL)
      • Metastatic disease to abdomen e.g. Lung - generalized abd

      Sweats?

      • Endocrine
        • Peri-menopause (Sx: hot flashes, vaginal dryness, age near ~50, irritable, other mood changes)
        • Hyperthyroidism (Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, wt loss, weakness, infetility, ED, menstrual irreg; PE: sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid, hyper-reflexia, moist skin)
      • Infection - see under ID, "Comprehensive list of pathogens" for detailed list
      • Auto-immune/inflammatory - see under ID, "Non-infectious causes of fever: autoimmune d/o" for detailed list
      • Malignacy - see under Hematology/Oncology for detailed list
      • Meds
        • Dx based on r/o other causes and temporal link between initiation med and fever onset
        • Malignant hyperthermia → e.g. inhalational anesthetics - typically in OR or soon thereafter
        • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome → e.g. haldol, chlorpromazine (Sx: high fever, cramps, confusion, autonomic instability)
        • Many other meds - including broad range of abx
      • Other
        • Acute physiologic stress→ MI, pneumonia, dvt/pe, etc

      Infertility or Miscarriage?

      • Infertility =s failure to conceive after 12m regular, unprotected intercourse; 6m if age > 35
      • F/U questions re infertility: (How long trying to conceive? How often intercourse? Past success? Spontaneous or therapeutic abortion? Prior evaluation? Genl health, meds, surgeries, etc? Partners health/issues → infertility Etiology 1/3 male, 1/3 female, 1/3 mixed)
      • Assoc w/Annovulation
        • Primary ovarian insufficiency (Etiology: age < 40, lost of periods due to idiopathic follicle dysfunction or depletion; function can recover; Sx: sometimes abnormal uterine bleeding; somethimes symptoms low estrogen→ sweats, hot flashed, irritability, vaginal dryness, dyspareunia)
        • Hypothal/pit d/o
        • Stress, extreme exercise, extreme wt loss/eating d/o (Etiology: related to loss of GnRH pulsatility from hypothalmus; Sx: loss of periods, skipped periods, lighter and/or shorter duration of bleeding when they occur)
        • Polycystic ovarian synd (Sx: irregular menstruation, diabetes; PE: obesity, hirsutism, male patterned balding, acanthosis nigricans)
        • Hyperproloactinemia (Sx: HA, visual field cuts, other hyothal/pit dysfxn, milk production when not pregnant)
        • Hx medical conditions/habits that affect systemic health/medications (Etiology: poorly controled diabetes, vascular dz, smoking, thyroid dz)
        • Early menopause (Etiology: spontaneous, chemotherapy; Sx: irregular/absent menstrual periods, hot flashes, irritability)
        • Meds (Etology: many meds including antiepileptics can cause hyperandrogenism, wt gain→ disrupt pit-hypthal axis)
      • Older maternal age; risk slowly increases from early 20s, sharp rise > 35 - qualitative oocyte problems
      • Endometriosis (Etiology: implantation of ectopic endometrial tissue leads to scarring, anatomic distortion; Sx: severe menstrual pain, irreg bleeding)
      • Uterine factors affecting implantation (Etiology: fibroids, scarring, anatomic variations→ bicornate, etc)
      • Fallopian tube problems (Etiology: scarring from past STIs, TOAs, hx ectopics)
      • Hx trauma, radiation, surgery affecting pelvic organs
      • Genetic d/o
      • Idiopathic - up to 20%
      • Miscarriages (Etiology: maternal & fetal factors)
        • 1st trimester (Etiology: often related to genetic/congenital abnl fetus, which is assoc w/advanced maternal age; other etiologies/contributors: maternal systemic illness/infection, trauma, meds, smoking, illicit drugs, anti-phospholipid syndrome)
        • 2nd trimester (Etiology: cervical incompetence, uterine factors, maternal systemic illness/infection, trauma, meds, illicit drugs, genetic/aneuploidy)

      Amenorrhea?

      Primay amenorrhea

      Failure to reach menarche by age 16
      • Congenital d/o - Turner syndrome, androgen insensitivity, other
      • Structural d/o - imperforate hymen, transverse vaginal septum, other

      Secondary amenorrhea

      Absence of menstruation for 3 cycles (if previously regular) or 6 months in patient w/irregular cycles
      • Pregnancy
      • Hypothalamic etiology
        • Stress, extreme exercise, extreme wt loss/eating d/o (Etiology: related to loss of GnRH pulsatility from hypothalmus; Sx: loss of periods, skipped periods, lighter and/or shorter duration of bleeding when they occur)
      • Pituitary etiology
        • Hyperprolactinemia (Etology: anovulatory, related to pituitary prolactinoma or meds that cause increase prolactin levels→ antipsychotics, many others; Sx: irregular periods, galatorrhea, head aches, infertility)
        • Meds (Etology: many meds including OCPs; antiepileptics can cause hyperandrogenism, wt gain→ disrupt pit-hypthal axis→ annovulatory irregular bleeding)
        • Injury to pituitary from surgery, trauma, hypoperfusion; infiltrative disease, other
      • Ovarian etiology
        • Primary ovarian insufficiency (Etiology: age < 40, lost of periods due to idiopathic follicle dysfunction or depletion; function can recover; Sx: sometimes abnormal uterine bleeding; somethimes symptoms low estrogen→ sweats, hot flashed, irritability, vaginal dryness, dyspareunia)
        • Perimenopausal (Etiology: anovulatory; Rfs: age 40-50; Sx: hot flashes, irritability, no other abd/pevlvic sx, increase duration between periods, variable length periods)
      • Anatomic
        • Acquired obstruction to outflow - cervical stenosis, intrauterine scarring→ Asherman's synd, other
      • Other, including systemic medical conditions
        • Polycystic ovarian synd (Etiology: anovulatory; Sx: irregular menstrual intervals, less frequent than monthly, bleeding can be heavy; diabetes, infertility; PE: obesity, hirsutism, acanthosis nigricans)
        • Breast feeding post-partum
        • Hyper or hypothyroidism, cortisol excess; androgen excess from tumor, congenital adrenal hyperplasia, consumption of exogenous androgens w/body building→ male patterned balding, facial hair, acne, clitormegaly

      Vaginal D/C?

      • Vaginitis
        • Bacterial vaginosis (Rfs: sexual activity, new partners; though can also get w/o sexual activity; Sx: malodorous d/c, assoc w/dyspareunia; PE: thin, grayish d/c)
        • Fungal vaginitis (Etiology: recurrent infection should prompt screen for dm, hiv; Sx: itchy, soreness, pain w/intercourse; PE: white/cottage cheese consistency d/c)
        • Trichomonas (parasite) (Etiology: spread thru sexual contact; Sx: itchy, malodorous, pain w/intercourse; PE: yellow/green, frothy d/c, cervix with "strawberry" appearance)
      • Cervicitis: STI (Etiology: chlamaydia and gonorrhea, infxn limited to cervix; Rfs: hx sexually active, prior STI; Sx: purulent discharge from cervix→ vagina, vaginal bleeding, burning w/urination; PE: discharge from cervix, redness around os, bleeds easily)
      • Pelvic inflammatory disease: STI (Etiology: progression of cervicitis from gc or chlamydia to involve uterus & fallopian tubes; Rfs: age < 25, hx sexual activity, hx STI, lower education level, multiple sex partners, new sex partner; Sx: acute lower abd/pelvic area pain, fever, malodorous smelling vaginal d/c; irreg vaginal bleeding; clinically more severe if tubo-ovarian abscess; PE: cervical d/c, cervical motion pain, uterine tenderness, pain on palpation adnexa)
      • Tubo-ovarian abscess: STI (Etiology: complication of PID; Sx: acute lower abd pain, fever, vaginal discharge; PE: fever, discharge from cervix, cervical motion pain, adnexal pain, adnexal mass)
      More on STIs from CDC

      Sexual dysfunction?

      Sexually active w/people of same sex, opposite sex, both? What types of activity? Any areas of concern? These questions help define risks for particular problems. Hx of sexual activity should prompt discussion about screening for STIs.
      • Decreased libido
        • Depression
        • Meds (many - in particular anti-depressants, steroid mis-use/abuse, chronic OCP use)
        • Chronic medical conditions (renal & liver disease, anemia, hypothyroidism, etc)
        • Hx sexual abuse that interferes w/ability to achieve/maintain intimacy
      • Pain or other mechanical problems associated w/intercourse
        • Decrease in vaginal lubrication, in partic post menopausal→ atrophic vaginitis (Etiology: post menopasul drop in estrogen levels→ thinning of vaginal mucosa; Sx: chronic discomfort w/intercourse, vaginal itching, sense of decreased lubrication w/stimulation; sometimes contributes to stress incontinence; PE: decreased turgor of vaginal tissues, atrophy, sometimes increased friability)
        • Surgery, medical conditions, or radiation affecting vaginal area
        • Hx musculoskeletal or neuro problems that interfere w/the mechanics of intimacy
        • Skin or other inflammatory conditions around the vagina
        • Involuntary spasm (vaginismus) of muscles around vagina
        • Uterine prolapse, vaginal or cervical malignancy
        May help to obtain info about partner, ? if they have issues.

      Incontinence?

      D/O uurine storage

      • Detrussor over activity (urge incontinence) (Sx idiopathic sudden urgency, need to void immediately, incont of moderate amounts of urine, day or night; less commonly→ UMN syndrome)
      • Detrussor under activity (overflow) (Etiology: nerve dysfxn w/impaired sensation or contraction of bladder→cauda equina, severe PN, other; Sx: impaired ability to sense bladder fullness, inability to empty; regular leakage small amounts urine; peripheral numbness, weakness; PE: decreased distal sensation, impaired strength, diminished reflexes, palpable bladder)

      D/O bladder outlet resistance

      • Increased resistance - overflow
        • BPH (Rfs: male, >50; Sx: chronic, progressive, urgency, frequency, hesitancy, difficulty starting/stopping stream, incomplete emptying, decrease force, voiding again soon after urinate; large prostate, rarely palpable bladder)
        • Urethral stricture (RFs: male, hx urethral trauma, hx gonorrhea, hx pelvic xrt, hx prostate surgery; ucommon in women due to short urethra unless hx urethritis or discrete trauma)
        • Prostate cancer (Rfs: male, > 50, fam hx; Sx: urgency, frequency, delayed emptying, hematuria→ if causing obstruction; bone pain if mets; PE: nodular/firm prostate)
      • Decreased resistance
        • Stress incontinence (Rfs: women >> men, age > 50, vaginal childbirth, Sx: worse w/cough/sneeze/sudden movement, small amounts, rarely at night; PE: incont may be reproduced if cough when in stirrups; sometimes prolapse bladder or uterus evident)
        • Complication of prostatectomy → damaged ext sphincter in men

      Mixed disorders

      • Urge incontinence coupled w/stress incontinence in women
      • Urge incontinence coupled w/increased resistance from BPH in men

      Lower urinary tract infxn

      • Either alone or coupled w/other processes

      Non-GU based d/o

      • Excess urine production → poorly controlled DM, diuretic use, hypercalcemia, diabetes insipidus (central or nephrogenic), CHF w/redistribution of volume at night
      • Meds can interfere w/ability to void: Anti-cholinergics, pseudophedrine, benzodiazepines, narcotics, other - in particular if superimposed on bph
      • Osteoarthritis or anything that impairs ability to get up and go to bathroom
      • Atrophic vaginitis in post-menopausal women
      • Among older patients in particular
        • Infection, delirium, immobility, meds, stool impaction, advanced dementia

      Vaginal ulcer or mass?

      Genital ulcer

      Infection

      • Syphilis (Rfs: unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's; Sx: Painless ulcer following exposure, resolves spontaneously; Pe: painless genital ulcer from primary infxn, later can have findings assoc w/secondary syphillis including: non-specific rash, w/predilection for palms, and soles, oral ulcers)
      • Herpes simplex virus (Rfs: sexually active, past STIs, past HSV; Sx: acute, painful, vesicles, sometimes fever w/acute infxn; can be recurrent, resolve spontaneously, sometimes urinary retention; PE: vessicles on a red base, ulcers when ruptures, inguinal adenopathy w/acute infxn)
      • Donavanosis (granualoma inguinale) (Rfs/Etiology: tropics & not in US unless travel, spread by direct sexual contact, incubation 1-3m; Rfs: same as for HIV; Sx: papule to painless ulcer in genital area, beefy red/bleeds, develops over weeks, can be hard to distinguish from chancroid; PE: painless papule or ulcer in genital region, can be beefy/red and bleed)
      • Lymphogranuloma venereum (RFs/Etiology: caused by chlamydia trachomatis, spread by sexual contact, rare in US, incubation 1-3 weeks, RFs same as for HIV; Sx: painless papule or ulcer on vagina/rectal area, then painful adenopathy; PE: painless ulcer or papule, painful adenopthy)
      • H ducreyi (chancroid) (Rfs/Etiology: Africa/Caribean & not in US unless travel, spread by direct sexual contact, RFs same as for HIV, incubation 1d-2w; Sx: papule to painless ulcer in genital area; PE: papule to painless ulcer in genital area, adenopathy)
      More on STIs from CDC

      Cancer

      • Vulvar (Etiology: least common of gyn malignancies; affects labia; Rfs: associated w/HPV infxn; Sx/PE: progressive mass or ulcer on labia, itching, bleeding, pain w/intercourse, regional adenopathy if spread)
      • Vaginal (Rfs: age >50, DES exposure, HPV, smoking; Sx: lower abd/vaginal area pain, irregular vaginal bleeding, pain and/or bleeding w/intercourse; PE: abnormality along vaginal wall)
      • BCC, melanoma→ not common in genital area as not sun exposed (Sx/PE: slow growing, can be ulcerated, sometimes rolled edges; for melanoma→ pigmentation, asymmetric, irreg borders

      Autoimmune/other

      • Behcets Dz (Sx: autoimmune d/o assoc w/waxing/waning sx; eye sx from iritis; also multi-system/systemic sx from vasculitis, arthritis, GI and neuro involvement; PE: painful ulcers in genital region and mouth)
      • Local trauma

      Mass

      • Bartholin's cyst (Sx: discrete swelling in labia; when infected→ acute pain, swelling, redness, sometimes spontaneous d/c; PE: swelling in labia @ 5 and 7 o'clock positions; when infected→ pain, redness, fluctuance)
      • HPV (Sx/Rfs: painless growths, can be single/grouped/or in multiple clusters, painless, acquired via sexual contact, travel w/other STIs; PE: single or clustered growths) more from CDC
      • Bacillary angiomatosis (Sx/RFs: occurs in HIV + or otherwise compromised hosts, painless, PE: nodules on skin, resembles Kaposi's sarcoma)
      • Condyloma lata (secondary syphillis) (Rfs: unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's; Sx: secondary manifestations weeks after primary chancre heals; include: condyloma lata→ moist, frond-like growth in genital area; non-specific rash, w/predilection for palms, and soles, mucosal involvement, adenopathy, alopecia) more from CDC
      • Vaginal cancer(Rfs: age >50, DES exposure, HPV, smoking; Sx: lower abd/vaginal area pain, irregular vaginal bleeding, pain and/or bleeding w/intercourse; PE: abnormality along vaginal wall)
      • Vulvar cancer (Etiology: least common of gyn malignancies; affects labia; Rfs: associated w/HPV infxn; Sx/PE: progressive mass or ulcer on labia, itching, bleeding, pain w/intercourse, regional adenopathy if spread)
      • BCC, melanoma→ not common in genital area as not sun exposed (Sx/PE: slow growing, can be ulcerated, sometimes rolled edges; for melanoma→ pigmentation, asymmetric, irreg borders

      Breast mass, pain or d/c?

      Breast exam
      • Mass
        • Malignancy (Sx: increases w/time, sometimes noted by patient, other times by clinician; PE: firm/hard, stuck to underlying tissues, sometimes overlying skin changes)
        • Benign→ cysts, fibrous tissues (Sx: size varies w/menstrual cycle, not growing, not stuck, no skin changes)
      • Changes in appearance of nipple or skin
        • Nipple inversion (Etiology: suggests underlying malignancy; PE: characteristically abnormal appearance of nipple)
        • Skin puckering/retraction/chronic inflammatory→ suggestive of malignancy
      • Discharge
        • Milk - normal during post-partum period
        • Blood, sero-sanguinous or serous
          • Malignancy (Sx: intermitent or persistent; PE: may have palpable mass; may express d/c on palpation)
          • Papiloma (Etil: benign intraductal growth; Sx: intermitent small amount of bleeding; PE: no mass on exam)
        • Milk when not post partum
          • Increased prolactin from pituitary prolactinoma (Sx: ha, visual sx, infertility)
          • Meds: some anti-pyschotics, anti-depressant, h2-blockers, others
      • Pain suggests inflammation
        • Mastitis→ post partum (Sx: acute, painful, warm, red)
        • Cancer - can be of the deeper breast tissue or inflammatory, which has characteristic orange-peel skin appearance
        • Cyclic→ occurs during partic time of menstrual cycle

      Hx Sexually Trans Infxn (STIs)?

      • STIs increases risk for:
        • Infertility→ tubal scarring via PID
        • Cervical CA via HPV
        • HIV, Hepatitis B, syphilis, other

      More Info About Ob/Gyn/Breast Disorders:
      National Library of Medicine/Medline Plus: Women's Health; Comprehensive breast exam

      Back

      Neurological

      Comprehensive neuro exam

      Known disease?

      • Stroke, seizure, neurodegenerative - Multiple sclerosis, ALS, etc

      Sudden loss of fxn?

      Stroke

      Abrupt onset symptoms: weakness face, arm and/or leg on one half of body; numbness/tingling face, arm and/or leg on one half body; difficulty w/speech; loss or coordination or gait problems; confusion; decreased level of consciousness; headache if intracranial or sub-arachnoid bleeding. To determine time of onset, ask patient/family when they were last normal. Particularly challenging if patient poor historian, no observer, or pre-existing deficits.

      Embolic

      • Cardiac source
        • Atrial fibrillation (Sx: A fib may or may not be known prior; sometimes palpatations/rapid HR, risk of stroke over 1y can be assessed w/CHADS2-VASc score, risk of bleeding w/HAS BLED score, deficits based on where clot lodges; PE: irreg irreg rhythm, acute neuro deficits)
        • Ventricle - stasis and clot from severe wall motion abnormality (Rf: Depressed LV fxn from prior anterior MI or other etiology)
        • Related to cardiac cath (Etiology: catheter flicks off aortic plaque; can embolize brain→ acute neuro deficits, elsewhere as well e.g. kidneys, legs)
        • From infected valve (Etiology: valve usually structurally abnl; Sx: f, c, sweats, embolize to brain→ acute neuro deficits)
      • Artery to artery
      • Paradoxical (Etiology: venous clot crossing PFO or ASD, relatively uncommon, often unknown prior to event; may also be etiology for brain abscess; Sx: deficits related to where embolous lodges)

      Thrombosis in situ

      • Assoc w/cardiovascular Rfs: known atherosclerosis, dm, htn, hyperlipidemia, smoking, early fam hx; consider hypercoaguable states if < 50, no RFs, recurrent events &/or those in unusual anatomic locations

      Arterial dissection

      • Aortic (Rfs: known atherosclerosis, dm, htn, hyperlipidemia, smoking, early fam hx; Sx: acute, tearing-type cp, radiates towards back, n, v, sweating; PE: asymmetry in pulse and BP, neuro deficits)
      • Carotid or Vetebral (Etiology: spontaneous or due to sudden flexion/extension; Sx: neck pain, abrupt onset neuro deficits)

      Hemorrhagic

      • Intra-Parenchymal bleeding
        • Assoc w/htn and atherosclerosis
        • Amyloid angiopathy (older patients)
        • Abnormal blood vessels - assoc w/AVMs, tumors
      • Subdural (Etiology: older→ assoc w/brain atrophy, mild (deceleration) to severe trauma; Sx: change in behavior/level of consciousness, acute to sub-acute)
      • Epidural (Etiology: assoc w/significant blunt trauma, often over middle meningeal artery; Sx: rapid decline in level of consciousness - which can wax and wane prior to demise)
      • Sub-arachnoid (Etiology: typically from a rupture aneurysm; Rfs: women > men, ages 40-60; Sx: acute and severe head ache→ classic thunderclap/worst HA of life, rapid decline in consciousness)
      • Assoc with primary or secondary bleeding d/o

      Systemic hypoperfusion

      • Etiology: anything that lowers bp below crtical level; Sx: ischemia and infarct most likely in distal areas/those supplied by atherosclerotic vessels, flobal insults

      TIA

      • Stroke sx that resolve w/in 24 h - high risk for recurrent events, stroke

      Other d/o of CNS/PNS/NMJ

    • CNS d/o
      • Trauma to brain or cord (Etiology: hx should be obvious)
      • Infectious or inflammatory process of brain
        • Encephalitis (Etiology: inflammation of diffuse or specifc areas of brain parenchyma; Sx: tend to have focal neuro deficits as compared w/meningitis; acute onset of headache, fever, confusion, irritability, motor and sensory impairment, altered speech; can also have meningoencephalitis)
          • Viral (most common) (Organisms: enteroviruses,, HSV, VZV, EBV, influenza, west nile, other arboviruses (transmitted by mosquitoes); and other viruses w/prevalence varying by season, region of the world)
          • Other uncommon infections (Organisms: Tick borne→ lyme; rabies, fungal, and mycobacteria)
          • Non-infectious (Etiology: collagen vascular disease, para-neoplastic, post infectious, post vaccination)
          • Autoimmune encephalitis (Etiology: antibody mediated→ multiple including anti-nmda; also paraneoplastic; Rfs: women, < 30, teratoma; Sx: acute change in personality, decline in functional status, agitation, confusion, bizarre behavior, autonomic instability, seizures, unusual movements, seziures, other neuro deficits)
          • ADEM (acute demyelinating encephalomyelitis) (Etiology: autoimmune d/o, often triggered by an infection→ URI, EBV; post vaccination, other; dx of exclusion; RFs: overall uncommon, though kids>>adults; Sx: acute, progressive, ha, f, confusion, weakness, ataxia, focal deficits; PE: f, focal deficits, patchy UMN and sensory findings)
        • Bacterial abscess (Etiology: reason for abscess → spread from adjacent site→ dental or sinuses, AVM, PFO, neurosurgery; Sx: acute/subacute, headache, fever, loss of function based on location, progressive, delirium)
        • Mycobacterial abscess (Rfs: known TB elsewhere, immuncompromised, otherwise exposed; Sx: subacute f, chills, ha, fatigue, stiff neck, delirium, loss of function based on location)
        • Fungal abscess (Rfs: often assoc w/compromised states → hiv, cancer, DM; systemic or from local spread; Sx: subacute, fever, feeling poorly in general, sub-acute headache & neck pain, delirium, deficits based on location)
        • Parasitic - Cysticercosis (T Solium - tapeworm) (Etiology: ingest eggs via infected beef that's undercooked; Mexico, Africa, Southeast Asia; eggs cross intestines, migrate to host muscles and brain; Sx:headache, seizures, otherwise unexplained muscles aches)
        • Parasitic - Toxoplasmosis (Rfs: HIV + w/CD4 < 200; Sx: sub-acute, headache, confusion, fever, focal neruo deficits based on location)
      • Infection affecting cord and/or vertebrae - osteomyelitis, discitis, epidural abscess
        • Bacterial (Etiology: bacteremia or local infection w/contiguous spread; also post-op or post procedure; Staph most common; Sx: acute/subacute f, c, back pain, neuro deficits)
        • Viral cord infection (Etiology: myelitis secondary to hsv, vzv, cmv, enterovirus, polio other; Sx: acute f, back pain, weakness or other deficits related to area of cord affected)
        • Mycobacterial (Etiology/Rfs: complication of systemic TB, often compromised host, sometimes known TB elsewhere; Sx: sub-acute back pain, f, c, chronic, sx related to tb elsewhere→ lungs, GI)
        • Fungal (Etiology: aspergillous, cocci; Rfs: compromised host; Sx: pain, f, deficits related to level of cord involvement)
      • Cancer - primary brain (Etiology: glioblastoma, astrocytoma, lymphoma, other; Sx: typically sub-acute development of deficits and sx - unless bleeding superimposed)
      • Cancer - metastatic (Etiology: predileciton for cns met→ lung, breast, renal, melanoma; Sx: may have sx from primary site; neuro sx can be acute or subacute)
      • Vascular - bleeding into avm in cord
      • Vascular - acute cord insufficiency (Etiology: post surgical→ AAA repair, post trauma, embolic; Sx: acute loss of function below affected level of cord)
      • Disc herniation (Sx: acute weakness/loss of function below affected level of cord
      • Inflammatory/Auto-immune
        • Transverse myelitis (Etiology: acute inflammation affecting cord, post viral, autoimmune or idiopathic. peak ages 10-20 & 30-40; Sx: impaired sensory & motor function below affected level, bowel & bladder dysfxn, sometimes back pain, onset over hours to days)
        • Multiple sclerosis (Rfs: white>black, women>men, age onset <30; Sx: more typically sub-acute, affects spinal cord and brain, sx wax/wane, progresses over year/decades, patchy sensory and motor deficits that can affect any of the neuro pathways and don't follow an anatomic pattern, visual disturbances, hearing deficits)
    • PNS d/o
      • Trauma or compression to specific PN - selected examples:
        • Radial nerve compression (Etiology: typically associated w/trauma at proximal humerus or prolonged compression in that area → intoxication and passed out x hours; Sx: numbness in hand and unable to use hand normally; PE: unable to extend at wrist, numbness back of hand)
        • Peroneal nerve (Etiology: compression/injury near fibula head; Sx/PE: weak in dorsiflexion and eversion; numbness dorsum foot, lateral shin)
      • Auto-immune/Inflammatory
        • Mononeuritis Multiplex (Etiology: occurs secondary to an underlying problem - DM, vasculitis, etc; Sx: abrupt onset, asymmetric, affects isolated peripheral nerves, motor and sensory symptoms)
        • Guillain barre (Sx: numbness/tingling legs and hands; most prominent feature is weakness that is acute, progressive, symmetric, and has an ascending pattern of involvement)
        • Peripheral CN 7 (Bell's) palsey (Etiology: most commonly from HSV infection; other possibilities: lyme, sarcoid, amyloid, compression from parotid tumor, idiopathic; Sx: acute dysfxn of muscles controling facial expression→ PE: inability to smile, raise foreahead, close eye on affcted side)
      • Malignancy - where tumor compresses nerve - uncommon
    • Toxins or other processes affecting NMJ
      • Botulism (Etiology: contaminated food, black tar heroin; Sx: acute onset→ 8-36h, difficulty swallowing secretions, difficulty breathing or speaking, double vision, abdominal cramps, weakness/paralysis starts w/CNs-->spreads symmetrically to limbs, afebrile, exposure to at risk food)
      • Organophosphate poisoning (Etiology: accidental, intentional or as biological weapon→ Sarin; inhibits cholinesterase; Sx: acute signs and sx related to ach excess→ confusion, lacrimation, excessive resp secretions, brady, weakness, wheezing)
      • Myasthenia gravis (Etiol: autoimmune w/ab targeting ACh receptor; Rfs: 20-30 y female predom, 50-70y male; Sx: painless, subacute, progressive; worse w/repetitive movement, end of day; ocular sx→ double vision, eyelid weakness; other cranial nerve palsies; can also cause systemic weakness affecting neck, extremities, other muscles→ asymmetric and prox > distal fashion; PE: no atrophy, reflexes preserved, no sensory findings, ptosis, eye muscle weakness, weakness in other muscles→ worse w/use)
      Note: Patient's self-reported temporal hx isn't always accurate. Also, underlying medical conditions (anemia, chronic infxn, thyroid dz, chronic liver/kidney dz, etc) may contribute to sx

      Non-neuro etiology

      • Intoxication/drug overdose
      • Hypoglycemia (Etiology: over treatment of dm, adrenal insuff, liver failure; Sx: confusion to non-responsive, corrects w/admin glucose)

      Syncope or presyncope?

      Challenging to identify etiology, as event often unwitnessed. Findings of facial lacerations, fx, other injury suggest true sudden loc - Exam directed toward etiology & any sequelae from the event

      Neuro etiol

      • Neurocardiogenic/Vaso-vagal: inappropriate bradycardia and/or loss of peripheral tone (Rfs: often younger, low risk for c/v dz; Sx: provoked by fear, anxiety, pain prolonged standing, carotid stimulation, urination, cough; feel suddenly sweaty, lightheaded/weak, blurry vision, warm prior to event; tends to recur in similar situations; recovery is usually rapid; sx may also abate if sit and/or lie down)
        • Situational→ assoc w/coughing, urination, defecation, pain, fear/anxiety/stressful events, prolonged standing
        • Cartoid hypersensitivity→ uncommon; sx provoked by pressue on carotid body in neck
      • Orthostatic hypotension from autonomic dysfxn (Etiology: failure to raise HR or peripheral tone w/standing, can be from long standing neuropathy from DM/other metabolic, intrinsic autonomic dz→ multi-system atrophy; Sx: more likely presyncope than syncope, recurrent/chronic w/positional changes; PE: impaired distal sensation, orthostatic blood pressure changes)
      • Multi-system atrophy (Rfs: age 50-60; Etiology: rare neurodegenerative d/o; progresses over 6-10 years; Sx: variability in presentaiton; initially autonomic dysfxn including orthostatic hypotension, if severe→ syncope/presyncope; urge incontinence, erectile dysfunction, other sexual dyxfxn; then parkisnonian features of slow movements, falls, rigidity, often aysmetric tremor, dysphonia dystonias; cerebellar dysfnx w/ataxia and dyscoordination; depression and anxiety; sob from stridor; PE: orhtostatic VS, abnormal posture, abnormal gait, cerebellar dysfxn→ action tremor, coordination problems, ataxic/wide-based gait, nystagumus)
      • Cerebral vascular disease affecting vertebral-basilar system (Etiology: vascular risk factors; Sx: in territory supplied by v-b system: sudden dizziness, double vision, swallowing/speech problems, nausea, vomiting)
      • Generalized seizure d/o (Etiology: more likely if: known seizure d/o, known structural brain dz, Sx: witnessed szr w/post-ictal state, incontinence, tongue biting, injury from not protecting self if fall
      • Non-convulsive status epilepticus (Etiology: related to an array of pathology including tox/met conditions, meds, structural brain dz, other; Sx: waxing and waning level of altertness, confusion, new onset inability to follow commands; much more subtle than generalized seizure; PE: subtle twitching, eye deveiation, blinking, repeating of words, other)
      • Acute intracranial bleeding
        • Subdural (Etiology/Rfs: older→ assoc w/brain atrophy, mild (deceleration) to severe trauma; Sx: change in behavior/level of consciousness, acute to sub-acute)
        • Epidural (Etiology: assoc w/significant blunt trauma, often over middle meningeal artery; Sx: rapid decline in level of consciousness - which can wax and wane prior to demise)
        • Sub-arachnoid (Etiology: typically from a rupture aneurysm; Rfs: women > men, ages 40-60; Sx: acute and severe head ache→ classic thunderclap/worst HA of life, rapid decline in consciousness)
        • Parenchymal (Etiology: trauma, amyloid angiopathy, htn; Sx: acute, loss of function→ based on location)
      • Trauma w/assoc bleeding and/or swelling
      • Acute CNS infection

      Cardiovascular etiologies

      Cardiogenic syncope has high morbidity/mortality. Increased risk if hx: smoking, diabetes, early family history, male, age >~ 50, HTN, hyperlipidemia. Also increased liklihood if known cad, cardiomyopathy, depressed EF for any reason, vascular dz elsewhere. Findings suggestive of c/v syncope: facial lacerations, fx, other injury suggesting true & sudden LOC→ fall w/o protecting head. These findings suggest sudden decreased cerebral perfusion→ Etiologies of low BP.
        Sudden drop in BP→ decrease in cerebral perfusion; BP= COxSVR = HRxSVxSVR = HRxPLxInoxSVR (HR=Heart rate, SV=Stroke Volume, PL=Pre-Load, Ino=Inotropy, SVR=System Vasc Resist)
      Categories of C/V syncope:
    • Decreased Inotropy
      • Severe LV systolic dysfunction (Etiology: CAD w/known MIs, known or newly dx cardiomyopathy; impaired LVs are also the substrate for VT→ see below; PE: lower extremity edema , + S3, elevated jvp, displaced pmi, rales on lung exam)
      • Aortic stenosis (Etiology: age 30-50→ bicuspid; age >60→ senile calcific; Sx: takes years to become severe→ other sx of doe, sob progressive over years; PE: characteristic sytolic murmur, crescendo-decrescendo, later peaking→ more severe)
      • Sub-Aortic Stenosis (Sx: takes years to become severe, typically younger patients PE: characteristic murmur, louder w/less pre-load
    • Decreased pre-load
      • Hypovolemia for any reason (Etiology: bleeding, diarrhea, severe N/V; Sx provoked by standing, or present at baseline if volume loss severe; PE: eleveated hr, low bp, +orthostatic vital sign changes)
      • Anemia for whatever reason (Etiology: in particular if occurs rapidly as w/blood loss→ hypovolemia)
      • Sudden hypoxemia for whatever reason (Etiology: such that blood reaching brain is O2 poor)
      • Other acute disruption in return of blood to heart (Etiology: tension pneumothroax, acute tamponade, pulmonary embolism, etc→ characteristic hx for each)
    • Bradycardia
        • Sx: fatigue, decrease exercise tolerance, CHF; if abrupt onset, then no antecedent sx
      • Primary conduction system problem → sick sinus syndrome, complete or high grade 2nd or 3rd degree AV nodal block
      • Secondary bradycardia (Etiology/Sx: ischemia→ assoc w/CP, exercise induced, known CAD; meds→ beta blockers, non-dihydro ccbs; hypoxemia for any reason)
    • Supraventricular tachycardia
      • SVT - a fib, a flutter, avnrt, WPW (Sx: rapid/irreg heart beat, palpatations; dont typically cause true syncope but rather light headedness and palpatation; syncope if also impaired LV fxn or hypovolemia)
    • Ventricular tach or V Fib
        • Highest risk for morbid/mortality:
      • Ventricular Tachycardia (VT) - Ischemic (Etiology: occurs in the setting of MI, assoc w/ischemic sx of chest pain, sob, diaphoresis; patient's w/CAD RFs)
      • VT - Acquired structural heart abnormality (Etiology: in US, most typically from prior MI → depressed LV fxn, could also be from cardiomyopathy of other Etiology→ idiopathic, tox/met, viral, etc)
      • VT - Congenital or other structural heart dz (Etiology: RV dysplasia, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, infiltrative dz → amyloidosis, sarcoid)
      • VT - Congenital or other acquired pre-disposition (Etiology: long QT syndrome → congenital variant presents in younger patients, can have family hx sudden death; acquired long QT assoc w/many meds; Brugada syndrome, etc)
      • Ventricular fibrillation (Etiology/Sx: abrupt onset; can occurly primarily→ w/acute MI or degeneration from VT; leads to death unless immediate defibrillation/cpr; occurs most commonly in those w/predisposition for VT→ see above)
    • Problems of low SVR
        • Problems of low SVR - Sx exacerbated by moving from lying/sitting to standing→ +orthostatic vital sign changes
      • Meds→ alpha blocking agents, other
      • Acquired conditions that lower SVR (sepsis, adrenal insufficiency, other - hx should be suggestive)
      Recognize that combinations of above can contribute to sudden hypoperfusion - eg. mod AS + sudden volume loss from bleeding→ syncope
