      Other

      • Hypoglycemia (Etiology: over treatment of dm, adrenal insuff, liver failure; Sx: confusion to non-responsive, corrects w/admin glucose)
      • Drug overdose, e.g. heroin
      • Psychiatric d/o (Etiology: anxiety, panic, somatization - on detailed questioning, may not in fact have had true syncope - or claimed but not witnessed)

      Seizure?

      Can be a challenging Sx, as often unwitnessed - Dx suspected on basis of corollary findings, patients report, and risk factor profile

      Primary seizure d/o (epilepsy)

      • Sx: can manifest in childhood thru adult life; can be generalized→ transient loss of consciousness, convulsions, tongue biting, incontinence, post-ictal; or partial/absence → transient state where awake but not normally responsive, can have loss of fxn/focal abnl movement
      • More from the CDC

      Secondary seizure

      • Structural brain dz
        • Cancer - primary brain (Etiology: glioblastoma, astrocytoma, lymphoma, other; Sx: typically sub-acute development of deficits and sx - unless bleeding superimposed)
        • Cancer - metastatic (Etiology: predileciton for cns met→ lung, breast, renal, melanoma; Sx: may have sx from primary site; neuro sx can be acute or subacute)
        • AVM - with or without bleeding
        • S/P stroke, global hypo-perfusion, anoxic injury
        • Traumatic brain injury
      • Infection (Etiology: secondary to acute→ infection meningitis, encephalitis, abscess; or a result of damage from infection)
      • Metabolic d/o (Etiology: hypoglycemia, hypo/hypernatremia, hypo/hypercalcemia, uremia, drug/benzo withdrawal, preganancy→ eclampsia)
      • Toxic ingestion (Etiology: drug abuse, in particular activating agents→ cocaine, pcp, amphetamine)
      • Adverse reaction to prescribed meds
      • Always consider cerebral hypoperfusion→ seizure as a secondary phenomenon(Etiology: cardiovascular syncope→ transient hypoperfusion as the real culprit)

      Non-seizure events

      • Anxiety/panic d/o
      • Psychiatric d/o→ pseudo-seizure
      • TIA/stroke→ transient or persistent loss of fxn
      • Cardiogenic syncope- see under LOC→ cardiovascular causes
      • Migraine HA

      Numbness?

      Sensory exam

      Numbness can occur with or without neuropathic-type pain (pins and needles sensation, burning, electric shock, tingling)

      Upper Extremities

      PNS Compress/Inj

      • Cervical nerve root compression (Etiology: Osteophytes→ narrowing neuroforamina; Disc herniation; Other: fracture, infection, cancer; Sx: acute if disc herniation or trauma; more typically sub-acute and chronic, pain radiates from neck down arm in accordance w/distribution of nerve, sx wax and wane, C7 and C6 roots most commonly affected)
          • Due to anatomic variability, the descriptions below will not hold for all patients
        • C5 (Sx: pain radiates to medial scapula, lateral upper arm; PE: if weakness→ deltoid, supraspinatus, infraspinatus→ shoulder abduction, external rotation; if numbness→ lateral upper arm; if reflexes affected→ brachioradialis, biceps)
        • C6 (Sx: pain radiates lateral forearm, thumb, index finger; PE: if weakness→ biceps & brachioradialis→ elbow flexion and suppination; wrist extension; if numbness→ thumb & index finger; if reflexes affected→ brachioradialis, biceps)
        • C7 (Sx: pain radiates to medial scapula, back of arm & forearm, 3rd finger; PE: if weakness→ triceps→ elbow extension, wrist flexion, finger extension; if numbness→ posterior forearm, 3rd finger; if reflex affected→ triceps)
        • C8 (Sx: pain radiates to shoulder, ulnar side of forearm, 5th finger; PE: if weakness→ thumb flexion, intrinsic muscles of hand; if numbness→ 5th finger)
      • Compression of PN
        • Median nerve compression (carpal tunnel syndrome) (Sx: chronic pain, affects thumb/2nd/3rd and 1/2 4th fingers, worse in AM, patient feels need to "shake out hands" to "improve blood flow," PE: hand exam often normal, pain sometimes provoked by forced wrist flexion, tapping over nerve; diminished 2 point discrimination, weakness and atrophy late findings)
        • Ulnar nerve compression (Sx: chronic pain, which radiate down to 1/2 ring and pinky fingers, often worse at night/in AM; PE: pain reproduced when tap over ulnar groove of elbow → "funny bone" sensation)
        • Radial nerve compression (Etiology: typically associated w/trauma at proximal humerus or prolonged compression in that area→ intoxication and passed out x hours; Sx: numbness in hand and unable to use hand normally; PE: unable to extend at wrist, numbness back of hand)

      PNS Inflam/Autoimmune

      • Amyloid associated (Sx: often painful, symmetric, distal upper or lower extremities, spreads relatively rapidly, can present w/carpal tunnel, autonomic dysfxn)
      • Celiac disease (Sx: chronic GI bloating, diarrhea, wt loss, neuropathy often painful, sometimes joint inflammation)
      • CIDP (Sx: symptom onset over 2m, painless, symmetrically decreased sensation, also proximal and distal weakness, upper or lower extremities - or both)
      • Cryogloblulinemia (Etiology: medium-vessel vasculitis caused by antigen-antibody complex deposition; Type I monoclonal→ IgM or IgG, related to lymphoprolif d/o→ lymphoma, myeloma; Type II and III, mixed cryos IgM and IgG; related to Hep C (most common), SLE, RA, lymphoma, myeloma, hiv, hep b, other autoimmune; RFs: female > male, ages 40-50; Sx: subacute fatigue, weakness, muscle and joint aches, cough/sob if pulmonary involvement; confusion; symmetric or asymmetric often painful distal neuropathy, painful skin ulcers of extremities, purpuric papules; membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis; PE: palpable purpura of vasculitis, Raynauds, livedo reticularis, distal skin ulcers)
      • Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss) (Etiology: idiopathic d/o, small-to-medium vessel vasculitis; w/high levels circulating and tissue invasive eosinophils; Rfs: men=women, assoc also w/leukotriene antagonists; Sx: progressive, adult onset asthma, cough & wheezing, nasal stuffiness→ w/resp sx usually ~2-10 y prior to systemic sx assoc w/eosinophilic deposition in target organs and vasculitis; in these later phases→ systemic sx including: sob from parenchymal lung involvement; f, c, muscle aches; hematuria from renal involvement; heart failure, pericarditis and dysrhythmia w/cardiac involvement; peripheral neuropathy; PE: wheezing, skin findings of vasculitis: small, palapable purpura, don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; hematuria/renal involvement; unexplained peripheral neuropathy)
      • Granulomatosis with poyangiitis (Wegeners) (Etiology: small-to-medium vessel vasculitis; Sx: vasculitis→ recurrent/progressive nasal congestion, cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; peripheral nerve dysfxn; PE: mucosal erythema, ulcer, nasal septum perf, unexplained peripheral neuropathy)
      • Guillain Barre (AIDP) (Etiology: autoimmune, though often infxn ~2w prior→ campylobacter, resp, other; Sx: numbness/tingling legs and hands; most prominent feature is weakness that's acute, progressive over hours-to-days, symmetric, w/an ascending pattern of involvement; often autonomic dysfxn→ tachy or brady, orthostasis, diaphoresis; PE: distal weakness, distal sensory impairment, diminished or absent reflexes)
      • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
      • Microscopic polyangitis (MPA) (Etiology: small-vessel vasculitis; Sx: fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, sweats, wt loss; recurrent/progressive cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; less often nasal sx c/w GPA; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; skin ulcers; neuropathy; PE: palpable purpura, skin ulcer/necrosis)
      • Mononeuritis Multiplex (Etiology: occurs secondary to an underlying problem - DM, vasculitis, etc; Sx: abrupt onset, asymmetric, affects isolated peripheral nerves, motor and sensory symptoms)
      • PAN (Rfs: 40s-50s, men>women, hep B/C; Sx: subacute over mos f, s, malaise, wt loss, muscle/joint pain; multiple systems: arthritis, glomerulonephritis, peripheral nerve pain/dysfxn, skin w/ulcers, purpura; abd pain, blood per rectum)
      • RA (Rfs: women > men; age 30-55; Sx: subacute (>6w), persistent/progressive joint pain, worse in AM due to gelling→ improves w/use, fatigue, tendency for bilateral involvement, commonly small and medium sized joints; nerve symptoms can be motor, sensory or from compression; PE: warmth, redness, spongy feeling from synovial inflam, pain w/squeezing of joints, effusion, abnormal appearing if longstanding, MCPs with chronic changes; extra articular findings: episcleritis, pleural/pericardial inflam, rheumatoid nodules) more from CDC
      • Sarcoid (Etiology: idiopathic systemic illness; Rfs: age usually <40, blacks >> other racial groups; Sx: recurrent/progressive cough, fever, fatigue, sob, wt loss, wheezing, joint pain, neuro sx, eye and skin complaints, chf from infiltrative cardiac dz, syncope/sudden death; often delays in dx as rx for asthma/other; PE: wheezing, other systemic findings including: uveitis, arthritis, erythema nodosum, purplish-skin plaques/nodules on face, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, CN7 palsey, CNS involvement, adnopathy, other organ infiltration)
      • Sjogrens/SICCA (Rfs: women>>men; age typically >50; Sx: dry eyes and mouth; can affect multiple systems, including painful periph neuropathy)

      PNS Meds/Tox/Met

      PNS dyxn can be related to medications, toxins, nutritional defic and metabolic disorders
      • Meds (Etiology: Chemotherapeutic agents: in particular those containing taxane and platin→ painful; INH & others)
      • Arsenic (Etiology: ingestion of contaminated water→ India, or poisoning; Sx: painful neuropathy, n, v, d, abd pain, confusion)
      • Lead (Etiology: lead based paints or other chronic unintentional ingestions; Sx: abd pain, nausea, constipation, anemia, muscle and joint pain, confusion and cognitive problems, altered sense of tasted, peripheral motor and sensory neuropathy)
      • ETOH (Etiology: long hx etoh abuse; Sx: distal sensory and motor impairment, can be painful)
      • Hypocalcemia (Etiology: usually patients s/p parathyroid or thyroid surgery; Sx: numbness/tingling peri-oral or upper extremities)
      • Hypothyroidism (Sx: wt gain, edema, dry skin, constipation, cold intolerance, depression/mood change, weakness, fatigue, neuropathic pain or decreased sensation, carpal tunnel sx; PE: often no findings aside from wt gain, sometimes decreased reflexes, edema, bradycardia)
      • Hyperthyroidism (Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, wt loss, weakness, decreased distal sensation; PE: sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid, hyper-reflexia)
      • Niacin deificiency (Etiology: nutritional deficiency; Sx: chronic, prgressive, symmetric, erythematous erruption, puritic, can resemble sunburn, often V-area of neck, skin is often dry & rough appearing; diarrhea; irritability, anxiety, delusions, apathy; symmetric, painful peripheral sensory and motor neuropathy, arms and legs)
      • B12 (Etiology: pernicious anemia, s/p gastrectomy, crohn's dz, rarely diet related; Sx: progressive, legs more common then arms, can be painful, impaired dorsal columns function, gait problems, tongue can be smooth and swollen if severe, s/s anemia if severe, rarely confusion)

      PNS Infxn

      • HIV assoc (Sx: often painful, known HIV disease) more from CDC
      • M Leprae (Etiology: spread via resp droplets; Rfs: Southeast Asia; Sx/PE: anesthetic macule, area of involvement spreads, direct nerve involvement, neuropathic pain and enlargement of involved nerve, weakness, nasal deformity & stuffiness, skin ulcers on feet as cant feel injuries) more from CDC

      PNS Malig

      • Paraneoplastic associated (Etiology: predilection for small cell lung or breast cancer; also lymphoma, myeloma, MGUS; Sx: neuropathy is often painful, can have unsteady gait and un-coordination)
      • POEMS (poly-neurop, organomeg, endocrinop, mono-clonal gammop, skin changes) (Etiology: idiopathic; Sx: progressive over mos, distal numbness, weakness distal>proximal, fatigue, skin probs, volume overload; major features are neuro mono-clonal gammop; others not always present; PE: decreased distal sensation, diminished reflexes, splenmegaly, hepatomegaly, edema, adenopathy, skin changes; not all present)

      CNS D/O

      Rigidity, hyper-reflexia, other UMN findings; sesnory or other localizing sx & findings
    • Brain: infection or inflammatory process
      • Encephalitis (Etiology: inflammation of diffuse or specifc areas of brain parenchyma; Sx: tend to have focal neuro deficits as compared w/meningitis; acute onset of headache, fever, confusion, irritability, motor and sensory impairment, altered speech; can also have meningoencephalitis)
        • Viral (most common) (Organisms: enteroviruses,, HSV, VZV, EBV, influenza, west nile, other arboviruses (transmitted by mosquitoes); and other viruses w/prevalence varying by season, region of the world)
        • Other uncommon infections (Organisms: Tick borne→ lyme; rabies, fungal, and mycobacteria)
        • Non-infectious (Etiology: collagen vascular disease, para-neoplastic, post infectious, post vaccination)
        • Autoimmune encephalitis (Etiology: antibody mediated→ multiple including anti-nmda; also paraneoplastic; Rfs: women, < 30, teratoma; Sx: acute change in personality, decline in functional status, agitation, confusion, bizarre behavior, autonomic instability, seizures, unusual movements, seziures, other neuro deficits)
        • ADEM (acute demyelinating encephalomyelitis) (Etiology: autoimmune d/o, often triggered by an infection→ URI, EBV; post vaccination, other; dx of exclusion; RFs: overall uncommon, though kids>>adults; Sx: acute, progressive, ha, f, confusion, weakness, ataxia, focal deficits; PE: f, focal deficits, patchy UMN and sensory findings)
      • Bacterial abscess (Etiology: reason for abscess → spread from adjacent site→ dental or sinuses, AVM, PFO, neurosurgery; Sx: acute/subacute, headache, fever, loss of function based on location, progressive, delirium)
      • Mycobacterial abscess (Rfs: known TB elsewhere, immuncompromised, otherwise exposed; Sx: subacute f, chills, ha, fatigue, stiff neck, delirium, loss of function based on location)
      • Fungal abscess (Rfs: often assoc w/compromised states → hiv, cancer, DM; systemic or from local spread; Sx: subacute, fever, feeling poorly in general, sub-acute headache & neck pain, delirium, deficits based on location)
      • Parasitic - Cysticercosis (T Solium - tapeworm) (Etiology: ingest eggs via infected beef that's undercooked; Mexico, Africa, Southeast Asia; eggs cross intestines, migrate to host muscles and brain; Sx:headache, seizures, otherwise unexplained muscles aches)
      • Parasitic - Toxoplasmosis (Rfs: HIV + w/CD4 < 200; Sx: sub-acute, headache, confusion, fever, focal neruo deficits based on location)
    • Brain: vascular process/lesion
      • Stroke (Sx: acute, focal deficits, known vascular dz risk factors)
      • Aneurysm (Sx: acute headache if leaking, other localizing sx if pushes on a nearby structure, when leaks/ruptures → sub-acrachnoid bleed)
      • AVM (Sx: acute or sub-acute, loss of function based on location, can have abrupt change if superimposed bleeding)
      • Parenchymal bleeding (Etiology: trauma, amyloid angiopathy, htn; Sx: acute, loss of function→ based on location)
    • Brain Tumor
      • Benign tumor (Etiology: meningioma, other; Sx: sub-acute, loss of function based on location, confusion/change in personality, headache)
      • Cancer - primary brain (Etiology: glioblastoma, astrocytoma, lymphoma, other; Sx: acute or subacute; headache, deficits, changes in personality, etc based on location)
      • Cancer - metastatic (Etiology: predileciton for cns met→ lung, breast, renal, melanoma; Sx: may have sx from primary site; neuro sx can be acute or subacute; headache, deficits, changes in personality, etc based on location)
    • Brain: other
      • Congenital or degenerative d/o
      • Radiation necrosis if prior xrt to head region
    • Spinal Cord: Cervical
        • Sx: weakness and numbness, typically bilateral UE, at or below level compression, problems w/fine movements/coordination, weakness and numbness LE, PE: wide based and stiff legged gait, spasticity and hyper-reflexia of affected limbs, bowel/bladder are late sx.
      • Disc herniation (Sx: acute, sub-acute or chronic; can be superimposed on congenital spinal stenosis or OA)
      • Spinal stenosis from OA, congenital or combined; sx typically slowly progressive
      • Inflammatory: arthritis→ RA, post XRT
      • Fracture/trauma→ acute sx w/antecedent event
      • Tumor→ acute/subacute, known tumor w/met potential, sx that localize to primary tumor, f, wt loss
      • Infection: osteomyelitis/discitis (Rfs: compromised host, ivdu, dm, esrd, etc; Sx: acute, subacute, or chronic, progressive pain, fever; pain over affected area of cervical spine; spread can lead to epidural abscess; PE: may have pain over cervical vertebrae, neuro deficits if cord or roots compromised)
        • Bacterial (Etiology: Staph most common; then e coli; can be the result of hematogenous seeding from bacteremia/endocarditis; or direct extension from superficial skin process, instrumentation/surgery, foley catheter/uti)
        • Mycobacterial (Etiology/Rfs: complication of systemic TB, often compromised host, sometimes known TB elsewhere; Sx: sub-acute/chronic cervical spine pain, f, c, sx related to tb elsewhere→ lungs, GI)
        • Fungal (Etiology: aspergillous, cocci, other; Rfs: compromised host or complication of an injection; Sx: subacute pain, f)
      • Infection: epidural abscess (Rfs: often compromised from dm, etoh, ivdu, other; Etiology: hematogenous seeding from systemic bacteremia, as w/endocarditis; or direct extension from adjacent osteomyelitis/discitis, instrumentation/surgery; Sx: progressive acute/subacute pain, fever, neuro compromise→ upper and lower extremity numbness or neuropathic pain; extremity weakness to paralysis, bowel/bladder incontinence)
        • Bacterial (Etiology: Staph most common; then e coli; can be the result of hematogenous seeding from bacteremia/endocarditis; or direct extension from superficial skin process, instrumentation/surgery, foley catheter/uti)
        • Mycobacterial (Etiology/Rfs: complication of systemic TB, often compromised host, sometimes known TB elsewhere; Sx: sub-acute/chronic progressive lbp, f, c, numbness, weakness, bowel/bladder sx)
        • Fungal (Etiology: aspergillous, cocci, other; Rfs: compromised host or complication of an injection; Sx: subacute, progressive pain, numbness, weakness, bowel/bladder sx)
      • Transverse myelitis (Etiology: acute inflammation affecting cord, viral, autoimmune or idiopathic. Peak ages 10-20 & 30-40; Sx: bilateral impaired sensory & motor function below affected level, bowel & bladder dysfxn, sometimes back pain, onset over hours to days)
      • Retroviral - HTLV 1 (Rfs: spread sexually, vertically, via transfusion; most prevalent in Caribbean, Central/South America, Japan; Sx: most are asx, no problems w/opportunistic infxn like HIV; Long term risks include: T-cell leukemia-lymphoma; PE: spastic paraparesis/myelopathy→ unremitting, progressive neuro syndrome characterized by lower extrem weakness, spasticity, hyper-reflexia, gait probs, incontinence, neruopathic pain; no cognitive or cranial nerve involvement)
      • Retroviral - HIV (Rfs: Known HIV or rfs for this dz, advanced/end stage; Sx: slow progressive causes myelopathy w/weakness, numbness and urinary dysfxn related to region of cord affected)
      • Syphillis (Rfs: known stis, hiv rfs; Sx: assoc w/later stage syphilis→ slowly progressive weakness, numbness, neuropathic pain, tingling, balance probs)
      • Other congenital or acquired
    • Processes affecting brain & cord
      • Multiple sclerosis (Rfs: demographics: white>black, women>men, age onset <30; Sx: affects spinal cord and brain, sub-acute, waxes/wanes, progresses over year/decades, patchy sensory and motor deficits that can affect any of the neuro pathways and don't follow an anatomic pattern, visual disturbances)

      Lower Extremities

      PNS Compress/Inj

      • Compression of Lumbar/Sacral nerve roots (Etiology: osteophyte, disc or both narrowing neuroforamina; typically L5 or S1; Sx: acute if disc herniation or trauma; more typically sub-acute and chronic, pain radiates from low back down leg in accordance w/distribution of nerve, sx wax and wane)
      • Spinal stenosis (Etiology: osteophytes, ligament hypertrophy, disc or combinations; Sx: slowly progressive, worse standing, radiates down B legs w/walking, feels better if walk while leaning forward→ e.g. while pushing a shopping cart)
      • Cauda equina (Etiology: occurs secondary to compression from tumor, disc, oa, infection or combinations; Sx: acute/sub-acute pain, bowel and/or bladder incontinence; PE: saddle distribution numbness; weakness and numbness of legs, decreased/absent rectal tone, hihg post void residual)
      • Compression or other dysfunction of PN
        • Tarsal tunnel (Sx: burning/tingling, bottom of foot, worse w/wt bearing)
        • Morton's neuroma (Sx: numbness that extends from ball of foot to one or few toes)
        • Lateral cutaneous nerve (Etiology: compression of nerve assoc w/obesity; Sx: numb patch lateral thigh)

      PNS Inflam/Autoimmune

      • Amyloid associated (Sx: often painful, symmetric, distal upper or lower extremities, spreads relatively rapidly, can present w/carpal tunnel, autonomic dysfxn)
      • Celiac disease (Sx: chronic GI bloating, diarrhea, wt loss, neuropathy often painful, sometimes joint inflammation)
      • Charcot-Marie-Tooth (Rfs: fam hx→ autosomal recessive; Sx: slowly progressive (years) of neuropathic pain, numbness and weakness, distal legs first; PE: muscle wasting, impaired sensation and loss of reflexes on exam)
      • CIDP (Sx: symptom onset over 2m, painless, symmetrically decreased sensation, also proximal and distal weakness, upper or lower extremities - or both)
      • Cryogloblulinemia (Etiology: medium-vessel vasculitis caused by antigen-antibody complex deposition; Type I monoclonal→ IgM or IgG, related to lymphoprolif d/o→ lymphoma, myeloma; Type II and III, mixed cryos IgM and IgG; related to Hep C (most common), SLE, RA, lymphoma, myeloma, hiv, hep b, other autoimmune; RFs: female > male, ages 40-50; Sx: subacute fatigue, weakness, muscle and joint aches, cough/sob if pulmonary involvement; confusion; symmetric or asymmetric often painful distal neuropathy, painful skin ulcers of extremities, purpuric papules; membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis; PE: palpable purpura of vasculitis, Raynauds, livedo reticularis, distal skin ulcers)
      • Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss) (Etiology: idiopathic d/o, small-to-medium vessel vasculitis; w/high levels circulating and tissue invasive eosinophils; Rfs: men=women, assoc also w/leukotriene antagonists; Sx: progressive, adult onset asthma, cough & wheezing, nasal stuffiness→ w/resp sx usually ~2-10 y prior to systemic sx assoc w/eosinophilic deposition in target organs and vasculitis; in these later phases→ systemic sx including: sob from parenchymal lung involvement; f, c, muscle aches; hematuria from renal involvement; heart failure, pericarditis and dysrhythmia w/cardiac involvement; peripheral neuropathy; PE: wheezing, skin findings of vasculitis: small, palapable purpura, don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; hematuria/renal involvement; unexplained peripheral neuropathy)
      • Granulomatosis with poyangiitis (Wegeners) (Etiology: small-to-medium vessel vasculitis; Sx: vasculitis→ recurrent/progressive nasal congestion, cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; peripheral nerve dysfxn; PE: mucosal erythema, ulcer, nasal septum perf, unexplained peripheral neuropathy)
      • Guillain Barre (AIDP) (Etiology: autoimmune, though often infxn ~2w prior→ campylobacter, resp, other; Sx: numbness/tingling legs and hands; most prominent feature is weakness that's acute, progressive over hours-to-days, symmetric, w/an ascending pattern of involvement; often autonomic dysfxn→ tachy or brady, orthostasis, diaphoresis; PE: distal weakness, distal sensory impairment, diminished or absent reflexes)
      • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
      • Microscopic polyangitis (MPA) (Etiology: small-vessel vasculitis; Sx: fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, sweats, wt loss; recurrent/progressive cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; less often nasal sx c/w GPA; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; skin ulcers; neuropathy; PE: palpable purpura, skin ulcer/necrosis)
      • Mononeuritis Multiplex (Etiology: occurs secondary to an underlying problem - DM, vasculitis, etc; Sx: abrupt onset, asymmetric, affects isolated peripheral nerves, motor and sensory symptoms)
      • PAN (Rfs: 40s-50s, men>women, Hep B; Sx: subacute over mos f, s, malaise, wt loss, muscle/joint pain; multiple systems: arthritis, glomerulonephritis, peripheral nerve pain/dysfxn, skin w/ulcers, purpura; abd pain, blood per rectum)
      • RA (Rfs: women > men; age 30-55; Sx: subacute (>6w), persistent/progressive joint pain, worse in AM due to gelling→ improves w/use, fatigue, tendency for bilateral involvement, commonly small and medium sized joints; nerve symptoms can be motor, sensory or from compression; PE: warmth, redness, spongy feeling from synovial inflam, pain w/squeezing of joints, effusion, abnormal appearing if longstanding, MCPs with chronic changes; extra articular findings: episcleritis, pleural/pericardial inflam, rheumatoid nodules) more from CDC
      • Sarcoid (Etiology: idiopathic systemic illness; Rfs: age usually <40, blacks >> other racial groups; Sx: recurrent/progressive cough, fever, fatigue, sob, wt loss, wheezing, joint pain, neuro sx, eye and skin complaints, chf from infiltrative cardiac dz, syncope/sudden death; often delays in dx as rx for asthma/other; PE: wheezing, other systemic findings including: uveitis, arthritis, erythema nodosum, purplish-skin plaques/nodules on face, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, CN7 palsey, PNS & CNS involvement, adnopathy, other organ infiltration)
      • Sjogrens/SICCA (Rfs: women>>men; age typically >50, dry eyes and mouth; can affect multiple systems, including painful periph neuropathy)

      PNS Meds/Tox/Met

      PNS dysfxn can be related to meds, toxins, nutritional defic, and metabolic d/o
      • Meds (Chemotherapeutic agents: in particular those containing taxane and platin, painful; INH)
      • Toxin induced
        • Arsenic (Etiology: ingestion of contaminated water→ India, or poisoning; Sx: painful neuropathy, n, v, d, abd pain, confusion)
        • Lead (Etiology: lead based paints or other chronic unintentional ingestions; Sx: abd pain, nausea, constipation, anemia, muscle and joint pain, confusion and cognitive problems, altered sense of tasted, peripheral motor and sensory neuropathy)
        • ETOH (Etiology: long hx etoh abuse; Sx: distal sensory and motor impairment, can be painful)
        • Niacin deificiency (Etiology: nutritional deficiency; Sx: chronic, prgressive, symmetric, erythematous erruption, puritic, can resemble sunburn, often V-area of neck, skin is often dry & rough appearing; diarrhea; irritability, anxiety, delusions, apathy; symmetric, painful peripheral sensory and motor neuropathy, arms and legs)
      • Metabolic D/O
        • DM (Etiology: common, hx poorly controlled DM; Sx: stocking glove ascending loss of sensation, may have autonomic dysfxn, can be painful or painless, loss of reflexes, affects dorsal columns and spinothalamics→ absent proprioception)
        • Renal failure (Etiology: advanced renal disease; Sx: often w/pain, symmetric and affects distal lower extremities first→ moving proximal over time, improves w/dialysis and/or transplant)
        • Hypothyroidism (Sx: wt gain, edema, dry skin, constipation, cold intolerance, depression/mood change, weakness, fatigue, neuropathic pain or decreased sensation, carpal tunnel sx; PE: often no findings aside from wt gain, sometimes decreased reflexes, edema, bradycardia)
        • Hyperthyroidism (Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, wt loss, weakness, decreased distal sensation; PE: sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid, hyper-reflexia)
      • B12 (Etiology: pernicious anemia, s/p gastrectomy, crohn's dz, rarely diet related; Sx: progressive, legs more common then arms, can be painful, impaired dorsal columns function, gait problems, tongue can be smooth and swollen if severe, s/s anemia if severe, rarely confusion)

      PNS: Infection

      • HIV assoc (Sx: often painful, known HIV disease) more from CDC
      • Leprosy (Sx: painful, slowly progressive, exposure to an endemic area→ Asia, Africa, South America; PE: hypo-pigmented patches of skin w/sensory loss, asymmetric, upper or lower extremities) more from CDC

      PNS: Malignancy Related

      • Paraneoplastic associated (Etiology: predilection for small cell lung or breast cancer; also lymphoma, myeloma, MGUS; Sx: neuropathy is often painful, can have unsteady gait and un-coordination)
      • POEMS (poly-neurop, organomeg, endocrinop, mono-clonal gammop, skin changes) (Etiology: idiopathic; Sx: progressive over mos, distal numbness, weakness distal>proximal, fatigue, skin probs, volume overload; major features are neuro mono-clonal gammop; others not always present; PE: decreased distal sensation, diminished reflexes, splenmegaly, hepatomegaly, edema, adenopathy, skin changes; not all present)

      CNS D/O

      Rigidity, hyper-reflexia, other UMN findings; sesnory or other localizing sx & findings
    • Brain: infection or inflammatory process
      • Encephalitis (Etiology: inflammation of diffuse or specifc areas of brain parenchyma; Sx: tend to have focal neuro deficits as compared w/meningitis; acute onset of headache, fever, confusion, irritability, motor and sensory impairment, altered speech)
        • Viral (most common) (Organisms: enteroviruses,, HSV, VZV, EBV, influenza, west nile, other arboviruses (transmitted by mosquitoes); and other viruses w/prevalence varying by season, region of the world)
        • Other uncommon infections (Organisms: Tick borne→ lyme; rabies, and mycobacteria)
        • Non-infectious (Etiology: collagen vascular disease, para-neoplastic, post infectious, post vaccination)
        • ADEM (acute demyelinating encephalomyelitis) (Etiology: autoimmune d/o, often triggered by an infection→ URI, EBV; post vaccination, other; dx of exclusion; RFs: overall uncommon, though kids>>adults; Sx: acute, progressive, ha, f, confusion, weakness, ataxia, focal deficits; PE: f, focal deficits, patchy UMN and sensory findings)
      • Abscess (Etiology: reason for abscess include spread from adjacent site→ sinuses, teeth; AVM, PFO, neurosurgery; Sx: acute/subacute, progressive, delirium, headache, fever, focal loss of neuro function based on location; can also have meningoencephalitis)
    • Brain: vascular process/lesion
      • Stroke (Sx: acute, focal deficits, known vascular dz risk factors)
      • Aneurysm (Sx: acute headache if leaking, other localizing sx if pushes on a nearby structure, when leaks/ruptures → sub-acrachnoid bleed)
      • AVM (Sx: acute or sub-acute, loss of function based on location, can have abrupt change if superimposed bleeding)
      • Parenchymal bleeding(Etiology: trauma, amyloid angiopathy, htn; Sx: acute, loss of function→ based on location)
    • Brain: tumor
      • Benign tumor (Etiology: meningioma, other; Sx: sub-acute, loss of function based on location, confusion/change in personality, headache)
      • Malignant tumor: Primary brain tumor(Sx: sub-acute, loss of function based on location, confusion/change in personality, headache; abrupt worsening if bleeding superimposed)
      • Malignant tumor: Metastatic to brain (Rfs: known primary w/tendency to met to brain → renal cell, breast, melanoma, lung; Sx: sub-acute, loss of function based on location, confusion/change in personality, headache; abrupt worsening if bleeding superimposed)
    • Brain: other
      • Congenital or degenerative d/o
      • Radiation necrosis if prior xrt to head region
    • Spinal Cord: Cervical
        • Sx: weakness and numbness, typically bilateral UE, at or below level compression, problems w/fine movements/coordination, weakness and numbness LE, PE: wide based and stiff legged gait, spasticity and hyper-reflexia of affected limbs, bowel/bladder are late sx.
      • Disc herniation (acute, sub-acute or chronic; can be superimposed on congential spinal stenosis or OA
      • Spinal stenosis from OA, congenital or combined; sx typically slowly prgressive
      • Inflammatory: arthritis→ RA, post XRT
      • Fracture/trauma→ acute sx w/antecedent event
      • Tumor→ acute/subacute, known tumor w/met potential, sx that localize to primary tumor, f, c, wt loss
      • Infection: osteomyelitis/discitis (Rfs: compromised host, ivdu, dm, esrd, etc; Sx: acute, subacute, or chronic, progressive pain, fever; pain over affected area of cervical spine; spread can lead to epidural abscess; PE: may have pain over cervical vertebrae, neuro deficits if cord or roots compromised)
        • Bacterial (Etiology: Staph most common; then e coli; can be the result of hematogenous seeding from bacteremia/endocarditis; or direct extension from superficial skin process, instrumentation/surgery, foley catheter/uti)
        • Mycobacterial (Etiology/Rfs: complication of systemic TB, often compromised host, sometimes known TB elsewhere; Sx: sub-acute/chronic cervical spine pain, f, c, sx related to tb elsewhere→ lungs, GI)
        • Fungal (Etiology: aspergillous, cocci, other; Rfs: compromised host or complication of an injection; Sx: subacute pain, f)
      • Infection: epidural abscess (Rfs: often compromised from dm, etoh, ivdu, other; Etiology: hematogenous seeding from systemic bacteremia, as w/endocarditis; or direct extension from adjacent osteomyelitis/discitis, instrumentation/surgery; Sx: progressive acute/subacute pain, fever, neuro compromise→ upper and lower extremity numbness or neuropathic pain; extremity weakness to paralysis, bowel/bladder incontinence)
        • Bacterial (Etiology: Staph most common; then e coli; can be the result of hematogenous seeding from bacteremia/endocarditis; or direct extension from superficial skin process, instrumentation/surgery, foley catheter/uti)
        • Mycobacterial (Etiology/Rfs: complication of systemic TB, often compromised host, sometimes known TB elsewhere; Sx: sub-acute/chronic progressive lbp, f, c, numbness, weakness, bowel/bladder sx)
        • Fungal (Etiology: aspergillous, cocci, other; Rfs: compromised host or complication of an injection; Sx: subacute, progressive pain, numbness, weakness, bowel/bladder sx)
      • Transverse myelitis (Etiology: acute inflammation affecting cord, viral, autoimmune or idiopathic. Peak ages 10-20 & 30-40; Sx: bilateral impaired sensory & motor function below affected level, bowel & bladder dysfxn, sometimes back pain, onset over hours to days)
      • Retroviral - HTLV 1 (Rfs: spread sexually, vertically, via transfusion; most prevalent in Caribbean, Central/South America, Japan; Sx: most are asx, no problems w/opportunistic infxn like HIV; Long term risks include: T-cell leukemia-lymphoma; PE: spastic paraparesis/myelopathy→ unremitting, progressive neuro syndrome characterized by lower extrem weakness, spasticity, hyper-reflexia, gait probs, incontinence, neruopathic pain; no cognitive or cranial nerve involvement)
      • Retroviral - HIV (Rfs: Known HIV or rfs for this dz, advanced/end stage; Sx: slow progressive causes myelopathy w/weakness, numbness and urinary dysfxn related to region of cord affected)
      • Syphillis (Rfs: known stis, hiv rfs; Sx: assoc w/later stage syphillis→ slowly progressive weakness, numbness, neuropathic pain, tingling, balance probs)
      • Other congenital or acquired
    • Spinal Cord: Thoracic
        • Sx: back pain, weakness & numbness, typically bilateral lower extremities; PE: stiff & wide based gait, and hyper-reflexia of affected limbs, bowel and bladder are late sx
      • Disc herniation (Sx: acute, sub-acute or chronic; can be superimposed on congential spinal stenosis or OA
      • Spinal stenosis from OA, congenital or combined; sx typically slowly progressive
      • Inflammatory arthritis→ RA
      • Fracture/trauma→ acute sx w/antecedent event
      • Tumor→ acute/subacute, known tumor w/met potential, sx that localize to primary tumor, f, c, wt loss
      • Infection: osteomyelitis/discitis (Rfs: compromised host, ivdu, dm, esrd, etc; Sx: acute, subacute, or chronic, progressive pain, fever; pain over affected area of thoracic spine; spread can lead to epidural or psoas abscess; PE: may have pain over thoracic vertebrae, neuro deficits if cord or roots compromised)
        • Bacterial (Etiology: Staph most common; then e coli; can be the result of hematogenous seeding from bacteremia/endocarditis; or direct extension from superficial skin process, instrumentation/surgery, foley catheter/uti)
        • Mycobacterial (Etiology/Rfs: complication of systemic TB, often compromised host, sometimes known TB elsewhere; Sx: sub-acute/chronic thoracic spine pain, f, c, sx related to tb elsewhere→ lungs, GI)
        • Fungal (Etiology: aspergillous, cocci, other; Rfs: compromised host or complication of an injection; Sx: subacute pain, f)
      • Infection: epidural abscess (Rfs: often compromised from dm, etoh, ivdu, other; Etiology: hematogenous seeding from systemic bacteremia, as w/endocarditis; or direct extension from adjacent osteomyelitis/discitis, instrumentation/surgery; Sx: progressive acute/subacute pain, fever, neuro compromise→ chest, abd or lower extremity numbness or neuropathic pain; lower extremity weakness to paralysis, bowel/bladder incontinence)
        • Bacterial (Etiology: Staph most common; then e coli; can be the result of hematogenous seeding from bacteremia/endocarditis; or direct extension from superficial skin process, instrumentation/surgery, foley catheter/uti)
        • Mycobacterial (Etiology/Rfs: complication of systemic TB, often compromised host, sometimes known TB elsewhere; Sx: sub-acute/chronic progressive lbp, f, c, numbness, weakness, bowel/bladder sx)
        • Fungal (Etiology: aspergillous, cocci, other; Rfs: compromised host or complication of an injection; Sx: subacute, progressive pain, numbenss, weakness, bowel/bladder sx)
      • Transverse myelitis (Etiology: acute inflammation affecting cord, viral, autoimmune or idiopathic. Peak ages 10-20 & 30-40; Sx: bilateral impaired sensory & motor function below affected level, bowel & bladder dysfxn, sometimes back pain, onset over hours to days)
      • Retroviral - HTLV 1 (Rfs: spread sexually, vertically, via transfusion; most prevalent in Caribbean, Central/South America, Japan; Sx: most are asx, no problems w/opportunistic infxn like HIV; Long term risks include: T-cell leukemia-lymphoma; PE: spastic paraparesis/myelopathy→ unremitting, progressive neuro syndrome characterized by lower extrem weakness, spasticity, hyper-reflexia, gait probs, incontinence, neruopathic pain; no cognitive or cranial nerve involvement)
      • Retroviral - HIV (Rfs: Known HIV or rfs for this dz, advanced/end stage; Sx: slow progressive causes myelopathy w/weakness, numbness and urinary dysfxn related to region of cord affected)
      • Syphilis (Rfs: known stis, hiv rfs; Sx: assoc w/later stage syphillis→ slowly progressive weakness, numbness, neuropathic pain, tingling, balance probs)
      • Other congenital or acquired
    • Spinal Cord: Lumbar
      • Lumbar spinal cord process not common only small amount of cord reaches lumbar region
      • Infection: osteomyelitis/discitis (Rfs: compromised host, ivdu, dm, esrd, etc; Sx: acute, subacute, or chronic, progressive pain, fever; pain over affected area of lumbar spine; spread can lead to epidural or psoas abscess; PE: may have pain over lumbar vertebrae, neuro deficits if cord or roots compromised, thigh sx if spread to psoas/abscess)
        • Bacterial (Etiology: Staph most common; then e coli; can be the result of hematogenous seeding from bacteremia/endocarditis; or direct extension from superficial skin process, instrumentation/surgery, foley catheter/uti)
        • Mycobacterial (Etiology/Rfs: complication of systemic TB, often compromised host, sometimes known TB elsewhere; Sx: sub-acute/chronic thoracic spine pain, f, c, sx related to tb elsewhere→ lungs, GI)
        • Fungal (Etiology: aspergillous, cocci, other; Rfs: compromised host or complication of an injection; Sx: subacute pain, f)
      • Infection: epidural abscess (Rfs: often compromised from dm, etoh, ivdu, other; Etiology: hematogenous seeding from systemic bacteremia, as w/endocarditis; or direct extension from adjacent osteomyelitis/discitis, instrumentation/surgery; Sx: progressive acute/subacute pain, fever, neuro compromise→ lower extremity numbness or neuropathic pain; lower extremity weakness to paralysis, bowel/bladder incontinence)
        • Bacterial (Etiology: Staph most common; then e coli; can be the result of hematogenous seeding from bacteremia/endocarditis; or direct extension from superficial skin process, instrumentation/surgery, foley catheter/uti)
        • Mycobacterial (Etiology/Rfs: complication of systemic TB, often compromised host, sometimes known TB elsewhere; Sx: sub-acute/chronic progressive lbp, f, c, numbness, weakness, bowel/bladder sx)
        • Fungal (Etiology: aspergillous, cocci, other; Rfs: compromised host or complication of an injection; Sx: subacute, progressive pain, numbness, weakness, bowel/bladder sx)
      • Other processes: tumor, fracture, inflammatory, autoimmune, congenital, vascular)
      • Lumbar spine numbness can be from isolated root compression or cauda equina - see under pns causes above
    • Processes affecting brain & cord
      • Multiple sclerosis (Rfs: demographics: white>black, women>men, age onset <30; Sx: affects spinal cord and brain, sub-acute, waxes/wanes, progresses over year/decades, patchy sensory and motor deficits that can affect any of the neuro pathways and don't follow an anatomic pattern, visual disturbances)

      Weakness?

      Motor exam

      Need to define what the patient means by weakness: Generalized fatigue? Tiredness? Loss of muscle strength? stamina? Expected strength given age, sex, size? etc

      Generalized Etiology

      One or combinations of following non-neuro d/o: deconditioning, poor nutrition, anemia, malignancies; chronic advanced medical conditions: chronic liver, kidney, cardiac, pulmonary, infectious dz; endocrine d/o: hypothyroidism, adrenal insuff, low testosterone, hypercalcemia, hypocalcemia, dm, growth hormone excess, etc)

      Muscle Disease

      Progressive, muscle weakness, no numbness, weakness usually is proximal
      • Inflammatory
        • Polymyositis (Etiology: rare, autoimmune; Rfs: female > male, age>20; Sx/PE: symmetrical proximal weakness of arms and legs, develops over weeks to months; neck flexor weakness; no sensory deficits; sometimes pain, though not prominent feature; dysphagia in 1/3; polyarthritis in 45%; PE: symmetric proximal > distal weakness, preserved reflexes)
        • Dermatomyositis (Etiology: autoimmune; Rfs: children and adults, female > male; Sx: weakness that develops over weeks; earliest affected often neck flexors, pectoral muscles, pelvic girdle; can be asymmetric; dysphagia and dysarthria in 1/3; pain not prominent; no sensory deficits, accompanied by rash, proximal; other organ systems affected including cardiac conduction system dz, arthralgias, arthritis, malignancy→ breast, prostate, colon, other; interstitial lung dz; PE: erythematous skin erruption in sun-exposed area, heliotropic rash around eyes→ purplish w/edema, Gottron's papules→ scaly and papular on knuckles, subcutaneous calcifications, progressive weakness, reflexes preserved until late)
        • Inclusion body myositis (Etiology: autoimmune; Rfs: age > 50, male>female; Sx: slowly progressive, weakness w/o pain, no sensory impairment, typically symmetric, distal > proximal, in particular feet and hands, 60% w/dysphagia, 20+% assoc w/connective tissue d/o; PE: progressive weakness, distal > proximal, refelxes diminish w/progression)
      • Metabolic or toxin induced
        • Hypothyroidism (Sx: wt gain, edema, dry skin, constipation, cold intolerance, depression/mood change, weakness, fatigue; PE: often no findings aside from wt gain, sometimes decreased reflexes, edema, bradycardia)
        • Hyperthyroidism (Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, wt loss, weakness, infetility, ED, menstrual irreg; PE: sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid, hyper-reflexia, moist skin)
        • Steroid induced (Rfs/Etiology: rare, typically from long term glucocorticoid use, cushings disease)
        • Statin induced (Sx: vague ache more than weakness; can occur at any time, rarely rhabdo)
        • Etoh induced
        • Periodic paralysis (Rfs: assoc w/hypokalemia, hyperthyroidism, male, Asian, ages 20-40; often precipitated by high carb meals, exercise, stress; also a rare familial form (not assoc w/hyperthyroidism), w/male predominance, onset < 20; Sx: episodic profound weakness, muscles affected often proximal, legs > arms, duration minutes to hours/days, intervals between attacks can be days to weeks to monthconsciousness preserved)
        • Hypocalcemia (Etiology: severe vit d defic, resistance to vit d, low intake calcium, hypoparthyroidism→ post surgical, xrt, idiopathic, other; Sx: weakness, perioral numbness, muscle cramps; PE: muscle irritability; twitching w/tap on facial nerve, hand/wrist spasm w/prolonged inflation bp cuff)
        • Hypercalcemia (Etiology: primary hyperparathyroidism, malignancy; Sx: fractures, renal stones, fatigue, confusion, weakness, abd pain; higher risk for sx w/higher ca2+)
        • Vitamin D deficiency
        • Low phosphorous
        • Storage d/o - very uncommon
      • Muscular dystrophy (Etiology: genetic d/o, may have family hx of similar problems; Sx: highly variable; can present in childhood, w/progressive weakness and wasting; other variants may only cause muscle aches w/activity→ limb-girdle md) more from CDC

      NMJ D/O

      • Myasthenia gravis (Etiol: autoimmune w/ab targeting ACh receptor; Rfs: 20-30 y female predom, 50-70y male; Sx: painless, subacute, progressive; worse w/repetitive movement, end of day; ocular sx→ double vision, eyelid weakness; other cranial nerve palsies; can also cause systemic weakness affecting neck, extremities, other muscles→ asymmetric and prox > distal fashion; PE: no atrophy, reflexes preserved, no sensory findings, ptosis, eye muscle weakness, weakness in other muscles→ worse w/use)
      • Lambert Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) (Etiology: auto-antibody against presynaptic side of nmj; Rfs: male>female, rare, 50% assoc w/malignancy→ in particular lung; can also occur w/other autoimmune dz→ thyroid, RA, vasculitis, other; age ~60 if cancer, 30s & 60s if no malignancy; Sx: progressive weakness over mos, fatigue, proximal muscles > distal, progresses caudal to cranial, eye & facial muscles not typically affected, autonomic dysfxn→ dry mouth, constipation, orthostatic lightheadedness, etc.; no numbness; PE: proximal weakness, diminished or absent reflexes)
      • Botulism (Rfs: exposure to at risk food; exposure to black tar heroin; Sx: acute onset→ 8-36h, difficulty swallowing secretions, difficulty breathing or speaking, double vision, abdominal cramps, weakness/paralysis starts w/CNs→ spreads symmetrically to limbs, afebrile)
      • Organophosphate poisoning (Etiology: accidental, intentional or as biological weapon→ Sarin; inhibits cholinesterase; Sx: related to ach excess→ acute confusion, lacrimation, excessive resp secretions, brady, weakness, wheezing)

      PNS Compress/Inj

      Weakness is usually distal
      • Cervical nerve root compression (Etiology: osteophytes→ narrowing neuroforamina; disc herniation; other: fracture, infection, cancer; Sx: acute if disc herniation or trauma; more typically sub-acute and chronic, pain radiates from neck down arm in accordance w/distribution of nerve, sx wax and wane, C6 and C7 roots most commonly affected)
      • Compression of Lumbar/Sacral nerve roots (Sx: acute if sudden disc herniation or trauma; more typically sub-acute and chronic, pain radiates from low back down leg in accordance w/distribution of root→ typically L5, S1, sx wax and wane)
        • Osteophytes narrowing NF - typically affect L5 or S1 roots
        • Disc herniation
        • Spinal stenosis (Sx: slowly progressive, worse standing, radiates down B legs w/walking, feels better if walk while leaning forward→ e.g. while pushing a shopping cart)
        • Cauda equina (Etiology: occurs secondary to compression from fracture, disc, infection, cancer→ lung, breast, prostate, thyroid, gi; Sx: acute/sub-acute pain, bowel and/or bladder incontinence; PE: saddle distribution numbness; weakness and numbness of legs, decreased/absent rectal tone, high post void residual)
      • Compression of Specific Peripheral Nerves
        • Upper Extremity
          • Median nerve compression (carpal tunnel syndrome) (Sx: chronic pain, affects thumb/2nd/3rd and 1/2 4th fingers, worse in AM, patient feels need to "shake out hands" to "improve blood flow;" PE: hand exam often normal, pain sometimes provoked by forced wrist flexion, tapping over nerve; diminished 2 point discrimination, weakness and atrophy late findings)
          • Ulnar nerve compression (Sx: chronic pain, which radiate down to 1/2 ring and pinky fingers, often worse at night/in AM; PE: pain reproduced when tap over ulnar goove of elbow → "funny bone" sensation)
          • Radial nerve compression (Etiology: typically associated w/trauma at proximal humerus or prolonged compression in that area → intoxication and passed out x hours; Sx: numbness in hand and unable to use hand normally; PE: unable to extend at wrist, numbness back of hand)
        • Lower Extremity
          • Peroneal nerve (Etiology: compression/injury typically near fibula head; Sx: weak raising foot, problems walking/negotiating steps; numbness dorsum foot, lateral shin; PE: weak in dorsiflexion and eversion; impaired sensation top of foot)

      PNS: Inflam D/O

      Often painful, with motor deficits as well - typically delays in dx as relatively uncommon
      • CIDP (Sx: symptom onset over 2m, painless, symmetrically decreased sensation, also proximal and distal weakness, upper or lower extremities - or both)
      • Charcot-Marie-Tooth (Rfs: fam hx→ autosomal recessive; Sx: slowly progressive (years) of neuropathic pain, numbness and weakness, distal legs first; PE: muscle wasting, impaired sensation and loss of reflexes on exam)
      • Mononeuritis Multiplex (Etiology: occurs secondary to an underlying problem - DM, vasculitis, etc; Sx: abrupt onset, asymmetric, affects isolated peripheral nerves, motor and sensory symptoms)
      • Guillain Barre (AIDP) (Etiology: autoimmune, though often infxn ~2w prior→ campylobacter, resp, other; Sx: numbness/tingling legs and hands; most prominent feature is weakness that's acute, progressive over hours-to-days, symmetric, w/an ascending pattern of involvement; often autonomic dysfxn→ tachy or brady, orthostasis, diaphoresis; PE: distal weakness, distal sensory impairment, diminished or absent reflexes)
      • Celiac disease (Sx: chronic GI bloating, diarrhea, wt loss, neuropathy often painful, sometimes joint inflammation)
      • Amyloid associated (Sx: often painful, symmetric, distal upper or lower extremities, spreads relatively rapidly, can present w/carpal tunnel, autonomic dysfxn)
      • Sarcoid (Etiology: idiopathic systemic illness; Rfs: age usually <40, blacks >> other racial groups; Sx: recurrent/progressive cough, fever, fatigue, sob, wt loss, wheezing, joint pain, neuro sx, eye and skin complaints, chf from infiltrative cardiac dz, syncope/sudden death; often delays in dx as rx for asthma/other; PE: wheezing, other systemic findings including: uveitis, arthritis, erythema nodosum, purplish-skin plaques/nodules on face, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, CN7 palsey, PNS & CNS involvement, adnopathy, other organ infiltration)
      • RA (Rfs: women > men; age 30-55; Sx: subacute (>6w), persistent/progressive joint pain, worse in AM due to gelling→ improves w/use, fatigue, tendency for bilateral involvement, commonly small and medium sized joints; nerve symptoms can be motor, sensory or from compression; PE: warmth, redness, spongy feeling from synovial inflam, pain w/squeezing of joints, effusion, abnormal appearing if longstanding, MCPs with chronic changes; extra articular findings: episcleritis, pleural/pericardial inflam, rheumatoid nodules) more from CDC
      • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
      • Polyarteritis Nodosa (vasculitis) (Etiology: medium-vessel-vasulitis; Rfs: 40s-50s, men>women, Hep B/C; Sx: more commonly subacute over mos f, s, malaise, wt loss, muscle/joint pain; multiple systems: arthritis, glomerulonephritis, peripheral nerve pain/dysfxn, skin w/ulcers, small, palapable purpura→ don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; abd pain, blood per rectum)
      • Sjogrens/SICCA (Rfs: women>>men; age typically >50, dry eyes and mouth; can affect multiple systems, including painful periph neuropathy; other systemic sx include arthralgias, arthritis, cutaneous vasculitis, other)
      • Cryogloblulinemia (Etiology: medium-vessel vasculitis caused by antigen-antibody complex deposition; Type I monoclonal→ IgM or IgG, related to lymphoprolif d/o→ lymphoma, myeloma; Type II and III, mixed cryos IgM and IgG; related to Hep C (most common), SLE, RA, lymphoma, myeloma, hiv, hep b, other autoimmune; RFs: female > male, ages 40-50; Sx: subacute fatigue, weakness, muscle and joint aches, cough/sob if pulmonary involvement; confusion; symmetric or asymmetric often painful distal neuropathy, painful skin ulcers of extremities, purpuric papules; membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis; PE: palpable purpura of vasculitis, Raynauds, livedo reticularis, distal skin ulcers)

      PNS Met/Tox/Meds

    • Metabolic d/o
      • DM (Etiology/Rfs: common, hx poorly controlled DM; Sx/PE: slowly progressive, stocking glove ascending loss of sensation, may have autonomic dysfxn, loss of reflexes, affects dorsal columns and spinothalamics→ absent proprioception, cna be painful or painless)
      • Renal failure (Etiology: advanced renal disease; Sx: often painful neuropathy, symmetric and affects distal lower extremities first-->moving proximal over time, improves w/dialysis and/or transplant)
      • Hypothyroidism (Sx: wt gain, edema, dry skin, constipation, cold intolerance, depression/mood change, weakness, fatigue; PE: often no findings aside from wt gain, sometimes decreased reflexes, edema, bradycardia)
    • Nutritional deficiencies
      • B12 (Etiology: pernicious anemia, s/p gastrectomy, crohn's dz, rarely diet related; Sx: progressive, legs more common then arms, can be painful, impaired dorsal columns function, gait problems, tongue can be smooth and swollen if severe, s/s anemia if severe, rarely confusion)
      • Niacin deificiency (Etiology: nutritional deficiency; Sx: chronic, prgressive, symmetric, erythematous erruption, puritic, can resemble sunburn, often V-area of neck, skin is often dry & rough appearing; diarrhea; irritability, anxiety, delusions, apathy; symmetric, painful peripheral sensory and motor neuropathy, arms and legs)
    • Toxins
      • Arsenic (Etiology: ingestion of contaminated water→ India, or poisoning; Sx: painful neuropathy, n, v, d, abd pain, confusion)
      • Lead (Etiology: lead based paints or other chronic unintentional ingestions; Sx: abd pain, nausea, constipation, anemia, muscle and joint pain, confusion and cognitive problems, altered sense of tasted, peripheral motor and sensory neuropathy)
      • ETOH (Etiology: long hx etoh abuse; Sx: distal sensory and motor impairment, can be painful)
    • Meds
        • Etiology: chemotherapeutic agents→ in particular those containing taxane and platin, painful; INH; many other meds

      PNS: Infection related

      • HIV assoc (Sx: often painful, known HIV disease) more from CDC
      • M Leprae (Etiology: spread via resp droplets; Rfs: Southeast Asia; Sx/PE: anesthetic macule, area of involvement spreads, direct nerve involvement, neuropathic pain and enlargement of involved nerve, weakness, nasal deformity & stuffiness, skin ulcers on feet as cant feel injuries) more from CDC

      PNS Malignancy related

      • Paraneoplastic associated (Etiology: predilection for small cell lung or breast cancer; also lymphoma, myeloma, MGUS; Sx: neuropathy is often painful, can have unsteady gait and un-coordination)
      • POEMS (poly-neurop, organomeg, endocrinop, mono-clonal gammop, skin changes) (Etiology: idiopathic; Sx: progressive over mos, distal numbness, weakness distal>proximal, fatigue, skin probs, volume overload; major features are neuro mono-clonal gammop; others not always present; PE: decreased distal sensation, diminished reflexes, splenmegaly, hepatomegaly, edema, adenopathy, skin changes; not all present)

      CNS D/O

      Rigidity, hyper-reflexia, other UMN findings; sensory or other localizing sx & findings
    • Brain: infection or inflammatory process
      • Encephalitis (Etiology: inflammation of diffuse or specifc areas of brain parenchyma; Sx: tend to have focal neuro deficits as compared w/meningitis; acute onset of headache, fever, confusion, irritability, motor and sensory impairment, altered speech; can also have meningoencephalitis)
        • Viral (most common) (Organisms: enteroviruses,, HSV, VZV, EBV, influenza, west nile, other arboviruses (transmitted by mosquitoes); and other viruses w/prevalence varying by season, region of the world)
        • Other uncommon infections (Organisms: Tick borne→ lyme; rabies, fungal, and mycobacteria)
        • Non-infectious (Etiology: collagen vascular disease, para-neoplastic, post infectious, post vaccination)
        • Autoimmune encephalitis (Etiology: antibody mediated→ multiple including anti-nmda; also paraneoplastic; Rfs: women, < 30, teratoma; Sx: acute change in personality, decline in functional status, agitation, confusion, bizarre behavior, autonomic instability, seizures, unusual movements, seziures, other neuro deficits)
        • ADEM (acute demyelinating encephalomyelitis) (Etiology: autoimmune d/o, often triggered by an infection→ URI, EBV; post vaccination, other; dx of exclusion; RFs: overall uncommon, though kids>>adults; Sx: acute, progressive, ha, f, confusion, weakness, ataxia, focal deficits; PE: f, focal deficits, patchy UMN and sensory findings)
      • Bacterial abscess (Etiology: reason for abscess → spread from adjacent site→ dental or sinuses, AVM, PFO, neurosurgery; Sx: acute/subacute, headache, fever, loss of function based on location, progressive, delirium)
      • Mycobacterial abscess (Rfs: known TB elsewhere, immuncompromised, otherwise exposed; Sx: subacute f, chills, ha, fatigue, stiff neck, delirium, loss of function based on location)
      • Fungal abscess (Rfs: often assoc w/compromised states → hiv, cancer, DM; systemic or from local spread; Sx: subacute, fever, feeling poorly in general, sub-acute headache & neck pain, delirium, deficits based on location)
      • Parasitic - Cysticercosis (T Solium - tapeworm) (Etiology: ingest eggs via infected beef that's undercooked; Mexico, Africa, Southeast Asia; eggs cross intestines, migrate to host muscles and brain; Sx:headache, seizures, otherwise unexplained muscles aches)
      • Parasitic - Toxoplasmosis (Rfs: HIV + w/CD4 < 200; Sx: sub-acute, headache, confusion, fever, focal neruo deficits based on location)
    • Brain: Vascular process/lesion
      • Stroke (Sx: acute, focal deficits, known vascular dz risk factors)
      • Aneurysm (Sx: acute headache if leaking, other localizing sx if pushes on a nearby structure, when leaks/ruptures → sub-arachnoid bleed)
      • AVM (Sx: acute or sub-acute, loss of function based on location, can have abrupt change if superimposed bleeding)
      • Parenchymal bleeding (Etiology: trauma, amyloid angiopathy, htn; Sx: acute, loss of function→ based on location)
    • Brain Tumor
      • Benign tumor (Etilogy: menigioma, other; Sx: sub-acute, loss of function based on location, confusion/change in personality, headache)
      • Malignant tumor: Primary brain tumor (Sx: acute or sub-acute; loss of function based on location, confusion/change in personality, headache)
      • Malignant tumor: Metastatic to brain (Rfs: known primary w/tendency to met to brain → renal cell, breast, melanoma, lung; Sx: acute or sub-acute, loss of function based on location, confusion/change in personality, headache)
    • Brain: other
      • Congenital or degenerative d/o
      • Radiation necrosis if prior xrt to head region
    • Spinal Cord: Cervical
        • General Sx: weakness and numbness in bilateral UE that are at or below level compression, problems w/fine movements/coordination, weakness and numbness LE, PE: wide based and stiff legged gait, spasticity and hyper-reflexia of affected limbs, bowel/bladder are late sx)
      • Disc herniation (Sx: acute, sub-acute or chronic; can be superimposed on congenital spinal stenosis or OA)
      • Spinal stenosis from OA, congenital or combined; sx typically slowly progressive
      • Inflammatory: arthritis→ RA, post XRT
      • Fracture/trauma→ acute sx w/antecedent event
      • Cancer (Etiology: known tumor w/met potential→ prostate, breast, lung, gi tumors, lymphoma & thyroid; Sx: acute/subacute, might localize to primary site of tumor; f, c, wt loss)
      • Infection: osteomyelitis/discitis (Rfs: compromised host, ivdu, dm, esrd, etc; Sx: acute, subacute, or chronic, progressive pain, fever; pain over affected area of cervical spine; spread can lead to epidural abscess; PE: may have pain over cervical vertebrae, neuro deficits if cord or roots compromised)
        • Bacterial (Etiology: Staph most common; then e coli; can be the result of hematogenous seeding from bacteremia/endocarditis; or direct extension from superficial skin process, instrumentation/surgery, foley catheter/uti)
        • Mycobacterial (Etiology/Rfs: complication of systemic TB, often compromised host, sometimes known TB elsewhere; Sx: sub-acute/chronic cervical spine pain, f, c, sx related to tb elsewhere→ lungs, GI)
        • Fungal (Etiology: aspergillous, cocci, other; Rfs: compromised host or complication of an injection; Sx: subacute pain, f)
      • Infection: epidural abscess (Rfs: often compromised from dm, etoh, ivdu, other; Etiology: hematogenous seeding from systemic bacteremia, as w/endocarditis; or direct extension from adjacent osteomyelitis/discitis, instrumentation/surgery; Sx: progressive acute/subacute pain, fever, neuro compromise→ upper and lower extremity numbness or neuropathic pain; extremity weakness to paralysis, bowel/bladder incontinence)
        • Bacterial (Etiology: Staph most common; then e coli; can be the result of hematogenous seeding from bacteremia/endocarditis; or direct extension from superficial skin process, instrumentation/surgery, foley catheter/uti)
        • Mycobacterial (Etiology/Rfs: complication of systemic TB, often compromised host, sometimes known TB elsewhere; Sx: sub-acute/chronic progressive lbp, f, c, numbness, weakness, bowel/bladder sx)
        • Fungal (Etiology: aspergillous, cocci, other; Rfs: compromised host or complication of an injection; Sx: subacute, progressive pain, numbness, weakness, bowel/bladder sx)
      • Transverse myelitis (Etiology: acute inflammation affecting cord, viral, autoimmune or idiopathic. Peak ages 10-20 & 30-40; Sx: bilateral impaired sensory & motor function below affected level, bowel & bladder dysfxn, sometimes back pain, onset over hours to days)
      • Retroviral - HTLV 1 (Rfs: spread sexually, vertically, via transfusion; most prevalent in Caribbean, Central/South America, Japan; Sx: most are asx, no problems w/opportunistic infxn like HIV; Long term risks include: T-cell leukemia-lymphoma; PE: spastic paraparesis/myelopathy→ unremitting, progressive neuro syndrome characterized by lower extrem weakness, spasticity, hyper-reflexia, gait probs, incontinence, neruopathic pain; no cognitive or cranial nerve involvement)
      • Retroviral - HIV (Rfs: Known HIV or rfs for this dz, advanced/end stage; Sx: slow progressive causes myelopathy w/weakness, numbness and urinary dysfxn related to region of cord affected)
      • Syphillis (Rfs: known stis, hiv rfs; Sx: assoc w/later stage syphillis→ slowly progressive weakness, numbness, neuropathic pain, tingling, balance probs)
      • Other congenital or acquired
    • Spinal Cord: Thoracic
        • General Sx: back pain, weakness & numbness bilateral lower extremities; PE: stiff & wide based gait, and hyper-reflexia of affected limbs, bowel and bladder are late sx
      • Posterior disc herniation (Sx: acute, sub-acute or chronic; can be superimposed on congential spinal stenosis or OA
      • Spinal stenosis from OA, congenital or combined; sx typically slowly progressive
      • Inflammatory arthritis→ RA
      • Fracture/trauma→ acute sx w/antecedent event
      • Cancer (Etiology: known tumor w/met potential→ prostate, breast, lung, gi tumors, lymphoma & thyroid; Sx: acute/subacute, might localize to primary site of tumor; f, c, wt loss)
      • Infection: osteomyelitis/discitis (Rfs: compromised host, ivdu, dm, esrd, etc; Sx: acute, subacute, or chronic, progressive pain, fever; pain over affected area of thoracic spine; spread can lead to epidural or psoas abscess; PE: may have pain over thoracic vertebrae, neuro deficits if cord or roots compromised)
        • Bacterial (Etiology: Staph most common; then e coli; can be the result of hematogenous seeding from bacteremia/endocarditis; or direct extension from superficial skin process, instrumentation/surgery, foley catheter/uti)
        • Mycobacterial (Etiology/Rfs: complication of systemic TB, often compromised host, sometimes known TB elsewhere; Sx: sub-acute/chronic thoracic spine pain, f, c, sx related to tb elsewhere→ lungs, GI)
        • Fungal (Etiology: aspergillous, cocci, other; Rfs: compromised host or complication of an injection; Sx: subacute pain, f)
      • Infection: epidural abscess (Rfs: often compromised from dm, etoh, ivdu, other; Etiology: hematogenous seeding from systemic bacteremia, as w/endocarditis; or direct extension from adjacent osteomyelitis/discitis, instrumentation/surgery; Sx: progressive acute/subacute pain, fever, neuro compromise→ chest, abd or lower extremity numbness or neuropathic pain; lower extremity weakness to paralysis, bowel/bladder incontinence)
        • Bacterial (Etiology: Staph most common; then e coli; can be the result of hematogenous seeding from bacteremia/endocarditis; or direct extension from superficial skin process, instrumentation/surgery, foley catheter/uti)
        • Mycobacterial (Etiology/Rfs: complication of systemic TB, often compromised host, sometimes known TB elsewhere; Sx: sub-acute/chronic progressive lbp, f, c, numbness, weakness, bowel/bladder sx)
        • Fungal (Etiology: aspergillous, cocci, other; Rfs: compromised host or complication of an injection; Sx: subacute, progressive pain, numbenss, weakness, bowel/bladder sx)
      • Transverse myelitis (Etiology: acute inflammation affecting cord, viral, autoimmune or idiopathic. Peak ages 10-20 & 30-40; Sx: bilateral impaired sensory & motor function below affected level, bowel & bladder dysfxn, sometimes back pain, onset over hours to days)
      • Retroviral - HTLV 1 (Rfs: spread sexually, vertically, via transfusion; most prevalent in Caribbean, Central/South America, Japan; Sx: most are asx, no problems w/opportunistic infxn like HIV; Long term risks include: T-cell leukemia-lymphoma; PE: spastic paraparesis/myelopathy→ unremitting, progressive neuro syndrome characterized by lower extrem weakness, spasticity, hyper-reflexia, gait probs, incontinence, neruopathic pain; no cognitive or cranial nerve involvement)
      • Retroviral - HIV (Rfs: Known HIV or rfs for this dz, advanced/end stage; Sx: slow progressive causes myelopathy w/weakness, numbness and urinary dysfxn related to region of cord affected)
      • Syphillis (Rfs: known stis, hiv rfs; Sx: assoc w/later stage syphillis→ slowly progressive weakness, numbness, neuropathic pain, tingling, balance probs)
      • Other congenital or acquired cns process afftecting thoracic area
    • Spinal Cord: Lumbar
      • Lumbar spinal cord process not common only small amount of cord reaches lumbar region
      • Infection: osteomyelitis/discitis (Rfs: compromised host, ivdu, dm, esrd, etc; Sx: acute, subacute, or chronic, progressive pain, fever; pain over affected area of lumbar spine; spread can lead to epidural or psoas abscess; PE: may have pain over lumbar vertebrae, neuro deficits if cord or roots compromised, thigh sx if spread to psoas/abscess)
        • Bacterial (Etiology: Staph most common; then e coli; can be the result of hematogenous seeding from bacteremia/endocarditis; or direct extension from superficial skin process, instrumentation/surgery, foley catheter/uti)
        • Mycobacterial (Etiology/Rfs: complication of systemic TB, often compromised host, sometimes known TB elsewhere; Sx: sub-acute/chronic thoracic spine pain, f, c, sx related to tb elsewhere→ lungs, GI)
        • Fungal (Etiology: aspergillous, cocci, other; Rfs: compromised host or complication of an injection; Sx: subacute pain, f)
      • Infection: epidural abscess (Rfs: often compromised from dm, etoh, ivdu, other; Etiology: hematogenous seeding from systemic bacteremia, as w/endocarditis; or direct extension from adjacent osteomyelitis/discitis, instrumentation/surgery; Sx: progressive acute/subacute pain, fever, neuro compromise→ lower extremity numbness or neuropathic pain; lower extremity weakness to paralysis, bowel/bladder incontinence)
        • Bacterial (Etiology: Staph most common; then e coli; can be the result of hematogenous seeding from bacteremia/endocarditis; or direct extension from superficial skin process, instrumentation/surgery, foley catheter/uti)
        • Mycobacterial (Etiology/Rfs: complication of systemic TB, often compromised host, sometimes known TB elsewhere; Sx: sub-acute/chronic progressive lbp, f, c, numbness, weakness, bowel/bladder sx)
        • Fungal (Etiology: aspergillous, cocci, other; Rfs: compromised host or complication of an injection; Sx: subacute, progressive pain, numbness, weakness, bowel/bladder sx)
      • Cancer (Etiology: known tumor w/met potential→ prostate, breast, lung, gi tumors, lymphoma & thyroid; Sx: acute/subacute, might localize to primary site of tumor; f, c, wt loss)
      • Other processes: fracture, discogenic, oa, inflammatory, autoimmune, congenital, vascular
      • Lumbar spine related numbness can be from isolated root compression or cauda equina - see under pns causes above
    • Processes affecting brain & cord
      • Multiple sclerosis (Rfs: demographics: white>black, women>men, age onset <30; Sx: affects spinal cord and brain, sub-acute, waxes/wanes, progresses over year/decades, patchy sensory and motor deficits that can affect any of the neuro pathways and don't follow an anatomic pattern, visual disturbances)

      Mixed CNS and PNS

      • ALS (Rfs: age onset 60s; Sx: progressive over years, upper and lower extremities, fatigue, dysphagia, sob; PE: muscle wasting and fasciculations)

      Other Neuro D/O

      • Parkinson's (Rfs: age > 70; Sx: pill rolling tremor of hands, sometimes head bobbing tremor, difficulty starting and stopping movements, balance and gait problems, sometimes cognitive decline; PE: characteristic pill-rolling tremor, shuffling gait, masked facies, difficulty getting up and starting movement, difficulty turning)

      Dizziness?

      A challenging sx, as patient description often vague. Need to have patient better define what dizziness means to them. 4 broad clinical categories:

      Vertigo

      Sensation of movement when none occurring

      Peripheral causes

      • Labrynthitis/vestibulitis (Etiology: often URI Sx prior; Sx: abrupt, worse w/ any head movement, self limited → lasts a few days)
      • Benign positional vertigo (Etiology: sometimes hx prior trauma; Sx: abrupt onset vertigo, worse w/any head movement→ roll over in bed, assoc n/v, episodes last 10-20 sec, no other neuro Sx, usually remits spontaneously; PE: sx provoked by Dix-Hallpike maneuver, associated rotational nystagmus toward affected side, treated w/canalith repositioning)
      • Meniere's Disease (Sx: tinnitus, waxes and wanes over months/years, vertigo can last hours, unilateral, hearing loss)
      • Acoustic neruoma (Sx: sub-acute, assoc w/unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus)
      • Migraine (Sx: typically assoc w/HA, N/V, aura, sensation flashing lights, lasts hours)
      • Medications (Etiology: many meds can cause vestibular dysfxn→ vertigo; Sx: key point is noting that patient w/vertigo is on a med linked to this problem)

      Central causes

      Less common than peripheral
      • Brain stem ischemia (Rfs: htn, dm, hyperlipidemia, male, smoking; Sx: abrupt onset, other focal neurological c/o in neighborhood → double vision, speech/swallowing probs, facial numbness, n, v, inability to walk)
      • Cerebellar stroke, hemmorhage (Rfs: htn, dm, hyperlipidemia, smoking, male; Sx: abrupt, often severe sx → cant walk, n, v, other focal cerebellar findings)
      • Multiple sclerosis (Rfs: demographics: white>black, women>men, age onset <30; Sx: affects spinal cord and brain, sub-acute, waxes/wanes, progresses over year/decades, patchy sensory and motor deficits that can affect any of the neuro pathways and don't follow an anatomic pattern, visual disturbances)

      Syncope or presyncope

      Challenging ddx, as often unwitnessed. Findings of facial lacerations, fx, other injury suggest true sudden loc - h&p directed toward identifying etiology & any sequelae from the event

      Neuro etiol

      • Neurocardiogenic/Vaso-vagal: inappropriate bradycardia and/or loss of peripheral tone (Rfs: often younger, low risk for c/v dz; Sx: provoked by fear, anxiety, pain prolonged standing, carotid stimulation, urination, cough; feel suddenly sweaty, lightheaded/weak, blurry vision, warm prior to event; tends to recur in similar situations; recovery is usually rapid; sx may also abate if sit and/or lie down)
        • Situational→ assoc w/coughing, urination, defecation, pain, fear/anxiety/stressful events, prolonged standing
        • Cartoid hypersensitivity→ uncommon; sx provoked by pressue on carotid body in neck
      • Orthostatic hypotension from autonomic dysfxn (Etiology: failure to raise HR or peripheral tone w/standing, can be from long standing neuropathy from DM/other metabolic, intrinsic autonomic dz→ Shy-Dragger syndrome; Sx: more likely presyncope than syncope, recurrent/chronic w/positional changes; PE: impaired distal sensation, orthostatic blood pressure changes)
      • Cerebral vascular disease affecting vertebral-basilar system (Etiology: vascular risk factors; Sx: in territory supplied by v-b system: sudden dizziness, double vision, swallowing/speech problems, nausea, vomiting)
      • Seizure d/o (Etiology: more likely if: known seizure d/o, known structural brain dz, Sx: witnessed szr w/post-ictal state, incontinence, tongue biting, injury from not protecting self if fall
      • Acute intracranial process → blood, tumor, trauma

      Cardio etiol

      Cardiogenic syncope has high morbidity/mortality. Increased risk if hx: smoking, diabetes, early family history, male, age >~ 50, HTN, hyperlipidemia. Also increased liklihood if known cad, cardiomyopathy, depressed EF for any reason, vascular dz elsewhere. Findings suggestive of c/v syncope: facial lacerations, fx, other injury suggesting true & sudden LOC→ fall w/o protecting head. These findings suggest sudden decreased cerebral perfusion→ Etiologies of low BP
        Sudden drop in BP→ decrease in cerebral perfusion; BP= COxSVR = HRxSVxSVR = HRxPLxInoxSVR (HR=Heart rate, SV=Stroke Volume, PL=Pre-Load, Ino=Inotropy, SVR=System Vasc Resist)
      Categories of C/V syncope:
    • Decreased Inotropy
      • Severe LV systolic dysfunction (Etiology: CAD w/known MIs, known or newly dx cardiomyopathy; impaired LVs are also the substrate for VT→ see below; PE: lower extremity edema , + S3, elevated jvp, displaced pmi, rales on lung exam)
