      • Aortic stenosis (Etiology: age 30-50→ bicuspid; age >60→ senile calcific; Sx: takes years to become severe→ other sx of doe, sob progressive over years; PE: characteristic systolic murmur, crescendo-decrescendo, later peaking→ more severe)
      • Sub-Aortic Stenosis (Sx: takes years to become severe, typically younger patients PE: characteristic murmur, louder w/less pre-load)
    • Decreased pre-load
      • Hypovolemia for any reason (Etiology: bleeding, diarrhea, severe N/V; Sx provoked by standing, or present at baseline if volume loss severe; PE: eleveated hr, low bp, +orthostatic vital sign changes)
      • Anemia for whatever reason (Etiology: in particular if occurs rapidly as w/blood loss→ hypovolemia)
      • Sudden hypoxemia for whatever reason (Etiology: such that blood reaching brain is O2 poor)
      • Other acute disruption in return of blood to heart (Etiology: tension pneumothroax, acute tamponade, pulmonary embolism, etc→ characteristic hx for each)
    • Bradycardia
        • Sx: fatigue, decrease exercise tolerance, CHF; if abrupt onset, then no antecedent sx
      • Primary conduction system problem → sick sinus syndrome, complete or high grade 2nd or 3rd degree AV nodal block
      • Secondary bradycardia (Etiology/Sx: ischemia→ assoc w/CP, exercise induced, known CAD; meds→ beta blockers, non-dihydro ccbs; hypoxemia for any reason)
    • Supraventricual tachycardia
      • SVT - a fib, a flutter, avnrt, WPW (Sx: rapid/irreg heart beat, palpatations; dont typically cause true syncope but rather light headeness and palpatation; syncope if also impaired LV fxn or hypovolemia)
    • Ventricular tach or V fib
        • Highest risk for morbid/mortality; sudden syncope, often w/injury as cant protect self if fall.
      • Ventricular Tachycardia (VT) - Ischemic (Etiology/Sx: occurs in the setting of MI, assoc w/ischemic sx of chest pain, sob, diaphoresis; patient's w/CAD RFs)
      • VT - Acquired structural heart abnormality (Etiology: in US, most typically from prior MI → depressed LV fxn, could also be from cardiomyopathy of other Etiology→ idiopathic, tox/met, viral, etc)
      • VT - Congenital or other structural heart dz (Etiology: RV dysplasia, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, infiltrative dz → amyloidosis, sarcoid)
      • VT - Congenital or other acquired pre-disposition (Etiology: long QT syndrome → congenital variant presents in younger patients, can have family hx sudden death; acquired long QT assoc w/many meds; also hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypocalcemia, Brugada syndrome, etc)
      • Ventricular fibrillation (Etiology/Sx: abrupt onset; can occur primarily→ w/acute MI or degeneration from VT; leads to death unless immediate defibrillation/cpr; occurs most commonly in those w/predisposition for VT→ see above)
    • Problems of low SVR
        • Problems of low SVR - Sx exacerbated by moving from lying/sitting to standing→ +orthostatic vital sign changes
      • Meds→ alpha blocking agents, other
      • Acquired conditions that lower SVR (sepsis, adrenal insufficiency, other - hx should be suggestive)
      • Anaphylaxis (Etiology: systemic response to a precipitant, including: meds, food, latex, insect bite/stings, other environmental triggers; Sx: acute, sob, doe, ill feeling, syncope/pre-syncope, n, v, abd pain, swelling, itching, angioedema, can be life threatening; PE: ill appearing, low bp/elevated hr, stridor, wheezing, hives, edema and redness of face and/or extremities)
      Recognize that combinations of above can contribute to sudden hypoperfusion - eg. mod AS + sudden volume loss from bleeding→ syncope

      Other

      • Hypoglycemia (Etiology: known DM & Rx w/meds; Sx: sweaty, irritable, resolves w/glucose admin)
      • Drug overdose, e.g. heroin
      • Psychiatric d/o (Etiology: anxiety, panic, somatization - on detailed questioning, may not in fact have had true syncope - or claimed but not witnessed)

      Dysequilibrium

      Off balance sensation w/standing or walking
      • Impaired sensory inputs when walking/standing (Etiology: Deficits in vision, hearing; peripheral neuropathy, arthritis/musculoskeletal d/o, neuro degen d/o; risk increases w/age, often more than one Etiology contrib)

      Light headedness

      Vague/non-specific sensation w/otherwise neg evaln; assoc w/anxiety, depression, other psychiatric d/o; hyperventilation

      Balance or gait problems?

      Primary neuro d/o

      Ataxia

      Decreased ability to walk in a balanced, steady fashion. Can lead to falls. May have other sx from loss of fine motor, depending on etiology.
      • Cerebellar (Etiology: stroke, tumor, bleeding, trauma, hereditary, neurodegenerative, toxic/metabolic→ etoh, other illicit, meds; Sx: difficulty with balance when walking, falls, lack of coordination, difficulty w/fine movements→ buttoning, drawing, picking up small items; acuity of presentation varies w/etiology; PE: wide based gait, lurching/staggering to keep balance, truncal instability, impaired tandem walking, difficulty with speech→ dysarthria, overshooting when pointing and problems with coordination of fine movements)
        • Multi-system atrophy (Rfs: age 50-60; Etiology: rare neurodegenerative d/o; progresses over 6-10 years; Sx: variability in presentaiton; initially autonomic dysfxn including orthostatic hypotension, if severe→ syncope/presyncope; urge incontinence, erectile dysfunction, other sexual dyxfxn; then parkisnonian features of slow movements, falls, rigidity, often aysmetric tremor, dysphonia dystonias; cerebellar dysfnx w/ataxia and dyscoordination; depression and anxiety; sob from stridor; PE: orhtostatic VS, abnormal posture, abnormal gait, cerebellar dysfxn→ action tremor, coordination problems, ataxic/wide-based gait, nystagumus)
      • Vestibular (Etiology: stroke, tumor, trauma, infection, idiopathic; Sx: abrupt onset, dizziness worse w/any head movement, often can't stand, nausea, falls to one side, duration varies w/etiology; PE: decrease in sx if lie quietly w/eyes closed; sx provoked w/any movement)
      • Sensory (Etiology: peripheral or central nerve dysfxn from dm, metabolic problems, toxins, meds, inflammation, infxn, B12 defic, etc; Sx: difficulty when get up and walk, not at rest, slowly progressive; PE: impaired proprioception→ diminished input from feet about their position, worse when cant see their feet, often strike ground hard w/each step in effort to feel, findings of dorsal column dysfunction)
      • Wernicke's encephalopathy (Etiology: thiamine (B1) deficiency; Rfs: alcoholic, others w/severe nutritional deficiency; Sx: delirium, severe balance problems, occulomotor dysfxn leading to double vision or other occular disturbances; most patients wont have all 3 symptoms; resolve w/thiamine, occulmotor most quickly; untreated→ Korsakoff's dementia→ inability to form new memories; PE: profound confusion, severe ataxia→ often unable to stand, occulomotor dysfxn including cranial nerve palsey, vertical or horizontal nystagmus)

      Common gait d/o

      • Parkinsonian gait (Rfs: age > 70; Sx: pill rolling tremor of hands, sometimes head bobbing tremor, difficulty starting and stopping movements, balance and gait problems, sometimes cognitive decline; PE: characteristic pill-rolling tremor, stooped forwards, shuffling gait, masked facies, difficulty getting up and starting movement, difficulty turning)
      • Hemiplegic gait (hemispheric lesion brain) (Rfs: often known lesion to frontal lobe motor cortex→ stroke, tumor, prior surgery, etc PE: arm abducted, elbow flexed, hand closed, circumduction at hip to move leg, increased tone and hyper-reflexia of afftected limbs)
      • Diplegic gait (typically assoc w/cerebral palsey) (Sx: if CP→ present from birth, affects legs>arms PE: flexion at hips and knees, tight hip aductors, feet turned in, walk w/circumduction of hips, knees can cross (scissor-like); arms less affected→ though still abducted and elbows bent; increased tone and hyper-reflexia of afftected limbs) more from CDC
      • Neuropathic gait (steppage gait→ foot drop) (Rfs: known reason for nerve dysfxn→ nerve injury, mononeuritis multiplex, etc; PE: lift affected leg high to keep foot from dragging, shoe worn/scuffed at toe; may use brace to keep foot dorsiflexed)
      • Myopathic gait (Etiology: myopathies cause weakness of pelvic muscles; Sx/PE: hip drops when put weight on that side, so try to switch back and forth→ waddling appearance, arched backwards) more from CDC

      Other CNS/PNS d/o

      • Multiple sclerosis (Rfs: white>black, women>men, age onset <30; Sx: affects spinal cord and brain, sub-acute, waxes/wanes, progresses over year/decades, patchy sensory and motor deficits that can cause balance probs, affect cerebellum)
      • Cervical myelopathy (Etiology: Congential or acquired process (disc herniation, oa/degenerative changes, RA, trauma, tumor) that narrows cervical canal, compressing cord; Sx: usually slowly progressive (unless trauma/infection/bleeding), difficulty with balance, upper>lower extremity weakness, loss of dexterity, numbness and sometimes neuroapthic pain, sometimes neck pain; PE: wide based gait, upper and lower extremity weakness, spasticity, hyper-reflexia)
      • Other CNS processes - w/associated weakness and spasticity
      • Peripheral nervous system dysfxn→ weakness, numbness
      • Neuro muscular dz
      • Other primary movement d/o - dystonia or other
      • Normal pressure hydrocelphalus (Rfs: older patient Sx: imbalance, confusion, and incontinence; PE: wide based, unsteady, shuffling or magnetic gait→ feet feel stuck to floor)

      Non-neuro d/o

      • Visual or hearing problems
      • Orthostatic sx - cardiovascular or autonomic etiology
      • MSK d/o (Rfs: advanced age, osteoporosis, prior injuries or falls; Etiology: osteoarthritis or other d/o of back, hips, knees, ankles, feet→ affects balance, causes pain; PE: joint deformities, pain w/joint movement; antalgic gait→ keep weight off painful joint)
      • Generalized weakness
        • Deconditioning
        • Severe acute or chronic illness - e.g. kidney or liver dz, anemia
        • See under: General sx→ fatigue
      • Cognitive disorders (dementia, delirium)
      • Medication side effects or illicit drugs
      Combinations of any of above neuro/non-neuro, in partic w/older pts

      Tremor?

      Primary neuro d/o

      • Parkinson's (Rfs: age > 70; Sx: pill rolling tremor of hands, sometimes head bobbing tremor, difficulty starting and stopping movements, balance and gait problems, sometimes cognitive decline; PE: characteristic pill-rolling tremor, shuffling gait, masked facies, difficulty getting up and starting movement, difficulty turning)
      • Secondary Parkinsons (Assoc w/many conditions, including: meds→ antipsychotics, antiemetics; repeated head trauma→ boxers; toxins→ MPTP; vascular dz)
      • Benign essential tremor (Rfs: Agre > 70; Sx: most noticeable in hands, worse with fine movements, exacerbated by stimulants; PE: more apparent if ask patient to do fine motor: pour water, write signature)
      • Cerebellar dz (Etiology: hereditary/degenerative, stroke, tumor, mult sclerosis, etoh/toxins, meds; Sx: onset/acuity varies w/Etiology; slow intention type tremor→ worse w/fine movements, assoc w/ataxia, dysarthria, and decreased coordination; PE: wide based gait, lurching/staggering to keep balance, impaired tandem walking, difficulty with speech→ dysarthria, overshooting when pointing and problems with coordination of fine movements)
      • Multi-system atrophy (Rfs: age 50-60; Etiology: rare neurodegenerative d/o; progresses over 6-10 years; Sx: variability in presentaiton; initially autonomic dysfxn including orthostatic hypotension, if severe→ syncope/presyncope; urge incontinence, erectile dysfunction, other sexual dyxfxn; then parkisnonian features of slow movements, falls, rigidity, often aysmetric tremor, dysphonia dystonias; cerebellar dysfnx w/ataxia and dyscoordination; depression and anxiety; sob from stridor; PE: orhtostatic VS, abnormal posture, abnormal gait, cerebellar dysfxn→ action tremor, coordination problems, ataxic/wide-based gait, nystagumus)
      • Associated w/idiopathic dystonias (Etiology: rare inherited d/o; Sx: irregular jerky tremor; assoc with involuntary limb movements
      • Wilson disease (Etiology: rare, inherited d/o causing accumulation of copper, age onset 20-40; Sx: proximal tremor of shoulder when abducted, elbows flexed, fingers pointing towards each other; also dsytonia, dysarthria, confusion; assoicated w/findings of chronic liver dz)

      Medical conditions

      • Hyperthyroidism (Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, wt loss, weakness, infetility, ED, menstrual irreg; PE: sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid, hyper-reflexia, moist skin)
      • Hepatic encephalopathy (Etiology: Associated w/cirrhosis of any etiology; PE: tremor exacerbated when hold hands out extended @ wrists→ flapping; also confusion, often assoicated w/findings of chronic liver dz)

      Stimulants & other substances

      • Cocaine, excessive caffeine, ADHD treatments, etc
      • Withdrawal from ETOH or benzos (Etiology: long standing users w/abrupt cessation; Sx: onset 12 to 72 h after stop, agitation, confusion

      Meds

      • Steroids, beta-agonists, other

      Headache?

      • Red flags: thunder clap→ acute, very severe, often of vascular Etiology; any new onset HA or change in quality of chronic HA; age greater 50; trauma, immunocompromised, loss of function, fever, delirium/behavioral change, awakens from sleep, unremitting, hx cancer w/met potential

      Chronic/Recurrent

      Recognize that even chronic/recurrent HA have a point of onset
      • Migraine (Rfs: often fam hx; Sx: recurrent, lasts 4 hours to days, severe, throbbing/pulsating, sometimes aura, assoc w/ N, V, light & sound sensitivity, unilateral; often seek quiet & dark places; worse w/movement)
      • Tension (Sx: most common HA, recurrent, usually bilateral, squeezing, no N/V/migraine/other sx)
      • Cluster (Sx: recurrent, brief→< 3h, severe, focused unilaterally around eye/temporal area; PE: assoc w/tearing, rhinorrhea, conj inflam)
      • Post concussive (Sx: hx discrete traumatic event, or hx recurrent events)
      • Rebound headache (Etiology: assoc w/overuse of NSAIDs, barbiturates, narcotics or other short acting rx for acute ha; Sx: chronic, recurrent ha, worse when stop short acting med; no other explanation found)
      • Chronic daily headache (Sx: headache 15d/m for 3m, represents transformation of a primary headache syndrome→ typically migraine or medication overuse)
      • Chronic Sinusitis (Sx: chronic/recurrent post nasal drip, nasal d/c, cough)
      • Pseudotumor cerebri (Etiology: idiopathic intracranial hypertension; Rfs: teens-to-30s, female, obesity; Sx: dull or throbbing, unremitting HA, fluctuates in severity, develops over weeks to mos; can be occipital or asymmetric; can be similar to tension or migraine HA; sometimes assoc w/blurred vision or progressive visual loss; somtimes diplopia; PE: papilledema, sometimes visual field loss, sometimes CN6 palsy)

      Acute

    • Blood in or around brain
      • Subdural (Etiology/Rfs: older→ assoc w/brain atrophy, mild (deceleration) to severe trauma; Sx: change in behavior/level of consciousness, acute to sub-acute)
      • Epidural (Etiology: assoc w/significant blunt trauma, often over middle meningeal artery; Sx: rapid decline in level of consciousness - which can wax and wane prior to demise)
      • Sub-arachnoid (Etiology: typically from a rupture aneurysm; Rfs: women > men, ages 40-60; Sx: acute and severe head ache→ classic thunderclap/worst HA of life, rapid decline in consciousness)
      • Parenchymal (Etiology: trauma, amyloid angiopathy, htn; Sx: acute, loss of function→ based on location)
      • Trauma: bleeding and/or swelling
    • Infections & other inflammatory processes
      • Meningitis (Etiology: inflammation of layers covering brain; Sx: photphobia, acute neck stiffness, headache, fever, confusion, and generalized illness; PE: f, + Kernigs (specific not sensitive)→ pain with passive knee extension when hip flexed to 90; + Brudzinski (specific not sensitive)→ hip and knee flexion occurs w/passive neck flexion; + jolt (sensitive not specific)→ worsening ha when patient rotates head back & forth; less common to have focal neurological findings and overall less impaired compared w/encephalitis)
        • Viral (Organisms: enteroviruses, herpes simplex, herpes zoster, ebv, west nile, influenza, hiv, measels, mumps; Sx: acute, fever, head ache, neck pain, n, v, delirium)
        • Bacterial (Organisms: strep pneumoniae, n meningiditis→ in particular when living in dormitories/college and not vax; grp b strep; listeria→ in the elderly; Sx: acute, fever, head ache, neck pain, n, v, delirium; rash)
        • Fungal (Rfs: often assoc w/compromised states → hiv, cancer; Organisms: cryptococcus, histoplasmosis, coccidioomycosis, blastomyces; Sx: subacute, fever, feeling poorly in general, sub-acute headache & neck pain, delirium)
        • Myobacterial (Rfs: known TB elsewhere, immuncompromised, otherwise exposed; Sx: subacute f, chills, ha, fatigue, stiff neck, delirium)
        • Parasitic - Cysticercosis (T Solium - tapeworm) (Etiology: ingest eggs via infected beef that's undercooked; Mexico, Africa, Southeast Asia; eggs cross intestines, migrate to host muscles and brain; Sx: ha, seizures, otherwise unexplained muscles aches)
        • Non-infectious: collagen vascular disease→ lupus, cancer involving the meninges, post infectious, medications→ nsaids, IVIG, other
        • More on meningitis from CDC
      • Encephalitis (Etiology: inflammation of diffuse or specifc areas of brain parenchyma; Sx: tend to have focal neuro deficits as compared w/meningitis; acute onset of headache, fever, confusion, irritability, motor and sensory impairment, altered speech; can also have meningoencephalitis)
        • Viral (most common) (Organisms: enteroviruses,, HSV, VZV, EBV, influenza, west nile, other arboviruses (transmitted by mosquitoes); and other viruses w/prevalence varying by season, region of the world)
        • Other uncommon infections (Organisms: Tick borne→ lyme; rabies, fungal, and mycobacteria)
        • Non-infectious (Etiology: collagen vascular disease, para-neoplastic, post infectious, post vaccination)
        • Autoimmune encephalitis (Etiology: antibody mediated→ multiple including anti-nmda; also paraneoplastic; Rfs: women, < 30, teratoma; Sx: acute change in personality, decline in functional status, agitation, confusion, bizarre behavior, autonomic instability, seizures, unusual movements, seziures, other neuro deficits)
        • ADEM (acute demyelinating encephalomyelitis) (Etiology: autoimmune d/o, often triggered by an infection→ URI, EBV; post vaccination, other; dx of exclusion; RFs: overall uncommon, though kids>>adults; Sx: acute, progressive, ha, f, confusion, weakness, ataxia, focal deficits; PE: f, focal deficits, patchy UMN and sensory findings)
      • Bacterial abscess (Etiology: reason for abscess → spread from adjacent site→ dental or sinuses, AVM, PFO, neurosurgery; Sx: acute/subacute, headache, fever, loss of function based on location, progressive, delirium)
      • Mycobacterial abscess (Rfs: known TB elsewhere, immuncompromised, otherwise exposed; Sx: subacute f, chills, ha, fatigue, stiff neck, delirium, loss of function based on location)
      • Fungal abscess (Rfs: often assoc w/compromised states → hiv, cancer, DM; systemic or from local spread; Sx: subacute, fever, feeling poorly in general, sub-acute headache & neck pain, delirium, deficits based on location)
      • Parasitic - Cysticercosis (T Solium - tapeworm) (Etiology: ingest eggs via infected beef that's undercooked; Mexico, Africa, Southeast Asia; eggs cross intestines, migrate to host muscles and brain; Sx:headache, seizures, otherwise unexplained muscles aches)
      • Parasitic - Toxoplasmosis (Rfs: HIV + w/CD4 < 200; Sx: sub-acute, headache, confusion, fever, focal neruo deficits based on location)
    • Tumor
      • Benign tumor (Etiology: meningioma, other; Sx: sub-acute, loss of function based on location, confusion/change in personality, headache)
      • Cancer - primary brain (Etiology: glioblastoma, astrocytoma, lymphoma, other; Sx: acute or subacute; deficits, changes in personality, etc based on location)
      • Cancer - metastatic (Etiology: predileciton for cns met→ lung, breast, renal, melanoma; Sx: may have sx from primary site; neuro sx can be acute or subacute; deficits, changes in personality, etc based on location)
    • Vascular lesion/process
      • Aneurysm (Sx: acute headache if leaking, other localizing sx if pushes on a nearby structure, when leaks/ruptures → sub-arachnoid bleed)
      • AVM (Sx: acute or sub-acute, loss of function based on location, can have abrupt change if superimposed bleeding)
      • Vasculitis: Temporal arteritis (Rfs: Hx PMR; Sx: older, acute, jaw pain w/chewing, , neck/shoulder aches, decreased vision, tender over temporal artery)
      • Carotid or vertebral dissection (Etiology: can be spontaneous, related to sudden flexion/extension, or from connective tissue d/o; Sx: acute, loss of function related to distribution dissection; neck/face pain)
      • Venous sinus thrombosis (Etiology: assoc w/hypercoaguable state or inflammation; Sx: can cause seizures and focal deficits, delirium, headache)

      HIV +

      Could still be due to any of causes mentioned above.
      • Infection
        • Bacterial
          • Meningitis (Sx: acute, neck pain, delirium, fever)
          • Abscess (Sx: fever, head ache, delirium, focal neuro deficits)
        • Parasites
          • Toxoplasmosis (Rfs: CD4 < 200 or untreated HIV; Sx: sub-acute, headache, confusion, fever, focal neruo deficits)
        • Virus
          • HSV (similar to non-HIV +, causes encephalitis &rarr fever, confusion)
        • Fungal
          • Cryptococcus (Rfs: CD4 < 50 or untreated HIV; Sx: sub-acute headache, fever, confusion)
          • Cocci (Rfs: CD4 < 250; Sx: headache, neck pain, lethargy, living in endemic area &rarr Southwest)
        • Mycobacterial
          • TB (Rfs: TB elsewhere, CD4 < 350; Sx: fever, sweats, weight loss, confusion)
        • Syphilis (Rfs: can occur at any CD4 level, sexual exposure; Etiology/Sx/PE: primary, secondary and tertiary manifestations; primary infection causes painless genital ulcer → heals 4-6w; secondary manifestations weeks later non-specific rash, w/predilection for palms , and soles, condyloma around genital areas, mucous involvement, adenopathy; ha, photophobia, stiff neck w/syphillitic meningitis; tertiary manifestations yrs later affecting CNS→ numbness, weakness, balance problems, dementia; large blood vessels→ aortitis, aneurysm) more from CDC
      • Malignancy
        • Lymphoma (NHL) (Etiology: tends to be aggressive; Sx: sub-acute, f, sweats, wt loss, adenopathy elsewhere, unexplained organogmegaly)
      • More from the CDC

      Non-Neuro Etiol

      • Depression (Sx: recognizing that HA will not be the sole manifestation of depression)
      • Eye related strain (Sx: slowly progressive, worse with reading, glasses working less well, no red flags)
      • Glaucoma (Sx: acute, eye pain, visual changes, eye redness, firm globe on palpation)
      • Sinusitis (Sx: acute, post nasal drip, facial pain, nasal d/c, cough)
      • Generalized viral or bacterial infections
      • Systemic hypertension (Sx: severe, though chronic htn is typically well tolerated and asx; acute increases in BP beyond a threshold; or very very high values)
      • Medications e.g. caffeine w/drawl, chemotherapy agents, birth control pills
      • Carbon monoxide (Sx: winter months w/exposure to heaters in closed spaces/poor ventilation, worse when in that environment → better outside, others w/similar sx who live/work in same place)
      • Obstructive sleep apnea (Etiology: obesity; Sx: snoring, witnessed apnea, not rested when awaken, day time fatigue, morning headache PE: bmi > 30; male neck circum > 17in, women > 16in, can't see back of throat when look in mouth)

      Confusion or Aggitation?

      Delirium

      RFs: age > 65, male, impaired hearing or vision, prior hx delirium, dementia, hospitalization, surgery or serious illness, multiple meds, baseline dementia; Sx: acute change from prior behavior, including→ disorganized thinking, impaired short term memory, inattention, disorientation, confusion, delusions, hallucinations, altered sleep patterns, hypo or hyperactivity; sx fluctuate; spectrum from somnolent to very agitated; typically reversible. Delirium is always secondary to something, including:

      Infection (genl)

      • Infection anywhere (Etiology: the greater magnitude infection, the more likely delirium, though frail/elderly/chronically ill can decompensate w/small burdens of infxn; Sx:site of infection identified by localizing sx & findings)

      CNS process

      Infection/Inflammation

      • Meningitis (genl) (Etiology: inflammation of layers covering brain; Sx: photphobia, acute neck stiffness, headache, fever, confusion, and generalized illness; PE: f, + Kernigs (specific not sensitive)→ pain with passive knee extension when hip flexed to 90; + Brudzinski (specific not sensitive)→ hip and knee flexion occurs w/passive neck flexion; + jolt (sensitive not specific)→ worsening ha when patient rotates head back & forth; less common to have focal neurological findings and overall less impaired compared w/encephalitis)
      • Viral (Organisms: enteroviruses, herpes simplex, herpes zoster, ebv, west nile, influenza, hiv, measels, mumps; Sx: acute, fever, head ache, neck pain, n, v, delirium)
      • Bacterial (Organisms: strep pneumoniae, n meningiditis→ in particular when living in dormitories/college and not vax; grp b strep; listeria→ in the elderly; Sx: acute, fever, head ache, neck pain, n, v, delirium; rash)
      • Fungal (Rfs: often assoc w/compromised states → hiv, cancer; Organisms: cryptococcus, histoplasmosis, coccidioomycosis, blastomyces; Sx: subacute, fever, feeling poorly in general, sub-acute headache & neck pain, delirium)
      • Myobacterial (Rfs: known TB elsewhere, immuncompromised, otherwise exposed; Sx: subacute f, chills, ha, fatigue, stiff neck, delirium)
      • Parasitic - Cysticercosis (T Solium - tapeworm) (Etiology: ingest eggs via infected beef that's undercooked; Mexico, Africa, Southeast Asia; eggs cross intestines, migrate to host muscles and brain; Sx: ha, seizures, otherwise unexplained muscles aches)
      • Non-infectious: collagen vascular disease→ lupus, cancer involving the meninges, post infectious, medications→ nsaids, IVIG, other
      • More on meningitis from CDC
      • Encephalitis (genl) (Etiology: inflammation of diffuse or specifc areas of brain parenchyma; Sx: tend to have focal neuro deficits as compared w/meningitis; acute onset of headache, fever, confusion, irritability, motor and sensory impairment, altered speech; can also have meningoencephalitis)
      • Viral (most common) (Organisms: enteroviruses,, HSV, VZV, EBV, influenza, west nile, other arboviruses (transmitted by mosquitoes); and other viruses w/prevalence varying by season, region of the world)
      • Other uncommon infections (Organisms: Tick borne→ lyme; rabies, fungal, and mycobacteria)
      • Non-infectious (Etiology: collagen vascular disease, para-neoplastic, post infectious, post vaccination)
      • Autoimmune encephalitis (Etiology: antibody mediated→ multiple including anti-nmda; also paraneoplastic; Rfs: women, < 30, teratoma; Sx: acute change in personality, decline in functional status, agitation, confusion, bizarre behavior, autonomic instability, seizures, unusual movements, seziures, other neuro deficits)
      • ADEM (acute demyelinating encephalomyelitis) (Etiology: autoimmune d/o, often triggered by an infection→ URI, EBV; post vaccination, other; dx of exclusion; RFs: overall uncommon, though kids>>adults; Sx: acute, progressive, ha, f, confusion, weakness, ataxia, focal deficits; PE: f, focal deficits, patchy UMN and sensory findings)
      • Bacterial abscess (Etiology: reason for abscess → spread from adjacent site→ dental or sinuses, AVM, PFO, neurosurgery; Sx: acute/subacute, headache, fever, loss of function based on location, progressive, delirium)
      • Mycobacterial abscess (Rfs: known TB elsewhere, immuncompromised, otherwise exposed; Sx: subacute f, chills, ha, fatigue, stiff neck, delirium, loss of function based on location)
      • Fungal abscess (Rfs: often assoc w/compromised states → hiv, cancer, DM; systemic or from local spread; Sx: subacute, fever, feeling poorly in general, sub-acute headache & neck pain, delirium, deficits based on location)
      • Parasitic - Cysticercosis (T Solium - tapeworm) (Etiology: ingest eggs via infected beef that's undercooked; Mexico, Africa, Southeast Asia; eggs cross intestines, migrate to host muscles and brain; Sx:headache, seizures, otherwise unexplained muscles aches)
      • Parasitic - Toxoplasmosis (Rfs: HIV + w/CD4 < 200; Sx: sub-acute, headache, confusion, fever, focal neruo deficits based on location)

      Other CNS

      • Trauma, bleeding, infection, tumor, post-ictal, stroke
      • Non-convulsive status epilepticus (Etiology: related to an array of pathology including tox/met conditions, meds, structural brain dz, other; Sx: waxing and waning level of altertness, confusion, new onset inability to follow commands; much more subtle than generalized seizure; PE: subtle twitching, eye deveiation, blinking, repeating of words, other)
      • Wernicke's encephalopathy (Etiology: thiamine (B1) deficiency; Rfs: alcoholic, others w/severe nutritional deficiency; Sx: delirium, severe balance problems, occulomotor dysfxn leading to double vision or other occular disturbances; most patients wont have all 3 symptoms; resolve w/thiamine, occulmotor most quickly; untreated→ Korsakoff's dementia→ inability to form new memories; PE: profound confusion, severe ataxia→ often unable to stand, occulomotor dysfxn including cranial nerve palsey, vertical or horizontal nystagmus)

      Meds/Drugs/Withdrawl

      • Cocaine, crystal meth, other stimulants or hallucinogens
      • ADHD meds, dopaminergics, SSRIs, steroids
      • Many other meds→ dx based on temporal relationship
      • Withdrawal from alcohol or benzodiazepines
      • Narcotic withdrawl
      • combinations of agents

      Toxins/Toxidomes/OD

      • Stimulants (Etiology: cocaine, crystal meth, other; Sx: aggitated, sweating, restless, very activated; PE: midriasis, tachycardia, sweating, tremor, psycho-motor activation)
      • Opioids (Etiology: heroin, opiods; Sx: sedation to somnolence; PE: hypothermia, sedation/decreased arrousability, slow respiratory rate, miosis, decreased bowel sounds)
      • Sedatives & hypnotics
        • Ethanol (typical drinking alcohol) (Etiology: degree of intoxication based on qty, chronicity of intake, function of metabolic pathways; Sx: excited, socially uninhibited, impaired judgement, aggressive behavior, aggitation; w/spectrum from hallucinations to sedation to somnolence if severe; PE: respiratory suppression if severe, characteristic odor, aggitation to sedation, slurred speech, ataxia)
        • Benzodiazepine (Etiology: degree of sx based on chronicity, quantity consumed, function of metabolic pathways; Sx: sedation to somnolence if severe; can also have aggitation, hallucinations; PE: aggitation/confusion to sedation, slurred speech, ataxia, respiratory suppression)
        • Ethylene glycol (Etiology: used in anti-freeze; colorless, odorless and sweet tasting→ accidental ingestions in kids or purposeful in adults; Sx: lower dose similar to ethanol, higher dose n, v, confusion, kidney/liver dysfxn, death, tachypnea from metaolic acidosis, osmolar gap; PE: euphoria, aggitation, social disinhibition; severe cases w/respiratory depression to coma; ataxia, slurred speech)
        • Methanol (wood alcohol) (Etiology: contained in wind shield wiper fluid, anti-freeze, fuel additives, paint thinners; consumed inadvertently by child or w/intent to harm self/others, very toxic; Sx: initially can appear inebriated; n, v, confusion, resp depression, death; long term neruo deficits, blindness; osmolar gap and later met acidosis; PE: initially inebriated; later can have tachypnea from met acidosis, visual disturbance, then somnolence, multi-sytem failure)
        • Isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) (Etiology: taken w/goal of inoxication; or unintentional or intentional overdose; Sx: similar to ethanol w/aggitation, disinhibition; w/spectrum including sedataion and coma; abd pain, vomiting; osmolar gap w/o sig metaoloic acidosis; PE: characteristic acetone breath odor, spectrum from aggitated to somnolence, respiratory depression if severe; slurred speech, ataxia)
      • Anticholinergics (Etiology: tricyclics, anihistamines, other; can be intential overdose; Sx: rapid onset < 12h after exposure, aggitated confusion, hallucinations, inability to urinate, blurred vision; PE: fever to > 38.8, flushed, tachycardic, aggitated delirium, dry mucous membranes, urinary retention, ileus, dry, red& warm skin, normal reflexes)
      • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (Etiologloy: exposure to haldol, chlorpomazine, other typical or atypical neruoleptics; more common w/high dose or soon after rx/dose change, but also idiosyncratic→ occurring after years of rx; sx progress over several d; Sx: autonomic instability w/HTN, tachycardia, tachypnea, temp can be > 41.1c, pale, sweaty, fluctuating delirium→ aggitated or stupor/alert mutism to coma, cramps, generalized lead-pipe type muscular rigidity, decreased reflexes)
      • Cholinergic agents (Etiology: organophosphate insecticide overdose or exposure; Sx: sedation, confusion, sweating, shortness of breath; PE: salivation, wheezing, lacrimation, bronchorrea, emesis, diarrhea, urination)
      • Serotonin syndrome (Etiology: SSRIs, MAOIs, anti-epileptics, others; rapid onset sx ususally following rx initiation or dose change, though can occur if received rx w/in 5w; sometimes med combinations precipitate syndrome; intential overdose; Sx: aggiation/easily startled, sweating, shivering, diarrhea; PE: spectrum→ htn, tachycardia, tachypnea, hyperthermia to > 41c, flushed & sweaty skin, tremor, confusion/aggitation to coma, increased bowel sounds, clonus, muscular hyperactivity/stiffness, hyper-reflexia)
      • In the setting of an over dose, multiple ingestions can occur simultaneously

      Acute Med Cond

      Many acute medical conditions can cause or contribute to delirium state.
      • Pulmonary
        • Hypoxemia
        • Hypercarbia
        • Pneumonia
        • Pulmonary embolism
      • Cardiac
        • Heart failure
        • Heart attack
        • Hypotension
        • Hypertensive encephalopathy
      • GI
        • Hepatic encephalopathy (Etiology: assoc w/chronic liver dz, most commonly hep b, c, etoh, other; acute infxn, meds, gi bleeding, other leads to decompensation; Sx: confusion to stupor in patient w/underlying dz; PE: findings of chronic liver dz, delirium, asterixis)
      • Renal
        • Uremia
        • Hypovolemia
      • Heme-Oncology
        • Malignancy, including para-neoplastic syndromes
        • Anemia
      • Endocrine
        • Hyper/hyponatremia
        • Hypercalcemia
        • Hyper/hypoglycemia
        • Hypo/hyperthyroidism
      • Neuro and Infections - see under main Delirium categories
      • Above is not exhaustive list - can have other significant target organ system disease contributing. Multi-system organ dysfunction possible too.

      Pain

      • Severe pain, in particular if coupled w/any of above

      Unfav environs

      • Hospitalization, disruption of normal sleep wake cycle, ICU stay, procedures, restraints, foley catheter
      Combinations of the above often contribute synergystically

      Dementia

      Rfs: age > 65; Sx: progressive, memory deficits, slowly progressive - define w/ comprehensive exam, collateral reports, Saint Louis University Mental Status (SLUMS) exam or Montreal Cognitive Assessment; note that delirium can be superimposed on dementia
      • Alzheimer's-type Dementia (Rfs: age > 65, hx Down's syndrome; Sx: progressive over years, loss of short term memory first; as progresses, affects ability to function; ultimately loss of higher level processing → ability to do calculations, engage in high level and then simpler conversations; can have behavioral problems; ultimately loss of long term memory, ability to recognize/interact/live independently) more from CDC
      • Vascular Dementia (Rfs: age > 60 and traditional CV risk factors; Sx: loss of memory and functionality; deficits can relate to areas of infarct; may progress abruptly in concert w/known strokes; or more slowly from chronic ischemia; can co-mingle w/Alzheimers dz)
      • Lewy Body Dementia (Rfs: increases w/age; Sx: declining cognitive fxn, visual/spatial impairment, inattention, hallucinations, fluctuation in sx; most patient will also have sx of Parkisons; can co-mingle w/AD or vascular dementia)
      • Fronto-temporal Dementia(Rfs: increases w/age; Sx: dominant feature is change in personality & behavioural problems→ ranging from withdrawl to aggression; loss of sense of social norms; binge eating; can also experience aphasia)
      • Normal Pressure Hydrocephalous (Rfs: age > 65; Sx: dementia, accompanied by wide-based gait & incontinence)
      • Korsakoff's dementia (Etiology: starts as Wernickes encephalopathy→ thiamine (B1) deficiency; Rfs: while uncommon, seem in alcoholics; Sx/PE: encephalopathy, ataxia from cerebellar dysfxn, opathalmoplegia leading to disconjugate gaze→ double vision, nystagmus; untreated can lead to Korsakoff's dementia→ inability to form new memories)
      • Rarer neruodegenerative d/o w/dementia
        • Huntington's dz (Etiology: autosomal dominant Sx: onset ~ 50s, movement problems, cognitive, memory & other impairments c/w dementia→ progressive & fatal)
        • Progressive supra-nuclear palsy (Sx: rare d/o assoc w/gait & balance problems, impaired eye movements, rigidity; cognitive impairment, behavioural issues, dis-inhibition, lost of executive fxn)
        • Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease (Sx: can affect old & young (<50); rapidly progressive decline in memory, cognition, thinking; onset to death w/in 1y; coordination probs and myoclonus may come first)

      Medical conditions

      • Acute Intermitent Porphyria (Etiology: uncommon, inherited d/o; often triggered by starvation, etoh, smoking, infection, or meds; also cutaneous variants; Sx: episodic bouts of unexplained severe abd pain, agitation/confusion, n, v, limb pain, motor and sonsory neuropathy, seizure; PE: episodic htn, tachycardia, generalized muscle weakness, dark urine)
      • Adrenal excess (Sx: central wt gain→ neck/face/thorax/abd, htn, glucose intol/dm; PE: striae, easy bruising, buffalo hump, moon face, hyperpigment in mouth/sun exposed areas if acth depen)
      • Adrenal insufficiency (Sx: feeling poorly in general, n, v, orthostatic sx)
      • B12 deficiency (Etiology: pernicious anemia, s/p gastrectomy, crohn's dz, rarely diet related; Sx: progressive, legs more common then arms, can be painful, impaired dorsal columns function, gait problems, tongue can be smooth and swollen if severe, s/s anemia if severe, rarely confusion)
      • HIV (RFs: men having sex w/men, sex w/prostitutes, IVDU, transfusion w/o screening, sexually active, past STI, TB, sex w/anyone w/HIV RFs, sex for money; Sx: wt loss, fatigue, f, sweats, delirium, infections typical of t-cell dysfxn→ fungal, mycobacterial, other)
      • Hyperthyroidism (Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, wt loss, weakness, infetility, ED, menstrual irreg; PE: sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid, hyper-reflexia, moist skin)
      • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
      • Progressive Multi-focal Leukoencephalopathy (PML) (Etiology: JC virus; RFs: HIV or immuncompromised meds; Sx: lethargy, apathy, hallucinations, inattentiveness, perservation, & other manifestations of confusional state that's progressive over months, unrelenting→ leading to disability and death)
      • Wilson's dz (Sx: initially present w/signs and sx of liver dz that's otherwise unexplained; neuro sx include dysarthria, dysphagia, tremor, dystonia, ataxia. fine motor issues; some will experience otherwise unexplained psychosis, personality changes, bizarre behavior)

      Primary psych d/o

      Assoc w/agitation and disorientation - hx can be of known disease which is untreated or initial presentation
      • Bi-polar d/o (Sx: mood d/o assoc w/episodes that differ from patient's normal mood & behaviour; cycling (variable duration & degree) between depression & mania→ manic sx: overly happy & outgoing, inpulsivity, participating in risky behavior, racing thoughts, easily distracted, poor performance school/work, not sleeping, unrealistic sense of abilities, increased activity; Depressive sx (not always prominent): feeling sad, hopeless, low energy, suicidality, disturbed sleeping & eating, lack of joy from activities)
      • Schizophrenia (Sx: age onset teens-30s; symptoms are positive, negative & cognitive; positive sx: losing touch w/reality→ delusions, hallucinations, disordered or dysfunctional thinking, agitation; negative sx: lack of interest in anything, inability to follow thru w/plan, flat affect, speaking little, social withdrawal; cognitive sx: impaired ability to understand & use info, impaired ability to make immediate use of learned info, impaired ability to focus/concentrate)
      • Schizoaffective (Sx: chronic psychotic sx including delusions & hallucinations similar to schizophrenia; however, also sustained affective sx including depression, mania or mixed)
      • Depression w/psychotic features (Sx: depressive sx commingled w/delusion, hallucinations)

      More Info About Neurologic Disorders:
      National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke; Comprehensive neuro exam

      Back

      Endocrine

      Known Endocrine disorder?

      • Diabetes, hypo/hyperthyroidism, parathyroid dz, adrenal d/o, pituitary/hypothalamic problems, osteoporosis, etc

      Polyuria or polydypsia

      D/O causing diuresis

      • Poorly controlled diabetes
      • Loop diuretic use, mannitol, other meds
      • CHF (C/V RFs; Sx: orthopnea, PND, orthopnea, doe, sob, nocturia related to volume redistribution; PE: lower extremity edema , + S3, elevated jvp, displaced pmi, rales on lung exam)
      • Excessive ETOH, caffeine and/or PM oral liquid intake
      • Psychogenic polydypsia

      Diabetes insipidus

      Loss of ability to concentrate urine.
      • Central DI: Decreased ADH secretion
        • Trauma or surgery affecting hypothalamic function
        • Infiltrative or inflammatory process affecting hypothalamus
        • Idiopathic; congenital
      • Nephrogenic DI: Decreased renal response to ADH
        • Meds that decrease effect of ADH on kidney→ e.g. Lithium
        • Hypercalcemia → decreased effect of ADH on kidney
          • Primary hyper-PTH (Sx: usually slowly progressive; assoc w/fractures, renal stones, fatigue, confusion, weakness; higher risks w/higher ca2+)
          • Malignancy (Sx related to primary cancer as well as hyper ca2+ → fatigue, confusion, pain weakness; can be relatively acute, varying w/cancer burden)
            • Elevated PTH-like hormone - in particular squamous cell cancer
            • Direct bone erosion e.g. myeloma, lymphoma, breast
            • Inappropriate production of 1,25-OH vit d→ lymphoma
          • Vitamin D related
            • Increased conversion of 25-OH to 1,25-OH vit D e.g. Sarcoid or other granulomatous disease
            • Excessive vit D or ca2+ ingestion
          • Meds→ e.g. HCTZ, lithium, antacids→ milk alkali synd
          • Immobility - though Ca2+ elev usually mild
          • Other endo related: hyperthyroidism, pheochromocytoma, hyper or hypoadrenal states
      • Congenital
      • Some types of chronic kidney disease e.g. polycystic kidneys

      Primary GU problem

      • BPH (Rfs: male, >50; Sx: chronic, progressive, urgency, frequency, hesitancy, difficulty starting/stopping stream, incomplete emptying, decrease force, voiding again soon after urinate)

      Fatigue?

      Fatigue is a symptom with many possible explanations. Need to define what patient means by fatigue: e.g. tired, lack of energy, muscle weakness, depressed, etc→ use further questions to identify Etiologyogy. Risk factors (e.g. age, sex), past history, meds and other historical clues should help to further categorize.

      Endocrine D/O

      • Hypercalcemia
        • Primary hyper-PTH (Sx: usually slowly progressive; assoc w/fractures, renal stones, fatigue, confusion, weakness; higher risks w/higher ca2+)
        • Malignancy (Sx related to primary cancer as well as hyper ca2+ → fatigue, confusion, pain weakness; can be relatively acute, varying w/cancer burden)
          • Elevated PTH-like hormone - in particular squamous cell cancer
          • Direct bone erosion e.g. myeloma, lymphoma, breast
          • Inappropriate production of 1,25-OH vit d→ lymphoma
        • Vitamin D related
          • Increased conversion of 25-OH to 1,25-OH vit D e.g. Sarcoid or other granulomatous disease
          • Excessive vit D or ca2+ ingestion
        • Meds→ e.g. HCTZ, lithium, antacids→ milk alkali synd
        • Immobility - though Ca2+ elev usually mild
        • Other endo related: hyperthyroidism, pheochromocytoma, hyper or hypoadrenal states
      • Hypocalcemia (Etiology: severe vit d defic, resistance to vit d, low intake calcium, hypoparthyroidism→ post surgical, xrt, idiopathic, other; Sx: weakness, perioral numbness, muscle cramps; PE: muscle irritability; twitching w/tap on facial nerve, hand/wrist spasm w/prolonged inflation bp cuff)
      • Hypothyroidism (Sx: wt gain, edema, dry skin, constipation, cold intolerance, depression/mood change, weakness, fatigue; PE: often no findings aside from wt gain, sometimes decreased reflexes, edema, bradycardia)
      • Hyperthyroidism (Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, wt loss, weakness, infetility, ED, menstrual irreg; PE: sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid, hyper-reflexia, moist skin)
        • Graves Dz (Etiology: autoimmune; RFs: female > male, ages 40-60; most common cause of hyperthyroidism 50-80% of cases; Sx: as above; typically progressive over 2-3m; PE: diffusely enlarged thyroid, sometimes bruit; exopthalmous/ophthalmopathy in up to 25%; otherwise as above)
        • Painless thyroiditis (Etiology: autoimmune; Rfs: often post partum; Sx: as above, onset over < 3m)
        • Painful thyroiditis (Etiology: often post-viral; Sx: acute, painful thyroid and neck, fatigue; Sx: initially hyperthyroid ~6w, then hypothyroid ~4-6w; may return to euthyroid or remain hypo; PE: painful thryoid)
        • Toxic multi-nodular goiter (Etiology: often in regions of world that are iodine deficient; RFs: age > 50, women > men; Sx: as above, severity and timing onset vary; PE: palpable nodularity)
        • Toxic solitary adenoma (Etiology: idiopathic, single, hyperfunctioning nodule; Rfs> increasing age, women > men; PE: sometimes single palpable nodule)
        • Exogenous thyroid hormone consumption (Etiology: unintentional or intentional over rx in patient w/known hyperthyroidim; surreptitious use of thyroid hormone in someone w/o thyroid dz, perhaps to aid w/weight loss, other)
      • Diabetes (Rfs/Etiology: known dz → poor control; Sx: polyuria, polydypsia)
      • Low testosterone (Sx: decreased libido, errectile dysfxn, generalized weakness, decreased muscle mass, depression)
        • Primary (Rf/Etiology: testicular hypofunction from: prior infection→ mumps; torsion/trauma/cancer/other reason for testicular death; past chemotherapy; genetic disorders→ prader-willi; PE: sometimes small or absent testes)
        • Secondary (Rf/Etiology: pituitary/hypothalamic dysfxn from: tumor, inflammatory processes, hypoperfusion; meds→ chronic narcotics, LHRH agonists for prostate ca; hemochromatosis; chronic diseases→ HIV, Dm, copd, chf, renal filuare, cirrhosis)
      • Adrenal insufficiency (Sx: feeling poorly in general, n, v, orthostatic sx)
        • Primary (Etiology: problem at level of adrenal gland: autoimmune destruction → assoc w/DM 1, celiac dz; hemorrhage/infarct; infection → TB, HIV; infiltration w/tumor; PE: sometimes darkening of mucous membranes, skin folds, & pressure points)
        • Secondary (Etiology: problem at level of pituitary/hypothalamus → low acth; can be from surgery, tumor, hypoperfusion, auto-immune, trauma, meds→ chronic glucocorticoids)
      • Acromegaly (growth hormone excess) (Etiology: typically pituitary tumor, age ~40; Sx: increase in hat or shoe size as an adult, increase in tongue size, fatigue, weakness, joint pain, increased height, sweating & body odor, headache, visual loss affecting temporal fields, infertility, menstrual irreg; PE: characteristic appearance of face w/prominent brow and jaw, enlarging hands, increasing shoe size, enlarging tongue)
      • Profound hypokalemia
      • Hyponatremia

      Sleep D/O

      • Obstructive sleep apnea (RFs: obesity, male, age, anatomically narrowed airway; 25-30% w/osa have nl BMI; Sx: snoring, observed apnea, poorly rested in AM, daytime fatigue, accidents, difficulty concentrating, morning head ache; PE: BMI > 30, OSA risk increased w/neck circumference >17in men, 16in women; osa risk increased if cant see back of throat) STOP-BANG OSA Screening Tool
      • Central sleep apnea (Rfs: assoc w/older age and other conditions including: CHF, ESRD, drugs→ e.g. methadone; Sx: observed apnea, poorly rested in AM, daytime fatigue)
      • Travel/jet lag, work with odd hours/shifts, poor sleep hygiene, meds, other

      Heme-Onc D/O

      Anemia

      Hemoglobin measurement needed to Dx anemia - but such a common problem that DDx provided below. Sx: weakness, fatigue, sob, doe. Degree of sx based on acuity of anemia, other co-morbid dz processes, genl activity level.
    • Decreased RBC production
      • Primary bone marrow production problem - Acquired
        • Hematologic malignancy e.g. leukemia, lymphoma, multiple myeloma, myeloproliferative disorders (Sx: wt loss, f, chills, sweats, bleeding, other cell lines affected)
        • Myelodysplastic syndrome (Rfs: Age > 60, a primary problem or secondary to chemotherapy or other d/o that can affect BM function; Sx: asx until anemia, low plt, or low wbc lead to sx→ fatigue, sob, doe, bleeding, infection; risk of transformation to AML)
        • Aplastic anemia (Etiology: Secondary→ meds, infection, xrt, other; all cell lines decreased; Sx: sob, fatigue from anemia; recurrent infections from low wbc; bleeding from low plt)
      • Primary bone marrow production problem - Hereditary
        • Thalassemia (Rfs/Etiology: mediterranean background, dx during childhood; Sx: failure to thrive)
        • Sickle cell (Rfs: black, family hx, identified in childhood; Sx: failure to thrive in childhood, recurrent bouts pain during crises)
        • Aplastic anemia (Etiology: primary→ related to a number of inherited conditions; all cell lines decreased; Sx: sob, fatigue from anemia; recurrent infections from low wbc; bleeding from low plt)
      • Secondary bone marrow production problem
        • Chronic kidney diease→ low erythropoietin
        • Chronic liver disease
        • Chronic inflammatory process of any sort→ anemia of chronic disease
        • Low testosterone in men (Sx: low libido, ED, decreased energy, non-specific weakness/fatigue, depression)
        • Hypothyroidism
        • ETOH abuse
        • B12 deficiency (Etiology: perinicious anemia, s/p gastrectomy, crohn's dz, rarely diet related; Sx: progressive, legs more common then arms, can be painful, impaired dorsal columns function, gait problems, tongue can be smooth and swollen if severe, s/s anemia if severe, rarely confusion)
        • Folate deficiency
        • Meds e.g. chemotherapeutic agents and many others
        • Iron deficiency - Primary (Etiology: lack of access to iron is unusual, unless extreme diet→ vegan)
        • Iron deficiency - Secondary (Etiology: blood loss→ see below; malabsorption of iron for any reason→ gastric surgery, gastric by-pass, celiac dz, IBD, elevated gastric pH from h2 blockers or PPIs, etc.)
    • Blood loss
        • Slow losses (compensated) tend to cause vague symptoms of fatigue and dyspnea. Rapid losses (uncompensated) tend to cause abnormal vital signs and are often visible (e.g. throwing up blood or passing blood per rectum). Internal sources of bleeding (intra-abdominal, retroperitoneal, thoracic) aren't directly visible but hx often suggestive.
      • Bleeding in upper GI tract - Stool is typically tarry/sticky and has characteristic odor
        • Ulcer - gastric or ducodenal (Rfs/Etiology: ETOH, h pylori, nsaid use; Sx: epigastric, better or worse w/food, black stools)
        • Esophageal varices→ secondary to portal htn, whose causes include:
          • Post-hepatic processes→ hepatic vein thrombosis, severe R/L CHF, constrictive pericardial diease, restrictive cardiomypathy
          • Intrahepatic processes→ chronic hepatitis of any etiology including: viral, toxin, autoimmune, infiltrative, malignant; sometimes acute d/o if fulminant or superimposed on chronic
          • Pre-hepatic processes→ portal vein thrombosis, portal vein obstruction from parasites/other
        • Stomach cancer (Rfs: 50, smoking, ETOH abuse, h pylori→ MALT assoc; Sx: sub-acute, feel full when eating ever smaller quantities of food, pain, bleeding)
        • Gastritis (Rfs: stress, ETOH, NSAIDs, h pylori; Sx: epigastric pain, black stools, better or worse w/food)
        • Esophagitis (Rfs: assoc w/obesity, ETOH, smoking, caffine, chocolate, mint; Sx: GERD type→ burning type pain, often worse after meals, worse if lie down after eating, bad taste in mouth, radiates up from epigastrium)
        • Swallowed blood from upper respiratory source→ nose bleed
        • Swallowed blood from oral bleeding site
        • Mallory Weiss Tear (Etiology/Rfs: hx repeated retching)
        • Dieulafoys lesions→ sub-mucosal artery (Sx: sudden, brisk bleeding)
        • Aorto-enteric fistula (Rfs: hx AAA graft; Sx: profound bleeding)
      • Bleeding in lower GI tract - structural causes
        • Colonic AVM (Sx: typically small amounts blood, avm not visible on exam)
        • Colonic polyp (Sx: typically small amounts blood, polyp no visible on exam)
        • Diverticulum (Sx: acute, bright red blood, can be small or large amnts)
        • External hemorrhoid (Sx: painless bleeding, unless thrombosed; readily visible on exam; if thrombosed then acute pain; PE: bluish venous structure in peri-rectal area; if thrombosed, readly visible)
        • Internal hemorrhoid (Sx: painless bleeding, small or large amounts, recurrent; rare site of variceal bleeding from portal htn; PE: not visible unless use anoscope or prolapsed; blood apparent on digital rectal if bleeding at time of exam)
        • Stercoral ulcer (Rfs/Etiology: older patient, immobile, related to hardened stool in low motility colon, dementia)
        • Rectal varices (Etiology: assoc w/portal htn; much less common than esophageal varices; Rf: any reason for portal htn→ pre, intra, or post-hepatic; Sx: related to chronic liver dz; profound bright red blood per rectum; PE: blood on digital exam, brisk bleeding, abnormal vital signs
        • Contribution from primary bleeding disorder
        • Colorectal cancer (adeno) (Rfs: no prior screening or screening > 10y ago, early family hx, polyposis syndromes, UC or colonic crohn's; Sx: anorexia, weight loss, vague pain, persistent/progressive, bloody stools, change in bowel habits, R sided→ fatigue from anemia, L sided→ obstructive sx; palpable if very distal)
        • Anal cancer (squamous cell)(Rfs: squamous cell ca around anus & assoc w/HPV infection, increased incidence w/anal intercourse, HIV, women, men who have sex w/men; Sx: anal pain, tenesmus, bleeding, pain, obstruction; PE: palpable mass or diffuse tissue infiltration around anus)
      • Bleeding in lower GI tract - inflammatory & infectious causes
        • Ulcerative colitis (Etiology: automimmune, genetic, environmentally triggered, other; affects colon, distal to prox; Rfs: Northen Europeans, North Americans; smoking and appendectomy protective; peak onset 15-30; Sx and PE: sub-acute, recurrent or chronic diarrhea; fatigue, wt loss, bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, nocturnal diarrhea, feeling poorly overall; spectrum from mild to severe; extra-GI: aphtous ulcers, erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosa, peripheral arthritis, ankylosing spond/sacroiliitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, eye sx→ episcleritis/scleritis/uveitis) More from CDC
        • Crohn's disease (Etiology: automimmune, genetic, environmentally triggered, other; transmural involvement; can affect anywhere in GI tract mouth-to-anus; Rfs: smoking and appendectomy increase risk; Northern Europeans and North Americans; peak onset 15-30; Sx: sub-acute, diarrhea→ though can be less prominent than w/UC, nocturnal diarrhea, sometimes bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, fever, abd pain, fatigue, wt loss, feeling poorly overall, fistulas, bowel obstruction, peri-rectal dz; spectrum of sx and findings; PE: sometimes abd mass; peri-rectal disease; extra-GI: aphtous ulcers, erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosa, peripheral arthritis, ankylosing spond/sacroiliitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, eye sx→ episcleritis/scleritis/uveitis) More from CDC
        • XRT induced (Rf/Etiology: hx radiation to lower abd/pv → e.g. prostate; Sx: small amounts of blood)
        • Bacterial enteritis often causes blood in stool, but not typically to extent that leads to anemia
        • Parasites → Entamoeba Hyst (Rfs: unclean water/poor sanitation, also via anal intercourse; Sx: diarrhea, abd pain, 2-4w incubation)
        • Parasites→Necator americanus (hookworm) (Rfs/Etiology: common world-wide, enter thru feet/skin if walk barefoot in soil w/infected feces → bloodstream → lungs → swallowed → small intestines → blood loss; Sx: fatigue, d)
        • Parasites→ Trichuris (whipworm) (Sx/Etiology: eggs ingested, live in colon; light infxn → Sx: often asx; if heavy burden → abd pain, diarrhea, bloody stools, n, v, anemia)
        • HIV + (chronic, atypical infxns → CMV, HSV; Kaposis; can also be bacterial)
        • Medications (e.g. Ipilimumab) (Etiology: immune modulating cancer therapy, can cause colitis, as can other meds; Sx: based on recognizing connection between med & GI bleeding; brb per rectum, non-specific abd pain)
      • Colonic ischemia
        • RFs/Etiology: hx vascular disease and RFs, hx hypoperfusion → hypotension for any reason; Sx: acute onset bleeding, pain
      • Small bowel source
        • Arterio-venous malformation (Rfs: age > 60, esrd, aortic stenosis, von-willebrand's dz; Sx: painless, bleed intermitently, no source seen on upper or lower endoscopy)
        • Small bowel polyps (Sx: related to familial polyposis syndromes, may have family hx gi malignancy)
        • Meckel's diverticulum (Etiology: ectopic stomach mucosa located in terminal ileum; Sx: can be asx, or cause, abdominal pain, gi bleeding, sbo)
        • Adenocarcinoma (Etiology: can be spontaneous, also assoc w/familial polyposis syndromes, duodenum is most common site; Sx: abd pain, wt loss, occult bleeding)
        • Lymphoma (Sx: sub-acute fever, sweats, abdominal pain, diarrhea, adenopathy elswewhere)
        • Metastatic dz (Sx: related to primary, mets to sb can cause pain, bleeding, obstruction
      • Trauma
        • Typically obvious - blood can escape externally or collect in body spaces → chest, abd, retroperit, thigh
      • Chronic blood donation or recurrent phlebotomy in hospitalized patients
      • GU losses
        • Unusual to lose a lot of blood in urine unless very obvious
      • GYN losses
        • Vaginal bleeding from heavy menses, polyps, fibroids, cancer
    • Hemolysis
        • Genl Sx: sob, doe, fatigue & those related to specific etiology; PE: if severe hemolysis→ abnl VS, jaundice, scleral icterus, bilirubinuria if intravascular; other sx related to specific Etiologyogy of hemolysis
      • Acquired d/o of RBC membrane - hemolysis intra-vascular
        • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) (Etiology: unusual d/o, avg age onset 30s, hemolysis due to increased susceptibility to compliment; Sx: spontaneous venous thrombosis→ portal, hepatic, mesenteric and extremity veins; episodic hemolysis, in partic after infxn, w/assoc sob, doe, fatigue; decreased production all cell lines)
      • Inherited d/o - Abnormal RBCs - hemolysis largely extra-vascular
        • Spherocytosis (Etiology: RBC membrane defect; Sx: those assoc w/anemia, splenomegaly and jaundice; spectrum of severity; neonate to adulthood)
        • Thalassemia (Rfs/Etiology: hemoglobin defect, mediterranean background, dx during childhood; Sx: failure to thrive)
        • Sickle cell (Rfs/Etiology: hemoglobin defect, black, family hx, identified in childhood; Sx: failure to thrive, recurrent bouts pain during crises)
        • G6PD Defic (Rfs/Etiology: enzyme defect, Mediter, Asian, African, Middle Eastern background; Sx: typically asx until presented w/acute oxidative stress→ infection, meds, fava beans → acute hemolysis → resolves when stress removed)
      • Secondary Hemolytic anemias - RBCs normal - hemolysis intra or extra-vascular
        • Autoimmune (Etiology: primary/idiopathic or secondary to: connective tissue d/o→ e.g. lupus, RA; infection→ viral, mycoplasma; malignancy→ e.g. CLL; meds→ e.g. penicillins or cephalosporins)
        • Transfusion rxn (occurs following blood transfusion)
        • Selected infections e.g. malaria, babesiosis
        • Hypersplenism (Sx: splenic enlargement for any reason can cause hemolysis → exaggeration of spleens nl fxn; causes include infection, cancer, infiltrative; often also assoc w/low plt and wbcs)
        • Severe malfunction of mechanical heart valve (Sx: accompanied by sx chf/other to suggest valve not opening/closing normally; nl fxning prostheses cause low level, asx hemolysis)
        • Microangiopathic: DIC (Etiology: secondary to a precipitant, including → systemic infxn, cancer, trauma, other serious event)
        • Microangiopathic: HUS-TTP (Etiology/Rfs: HUS→ kids, TTP→ adults; Sx: acute, assoc w/anemia, acute kidney injury; secondary to an inciting event, including meds → e.g clopidogrel, infection→ e.g. e coli 0157h7, cancer, etc.)
      Contribution from bleeding d/o - acquired or congenital - can contribute to any of above

      Cancer

    • Solid tumors (primary)
      • Anal cancer (squamous cell) (Rfs: assoc w/HPV infection, increased incidence w/anal intercourse, HIV, women, men who have sex w/men; Sx: anal pain, tenesmus, bleeding, pain, obstruction PE: palpable mass or diffuse tissue infiltration around anus)
      • Biliary (cholangiocarcinoma) (Rfs: PSC, other chronic biliary inflammation; Sx: RUQ/epigsatric persistent/progressive discomfort, anorexia, weight loss, jaundice, ictreus, lighter color stools)
      • Bladder or other urothelial (transitional, squamous) (Rfs: smoking hx, male, age > 50, anyline dye exposure→ TCC; chronic foley or schistosomiasis→ SCC; Sx: lower abd/pelvis discomfort, wt loss, hematuria/dysuria, urinary frequency/urgency)
      • Bone - osteoscaroma (Etiology: uncommon; Sx: bone pain, fracture w/o mechanism, wt loss, feeling poorly)
      • Brain - can originate from any CNS tissues→ astrocytoma/glioblastoma, glioma, oligodendroglyoma, medulloblastoma, ependymoma, pituitary/hypothalamic, pinealoma, meningioma (benign) (Sx: progressive, head ache, seizures, feeling poorly, neuro deficits PE: weakness/loss of function, sensory deficits, behavioral changes, etc)
      • Breast (ductal, lobular) (Rfs: women>>>male, can occur any age, though typically > 50, other risk factors: early menarche, late menopause, never pregnant, family hx, past hx breast ca; Sx: patient notes breast mass, nipple retraction, bloody nipple d/c, skin changes; bone, brain lung, or other organ sx if present w/mets; PE: palpable disrete mass, bloody nipple d/c, nipple inversion, skin changes, axillary adenopathy)
      • Cervical (squamous, adeno) (Rfs: smoking, early age first intercourse, multiple sexual partners, hx STIs, hx HPV→ scc, HIV; Sx: vague lower abd discomfort, vaginal bleeding, pain w/intercourse; PE: abnormal cervix on exam)
      • Colorectal (adeno) (Rfs: no prior screening or screening > 10y ago, early family hx, polyposis syndromes, UC or colonic crohn's; Sx: anorexia, weight loss, vague pain, persistent/progressive, bloody stools, change in bowel habits, R sided→ fatigue from anemia, L sided→ obstructive sx; PE: palpable by digital exam if very distal; palpable on abdominal exam if very large or mets, gross blood or guaiac + on digital exam)
      • Esophageal (Sx: progressive swallowing problems, food gets stuck, worse w/solids then liquids, pain, patient can often point to level of obstruction)
        • Squamous Cell (Etiology: upper 2/3 of esophagus; Rfs: ETOH, smoking, age > 50)
        • Adenocarcinoma (Etiology: lower 1/3 of esophagus; Rfs: GERD → Barret's, age > 50)
      • Head and Neck (squamous) (Rfs: smoking, etoh, chewing tobacco, HPV infection; Etiology: typically squamous cell; Sx: present w/ulcers that don't heal in mouth, masses in mouth, difficulty swallowing, neck adenopathy PE: slow growing, non-healing ulcer or mass of oral mucosa, edges indurated, lymph nodes firm, stuck to each other & underlying tissue, growing)
      • Liver (hepatocellular) (Rfs: chronic hepatitis for any reason→ viral, etoh, etc; Sx: RUQ/epigastric persistent/progressive discomfort, anorexia, weight loss; PE: palpable, firm liver if advanced)
      • Lung (Sx: cough, sob/doe, chest pain, hemoptysis, hoarseness, wt loss, f, sweats; other organs if mets at presentation→ brain, liver PE: may have auscutatory findings if involves enough parenchyma, wheezing if affects large airway, findings assoc w/effusion if advanced)
        • Non-small cell (Rfs: more common, smoking assoc, asbestos exposure)
        • Small cell (Etiology: 10-15% of lung ca, more chemo responsive than non-small cell; RFs: smoking & asbestos exposure)
      • Melanoma (Rfs: fair skin, fair hair, prior melanoma, dysplastic moles, family hx, hx blistering sun burns, immunocompromised; Sx/PE: asymmetric, bleeds, irregular borders, non-homogeneous pigment, grows, doesn't heal, reginal adenopathy if spread, sx related to mets to brain, lung, liver)
      • Mesothelioma (Etiology: secondary to asbestos exposure from mining, work w/insulation→ pipes, brakes, ship building; or family exposed to clothing of those who worked direclty w/asbestos; Sx: causes pleural disease & effusion w/SOB, chest wall pain)
      • Metastatic disease→ almost any solid organ can have a met from cancer elsewhere
      • Ovarian (epithelial) (Rfs: age > 50, fam hx breast/ovarian, nulliparity, obesity; Sx: vague, progressive, abdominal/pelvic fullness/discomfort, constipation, bloating, anoexia, nausea increased girth if malignant ascites, irregular vaginal bleeding; PE: palpably enlarged ovary if advanced)
      • Pancreatic (adeno) (Rfs: male, age > 50, chronic pancreatitis, smoking, family hx; Sx: epigastric area, anorexia, weight loss, epigastric pain radiating to back, persistent/progressive, sometimes diarrhea; PE: palpable mass from primary or met if advanced; jaundice if affecting head of pnacreas and obstructing CBD)
      • Prostate (adeno) (Sx: asx early, can cause urgency, frequency, delayed emptying, hematuria; bone pain if mets; PE: nodular, firm prostate)
      • Renal cell (Rfs: smoking, obesity, family hx, male; avg age ~mid 60s; Sx: low back to lower abd/groin discomfort, wt loss, sweats, fever, flank pain, hematuria; PE: papable only if very advanced)
      • Sarcoma (soft tissue) (Etiology: uncommon; Sx: relatively uncommon malignancies, growing mass that arises from muscle/other tissue, other sx based on growth/interference w/adjacent structures)
      • Small bowel (adeno, lymphoma, carcinoid) (Etiology: less common than other GI tract malignancies; Sx: pain, bleeding, wt loss, obstruction; carcinoid→ diarrhea, episodic flushing, wheezing, hypotension)
      • Stomach (adeno, lymphoma) (Rfs: 50, smoking, ETOH abuse, h pylori→ MALT assoc; Sx: feel full when eating ever smaller quantities of food, pain, bleeding)
      • Testicular (seminomas, non-seminomas) (Rfs: typical age 15-30, undescended testicle; Sx: painless, progressive firm nodule; unexplained hydrocele; PE: firm testicle, discrete or diffuse)
      • Thyroid (papillary, follicular, medullary, anaplastic) (Rfs: hx radiation to head/neck, family hx; Sx: typically euthyroid; pt may note thyroid mass or adenopathy, sob or change in voice if spread; PE: thyroid nodules or enlargement; cervical adenopathy if spread)
      • Uterine (endometrial) (Rfs: older age, early menarche, late menoapause, receiving unopposed estrogens, obesity; Sx vague lower abd discomfort, wt loss, progressive, vaginal bleeding; PE: enlarged uterus on exam)
      • Vaginal (squamous) (Rfs: age >50, DES exposure, HPV, smoking; Sx: lower abd/vaginal area pain, vaginal bleeding; PE: vaginal wall abnormality on exam)
      • Other→ any solid structure can have a primary malignancy - though above are the most common
    • Leukemia
        • General Sx: fevers, chills, weight loss, adenopathy, decreased appetite; fatigue/low energy/chronically tired/SOB→ from aneamia, mucocutaneous bleeding→ from low plt; impaired immunity, recurrent infections from→ low numbers or dysfunctional WBCs.
      • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) (Etiology: monoclonal B cell d/o; Rfs: age > 60, male sl > female, agent orange exposure; Sx: often asx x years→ picked up on incidental labs; then fever, sweats, adenopathy, fatigue, wt loss, bleeding, infections; can transform into acute leukemia or lmphoma; can develop auto-immune hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia; PE: as progresses→ adenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly)
      • Chronic myelocytic leukemia (CML) (Etiology: associated w/9:22 chromosome translocation; Rfs: avg age 55-60, radiation, male sl > female; Sx: fatigue, abdominal fullness, f, weats, wt loss; WBCs elevated, often plt too; chronic phase x 3-5y; then accelerated phase w/blast crisis→ infection, bleeding; PE: often splenomegaly)
      • Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) (Etiology: most common acute leukemia in kids; in adults, represents 20% of acute leukemias; RFs: in adults→ male, hx prior radiation or chemo, > age 70, Down's syndrome; Sx: fatigue, sob, weakness, fever, sweats, easy bruising/bleeding; PE: palor, petechiae, echymoses; sometimes adenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)
      • Acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) (Etiology: most common adult acute leukemia; Rfs: male, age > 60, smoking, hx prior chemo or xrt; hx of myelofibrosis, essential thrombocythemia, polycythemia vera; Sx: fatigue, fever, dyspnea, easy bruising; PE: palor, echymoses, petechiae, musocal bleeding; sometimes adenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)
      • Other leukemias
      • Myelofibrosis (Etiology: sometimes have p vera, cml or ET first; Sx: generalized fatigue, night sweats, wt loss, fever; sob, doe→ from anemia; abd discomfort from hepato-splenomegaly→ sites of extra med hematopoeisis; PE: hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)
    • Lymphoma
        • General (Sx: wt loss/decreased appetite sweats, fevers, chills, adenopathy, organomegaly, abdominal fullness; CNS involvement and sx w/NHL; skin involvement w/cutaneous t-cell NHL; PE: generalized adenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, erythroderma,, sometimes focal neurological findings if CNS involvement)
      • Hodgkins (Etiology: 10% of lymphomas; Rfs: age 15-40 & > 55, hiv +, EBV infection, fam hx; Sx: fever, sweats, wt loss, adenopathy; cough/sob if mediastinal invovlmenet; PE: painless, progressive adenopathy, in particular head/neck; sometimes splenomegaly, hepatomegaly)
      • Non-Hodgkins (Etiology: 90% of lymphomas; many different types (B & T cell), significant variability in how aggressive they may be; Rfs: age > 60, hx hiv + confers markedly increased risk aggressive NHL; EBV→ Burkitts; h pylori→ stomach MALT; Sx: f, c, sweats, fatigue, wt loss; PE: progressive, painless, generalized adenopathy; splenomegaly; extra-nodal dz can involve almost any organ system)
    • Multiple Myeloma
      • Rfs: age > 60, hx MGUS; Sx: fatigue, sob, wt loss, doe→ from anemia, renal involvement, hypercalcemia or combinations; bone pain from lytic lesions; infection
    • Myeloproliferative disorders
      • Polycythemia vera (Etiology: primary bone marrow problem→ w/inappropriate RBC production; age onset typically > 50; Sx: hepatic vein or other venous clot in unusual location or otherwise unexplained; mi, stroke, tia, headache, mesenteric ischemia, other arterial insufficiency from sludging; itching exacerbated by hot shower; sometimes bleeding; often picked up incidentally on CBC; PE: ruddy complexion, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly)
      • Chronic myelocytic leukemia (CML) (Etiology: associated w/9:22 chromosome translocation; Rfs: avg age 55-60, radiation, male sl > female; Sx: fatigue, abdominal fullness, f, weats, wt loss; WBCs elevated, often plt too; chronic phase x 3-5y; then accelerated phase w/blast crisis→ infection, bleeding; PE: often splenomegaly)
      • Myelofibrosis (Etiology: sometimes have p vera, cml or ET first; Sx: generalized fatigue, night sweats, wt loss, fever; sob, doe→ from anemia; abd discomfort from hepato-splenomegaly→ sites of extra med hematopoeisis; PE: hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)
    • Myelodysplastic syndrome
      • Rfs: Age > 60, a primary problem or secondary to chemotherapy or other d/o that can affect BM function; Sx: asx until anemia, low plt, or low wbc lead to sx→ fatigue, sob, doe, bleeding, infection; risk of transformation to AML

      Mental Health D/O

      • Depression (Sx: little interest or pleasure in doing things; feeling down depressed or hopeless)
      • Substance abuse

      MSK/Rheum D/O

      • Osteoarthritis (Rfs: age > 50, obesity, prior injury; Sx: chronic pain at site of arthritis, worse when moving or weight bearing on affected joints, slowly progressive, better w/rest) more from CDC
      • Polymyalgia Rheumatica - PMR (Sx/RFs: sub-acute, age > 50, morning shoulder and hip aches, no findings on exam of joint inflammation, no objective findings of weakness)
      • Giant Cell Arteritis (Rfs: age > 50, often prior hx PMR; Sx: fatigue, headache, joint aches, visual loss)
      • Mixed connective tissue d/o (Etiology: rare d/o, cross over between lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis; Sx: fatigue, muscle and joint aches, finger pain after exposure to cold; PE: raynauds → fingers blanch/hurt when exposed to cold temp, sausage-type thickening of fingers)
      • Other vasculitides or automimmune disorders - w/characteristic localizing sx→ Rheumatoid Arthritis, Lupus, etc
      • Chronic fatigue syndrome (Sx: x 6m, no other explanation, not improved w/rest, otherwise unexplained muscle/joint pain, non-refreshing sleep, fatigue lasting 24h after exercise, sore throat, adenopathy) more from CDC
      • Fibromyalgia (Sx: chronic, multi-site muscle and joint pain, fatigue, multiple tender points on palpation, no findings of inflammation, no other etiology uncovered) more from CDC
      • Takayasu's arteritis (Etiology: large vessel vasculitis, onset 10-30yo, Asian background, women > men; Sx: sub-acute and progressive, fevers, fatigue, wt loss, myalgias arthralgias; target organ sx based on affected vessels: abdominal aorta & branches→ abdominal pain, htn; thoracic aorta & branches→ chest pain, sob, tia/stroke; PE: loss of palpable pulses radial, carotid, lower extremity)

      Infectious D/O

      • Chronic
        • HIV (RFs: men having sex w/men, sex w/prostitutes, IVDU, transfusion w/o screening, sexually active, past STI, TB, sex w/anyone w/HIV RFs, sex for money; Sx: wt loss, fatigue, f, sweats, infections typical of t-cell dysfxn→ fungal, mycobacterial, other)
        • TB (Rfs: immunocompromised → malnourished, chronic steroids, known HIV or HIV RFs, malnutrition; chronic kidney, lung or liver dz; dialysis; homeless; healthcare worker, endemic area; Sx: cough x weeks, hemoptysis, wt loss)
        • Hepatitis B (RFs: spread via sexual contact, vertical, shared needles, needle sticks in health care workers, unscreened blood transfusion, ~5% of acute infxn become chronic, long term risk cirrhosis and HCC; incubation period 3m; PE: asx until cirrhosis or HCC; then icterus, jaudice and other findings of chronic liver dz)
        • Hepatitis C (RFs: spread via needles, unscreened blood transfusion, cocaine inhaling tools, needle sticks in health care workers, vertical, sexual; 10-20% resolve; long term risk cirrhosis and HCC; Sx: acute infection generally not recognized, more commonly causes chronic hepatitis; PE: asx until cirrhosis or HCC; then icterus, jaudice and other findings of chronic liver dz)
      • Acute infection - short term fatigue - symptoms based on primary site
      • Sub-acute: endocarditis

      Pulmonary D/O

      • COPD (Rfs: Smoking hx; Sx: SOB, DOE, sputum, acute or chronic, cough, wheezing)
      • Other chronic pulmonary disorders

      Cardiovascular D/O

      • CHF (C/V RFs; Sx: orthopnea, pnd, doe; PE: lower extremity edema , + S3, elevated jvp, displaced pmi, rales on lung exam)
      • Bradycardia (Sx: fatigue, decrease exercise tolerance, sob, lightheaded/presycnope/syncope)
      • SVT - a fib, a flutter, avnrt, WPW (Sx: rapid/irreg heart beat, palpatations; fatigue related to decreased exercise tolerance or CHF)

      GI D/O

      • Bleeding from upper GI source→ anemia
      • Bleeding from lower GI source→ anemia
      • Chronic diarrhea→ malabsorption of nutrients
      • IBD (Etiology: Crohn's dz or ulcerative colitis; Sx: sub-acute, recurrent or chronic; wt loss, bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, nocturnal diarrhea; systemically feeling poorly, presentation can also be fulminant; extraintestinal sx affecting msk, skin, eyes)
      • Chronic liver disease - Hepatitis B & C, ETOH; less common: Wilson's, alpha-1 antytripsin defic, automimmune hepatitis, etc.

      Neurological D/O
