      Neuro disorders more typically cause weakness, numbness, neuropathic pain or other focal sx rather than fatigue. However, some patients may experience weakness as fatigue, or note fatigue as a co-existing complaint
    • Muscle Disease
        • Progressive proximal muscle weakness, no numbness
      • Inflammatory
        • Polymyositis (Etiology: rare, autoimmune; Rfs: female > male, age>20; Sx/PE: symmetrical proximal weakness of arms and legs, develops over weeks to months; neck flexor weakness; no sensory deficits; sometimes pain, though not prominent feature; dysphagia in 1/3; polyarthritis in 45%; PE: symmetric proximal > distal weakness, preserved reflexes)
        • Dermatomyositis (Etiology: autoimmune; Rfs: children and adults, female > male; Sx: weakness that develops over weeks; earliest affected often neck flexors, pectoral muscles, pelvic girdle; can be asymmetric; dysphagia and dysarthria in 1/3; pain not prominent; no sensory deficits, accompanied by rash, proximal; other organ systems affected including cardiac conduction system dz, arthralgias, arthritis, malignancy→ breast, prostate, colon, other; interstitial lung dz; PE: erythematous skin erruption in sun-exposed area, heliotropic rash around eyes→ purplish w/edema, Gottron's papules→ scaly and papular on knuckles, subcutaneous calcifications, progressive weakness, reflexes preserved until late)
        • Inclusion body myositis (Etiology: autoimmune; Rfs: age > 50, male>female; Sx: slowly progressive, weakness w/o pain, no sensory impairment, typically symmetric, distal > proximal, in particular feet and hands, 60% w/dysphagia, 20+% assoc w/connective tissue d/o; PE: progressive weakness, distal > proximal, refelxes diminish w/progression)
      • Metabolic or toxin induced
        • Hypothyroidism (Sx: wt gain, edema, dry skin, constipation, cold intolerance, depression/mood change, weakness, fatigue; PE: often no findings aside from wt gain, sometimes decreased reflexes, edema, bradycardia)
        • Hyperthyroidism (Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, wt loss, weakness; PE: sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid, hyper-reflexia)
        • Steroid induced (Rfs/Etiology: rare, typically from long term glucocorticoid use, cushings disease)
        • Statin induced (Sx: vague ache more than weakness; can occur at any time, rarely rhabdo)
        • Etoh induced
        • Periodic paralysis (Rfs: assoc w/hypokalemia, hyperthyroidism; Sx: episodic profound weakness, consciousness preserved)
        • Low phosphorous
        • Storage d/o - very uncommon
      • Muscular dystrophy (progressive weakness and wasting, onset from early childhood to 20s)
    • Neuromuscular Junction d/o
      • Myasthenia gravis (Sx: subacute, progressive, worse w/repetitive movement, ocular sx→ double vision)
      • Lambert Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) (Etiology: auto-antibody against presynaptic side of nmj; Rfs: male>female, rare, 50% assoc w/malignancy→ in particular lung; can also occur w/other autoimmune dz→ thyroid, RA, vasculitis, other; age ~60 if cancer, 30s & 60s if no malignancy; Sx: progressive weakness over mos, fatigue, proximal muscles > distal, progresses caudal to cranial, eye & facial muscles not typically affected, autonomic dysfxn→ dry mouth, constipation, orthostatic lightheadedness, etc.; no numbness; PE: proximal weakness, diminished or absent reflexes)
      • Botulism (Rfs: exposure to at risk food, black tar heroin; Sx: acute onset→ 8-36h, difficulty swallowing secretions, difficulty breathing or speaking, double vision, abdominal cramps, weakness/paralysis starts w/CNs→ spreads symmetrically to limbs, afebrile)
      • Organophosphate poisoning (Etiology: accidental, intentional or as biological weapon→ Sarin; inhibits cholinesterase; Sx: related to ach excess→ acute confusion, lacrimation, excessive resp secretions, brady, weakness, wheezing)
    • Peripheral nervous system d/o
        • Weakness is usually distal
      • Compression from tumor, infection, fracture, OA, etc→ typically focal deficits, suggestive hx
      • Vasulitis/Autoimmune: 0ften painful, w/motor deficits; typically delays in dx as uncommon
        • CIDP (Sx: symptom onset over 2m, painless, symmetrically decreased sensation, also proximal and distal weakness, upper or lower extremities - or both)
        • Guillain barre (Rfs: past infxn, in partic campy; Sx: numbness/tingling legs and hands; most prominent feature is weakness that is acute, progressive, symmetric, and has an ascending pattern of involvement)
        • Charcot-Marie-Tooth (Rfs: fam hx→ autosomal recessive; Sx: slowly progressive (years) of neuropathic pain, numbness and weakness, distal legs first; PE: muscle wasting, impaired sensation and loss of reflexes on exam)
      • Metabolic processes or nutritional deficiencies
        • DM (Rfs/Etiology: common, hx poorly controlled DM; Sx: stocking glove ascending loss of sensation, may have autonomic dysfxn, loss of reflexes, affects dorsal columns and spinothalamics→ loss of proprioception, sometimes w/pain, otherwise painless)
        • Renal failure (Rfs: advanced renal disease; Sx: often w/pain, symmetric and affects distal lower extremities first→ moving proximal over time, improves w/dialysis and/or transplant)
        • Hypothyroidism (Sx: wt gain, edema, dry skin, constipation, cold intolerance, depression/mood change, weakness, fatigue; PE: often no findings aside from wt gain, sometimes decreased reflexes, edema, bradycardia)
        • B12 (Sx: progressive, legs more common then arms, can be painful, impaired dorsal columns function, gait problems, tongue can be smooth and swollen if severe, s/s anemia if severe)
      • Meds or Toxins
        • Chemotherapeutic agents (Rfs: in particular those containing taxane and platin; INH; Sx: painful
        • Arsenic (Rfs: ingestion of contaminated water→ India, or poisoning; Sx: painful neuropathy; n, v, d, abd pain, confusion)
        • Lead (Etiology: lead based paints or other chronic unintentional ingestions; Sx: abd pain, nausea, constipation, anemia, muscle and joint pain, confusion and cognitive problems, altered sense of tasted, peripheral motor and sensory neuropathy)
        • ETOH (Rfs: long hx etoh abuse; Sx: distal sensory and motor impairment, can be painful)
      • Infection
        • HIV assoc (Rfs: known HIV disease or RFs; Sx: often painful)
        • Leprosy (Rfs: exposure to an endemic area→ Asia, Africa, South America; Sx: painful, slowly progressive, hypo-pigmented patches of skin w/sensory loss, asymmetric, upper or lower extremities)
      • Malignancies
        • Para-neoplastic associated - lung, breast, lymphoma, myeloma, MGUS - often painful
    • CNS d/o
      • Spinal cord/brain tumor, infection, fracture, stroke/vascular insuff, arthritis or other process→ typically cause focal deficits
      • Multiple sclerosis (Rfs/Etiology: white>black, women>men, age onset <30; Sx: affects spinal cord and brain, sub-acute, waxes/wanes, progresses over year/decades, patchy sensory and motor deficits that can affect any of the neuro pathways and don't follow an anatomic pattern, visual disturbances)
    • Mixed CNS & PNS
      • ALS (Rfs: age onset 60s; Sx: progressive over years, upper and lower extremities, fatigue, dysphagia, sob; on exam muscle wasting and fasciculations)
    • Other Neuro d/o
      • Parkinson's (Rfs: age > 70; Sx: pill rolling tremor of hands, sometimes head bobbing tremor, difficulty starting and stopping movements, balance and gait problems, sometimes cognitive decline; PE: characteristic pill-rolling tremor, shuffling gait, masked facies, difficulty getting up and starting movement, difficulty turning)
      • Other neurodegenerative d/o

      Other

      • Chronic liver disease
      • Chronic kidney disease
      • Profound hypokalemia
      • Hypercalcemia
      • Hyponatremia
      • Poor nutrition
      • Deconditioning
      • Meds→ prescribed or illicit (narcotics or benzos can disrupt sleep/wake cycles; meds for ADHD; illicit stimulants→cocaine, crystal)
      • Combinations of any of the above conditions

      Weight Loss?

      Key point: Measure the patient's weight to quantify/confirm weight loss

      Intentional

      • Appropriate→ dieting to achieve a healthier weight
      • Inappropriate→ anorexia (Rfs: women>men; peek onset in 20s; Sx: chronic, hyper-concern about weight and body image→ always believe they are fat, hide eating habits, relentless pursuit of wt loss via diet & exercise; osteoporosis, gerd sx, amenorrhea, infertility, fatigue)
      • Inappropriate → bulimia (Rfs: women>men; peek onset late teens; Sx: chronic, cycles of eating and purging→ vomiting or laxatives; distorted body image; don't necessarily lose wt unless coupled w/anorexia; gerd sx, sore throat; PE: prominent salivary glands, dental decay)

      Unintentional

      Lack of calories

      Rfs: poverty or lack of access to food resources for whatever reason

      Cachexia w/chronic dz

      • Advanced COPD, CHF and CKD can lead to cachexia, a multi-factorial process assoc w/loss of muscle mass, fat stores, weakness & poor prognosis
      • Chronic infections - in particular TB and HIV

      Endocrine dz

      • Hyperthyroidism (Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, wt loss, weakness, infetility, ED, menstrual irreg; PE: sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid, hyper-reflexia, moist skin)
        • Graves Dz (Etiology: autoimmune; RFs: female > male, ages 40-60; most common cause of hyperthyroidism 50-80% of cases; Sx: as above; typically progressive over 2-3m; PE: diffusely enlarged thyroid, sometimes bruit; exopthalmous or other ophthalmopathy in up to 25%; otherwise as above)
        • Painless thyroiditis (Etiology: autoimmune; Rfs: often post partum; Sx: as above, onset over < 3m)
        • Painful thyroiditis (Etiology: often post-viral; Sx: acute, painful thyroid and neck, fatigue; Sx: initially hyperthyroid ~6w, then hypothyroid ~4-6w; may return to euthyroid or remain hypo; PE: painful thryoid)
        • Toxic multi-nodular goiter (Etiology: often in regions of world that are iodine deficient; RFs: age > 50, women > men; Sx: as above, severity and timing onset vary; PE: palpable nodularity)
        • Toxic solitary adenoma (Etiology: idiopathic, single, hyperfunctioning nodule; Rfs> increasing age, women > men; PE: sometimes single palpable nodule)
        • Exogenous thyroid hormone consumption (Etiology: unintentional or intentional over rx in patient w/known hyperthyroidim; surreptitious use of thyroid hormone in someone w/o thyroid dz, perhaps to aid w/weight loss, other)
      • Diabetes - Type 1 (Sx: assoc w/polyuria, polydypsia, fatigue; type 2 more typically assoc w/wt gain)
      • Hypercalcemia
        • Primary hyper-PTH (Sx: usually slowly progressive; assoc w/fractures, renal stones, fatigue, confusion; higher riks w/higher ca2+)
        • Malignancy (Sx: related to primary cancer as well as hyper ca2+ → fatigue, confusion, pain; can be relatively acute, varying w/cancer burden)
        • Vitamin D related(Rfs: increased converstion of 25-OH to 1,25-OH vit D → Sarcoid; Excessive vit D ingestion
        • Meds (HCTZ, vitamin D or ca2+ over dose)
        • Immobility (ca2+ elev usually mild)
      • Low testosterone (Sx: decreased libido, errectile dysfxn, generalized weakness, decreased muscle mass, depression)
        • Primary (Rf/Etiology: testicular hypofunction from: prior infection→ mumps; torsion/trauma/cancer/other reason for testicular death; past chemotherapy; genetic disorders→ prader-willi; PE: sometimes small or absent testes)
        • Secondary (Rf/Etiology: pituitary/hypothalamic dysfxn from: tumor, inflammatory processes, hypoperfusion; meds→ chronic narcotics, LHRH agonists for prostate ca; hemochromatosis; chronic diseases→ HIV, Dm, copd, chf, renal failure, cirrhosis)
      • Cushing's disease (glucocorticoid excess) (Sx: central wt gain→ neck/face/thorax/abd, htn, glucose intol/dm; PE: purple/red striae, easy bruising, buffalo hump, moon face, hyperpigment in mouth/sun exposed areas if acth depen)
      • Adrenal insufficiency (Sx: feeling poorly in general, n, v, orthostatic sx)
        • Primary (Etiology: problem at level of adrenal gland: autoimmune destruction → assoc w/DM 1, celiac dz; hemorrhage/infarct; infection → TB, HIV; infiltration w/tumor; PE: sometimes darkening of mucous membranes, skin folds, & pressure points)
        • Secondary (Etiology: problem at level of pituitary/hypothalamus → low acth; can be from surgery, tumor, hypoperfusion, auto-immune, trauma, meds→ chronic glucocorticoids)

      Prescribed or Illicit drug use

      • Prescribed Rx (Etiology: meds that decrease appetite or increase metabolic rate→ADHD Rx; meds causing nausea, abdominal pain, diarrhea→chemo for cancer, HIV rx, etc)
      • Drug abuse (Etiology: in particular methamphetamines - focus of life and money solely on drug use)

      Oral Pathology

      • Mechanical problems with chewing (Etiology: dental problems → prevent chewing and/or cause pain)
      • Sores/ulcers
        • Squamous cell cancer (RFs: smoking, drinking, chewing tobacco; Pe: slow growing, non-healing ulcer or mass of oral mucosa, edges indurated, lymph nodes firm, stuck to each other & underlying tissue, growing)
        • Candida (Rfs: immuno-supressed→ chemo or hiv, abx exposure, steroids; Pe: white discharge, bleeds when scraped)
        • Apthous ulcer (Sx: acute, painful, self limited; Etiology: can be assoc w/viral infxn, meds, cancer, hiv, or idiopathic; PE: ulcer(s) with surrounding erythema)
        • HSV (pain can precede appearance, worse if immunocmop, can be recurrent; Pe: clear vessicles on red base, small ulcer after uncovered)
        • Behcets dz (Etiology: autoimmune d/o assoc; Sx: waxing & waning sx; painful ulcers in genital region and mouth; eye sx from iritis; also multi-system/systemic sx from vasculitis, arthritis, GI and neuro involvement
        • Mucositis from chemotherapy

      Esophageal d/o

      Cancer

    • Progressive swallowing problems(Sx: food gets stuck, worse w/solids then liquids, pain, patient can often point to level of obstruction)
      • Squamous cell (Etiology: Upper 2/3 of esophagus; RFs: associated with ETOH and smoking, age >50)
      • Adenocarcinoma (Etiology: Lower 1/3 of esophagus; RFs: associated with GERD→ Barret's, age > 50)

      Benign obstruct

      • Zenker's diverticulum (Sx: chronic, bad breath, sensation food stuck in throat/upper esoph, regurgitation undigested food)
      • Esophageal web or ring (Sx: chronic, non-or slowly progressive, sensation of food getting stuck → occurring more w/larger solids)
      • Esophageal stricture (Etiology: long hx gerd or hx caustic ingestion; Sx: sensation of food getting stuck → occurring more w/larger solids, can be progressive if related to chronic inflammatory process)

      Inflammatory

      • GERD (Rfs: assoc w/obesity, ETOH, smoking, caffeine, chocolate, mint; increased BMI, age >50; Sx: chronic/recurrent burning type pain, often worse after meals, worse if lie down after eating, bad taste in mouth, radiates up from epigastrium)
      • Eosinophilic esophagitis (Sx: dysphagia, chest/upper abd pain, food impaction)
      • Pills (Sx: occur soon after incomplete swallowing of pill, patient can often point to spot along esophagus where pain is focused)

      Infection

      • Candidiasis (RFs: often compromised host→ cancer/chemo/hiv; PE: evidence candida in mouth)
      • HSV (RFs: often compromised host→ cancer, chemo, hiv; PE: HSV on exam)

      Dysmotility

      • Achalasia (Sx: progressive dysphagia, solids and liquids, regurgitation, GERD sx, food sticks lower area esophagus)
      • Esophageal spasm (Sx: acute, intermittent pain and difficulty w/swallowing)
      • Eosinophilic esophagitis (RFs: allergies, asthma; Sx: no pain, no response to PPI)
      • American Trypanosomiasis (chagas dz - t cruzi) (Etiology: Central and South America, via reduviid bug bite; incubation 1-2w; Sx: most have no acute sx; if acute sx present, can include→ f, c, sweats, malaise, ha, n, v, d x weeks; chronic sx in 20-30%, including: lower esophageal dysmotility; cardiomyopathy→ CHF, dysrhythmia; PE: rare acute findings: skin nodule at bite; eyelid edema)
      • Scleroderma (RFs: women > men, < 50; Sx: GERD, known scleroderma sx including: skin thickening, raynauds, telangiectasias, sub-cu calcium, etc; PE: skin tightening)

      Stomach Disorders

      • Cancer (Rx: age > 50, smoking, ETOH abuse; Sx: feel full when eating ever smaller quantities of food, epigastic pain)
      • Obstruction from other causes
        • Pyloric stricture (RFs: history ulcer disease, NSAID use, h pylori, hx past gastric surgery; Sx: early satiety, wt loss, n)
        • Extrinsic gastric compression (Etiology: from intra-abdominal mass e.g. profound splenomegaly)
        • Bezoar (Etiology: build up of undigested material that fills stomach and cant be disolved or passed along→ e.g. hair; fills up stomach/takes up space; Sx: slowly progressive sx leading to n, v, wt loss)
      • Dysmotility
        • Gastroparesis from autonomic dysfxn (Rfs: Hx DM w/poor control or other tox/met process; Sx: early satiety, decreased sensation feet/other evidence DM induced neuropathy)

      Abdominal d/o

      • Chronic pancreatitis (Etio: hx multiple episodes prior pancreatitis from any etiology; Sx: chronic epigastric pain, worse w/eating, diarrhea→ malabsobtion)
      • IBD - Crohn's Disease or UC (Sx: sub-acute, recurrent or chronic; wt loss, bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, nocturnal diarrhea; systemically feeling poorly; presentation can also be fulminant)
      • Mesenteric ischemia (RFs: known atherosclerosis or risk factors; Sx: sub-acute, progressive generalized pain w/eating, food avoidance)

      Cancer

      Cancers can cause weight loss by: using up calories, making patient feel poorly in general/decreaing appetite, or interfering w/consumption and absorbtion of nutrients
    • Solid tumors (primary)
      • Anal cancer (squamous cell) (Rfs: assoc w/HPV infection, increased incidence w/anal intercourse, HIV, women, men who have sex w/men; Sx: anal pain, tenesmus, bleeding, pain, obstruction PE: palpable mass or diffuse tissue infiltration around anus)
      • Biliary (cholangiocarcinoma) (Rfs: PSC, other chronic biliary inflammation; Sx: RUQ/epigsatric persistent/progressive discomfort, anorexia, weight loss, jaundice, ictreus, lighter color stools)
      • Bladder or other urothelial (transitional, squamous) (Rfs: smoking hx, male, age > 50, anyline dye exposure→ TCC; chronic foley or schistosomiasis→ SCC; Sx: lower abd/pelvis discomfort, wt loss, hematuria/dysuria, urinary frequency/urgency)
      • Bone - osteoscaroma (Etiology: uncommon; Sx: bone pain, fracture w/o mechanism, wt loss, feeling poorly)
      • Brain - can originate from any CNS tissues→ astrocytoma/glioblastoma, glioma, oligodendroglyoma, medulloblastoma, ependymoma, pituitary/hypothalamic, pinealoma, meningioma (benign) (Sx: progressive, head ache, seizures, feeling poorly, neuro deficits PE: weakness/loss of function, sensory deficits, behavioral changes, etc)
      • Breast (ductal, lobular) (Rfs: women>>>male, can occur any age, though typically > 50, other risk factors: early menarche, late menopause, never pregnant, family hx, past hx breast ca; Sx: patient notes breast mass, nipple retraction, bloody nipple d/c, skin changes; bone, brain lung, or other organ sx if present w/mets; PE: palpable disrete mass, bloody nipple d/c, nipple inversion, skin changes, axillary adenopathy)
      • Cervical (squamous, adeno) (Rfs: smoking, early age first intercourse, multiple sexual partners, hx STIs, hx HPV→ scc, HIV; Sx: vague lower abd discomfort, vaginal bleeding, pain w/intercourse; PE: abnormal cervix on exam)
      • Colorectal (adeno) (Rfs: no prior screening or screening > 10y ago, early family hx, polyposis syndromes, UC or colonic crohn's; Sx: anorexia, weight loss, vague pain, persistent/progressive, bloody stools, change in bowel habits, R sided→ fatigue from anemia, L sided→ obstructive sx; PE: palpable by digital exam if very distal; palpable on abdominal exam if very large or mets, gross blood or guaiac + on digital exam)
      • Esophageal (Sx: progressive swallowing problems, food gets stuck, worse w/solids then liquids, pain, patient can often point to level of obstruction)
        • Squamous Cell (Etiology: upper 2/3 of esophagus; Rfs: ETOH, smoking, age > 50)
        • Adenocarcinoma (Etiology: lower 1/3 of esophagus; Rfs: GERD → Barret's, age > 50)
      • Head and Neck (squamous) (Rfs: smoking, etoh, chewing tobacco, HPV infection; Etiology: typically squamous cell; Sx: present w/ulcers that don't heal in mouth, masses in mouth, difficulty swallowing, neck adenopathy PE: slow growing, non-healing ulcer or mass of oral mucosa, edges indurated, lymph nodes firm, stuck to each other & underlying tissue, growing)
      • Liver (hepatocellular) (Rfs: chronic hepatitis for any reason→ viral, etoh, etc; Sx: RUQ/epigastric persistent/progressive discomfort, anorexia, weight loss; PE: palpable, firm liver if advanced)
      • Lung (Sx: cough, sob/doe, chest pain, hemoptysis, hoarseness, wt loss, f, sweats; other organs if mets at presentation→ brain, liver PE: may have auscutatory findings if involves enough parenchyma, wheezing if affects large airway, findings assoc w/effusion if advanced)
        • Non-small cell (Rfs: more common, smoking assoc, asbestos exposure)
        • Small cell (Etiology: 10-15% of lung ca, more chemo responsive than non-small cell; RFs: smoking & asbestos exposure)
      • Melanoma (Rfs: fair skin, fair hair, prior melanoma, dysplastic moles, family hx, hx blistering sun burns, immunocompromised; Sx/PE: asymmetric, bleeds, irregular borders, non-homogeneous pigment, grows, doesn't heal, reginal adenopathy if spread, sx related to mets to brain, lung, liver)
      • Mesothelioma (Etiology: secondary to asbestos exposure from mining, work w/insulation→ pipes, brakes, ship building; or family exposed to clothing of those who worked direclty w/asbestos; Sx: causes pleural disease & effusion w/SOB, chest wall pain)
      • Metastatic disease→ almost any solid organ can have a met from cancer elsewhere
      • Ovarian (epithelial) (Rfs: age > 50, fam hx breast/ovarian, nulliparity, obesity; Sx: vague, progressive, abdominal/pelvic fullness/discomfort, constipation, bloating, anoexia, nausea increased girth if malignant ascites, irregular vaginal bleeding; PE: palpably enlarged ovary if advanced)
      • Pancreatic (adeno) (Rfs: male, age > 50, chronic pancreatitis, smoking, family hx; Sx: epigastric area, anorexia, weight loss, epigastric pain radiating to back, persistent/progressive, sometimes diarrhea; PE: palpable mass from primary or met if advanced; jaundice if affecting head of pnacreas and obstructing CBD)
      • Prostate (adeno) (Sx: asx early, can cause urgency, frequency, delayed emptying, hematuria; bone pain if mets; PE: nodular, firm prostate)
      • Renal cell (Rfs: smoking, obesity, family hx, male; avg age ~mid 60s; Sx: low back to lower abd/groin discomfort, wt loss, sweats, fever, flank pain, hematuria; PE: papable only if very advanced)
      • Sarcoma (soft tissue) (Etiology: uncommon; Sx: relatively uncommon malignancies, growing mass that arises from muscle/other tissue, other sx based on growth/interference w/adjacent structures)
      • Small bowel (adeno, lymphoma, carcinoid) (Etiology: less common than other GI tract malignancies; Sx: pain, bleeding, wt loss, obstruction; carcinoid→ diarrhea, episodic flushing, wheezing, hypotension)
      • Stomach (adeno, lymphoma) (Rfs: 50, smoking, ETOH abuse, h pylori→ MALT assoc; Sx: feel full when eating ever smaller quantities of food, pain, bleeding)
      • Testicular (seminomas, non-seminomas) (Rfs: typical age 15-30, undescended testicle; Sx: painless, progressive firm nodule; unexplained hydrocele; PE: firm testicle, discrete or diffuse)
      • Thyroid (papillary, follicular, medullary, anaplastic) (Rfs: hx radiation to head/neck, family hx; Sx: typically euthyroid; pt may note thyroid mass or adenopathy, sob or change in voice if spread; PE: thyroid nodules or enlargement; cervical adenopathy if spread)
      • Uterine (endometrial) (Rfs: older age, early menarche, late menoapause, receiving unopposed estrogens, obesity; Sx vague lower abd discomfort, wt loss, progressive, vaginal bleeding; PE: enlarged uterus on exam)
      • Vaginal (squamous) (Rfs: age >50, DES exposure, HPV, smoking; Sx: lower abd/vaginal area pain, vaginal bleeding; PE: vaginal wall abnormality on exam)
      • Other→ any solid structure can have a primary malignancy - though above are the most common
    • Leukemia
        • General Sx: fevers, chills, weight loss, adenopathy, decreased appetite; fatigue/low energy/chronically tired/SOB→ from aneamia, mucocutaneous bleeding→ from low plt; impaired immunity, recurrent infections from→ low numbers or dysfunctional WBCs.
      • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) (Etiology: monoclonal B cell d/o; Rfs: age > 60, male sl > female, agent orange exposure; Sx: often asx x years→ picked up on incidental labs; then fever, sweats, adenopathy, fatigue, wt loss, bleeding, infections; can transform into acute leukemia or lmphoma; can develop auto-immune hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia; PE: as progresses→ adenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly)
      • Chronic myelocytic leukemia (CML) (Etiology: associated w/9:22 chromosome translocation; Rfs: avg age 55-60, radiation, male sl > female; Sx: fatigue, abdominal fullness, f, weats, wt loss; WBCs elevated, often plt too; chronic phase x 3-5y; then accelerated phase w/blast crisis→ infection, bleeding; PE: often splenomegaly)
      • Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) (Etiology: most common acute leukemia in kids; in adults, represents 20% of acute leukemias; RFs: in adults→ male, hx prior radiation or chemo, > age 70, Down's syndrome; Sx: fatigue, sob, weakness, fever, sweats, easy bruising/bleeding; PE: palor, petechiae, echymoses; sometimes adenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)
      • Acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) (Etiology: most common adult acute leukemia; Rfs: male, age > 60, smoking, hx prior chemo or xrt; hx of myelofibrosis, essential thrombocythemia, polycythemia vera; Sx: fatigue, fever, dyspnea, easy bruising; PE: palor, echymoses, petechiae, musocal bleeding; sometimes adenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)
      • Other leukemias
      • Myelofibrosis (Etiology: sometimes have p vera, cml or ET first; Sx: generalized fatigue, night sweats, wt loss, fever; sob, doe→ from anemia; abd discomfort from hepato-splenomegaly→ sites of extra med hematopoeisis; PE: hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)
    • Lymphoma
        • General (Sx: wt loss/decreased appetite sweats, fevers, chills, adenopathy, organomegaly, abdominal fullness; CNS involvement and sx w/NHL; skin involvement w/cutaneous t-cell NHL; PE: generalized adenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, erythroderma,, sometimes focal neurological findings if CNS involvement)
      • Hodgkins (Etiology: 10% of lymphomas; Rfs: age 15-40 & > 55, hiv +, EBV infection, fam hx; Sx: fever, sweats, wt loss, adenopathy; cough/sob if mediastinal invovlmenet; PE: painless, progressive adenopathy, in particular head/neck; sometimes splenomegaly, hepatomegaly)
      • Non-Hodgkins (Etiology: 90% of lymphomas; many different types (B & T cell), significant variability in how aggressive they may be; Rfs: age > 60, hx hiv + confers markedly increased risk aggressive NHL; EBV→ Burkitts; h pylori→ stomach MALT; Sx: f, c, sweats, fatigue, wt loss; PE: progressive, painless, generalized adenopathy; splenomegaly; extra-nodal dz can involve almost any organ system)
    • Multiple Myeloma
      • Rfs: age > 60. hx MGUS; Sx: fatigue, sob, wt loss, doe→ from anemia, renal involvement, hypercalcemia or combinations; bone pain from lytic lesions; infection
    • Myeloproliferative disorders
      • Polycythemia vera (Etiology: primary bone marrow problem→ w/inappropriate RBC production; age onset typically > 50; Sx: hepatic vein or other venous clot in unusual location or otherwise unexplained; mi, stroke, tia, headache, mesenteric ischemia, other arterial insufficiency from sludging; itching exacerbated by hot shower; sometimes bleeding; often picked up incidentally on CBC; PE: ruddy complexion, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly)
      • Chronic myelocytic leukemia (CML) (Etiology: associated w/9:22 chromosome translocation; Rfs: avg age 55-60, radiation, male sl > female; Sx: fatigue, abdominal fullness, f, weats, wt loss; WBCs elevated, often plt too; chronic phase x 3-5y; then accelerated phase w/blast crisis→ infection, bleeding; PE: often splenomegaly)
      • Myelofibrosis (Etiology: sometimes have p vera, cml or ET first; Sx: generalized fatigue, night sweats, wt loss, fever; sob, doe→ from anemia; abd discomfort from hepato-splenomegaly→ sites of extra med hematopoeisis; PE: hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)
    • Myelodysplastic syndrome
      • Rfs: Age > 60, a primary problem or secondary to chemotherapy or other d/o that can affect BM function; Sx: asx until anemia, low plt, or low wbc lead to sx→ fatigue, sob, doe, bleeding, infection; risk of transformation to AML

      Chronic autoimmune

        Chronic auto-immune/inflammatory conditions - specific processes identified via hx and characteristic symptoms

      Chronic Infections

      • HIV (Etiology/Rfs: hiv risk factors→ men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/somone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; risks of unusual infection increase as CD4 declines - see organ specific sx) more from CDC
      • TB (Rfs: immunocompromised → malnourished, chronic steroids, known HIV or HIV RFs, malnutrition; endemic area; Sx: cough x weeks, hemoptysis, wt loss)
      • Entamoeba histolytica → amebiasis (protozoa) (Rfs: acquired via unclean water/poor sanitation, also anal intercourse; Sx: only 10-20% develop sx; incubation 2-4w; abd pain, bloody diarreha; wt loss more common if develope liver abscess)
      • Chronic liver or lung abcess - which can be insidious

      Other Malabsorptive D/O

      All are assoc w/diarrhea
      • Ulcerative colitis (Etiology: automimmune, genetic, environmentally triggered, other; affects colon, distal to prox; Rfs: Northen Europeans, North Americans; smoking and appendectomy protective; peak onset 15-30; Sx and PE: sub-acute, recurrent or chronic diarrhea; fatigue, wt loss, bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, nocturnal diarrhea, feeling poorly overall; spectrum from mild to severe; extra-GI: aphtous ulcers, erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosa, peripheral arthritis, ankylosing spond/sacroiliitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, eye sx→ episcleritis/scleritis/uveitis) More from CDC
      • Crohn's disease (Etiology: automimmune, genetic, environmentally triggered, other; transmural involvement; can affect anywhere in GI tract mouth-to-anus; Rfs: smoking and appendectomy increase risk; Northern Europeans and North Americans; peak onset 15-30; Sx: sub-acute, diarrhea→ though can be less prominent than w/UC, nocturnal diarrhea, sometimes bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, fever, abd pain, fatigue, wt loss, feeling poorly overall, fistulas, bowel obstruction, peri-rectal dz; spectrum of sx and findings; PE: sometimes abd mass; peri-rectal disease; extra-GI: aphtous ulcers, erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosa, peripheral arthritis, ankylosing spond/sacroiliitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, eye sx→ episcleritis/scleritis/uveitis) More from CDC
      • Celiac disease (Sx: bloating, gas, wt loss/inability to gain weight, chronic symptoms, oligo or polyarticular arthritis, painful peripheral neuropathy)
      • Chronic pancreatitis (Rfs: multiple past episodes pancreatitis, ETOH abuse or other chronic exposure to pancreatitis inducing toxins/process; Sx: chronic upper abdominal pain, back pain, n, v, bloating, stools difficult to flush)
      • Lactose intolerance (n, bloating, gas, abd discomfort → within few hours eating milk/milk products)
      • Whipple's disease (Sx: rare d/o, chronic diarrhea, wt loss, abd pain, male>female, fatigue, joint pain)
      • Laxative, sorbitol, use/abuse; excessive caffeine intake
      • Bacterial overgrowth s/p gastric bypass (Sx: bloating, gas, steatorrhea, non-specific discomfort)
      • Short gut after resection of large amount of small bowel

      Neuro d/o

      • Stroke (Rfs: htn, fam hx, smoking, dm, past stroke, hyperlipidemia: problems w/initiating swallowing, hx aspiration; PE: cranial nerve deficits, rigidity, hyper-reflexia, other focal cns findings)
      • Any neuro d/o that interferes w/ability to put food in mouth, swallow, or digest

      Other Med Cond

      Many medical conditions affect appetite directly, cause nause, etc.
      • Anosmia→ can't smell normally, which affects taste
      • Chronic or acute kidney disease
      • Chronic or acute liver disease
      • Other chronic medical conditions
      • Depression, psychiatric illness

      Weight gain?

      Key point: Measure the patient's weight to quantify/confirm weight gain
      • Typical obesity (Etiology: relative inactivity, excess calories, superimposed on native metabolic rate, genetic predispositions; secondary causes uncommon: endocrine→ cushings, congenital→ Prader-Willi; Sx: sob/doe from deconditiong, cardiovascular dz, fatigue from osa, joint pain from osteoarthritis; PE: BMI > 30, OSA risk increased w/neck circumference >17in men, 16in women; osa risk increased if cant see back of throat) more from CDC
      • Fluid retention
        • CHF (Rfs: known vascular dz, htn, dm, smoking, hyperlipidemia, etc; Sx: orthopnea, PND, sob, doe; PE: lower extremity edema , + S3, elevated jvp, displaced pmi, rales on lung exam)
        • Cirrhosis (Rfs: known chronic liver disease w/portal hypertension; Pe: leg swelling and other findings assoc w/chronic liver disease)
        • Advanced kidney disease
        • Edema from meds→ minoxidil, di-hydropyridine calcium channel blockers, glucocorticoids, etc
      • Hypothyroidism (Sx: wt gain, edema, dry skin, constipation, cold intolerance, depression/mood change, weakness, fatigue; PE: often no findings aside from wt gain, sometimes decreased reflexes, edema, bradycardia)
      • Cushing's disease (glucocorticoid excess) (Sx: central wt gain→ neck/face/thorax/abd, htn, glucose intol/dm; PE: purple/red striae, easy bruising, buffalo hump, moon face, hyperpigment in mouth/sun exposed areas if acth depen)
      • Meds
        • Insulin and other diabetes rx
        • Anabolic steroid use (Rfs: often young men, desire to gain muscle mass/strength→ sports performance or appearance Sx: rapid gain in muscle mass and strength, incresaed aggression, sudden increase sports performance, mood swings, worsening of acne)
      • Social and Economic factors (Etiology: Healthier food choices often cost more, which limits access for many. Well stocked super markets are not universally available. Safe places for physical activity may be limited in urban/other environments)
      • Depression, psychiatric illness
      • Other: Pregnancy, menopause, occult intra-abd malignancy→ ovary, uterus

      Unexplained fractures?

      Sex specific risk factors

      Fractures from osteoporosis most common in older patients, though attn to bone health relevant @ any age. Osteoporosis w/o fracture is asx, though can be detected by screening at risk populations. Osteoporosis related fractures (spine, hips, extremities) often occur w/minimum trauma (insufficiency fx)
      • Women (Rfs: age > 65, post menopausal, onset menoapause <45, hx prior osteoporosis related fx, first degree relative w/osteoporosis related fx, low body weight, smoking, hx falls or risk for falls, frailty, dementia, inactivity)
      • Men (Rfs: age > 70, family hx, low body weight, prior osteoporotic fracture, inactivity, smoking, low testosterone, hx falls or risk for falls, frailty, dementia, hx prostate ca & receiving rx to lower testosterone)

      Metabolic contributors

      • Low calcium intake, low vitamin D levels
      • Hyperparathyroidism, hyperthyroidism, chronic kidney disease, celiac dz, multiple myeloma, other chronic inflammatory d/o, eating d/o
      • Pathologic fx (Etiology: underlying cancer, infection or other process that weakens bones; Sx: acute pain and fx w/minimal or less than expected force)

      Toxins or meds

      • Chronic steroid use, chronic ETOH abuse, chemotherapy

      Connective tissue d/o

      • Osteogenesis imperfecta or other rare congenital d/o that lead to poor quality bone (Etiology: uncommon, sometimes family hx; Sx: long hx fractures from childhood, typically w/low force; must exclude child abuse or other metabolic contributors)

      More Info About Endocrine Disorders:
      National Endocrine and Metabolic Diseases Clearinghouse

      Back

      Infectious Diseases

      Known disease?

      • TB, HIV, endocarditis, chronic hepatitis B or C, immune compromised state, other
        • acute or chronic infections, etc

      Bacteria

      Aerobes: GNR & GNC

    • Gram negative rods
      • Acinetobacter (Site: wounds, urine, lung; Etiology: usually hospital acquired; not typically pathogenic for healthy hosts) more from CDC
      • Bacillary angiomatosis (bartonella sp) (Site: skin; Rfs: occurs in HIV infected or otherwise compromised pts; Sx/PE: nodules on skin, resemble Kaposis Sarcoma) more from CDC
      • Bartonella henslae (cat scratch) (Sites: skin and lymph nodes; Rfs/Etiology: caused by cat scratch; Sx: may see inflamation at innoculation site, then tender regional adenopathy w/in few weeks, fatigue, fever) more from CDC
      • Brucella (Sites: systemic; Etiology: ingestion of raw/uncooked dairy or handling infected animals; Rfs: veterinarians, meat packers, slaughter house workers, farmers; Middle East, Mediterranean, Mexico, Africa; Sx/PE: causes weeks/months of recurrent f, c, sweats, arthritis, adenopathy, orchitis, hepato-splenomegaly) more from CDC
      • Campylobacter (Site: small bowel; Etiology: spread thru contaminated food; Sx: d, n, v, cramps, often w/bloody stools; incubation 2-5d; typically self limited to 1w) more from CDC
      • Citrobacter (Site: urine most common; then biliary tree, peritoneum, respiratory, intravasc, other; Rfs/Etiology: often hospital acquired, compromised/ill host)
      • Donavanosis (granualoma inguinale) (Site: genital regions; Rfs: tropics & not in US unless travel, spread by direct sexual contact, can be hard to distinguish from chancroid, similar RFs for HIV; Sx/PE: incubation 1-3m, papule to painless ulcer in genital area, beefy red/bleeds, develops over weeks)
      • E coli (Sites: urinary tract, abdominal/pelvic/peri-rectal infection and abscess; O157:H7 causes enteritis and HUS) more from CDC
      • Eikenella (E Corrodens) (RFs: lives in human mouthrarr; assoc w/human bite; Sites: hands, arms or anyplace that bite occurs; rarely endocarditis→ HACEK organism; Sx: acute pain, redness, swelling, pain w/movement of fingers if tenosynovitis; subacute f, c if endocarditis; PE: wound where bite occurred, redness, warmth, fluctuance if abscess; persistent pain and drainage w/deeper infection of soft tissue or bone; streaky erythema w/lymphangitis; murmur if endocarditis)
      • Enterobacter (Sites: biliary tract, urinary tract, abdominal/pelvic/peri-rectal infection or abscesses; in hospitalized patients→ pneumonia, wound infection, uti)
      • Extended spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL) producing organisms (Sites: infects urine, wounds, other; RFs/Etiology: GNRs including enterobacter, e coli, klebsiella; an emerging hospital acquired infxn amongst those who are severely ill, having typically received abx prior)
      • Francisella tularensis (tularemia) (Sites: skin, lymph nodes, lung; Etiology/Rfs: passed from dying wild animals to humans via ticks/insects, US Southeast and Rocky Mtns; Sx: f, c, ha, oral or skin ulcers, painful adenopathy, sob, muscle aches) more from CDC
      • H ducreyi (chancroid) (Site: genital region; Rfs: Africa/Caribean & not in US unless travel, spread by direct sexual contact, similar RFs for HIV; Sx/PE: incubation 1d-2w, papule to painless ulcer in genital area, adenopathy) more from CDC
      • Haemophilus influenza (Sites: upper and lower respiratory tract, cns; RFs: much less common since widespread use of vaccine; increased risk s/p splenectomy; Sites: pneumonia, otitis media, epiglottitis, meningitis) more from CDC
      • HACEK (Haemophilus, Actinobacillus, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, Kingella) organisms (Sites: systemic bacteremia→ endocarditis; Sx: typically sub-acute→ f, c, malaise x weeks)
      • Helicobacter pylori (Site: stomach; Etiology: lives in stomach, often asx; Sx: common cause of stomach ulcers→ epigastric pain, n, v, hematemesis) more from CDC
      • Klebsiella (Sites: pneumonia, wound infection→ hospital acquired infections; Rfs: hospitalized patients, compromised hosts) more from CDC
      • Legionella (Rfs: acquired via inhalation; grows in colonized water collection systems, cooling towers, nebs, whirlpools, etc; Site: community acquired pneumonia; also hospital acquired if water contaminated; Sx: acute cough, sputum, f, c, d, confusion) more from CDC
      • Morganella Morganii (Rf: debilitated/chronically ill patients, hospitalized, prior abx, urinary catheters; high rates resistance; Sites: urinary tract→ can form urinary stones, surgical sites, chronic wounds, intravascular, snake bites)
      • Pertussis (Bordatella Pertussis) (Site: upper airwary; rarely lung; Rfs/Etiology: easily spread; vax of kids and re-vax of adults preventive; kids can have airway compromise due to small size; incubation avg 7-10d; Sx: catarrhal stage 1-2w→ cold sx, sometimes low grade T; then paroxysmal stage→ characteristic whooping cough, post-tussive vomiting; then convaslescent stage→ adults present w/persistent cough x 6-10 weeks) more from CDC
      • Pasturella (P multocida) (RFs: lives in mouths of dogs and cats→ assoc w/bites; Sites: hands, arms or anyplace that bite occurs; Sx: acute pain, redness, swelling, pain w/movement of fingers if tenosynovitis; PE: puncture wounds, redness, warmth, fluctuance if abscess; persistent pain and drainage w/deeper infection of soft tissue or bone; streaky erythema w/lymphangitis)
      • Proteus (Sites: common cause of urinary tract infection, can contribute to stone formation; wound infections in hospitalized patients)
      • Pseudomonas (Sites: lung; bacteremia in patients w/neutropenia, abdominal/pelvic abscesses, wound infection in patients w/DM; wound and urinary infections hospitalized/compromised pts; osteomyelitis; otitis externa in patients w/DM; Rfs: brochiectasis, cystic fibrosis, DM, chemotherapy w/neutropenia, chronic illness or otherwise compromised host)
      • Salmonella typhi (typhoid fever) (Site: small bowel, systemic infxn; Etiology: related to poor sanitation→ outbreaks, travel to endemic areas, spread by contaminated/unwashed food, poor sanitation, unclean water; gall bladder can act as reservoir; Rfs: from endemic area or travel; Sx/PE: relapsing daily fever x weeks, malaise, ha, chills, abd pain, diarrhea, maculop-pap rash→ rose spots, relative brady; aside from fever, sx quite variable)
      • Salmonella (non-typhoidal) (Site: small bowel; Rfs: exposure from eggs, chicken, turtles; most recover in 4-7d; Site: small bowel; Sx: d, n, v, cramps, often w/bloody stools, incubation 12h to 3d; rarely can spread to distant sites in compromised hosts→ osteomyelitis, endovascular, other) more from CDC
      • Serratia (Sites: common cause of hospital acquired infections, compromised hosts: pneumonia, wound infection, uti)
      • Shigella (Site: small bowel; Etiology: spread person to person or from food; Site: small bowel; Sx: d, n, v, cramps, often w/bloody stools, avg incubation 3d; typically self limited to 4-7d) more from CDC
      • Vibrio cholera (Site: small bowel; Etiology/Rfs: toxin mediated profound watery diarrhea, related to exposure to unclean water sources, often s/p natural disasters→ presents as epidemics; Sx: profound watery diarrhea; can lead to hypovolemic death in hours if severe) more from CDC
      • Vibrio vulnificus and parahemolytics (Rfs/Sites: causes bacteremia→ sepsis in hosts w/cirrhosis or otherwise compromised hosts, exposure via raw/under cooked shellfish; wound/skin infection if same hosts exposed via inoculation w/affected water→ walking in surf w/exposed wounds in endemic area; Sx: acute n, v, f, cramps, diarrhea; extremity pain and swelling if via wound) more from CDC
      • Yersinia enterocolitica (Site: small bowel; Etiology: spread via contaminated food; Sx: f, c, cramps, bloody diarrhea; incubation 4-7d; typically self limited to 4-7d) more from CDC
      • Yersinia pestis (plague) (Site: respiratory tract; skin; Rf/Etiology: passed from rodents to humans by fleas, direct contact w/feces, or respiratory droplets; Sx: rapid onset f, c, sepsis, pneumonia; erythema, edema, tender aenopathy) more from CDC
    • Gram negative cocci
      • Neisseria meningitidis (Site: meninges, bacteremia; Rfs: often in outbreaks amongst young adults living in close quarters→ college dorms, barracks; unvaccinated; Sx: f, c, ha, n, v, sepsis; PE: very ill, ha, f, neck pain/stiffness, purpura) more from CDC
      • Neisseria gonorrhea (Site: urethra, cervix, uterus, fallopian tubes, testes, pharynx, ano-rectal, joints; Rfs: sexual activity; PE: penile d/c, cervical d/c, cervical pain and uterine pain if PID; pharyngeal inflammation; anorectal d/c; if disseminated→ pustules, infectious arthritis) more from CDC
      • Moraxella (Sites: otitis media; bronchitis in copd exacerbation; pneumonia in COPD; Sx: cough, sob, f, sputum)

      Aerobes: GPC & GPR

    • Gram positive cocci
      • Staph aureus: coag + (Sites/Sx: skin infection, abscess, wound infection; osteomyelitis via direct extension; arthritis; bacteremia, with seeding of abnormal or artificial valves, joints or devices; virulent w/rapid destruction valves/death w/in hours/days; toxic shock→ often no apparent primary, severe & rapidly progressive illness, macular erruption; pneumonia following viral infection; toxin based food poisoning→ n/v hours after exposure, others affected who ate same; PE: cellulitis→ redness, warmth, induration, skin abscess→ focal redness and fluctuance)
      • Staph aureus: coag - (Sites: skin infection, abscess, wound infection; bacteremia, w/seeding of abnormal or artificial valves, joints or devices; overall less virulent than coag +; PE: cellulitis, skin abscess)
      • Methicillin Resistant Saph Aureus (MRSA) (Sites: skin infection, abscess; bacteremia, w/seeding of abnormal or artificial valves, joints or devices, can be hospital or community acquired; healthcare assoc pna; PE: cellulitis, skin abscess) more from CDC
      • Streptococcus: Group A (strep pyogenes) (Sites: cellulitis/lymphangitis; skin abscess; erysipelas; impetigo, throat infections→ acute pain, f, adenopathy; scarlet fever → high temp, rash, palatal petchiae, throat sx; necrotizing fasciits; PE: strep throat→ pharyngeal erythema, d/c, adenop, necrotizing fasciitis, red streaking from lymphangitis) more from CDC
      • Streptococcus: Group B (strep agalactiae) (Sites: endometritis, meningitis, bacteremia, neonatal infection) more from CDC
      • Streptococcus: Group D (enterococcus) (Sites: urinary tract infection, pelvic/abd abscess, wound/other infxn in chronically ill/hospitalized patients)
      • Streptococcus Viridans (Etiology: mouth flora, bacteremia via dental procedure; Sites and Sx: endocarditis→ subacute w/sx f, c, malaise x weeks)
      • Streptococcus Pneumoniae (pneumococcus)(Sites: pneumonia, upper respiratory infections, meningitis; bacteremia if severe; Rfs: s/p splenectomy or fxnl asplenia, eldery and very young, any chronic medical condition→ copd, liver or renal dz, chf, cancer, diabetes, HIV, or otherwise immunocompromised; also csf leaks, cochlear implants; decreased risk if vaccinated) more from CDC
      • Streptococcus Bovis (non-enterococcal Group D) (Etiology: associated w/colon cancer, which may be otherwise unknown at time of infection; Sites: bacteremia, endocarditis)
      • Vancomycin resistant eterococcus (VRE) (Sites and Rfs: hospital acquired infection, affecting those w/multi-system illness; can cause wound, urinary, respiratory infections) more from CDC
    • Gram positive rods
      • Anthrax (Etiology: acquired from animal exposure or biological weapon; Sx: inhalation: cough, f, c, pneumonia sepsis; cutaneous: ulcer to eshcar w/surrounding edema) more from CDC
      • Corynebacterium (diptheroid) (Site: Skin infxn→ eyrthrasma; diptheroids not typically pathogenic; Sx: chronic infection; groin, underarm, skin folds; more common in diabetics & obese patients; often mistaken for tinea; PE: reddish patch, sometimes scaly, sometimes itchy, sharp borders)
      • Diptheria (Site: upper respiratory tract; Sx: cough, f, sore throat, uncommon now w/vax; PE: pseudo-membrane w/airway obstruction) more from CDC
      • Listeria (Site: bacteremia, CNS; Etiology: contaminated food; RFs: older persons, newborns, pregnant, immunocompromised; Sx: f, c, d, n, aches; ha, neck stiffness→ meningitis) more from CDC
      • T Whipplei (Whipple's disease) (Etiology: possibly sewage, fecal oral spread; RFs: male>female, age 40-60; Sx: rare d/o, multipple chronic sx; wt loss, diarrhea, abd pain, fatigue; intermitent migratory arthritis that sometimes precedes GI sx x years, involves larger joints→ knees, wrists, ankles; f, adenopathy; broad range neuro sx→ cog impairment, uveitis, ha, supranuclear ophthalmoplegia, other; also skin, cardiac, pulmonary)

      Anaerobes

      Anaerobes (GN or GP) (Often associated with mixed/complex infections/abscesses of abdomen, pelvis, lung, mouth)
      • Bacteroides fragilis (GNR) (Sites: along w/GNRs→ contributes to abdominal/pelvic, lung abscesses)
      • Clostridium Perfringes (GPR) (Etiology: most common cause food born diarrhea→ undercooked meat, other who ate same ill simultaneously, resolves in 24h; can contribute to nec fasciitis; Sx: cramps, diarrhea, 6-18h after ingestion, contribute to abd/pv abscess; NEC in neonates; PE: deep tissue infection from necrotizing faciitis) more from CDC
      • Clostridium Difficile (GPR) (Etiology: antibiotic associated colitis; toxin based; Rfs: can occur after any abx, also passed to patients in houspital via healthcare workers; Sx: cramps, diarrhea, severe pain and sepsis if advanced) more from CDC
      • Clostridium Tetani (GPR) (Etiology: exposure via contaminated wounds; toxin mediated; vaccination markedly decreases incidence dz w/50 cases/y US; Sx: ~1w incubation, increased tone in jaw muscles, dysphagia, diffuse musle pain/spasms, sweating, airway compromise; PE: fever, tachycardia, elevated bp, lock jaw, severe muscle spasm) more from CDC
      • Clostridium Botulinum (GPR) (Etiology: food/wound born toxin, black tar heroin; Sx: incubation 1-2d, rapid descending symmetric paralysis starting w/cranial nerves, dizziness, dry mouth, bouble vision, blurred vision, no sensory deficits, agitation, resp failure, death) more from CDC
      • Peptostreptococus (GPC) (Sites: lives in mouth, contributes to mixed oral/lung infxns/abscess)

      Other bacteria

      • Actinomyces (Sites: oral/neck/face, other organ systems Sx: slow growing abscess, often w/sinus tract development)
      • Chlamydia trachomatis (sti) (Sites: urethra, cervix, uterus, fallopian tubes, testes; Etiology: urethritis, epididymo-orchitis, cervicitis, PID; Sx: cervical or urethral d/c, vaginal bleeding; PID→ lower abd pain, f; women often asx; PE: cervicitis→ purulent cervical d/c, friable cervix; PID→ cervical d/c, cervical motion tenderness, adnexal pain, uterine pain; men→ urethral d/c, testicular/epididymal swelling & pain if testic involvement) more from CDC
      • Chlamydia trachomatis (lymphogranuloma venereum) (Site: Genital region; Etiology: spread by sexual contact, rare in US, Rfs: same as for HIV; Sx: incubation 1-3 weeks, painless papule or ulcer on penis/vagina/rectal area, then painful adenopathy) more from CDC
      • Chlamydia trachomatis (trachoma) (Site: eye; Etiology: spread thru poor hand hygiene, sharing towels, or via flies, endemic in poor/developing countries, a leading cause blindeness world-wide; Sx: chronic, purulent conjunctivitis, can lead to scarring of lid→ inward turned lashes→ scarring of cornea→ blindness) more from CDC
      • Chlamydia pneumoniae (Site: upper resp tract and lung→ atypical cmnty acquired pna; Sx: sore throat, fever, non-productive cough) more from CDC
      • Chlamydia psittaci (psitacosis) (Site: lung; Etiology: spread by exposure to parrots & sometimes other birds Sx: 1-2 week incubation; fever, cough, severe HA; other organ systems as well) more from CDC
      • Mycoplasma pneumoniae (Etiology: common cause CAP; also upper resp tract infxn; Sx: acute f, c, cough, upper resp sx; not usually severe) more from CDC
      • Nocardia (Sites: lung, skin; Etiology: lives in soil, inhaled or via open wound; Sx: w/pneumonia→ subacute cough, sob; f, abscess, cellulitis, lymphangitis if direct inoculation) more from CDC

      Viruses

    • Respiratory
      • Adeno (Etiology/Site: cause of upper respiratory infxn→ common cold, conjunctivitis, otitis media; Sx: cough, nasal congestion, sore throat, ear pain, conjunctival inflamation; much less commonly pneumonia; PE: throat redness, conjunctivitis, anterior auricular adenopathy) more from CDC
      • Enterovirus (non-polio) (Etiology: passed fecal-oral, close contact, ingesting infected water; Site: brain→ meningitis & encephalitis, oral mucosa and skin→ hand/foot/mouth dz, heart→ myocarditis and pericarditis; conjunctiva→ conjunctivitits; upper resp tract; Sx: most have mild illness; w/more severe dz→ fever, ha, cough, runny nose, muscle aches, confusion) more from CDC
      • Hanta (Etiology: rodent exposure, incubation 3-4d; Sx: f, myalgias, HA, n, v, abd pain; then rapidly progressive resp sx) more from CDC
      • Herpes simplex pneumonia (Etiology: can be primary or reactivation; Sites: typically oral, genital or cns; rarely pna; Rfs: passed by sexual or oral contact; Sx/PE: cough, sob, confusion, oral area vesicles)
      • Influenza (Etiology: common cause upper and lower respiratory infection; Rfs: seasonal in North America Oct to April, increase risk amongst old, young, pregnant, chronic lung disease, any chronic illness, no vaccination; Sx: abrupt onset of myalgias, arthralgias, fever, chills) more from CDC
      • Measels (rubeola) (Etiology: spread thru resp droplets, highly contagious; Rfs: too young to be vaccinated (<1y), or never vaccinated; winter/spring in US; Sx: incubation 7-14d; cough, high f, malaise; rash 4-5d after sx onset; PE: conjunctivitis, runny nose, then white (Koplick's) spots on oral mucosa, then rash; complications include encephalitis, pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Middle Eastern Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) (Etiology: coronavirus; Rfs: travel to or close contact in past 14d w/someone from Middle East; Sx: acute fever, cough, sob; sometimes n/v/d; can be rapidly progressive)
      • Para-influenza (Etiology: upper resp infection/croup, tracheobronchitis) more from CDC
      • Rhino (Etiology: cause of upper respiratory infxn→ common cold, typically self limited; Sx: cough, nasal congestion, sore throat) more from CDC
      • RSV (Sites: upper and lower resp tract→ croup, brochiolitis, pna; Rfs: winter mos, typically affects infants and children; in partic if premature or w/chronic lung or heart dz; Sx: cough, fever, sob) more from CDC
      • SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome) (Etiology: coronavirus; initial outbreak in China→ rapid spread/pandemic Sx: high fever, aches, sometimes cough; then pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Varicella zoster (chicken pox) (Rfs: rare in kids as vaccine preventable; Sx: f, fatigue, ha, generalized vesicular erruption, duration 5-10d, can still get mild dz if vax, pneumonia in setting severe chicken pox or immunocomp) CDC
    • Liver
      • Hepatitis A (Etiology/Rfs: spread fecal/oral/ingestion contaminated food, can be epidemic, incubation 2-4w; Sx: n, v, RUQ abd pain, puritis, dark urine, light colored stool, f, jaundice, icterus; sx generally resolve w/in 2-4w; very rarely fulminant, not assoc w/chronic infxn; PE: jaundice, icterus, RUQ pain, hepatomegaly)
      • Hepatitis B (RFs: spread via sexual contact, vertical, shared needles, needle sticks in health care workers, unscreened blood transfusion; Sx: many are asx; incubataion is 1-4m; acute infxn assoc w/n, v, jaundice; puritus, icterus, dark urine, light colored stool, malaise; typically self limited, w/resoln sx 2-3m; 5% go on to chronic infxn, w/risk cirrhosis, spread to others, and hcc decades after initial infxn; PE: chronic infxn can lead to icterus, jaudice and other findings of chronic liver dz)
      • Hepatits C (RFs: spread via needles, unscreened blood transfusion, shared cocaine inhaling tools, needle sticks in health care workers, vertical, sexual; 10-20% resolve spontaneously; long term risk cirrhosis and HCC w/chronic infxn; Sx: most w/acute hep C are asx; those w/sx have RUQ pain, f, malaise, jaudice; can have sx cirrhosis and hcc decades later; PE: most have no findings in acute phase; chronic infxn can lead to icterus, jaudice and other findings of chronic liver dz)
      • Hepatitis D (RFs: occurs as a co-infection w/hep b, uncommon in west, found in Mediterranean and Asian countries; spread via same mechanisms as hep b)
      • Hepatitis E (RFs: uncommon in western nations, though most common cause of acute hep in developing world, can be sporadic or epidemic, water born w/spread similar to hep a; Sx: incubation 3-8w, sx of malaise, n, jaundice x ~ 2w; usually self limited, rarely fulminant, rarely chronic)
      More on viral hepatitis from CDC
    • EBV→ mononucleosis (Sx: incubation 4-6w, pro-drome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias; then f, sore thorat; rash w/amox; PE: head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly) more from CDC
    • CMV (Etol/Rfs: retinitis/colitis/disseminated dz in patients w/HIV; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w; Sx: f, c, malaise hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, fatigue x 4-6w; head/neck adenopathy & pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC
    • Small bowel
      • Norovirus (Etiology/Rfs: common cause of acute enteritis in adults, daycare/hospitals/nursing homes; Sx: abrupt onset n, v, diarrhea, low grade f) more from CDC
      • Rotavirus (Etiology/Rfs: common cause of acute enteritis in kids <5; vaccine preventable; Sx: abrupt onset n, v, diarrhea, f) more from CDC
    • Neuro
      • Arbovirus (Organisms: equine, west nile, lacrosse, other; Site: brain→ encephalitis; Etiology: carried by mosquitos; Sx: incubation 2d-2w; f, fatigue, HA, stiff neck, delirium) more from CDC
      • EBV (mononucleosis) (Rfs: spread by direct contact→ kissing, shared drinking glasses, shared toothbrushes, etc; Sites: pharynx, spleen, rarely brain and/or meninges; Sx: incubation 4-6w, prodrome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias, then f, sorethroat; PE: maculo-pap rash after amox or other abx, head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly; confusion, ha, f, deficits if CNS involvement) more from CDC
      • Enterovirus (non-polio: coxsackie, echo, other entero) (Etiology: passed fecal-oral, close contact, ingesting infected water; Site: brain→ meningitis & encephalitis, oral mucosa and skin→ hand/foot/mouth dz, heart→ myocarditis and pericarditis; conjunctiva→ conjunctivitits; upper resp tract; Sx: most have mild illness; w/more severe dz→ fever, ha, cough, runny nose, muscle aches, confusion) more from CDC
      • Herpes simplex encephalitis (Etiology: can be primary or reactivation; RFs: passed by sexual or oral contact; Site: brain→ meningitis & encephalitis; Sx: acute, HA, delirium vesicles)
      • Measels (rubeola) (Etiology: spread thru resp droplets, highly contagious; Rfs: too young to be vaccinated (<1y), or never vaccinated; winter/spring in US; Sx: incubation 7-14d; cough, high f, malaise; rash 4-5d after sx onset; PE: conjunctivitis, runny nose, then white (Koplick's) spots on oral mucosa, then rash; complications include encephalitis, pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Polio - eradicated in US w/vaccine (Etiology: summer mos, most have no sx; Sx: fever, headache, stiff neck/back, limb pain→ a minority of these develop flacid paralysis of legs, respiratory muscles) more from CDC
      • Rabies (Etiology: bite from infected animal→ skunk, bat, squirrel, dog; incubation can be days to mos→ time to travel along pns to cns; Sx: f, ha, myalgias, arthralgias, hydrophobia, intermitent confusion/agitation, sensitivity to sound/light, pain at bite site, autonomic dysfxn; 20% w/progressive flaccid paralysis, starting near bite; sx onset to death avg 4d) more from CDC
      • Varicella zoster (chicken pox & zoster) (Rfs: rare in kids as vaccine preventable; Sites: skin, lung, brain→ meningitis & encephalitis; Sx: f, fatigue, ha, generalized vesicular erruption, duration 5-10d, can still get mild dz if vax, pneumonia in setting severe chicken pox or immunocomp; also ha, stiff neck, confusion if encephalitis and/or meningitis) CDC
      • West Nile (Etiology: incubation 2d-2w; summer/fall in North America; Site: brain→ meningitis & encephalitis; Sx: fever, muscle aches, confusion, ha, stiff neck, rash, confusion) more from CDC
    • Associated w/derm manifestations
      • Coxsackievirus (enterovirus) (Etiology: myocarditis, pericarditis, erruption on palms/soles; Sx: w/cardiac involvement chest pain, sob; in kids f, malaise, vessicles in mouth and hands and soles) More from CDC
      • Herpes simplex oral/genital infxn (Etiology: primary infxn sometimes assoc w/fever; Sites: genital, oral; Rfs: passed by sexual or oral contact; Sx/PE: acute, painful, genital or oral area vesicles, adenopathy) more from CDC
      • HPV (Sites/Sx: painless growth in genital or rectal areas, spread sexually, years later causes cervical cancer, head/neck scc, penile scc; PE: clustered growths, genital warts, peri-anal warts) more from CDC
      • Parvo (Rfs: most common ages 5-19, Sx/PE: slapped cheek rash, also rash on arms, soles, palms; acute arthralgias/arthritis that can mimic RA; can cause acute hypoprolif anemia) CDC
      • Measels (rubeola) (Etiology: spread thru resp droplets, highly contagious; Rfs: too young to be vaccinated (<1y), or never vaccinated; winter/spring in US; Sx: incubation 7-14d; cough, high f, malaise; rash 4-5d after sx onset; PE: conjunctivitis, runny nose, then white (Koplick's) spots on oral mucosa, then rash; complications include encephalitis, pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Rubella (German measels) (Rfs: uncommon w/vaccination, spread via resp droplets; Sx: incubation ~14d; often prodrome 1-4d of malaise, fever, nasal congestion; rash starts on face and spreads; auricular/occipital adenopathy common; can be congenitally acquired)
      • Varicella zoster (chicken pox) (Rfs: rare in kids as vaccine preventable; Sx: f, fatigue, ha, generalized vesicular erruption, duration 5-10d, can still get mild dz if vax, pneumonia in setting severe chicken pox or immunocomp) CDC
      • Varicella zoster (shingles) (Rfs: increasing age over 50, immunocompromised; Etiology: dermatomal manifestation of prior chicken pox; adult can be vaccinated Sx: burning type pain for 1-3 d prior to erruption; PE: dermatomal vesicles, resolution of skin findings in 2w, can have post-herpetic neuralgia x mos/yrs) CDC
    • Associated w/MSK manifestations
      • CMV (Sx/PE: retinitis/colitis/disseminated dz in patients w/HIV; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w, then f, c, malaise hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, fatigue x 4-6w; head/neck adenopathy & pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC
      • Chikungunya (RFs: travel to Carribean, mosquitoe bite; Sx: fever, symmetric arthralgia, inflammatory arthritis wrists, fingers, ankles; muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash; onset 3-7d after bite; usually last days to weeks, sometimes mos) more from CDC
      • Dengue (Etiology: spread by aedes aegypti mosquito; RFs: exposure in tropics, SE Asia, Carribean, South America; Sx: incubation 4-7d, abrupt onset high fever, aches, retro-orbital pain, bone/muscle/joint pain, often low back pain, maculo-pap rash; sx resolve in 3-4d; can recur) more from CDC
      • Ebola (Etiology: spread via close human contact, bats as reservoir; RFs: travel to West Africa or exposure to someone at risk, spread via contact w/body fluids of infected person; Sx: incubation of up to 3w; high fever, fatigue, aches→ 0-3d; epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, arthralgias, myalgias, sorethroat, chest pain, headaches, delirium, conjunctival injection→ 3-10d; severe illness, shock, GI hemorrhage or other complications, death or recovery→ 7-12d) more from CDC
      • EBV (mononucleosis) (Rfs: spread by direct contact→ kissing, shared drinking glasses, shared toothbrushes, etc; Sx: incubation 4-6w, prodrome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias, then f, sore throat; PE: maculo-pap rash after amox or other abx, head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly) more from CDC
      • Enterovirus (non-polio) (Etiology: passed fecal-oral, close contact, ingesting infected water; Site: brain→ meningitis & encephalitis, oral mucosa and skin→ hand/foot/mouth dz, heart→ myocarditis and pericarditis; conjunctiva→ conjunctivitits; upper resp tract; Sx: most have mild illness; w/more severe dz→ fever, ha, cough, runny nose, muscle aches, confusion) more from CDC
      • Hep B (acute)(RFs: spread via sexual contact, vertical, shared needles, needle sticks in health care workers, unscreened blood transfusion; Sx: many are asx; incubation is 1-4m; acute infxn assoc w/n, v, jaundice; puritus, icterus, dark urine, light colored stool, malaise; typically self limited, w/resoln sx 2-3m; a minority develop symetric inflammatory arthritis of MCPs, PIP, knees, ankles; resoves in few weeks; PE: jaundice, icterus, RUQ pain, hepatomegaly, symetric inflammatory arthritis)
      • Influenza (Etiology: common cause upper and lower respiratory infection; Rfs: seasonal in North America Oct to April, increase risk amongst old, young, pregnant, chronic lung disease, any chronic illness, no vaccination; Sx: abrupt onset of myalgias, arthralgias, fever, chills) more from CDC
      • Parvo (Sx: acute, febrile illness in ages 5-19, runny nose, headache PE: skin erruption w/slapped cheek appearance, also rash on arms, soles, palms; sometimes symetric inflammatory arthritis can mimic RA; can cause acute hypoprolif anemia) more from CDC
      • West Nile (Etiology: incubation 2d-2w; summer/fall in North America; Site: brain→ meningitis & encephalitis; Sx: fever, muscle aches, confusion, ha, stiff neck, rash, confusion) more from CDC
    • Associated w/generalized f, c, aches, fatigue
      • CMV (Sx/PE: retinitis/colitis/disseminated dz in patients w/HIV; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w, then f, c, malaise hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, fatigue x 4-6w; head/neck adenopathy & pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC
      • Chikungunya (RFs: travel to Carribean, mosquitoe bite; Sx: fever, symmetric arthralgia, inflammatory arthritis wrists, fingers, ankles; muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash; onset 3-7d after bite; usually last days to weeks, sometimes mos) more from CDC
      • Dengue (Etiology: spread by aedes aegypti mosquito; RFs: exposure in tropics, SE Asia, Carribean, South America; Sx: incubation 4-7d, abrupt onset high fever, aches, retro-orbital pain, bone/muscle/joint pain, often low back pain, maculo-pap rash; sx resolve in 3-4d; can recur) more from CDC
      • Ebola (Etiology: spread via close human contact, bats as reservoir; RFs: travel to West Africa or exposure to someone at risk, spread via contact w/body fluids of infected person; Sx: incubation of up to 3w; high fever, fatigue, aches→ 0-3d; epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, arthralgias, myalgias, sorethroat, chest pain, headaches, delirium, conjunctival injection→ 3-10d; severe illness, shock, GI hemorrhage or other complications, death or recovery→ 7-12d) more from CDC
      • EBV (mononucleosis) (Rfs: spread by direct contact→ kissing, shared drinking glasses, shared toothbrushes, etc; Sx: incubation 4-6w, prodrome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias, then f, sore throat; PE: maculo-pap rash after amox or other abx, head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly) more from CDC
    • Associated w/parotid, testicle, cardiac involvement
      • Coxsackievirus (Sites: myocarditis, pericarditis, palms/soles; Sx: w/cardiac involvement chest pain, sob; in kids f, malaise, vessicles in mouth and hands and soles) More from CDC
      • Mumps (Etiology: uncommon w/vaccination; Sx: f, myalgia, malaise, affects B parotids and testicles) More from CDC

      Fungi

    • Muco-cutaneous fungal infections
      • Blastomycosis dermatidis (RFs: lives in soil, most commonly found Great Lakes, Mississippi & Ohio river valleys, SE US; typically inhaled; hosts usually of normal health; Sites: lungs, skin if disseminated or as primary problem; Sx: many are asymptomatic; sometimes flu-like illness; others w/sub acute cough, fever, sob; skin nodules or ulcers) more from CDC
      • Candida ballanitis (Sites: head of penis, in partic if uncircumcised; Rfs: worse if immunocompromised→ DM, HIV, chronic steroids; PE: bright red erruption, sometimes w/white d/c)
      • Candida - Infra-mammary/diaper area(Site: below breasts, diaper distribution w/babies; Sx/Rfs: candida has predilection for moist spaces, also worse if immunocompromised→ DM, HIV, chronic steroids, itchy and sometimes painful PE: bright red erruption)
      • Coccidiomycosis (Etiology: south west US, higher risk if immune-compromised Site: lung parenchyma and pleural space, joints, skin; Sx: sub-acute sob, cough, f, also arthritis, skin nodules, seeding of other sites) more from CDC
      • Mucosal candidiasis - mouth/esophagus (Site: mouth and esophagus Rfs: often hx abx exposure or immunocomp→ HIV, steroids, chemo; Sx: white plaques; often bleed when scraped; pain w/swallowing)
      • Onychomycosis (Site: nails; Sx: common, chronic, nail infection; more common in toes than fingers; PE: nail appears thickened, opaque and deformed/ragged; non tender; can cause onycholysis→separation of nail from bed)
      • Sporothrichosis(Rfs: lives in soil, infection via cut when handling dirg, vegetation; Sx: painless skin nodule at site of innoculation; develops over 1 to 12 weeks; increases in size and can ulcerate; sometimes local adenpathy)
      • Tinea capitis ("ring worm") (Site: scalp; Sx/PE: scaly, inflamed, raised, well defined patch(es) on scalp, associated w/focal hair loss)
      • Tinea corporis ("ring worm") (Site: skin - anywhere; PE/Sx: well circumscribed, scaly, patch on skin, sometimes puritic, central clearing w/active border)
      • Tinea cruris ("jock itch") (Site: inguinal crease, genitals; Sx/PE: puritic, scaly, red leading edge)
      • Tinea pedis ("athlete's foot") (Site: feet; Sx: itchy, pain if cracking; can be portal for secondary bacterial infxn; can sometimes blister; PE: scaly, predilection for sides/soles, macerated appearance in web spaces)
      • Tinea versicolor (Sites; back, chest: Sx: multiple hypopigmented patches; sometimes puritic; PE: well circumscribed, hypopigmented patches, w/light scale)
    • Systemic fungal infections
      • Aspergillus (Rfs: lung dz assoc w/immunocompromised host and/or w/structual lung dz→ e.g. bronchiectasis; Sites: lungs→ can be tissue invasive or chronic (e.g. fungal ball); sinuses, skin, other; Sx: can be indolent or acute; cough, sob, wt loss, cp, fatigue, hemoptysis; facial fullness/pain, nasal d/c→ invasive sinusitis in patients w/DM or otherwise compromised; recurrent wheezing in normal hosts→ ABPA)
      • Blastomycosis dermatidis (RFs: lives in soil, most commonly found Great Lakes, Mississippi & Ohio river valleys, SE US; typically inhaled; hosts usually of normal health; Sites: lungs, skin if disseminated or as primary problem; Sx: many are asymptomatic; sometimes flu-like illness; others w/sub acute cough, fever, sob; skin nodules or ulcers) more from CDC
      • Candida (Rfs: compromised host→ HIV, chemo, steroids, long term abx w/indwelling lines, TPN use, long ICU stays; Sx: fevers, systemic sx/sepsis)
      • Coccidioidomycosis (Etiology: south west US, higher risk if immune-compromised; Site: lung parenchyma and pleural space, joints, skin; Rfs: inhaled when spores stirred up by construction, gardening, wind, etc; Sx: sub-acute sob also arthritis, skin nodules, seeding of other sites)
      • Cryptococcus (neoformans) (Sites: cns, lungs, skin; Rfs: assoc w/immunocompromised, CD4 < 50 or untreated HIV; Sx: CNS disease→ sub-acute headache, fever, confusion; pulmonary→ subacute cough, sob, chest pain, f)
      • Cryptococcus (gattii) (Sites: lungs, skin, cns; Rfs: found on West coast/Pacific Northwest; can cause pneumonia in normal hosts; can also infect those w/HIV and advance t-cell deficiencincy states; Sx: subacute cough, sob, chest pain, f; CNS sx of subacute confusion, ha)
      • Histoplasmosis (Sites; lungs, liver, spleen, eye, mouth, systemic; Rfs: exposure to Mississippi & Ohio river valley, HIV+; Sx: can be asx/mild and resolve spont; often see x-ray evidence prior infection lung, spleen w/o known past infxn; cough, fever; can cause resp/systemic illness in HIV+)
      • Mucor (Sites: lung→ pneumonia, sinuses→ invasive sinusitis; Rf: DM or otherwise compromised; PE: cough, fever, HA, sinus pain)
      • Pneumocystis jerovecii (Sites: lung Rfs: HIV +, prolonged steroid use; Sx: cough, f, sob pneumonia)
      More on fungi from CDC

      Mycobacteria

      • Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) (Rfs: HIV + w/CD4 < 50 for disseminated dz; hx bronchietasis for lung sx; Sx: diarrhea in HIV +; persistent/progressive lung infection in patients with bronchiectasis) more from CDC
      • Mycobacterium avium intracellulare (MAI) (Rfs: HIV + w/CD4 < 50; Sx: diarrhea, n, v, abdominal pain, f, c, fatigue; can infect liver, spleen, lymph nodes, bone marrow, lung, pericardium→ causing adenopathy or organomegaly, anemia)
      • M Kansii (Rfs: immunocompromised, broanchiectasis or other chronic lung dz; Sx: similar to M Tb w/subacute cough, fever, heomptysis, sob)
      • M Leprae (Etiology: spread via resp droplets; long incubation, btwn 2 & 7 yrs avg; Rfs: Southeast Asia; Sx/PE: anesthetic macule, area of involvement spreads, direct nerve involvement, neuropathic pain and enlargement of involved nerve, weakness, nasal deformity & stuffiness, skin ulcers on feet as cant feel injuries) more from CDC
      • M Marinum (Rfs: exposure via fish tanks; Sx: sub-acute skin infection; PE: sub-acute, progressive skin infxn, not repsonsive to typical rx)
      • M Tuberculosis (MTB) (RFs: HIV +, ETOh, chronic kidney, liver, lung dz; dialysis, homeless, immunocompromised for other reason→ steroid, TNF inhibitors, other; though can occur in anyone, reactivating sometimes years after initial exposure; extra-pulm TB increases in HIV+ w/CD4 < 350; Sx: sub-acute, cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, sweats, fatigue; can also infect GI/GU tracts, pericardium, bones, cns, lymph nodes or become widely disseminated) more from CDC

      Retrovirus

      • HIV (Etiology/Rfs: hiv risk factors→ men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; risks of unusual infection increase as CD4 declines; Sx: acute infection→ fever, chills, sweats, adenopathy, rash, pharyngitis w/in 2-4 weeks - then resolves; latency until sx develop 6-10y after initial infxn (if not treated) related to drop in CD4: generalized sx include f, c, cough, wt loss; other illnesses: mucosal candidiasis; fungal, mtb lung infection; persistent diarrhea; CNS toxo; non hodgkins lymphoma; kaposis sarcoma of skin, adenopathy, etc) more from CDC
      • HTLV 1 (Rfs: spread sexually, vertically, via transfusion; most prevalent in Caribbean, Central/South America, Japan; Sx: most are asx, no problems w/opportunistic infxn like HIV; Long term risks include: T-cell leukemia-lymphoma; also spastic paraparesis/myelopathy→ unremitting, progressive neuro syndrome characterized by lower extrem weakness, spasticity, hyper-reflexia, gait probs, incontinence, neruopathic pain; no cognitive or cranial nerve involvement)

      Spirochetes

      • Borrelia burgdorferi (lyme) (Etiology: tick borne, endemic area north east, upper mid west, tick contact x 24-48h; incubation days to weeks; Sx: rash, f, c, aches; then arthralgias, heart block, CNS involvement; later still arthritis; can co-infect w/organisms causing babesiosis and anaplasmosis; PE: erythema migrans bull's eye type rash, sometime inflammatory arthritis) more from CDC
      • Borrelia miyamotoi (Etiology: tick borne, endemic area north east, summer mos; Sx: f, c, headache, arthralgias, myalgias, malaise/fatigue; PE: often ill appearing, sometimes faint lacy rash) more from CDC
      • Borrelia - other sp (relapsing fever) (Etiology: tick borne, mountainous US→ West/Southwest, plateau of Mexico, South America; Sx: fever x ~3d→ then fever free x 1w→ then recurs; chills, ha, muscle aches, n, photophobia, joint aches, confusion; PE: non-specific; sometimes conj injection, confusion, mac-pap rash)
      • Leptospirosis (Etiology: contract via exposure to rodent/wild animal feces; incubation several weeks; Sx/PE: mild dz is self limited f, c, ha, n, v, muscle aches, conjunctival injection; severe dz with hepatic and renal involvement, pulmonary hemorrhage, and icterus) CDC
      • Syphillis (T Pallidum) (Rfs: sexual exposure, Etiology/Sx/PE: primary, secondary and tertiary manifestations; primary infection causes painless genital ulcer, ~3w after exposure → heals 4-6w, regional adenopathy; secondary manifestations weeks to mos later w/non-specific rash, predilection for palms, and soles; condyloma around genital areas, mucous involvement, generalized adenopathy, f, sweats, eyes→ iritis/uveitis; tertiary manifestations yrs later affecting CNS→ numbness, weakness, balance problems, dementia; large blood vessels→ aortitis, aneurysm) More from CDC

      Rickettsiae

      Obligate intracellular gram negative bacteria which are spread by tick, mite, flea, louse, or chiggers.
      • Anaplasmosis (Etiology: tick born, incubation 1-2w, Midwest and Eastern US; can co-infect w/organisms causing Lyme and babesiosis; Sx: f, ha, n, v, myalgias; often causes BM suppression)
      • Coxiella Burnetti (Q fever: Rickettsia-like) (Etiology: spread from cattle and sheep, incubation 5d-2w; Sx: fever, chills, severe ha, myalgias, malaise, cough, abd pain; many recover spont; can cause pneumonia, hepatitis, myocarditis)
