        • M tuberculosis (MTB) (RFs: HIV +, steroids, chronic kidney, liver or lung dz; ivdu, from enedemic area, healthcare worker, otherwise immunocomp; extra-pulm TB increases in HIV+ w/CD4 < 350; Sx: sub-acute, cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, sweats, fatigue; can also infect GI/GU tracts; adenopathy most commonly head/neck) more from CDC
        • Mycobacterium avium intracellulare (MAI) (Rfs: HIV + w/CD4 < 50; Sx: diarrhea, n, v, abdominal pain, f, c, fatigue; can infect liver, spleen, lymph nodes, bone marrow, lung, pericardium→ causing adenopathy or organomegaly, anemia)

        Rickettsia

        • Typhus (various types) (Etiology: spread via flea, louse or tick, reservoirs often rodents squirrels; summer mos, incubation 1-2w, Central/South America, Asia, Central Africa, tropics; Sx: non-specific f, c, ha, malaise, myalgias; PE: non-specific mac-pap rash, sometimes adenopathy)

        Spirochetes

        • Syphillis (Rfs: sexual exposure, Etiology/Sx/PE: primary, secondary and tertiary manifestations; primary infection causes painless genital ulcer, ~3w after exposure → heals 4-6w, regional adenopathy; secondary manifestations weeks to mos later w/non-specific rash, predilection for palms, and soles; condyloma around genital areas, mucous involvement, generalized adenopathy, f, sweats, eyes→ iritis/uveitis; tertiary manifestations yrs later affecting CNS→ numbness, weakness, balance problems, dementia; large blood vessels→ aortitis, aneurysm) More from CDC

        Parasites

        • Leishmaniasis (Kala Azar) (Etiology: spread by sand-fly bite, widespread throughout subtropics→ Africa, Central & South America, India, Mediterranean basin, Asia, Middle East; Sx/PE: cutaneous: papule→ nodule→ painless raised & indurated ulcers that don't heal over weeks to mos; visceral→ can be silent, or cause fevers, sweats, chills, wt loss, adnenopathy, organomegaly)
        • W bancrofti (filariasis) (Rfs/Etiology; tropics/sub-tropics, spread by mosquitoes; Sx: most are asx and wont have sequelae; some will have acute f, c, adenopathy; filaria invade lymphatics, after years→ lymphedema from obstruction of channels; PE: in some, chronic lymphedema)

      Assoc w/Heme Abnl

      Many severe systemic infections can cause bone marrow suppression, anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia and DIC. Below are a few more commonly linked to hematologic pertubations.
      • Parasites
        • Babesiosis (B. microti - protozoa) (Etiology: tick born, endemic Northeast/Northern Mid-west US; can co-infect w/lyme and anaplasmosis; Sx: 1-4 w after infxn; subacute f, c, sweats, HA, muscle aches; in severe cases hemolytic anemia, kidney, liver injury, resp distress)
        • Malaria (Etiology: spread by anopheles mosquito, tropical climates, in partic Southeast Asia, Africa; variants = P vivax, falciparum, ovale and malariae; Sx: incubation 1-4w; recurrent high fevers, C, HA; hemolysis; mild to life threatening (falciparum))
      • Rickettsia
        • Anaplasmosis (obligate intracellular bacteria) (Etiology: tick born, incubation 1-2w, Midwest and Eastern US; can co-infect w/organisms causing Lyme and babesiosis; Sx: f, ha, n, v, myalgias; often causes BM suppression)
        • Human ehrlichiosis (obligate intracellular bacteria) (Etiology: tick borne, incubation 1-2w, endemic South Eastern, South Central and Eastern US; similar presentation to anaplasmosis; Sx: f, ha, n, v, myalgias; often causes BM suppression)
      • Mycobacteria
        • Mycobacterium avium intracellulare (MAI) (Rfs: HIV + w/CD4 < 50; Sx: diarrhea, n, v, abdominal pain, f, c, fatigue; can infect liver, spleen, lymph nodes, bone marrow, lung, pericardium→ causing adenopathy or organomegaly, anemia)
        • M Tuberculosis (MTB) (RFs: HIV +, ETOh, chronic kidney, liver, lung dz; dialysis, homeless, immunocompromised for other reason→ steroid, TNF inhibitors, other; though can occur in anyone, reactivating sometimes years after initial exposure; extra-pulm TB increases in HIV+ w/CD4 < 350; Sx: sub-acute, cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, sweats, fatigue; can also infect GI/GU tracts, pericardium, bones, cns, lymph nodes, bone marrow, or become widely disseminated) more from CDC
      • Viral and retroviral
        • Dengue (Etiology: spread by aedes aegypti mosquito; RFs: exposure in tropics, SE Asia, Carribean, South America; Sx: incubation 4-7d, abrupt onset high fever, aches, retro-orbital pain, bone/muscle/joint pain, often low back pain, maculo-pap rash, throbocytopenia w/assoc petechiae and mucosal bleeding; sx resolve in 3-4d; can recur) more from CDC
        • HIV (Etiology/Rfs: hiv risk factors→ men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; risks of unusual infection increase as CD4 declines; Sx: acute infection→ fever, chills, sweats, adenopathy, rash, pharyngitis w/in 2-4 weeks - then resolves; latency until sx develop 6-10y after initial infxn (if not treated) related to drop in CD4: generalized sx include f, c, cough, wt loss; other illnesses: mucosal candidiasis; fungal, mtb lung infection; persistent diarrhea; CNS toxo; non hodgkins lymphoma; kaposis sarcoma of skin, adenopathy, etc; can cause acute hypoprolif and hemolytic anemias) more from CDC
        • Parvo (Rfs: most common ages 5-19, Sx/PE: slapped cheek rash, also rash on arms, soles, palms; acute arthralgias/arthritis that can mimic RA; can cause acute hypoprolif anemia) CDC
      • Bacteria
        • Clostridium Perfringes (GPR) (Etiology: most common cause food born diarrhea→ undercooked meat, other who ate same ill simultaneously, resolves in 24h; can contribute to nec fasciitis; Sx: cramps, diarrhea, 6-18h after ingestion, contribute to abd/pv abscess; NEC in neonates; hemolytic anemia; PE: deep tissue infection from necrotizing faciitis) more from CDC
        • Mycoplasma pneumoniae (Etiology: common cause CAP; also upper resp tract infxn; Sx: acute f, c, cough, upper resp sx; not usually severe; hemolytic anemia) more from CDC

      Musculoskeletal

      Osteomyelitis

      • Osteomyelitis (Etiology: in adult, most commonly occurs in distal extremity, assoc w/neuropathy and peripheral arterial dz; can also be from traumatic innoculation of bacteria; also bacteremia→ more common in kids; Sx: if from pad/dm→ typically distal ulcer or sinus tract, non-healing, pain; if traumatic, then suggestive hx, open wound or draining sinus; PE: pain, swelling, redness non-healing ulcer; probe to bone→ clinical osteomyelitis)

      Septic Arthritis

      One/Few Joints

      Bacterial, fungal and spirochetes
      • Staph or strep (Etiology: most common staph, strep; enter joint via direct innoculation→ trauma, bite, surgery; extension from overlying skin infection; or bactermeia; Sx: acute, painful, red, swollen, fever, chills: PE: sig inflammatory signs→ red, warm, worse w/passive or active movement, effusion)
      • Gonorrhea (Rfs: hx sti, hx sexual activity; Sx: f, c, penile or cervical d/c; migratory polyarthritis/arthralgias, skin lesions, predilaction for small joints; PE: affected joint(s) warm, red, pain w/active or passive ROM, effusion, pustules)
      • Endocarditis can also cause migratory poly-arthritis
      • Fungal (Etol: relatively uncommon, hx coccidiomycosis, exposure to endemic areas for cocci→ Southwest; Sx: sub-acute, persisten/progressive joint pain, swelling, warmth, pain w/ROM, effusion)
      • Spirochete (lyme) (Rfs: hx living in area endemic w/lyme→ Northeast, WI/MN, Northern Calif, occurs secondary to tick bite; Sx: bull's eye type rash→ erythema migrans, f, c, adenopathy, arhtralgias; joint inflammation mos to yrs later, large joints, can wax/wane; PE: joint pain, swelling, effusion) more from CDC

      Multiple Joints

      Bacterial, viral, other
      • Staph or strep (Etiology: most common staph, strep; multi-joint involvement via bactermeia; Sx: acute, painful, red, swollen, fever, chills: PE: f, systemic illness, sig joint inflammatory signs→ red, warm, worse w/passive or active movement, effusion)
      • Gonorrhea (disseminated) (Rfs: hx sti, hx sexual activity; Sx: f, c, penile or cervical d/c; migratory polyarthritis/arthralgias, skin lesions, predilaection for small joints; PE: affected joint(s) warm, red, pain w/active or passive ROM, effusion, pustules) more from CDC
      • Endocarditis/systemic bacteremia - can also cause migratory poly-arthritis
      • T Whipplei (Whipple's disease) (Etiology: possibly sewage, fecal oral spread; RFs: male>female, age 40-60; Sx: rare d/o, multipple chronic sx; wt loss, diarrhea, abd pain, fatigue; intermitent migratory arthritis that sometimes precedes GI sx x years, involves larger joints→ knees, wrists, ankles; f, adenopathy; broad range neuro sx→ cog impairment, uveitis, ha, supranuclear ophthalmoplegia, other; also skin, cardiac, pulmonary)
      • Viral - Parvo (Sx: acute, febrile illness in ages 5-19, runny nose, headache PE: skin erruption w/slapped cheek appearance, also rash on arms, soles, palms; sometimes symetric inflammatory arthritis can mimic RA; can cause acute hypoprolif anemia) more from CDC
      • Viral - acute Hep B (RFs: spread via sexual contact, vertical, shared needles, needle sticks in health care workers, unscreened blood transfusion; Sx: many are asx; incubation is 1-4m; acute infxn assoc w/n, v, jaundice; puritus, icterus, dark urine, light colored stool, malaise; typically self limited, w/resoln sx 2-3m; a minority develop symetric inflammatory arthritis of MCPs, PIP, knees, ankles; resoves in few weeks; PE: jaundice, icterus, RUQ pain, hepatomegaly, symetric inflammatory arthritis)
      • Viral - Chikungunya (RFs: travel to Carribean, mosquitoe bite; Sx: fever, symmetric arthralgia, inflammatory arthritis wrists, fingers, ankles; muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash; onset 3-7d after bite; usually last days to weeks, sometimes mos) more from CDC
      • Acute rheumatic fever (Sx: relatively uncommon, occurs 2-3w after strep pharyngitis, assoc w/fever, fatigue, acute/abrupt onset, migratory inflammatory arthritis of large joints typically; chest pain or sob related to pericarditis; long term risk of mitral or aortic valve dz; PE: affected joint(s) are warm, red, pain w/movement)
      • Reactive arthritis (Sx: occur weeks following chlamydia GU infection or bacterial gastroenteritis; Sx/PE: asymmetric inflammatory migratory arthritis, typically one or a few joints→ knees, ankles, wrists in partic; lbp/SI area pain w/AM stiffness and muscle aches; eye sx→ conjunctivits, iritis; dysuria; oral ulcers; pain at tendon insertions→enthesitis, digit swelling→ dactylitis)

      Bursitis/Tenosynovitis

      • Bursitis (Sx: acute pain, fever, swelling, redness over a known anatomic bursa; PE: focal redness, warmth, pain on touch, swelling, over an anatomic bursa)
      • Teno-synovitis (Etiology: often direct innoculation of bacteria as w/a bite wound or trauma; Sx/PE: worse w/active motion compared w/passive; localized over tendon)

      Infnx w/Muscle sx

      Many infections affect muscles (myositis) or have a tendency to cause significant myalgias

        Bacterial

        • Hematogenous seeding eg. Psoas abscess from endocarditis
        • Direct extension into muscle from adjacent infection e.g. psoas abscess from vertebral osteo
        • Necrotizing fasciitis (Etiology: relatively uncommon; assoc w/dm, impaired immunity or perfusion; typically polymicrobial: strep, staph, clostridium, other; Sx: acute pain, swelling, fever, toxic appearing, often rapidly progressive; PE: typically abnl vs consistent w/severe illness, skin findings sometimes subtle→ redness, dusky discoloration, bulla; more profound findings as dz progresses) LRINEC Score
        • Diabetic muscular infarct (Etiology: related to small vessel infarct in leg→ typically patient w/DM; Sx: acute pain, swelling; PE: non-specific→ may have redness)
        • Pyomyositis (Etiology: related to deep muscle infection w/seeding from direct trauma/injury or bacteremia; relatively uncommon, affecting compromised hosts→ DM, HIV; Sx: acute pain, swelling, fevers/systemic illness)

        Viral

        • CMV (Sx/PE: retinitis/colitis/disseminated dz in patients w/HIV; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w, then f, c, malaise hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, fatigue x 4-6w; head/neck adenopathy & pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC
        • Chikungunya (RFs: travel to Carribean, mosquitoe bite; Sx: fever, symmetric arthralgia, inflammatory arthritis wrists, fingers, ankles; muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash; onset 3-7d after bite; usually last days to weeks, sometimes mos) more from CDC
        • Dengue (Etiology: spread by aedes aegypti mosquito; RFs: exposure in tropics, SE Asia, Carribean, South America; Sx: incubation 4-7d, abrupt onset high fever, aches, retro-orbital pain, bone/muscle/joint pain, often low back pain, maculo-pap rash; sx resolve in 3-4d; can recur) more from CDC
        • Ebola (Etiology: spread via close human contact, bats as reservoir; RFs: travel to West Africa or exposure to someone at risk, spread via contact w/body fluids of infected person; Sx: incubation of up to 3w; high fever, fatigue, aches→ 0-3d; epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, arthralgias, myalgias, sorethroat, chest pain, headaches, delirium, conjunctival injection→ 3-10d; severe illness, shock, GI hemorrhage or other complications, death or recovery→ 7-12d) more from CDC
        • EBV (mononucleosis) (Rfs: spread by direct contact→ kissing, shared drinking glasses, shared toothbrushes, etc; Sx: incubation 4-6w, prodrome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias, then f, sore throat; PE: maculo-pap rash after amox or other abx, head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly) more from CDC
        • Enterovirus (non-polio) (Etiology: passed fecal-oral, close contact, ingesting infected water; Site: brain→ meningitis & encephalitis, oral mucosa and skin→ hand/foot/mouth dz, heart→ myocarditis and pericarditis; conjunctiva→ conjunctivitits; upper resp tract; Sx: most have mild illness; w/more severe dz→ fever, ha, cough, runny nose, muscle aches, confusion) more from CDC
        • Influenza (Etiology: common cause upper and lower respiratory infection; Rfs: seasonal in North America Oct to April, increase risk amongst old, young, pregnant, chronic lung disease, any chronic illness, no vaccination; Sx: abrupt onset of myalgias, arthralgias, fever, chills) more from CDC
        • West Nile (Etiology: incubation 2d-2w; summer/fall in North America; Site: brain→ meningitis & encephalitis; Sx: fever, muscle aches, confusion, ha, stiff neck, rash, confusion) more from CDC

        Parasitic

        • Cysticercosis (T Solium - pork tapeworm) (Etiology: ingest eggs via infected beef that's undercooked; Mexico, Africa, Southeast Asia; eggs cross intestines, migrate to host muscles and brain; Sx: no f, otherwise unexplained muscles aches, ha, seizures)
        • Trichinella (roundworm) (Etiology: rare in US; from eating infected meat; Sx: abd pain, n, v, diarrhea; after 1-2w, muscle pain when migrate to muscles, rash, f, ha, n, v)

        Rickettsiae

        • Anaplasmosis (obligate intracellular bacteria) (Etiology: tick born, incubation 1-2w, Midwest and Eastern US; can co-infect w/organisms causing Lyme and babesiosis; Sx: f, ha, n, v, myalgias; often causes BM suppression)
        • Coxiella Burnetti (Q fever) (Etiology: spread from cattle and sheep, incubation 5d-2w; Sx: fever, chills, severe ha, myalgias, malaise, cough, abd pain; many recover spont; can cause pneumonia, hepatitis, myocarditis)
        • Human ehrlichiosis (obligate intracellular bacteria) (Etiology: tick borne, incubation 1-2w, endemic South Eastern, South Central and Eastern US; similar presentation to anaplasmosis; Sx: f, ha, n, v, myalgias; often causes BM suppression)
        • Rocky Mtn Spotted Fever (Etiology: tick borne, incubation 2d to 2w; can occur in most states in US, Sx: f, c, ha, arthralgias, then generalized rash; can be severe/fatal)
        • Typhus (various types) (Etiology: spread via flea, louse or tick, reservoirs often rodents squirrels; summer mos, incubation 1-2w, Central/South America, Asia, Central Africa, tropics; Sx: non-specific f, c, ha, malaise, myalgias; PE: non-specific mac-pap rash, sometimes adenopathy)
        • More on Rickettsiae from CDC

        Spirochetes

        • Borrelia burgdorferi (lyme) (Etiology: tick borne, endemic area north east, upper mid west, tick contact x 24-48h; incubation days to weeks; Sx: rash, f, c, aches; then arthralgias, heart block, CNS involvement; later still arthritis; can co-infect w/organisms causing babesiosis and anaplasmosis; PE: erythema migrans bull's eye type rash, sometime inflammatory arthritis) more from CDC
        • Borrelia miyamotoi (Etiology: tick borne, endemic area north east, summer mos; Sx: f, c, headache, arthralgias, myalgias, malaise/fatigue; PE: often ill appearing, sometimes faint lacy rash) more from CDC
        • Borrelia - other sp (relapsing fever) (Etiology: tick borne, mountainous US→ West/Southwest, plateau of Mexico, South America; Sx: fever x ~3d→ then fever free x 1w→ then recurs; chills, ha, muscle aches, n, photophobia, joint aches, confusion; PE: non-specific; sometimes conj injection, confusion, mac-pap rash)
        • Leptospirosis (Etiology: contract via exposure to rodent/wild animal feces; incubation several weeks; Sx/PE: mild dz is self limited f, c, ha, n, v, muscle aches, conjunctival injection; severe dz with hepatic and renal involvement, pulmonary hemorrhage, and icterus) CDC

        Fungal

        • Rare cause of muscle infection. Usually associated with immunocompromised hosts. Pathogens include: candida, aspergillus, cryptococcus, histoplasma, other.

      Neuro

      Mening/Enceph

      Organisms associated w/meningitis and encephalitis.
      • Meningitis (Etiology: inflammation of layers covering brain; Sx: photphobia, acute neck stiffness, headache, fever, confusion, and generalized illness; PE: f, + Kernigs (specific not sensitive)→ pain with passive knee extension when hip flexed to 90; + Brudzinski (specific not sensitive)→ hip and knee flexion occurs w/passive neck flexion; + jolt (sensitive not specific)→ worsening ha when patient rotates head back & forth; less common to have focal neurological findings and overall less impaired compared w/encephalitis)
        • Viral (Organisms: enteroviruses, herpes simplex, herpes zoster, ebv, west nile, influenza, hiv, measels, mumps; Sx: acute, fever, head ache, neck pain, n, v, delirium)
        • Bacterial (Organisms: strep pneumoniae, n meningiditis→ in particular when living in dormitories/college and not vax; grp b strep; listeria→ in the elderly; Sx: acute, fever, head ache, neck pain, n, v, delirium; rash)
        • Fungal (Rfs: often assoc w/compromised states → hiv, cancer; Organisms: cryptococcus, histoplasmosis, coccidioomycosis, blastomyces; Sx: subacute, fever, feeling poorly in general, sub-acute headache & neck pain, delirium)
        • Myobacterial (Rfs: known TB elsewhere, immuncompromised, otherwise exposed; Sx: subacute f, chills, ha, fatigue, stiff neck, delirium)
        • Parasitic - Cysticercosis (T Solium - tapeworm) (Etiology: ingest eggs via infected beef that's undercooked; Mexico, Africa, Southeast Asia; eggs cross intestines, migrate to host muscles and brain; Sx: ha, seizures, otherwise unexplained muscles aches)
        • Non-infectious: collagen vascular disease→ lupus, cancer involving the meninges, post infectious, medications→ nsaids, IVIG, other
        • More on meningitis from CDC
      • Encephalitis (Etiology: inflammation of diffuse or specifc areas of brain parenchyma; Sx: tend to have focal neuro deficits as compared w/meningitis; acute onset of headache, fever, confusion, irritability, motor and sensory impairment, altered speech; can also have meningoencephalitis)
        • Viral (most common) (Organisms: enteroviruses,, HSV, VZV, EBV, influenza, west nile, other arboviruses (transmitted by mosquitoes); and other viruses w/prevalence varying by season, region of the world)
        • Other uncommon infections (Organisms: Tick borne→ lyme; rabies, fungal, and mycobacteria)
        • Non-infectious (Etiology: collagen vascular disease, para-neoplastic, post infectious, post vaccination)
        • Autoimmune encephalitis (Etiology: antibody mediated→ multiple including anti-nmda; also paraneoplastic; Rfs: women, < 30, teratoma; Sx: acute change in personality, decline in functional status, agitation, confusion, bizarre behavior, autonomic instability, seizures, unusual movements, seziures, other neuro deficits)
        • ADEM (acute demyelinating encephalomyelitis) (Etiology: autoimmune d/o, often triggered by an infection→ URI, EBV; post vaccination, other; dx of exclusion; RFs: overall uncommon, though kids>>adults; Sx: acute, progressive, ha, f, confusion, weakness, ataxia, focal deficits; PE: f, focal deficits, patchy UMN and sensory findings)

      Abscess (brain)

      • Bacterial abscess (Etiology: reason for abscess → spread from adjacent site→ dental or sinuses, AVM, PFO, neurosurgery; Sx: acute/subacute, headache, fever, loss of function based on location, progressive, delirium)
      • Mycobacterial abscess (Rfs: known TB elsewhere, immuncompromised, otherwise exposed; Sx: subacute f, chills, ha, fatigue, stiff neck, delirium, loss of function based on location)
      • Fungal abscess (Rfs: often assoc w/compromised states → hiv, cancer, DM; systemic or from local spread; Sx: subacute, fever, feeling poorly in general, sub-acute headache & neck pain, delirium, deficits based on location)
      • Parasitic - Cysticercosis (T Solium - tapeworm) (Etiology: ingest eggs via infected beef that's undercooked; Mexico, Africa, Southeast Asia; eggs cross intestines, migrate to host muscles and brain; Sx:headache, seizures, otherwise unexplained muscles aches)
      • Parasitic - Toxoplasmosis (Rfs: HIV + w/CD4 < 200; Sx: sub-acute, headache, confusion, fever, focal neruo deficits based on location)

      Cord Abscess/Osteo

      • Osteomyelitis/discitis (Rfs: compromised host, ivdu, dm, esrd, etc; Sx: acute, subacute, or chronic, progressive pain, fever; pain over affected area of cervical spine; spread can lead to epidural abscess; PE: may have pain over cervical vertebrae, neuro deficits if cord or roots compromised)
        • Bacterial (Etiology: Staph most common; then e coli; can be the result of hematogenous seeding from bacteremia/endocarditis; or direct extension from superficial skin process, instrumentation/surgery, foley catheter/uti)
        • Mycobacterial (Etiology/Rfs: complication of systemic TB, often compromised host, sometimes known TB elsewhere; Sx: sub-acute/chronic cervical spine pain, f, c, sx related to tb elsewhere→ lungs, GI)
        • Fungal (Etiology: aspergillous, cocci, other; Rfs: compromised host or complication of an injection; Sx: subacute pain, f)
      • Epidural abscess (Rfs: often compromised from dm, etoh, ivdu, other; Etiology: hematogenous seeding from systemic bacteremia, as w/endocarditis; or direct extension from adjacent osteomyelitis/discitis, instrumentation/surgery; Sx: progressive acute/subacute pain, fever, neuro compromise→ upper and lower extremity numbness or neuropathic pain; extremity weakness to paralysis, bowel/bladder incontinence)
        • Bacterial (Etiology: Staph most common; then e coli; can be the result of hematogenous seeding from bacteremia/endocarditis; or direct extension from superficial skin process, instrumentation/surgery, foley catheter/uti)
        • Mycobacterial (Etiology/Rfs: complication of systemic TB, often compromised host, sometimes known TB elsewhere; Sx: sub-acute/chronic progressive lbp, f, c, numbness, weakness, bowel/bladder sx)
        • Fungal (Etiology: aspergillous, cocci, other; Rfs: compromised host or complication of an injection; Sx: subacute, progressive pain, numbness, weakness, bowel/bladder sx)
      • Transverse myelitis (Etiology: acute inflammation affecting cord, viral, autoimmune or idiopathic. Peak ages 10-20 & 30-40; Sx: bilateral impaired sensory & motor function below affected level, bowel & bladder dysfxn, sometimes back pain, onset over hours to days)
      • Retroviral - HTLV 1 (Rfs: spread sexually, vertically, via transfusion; most prevalent in Caribbean, Central/South America, Japan; Sx: most are asx, no problems w/opportunistic infxn like HIV; Long term risks include: T-cell leukemia-lymphoma; PE: spastic paraparesis/myelopathy→ unremitting, progressive neuro syndrome characterized by lower extrem weakness, spasticity, hyper-reflexia, gait probs, incontinence, neruopathic pain; no cognitive or cranial nerve involvement)
      • Retroviral - HIV (Rfs: Known HIV or rfs for this dz, advanced/end stage; Sx: slow progressive causes myelopathy w/weakness, numbness and urinary dysfxn related to region of cord affected)
      • Syphillis (Rfs: known stis, hiv rfs; Sx: assoc w/later stage syphillis→ slowly progressive weakness, numbness, neuropathic pain, tingling, balance probs)

      PNS Infxn

      • HIV (Etiology/Rfs: hiv risk factors→ men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; risks of unusual infection increase as CD4 declines; Sx of PN: bilateral, tingling and pain; begins distal and moves prox; related to HIV virus and/or ARVs; PE: decreased peripheral sensation, loss of reflexes) more from CDC
      • M Leprae (Etiology: spread via resp droplets; long incubation, btwn 2 & 7 yrs avg; Rfs: Southeast Asia; Sx/PE: anesthetic macule, area of involvement spreads, direct nerve involvement, neuropathic pain and enlargement of involved nerve, weakness, nasal deformity & stuffiness, skin ulcers on feet as cant feel injuries) more from CDC

      Parasites/Other

      Parasites, Spirochetes and Rickettsiae that cause neruological symptoms.
      • Parasites
        • Cysticercosis (T Solium - pork tapeworm) (Etiology: ingest eggs via infected beef that's undercooked; Mexico, Africa, Southeast Asia; eggs cross intestines, migrate to host muscles and brain; Sx: no f, otherwise unexplained muscles aches, ha, seizures)
        • Malaria (Etiology: spread by anopheles mosquito, tropical climates, in partic Southeast Asia, Africa; variants = P vivax, falciparum, ovale and malariae; incubation 1-4w; Sx: recurrent high fevers, C, HA; mild to life threatening (falciparum)
        • Toxoplasmosis (protozoa) (Etiology: carried in cat feces, healthy hosts not affected, in HIV + causes brain infection cd4 < 200; pregnant women can pass in utero→ congenital abnormalities; Sx: acute f, c, headache, delirium, szr, eye pain and visual loss from retinal involvement)
        • Trichinella (roundworm) (Etiology: rare in US; from eating infected meat; Sx: abd pain, n, v, diarrhea; after 1-2w, muscle pain when migrate to muscles, rash, f, ha, n, v)
      • Spirochetes
        • Borrelia burgdorferi (lyme) (Etiology: tick borne, endemic area north east, upper mid west, tick contact x 24-48h; incubation days to weeks; Sx: rash, f, c, aches; then arthralgias, heart block, CNS involvement; later still arthritis; can co-infect w/organisms causing babesiosis and anaplasmosis; PE: erythema migrans bull's eye type rash, sometime inflammatory arthritis) more from CDC
        • Borrelia - other sp (relapsing fever) (Etiology: tick borne, mountainous US→ West/Southwest, plateau of Mexico, South America; Sx: fever x ~3d→ then fever free x 1w→ then recurs; chills, ha, muscle aches, n, photophobia, joint aches, confusion; PE: non-specific; sometimes conj injection, confusion, mac-pap rash)
        • Leptospirosis (Etiology: contract via exposure to rodent/wild animal feces; incubation several weeks; Sx/PE: mild dz is self limited f, c, ha, n, v, muscle aches, conjunctival injection; severe dz with hepatic and renal involvement, pulmonary hemorrhage, and icterus) CDC
        • Syphillis (T Pallidum) (Rfs: sexual exposure, Etiology/Sx/PE: primary, secondary and tertiary manifestations; primary infection causes painless genital ulcer, ~3w after exposure → heals 4-6w, regional adenopathy; secondary manifestations weeks to mos later w/non-specific rash, predilection for palms, and soles; condyloma around genital areas, mucous involvement, generalized adenopathy, f, sweats, eyes→ iritis/uveitis; tertiary manifestations yrs later affecting CNS→ numbness, weakness, balance problems, dementia; large blood vessels→ aortitis, aneurysm) More from CDC
      • Rickettsiae
        • Rocky Mtn Spotted Fever (Etiology: tick borne, incubation 2d to 2w; can occur in most states in US, can cause meningo-encephalitis; Sx: f, c, ha, arthralgias, then generalized rash; can be severe/fatal)
        • Typhus (various types) (Etiology: spread via flea, louse or tick, reservoirs often rodents squirrels; summer mos, incubation 1-2w, Central/South America, Asia, Central Africa, tropics; can cause meningo-encephalitis; Sx: non-specific f, c, ha, malaise, myalgias; PE: non-specific mac-pap rash, sometimes adenopathy)

      Skin & Mucous Membranes

      Local Infections

        Fungal

        • Blastomycosis dermatidis (RFs: lives in soil, most commonly found Great Lakes, Mississippi & Ohio river valleys, SE US; typically inhaled; hosts usually of normal health; Sites: lungs, skin if disseminated or as primary problem; Sx: many are asymptomatic; sometimes flu-like illness; others w/sub acute cough, fever, sob; skin nodules or ulcers) more from CDC
        • Candida ballanitis (Sites: head of penis, in partic if uncircumcised; Rfs: worse if immunocompromised→ DM, HIV, chronic steroids; PE: bright red erruption, sometimes w/white d/c)
        • Coccidiomycosis (Etiology: south west US, higher risk if immune-compromised Site: lung parenchyma and pleural space, joints, skin; Sx: sub-acute sob, cough, f, also arthritis, skin nodules, seeding of other sites) more from CDC
        • Onychomycosis (Site: nails; Sx: common, chronic, nail infection; more common in toes than fingers; PE: nail appears thickened, opaque and deformed/ragged; non tender; can cause onycholysis→ separation of nail from bed)
        • Sporothrichosis(Rfs: lives in soil, infection via cut when handling dirg, vegetation; Sx: painless skin nodule at site of innoculation; develops over 1 to 12 weeks; increases in size and can ulcerate; sometimes local adenpathy)
        • Tinea cruris ("jock itch") (Site: inguinal crease, genitals; Sx/PE: puritic, scaly, red leading edge)
        • Tinea pedis ("athlete's foot") (Site: feet; Sx:can itch, pain if cracking; can be portal for secondary bacterial infxn; can sometimes blister; PE: scaly, predilection for sides/soles, macerated appearance in web spaces)
        • Tinea veriscolor (Sites; back, chest: Sx: multiple hypopigmented patches; sometimes puritic; PE: well circumscribed, hypopigmented patches, w/light scale)
        • Tinea capitis ("ring worm") (Site: scalp; PE: scaly, inflamed, raised, well defined patch(es) on scalp, associated w/focal hair loss)
        • Tinea corporis ("ring worm") (Site: skin - anywhere; PE/Sx: well circumscribed, scaly, patch on skin, sometimes puritic, central clearing w/active border)
        • Inframammary & diaper area candida (Site: below breasts, diaper distribution w/babies; Rfs: candida has predilection for moist spaces, also worse if immunocompromised→ DM, HIV, chronic steroids, itchy and sometimes painful PE: bright red eruption)
      • More on fungal infections from CDC

        • Bacterial

        • Cellulitis (Etiology: strep, staph, mrsa; Sx/PE: acute, painful, redness, fever; most commonly strep, though can be staph as well; focal swelling if associated with skin abscess - tend to be staph)
        • Erysipelas (Etiology: Streptococcus: Group A; Sites: often face; acute, red, f, pain PE: bright red, indurated, tender, well demarcated border, sometime oraange-peel consistency) more from CDC
        • Impetigo Streptococcus: Group A (Etiology: Streptococcus: Group A; Sites: often face; in particular kids; Sx: acute, crusted groups of lesions, often w/serous dc, not ill PE: honey crusted lesions, often around face, w/discharge) more from CDC
        • Erythrasma (corynebacterium) (Sx: chronic infection, groin, underarm, under skin folds, commonly mistaken for tinea, more common in diabetics & obese patients; otherwise, diptheroids not typically pathogenic; PE: reddish patch, sometimes scaly, sometimes itchy, sharp borders)
        • Folliculitis (Etiology: acute inflammatory process that starts around hair follicle, typically bacterial (staph, pseudomonas w/hot tubs); Sx: acute, painful, red; PE: tender, erythematous pustules)
        • Lympangitis (Sx: rapidly ascending red streak, assoc w/strep or staph, fever, tender; PE: ascending red streak, sometimes tender nodes)
        • Anthrax (Etiology: acquired from animal exposure or biological weapon; Sx: cutaneous ulcer to eshcar w/surrounding edema; if not inhalational, then no resp sx) more from CDC
        • Actinomyces (Sites: oral/neck/face, other organ systems Sx: slow growing abscess, often w/sinus tract development)
        • Nocardia (Sites: lung, skin; Etiology: lives in soil, inhaled or via open wound; Sx: w/pneumonia→ subacute cough, sob; f, abscess, cellulitis, lymphangitis if direct inoculation) more from CDC
        • Necrotizing fasciitis (Etiology: relatively uncommon; assoc w/dm, impaired immunity or perfusion; typically polymicrobial: strep, staph, clostridium, other; Sx: acute pain, swelling, fever, toxic appearing, often rapidly progressive; PE: typically abnl vs consistent w/severe illness, skin findings sometimes subtle→ redness, dusky discoloration, bulla; more profound findings as dz progresses)

        Viral

        • Herpes Zoster (Sx: acute vessicular erruption, pain a few days prior to skin lesions, neuropathic/burning type pain, PE: vessicles in a dermatomal distribution) more from CDC
        • Herpes simplex (Etiology/Rfs: past by sexual or oral contact; genital or oral herpes, encephalitis; Sx: fever or pain prior to appears vesicles ; resolves spont; can recur, can be congenitally acquired; rare cause pneumonia) more from CDC
        • HPV (Sx/Rfs: painless growths, can be single/grouped/or in multiple clusters, painless, acquired via sexual contact, travel w/other STIs; PE: single or clustered growths) more from CDC
        • Molluscum Contagiosum (Sx: acute papular erruption, assoc w/viral infection; PE: papules) more from CDC

        Mycobacterial

        • M Mariunum (Rfs: local infection, often of hand, related to exposure to fish tanks/cleaning; local papules to nodules, can ulcerate)

        Parasites

        • Leishmaniasis (Kala Azar) (Etiology: spread by sand-fly bite, widespread throughout subtropics→ Africa, Central & South America, India, Mediterranean basin, Asia, Middle East; Sx/PE: cutaneous: papule→ nodule→ painless raised & indurated ulcers that don't heal over weeks to mos; visceral→ can be silent, or cause fevers, sweats, chills, wt loss, adnenopathy, organomegaly)
        • Cutaneous larva migrans (hookworm) (Etiology: typical hosts are cats and dogs; larvae shed in tool, enter humans thru bare feet; Sx: migrate thru the skin, causing itchiness and red lines; die after a few weeks w/resolution of sx)
        • Schistosomiasis (fluke) (Etiology: South America, Middle East, Caribbean, Africa: flukes, invade skin of swimmers, enter blood stream→ live in portal/mesenteric veins; Sx: itching and erruption during first few days @ site where enters skin; can cause portal htn after years; also f, c, abd pain, diarrhea; can live in bladder → SCC after years)
        • Strongyloidiasis (Etiology: warm/temperate regions including southeast US, tropics/subtropics including Asia/Southeast Asia; larvae enter thru feet/skin if walk barefoot in soil w/infected feces→ enter skin, where they can cause itching→ travel to lung→ penetrate alveoli and travel up trachea→ cough and then swallowed→ travel to and live in small intestine; Sx: most carry life-long w/o any sx; non-compromised hosts can have vague sx including cough, epigastic pain, weakness, watery diarrhea, itching, constipation; can cause life threatening hyper-infxn syndrome w/systemic symptoms if compromised from glucocorticoids, malignancy, HTLV-1 or organ transplant; PE: sometimes serpiginous red erruption from migrating larva under skin)
        • Lice (Sx: itching in hair, often occurs in outbreaks amongst kids; PE: can sometimes see moving lice on scalp; nits on hair shaft) more from CDC
        • Scabies (Sx: can be acute or chronic, intense itching→in particular at night, predilection for web spaces/hands/arms though can be anywhere, sometimes burrows visible, but often just papules and excoriations seen; spread person to person, including via sexual contact) more from CDC

      Systemic Infections

      Bacterial

      • Disseminated gonorrhea (Etiology/Rfs: sexual activity w/at risk groups, relatively uncommon; Sx: acute, tender pustules; can also present w/tenosynovitis, arthritis; PE: painful pustules) more from CDC
      • Endocarditis (Rfs: prior endocarditis, unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart dz, prosthetic valve, acquired valvular heart dz (e.g. mitral prolapse w/regurg, aortic stenosis, rheumatic heart dz), IVDU, HIV, hemodialysis; Sx: f, c, sweats, sepsis, embolic events w/seeding and assoc sx; rapidity of clinical progression affected by organism and pt substrate; Etiology: 80% staph, strep; other less common organisms HACEK, Coxiella, T Whiplei, fungal; PE: fever, new or worse murmur, relatively rare skin findings include Janeway lesions→flat, painless, erythematous lesions on hands, and Osler's nodes→ painful nodules on fingers, findings associated w/seeding→ e.g. lbp or neuro findings from vertebral osteo, epidural abscess; focal neuro deficits from stroke or brain abscess) Duke criteria for endocarditis
      • Ecthyma gangrenosa (Etiology: assoc w/pseudomonal bacteremia; often in compromised host; Sx: acute redness, induration, fever; initially painless; one or multiple; evolve rapidly (<24h), macule--> pustules/bullae--> ulcer w/gangrenous tissue; PE: redness, induaration, bualle, central eschar/ulcer)
      • Neisseria meningitidis (Site: meninges, bacteremia; Rfs: often in outbreaks amongst young adults living in close quarters→ college dorms, barracks; unvaccinated; Sx: f, c, ha, n, v, sepsis; PE: very ill, ha, f, neck pain/stiffness, purpura) more from CDC
      • Toxic Shock Syndrome (Etiology: toxin mediated, related to staph or strep, first noted w/hyperabsorbent tampons; Site: w/staph, often dont find primary infxn; step assoc w/primary skin infection or other often necrotizing site; Sx: severe illness w/fever, hypotension, confusion, target organ dysfxn; PE: ill appearing, abnormal vitals, rapid deterioration often skin primary site if step, sometimes macular rash, desquamation 1-2w after onset) more from CDC Staph or CDC Strep
      • Vasculitis (Rfs: can occur secondary to many processes including: infection, rheum d/o, malignancy, etc; Sx: diffuse erruption, can occur anywhere; PE: small, palapable purpura, dont blanch when compress them, can coalesce)
      • Salmonella typhi (typhoid fever) (Site: small bowel, systemic infxn; Etiology: related to poor sanitation→ outbreaks, travel to endemic areas, spread by contaminated/unwashed food, poor sanitation, unclean water; gall bladder can act as reservoir; Rfs: from endemic area or travel; Sx/PE: relapsing daily fever x weeks, malaise, ha, chills, abd pain, diarrhea, maculop-pap rash→ rose spots, relative brady; aside from fever, sx quite variable)
      • In compromised hosts, any severe systemic infxn (bacterial or fungal) can metastasize to skin

      Viral

      • EBV (mononucleosis) (Sx: incubation 4-6w, pro-drome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias, then f, sore throat; PE: head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, maculo-pap rash after amox/other abx) more from CDC
      • Erythema multiforme (Sx/Etiology: acute, erythematous erruption, assoc with allergic reaction to meds, viral infections, auto-immune, idiopathic; usually self limited; PE: erythematous eruption, often w/central clearing)
      • Erythema nodosum (Etiology: acute, nodular erruption associated with infection, sarcoid, IBD, Bechets dz, other inflammatory/autoimmune conditions; PE: erythematous, painful nodules; often on legs)
      • Fifths disease (parvo virus) (Sx: acute, febrile illness in ages 5-19, runny nose, headache PE: skin erruption w/slapped cheek appearance, also rash on arms, soles, palms; sometimes symmetric inflammatory arthritis can mimic RA; can cause acute hypoprolif anemia) more from CDC
      • Hand, foot and mouth dz (coxsackievirus) (Sx: acute febrile illness, common in children, self limited, irritable/cranky, sometimes wont eat/drink due to oral invovelement, vessicles appear 1-2d after fever onset; PE: vessicles on soles of feet, palms and in mouth, also genitals, buttocks, elbows, knees) more from CDC
      • Measels (Etiology: uncommon w/vaccination, winter/spring in US, complications include encephalitis, pneumonia; Sx: cough, f, malaise, PE: conjunctivitis, runny nose, then rash, white spots on oral mucosa) more from CDC
      • Pityriasis rosea (Etiology: thought to be viral assoc; Sx: initial erruption is 2-5cm scaly "herald patch" on trunk, neck or legs; scaly w/central clearing; followed w/in days to weeks by wider spread erruption→ trunk, neck, back, legs→ many oval, scaly, pathces; can have "Christmas tree" distribution; variably puritic; lasts 6-8w, then resolves spont)
      • Roseola (herpes-6) (Sx: acute febrile illness, children typically < 3; PE: high fever, maculo-papular pink erruption, starts on trunk→ spreads to arms, legs; eyelid swelling)
      • Rubella (German measels) (Etiology: uncommon w/vaccination Sx: rash starts on face, fever, adenopathy; can be congenitally acquired) more from CDC
      • Varicella zoster (chicken pox) (Etiology: rare in kids as vaccine preventable; Sx: f, fatigue, ha, generalized vesicular erruption , duration 5-10d, can still get mild dz if vax, pneumonia in setting severe chicken pox or immunocomp) more from CDC

      Fungal

      • Blastomycosis dermatidis (RFs: lives in soil, most commonly found Great Lakes, Mississippi & Ohio river valleys, SE US; typically inhaled; hosts usually of normal health; Sites: lungs, skin if disseminated or as primary problem; Sx: many are asymptomatic; sometimes flu-like illness; others w/sub acute cough, fever, sob; skin nodules or ulcers) more from CDC
      • Coccidiomycosis (Etiology: south west US, higher risk if immune-compromised; Site: lung parenchyma and pleural space, joints, skin; Sx: sub-acute sob, cough, f, also arthritis, skin nodules, seeding of other sites) more from CDC
      • In compromised hosts, any severe systemic infxn (bacterial or fungal) can metastasize to skin

      Rickettsial

      • Rocky Mtn Spotted Fever (Etiology: tick borne, incubation 2d to 2w; can occur in most states in US, Sx: f, c, ha, arthralgias, then generalized rash; can be severe/fatal) more from CDC
      • Typhus (various types) (Etiology: spread via flea, louse or tick, reservoirs often rodents squirrels; summer mos, incubation 1-2w, Central/South America, Asia, Central Africa, tropics; Sx: non-specific f, c, ha, malaise, myalgias; PE: non-specific mac-pap rash, sometimes adenopathy)

      Spirochete

      • Secondary syphillis (Rfs: unprotected intercourse, men who have sex w/men, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's; Sx: secondary manifestations weeks after primary chancre heals; include: condyloma lata→ moist, frond-like growth in genital area; non-specific rash ,w/predilection for palms , and soles, mucosal involvement, adenopathy, alopecia) more from CDC
      • Lyme (Rfs: hx living in area endemic w/Lyme→ Northeast, WI/MN, Northern Calif, occurs secondary to tick bite; Sx: bull's eye type rash→ erythema migrans, f, c, adenopathy, arthralgias; joint inflammation mos to yrs later, large joints, can wax/wane; PE: erythema migrans rash, joint pain, swelling, effusion) more from CDC

      Parasitic

      • Cutaneous larva migrans (hookworm) (Etiology: typical hosts are cats and dogs; larvae shed in tool, enter humans thru bare feet; Sx: migrate thru the skin, causing itchiness and red lines; die after a few weeks w/resolution of sx)
      • Leishmaniasis (Kala Azar) (Etiology: spread by sand-fly bite, widespread throughout subtropics→ Africa, Central & South America, India, Mediterranean basin, Asia, Middle East; Sx/PE: cutaneous: papule→ nodule→ painless raised & indurated ulcers that don't heal over weeks to mos; visceral→ can be silent, or cause fevers, sweats, chills, wt loss, adnenopathy, organomegaly)
      • Lice (Sx: itching in hair, often occurs in outbreaks amongst kids; PE: can sometimes see moving lice on scalp; nits on hair shaft) more from CDC
      • Loa Loa (Etiology: from bite of deerfly; central and west Africa; Sx: diffue or local itching; transient, painless, red swellings; tendency for arms, legs, near joints; transient blurriness if crawl across eye; many are asx; takes mos after bite for sx to develop in those that get them; PE: transient, painless, red swelling; sometimes see worms moving under skin) more from CDC
      • Scabies (Sx: can be acute or chronic, intense itching→in particular at night, predilection for web spaces/hands/arms though can be anywhere, sometimes burrows visible, but often just papules and excoriations seen; spread person to person, including via sexual contact) more from CDC
      • Schistosomiasis (fluke) (Etiology: South America, Middle East, Caribbean, Africa: flukes, invade skin of swimmers, enter blood stream→ live in portal/mesenteric veins; Sx: itching and erruption during first few days @ site where enters skin; can cause portal htn after years; also f, c, abd pain, diarrhea; can live in bladder → SCC after years)
      • Strongyloidiasis (Etiology: warm/temperate regions including southeast US, tropics/subtropics including Asia/Southeast Asia; larvae enter thru feet/skin if walk barefoot in soil w/infected feces→ enter skin, where they can cause itching→ travel to lung→ penetrate alveoli and travel up trachea→ cough and then swallowed→ travel to and live in small intestine; Sx: most carry life-long w/o any sx; non-compromised hosts can have vague sx including cough, epigastic pain, weakness, watery diarrhea, itching, constipation; can cause life threatening hyper-infxn syndrome w/systemic symptoms if compromised from glucocorticoids, malignancy, HTLV-1 or organ transplant; PE: sometimes serpiginous red erruption from migrating larva under skin)

      HIV

      The following are skin disorders most commonly associated w/HIV. They tend to track w/CD4 counts, though it's important to recognize that patient's w/HIV can still suffer from disorders that occur in the general population.

      Acute HIV

      • Acute HIV (Rfs: men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/somone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; Sx/PE: throat pain and redness w/o exudate, fevers, chills, non-specific rash, adenopathy)

      Bacterial

      • Bacillary angiomatosis (bartonella sp) (Site: skin; Rfs: occurs in HIV infected or otherwise compromised pts; Sx: fevers, sweats, wt loss; PE: nodules on skin, resemble Kaposis Sarcoma) more from CDC
      • Cellulitis (Rfs: common bacterial infxn w/HIV +; Etiology: strep, staph, mrsa; Sx/PE: acute, painful, redness, fever; most commonly strep, though can be staph as well; focal swelling if associated with skin abscess - tend to be staph)
      • Folliculitis (Etiology: acute inflammatory process that starts around hair follicle, typically bacterial (staph, pseudomonas w/hot tubs); Sx: acute, painful, red; PE: tender, erythematous pustules)

      Fungal

      • Oral candidiasis (thrush) (Rfs: lower CD4 counts associated w/peristence and/or recurrence; PE: white discharge, bleeds when scraped)
      • Vaginal candidiasis (Rfs: lower CD4 counts associated w/peristence and/or recurrence; PE: cottage-cheese type discharge, itchy, bleeds when scraped)
      • Histoplasmosis (Sites; lungs, liver, spleen, mouth, systemic; Rfs: exposure to Mississippi & Ohio river valley, HIV+; Sx: can be asx/mild and resolve spont; often see x-ray evidence prior infection lung, spleen w/o known past infxn; cough, fever; can cause resp/systemic illness, oral ulcers in HIV+)
      • Blastomycosis dermatidis (RFs: lives in soil, most commonly found Great Lakes, Mississippi & Ohio river valleys, SE US; typically inhaled; hosts usually of normal health; Sites: lungs, skin if disseminated or as primary problem; Sx: many are asymptomatic; sometimes flu-like illness; others w/sub acute cough, fever, sob; skin nodules or ulcers) more from CDC
      • Coccidiomycosis (Etiology: south west US, higher risk if immune-compromised Site: lung parenchyma and pleural space, joints, skin; Sx: sub-acute sob, cough, f, also arthritis, skin nodules, seeding of other sites) more from CDC

      Viral

      • Herpes Simplex Virus (Sx: acute, painful, vessicles; pain often present before lesions appear, regress spontaneously 1-3w; w/low CD4 counts, may recur or persist)
      • HIV related apthous ulcers (Rfs: men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/somone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, hx needle stick injury from infected person; PE: painful ulcer(s) w/surrounding erythema)
      • Herpes Zoster (Rfs: increased incidence and recurrence rates as CD4 drops; Sx: acute vessicular erruption, pain a few days prior to skin lesions, neuropathic/burning type pain, PE: vessicles in a dermatomal distribution) more from CDC
      • HPV (Rfs: Low CD4; Sx: painless growths, can be single/grouped/or in multiple clusters, painless, acquired via sexual contact, travel w/other STIs; PE: single or clustered growths) more from CDC
      • Molluscum Contagiosum (Etiology: w/CD4 < 200→ molluscum more numerous & less likely resolved spont; Sx: acute papular erruption, assoc w/viral infection; PE: papules) more from CDC
      • Varicella zoster (chicken pox) (Etiology: if first infxn, can be severe and disseminated w/HIV+; Sx: f, fatigue, ha, generalized vesicular erruption, can still get mild dz if vax, pneumonia in setting severe chicken pox or immunocomp) more from CDC

      Spirochete

      • Syphilis (Rfs: men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/somone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's; PE: other findings assoc w/secondary syphillis including: non-specific rash, w/predilection for palms, and soles; hx painless genital ulcer from primary infxn)

      Parasitic

      • Scabies (Rfs: lower CD4 assoc w/crusted (Norwegian)scabies; Sx: can be acute or chronic, intense itching→ in particular at night, predilection for web spaces/hands/arms though can be anywhere, sometimes burrows visible, but often just papules and excoriations seen; spread person to person, including via sexual contact) more from CDC

      Cancer

      • Kaposis sarcoma (RFs: most commonly assoc w/advanced HIV, though can occur in elderly/others; Sx: purplish, red, brown nodules that can occur anywhere on skin; can affect any organ system including: intestines, liver, lung, etc→ sx related to degree of organ dysfxn; PE: purplish/red/brown nodules)
      • Non-Hodgkins (Etiology: 90% of lymphomas; many different types (B & T cell), significant variability in how aggressive they may be; Rfs: age > 60, hx hiv + confers markedly increased risk aggressive NHL; EBV→ Burkitts; h pylori→ stomach MALT; Sx: f, c, sweats, fatigue, wt loss; PE: progressive, painless, generalized adenopathy; splenomegaly; extra-nodal dz can involve almost any organ system)
      • Basal cell cancer (Etiology: more common w/HIV +; Rfs: chronic sun expossure, fair skin, prior bcc, immuncompromised; Sx: Non-healing, ulcerated, bleeding on a sun exposed region PE: rolled edges, growing, non-healing, central depression, pearly, w/telangiectasias)
      • Squamous cell cancer (Etiology: more common w/HIV +; Rfs: chronic sun expossure, fair skin, prior scc, immuncompromised; Sx: Non-healing, ulcerated, bleeding on a sun exposed region PE: non-healing, growing, crusted, firm, sun exposed areas)

      Autoimmune, inflammatory d/o, or drug reactions

      • Atopic dermatitis or eczema (Rfs: CD4< 200; Sx: chronic, waxes/wanes, hands/arms/face, itchy; PE: cracked, sometime peeling, puritic, erythematous skin)
      • Seborrheic dermatitis (Etiology: often more pronounced and severe in setting HIV +; Sx: persistent/recurrent scaly, red patches, affecting face, scalp, behind ears, body folds; PE scaly, red, flaky)
      • Psoriasis (Etiology: often more pronounced and severe in setting CDS < 200; Sx: plaques and scale; predilection for knees, elbows, behind ears, umbillicus, gluteal cleft, hands PE: raised plaques & scale on ertheymatous base, pitting of nails) more from CDC
      • HIV Lipodystrophy (Etiology: assoc w/HAART; Sx: abnormal deposition of fat in abd, back of neck, breasts, trunk; loss of sub cu fat in face, extremities, buttocks; assoc w/insulin resistance)
      • Generalized allergic reaction (Etiology: more common w/HIV +; Sx: occurs w/in a week of exposure to a med, itchy, can be local or generalized, morbilliform (measels-like); PE: erythematous, macular, often areas of coalescence)
      More on HIV from CDC

      Infxns Causing Genl Sx F, C, Sw

      Serious infections from many pathogens (bacteria, viruses, spirochetes, rickettsia, fungi, parasites) can cause systemic sx of f, c, and/or sweats. The site of origin of the infection (e.g. lung, kidney, etc) usually identified by presence of focal sx occurring prior to or concurrent w/generalized sx. (e.g. cough, sob, sputum→ pneumonia). Infections can also start locally and spread to other sites, leading to focal findings distant from place of origin (e.g. staph endocarditis can lead to an epidural abscess). The infections below tend to cause systemic sx w/o necessarily having localizing sx/site of origin.

      Bacterial

      • Endocarditis (Rfs: prior endocarditis, unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart dz, prosthetic valve, acquired valvular heart dz (e.g. mitral prolapse w/regurg, aortic stenosis, rheumatic heart dz), IVDU, HIV, hemodialysis; Sx: f, c, sweats, sepsis, embolic events w/seeding and assoc sx; rapidity of clinical progression affected by organism and pt substrate; Etiology: 80% staph, strep; other less common organisms HACEK, Coxiella, T Whiplei, fungal; PE: fever, new or worse murmur, relatively rare skin findings include Janeway lesions→flat, painless, erythematous lesions on hands, and Osler's nodes→ painful nodules on fingers, findings associated w/seeding→ e.g. lbp or neuro findings from vertebral osteo, epidural abscess; focal neuro deficits from stroke or brain abscess) Duke criteria for endocarditis
      • Brucellosis (Brucella) (Sites: systemic; Etiology: ingestion of raw/uncooked dairy or handling infected animals; Rfs: veterinarians, meat packers, slaughter house workers, farmers; Middle East, Mediterranean, Mexico, Africa; Sx/PE: causes weeks/months of recurrent f, c, sweats, arthritis, adenopathy, orchitis, hepato-splenomegaly) more from CDC
      • Tularemia (Francisella tularensis) (Sites: skin, lymph nodes, lung; Etiology/Rfs: passed from dying wild animals to humans via ticks/insects, US Southeast and Rocky Mtns; Sx: f, c, ha, oral or skin ulcers, painful adenopathy, sob, cough, muscle aches) more from CDC
      • Neisseria meningitidis (Site: meninges, bacteremia; Rfs: often in outbreaks amongst young adults living in close quarters→ college dorms, barracks; unvaccinated; Sx: f, c, ha, n, v, sepsis; PE: very ill, ha, f, neck pain/stiffness, purpura) more from CDC
      • Typhoid fever (Salmonella typhi) (Site: small bowel, systemic infxn; Etiology: related to poor sanitation→ outbreaks, travel to endemic areas, spread by contaminated/unwashed food, poor sanitation, unclean water; gall bladder can act as reservoir; Rfs: from endemic area or travel; Sx/PE: relapsing daily fever x weeks, malaise, ha, chills, abd pain, diarrhea, maculop-pap rash→ rose spots, relative brady; aside from fever, sx quite variable)
      • Streptococcus Pneumoniae (pneumococcus)(Sites: pneumonia, upper respiratory infections, meningitis; bacteremia if severe; Rfs: s/p splenectomy or fxnl asplenia, eldery and very young, any chronic medical condition→ copd, liver or renal dz, chf, cancer, diabetes, HIV, or otherwise immunocompromised; also csf leaks, cochlear implants; decreased risk if vaccinated) more from CDC

      Viral

      • CMV (Sx/PE: retinitis/colitis/disseminated dz in patients w/HIV; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w, then f, c, malaise hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, fatigue x 4-6w; head/neck adenopathy & pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC
      • Chikungunya (RFs: travel to Carribean, mosquitoe bite; Sx: fever, symmetric arthralgia, inflammatory arthritis wrists, fingers, ankles; muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash; onset 3-7d after bite; usually last days to weeks, sometimes mos) more from CDC
      • Dengue (Etiology: spread by aedes aegypti mosquito; RFs: exposure in tropics, SE Asia, Carribean, South America; Sx: incubation 4-7d, abrupt onset high fever, aches, retro-orbital pain, bone/muscle/joint pain, often low back pain, maculo-pap rash; sx resolve in 3-4d; can recur) more from CDC
      • Ebola (Etiology: spread via close human contact, bats as reservoir; RFs: travel to West Africa or exposure to someone at risk, spread via contact w/body fluids of infected person; Sx: incubation of up to 3w; high fever, fatigue, aches→ 0-3d; epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, arthralgias, myalgias, sorethroat, chest pain, headaches, delirium, conjunctival injection→ 3-10d; severe illness, shock, GI hemorrhage or other complications, death or recovery→ 7-12d) more from CDC
      • EBV (mononucleosis) (Rfs: spread by direct contact→ kissing, shared drinking glasses, shared toothbrushes, etc; Sx: incubation 4-6w, prodrome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias, then f, sore throat; PE: maculo-pap rash after amox or other abx, head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly) more from CDC
      • Influenza (Etiology: common cause upper and lower respiratory infection; Rfs: seasonal in North America Oct to April, increase risk amongst old, young, pregnant, chronic lung disease, any chronic illness, no vaccination; Sx: abrupt onset of myalgias, arthralgias, fever, chills) more from CDC

      Retroviral

      • HIV (Etiology/Rfs: hiv risk factors→ men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; risks of unusual infection increase as CD4 declines; Sx: acute infection→ fever, chills, sweats, adenopathy, rash, pharyngitis w/in 2-4 weeks - then resolves; latency until sx develop 6-10y after initial infxn (if not treated) related to drop in CD4: generalized sx include f, c, cough, wt loss; other illnesses: mucosal candidiasis; fungal, mtb lung infection; persistent diarrhea; CNS toxo; non hodgkins lymphoma; kaposis sarcoma of skin, adenopathy, etc) more from CDC

      Spirochetes

      • Borrelia burgdorferi (lyme) (Etiology: tick borne, endemic area north east, upper mid west, tick contact x 24-48h; incubation days to weeks; Sx: rash, f, c, aches; then arthralgias, heart block, CNS involvement; later still arthritis; can co-infect w/organisms causing babesiosis and anaplasmosis; PE: erythema migrans bull's eye type rash, sometime inflammatory arthritis) more from CDC
      • Borrelia miyamotoi (Etiology: tick borne, endemic area north east, summer mos; Sx: f, c, headache, arthralgias, myalgias, malaise/fatigue; PE: often ill appearing, sometimes faint lacy rash) more from CDC
      • Borrelia - other sp (relapsing fever) (Etiology: tick borne, mountainous US→ West/Southwest, plateau of Mexico, South America; Sx: fever x ~3d→ then fever free x 1w→ then recurs; chills, ha, muscle aches, n, photophobia, joint aches, confusion; PE: non-specific; sometimes conj injection, confusion, mac-pap rash)
      • Leptospirosis (Etiology: contract via exposure to rodent/wild animal feces; incubation several weeks; Sx/PE: mild dz is self limited f, c, ha, n, v, muscle aches, conjunctival injection; severe dz with hepatic and renal involvement, pulmonary hemorrhage, andicterus) CDC

      Parasites

      • African Trypanosomiasis (t brucei sleeping sickness) (Etiology: Africa, from tsetse fly; Sx: f, c, HA, delirium, muscle and joint aches, death in mos if untreated; PE: chancre→ skin sore at bite site, adenopathy)
      • Babesiosis (B. microti - protozoa) (Etiology: tick born, endemic Northeast/Northern Mid-west US; can co-infect w/lyme and anaplasmosis; Sx: 1-4 w after infxn; subacute f, c, sweats, HA, muscle aches; in severe cases hemolytic anemia, kidney, liver injury, resp distress)
      • Leishmaniasis (Kala Azar) (Etiology: spread by sand-fly bite, widespread throughout subtropics→ Africa, Central & South America, India, Mediterranean basin, Asia, Middle East; Sx/PE: cutaneous: papule→ nodule→ painless raised & indurated ulcers that don't heal over weeks to mos; visceral→ can be silent, or cause fevers, sweats, chills, wt loss, adnenopathy, organomegaly)
      • Malaria (Etiology: spread by anopheles mosquito, tropical climates, in partic Southeast Asia, Africa; variants = P vivax, falciparum, ovale and malariae; Sx: incubation 1-4w; recurrent high fevers, C, HA; mild to life threatening (falciparum))
      • Strongyloidiasis (Etiology: warm/temperate regions including southeast US, tropics/subtropics including Asia/Southeast Asia; larvae enter thru feet/skin if walk barefoot in soil w/infected feces→ enter skin, where they can cause itching→ travel to lung→ penetrate alveoli and travel up trachea→ cough and then swallowed→ travel to and live in small intestine; Sx: most carry life-long w/o any sx; non-compromised hosts can have vague sx including cough, epigastic pain, weakness, watery diarrhea, itching, constipation; can cause life threatening hyper-infxn syndrome w/fever, chills, sweats, abd pain, sepsis if compromised from glucocorticoids, malignancy, HTLV-1 or organ transplant; PE: sometimes serpiginous red erruption from migrating larva under skin)
      • Toxoplasmosis (protozoa) (Etiology: carried in cat feces, healthy hosts not affected, in HIV + causes brain infection cd4 < 200; pregnant women can pass in utero→ congenital abnormalities; Sx: acute f, c, headache, delirium, szr, focal neuro deficits, eye pain and visual loss from retinal involvement)
      • W bancrofti (filariasis) (Rfs/Etiology; tropics/sub-tropics, spread by mosquitoes; Sx: most are asx and wont have sequelae; some will have acute f, c, adenopathy; filaria invade lymphatics, after years→ lymphedema from obstruction of channels; PE: in some, chronic lymphedema)

      Rickettsiae

      • Anaplasmosis (Etiology: tick born, incubation 1-2w, Midwest and Eastern US; can co-infect w/organisms causing Lyme and babesiosis; Sx: f, ha, n, v, myalgias; often causes BM suppression)
      • Coxiella Burnetti (Q fever) (Etiology: spread from cattle and sheep, incubation 5d-2w; Sx: fever, chills, severe ha, myalgias, malaise, cough, abd pain; many recover spont; can cause pneumonia, hepatitis, myocarditis)
      • Human ehrlichiosis (Etiology: tick borne, incubation 1-2w, endemic South Eastern, South Central and Eastern US; similar presentation to anaplasmosis; Sx: f, ha, n, v, myalgias; often causes BM suppression)
      • Rocky Mtn Spotted Fever (Etiology: tick borne, incubation 2d to 2w; can occur in most states in US, Sx: f, c, ha, arthralgias, then generalized rash; can be severe/fatal)
      • Typhus (various types) (Etiology: spread via flea, louse or tick, reservoirs often rodents squirrels; summer mos, incubation 1-2w, Central/South America, Asia, Central Africa, tropics; Sx: non-specific f, c, ha, malaise, myalgias; PE: non-specific mac-pap rash, sometimes adenopathy)
      • More on Rickettsiae from CDC

      Fungi

      Typically assoc w/compromised host.
      • Aspergillus (Rfs: lung dz assoc w/immunocompromised host and/or w/structual lung dz→ e.g. bronchiectasis; Sites: lungs→ can be tissue invasive or chronic (e.g. fungal ball); sinuses, skin, other; Sx: can be indolent or acute; cough, sob, wt loss, cp, fatigue, hemoptysis; facial fullness/pain, nasal d/c→ invasive sinusitis in patients w/DM or otherwise compromised)
      • Blastomycosis dermatidis (RFs: lives in soil, most commonly found Great Lakes, Mississippi & Ohio river valleys, SE US; typically inhaled; hosts usually of normal health; Sites: lungs, skin if disseminated or as primary problem; Sx: many are asymptomatic; sometimes flu-like illness; others w/sub acute cough, fever, sob; skin nodules or ulcers) more from CDC
      • Candida (Rfs: compromised host→ HIV, chemo, steroids, long term abx w/indwelling lines, TPN use, long ICU stays; Sx: fevers, systemic sx/sepsis)

      Mycobacteria

      • M Tuberculosis (MTB) (RFs: HIV +, ETOh, chronic kidney, liver, lung dz; dialysis, homeless, immunocompromised for other reason→ steroid, TNF inhibitors, other; though can occur in anyone, reactivating sometimes years after initial exposure; extra-pulm TB increases in HIV+ w/CD4 < 350; Sx: sub-acute, cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, sweats, fatigue; can also infect GI/GU tracts, pericardium, bones, cns, lymph nodes or become widely disseminated) more from CDC

      HIV

      HIV can manifest in many ways. Below are common conditions (organized by organ system) associated w/this protean infection. Note that CD4 thresholds should be viewed as rough guidelines.

      Acute HIV Infxn

      • HIV (Etiology/Rfs: hiv risk factors→ men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; risks of unusual infection increase as CD4 declines; Sx: acute infection→ fever, chills, sweats, adenopathy, rash, pharyngitis; sometimes aseptic meningitis/encepahlitis; occur w/in 2-4 weeks exposure - then resolve; latency until later sx develop 6-10y after initial infxn if un-treated)

      IRIS

      • Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (RFs: low cd4, untreated or sub-optimally treated HIV, known or quiescent opportunistic infections (OIs), cancer (e.g. Kaposis) or autoimmune d/o: Etiology: reconstitution of immune system w/initiation of Anti-retroviral therapy→ profound inflammatory reaction as body responds to pathogen(s)/diseases; Sx: f, transient worsening of known infection/disease or unmasking of quiescent/unknown condition; specific sx based on the OI(s)/pathological condition and the anatomic site where focused; e.g: if pulmonary TB>worsening sob and hypoxia; if CNS crypto→ worsening meningitis; if CMV retinitis→ worsening visual sx, etc.; sx range from mild to severe; occurs within days to ~8 weeks of starting ARVs; then sx resolve & patient improves.)

      Neuro - Headache

      Could still be due to any of the problems that affect normal hosts.
      • Infection
        • Bacterial Meningitis (Etiology: inflammation of layers covering brain; Sx: photphobia, acute neck stiffness, headache, fever, confusion, and generalized illness; PE: f, + Kernigs (specific not sensitive)→ pain with passive knee extension when hip flexed to 90; + Brudzinski (specific not sensitive)→ hip and knee flexion occurs w/passive neck flexion; + jolt (sensitive not specific)→ worsening ha when patient rotates head back & forth; less common to have focal neurological findings and overall less impaired compared w/encephalitis)
        • Bacterial Abscess (Etiology: reason for abscess → spread from adjacent site→ dental or sinuses, AVM, PFO, neurosurgery; organism based on underlying etiology: can be single, mixed; also consider nocardia; Sx: acute/subacute, headache, fever, loss of function based on location, progressive, delirium)
        • Toxoplasmosis (parasite) (Etiology: typically causes mass lesion; less commonly encephalitis; Rfs: CD4 < 200; Sx: sub-acute, headache, confusion, fever, seizure, focal neuro deficits)
        • HSV (Etiology: causes encephalitis; Sx: fever, confusion, progressive over days to weeks)
        • VZV (Etiology: causes menongo-encephalitis; Sx: fever, confusion, rash, focal deficits including CN palseys)
        • CMV (Etiology: relatively rare cause encephalitis; RFs: CD4 < 50; Sx: progresses over days)
        • Cryptococcus (fungal) (Rfs: CD4 < 50; Etiology: typically causes meningitis, less commonly cryptococcomas; often assoc w/increased ICP; Rfs: CD4 < 50; Sx: headache, fever, confusion; progresses over hours to days)
        • Cocci (fungal) (Rfs: CD4 < 250; Sx: headache, neck pain, lethargy, living in endemic area &rarr Southwest)
        • TB (Etiology: can cause meningitis, tuberculomas or both; Rfs: TB elsewhere, CD4 < 350; Sx: fever, sweats, weight loss, confusion; focal deficits)
        • Syphilis (spirochete) (Rfs: can occur at any CD4 level, sexual exposure; Etiology/Sx/PE: primary, secondary and tertiary manifestations; primary infection causes painless genital ulcer → heals 4-6w; secondary manifestations weeks later non-specific rash, w/predilection for palms , and soles, condyloma around genital areas, mucous involvement, adenopathy; ha, photophobia, stiff neck w/syphillitic meningitis; tertiary manifestations yrs later affecting CNS→ numbness, weakness, balance problems, dementia; large blood vessels→ aortitis, aneurysm) more from CDC
      • Malignancy
        • Primary CNS Lymphoma (Etiology: typically B-cell; Rfs: CD4 < 50; Sx: sub-acute, lethargy, confusion, HA, focal deficits, seizure)
        • Systemic Lymphoma(Etiology: nhl, tends to be aggressive; Rfs: CD4 < 50; Sx: sub-acute, f, sweats, wt loss, confusion, focal deficits, seizure, adenopathy elsewhere, unexplained organogmegaly)

      Neuro - Other

      10-20% have neuro dysfxn as first manifestation HIV; 60% w/neuro dysfxn w/advanced dz.
      • AIDS Related Dementia (Etiology: related to toxic effect of HIV itself; tracks w/low CD4 count and high VL; RFs: not on HAART, high VL, low CD4; Sx: cognition→ inattention, reduced conentration, slowed processing; motor→ slowed movement, clumsiness, ataxia; behavior→ ranges from apathetic/dulled to aggitated; progressive over time to severe impairment and death; some component reversible w/rx HAART)
      • Delirium (Etiology: multi factorial; high risk if low CD4, as suseptible to many OIs and related organ dysfxn; also related to meds and other contributors as w/non-HIV patients)
      • Demyelinating polyneuropathy - CIDP or Guillain-Barre like
      • Mononeuritis multiplex (Etiology: can occur w/low or higher CD4; Sx: isolated or multifocal peripheral nerve or root dysfxn; asymmetric; motor and sensory; develops over weeks; in those w/higher CD4s often self-limited)
      • Myelopathy (Rfs: advanced/end stage; Sx: slowly progressive over mos, bilateral weakness, numbness and urinary dysfxn; specifics related to region of cord affected; PE: symmetirc spasticity, hyperreflexia, babinski, impaired sensation)
      • Myopathy (Etiology: rare; related to HIV or meds; Sx: progressive, proximal muscle weakness; sensory fxn preserved; sometimes muscle pain; PE: proximal muscle weakness, nl sensation and reflexes)
      • Peripheral Neuropathy (Sx: bilateral, tingling and pain; begins distal and moves prox; related to HIV virus and/or ARVs; PE: decreased peripheral sensation, loss of reflexes)
      • Progressive lumbrosacral polyradiculopathy (Etiology: uncommon, related to CMV or other pathogens; Sx: progressive B leg weakness, impaired sensation; develops over weeks, leads to paralysis, incontinence)
      • Progressive Multi-focal Leukoencephalopathy (PML) (Etiology: JC virus; RFs: CD4 < 100; Sx: lethargy, apathy, hallucinations, inattentiveness, perservation, & other manifestations of confusional state that's progressive over months, unrelenting→ leading to disability and death)
      • Seizures (Etiology: related to structural brain dz from infection or cancer; meds/drug of abuse/withdrawl; toxic-metabolic process; or could have unrelated szr d/o)
      • Stroke (Etiology: related to metabolic complications of meds, aging of patients w/HIV; Sx: similar to non-HIV patients - w/loss of fxn based on site of stroke)

      Skin/Mucous Membranes

      The following are skin and mucous membrane d/o most commonly associated w/HIV. They tend to track w/CD4 counts, though it's important to recognize that patient's w/HIV can still suffer from disorders that occur in the general population.

      Acute HIV

      • Acute HIV (Rfs: men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/somone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; Sx/PE: throat pain and redness w/o exudate, fevers, chills, non-specific rash, adenopathy)

      Bacterial

      • Bacillary angiomatosis (bartonella sp) (Site: skin; Rfs: occurs in HIV infected or otherwise compromised pts; Sx: fevers, sweats, wt loss; PE: nodules on skin, resemble Kaposis Sarcoma) more from CDC
      • Cellulitis (Rfs: common bacterial infxn w/HIV +; Etiology: strep, staph, mrsa; Sx/PE: acute, painful, redness, fever; most commonly strep, though can be staph as well; focal swelling if associated with skin abscess - tend to be staph)
      • Folliculitis (Etiology: acute inflammatory process that starts around hair follicle, typically bacterial (staph, pseudomonas w/hot tubs); Sx: acute, painful, red; PE: tender, erythematous pustules)

      Fungal

      • Oral candidiasis (thrush) (Rfs: lower CD4 counts associated w/peristence and/or recurrence; PE: white discharge, bleeds when scraped)
      • Vaginal candidiasis (Rfs: lower CD4 counts associated w/peristence and/or recurrence; PE: cottage-cheese type discharge, itchy, bleeds when scraped)
      • Histoplasmosis (Sites; lungs, liver, spleen, mouth, systemic; Rfs: exposure to Mississippi & Ohio river valley, HIV+; Sx: can be asx/mild and resolve spont; often see x-ray evidence prior infection lung, spleen w/o known past infxn; cough, fever; can cause resp/systemic illness, oral ulcers in HIV+)
      • Blastomycosis dermatidis (RFs: lives in soil, most commonly found Great Lakes, Mississippi & Ohio river valleys, SE US; typically inhaled; hosts usually of normal health; Sites: lungs, skin if disseminated or as primary problem; Sx: many are asymptomatic; sometimes flu-like illness; others w/sub acute cough, fever, sob; skin nodules or ulcers) more from CDC
      • Coccidiomycosis (Etiology: south west US, higher risk if immune-compromised Site: lung parenchyma and pleural space, joints, skin; Sx: sub-acute sob, cough, f, also arthritis, skin nodules, seeding of other sites) more from CDC

      Viral

      • Herpes Simplex Virus (Sx: acute, painful, vessicles; pain often present before lesions appear, regress spontaneously 1-3w; w/low CD4 counts, may recur or persist)
      • HIV related apthous ulcers (Rfs: men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/somone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, hx needle stick injury from infected person; PE: painful ulcer(s) w/surrounding erythema)
      • Herpes Zoster (Rfs: increased incidence and recurrence rates as CD4 drops; Sx: acute vessicular erruption, pain a few days prior to skin lesions, neuropathic/burning type pain, PE: vessicles in a dermatomal distribution) more from CDC
      • HPV (Rfs: Low CD4; Sx: painless growths, can be single/grouped/or in multiple clusters, painless, acquired via sexual contact, travel w/other STIs; PE: single or clustered growths) more from CDC
      • Molluscum Contagiosum (Etiology: w/CD4 < 200→ molluscum more numerous & less likely resolved spont; Sx: acute papular erruption, assoc w/viral infection; PE: papules) more from CDC
      • Varicella zoster (chicken pox) (Etiology: if first infxn, can be severe and disseminated w/HIV+; Sx: f, fatigue, ha, generalized vesicular erruption, can still get mild dz if vax, pneumonia in setting severe chicken pox or immunocomp) more from CDC

      Spirochete

      • Syphilis (Rfs: men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/somone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's; PE: other findings assoc w/secondary syphillis including: non-specific rash, w/predilection for palms, and soles; hx painless genital ulcer from primary infxn)

      Parasitic

      • Scabies (Rfs: lower CD4 assoc w/crusted (Norwegian)scabies; Sx: can be acute or chronic, intense itching→ in particular at night, predilection for web spaces/hands/arms though can be anywhere, sometimes burrows visible, but often just papules and excoriations seen; spread person to person, including via sexual contact) more from CDC

      Cancer

      • Kaposis sarcoma (RFs: most commonly assoc w/advanced HIV, though can occur in elderly/others; Sx: purplish/red/brown nodules that can occur anywhere on skin; can affect any organ system including: intestines, liver, lung, etc→ sx related to degree of organ dysfxn; PE: purplish/red/brown nodules)
      • Non-Hodgkins (Etiology: 90% of lymphomas; many different types (B & T cell), significant variability in how aggressive they may be; Rfs: age > 60, hx hiv + confers markedly increased risk aggressive NHL; EBV→ Burkitts; h pylori→ stomach MALT; Sx: f, c, sweats, fatigue, wt loss; PE: progressive, painless, generalized adenopathy; splenomegaly; extra-nodal dz can involve almost any organ system)
      • Basal cell cancer (Etiology: more common w/HIV +; Rfs: chronic sun expossure, fair skin, prior bcc, immuncompromised; Sx: Non-healing, ulcerated, bleeding on a sun exposed region PE: rolled edges, growing, non-healing, central depression, pearly, w/telangiectasias)
      • Squamous cell cancer (Etiology: more common w/HIV +; Rfs: chronic sun expossure, fair skin, prior scc, immuncompromised; Sx: Non-healing, ulcerated, bleeding on a sun exposed region PE: non-healing, growing, crusted, firm, sun exposed areas)

      Autoimmune/Inflamd/o, or drug reactions

      The following are autoimmune, inflammatory d/o, or drug reactions associated w/HIV.
      • Atopic dermatitis/eczema (Rfs: CD4< 200; Sx: chronic, waxes/wanes, hands/arms/face, itchy; PE: cracked, sometime peeling, puritic, erythematous skin)
      • Seborrheic dermatitis (Etiology: often more pronounced and severe in setting HIV +; Sx: persistent/recurrent scaly, red patches, affecting face, scalp, behind ears, body folds; PE scaly, red, flaky)
