      • Psoriasis (Etiology: often more pronounced and severe in setting CDS < 200; Sx: plaques and scale; predilection for knees, elbows, behind ears, umbillicus, gluteal cleft, hands PE: raised plaques & scale on ertheymatous base, pitting of nails) more from CDC
      • HIV Lipodystrophy (Etiology: assoc w/HAART; Sx: abnormal deposition of fat in abd, back of neck, breasts, trunk; loss of sub cu fat in face, extremities, buttocks; assoc w/insulin resistance)
      • Generalized allergic reaction (Etiology: more common w/HIV +; Sx: occurs w/in a week of exposure to a med, itchy, can be local or generalized, morbilliform (measels-like); PE: erythematous, macular, often areas of coalescence)

      SOB/Cough

      Etiology can still be any that affect HIV -; additional considerations based on degree of immune compromise
      • Infection
        • Bacterial pneumonia community acquired: pneumococcus, h influenza, legionella
        • Viral pneumonia - cmv, hsv, vzv
        • Fungi - Coccidimycosis (Rfs: CD4 < 250, living or visit to Southwest; Sx: cough, fever, sob)
        • Fungi - Histoplasmosis (Rfs: CD4 < 300; Sx: cough, sob, sweats; can have multiple other organ systems involved, including: liver, spleen, cns)
        • Fungi - Pneumocystis Jirovecii (Rfs: CD4 < 100 or untreated HIV; Sx: sub-acute, cough, sob, chest pain)
        • Fungi - Cryptococcus (neoformans) (Sites: cns, lungs, skin; Rfs: assoc w/immunocompromised, CD4 < 50 or untreated HIV; Sx: CNS disease→ sub-acute headache, fever, confusion; pulmonary→ subacute cough, sob, chest pain, f)
        • Fungi - Cryptococcus (gattii) (Sites: lungs, skin, cns; Rfs: found on West coast/Pacific Northwest; can cause pneumonia in normal hosts; can also infect those w/HIV and advance t-cell deficiencincy states; Sx: subacute cough, sob, chest pain, f; CNS sx of subacute confusion, ha)
        • Mycobacteria - TB (Rfs: can occur at any CD4, w/CD4 < 350→ extra-pulmonary TB increases; Sx: if > 350, similar sx to non-hiv +→ cough, fever, sweats, sob, hemoptysis)
        • Mycobacterium - MAC (Rfs: HIV + w/CD4 < 50 for disseminated dz; hx bronchietasis for lung sx; Sx: persistent/progressive cough, sputum, sob)
      • Malignancy
        • Kaposis Sarcoma (Rfs: CD4 < 150, Sx: sob, cough, PE: KS elsewhere on body)
        • Lymphoma (Sx: sub-actue, f, sweats, wt loss, PE: adenopathy elsewhere, unexplained organogmegaly)

      Diarrhea

      Can still be any of the processes that affect normal hosts as above; also HIV meds; other infectious or malignancy related Etiologyogies increase as cd4 levels decline.

      Infection

      • Parasite
        • Isosporiasis (Rfs: CD4 < 100 or untreated HIV, associated with drinking untreated water)
        • Giardia (protozoa) (Etiology: spread via poor hygiene, contaminated water, drinking from ponds/streams, anal intercourse; many infected are asx; Sx: incubation 1-3w; non-bloody watery/greasy/foul smelling diarrhea, gas, burping)
        • Cryptosporidium (Rfs: CD4 < 100 or untreated HIV; Sx: acute or subacute profound diarrhea, abdominal cramps, fever, n, v, )
        • Microsporidiosis (Etiology/Rfs: associated with drinking untreated water, CD4 < 100 or untreated HIV; Sx: in addn to diarrhea, can affect other systems, causing→ keratitis, encephalitis, other)
      • Fungal
        • Histoplasmosis (Rfs: CD4 < 150; Sx: f, c, wt loss, abd pain; liver, spleen and lymph node involvement)
      • Mycobacteria
        • MAI (Rfs: CD4 < 50; Sx: diarrhea, n, v, abdominal pain, f, c, fatigue; can infect liver, spleen, lymph nodes, bone marrow, lung, pericardium→ causing adenopathy or organomegaly, anemia)
      • Viral
        • CMV (Rfs: CD 4 < 50; Sx: cramps, abd pain persistent diarrhea - sometimes w/blood, anorexia, wt loss, fatigue, cmv elsewhere→ retinitis)

      Malignancy

      • Kaposis (Rfs: CD4 < 150, KS on skin or elsewhere on body)
      • Lymphoma (in partic NHL) (Sx: subacute, f, sweats, wt loss, adenopathy elsewhere, unexplained organogmegaly, focal cns sx)

      Cancer as Cause of Fever

      Cancers cause fever as primary manifestation of malignancy or a result of infection→ induced immunocompromised state and/or chemotherpy. Malignancies most commonly linked to pimary fever listed below:

      Solid tumors

      • Renal cell (Rfs: smoking, obesity, family hx; Sx: low back to lower abd/groin discomfort, wt loss, sweats, fever, flank pain, hematuria; PE: papable only if very advanced)
      • Liver (hepatocellular) (Rfs: chronic hepatitis for any reason→ viral, etoh, etc; Sx: RUQ/epigastric persistent/progressive discomfort discomfort, anorexia, weight loss; PE: palpable, firm liver if advanced)
      • Metastatic disease involving the liver - primary can be anywhere

      Leukemia

      Sx: fevers, chills, weight loss, adenopathy, decreased appetite; fatigue/low energy/chronically tired/SOB→ from anemia, mucocutaneous bleeding→ from low plt; impaired immunity, recurrent infections from→ low numbers or dysfunctional WBCs
      • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) (Etiology: monoclonal B cell d/o; Rfs: age > 60, male sl > female, agent orange exposure; Sx: often asx x years→ picked up on incidental labs; then fever, sweats, adenopathy, fatigue, wt loss, bleeding, infections; can transform into acute leukemia or lmphoma; can develop auto-immune hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia; PE: as progresses→ adenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly)
      • Chronic myelocytic leukemia (CML) (Etiology: associated w/9:22 chromosome translocation; Rfs: avg age 55-60, radiation, male sl > female; Sx: fatigue, abdominal fullness, f, weats, wt loss; WBCs elevated, often plt too; chronic phase x 3-5y; then accelerated phase w/blast crisis→ infection, bleeding; PE: often splenomegaly)
      • Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) (Etiology: most common acute leukemia in kids; in adults, represents 20% of acute leukemias; RFs: in adults→ male, hx prior radiation or chemo, > age 70, Down's syndrome; Sx: fatigue, sob, weakness, fever, sweats, easy bruising/bleeding; PE: palor, petechiae, echymoses; sometimes adenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)
      • Acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) (Etiology: most common adult acute leukemia; Rfs: male, age > 60, smoking, hx prior chemo or xrt; hx of myelofibrosis, essential thrombocythemia, polycythemia vera; Sx: fatigue, fever, dyspnea, easy bruising; PE: palor, echymoses, petechiae, musocal bleeding; sometimes adenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)
      • Other leukemias
      • Myelofibrosis (Etiology: sometimes have p vera, cml or ET first; Sx: generalized fatigue, night sweats, wt loss, fever; sob, doe→ from anemia; abd discomfort from hepato-splenomegaly→ sites of extra med hematopoeisis; PE: hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)

      Lymphoma

      General (Sx: wt loss/decreased appetite sweats, fevers, chills, adenopathy, organomegaly, abdominal fullness; CNS involvement and sx w/NHL; skin involvement w/cutaneous t-cell NHL; PE: generalized adenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, erythroderma,, sometimes focal neurological findings if CNS involvement)
      • Hodgkins (Etiology: 10% of lymphomas; Rfs: age 15-40 & > 55, hiv +, EBV infection, fam hx; Sx: fever, sweats, wt loss, adenopathy; cough/sob if mediastinal invovlmenet; PE: painless, progressive adenopathy, in particular head/neck; sometimes splenomegaly, hepatomegaly)
      • Non-Hodgkins (Etiology: 90% of lymphomas; many different types (B & T cell), significant variability in how aggressive they may be; Rfs: age > 60, hx hiv + confers markedly increased risk aggressive NHL; EBV→ Burkitts; h pylori→ stomach MALT; Sx: f, c, sweats, fatigue, wt loss; PE: progressive, painless, generalized adenopathy; splenomegaly; extra-nodal dz can involve almost any organ system)

      Autoimmune/Rheum Fever

      Specific autoimmune/rheum disorder causing fever is based on other symptoms and findings - relatively uncommon (compared w/above)
      • Acute rheumatic fever (Sx: relatively uncommon, occurs 2-3w after strep pharyngitis, assoc w/fever, fatigue, acute/abrupt onset, migratory inflammatory arthritis of large joints typically; long term risk of mitral or aortic valve dz; PE: affected joint(s) are warm, red, pain w/movement)
      • Adult Still's Disease (Etiology: febrile illness of unknown etiology; Sx: f and other sx are persistent, sub-acute; evaluation of f does not reveal other etiology; also arhtritis & arthralgias of larger joints; salmon colored, maculo-pap non-puritic skin erruption; myalgias, adenopathy, sore throat, pericarditis and pleuritis; PE: erruption is light salmon colored mac/pap, pharyngitis, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy)
      • Cryogloblulinemia (Etiology: small-vessel vasculitis caused by antigen-antibody complex deposition; Type I monoclonal→ IgM or IgG, related to lymphoprolif d/o→ lymphoma, myeloma; Type II and III, mixed cryos IgM and IgG; related to Hep C (most common), SLE, RA, lymphoma, myeloma, hiv, hep b, other autoimmune; RFs: female > male, ages 40-50; Sx: subacute fatigue, weakness, muscle and joint aches, cough/sob if pulmonary involvement; confusion; symmetric or asymmetric often painful distal neuropathy, painful skin ulcers of extremities, purpuric papules; membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis; PE: palpable purpura of vasculitis, Raynauds, livedo reticularis, distal skin ulcers)
      • Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss) (Etiology: idiopathic d/o, small-to-medium vessel vasculitis; w/high levels circulating and tissue invasive eosinophils; Rfs: men=women, assoc also w/leukotriene antagonists; Sx: progressive, adult onset asthma, cough & wheezing, nasal stuffiness→ w/resp sx usually ~2-10 y prior to systemic sx assoc w/eosinophilic deposition in target organs and vasculitis; in these later phases→ systemic sx including: sob from parenchymal lung involvement; f, c, muscle aches; hematuria from renal involvement; heart failure, pericarditis and dysrhythmia w/cardiac involvement; peripheral neuropathy; PE: wheezing, skin findings of vasculitis: small, palapable purpura, don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; hematuria/renal involvement; unexplained peripheral neuropathy)
      • Familial Med Fevers (Rfs: Mediterranean descent→ Turkish, Jewish, Armenian, Arab, other; family hx; Sx: uncommon, associated w/cryptic abdominal pain, rash, arthritis, arthralgias, myalgias, recurrent fever)
      • Giant Cell Arteritis (Rfs: age > 50, often prior hx PMR; Sx fatigue, headache, joint aches, acute visual loss; PE: sometimes scalp or temp art tenderness, abnl optic nerve)
      • Granulomatosis with poyangiitis (Wegeners) (Etiology: small-to-medium vessel vasculitis; Sx: vasculitis→ recurrent/progressive nasal congestion, cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; PE: mucosal erythema, ulcer, nasal septum perf)
      • Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) ()Etiology: uncontrolled activation of T Cells, w/inappropriate release of cytokines and macrophage activation; Rx directed at underlying cause; Rfs: triggered by lymphoma, leukemia, autoimmunes dz, infxns→ ebv, enterovirus, gastroenteritis, other; also a rare familial form; Sx: f that's unexplained, other related to the inciting process, increased ferretin, cytopenias, hyper-TGs; PE: f, splenomegaly)
      • Inflammatory bowel disease - Crohn's dz or UC (Sx: sub-acute, recurrent or chronic diarrhea; wt loss, bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, nocturnal diarrhea; systemic sx; presentation can also be fulminant)
      • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
      • Microscopic polyangitis (MPA) (Etiology: small vessel vasculitis; Sx: fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, sweats, wt loss; recurrent/progressive cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; less often nasal sx c/w GPA; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; skin ulcers; neuropathy; PE: palpable purpura, skin ulcer/necrosis)
      • Polyarteritis Nodosa (Etiology: medium-vessel-vasculitis; Rfs: 40s-50s, men>women, Hep B/C; Sx: more commonly subacute over mos f, s, malaise, wt loss, muscle/joint pain; multiple systems: arthritis, glomerulonephritis, peripheral nerve pain/dysfxn, skin w/ulcers, small, palapable purpura→ don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; abd pain, blood per rectum)
      • Polymyalgia Rheumatica (PMR) (Rfs: age > 50, Sx: subacute arthralgias affecting hips and shoulders, worse in AM; can't sleep secondary to inability to find comfortable position; PE: no findings of arthritis/synovitis on exam, no objective findings of weakness)
      • RA (Etiology: can cause interstitial lung dz, pleural inflammation, pulm vasc dz; meds for RA can have lung tox, also→ immunocomp→ infxn; Rfs: women > men; age 30-55; Sx: subacute (>6w), persistent/progressive joint pain, worse in AM due to gelling→ improves w/use, fatigue, tendency for bilateral involvement, commonly small and medium sized joints; nerve symptoms can be motor, sensory or from compression; PE: warmth, redness, spongy feeling from synovial inflam, pain w/squeezing of joints, effusion, abnormal appearing if longstanding, MCPs with chronic changes; extra articular findings: episcleritis, pleural/pericardial inflam, rheumatoid nodules) more from CDC
      • Serum sickness (Rfs: typically from rxn to abx, or secondary to viral infxn → e.g. acute hep b; Sx: acute, symetric, additive/migratory, polyarthritis; myalgias, fever, rash, onset days to weeks after exposure)
      • Takayasu's arteritis (Etiology: large vessel vasculitis, onset 10-30yo, Asian background, women > men; Sx: sub-acute and progressive, fevers, fatigue, wt loss, myalgias arthralgias; target organ sx based on affected vessels: abdominal aorta & branches→ abdominal pain, htn; thoracic aorta & branches→ chest pain, sob, tia/stroke; PE: loss of palpable pulses radial, carotid, lower extremity)
      • Vasculitis - other

      Endocrine Causes of Fever

      • Menopause (Rfs: age ˜ 50; Sx: sweats but no fever, irregular menstruation)
      • Hyperthyroidism (Etiology: grave's disease, thyroiditis, multi-nodular or single toxic adenoma, exogenous thyroid hormone consumption; Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, sweating, wt loss, weakness; PE: fever, sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid→ nodules, pain or diffuse enlargement based on etiology, hyper-reflexia, moist skin)
      • Thyroid storm (Etiology: a profound thyrotoxic state, w/mortality 20-30%; Rfs: untreated or undiagnosed hyperthyroidism, often triggered by stress/infection or iodine admin from CT; Sx: acute, severe palpatations, sob/doe, tremor, abd discomfort, n, v, d, delirium; PE: ill appearing, fever, tachycardia, a fib, tremor, enlarged thyroid, abd discomfort, pulmonary edema/findings of chf, confusion)
      • Low testosterone (Sx: decreased libido, errectile dysfxn, generalized weakness, decreased muscle mass, depression)
        • Primary (Rf/Etiology: testicular hypofunction from: prior infection→ mumps; torsion/trauma/cancer/other reason for testicular death; past chemotherapy; genetic disorders→ prader-willi; PE: sometimes small or absent testes)
        • Secondary (Rf/Etiology: pituitary/hypothalamic dysfxn from: tumor, inflammatory processes, hypoperfusion; meds→ chronic narcotics, LHRH agonists for prostate ca; hemochromatosis; chronic diseases→ HIV, Dm, copd, chf, renal failure, cirrhosis)
      • Adrenal insufficiency (Sx: feeling poorly in general, n, v, orthostatic sx)
        • Primary (Etiology: problem at level of adrenal gland: autoimmune destruction → assoc w/DM 1, celiac dz; hemorrhage/infarct; infection → TB, HIV; infiltration w/tumor; PE: sometimes darkening of mucous membranes, skin folds, & pressure points)
        • Secondary (Etiology: problem at level of pituitary/hypothalamus → low acth; can be from surgery, tumor, hypoperfusion, auto-immune, trauma, meds→ chronic glucocorticoids)

      Meds Causing Fever

      Dx based on r/o other causes and temporal link between initiation med and fever onset
      • Malignant hyperthermia (Etiology: exposure to inhalational anesthetics or succinylcholine, typically in OR or w/in 24h; Sx: abrupt onset high fever, aggitation; PE: temp to 46c, Htn, tachycardia, tachypnea, ill appearing, diaphoretic, mottled skin, severe generalized rigidity, decreased reflexes)
      • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (Etiology: exposure to haldol, chlorpomazine, other typical or atypical neruoleptics; more common w/high dose or soon after rx/dose change, but also idiosyncratic→ occurring after years of rx; sx progress over several d; Sx: autonomic instability w/HTN, tachycardia, tachypnea, temp can be > 41.1c, pale, sweaty, fluctuating delirium→ aggitated or stupor/alert mutism to coma, cramps, generalized lead-pipe type muscular rigidity, decreased reflexes)
      • Cholinergic agents (Etiology: organophosphate insecticide overdose or exposure; Sx: sedation, confusion, sweating, shortness of breath; PE: salivation, wheezing, lacrimation, bronchorrea, emesis, diarrhea, urination)
      • Serotonin syndrome (Etiology: SSRIs, MAOIs, anti-epileptics, others; rapid onset sx ususally following rx initiation or dose change, though can occur if received rx w/in 5w; sometimes med combinations precipitate syndrome; intential overdose; Sx: aggiation/easily startled, sweating, shivering, diarrhea; PE: spectrum→ htn, tachycardia, tachypnea, hyperthermia to > 41c, flushed & sweaty skin, tremor, confusion/aggitation to coma, increased bowel sounds, clonus, muscular hyperactivity/stiffness, hyper-reflexia)
      • Many other meds - including broad range of abx

      Other Causes of Fever

      • Pulmonary emboli (RFs for dvt/pulm embolous→ immobility, trauma, hypercoaguable state; Sx: acute or subacute if recurrent events, cough, SOB, pleuritic cp, hemoptysis; PE: tachycardia, tachypnea, often clear lungs; less commonly wheezing or findings of effusion; unexplained unliateral edema; Well's Criteria for DVT; Well's Criteria for PE)

      More Info About Infectious Diseases: Infectious Disease Soc of America, CDC, World Health Organization. and National Institute for Allergy and Infectious Diseases

      Back

      Musculoskeletal & Rheum

      Comprehensive Musculoskeletal Exam

      Making sense of MSK problems depends heavily on knowledge of anatomy & pathoanatomy

      Known disease?

      • Degenerative joint disease/Osteoarthritis, Rheumatoid Arthritis, Lupus, gout, etc.

      Joint pain or swelling

      One/Few joints

      Infxn/Inflam

      • Bacterial
        • Staph or strep (Etiology: most common staph, strep; enter joint via direct innoculation→ trauma, bite, surgery; extension from overlying skin infection; or bactermeia; Sx: acute, painful, red, swollen, fever, chills: PE: sig inflammatory signs→ red, warm, worse w/passive or active movement, effusion)
        • Gonorrhea (Rfs: hx sti, hx sexual activity; Sx: f, c, penile or cervical d/c; migratory polyarthritis/arthralgias, skin lesions, predilaction for small joints; PE: affected joint(s) warm, red, pain w/active or passive ROM, effusion, pustules)
        • Endocarditis can also cause migratory poly-arthritis
      • Fungal (Etol: relatively uncommon, hx coccidiomycosis, exposure to endemic areas for cocci→ Southwest; Sx: sub-acute, persisten/progressive joint pain, swelling, warmth, pain w/ROM, effusion)
      • Spirochete (lyme) (Rfs: hx living in area endemic w/lyme→ Northeast, WI/MN, Northern Calif, occurs secondary to tick bite; Sx: bull's eye type rash→ erythema migrans, f, c, adenopathy, arhtralgias; joint inflammation mos to yrs later, large joints, can wax/wane; PE: joint pain, swelling, effusion) more from CDC
      • Crystal Induced - red, warm, effusion
        • Gout (Rfs: male, > 50, prior hx gout, etoh, high purine foods→ fish, red meat, diuretics; Sx: acute joint pain, worse w/movement, one or few joints, most commonly great toe→ podagra, often self limited; sometimes renal stones as well; PE: very painful w/any movement, warmth and redness over joint, rarely evidence of tophi) more from CDC
        • Pseudogout (Rfs: tendency to affect joints w/established OA/trauma; also assoc w/hyperparathyroidism, hyothyroid, hemochrom; often idiopathic; age > 50; Sx: acute joint pain and inflammation, typically knees & hands, can look like gout, often self limited, recurrent; PE: warmth, redness, effusion and pain w/movement of affected joint)

      Autoimmune

      • Acute rheumatic fever (Sx: relatively uncommon, occurs 2-3w after strep pharyngitis, assoc w/fever, fatigue, acute/abrupt onset, migratory inflammatory arthritis of large joints typically; long term risk of mitral or aortic valve dz; PE: affected joint(s) are warm, red, pain w/movement)
      • Reactive arthritis (Sx: occur weeks following chlamydia GU infection or bacterial gastroenteritis; Sx/PE: asymmetric inflammatory migratory arthritis, typically one or a few joints→ knees, ankles, wrists in partic; lbp/SI area pain w/AM stiffness and muscle aches; eye sx→ conjunctivits, iritis; dysuria; oral ulcers; pain at tendon insertions→enthesitis, digit swelling→ dactylitis)
      • Lupus, RA typically have multiple joint involvement

      Osteoarthritis/Trauma

      • Osteoarthritis (Rfs: increasing age, prior injury, obesity; inflammatory OA in middle aged women; Sx: subacute/chronic pain, worse w/activity, slowly progressive, sometimes prior injury, worse in wt bearing joints (knees, hips) characteristic of degnerative joint dz (DJD); a minority have inflammatory OA, causing pain & swelling, in particular of PIPs and DIPs of hands; PE: decreased ROM of affected joint(s); heteroptopic bone growth along joint margins; firm, boney, non-tender→ in hands called heberdens or bouchards nodes at PIPs & DIPs; sometimes inflammation, though typically not symmetric and no synovitis) more from CDC
      • Trauma - hx suggestive

      Multiple joints

      Infxn/Inflam

      • Bacterial
        • Staph or strep (Etiology: most common staph, strep; multi-joint involvement via bactermeia; Sx: acute, painful, red, swollen, fever, chills: PE: f, systemic illness, sig joint inflammatory signs→ red, warm, worse w/passive or active movement, effusion)
        • Gonorrhea (disseminated) (Rfs: hx sti, hx sexual activity; Sx: f, c, penile or cervical d/c; migratory polyarthritis/arthralgias, skin lesions, predilaection for small joints; PE: affected joint(s) warm, red, pain w/active or passive ROM, effusion, pustules) more from CDC
        • Endocarditis/systemic bacteremia - can also cause migratory poly-arthritis
        • T Whipplei (Whipple's disease) (Etiology: possibly sewage, fecal oral spread; RFs: male>female, age 40-60; Sx: rare d/o, multipple chronic sx; wt loss, diarrhea, abd pain, fatigue; intermitent migratory arthritis that sometimes precedes GI sx x years, involves larger joints→ knees, wrists, ankles; f, adenopathy; broad range neuro sx→ cog impairment, uveitis, ha, supranuclear ophthalmoplegia, other; also skin, cardiac, pulmonary)
      • Viral - Parvo (Sx: acute, febrile illness in ages 5-19, runny nose, headache PE: skin erruption w/slapped cheek appearance, also rash on arms, soles, palms; sometimes symetric inflammatory arthritis can mimic RA; can cause acute hypoprolif anemia) more from CDC
      • Viral - acute Hep B (RFs: spread via sexual contact, vertical, shared needles, needle sticks in health care workers, unscreened blood transfusion; Sx: many are asx; incubation is 1-4m; acute infxn assoc w/n, v, jaundice; puritus, icterus, dark urine, light colored stool, malaise; typically self limited, w/resoln sx 2-3m; a minority develop symetric inflammatory arthritis of MCPs, PIP, knees, ankles; resoves in few weeks; PE: jaundice, icterus, RUQ pain, hepatomegaly, symetric inflammatory arthritis)
      • Viral - Chikungunya (RFs: travel to Carribean, mosquitoe bite; Sx: fever, symmetric arthralgia, inflammatory arthritis wrists, fingers, ankles; muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash; onset 3-7d after bite; usually last days to weeks, sometimes mos) more from CDC
      • Crystal Induced - red, warm, effusion
        • Gout (Rfs: male, > 50, prior hx gout, etoh, high purine foods→ fish, red meat, diuretics; Sx: acute joint pain, worse w/movement, one or few joints, most commonly great toe→ podagra, often self limited; sometimes renal stones as well; PE: very painful w/any movement, warmth and redness over joint, rarely evidence of tophi) more from CDC
        • Pseudogout (Rfs: tendency to affect joints w/established OA/trauma; also assoc w/hyperparathyroidism, hypothyroid, hemochromatosis; often idiopathic; age > 50 Sx: acute joint pain and inflammation, typically knees & hands, can look like gout, often self limited, recurrent; PE: warmth, redness, effusion and pain w/movement of affected joint)
      • Acute rheumatic fever (Sx: relatively uncommon, occurs 2-3w after strep pharyngitis, assoc w/fever, fatigue, acute/abrupt onset, migratory inflammatory arthritis of large joints typically; chest pain or sob related to pericarditis; long term risk of mitral or aortic valve dz; PE: affected joint(s) are warm, red, pain w/movement)
      • Reactive arthritis (Sx: occur weeks following chlamydia GU infection or bacterial gastroenteritis; Sx/PE: asymmetric inflammatory migratory arthritis, typically one or a few joints→ knees, ankles, wrists in partic; lbp/SI area pain w/AM stiffness and muscle aches; eye sx→ conjunctivits, iritis; dysuria; oral ulcers; pain at tendon insertions→enthesitis, digit swelling→ dactylitis)

      Autoimmune/Metabolic

      • Acute rheumatic fever (Sx: relatively uncommon, occurs 2-3w after strep pharyngitis, assoc w/fever, fatigue, acute/abrupt onset, migratory inflammatory arthritis of large joints typically; long term risk of mitral or aortic valve dz; PE: affected joint(s) are warm, red, pain w/movement)
      • Adult Still's Disease (Etiology: febrile illness of unknown etiology; Sx: f and other sx are persistent, sub-acute; evaluation of f does not reveal other etiology; also arhtritis & arthralgias of larger joints; salmon colored, maculo-pap non-puritic skin erruption; myalgias, adenopathy, sore throat, pericarditis and pleuritis; PE: erruption is light salmon colored mac/pap, pharyngitis, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy)
      • Celiac disease (Sx: joint sx of oligo or polyarticular arthritis; GI sx of chronic bloating, gas, wt loss/inability to gain weight)
      • Cryogloblulinemia (Etiology: small-vessel vasculitis caused by antigen-antibody complex deposition; Type I monoclonal→ IgM or IgG, related to lymphoprolif d/o→ lymphoma, myeloma; Type II and III, mixed cryos IgM and IgG; related to Hep C (most common), SLE, RA, lymphoma, myeloma, hiv, hep b, other autoimmune; RFs: female > male, ages 40-50; Sx: subacute fatigue, weakness, muscle and joint aches, cough/sob if pulmonary involvement; confusion; symmetric or asymmetric often painful distal neuropathy, painful skin ulcers of extremities, purpuric papules; membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis; PE: palpable purpura of vasculitis, Raynauds, livedo reticularis, distal skin ulcers)
      • Hemochromatosis (Rfs: age < 50, family hx; Sx: joint sx of symetric arthralgias and arthritis hands; can also involves knees, hips, other; more common sx include→ unexplained liver disease, diabetes, hypogonadism, errectile dysfxn; PE: skin hyper-pigmentation, joint inflamation, small testes) more from CDC
      • IBD associated - Crohns or UC (Sx: large joints, often asymmetric; in patient w/known IBD or suggestive sx→ wt loss, bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, nocturnal diarrhea, PE: red, warm, pain w/movement more from CDC
      • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
      • Mixed connective tissue d/o (Etiology: rare d/o, cross over between lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis; Sx: fatigue, muscle and joint aches, finger pain after exposure to cold, sob if pulm htn; PE: raynauds → fingers blanch/hurt when exposed to cold temp, sausage-type thickening of fingers, skin thickening/tightness)
      • Polyarteritis Nodosa (vasculitis) (Etiology: medium-vessel-vasculitis; Rfs: 40s-50s, men>women, Hep B/C; Sx: more commonly subacute over mos f, s, malaise, wt loss, muscle/joint pain; multiple systems: arthritis, glomerulonephritis, peripheral nerve pain/dysfxn, skin w/ulcers, small, palapable purpura→ don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; abd pain, blood per rectum)
      • Polymyalgia Rheumatica (PMR) (Rfs: age > 50, Sx: subacute arthralgias affecting hips and shoulders, worse in AM; can't sleep secondary to inability to find comfortable position; PE: no findings of arthritis/synovitis on exam, no objective findings of weakness)
      • Microscopic polyangitis (MPA) (Etiology: small vessel vasculitis; Sx: fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, sweats, wt loss; recurrent/progressive cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; less often nasal sx c/w GPA; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; skin ulcers; neuropathy; PE: palpable purpura, skin ulcer/necrosis)
      • Psoriatic arthritis (Sx: hx psoriasis, pain and swelling, tendency to affect multiple peripheral joints: PE: red, warm, pain w/movement of joint, skin findings of psoriasis)
      • RA (Rfs: women > men; age 30-55; Sx: subacute (>6w), persistent/progressive joint pain, worse in AM due to gelling→ improves w/use, fatigue, tendency for bilateral involvement, commonly small and medium sized joints; PE: warmth, redness, spongy feeling from synovial inflam, pain w/squeezing of joints, effusion, abnormal appearing if longstanding, MCPs with chronic changes; extra articular findings: episcleritis, pleural/pericardial inflam, rheumatoid nodules) more from CDC
      • Scleroderma (Rfs: age onset < 50, women > men; Sx: can be localized to skin or cause systemic dz; local skin; local disease causes focal skin thickening, skin pigmentation; greater involvement can include: GERD, skin tightening/thickened fingers, telangiectasias, raynauds→ finger hypoperfusion and pain in cold, calcium deposits in sub-cu; w/systemic sclerosis, wide spread dz affecting skin, lungs→ sob from pulm htn and interstitial lung dz; joints→ athralgias & myalgias; kidneys→ scleroderma crisis; pericardium→ pericarditis; gi→ GERD; PE: raynauds → fingers blanch/hurt when exposed to cold temp, skin thickening/tightness, hyperpigmentation)
      • Serum sickness (Rfs: typically from rx to abx, or secondary to viral infxn → e.g. acute hep b; Sx: acute, symetric, additive/migratory, polyarthritis; myalgias, fever, rash, onset days to weeks after exposure)
      • Takayasu's arteritis (Etiology: large vessel vasculitis, onset 10-30yo, Asian background, women > men; Sx: sub-acute and progressive, fevers, wt loss, fatigue, myalgias arthralgias; target organ sx based on affected vessels: abdominal aorta & branches→ abdominal pain, htn; thoracic aorta & branches→ chest pain, sob, tia/stroke; PE: loss of palpable pulses radial, carotid, lower extremity)

      Osteoarthritis

      • Osteoarthritis (Rfs: increasing age, prior injury, obesity; inflammatory OA in middle aged women; Sx: subacute/chronic pain, worse w/activity, slowly progressive, sometimes prior injury, worse in wt bearing joints (knees, hips) characteristic of degnerative joint dz (DJD); a minority have inflammatory OA, causing pain & swelling, in particular of PIPs and DIPs of hands; PE: decreased ROM of affected joint(s); heteroptopic bone growth along joint margins; firm, boney, non-tender→ in hands called heberdens or bouchards nodes at PIPs & DIPs; sometimes inflammation, though typically not symmetric and no synovitis) more from CDC

      Structures Near Joints

      • Bursitis (Sx: acute pain, fever, swelling, redness over a known anatomic bursa; PE: focal redness, warmth, pain on touch, swelling, over an anatomic bursa)
      • Cellulitis(Sx: acute pain, swelling, fever; PE: area of involvement not restricted to a joint or anatomic bursa, not clearly worse w/movement, local redness)
      • Teno-synovitis (Sx/PE: worse w/active motion, localized over tendon)
      • Muscle pain
      • Other/non-joint related pathology - e.g. arthralgias from systemic illness, in which case exam of the joint is normal

      Muscle aches?

      • Fibromyalgia (Etiology: idiopathic; Sx: chronic, no other explanation found on exam and labs, fatigue, head aches; PE: pain at multiple trigger sites) more from CDC
      • Meds/drugs→ cocaine, statins
      • Referred from joint pathology
      • Extreme exercise, or new exercise regimen when previously inactive
      • Systemic infection
      • Local infection, parasitic infection→ cystecercosis
      • Cramps - often non-specific (Etiology: hypokalemia, dehydration, idiopathic)
      • Autoimmune/Inflammatory d/o
        • Cryogloblulinemia (Etiology: small-vessel vasculitis caused by antigen-antibody complex deposition; Type I monoclonal→ IgM or IgG, related to lymphoprolif d/o→ lymphoma, myeloma; Type II and III, mixed cryos IgM and IgG; related to Hep C (most common), SLE, RA, lymphoma, myeloma, hiv, hep b, other autoimmune; RFs: female > male, ages 40-50; Sx: subacute fatigue, weakness, muscle and joint aches, cough/sob if pulmonary involvement; confusion; symmetric or asymmetric often painful distal neuropathy, painful skin ulcers of extremities, purpuric papules; membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis; PE: palpable purpura of vasculitis, Raynauds, livedo reticularis, distal skin ulcers)
        • Giant cell/temporal arteritis (Rfs: age > 50, F>M; 20% w/PMR will develop GCA; 50% w/GCA had PMR; Sx: f, ha, jaw claudication, wt loss, scalp pain, muscle aches typically x mos; visual loss abrupt, w/other sx typically first; PE: sometimes scalp/temp art tenderness, edematous optic nerve)
        • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
        • Microscopic polyangitis (MPA) (Etiology: small vessel vasculitis; Sx: fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, sweats, wt loss; recurrent/progressive cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; less often nasal sx c/w GPA; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; skin ulcers; neuropathy; PE: palpable purpura, skin ulcer/necrosis)
        • Mixed connective tissue d/o (Etiology: rare d/o, cross over between lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis; Sx: fatigue, muscle and joint aches, finger pain after exposure to cold; PE: raynauds → fingers blanch/hurt when exposed to cold temp, sausage-type thickening of fingers, skin thickening/tightness)
        • Polyarteritis Nodosa (vasculitis) (Etiology: medium-vessel vasulitis; Rfs: 40s-50s, men>women, Hep B/C; Sx: more commonly subacute over mos f, s, malaise, wt loss, muscle/joint pain; multiple systems: arthritis, glomerulonephritis, peripheral nerve pain/dysfxn, skin w/ulcers, small, palapable purpura→ don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; abd pain, blood per rectum)
        • Polymyalgia Rheumatica (PMR) (Rfs: age > 50, Sx: subacute arthralgias affecting hips and shoulders, worse in AM; can't sleep secondary to inability to find comfortable position; PE: no findings of arthritis/synovitis on exam, no objective findings of weakness)
        • Scleroderma (Rfs: age onset < 50, women > men; Sx: can be localized to skin or cause systemic dz; local skin; local disease causes focal skin thickening, skin pigmentation; greater involvement can include: GERD, skin tightening/thickened fingers, telangiectasias, raynauds→ finger hypoperfusion and pain in cold, calcium deposits in sub-cu; w/systemic sclerosis, wide spread dz affecting skin, lungs→ sob from pulm htn and interstitial lung dz; joints→ athralgias & myalgias; kidneys→ scleroderma crisis; pericardium→ pericarditis; gi→ GERD; PE: raynauds → fingers blanch/hurt when exposed to cold temp, skin thickening/tightness, hyperpigmentation)
        • Takayasu's arteritis (Etiology: large vessel vasculitis, onset 10-30yo, Asian background, women > men; Sx: sub-acute and progressive, fevers, fatigue, wt loss, myalgias arthralgias; target organ sx based on affected vessels: abdominal aorta & branches→ abdominal pain, htn; thoracic aorta & branches→ chest pain, sob, tia/stroke; PE: loss of palpable pulses radial, carotid, lower extremity)
        • Adult Still's Disease (Etiology: febrile illness of unknown etiology; Sx: f and other sx are persistent, sub-acute; evaluation of f does not reveal other etiology; also arhtritis & arthralgias of larger joints; salmon colored, maculo-pap non-puritic skin erruption; myalgias, adenopathy, sore throat, pericarditis and pleuritis; PE: erruption is light salmon colored mac/pap, pharyngitis, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy)
        • Vasculitis - other
      • Endocrinopathies
        • Adrenal insufficiency (Sx: feeling poorly in general, n, v, orthostatic sx)
        • Hyperthyroidism (Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, wt loss, weakness; PE: sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid, hyper-reflexia)
        • Hypothyroidism (Sx: wt gain, edema, dry skin, constipation, cold intolerance, depression/mood change, weakness, fatigue; PE: often no findings aside from wt gain, sometimes decreased reflexes, edema, bradycardia)
        • Hypocalcemia (Etiology: severe vit d defic, resistance to vit d, low intake calcium, hypoparthyroidism→ post surgical, xrt, idiopathic, other; Sx: weakness, perioral numbness, muscle cramps; PE: muscle irritability; twitching w/tap on facial nerve, hand/wrist spasm w/prolonged inflation bp cuff)
          • Primary (Etiology: problem at level of adrenal gland: autoimmune destruction → assoc w/DM 1, celiac dz; hemorrhage/infarct; infection → TB, HIV; infiltration w/tumor; PE: sometimes darkening of mucous memberanes, skin folds, & pressure points)
          • Secondary (Etiology: problem at level of pituitary/hypothalamus → low acth; can be from surgery, tumor, hypoperfusion, auto-immune, trauma, meds→ chronic glucocorticoids)
        • Vitamin D deficiency
      • Myopathy/Myositis
        • Dermatomyositis (Etiology: autoimmune; Rfs: children and adults, female > male; Sx: weakness that develops over weeks; earliest affected often neck flexors, pectoral muscles, pelvic girdle; can be asymmetric; dysphagia and dysarthria in 1/3; pain not prominent; no sensory deficits, accompanied by rash, proximal; other organ systems affected including cardiac conduction system dz, arthralgias, arthritis, malignancy→ breast, prostate, colon, other; interstitial lung dz; PE: erythematous skin erruption in sun-exposed area, heliotropic rash around eyes→ purplish w/edema, Gottron's papules→ scaly and papular on knuckles, subcutaneous calcifications, progressive weakness, reflexes preserved until late)
        • Muscular dystrophy (Etiology: genetic d/o, may have family hx of similar problems; Sx: highly variable; can present in childhood, w/progressive weakness and wasting; other variants may only cause muscle aches w/activity→ limb-girdle md) more from CDC
        • Polymyositis (Etiology: rare, autoimmune; Rfs: female > male, age>20; Sx/PE: symmetrical proximal weakness of arms and legs, develops over weeks to months; neck flexor weakness; no sensory deficits; sometimes pain, though not prominent feature; dysphagia in 1/3; polyarthritis in 45%; PE: symmetric proximal > distal weakness, preserved reflexes)

      Fatigue?

      Fatigue is a symptom with many possible explanations. Need to define what patient means by fatigue: e.g. tired, lack of energy, muscle weakness, depressed, etc→ use further questions to identify etiology. Risk factors (e.g. age, sex), past history, meds and other historical clues should help to further categorize.

      MSK/Rheum D/O

      • Chronic fatigue syndrome (Sx: x 6m, no other explanation, not improved w/rest, otherwise unexplained muscle/joint pain, unrefreshing sleep, fatigue lasting 24h after exercise, sore throat, adenopathy) more from CDC
      • DJD (Rfs: age > 50, obesity, prior injury; Sx: chronic pain at site of arthritis, worse when moving or weight bearing on affected joints, slowly progressive, better w/rest) more from CDC
      • Fibromyalgia (Sx: chronic, multi-site muscle and joint pain, fatigue, multiple tender points on palpation, no findings of inflammation, no other etiology uncovered) more from CDC
      • Polymyalgia Rheumatica - PMR (Sx: sub-acute, age > 50, morning shoulder and hip aches, f, c, no findings on exam of joint inflammation, no objective findings of weakness)
      • Giant Cell Arteritis (Rfs: age > 50, often prior hx PMR; Sx: fatigue, headache, joint aches, f, c, visual loss; PE: sometimes scalp/temp art tenderness, abnl appearing optic nerve)
      • Cryogloblulinemia (Etiology: small-vessel vasculitis caused by antigen-antibody complex deposition; Type I monoclonal→ IgM or IgG, related to lymphoprolif d/o→ lymphoma, myeloma; Type II and III, mixed cryos IgM and IgG; related to Hep C (most common), SLE, RA, lymphoma, myeloma, hiv, hep b, other autoimmune; RFs: female > male, ages 40-50; Sx: subacute fatigue, weakness, muscle and joint aches, cough/sob if pulmonary involvement; confusion; symmetric or asymmetric often painful distal neuropathy, painful skin ulcers of extremities, purpuric papules; membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis; PE: palpable purpura of vasculitis, Raynauds, livedo reticularis, distal skin ulcers)
      • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
      • Mixed connective tissue d/o (Etiology: rare d/o, cross over between lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis; Sx: fatigue, muscle and joint aches, finger pain after exposure to cold; PE: raynauds → fingers blanch/hurt when exposed to cold temp, sausage type swelling of fingers)
      • Microscopic polyangitis (MPA) (Etiology: small vessel vasculitis; Sx: fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, sweats, wt loss; recurrent/progressive cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; less often nasal sx c/w GPA; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; skin ulcers; neuropathy; PE: palpable purpura, skin ulcer/necrosis)
      • Other vasculitides or automimmune disorders - w/characteristic localizing sx→ Scleroderma, etc
      • RA (Rfs: women > men; age 30-55; Sx: subacute (>6w), persistent/progressive joint pain, worse in AM due to gelling→ improves w/use, fatigue, tendency for bilateral involvement, commonly small and medium sized joints; nerve symptoms can be motor, sensory or from compression; PE: warmth, redness, spongy feeling from synovial inflam, pain w/squeezing of joints, effusion, abnormal appearing if longstanding, MCPs with chronic changes; extra articular findings: episcleritis, pleural/pericardial inflam, rheumatoid nodules) more from CDC
      • Takayasu's arteritis (Etiology: large vessel vasculitis, onset 10-30yo, Asian background, women > men; Sx: sub-acute and progressive, fevers, fatigue, wt loss, myalgias arthralgias; target organ sx based on affected vessels: abdominal aorta & branches→ abdominal pain, htn; thoracic aorta & branches→ chest pain, sob, tia/stroke; PE: loss of palpable pulses radial, carotid, lower extremity)

      Sleep D/O

      • Obstructive sleep apnea (Rfs: obesity, though 25-30% w/OSA have nl BMI; Sx: snoring, observed apnea, poorly rested in AM, daytime fatigue, AM head ache, difficulty concentrating, motor vehicle accidents; PE: BMI > 30, OSA risk increased w/neck circumference >17in men, 16in women; osa risk increased if cant see back of throat)
      • Obesity-Hypoventilation syndrome (Etiology: obesity; vast majority also have OSA, though most w/OSA dont have obsesity-hypovent; labs indicate chronic compensated respiratory acidosis; Sx: snoring, obese, observed apnea/gasping at night, poorly rested in AM, daytime fatigue, sob; PE: BMI > 30, often significantly higher; often elevated jvp, edema→ right sided chf)
      • Central sleep apnea (Rfs: assoc w/older age and other conditions including: CHF, ESRD, drugs→ e.g. methadone; Sx: observed apnea, poorly rested in AM, daytime fatigue)
      • Travel/jet lag, work with odd hours/shifts, poor sleep hygiene, meds, other

      Endocrine D/O

      • Hypercalcemia
        • Primary hyper-PTH (Sx: usually slowly progressive; assoc w/fractures, renal stones, fatigue, confusion, weakness; higher risks w/higher ca2+)
        • Malignancy (Sx related to primary cancer as well as hyper ca2+ → fatigue, confusion, pain weakness; can be relatively acute, varying w/cancer burden)
          • Elevated PTH-like hormone - in particular squamous cell cancer
          • Direct bone erosion e.g. myeloma, lymphoma, breast
          • Inappropriate production of 1,25-OH vit d - lymphoma
        • Vitamin D related
          • Increased conversion of 25-OH to 1,25-OH vit D e.g. Sarcoid
          • Excessive vit D or ca2+ ingestion
        • Meds→ e.g. HCTZ)
        • Immobility - though Ca2+ elev usually mild
      • Hypocalcemia (Etiology: severe vit d defic, resistance to vit d, low intake calcium, hypoparthyroidism→ post surgical, xrt, idiopathic, other; Sx: weakness, perioral numbness, muscle cramps; PE: muscle irritability; twitching w/tap on facial nerve, hand/wrist spasm w/prolonged inflation bp cuff)
      • Hypothyroidism (Sx: wt gain, edema, dry skin, constipation, cold intolerance, depression/mood change, weakness, fatigue; PE: often no findings aside from wt gain, sometimes decreased reflexes, edema, bradycardia)
      • Hyperthyroidism (Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, wt loss, weakness, infetility, ED, menstrual irreg; PE: sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid, hyper-reflexia, moist skin)
      • Diabetes (Rfs/Etiology: known dz → poor control; Sx: polyuria, polydypsia)
      • Low testosterone (Sx: decreased libido, errectile dysfxn, generalized weakness, decreased muscle mass, depression)
        • Primary (Rf/Etiology: testicular hypofunction from: prior infection→ mumps; torsion/trauma/cancer/other reason for testicular death; past chemotherapy; genetic disorders→ prader-willi; PE: sometimes small or absent testes)
        • Secondary (Rf/Etiology: pituitary/hypothalamic dysfxn from: tumor, inflammatory processes, hypoperfusion; meds→ chronic narcotics, LHRH agonists for prostate ca; hemochromatosis; chronic diseases→ HIV, Dm, copd, chf, renal filuare, cirrhosis)
      • Adrenal insufficiency (Sx: feeling poorly in general, n, v, orthostatic sx)
        • Primary (Etiology: problem at level of adrenal gland: autoimmune destruction → assoc w/DM 1, celiac dz; hemorrhage/infarct; infection → TB, HIV; infiltration w/tumor; PE: sometimes darkening of mucous membranes, skin folds, & pressure points)
        • Secondary (Etiology: problem at level of pituitary/hypothalamus → low acth; can be from surgery, tumor, hypoperfusion, auto-immune, trauma, meds→ chronic glucocorticoids)
      • Acromegaly (growth hormone excess) (Etiology: typically pituitary tumor, age ~40; Sx: increase in hat or shoe size as an adult, fatigue, weakness, joint pain, increased height, sweating & body odor, headache, visual loss afffecting temporal fields, infertility, menstrual irreg; PE: characteristic appearance of face w/prominent brow and jaw, enlarging hands, increasing shoe size, enlarging tongue)
      • Profound hypokalemia
      • Hyponatremia

      Heme-Onc D/O

      Anemia

      Hemoglobin measurement needed to Dx anemia - but such a common problem that DDx provided below. Sx: weakness, fatigue, sob, doe. Degree of sx based on acuity of anemia, other co-morbid dz processes, genl activity level.
    • Decreased RBC production
      • Primary bone marrow production problem - Acquired
        • Myelodysplastic syndrome (Rfs: Age > 60, a primary problem or secondary to chemotherapy or other d/o that can affect BM function; Sx: asx until anemia, low plt, or low wbc lead to sx→ fatigue, sob, doe, bleeding, infection; risk of transformation to AML)
        • Aplastic anemia (Etiology: Secondary→ meds, infection, xrt, other; all cell lines decreased; Sx: sob, fatigue from anemia; recurrent infections from low wbc; bleeding from low plt)
        • Hematologic malignancy e.g. leukemia, lymphoma, multiple myeloma, myeloproliferative disorders (Sx: wt loss, f, chills, sweats, bleeding, other cell lines affected)
      • Primary bone marrow production problem - Hereditary
        • Thalassemia (Rfs/Etiology: mediterranean background, dx during childhood; Sx: failure to thrive)
        • Sickle cell (Rfs: black, family hx, identified in childhood; Sx: failure to thrive in childhood, recurrent bouts pain during crises)
        • Aplastic anemia (Etiology: primary→ related to a number of inherited conditions; all cell lines decreased; Sx: sob, fatigue from anemia; recurrent infections from low wbc; bleeding from low plt)
      • Secondary bone marrow production problem
        • Chronic kidney diease→ low epo
        • Chronic liver disease
        • Chronic inflammatory process of any sort→ anemia of chronic disease
        • Low testosterone in men (Sx: low libido, ED, decreased energy, non-specific weakness/fatigue, depression)
        • Hypothyroidism (Sx: wt gain, edema, dry skin, constipation, cold intolerance, depression/mood change, weakness, fatigue; PE: often no findings aside from wt gain, sometimes decreased reflexes, edema, bradycardia)
        • ETOH abuse
        • B12 deficiency (Etiology: perinicious anemia, s/p gastrectomy, crohn's dz, rarely diet related; Sx: progressive, legs more common then arms, can be painful, impaired dorsal columns function, gait problems, tongue can be smooth and swollen if severe, s/s anemia if severe, rarely confusion)
        • Folate deficinecy
        • Meds e.g. chemotherapeutic agents and many others
        • Iron deficiency - Primary (Etiology: lack of access to iron is unusual, unless extreme diet→ vegan)
        • Iron deficiency - Secondary (Etiology: blood loss→ see below; malabsorption of iron for any reason→ gastric surgery, gastric by-pass, celiac dz, IBD, elevated gastric pH from h2 blockers or PPIs, etc.)
    • Blood loss
        • Slow losses (compensated) tend to cause vague symptoms of fatigue and dyspnea. Rapid losses (uncompensated) tend to cause abnormal vital signs and are often visible (e.g. throwing up blood or passing blood per rectum). Internal sources of bleeding (intra-abdominal, retroperitoneal, thoracic) aren't directly visible but hx often suggestive.
      • Bleeding in upper GI tract - Stool is typically tarry/sticky and has characteristic odor
        • Ulcer - gastric or ducodenal (Rfs/Etiology: ETOH, h pylori, nsaid use; Sx: epigastric, better or worse w/food, black stools)
        • Esophageal varices→ secondary to portal htn, whose causes include:
          • Post-hepatic processes→ hepatic vein thrombosis, severe R/L CHF, constrictive pericardial disease, restrictive cardiomypathy
          • Intrahepatic processes→ chronic hepatitis of any etiology including: viral, toxin, autoimmune, infiltrative, malignant; sometimes acute d/o if fulminant or superimposed on chronic
          • Pre-hepatic processes→ portal vein thrombosis, portal vein obstruction from parasites/other
        • Stomach cancer (Rfs: 50, smoking, ETOH abuse, h pylori→ MALT assoc; Sx: sub-acute, feel full when eating ever smaller quantities of food, pain, bleeding)
        • Gastritis (Rfs: stress, ETOH, NSAIDs, h pylori; Sx: epigastric pain, black stools, better or worse w/food)
        • Esophagitis (Rfs: assoc w/obesity, ETOH, smoking, caffine, chocolate, mint; Sx: GERD type→ burning type pain, often worse after meals, worse if lie down after eating, bad taste in mouth, radiates up from epigastrium)
        • Swallowed blood from upper respiratory source→ nose bleed
        • Swallowed blood from oral bleeding site
        • Mallory Weiss Tear (Etiology/Rfs: hx repeateed retching)
        • Dieulafoys lesions→ sub-mucosal artery (Sx: sudden, brisk bleeding)
        • Aorto-enteric fistula (Rfs: hx AAA graft; Sx: profound bleeding)
      • Bleeding in lower GI tract - structural causes
        • Colonic AVM (Sx: typically small amounts blood, avm not visible on exam)
        • Colonic polyp (Sx: typically small amounts blood, polyp not visible on exam)
        • Diverticulum (Sx: acute, bright red blood, can be small or large amnts)
        • External hemorrhoid (Sx: painless bleeding, unless thrombosed; readily visible on exam; if thrombosed then acute pain PE: bluish venous structure in peri-rectal area, if thrombosed, readily visible)
        • Internal hemorrhoid (Sx: painless bleeding, small or large amounts, recurrent; rare site of variceal bleeding from portal htn PE: not visible unless use anoscope or prolapsed; blood apparent on digital rectal if bleeding at time)
        • Stercoral ulcer (Rfs/Etiology: older patient, immobile, related to hardened stool in low motility colon, dementia)
        • Rectal varices (Etiology: assoc w/portal htn; much less common than esophageal varices; Rf: any reason for portal htn→ pre, intra, or post-hepatic; Sx: related to chronic liver dz; profound bright red blood per rectum; PE: blood on digital exam, brisk bleeding, abnormal vital signs)
        • Contribution from primary bleeding disorder
        • Colorectal cancer (adeno) (Rfs: no prior screening or screening > 10y ago, early family hx, polyposis syndromes, UC or colonic crohn's; Sx: anorexia, weight loss, vague pain, persistent/progressive, bloody stools, change in bowel habits, R sided→ fatigue from anemia, L sided→ obstructive sx; PE: sometimes palpable if very distal and/or large)
        • Anal cancer (squamous cell) (Rfs: squamous cell ca around anus & assoc w/HPV infection, increased incidence w/anal intercourse, HIV, women, men who have sex w/men; Sx: anal pain, tenesmus, bleeding, pain, obstruction PE: palpable mass or diffuse tissue infiltration around anus)
      • Bleeding in lower GI tract - inflammatory/infectious causes
        • Ulcerative colitis (Etiology: automimmune, genetic, environmentally triggered, other; affects colon, distal to prox; Rfs: Northen Europeans, North Americans; smoking and appendectomy protective; peak onset 15-30; Sx and PE: sub-acute, recurrent or chronic diarrhea; fatigue, wt loss, bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, nocturnal diarrhea, feeling poorly overall; spectrum from mild to severe; extra-GI: aphtous ulcers, erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosa, peripheral arthritis, ankylosing spond/sacroiliitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, eye sx→ episcleritis/scleritis/uveitis) More from CDC
        • Crohn's disease (Etiology: automimmune, genetic, environmentally triggered, other; transmural involvement; can affect anywhere in GI tract mouth-to-anus; Rfs: smoking and appendectomy increase risk; Northern Europeans and North Americans; peak onset 15-30; Sx: sub-acute, diarrhea→ though can be less prominent than w/UC, nocturnal diarrhea, sometimes bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, fever, abd pain, fatigue, wt loss, feeling poorly overall, fistulas, bowel obstruction, peri-rectal dz; spectrum of sx and findings; PE: sometimes abd mass; peri-rectal disease; extra-GI: aphtous ulcers, erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosa, peripheral arthritis, ankylosing spond/sacroiliitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, eye sx→ episcleritis/scleritis/uveitis) More from CDC
        • XRT induced (Rf/Etiology: hx radiation to lower abd/pv → e.g. prostate; Sx: small amounts of blood)
        • Bacterial intestinal infections are usually self limited and don't lead to anemia
        • Parasites → Entamoeba Hyst (Rfs: unclean water/poor santiation, also via anal intercourse; Sx: diarrhea, abd pain, 2-4w incubation)
        • Parasites→ Necator americanus (hookworm) (Rfs/Etiology: common world-wide, enter thru feet/skin if walk barefoot in soil w/infected feces → bloodstream → lungs → swallowed → small intestines → blood loss; Sx: fatigue, d)
        • Parasites→ Trichuris (whipworm) (Sx/Etiology: eggs ingested, live in colon; light infxn → Sx: often asx; if heavy burden → abd pain, diarrhea, bloody stools, n, v, anemia)
        • HIV + (chronic, atypical infxns → CMV, HSV; Kaposis; can also be bacterial)
        • Medications (e.g. Ipilimumab) (Etiology: immune modulating cancer therapy can cause colitis, as can other meds as well; Sx: dx based on recognizing connection between med & GI bleeding; brb per rectum, non-specific abd pain)
      • Colonic ischemia
        • RFs/Etiology: hx vascular disease and RFs, hx hypoperfusion → hypotension for any reason; extreme athletics→ marathon runners; Sx: acute onset bleeding, pain
      • Small bowel source
        • Arterio-venous malformation (Rfs: age > 60, esrd, aortic stenosis, von-willebrand's dz; Sx: painless, bleed intermitently, no source seen on upper or lower endoscopy)
        • Small bowel polyps (Sx: related to familial polyposis syndromes, may have family hx gi maliganancy)
        • Crohn's disease (Etiology: automimmune, genetic, environmentally triggered, other; transmural involvement; can affect anywhere in GI tract mouth-to-anus; Rfs: smoking and appendectomy increase risk; Northern Europeans and North Americans; peak onset 15-30; Sx: sub-acute, diarrhea→ though can be less prominent than w/UC, nocturnal diarrhea, sometimes bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, fever, abd pain, fatigue, wt loss, feeling poorly overall, fistulas, bowel obstruction, peri-rectal dz; spectrum of sx and findings; PE: sometimes abd mass; peri-rectal disease; extra-GI: aphtous ulcers, erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosa, peripheral arthritis, ankylosing spond/sacroiliitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, eye sx→ episcleritis/scleritis/uveitis) More from CDC
        • Meckel's diverticulum (Etiology: ectopic stomach mucosa located in terminal ileum; Sx: can be asx, or cause, abdominal pain, gi bleeding, sbo)
        • Adenocarcinoma (Etiology: can be spontaneous, also assoc w/familial polyposis syndromes, duodenum is most common site; Sx: abd pain, wt loss, occult bleeding)
        • Lymphoma (Sx: sub-acute fever, sweats, abdominal pain, diarrhea, adenopathy elswewhere)
        • Metastatic dz (Sx: related to primary, mets to sb can cause pain, bleeding, obstruction
      • Trauma
        • Typically obvious - blood can escape externally or collect in body spaces → chest, abd, retroperit, thigh
      • Chronic blood donation or recurrent phlebotomy in hospitalized patients
      • GU losses
        • Unusual to lose a lot of blood in urine unless very obvious
      • GYN losses
        • Vaginal bleeding from heavy menses, polyps, fibroids, cancer
    • Hemolysis
        • Genl Sx: sob, doe, fatigue & those related to specific etiology; PE: if severe hemolysis→ abnl VS, jaundice, scleral icterus, bilirubinuria if intravascular; other sx related to specific Etiologyogy of hemolysis
      • Acquired d/o of RBC membrane - hemolysis intra-vascular
        • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) (Etiology: unusual d/o, avg age onset 30s, hemolysis due to increased susceptibility to compliment; Sx: spontaneous venous thrombosis→ portal, hepatic, mesenteric and extremity veins; episodic hemolysis, in partic after infxn, w/assoc sob, doe, fatigue; decreased production all cell lines)
      • Inherited d/o - Abnormal RBCs - hemolysis largely extra-vascular
        • Spherocytosis (Etiology: RBC membrane defect; Sx: those assoc w/anemia, splenomegaly and jaundice; spectrum of severity; neonate to adulthood)
        • Thalassemia (Rfs/Etiology: hemoglobin defect, mediterranean background, dx during childhood; Sx: failure to thrive)
        • Sickle cell (Rfs/Etiology: hemoglobin defect, black, family hx, identified in childhood; Sx: failure to thrive, recurrent bouts pain during crises)
        • G6PD Defic (Rfs/Etiology: enzyme defect, Mediter, Asian, African, Middle Eastern background; Sx: typically asx until presented w/acute oxidative stress→ infection, meds, fava beans → acute hemolysis → resolves when stress removed)
      • Secondary Hemolytic anemias - RBCs normal - hemolysis intra or extra-vascular
        • Autoimmune (Etiology: primary/idiopathic or secondary to: connective tissue d/o→ e.g. lupus, RA; infection→ viral, mycoplasma, malignancy→ e.g. CLL; meds→ e.g. penicillins or cephalosporins)
        • Transfusion rxn (occurs following blood transfusion)
        • Selected infections e.g. malaria, babesiosis
        • Hypersplenism (Sx: splenic enlargement for any reason can cause hemolysis → exaggeration of spleens nl fxn; causes include infection, cancer, infiltrative; often also assoc w/low plt and wbcs)
        • Severe malfunction of mechanical heart valve (Sx: accompanied by sx chf/other to suggest valve not opening/closing normally; nl fxning prostheses cause low level, asx hemolysis)
        • Microangiopathic
          • DIC (Etiology: secondary to a precipitant, including → systemic infxn, cancer, trauma, other serious event)
          • HUS-TTP (Etiology/Rfs: HUS→ kids, TTP→ adults; Sx: acute, assoc w/anemia, acute kidney injury; secondary to an inciting event, including meds → e.g clopidogrel, infection→ e.g. e coli 0157h7, cancer, etc.)
      Contribution from bleeding d/o - acquired or congenital - can contribute to any of above

      Cancer

    • Solid tumors (primary)
      • Anal cancer (squamous cell) (Rfs: assoc w/HPV infection, increased incidence w/anal intercourse, HIV, women, men who have sex w/men; Sx: anal pain, tenesmus, bleeding, pain, obstruction PE: palpable mass or diffuse tissue infiltration around anus)
      • Biliary (cholangiocarcinoma) (Rfs: PSC, other chronic biliary inflammation; Sx: RUQ/epigsatric persistent/progressive discomfort, anorexia, weight loss, jaundice, ictreus, lighter color stools)
      • Bladder or other urothelial (transitional, squamous) (Rfs: smoking hx, male, age > 50, anyline dye exposure→ TCC; chronic foley or schistosomiasis→ SCC; Sx: lower abd/pelvis discomfort, wt loss, hematuria/dysuria, urinary frequency/urgency)
      • Bone - osteoscaroma (Etiology: uncommon; Sx: bone pain, fracture w/o mechanism, wt loss, feeling poorly)
      • Brain - can originate from any CNS tissues→ astrocytoma/glioblastoma, glioma, oligodendroglyoma, medulloblastoma, ependymoma, pituitary/hypothalamic, pinealoma, meningioma (benign) (Sx: progressive, head ache, seizures, feeling poorly, neuro deficits PE: weakness/loss of function, sensory deficits, behavioral changes, etc)
      • Breast (ductal, lobular) (Rfs: women>>>male, can occur any age, though typically > 50, other risk factors: early menarche, late menopause, never pregnant, family hx, past hx breast ca; Sx: patient notes breast mass, nipple retraction, bloody nipple d/c, skin changes; bone, brain lung, or other organ sx if present w/mets; PE: palpable disrete mass, bloody nipple d/c, nipple inversion, skin changes, axillary adenopathy)
      • Cervical (squamous, adeno) (Rfs: smoking, early age first intercourse, multiple sexual partners, hx STIs, hx HPV→ scc, HIV; Sx: vague lower abd discomfort, vaginal bleeding, pain w/intercourse; PE: abnormal cervix on exam)
      • Colorectal (adeno) (Rfs: no prior screening or screening > 10y ago, early family hx, polyposis syndromes, UC or colonic crohn's; Sx: anorexia, weight loss, vague pain, persistent/progressive, bloody stools, change in bowel habits, R sided→ fatigue from anemia, L sided→ obstructive sx; PE: palpable by digital exam if very distal; palpable on abdominal exam if very large or mets, gross blood or guaiac + on digital exam)
      • Esophageal (Sx: progressive swallowing problems, food gets stuck, worse w/solids then liquids, pain, patient can often point to level of obstruction)
        • Squamous Cell (Etiology: upper 2/3 of esophagus; Rfs: ETOH, smoking, age > 50)
        • Adenocarcinoma (Etiology: lower 1/3 of esophagus; Rfs: GERD → Barret's, age > 50)
      • Head and Neck (squamous) (Rfs: smoking, etoh, chewing tobacco, HPV infection; Etiology: typically squamous cell; Sx: present w/ulcers that don't heal in mouth, masses in mouth, difficulty swallowing, neck adenopathy PE: slow growing, non-healing ulcer or mass of oral mucosa, edges indurated, lymph nodes firm, stuck to each other & underlying tissue, growing)
      • Liver (hepatocellular) (Rfs: chronic hepatitis for any reason→ viral, etoh, etc; Sx: RUQ/epigastric persistent/progressive discomfort, anorexia, weight loss; PE: palpable, firm liver if advanced)
      • Lung (Sx: cough, sob/doe, chest pain, hemoptysis, hoarseness, wt loss, f, sweats; other organs if mets at presentation→ brain, liver PE: may have auscutatory findings if involves enough parenchyma, wheezing if affects large airway, findings assoc w/effusion if advanced)
        • Non-small cell (Rfs: more common, smoking assoc, asbestos exposure)
        • Small cell (Etiology: 10-15% of lung ca, more chemo responsive than non-small cell; RFs: smoking & asbestos exposure)
      • Melanoma (Rfs: fair skin, fair hair, prior melanoma, dysplastic moles, family hx, hx blistering sun burns, immunocompromised; Sx/PE: asymmetric, bleeds, irregular borders, non-homogeneous pigment, grows, doesn't heal, reginal adenopathy if spread, sx related to mets to brain, lung, liver)
      • Mesothelioma (Etiology: secondary to asbestos exposure from mining, work w/insulation→ pipes, brakes, ship building; or family exposed to clothing of those who worked direclty w/asbestos; Sx: causes pleural disease & effusion w/SOB, chest wall pain)
      • Metastatic disease→ almost any solid organ can have a met from cancer elsewhere
      • Ovarian (epithelial) (Rfs: age > 50, fam hx breast/ovarian, nulliparity, obesity; Sx: vague, progressive, abdominal/pelvic fullness/discomfort, constipation, bloating, anoexia, nausea increased girth if malignant ascites, irregular vaginal bleeding; PE: palpably enlarged ovary if advanced)
      • Pancreatic (adeno) (Rfs: male, age > 50, chronic pancreatitis, smoking, family hx; Sx: epigastric area, anorexia, weight loss, epigastric pain radiating to back, persistent/progressive, sometimes diarrhea; PE: palpable mass from primary or met if advanced; jaundice if affecting head of pnacreas and obstructing CBD)
      • Prostate (adeno) (Sx: asx early, can cause urgency, frequency, delayed emptying, hematuria; bone pain if mets; PE: nodular, firm prostate)
      • Renal cell (Rfs: smoking, obesity, family hx, male; avg age ~mid 60s; Sx: low back to lower abd/groin discomfort, wt loss, sweats, fever, flank pain, hematuria; PE: papable only if very advanced)
      • Sarcoma (soft tissue) (Etiology: uncommon; Sx: relatively uncommon malignancies, growing mass that arises from muscle/other tissue, other sx based on growth/interference w/adjacent structures)
      • Small bowel (adeno, lymphoma, carcinoid) (Etiology: less common than other GI tract malignancies; Sx: pain, bleeding, wt loss, obstruction; carcinoid→ diarrhea, episodic flushing, wheezing, hypotension)
      • Stomach (adeno, lymphoma) (Rfs: 50, smoking, ETOH abuse, h pylori→ MALT assoc; Sx: feel full when eating ever smaller quantities of food, pain, bleeding)
      • Testicular (seminomas, non-seminomas) (Rfs: typical age 15-30, undescended testicle; Sx: painless, progressive firm nodule; unexplained hydrocele; PE: firm testicle, discrete or diffuse)
      • Thyroid (papillary, follicular, medullary, anaplastic) (Rfs: hx radiation to head/neck, family hx; Sx: typically euthyroid; pt may note thyroid mass or adenopathy, sob or change in voice if spread; PE: thyroid nodules or enlargement; cervical adenopathy if spread)
      • Uterine (endometrial) (Rfs: older age, early menarche, late menoapause, receiving unopposed estrogens, obesity; Sx vague lower abd discomfort, wt loss, progressive, vaginal bleeding; PE: enlarged uterus on exam)
      • Vaginal (squamous) (Rfs: age >50, DES exposure, HPV, smoking; Sx: lower abd/vaginal area pain, vaginal bleeding; PE: vaginal wall abnormality on exam)
      • Other→ any solid structure can have a primary malignancy - though above are the most common
    • Leukemia
      • Liquid tumors (Sx: fevers, chills, weight loss, adenopathy, decreased appetite; fatigue/low energy/chronically tired/SOB→ from anemia, mucocutaneous bleeding→ from low plt; impaired immunity, recurrent infections from→ low numbers or dysfunctional WBCs
      • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) (Etiology: monoclonal B cell d/o; Rfs: age > 60, male sl > female, agent orange exposure; Sx: often asx x years→ picked up on incidental labs; then fever, sweats, adenopathy, fatigue, wt loss, bleeding, infections; can transform into acute leukemia or lmphoma; can develop auto-immune hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia; PE: as progresses→ adenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly)
      • Chronic myelocytic leukemia (CML) (Etiology: associated w/9:22 chromosome translocation; Rfs: avg age 55-60, radiation, male sl > female; Sx: fatigue, abdominal fullness, f, weats, wt loss; WBCs elevated, often plt too; chronic phase x 3-5y; then accelerated phase w/blast crisis→ infection, bleeding; PE: often splenomegaly)
      • Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) (Etiology: most common acute leukemia in kids; in adults, represents 20% of acute leukemias; RFs: in adults→ male, hx prior radiation or chemo, > age 70, Down's syndrome; Sx: fatigue, sob, weakness, fever, sweats, easy bruising/bleeding; PE: palor, petechiae, echymoses; sometimes adenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)
      • Acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) (Etiology: most common adult acute leukemia; Rfs: male, age > 60, smoking, hx prior chemo or xrt; hx of myelofibrosis, essential thrombocythemia, polycythemia vera; Sx: fatigue, fever, dyspnea, easy bruising; PE: palor, echymoses, petechiae, musocal bleeding; sometimes adenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)
      • Other leukemias
      • Myelofibrosis (Etiology: sometimes have p vera, cml or ET first; Sx: generalized fatigue, night sweats, wt loss, fever; sob, doe→ from anemia; abd discomfort from hepato-splenomegaly→ sites of extra med hematopoeisis; PE: hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)
    • Lymphoma
      • Lymphoma Sx: wt loss/decreased appetite sweats, fevers, chills, adenopathy, organomegaly, abdominal fullness; CNS involvement and sx w/NHL; skin involvement w/cutanous t-cell NHL
      • Hodgkins (Etiology: 10% of lymphomas; Rfs: age 15-40 & > 55, hiv +, EBV infection, fam hx; Sx: fever, sweats, wt loss, adenopathy; cough/sob if mediastinal invovlmenet; PE: painless, progressive adenopathy, in particular head/neck; sometimes splenomegaly, hepatomegaly)
      • Non-Hodgkins (Etiology: 90% of lymphomas; many different types (B & T cell), significant variability in how aggressive they may be; Rfs: age > 60, hx hiv + confers markedly increased risk aggressive NHL; EBV→ Burkitts; h pylori→ stomach MALT; Sx: f, c, sweats, fatigue, wt loss; PE: progressive, painless, generalized adenopathy; splenomegaly; extra-nodal dz can involve almost any organ system)
    • Multiple Myeloma
      • Rfs: age > 60, hx MGUS; Sx: fatigue, sob, wt loss, doe→ from anemia, renal involvement, hypercalcemia or combinations; bone pain from lytic lesions; infection
    • Myeloproliferative disorders
      • Polycythemia vera (Etiology: primary bone marrow problem→ w/inappropriate RBC production; age onset typically > 50; Sx: hepatic vein or other venous clot in unusual location or otherwise unexplained; mi, stroke, tia, headache, mesenteric ischemia, other arterial insufficiency from sludging; itching exacerbated by hot shower; sometimes bleeding; often picked up incidentally on CBC; PE: ruddy complexion, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly)
      • Chronic myelocytic leukemia (CML) (Etiology: associated w/9:22 chromosome translocation; Rfs: avg age 55-60, radiation, male sl > female; Sx: fatigue, abdominal fullness, f, weats, wt loss; WBCs elevated, often plt too; chronic phase x 3-5y; then accelerated phase w/blast crisis→ infection, bleeding; PE: often splenomegaly)
      • Myelofibrosis (Etiology: sometimes have p vera, cml or ET first; Sx: generalized fatigue, night sweats, wt loss, fever; sob, doe→ from anemia; abd discomfort from hepato-splenomegaly→ sites of extra med hematopoeisis; PE: hepatomegaly, splenomegaly)
    • Myelodysplastic syndrome
      • Rfs: Age > 60, a primary problem or secondary to chemotherapy or other d/o that can affect BM function; Sx: asx until anemia, low plt, or low wbc lead to sx→ fatigue, sob, doe, bleeding, infection; risk of transformation to AML

      Mental Health D/O

      • Depression (Sx: little interest or pleasure in doing things; feeling down depressed or hopeless)
      • Substance abuse

      Infectious D/O

      • Chronic
        • HIV (RFs: men having sex w/men, sex w/prostitutes, IVDU, transfusion w/o screening, sexually active, past STI, TB, sex w/anyone w/HIV RFs, sex for money; Sx: wt loss, fatigue, f, sweats, infections typical of t-cell dysfxn→ fungal, mycobacterial, other)
        • TB (Rfs: immunocompromised → malnourished, chronic steroids, known HIV or HIV RFs, chronic liver, lung or kidney dz, dialysis, health care worker, from endemic area; Sx: cough x weeks, hemoptysis, wt loss)
        • Hepatitis B (RFs: spread via sexual contact, vertical, shared needles, needle sticks in health care workers, unscreened blood transfusion, ~5% of acute infxn become chronic, long term risk cirrhosis and HCC: PE: asx until cirrhosis or HCC; then icterus, jaudice and other findings of chronic liver dz)
        • Hepatitis C (RFs: spread via needles, unscreened blood transfusion, shared cocaine inhaling tools, needle sticks in health care workers, vertical, sexual; 10-20% resolve; long term risk cirrhosis and HCC; PE: asx until cirrhosis or HCC; then icterus, jaudice and other findings of chronic liver dz)
      • Acute infection - short term fatigue - symptoms based on primary site
      • Sub-acute: endocarditis

      Pulmonary D/O

      • COPD (Rfs: Smoking hx; Sx: SOB, DOE, sputum, acute or chronic, cough, wheezing)
      • Other chronic pulmonary disorders

      Cardiovascular D/O

      • CHF (RFs: known vascular dz, htn, dm, smoking, etc; Sx: orthopnea, pnd, doe; Pe: lower extremity edema , + S3, elevated jvp, displaced pmi, rales on lung exam)
      • Bradycardia (Sx: fatigue, decrease exercise tolerance, sob, lightheaded/presycnope/syncope; PE: bradycardia, sometime chf)
      • SVT - a fib, a flutter, avnrt, WPW (Sx: rapid/irreg heart beat, palpatations; fatigue related to decreased exercise tolerance or CHF; PE: rapid hr, sometimes chf findings)

      GI D/O

      • Bleeding from upper GI source→ anemia
      • Bleeding from lower GI source→ anemia
      • Chronic diarrhea→ malabsorption of nutrients
      • IBD - Crohn's Disease or UC (Sx: sub-acute, recurrent or chronic; wt loss, bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, nocturnal diarrhea; systemically feeling poorly; presentation can also be fulminant)
      • Chronic liver disease - Hepatitis B & C, ETOH; less common: Wilson's, alpha-1 antytripsin defic, automimmune hepatitis, etc.

      Neurological D/O

      Neuro disorders more typically cause weakness, numbness, neuropathic pain or other focal sx rather than fatigue. However, some patients may experience weakness as fatigue, or note fatigue as a co-existing complaint

      Muscle disease

      Typically progressive, proximal muscle weakness, no numbness
      • Inflammatory
        • Polymyositis (Etiology: rare, autoimmune; Rfs: female > male, age>20; Sx/PE: symmetrical proximal weakness of arms and legs, develops over weeks to months; neck flexor weakness; no sensory deficits; sometimes pain, though not prominent feature; dysphagia in 1/3; polyarthritis in 45%; PE: symmetric proximal > distal weakness, preserved reflexes)
        • Dermatomyositis (Etiology: autoimmune; Rfs: children and adults, female > male; Sx: weakness that develops over weeks; earliest affected often neck flexors, pectoral muscles, pelvic girdle; can be asymmetric; dysphagia and dysarthria in 1/3; pain not prominent; no sensory deficits, accompanied by rash, proximal; other organ systems affected including cardiac conduction system dz, arthralgias, arthritis, malignancy→ breast, prostate, colon, other; interstitial lung dz; PE: erythematous skin erruption in sun-exposed area, heliotropic rash around eyes→ purplish w/edema, Gottron's papules→ scaly and papular on knuckles, subcutaneous calcifications, progressive weakness, reflexes preserved until late)
