        • Inclusion body myositis (Etiology: autoimmune; Rfs: age > 50, male>female; Sx: slowly progressive, weakness w/o pain, no sensory impairment, typically symmetric, distal > proximal, in particular feet and hands, 60% w/dysphagia, 20+% assoc w/connective tissue d/o; PE: progressive weakness, distal > proximal, refelxes diminish w/progression)
      • Metabolic or toxin induced
        • Hypothyroidism (Sx: wt gain, edema, dry skin, constipation, cold intolerance, depression/mood change, weakness, fatigue; PE: often no findings aside from wt gain, sometimes decreased reflexes, edema, bradycardia)
        • Hyperthyroidism (Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, wt loss, weakness, infetility, ED, menstrual irreg; PE: sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid, hyper-reflexia, moist skin)
        • Steroid induced (Rfs/Etiology: rare, typically from long term glucocorticoid use, cushings disease)
        • Etoh induced
        • Statin induced (Sx: vague ache more than weakness; can occur at any time, rarely rhabdo)
        • Periodic paralysis (Rfs: assoc w/hypokalemia, hyperthyroidism, male, Asian, ages 20-40; often precipitated by high carb meals, exercise, stress; also a rare familial form (not assoc w/hyperthyroidism), w/male predominance, onset < 20; Sx: episodic profound weakness, muscles affected often proximal, legs > arms, duration minutes to hours/days, intervals between attacks can be days to weeks to monthconsciousness preserved)
        • Low phosphorous
        • Glycogen storage d/o - very uncommon
      • Muscular dystrophy (progressive weakness and wasting, onset from early childhood to 20s)

      NMJ D/O

      • Myasthenia gravis (Etiol: autoimmune w/ab targeting ACh receptor; Rfs: 20-30 y female predom, 50-70y male; Sx: painless, subacute, progressive; worse w/repetitive movement, end of day; ocular sx→ double vision, eyelid weakness; other cranial nerve palsies; can also cause systemic weakness affecting neck, extremities, other muscles→ asymmetric and prox > distal fashion; PE: no atrophy, reflexes preserved, no sensory findings, ptosis, eye muscle weakness, weakness in other muscles→ worse w/use)
      • Lambert Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) (Etiology: auto-antibody against presynaptic side of nmj; Rfs: male>female, rare, 50% assoc w/malignancy→ in particular lung; can also occur w/other autoimmune dz→ thyroid, RA, vasculitis, other; age ~60 if cancer, 30s & 60s if no malignancy; Sx: progressive weakness over mos, fatigue, proximal muscles > distal, progresses caudal to cranial, eye & facial muscles not typically affected, autonomic dysfxn→ dry mouth, constipation, orthostatic lightheadedness, etc.; no numbness; PE: proximal weakness, diminished or absent reflexes)
      • Botulism (Rfs: exposure to at risk food; exposure to black tar heroin; Sx: acute onset→ 8-36h, difficulty swallowing secretions, difficulty breathing or speaking, double vision, abdominal cramps, weakness/paralysis starts w/CNs→ spreads symmetrically to limbs, afebrile)
      • Organophosphate poisoning (Etiology: accidental, intentional or as biological weapon→ Sarin; inhibits cholinesterase; Sx: related to ach excess→ acute confusion, lacrimation, excessive resp secretions, brady, weakness, wheezing)

      PNS d/o

        Weakness is usually distal
      • Compression from tumor, infection, fracture, OA, etc→ typically focal deficits, suggestive hx
      • Vasculitis/Autoimmune: 0ften painful, w/motor deficits; typically delays in dx as uncommon
        • CIDP (Sx: symptom onset over 2m, painless, symmetrically decreased sensation, also proximal and distal weakness, upper or lower extremities - or both)
        • Guillain Barre (AIDP) (Etiology: autoimmune, though often infxn ~2w prior→ campylobacter, resp, other; Sx: numbness/tingling legs and hands; most prominent feature is weakness that's acute, progressive over hours-to-days, symmetric, w/an ascending pattern of involvement; often autonomic dysfxn→ tachy or brady, orthostasis, diaphoresis; PE: distal weakness, distal sensory impairment, diminished or absent reflexes)
        • Charcot-Marie-Tooth (Rfs: fam hx→ autosomal recessive; Sx: slowly progressive (years) of neuropathic pain, numbness and weakness, distal legs first; PE: muscle wasting, impaired sensation and loss of reflexes on exam)
      • Metabolic processes or nutritional deficiencies
        • DM (Rfs/Etiology: common, hx poorly controlled DM; Sx: stocking glove ascending loss of sensation, may have autonomic dysfxn, loss of reflexes, affects dorsal columns & spinothalamics, absent proprioception, can be painful or painless)
        • Renal failure (Rfs: advanced renal disease; Sx: often w/pain, symmetric and affects distal lower extremities first→ moving proximal over time, improves w/dialysis and/or transplant)
        • Hypothyroidism (Sx: wt gain, edema, dry skin, constipation, cold intolerance, depression/mood change, weakness, fatigue; PE: often no findings aside from wt gain, sometimes decreased reflexes, edema, bradycardia)
        • B12 (Sx: progressive weakness, legs more common then arms, can be painful, sx of fatigue/doe if anemia as well; PE: impaired dorsal columns function, gait problems, tongue can be smooth and swollen if severe)
      • Meds or Toxins
        • Chemotherapeutic agents (Rfs: in particular those containing taxane and platin; INH; Sx: painful)
        • Arsenic (Rfs: ingestion of contaminated water→ India, or poisoning; Sx: painful neuropathy; n, v, d, abd pain, confusion)
        • Lead (Etiology: lead based paints or other chronic unintentional ingestions; Sx: abd pain, nausea, constipation, anemia, muscle and joint pain, confusion and cognitive problems, altered sense of tasted, peripheral motor and sensory neuropathy)
        • ETOH (Rfs: long hx etoh abuse; Sx: distal sensory and motor impairment, can be painful)
      • Infection
        • HIV assoc (Etiology/Rfs: hiv risk factors→ men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/somone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; risks of unusual infection increase as CD4 declines; neuropathy often painful more from CDC
        • Leprosy (Rfs: exposure to an endemic area→ Asia, Africa, South America; Sx: painful, slowly progressive, hypo-pigmented patches of skin w/sensory loss, asymmetric, upper or lower extremities)
      • Malignancies
        • Para-neoplastic associated - lung, breast, lymphoma, myeloma, MGUS - often painful

      CNS d/o

      • Spinal cord/brain tumor, infection, fracture, stroke/vascular insuff, arthritis or other process→ typically cause focal deficits
      • Multiple sclerosis (Rfs/Etiology: white>black, women>men, age onset <30; Sx: affects spinal cord and brain, sub-acute, waxes/wanes, progresses over year/decades, patchy sensory and motor deficits that can affect any of the neuro pathways and don't follow an anatomic pattern, visual disturbances)

      Mixed CNS & PNS d/o

      • ALS (Rfs: age onset 60s; Sx: progressive over years, upper and lower extremities, fatigue, dysphagia, sob; on exam muscle wasting and fasciculations)

      Other neuro d/o

      • Parkinson's (Rfs: age > 70; Sx: pill rolling tremor of hands, sometimes head bobbing tremor, difficulty starting and stopping movements, balance and gait problems, sometimes cognitive decline; PE: characteristic pill-rolling tremor, shuffling gait, masked facies, difficulty getting up and starting movement, difficulty turning)
      • Other neurodegnerative d/o

      Other

      • Chronic liver disease
      • Chronic kidney disease
      • Profound hypokalemia
      • Hypercalcemia
      • Hyponatremia
      • Poor nutrition
      • Deconditioning
      • Meds→ prescribed or illicit (narcotics or benzos can disrupt sleep/wake cycles; meds for ADHD; illicit stimulants→cocaine, crystal)
      • Combinations of any of the above conditions

      Fevers, chills, sweats?

      Autoimmune/Rheum d/o

      Specific disorder based on other symptoms and findings - relatively uncommon (compared w/above)
      • Adult Still's Disease (Etiology: febrile illness of unknown etiology; Sx: f and other sx are persistent, sub-acute; evaluation of f does not reveal other etiology; also arhtritis & arthralgias of larger joints; salmon colored, maculo-pap non-puritic skin erruption; myalgias, adenopathy, sore throat, pericarditis and pleuritis; PE: erruption is light salmon colored mac/pap, pharyngitis, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy)
      • Acute rheumatic fever (Sx: relatively uncommon, occurs 2-3w after strep pharyngitis, assoc w/fever, fatigue, acute/abrupt onset, migratory inflammatory arthritis of large joints typically; long term risk of mitral or aortic valve dz; PE: affected joint(s) are warm, red, pain w/movement)
      • Cryogloblulinemia (Etiology: small-vessel vasculitis caused by antigen-antibody complex deposition; Type I monoclonal→ IgM or IgG, related to lymphoprolif d/o→ lymphoma, myeloma; Type II and III, mixed cryos IgM and IgG; related to Hep C (most common), SLE, RA, lymphoma, myeloma, hiv, hep b, other autoimmune; RFs: female > male, ages 40-50; Sx: subacute fatigue, weakness, muscle and joint aches, cough/sob if pulmonary involvement; confusion; symmetric or asymmetric often painful distal neuropathy, painful skin ulcers of extremities, purpuric papules; membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis; PE: palpable purpura of vasculitis, Raynauds, livedo reticularis, distal skin ulcers)
      • Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss) (Etiology: idiopathic d/o, small-to-medium vessel vasculitis; w/high levels circulating and tissue invasive eosinophils; Rfs: men=women, assoc also w/leukotriene antagonists; Sx: progressive, adult onset asthma, cough & wheezing, nasal stuffiness→ w/resp sx usually ~2-10 y prior to systemic sx assoc w/eosinophilic deposition in target organs and vasculitis; in these later phases→ systemic sx including: sob from parenchymal lung involvement; f, c, muscle aches; hematuria from renal involvement; heart failure, pericarditis and dysrhythmia w/cardiac involvement; peripheral neuropathy; PE: wheezing, skin findings of vasculitis: small, palapable purpura, don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; hematuria/renal involvement; unexplained peripheral neuropathy)
      • Familial Med Fevers (Rfs: Mediterranean descent→ Turkish, Jewish, Armenian, Arab, other; family hx; Sx: uncommon, associated w/cryptic abdominal pain, rash, arthritis, arthralgias, myalgias, recurrent fever)
      • Giant Cell Arteritis (Rfs: age > 50, often prior hx PMR; Sx fatigue, headache, joint aches, f, c, acute visual loss; PE: sometimes scalp or temp art tenderness, abnl optic nerve)
      • Granulomatosis with poyangiitis (Wegeners) (Etiology: small-to-medium vessel vasculitis; Sx: vasculitis→ recurrent/progressive nasal congestion, cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; PE: mucosal erythema, ulcer, nasal septum perf)
      • Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) ()Etiology: uncontrolled activation of T Cells, w/inappropriate release of cytokines and macrophage activation; Rx directed at underlying cause; Rfs: triggered by lymphoma, leukemia, autoimmunes dz, infxns→ ebv, enterovirus, gastroenteritis, other; also a rare familial form; Sx: f that's unexplained, other related to the inciting process, increased ferretin, cytopenias, hyper-TGs; PE: f, splenomegaly)
      • Inflammatory bowel disease - Crohn's dz or UC (Sx: sub-acute, recurrent or chronic diarrhea; wt loss, bloody stools, mucous, cramps, constipation, nocturnal diarrhea; systemic sx; presentation can also be fulminant)
      • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
      • Microscopic polyangitis (MPA) (Etiology: small vessel vasculitis; Sx: fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, sweats, wt loss; recurrent/progressive cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; less often nasal sx c/w GPA; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; skin ulcers; neuropathy; PE: palpable purpura, skin ulcer/necrosis)
      • Polyarteritis Nodosa (Etiology: medium-vessel-vasculitis; Rfs: 40s-50s, men>women, Hep B/C; Sx: more commonly subacute over mos f, s, malaise, wt loss, muscle/joint pain; multiple systems: arthritis, glomerulonephritis, peripheral nerve pain/dysfxn, skin w/ulcers, small, palapable purpura→ don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; abd pain, blood per rectum)
      • Polymyalgia Rheumatica (PMR) (Rfs: age > 50, Sx: subacute arthralgias affecting hips and shoulders, worse in AM, f, c; can't sleep secondary to inability to find comfortable position; PE: no findings of arthritis/synovitis on exam, no objective findings of weakness)
      • RA (Etiology: can cause interstitial lung dz, pleural inflammation, pulm vasc dz; meds for RA can have lung tox, also→ immunocomp→ infxn; Rfs: women > men; age 30-55; Sx: subacute (>6w), persistent/progressive joint pain, worse in AM due to gelling→ improves w/use, fatigue, tendency for bilateral involvement, commonly small and medium sized joints; nerve symptoms can be motor, sensory or from compression; PE: warmth, redness, spongy feeling from synovial inflam, pain w/squeezing of joints, effusion, abnormal appearing if longstanding, MCPs with chronic changes; extra articular findings: episcleritis, pleural/pericardial inflam, rheumatoid nodules) more from CDC
      • Serum sickness (Rfs: typically from rxn to abx, or secondary to viral infxn → e.g. acute hep b; Sx: acute, symetric, additive/migratory, polyarthritis; myalgias, fever, rash, onset days to weeks after exposure)
      • Takayasu's arteritis (Etiology: large vessel vasculitis, onset 10-30yo, Asian background, women > men; Sx: sub-acute and progressive, fevers, fatigue, wt loss, myalgias arthralgias; target organ sx based on affected vessels: abdominal aorta & branches→ abdominal pain, htn; thoracic aorta & branches→ chest pain, sob, tia/stroke; PE: loss of palpable pulses radial, carotid, lower extremity)
      • Vasculitis - other

      Pathogens assoc w/fever

      Specific infections identified on basis of focality (i.e. patient complaints pointing to specific organ systems), risk factors, corollary sx and exam findings; labs/imaging help to pinpoint precise etiology and extent

      Bacteria

      Aerobes: GNR & GNC

    • Gram negative rods
      • Acinetobacter (Site: wounds, urine, lung; Etiology: usually hospital acquired; not typically pathogenic for healthy hosts) more from CDC
      • Bacillary angiomatosis (bartonella sp) (Site: skin; Rfs: occurs in HIV infected or otherwise compromised pts; Sx/PE: nodules on skin, resemble Kaposis Sarcoma) more from CDC
      • Bartonella henslae (cat scratch) (Sites: skin and lymph nodes; Rfs/Etiology: caused by cat scratch; Sx: may see inflamation at innoculation site, then tender regional adenopathy w/in few weeks, fatigue, fever) more from CDC
      • Brucella (Sites: systemic; Etiology: ingestion of raw/uncooked dairy or handling infected animals; Rfs: veterinarians, meat packers, slaughter house workers, farmers; Middle East, Mediterranean, Mexico, Africa; Sx/PE: causes weeks/months of recurrent f, c, sweats, arthritis, adenopathy, orchitis, hepato-splenomegaly) more from CDC
      • Campylobacter (Site: small bowel; Etiology: spread thru contaminated food; Sx: d, n, v, cramps, often w/bloody stools; incubation 2-5d; typically self limited to 1w) more from CDC
      • Citrobacter (Site: urine most common; then biliary tree, peritoneum, respiratory, intravasc, other; Rfs/Etiology: often hospital acquired, compromised/ill host)
      • Donavanosis (granualoma inguinale) (Site: genital regions; Rfs: tropics & not in US unless travel, spread by direct sexual contact, can be hard to distinguish from chancroid, similar RFs for HIV; Sx/PE: incubation 1-3m, papule to painless ulcer in genital area, beefy red/bleeds, develops over weeks)
      • E coli (Sites: urinary tract, abdominal/pelvic/peri-rectal infection and abscess; O157:H7 causes enteritis and HUS) more from CDC
      • Eikenella (E Corrodens) (RFs: lives in human mouthrarr; assoc w/human bite; Sites: hands, arms or anyplace that bite occurs; rarely endocarditis→ HACEK organism; Sx: acute pain, redness, swelling, pain w/movement of fingers if tenosynovitis; subacute f, c if endocarditis; PE: wound where bite occurred, redness, warmth, fluctuance if abscess; persistent pain and drainage w/deeper infection of soft tissue or bone; streaky erythema w/lymphangitis; murmur if endocarditis)
      • Enterobacter (Sites: biliary tract, urinary tract, abdominal/pelvic/peri-rectal infection or abscesses; in hospitalized patients→ pneumonia, wound infection, uti)
      • Extended spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL) producing organisms (Sites: infects urine, wounds, other; RFs/Etiology: GNRs including enterobacter, e coli, klebsiella; an emerging hospital acquired infxn amongst those who are severely ill, having typically received abx prior)
      • Francisella tularensis (tularemia) (Sites: skin, lymph nodes; Etiology/Rfs: passed from dying wild animals to humans via ticks/insects, US Southeast and Rocky Mtns; Sx: f, c, ha, oral or skin ulcers, painful adenopathy, sob, muscle aches) more from CDC
      • H ducreyi (chancroid) (Site: genital region; Rfs: Africa/Caribean & not in US unless travel, spread by direct sexual contact, similar RFs for HIV; Sx/PE: incubation 1d-2w, papule to painless ulcer in genital area, adenopathy) more from CDC
      • Haemophilus influenza (Sites: upper and lower respiratory tract, cns; RFs: much less common since widespread use of vaccine; increased risk s/p splenectomy; Sites: pneumonia, otitis media, epiglottitis, meningitis) more from CDC
      • HACEK (Haemophilus, Actinobacillus, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, Kingella) organisms (Sites: systemic bacteremia→ endocarditis; Sx: typically sub-acute→ f, c, malaise x weeks)
      • Klebsiella (Sites: pneumonia, wound infection→ hospital acquired infections; Rfs: hospitalized patients, compromised hosts) more from CDC
      • Legionella (Rfs: acquired via inhalation; grows in colonized water collection systems, cooling towers, nebs, whirlpools, etc; Site: community acquired pneumonia; also hospital acquired if water contaminated; Sx: acute cough, sputum, f, c, d, confusion) more from CDC
      • Morganella Morganii (Rf: debilitated/chronically ill patients, hospitalized, prior abx, urinary catheters; high rates resistance; Sites: urinary tract→ can form urinary stones, surgical sites, chronic wounds, intravascular, snake bites)
      • Pertussis (Bordatella Pertussis) (Site: upper airwary; Rfs/Etiology: easily spread; vax of kids and re-vax of adults preventive; kids can have airway compromise due to small size; incubation avg 7-10d; Sx: catarrhal stage 1-2w→ cold sx, sometimes low grade T; then paroxysmal stage→ characteristic whooping cough, post-tussive vomiting; then convaslescent stage→ adults present w/persistent cough x 6-10 weeks) more from CDC
      • Pasturella (P multocida) (RFs: lives in mouths of dogs and cats→ assoc w/bites; Sites: hands, arms or anyplace that bite occurs; Sx: acute pain, redness, swelling, pain w/movement of fingers if tenosynovitis; PE: puncture wounds, redness, warmth, fluctuance if abscess; persistent pain and drainage w/deeper infection of soft tissue or bone; streaky erythema w/lymphangitis)
      • Proteus (Sites: common cause of urinary tract infection, can contribute to stone formation; wound infections in hospitalized patients)
      • Pseudomonas (Sites: lung; bacteremia in patients w/neutropenia, abdominal/pelvic abscesses, wound infection in patients w/DM; wound and urinary infections hospitalized/compromised pts; osteomyelitis; otitis externa in patients w/DM; Rfs: brochiectasis, cystic fibrosis, DM, chemotherapy w/neutropenia, chronic illness or otherwise compromised host)
      • Salmonella typhi (typhoid fever) (Site: small bowel, systemic infxn; Etiology: related to poor sanitation→ outbreaks, travel to endemic areas, spread by contaminated/unwashed food, poor sanitation, unclean water; gall bladder can act as reservoir; Rfs: from endemic area or travel; Sx/PE: relapsing daily fever x weeks, malaise, ha, chills, abd pain, diarrhea, maculop-pap rash→ rose spots, relative brady; aside from fever, sx quite variable)
      • Salmonella (non-typhoidal) (Site: small bowel; Rfs: exposure from eggs, chicken, turtles; most recover in 4-7d; Site: small bowel; Sx: d, n, v, cramps, often w/bloody stools; incubation 12h-3d; rarely can spread to distant sites in compromised hosts→ osteomyelitis, endovascular, other) more from CDC
      • Serratia (Sites: common cause of hospital acquired infections, compromised hosts: pneumonia, wound infection, uti)
      • Shigella (Site: small bowel; Etiology: spread person to person or from food; Site: small bowel; Sx: d, n, v, cramps, often w/bloody stools; avg incubation 3d; typically self limited to 4-7d) more from CDC
      • Vibrio cholera (Site: small bowel; Etiology/Rfs: toxin mediated profound watery diarrhea, related to exposure to unclean water sources, often s/p natural disasters→ presents as epidemics; Sx: profound watery diarrhea; can lead to hypovolemic death in hours if severe) more from CDC
      • Vibrio vulnificus and parahemolytics (Rfs/Sites: causes bacteremia→ sepsis in hosts w/cirrhosis or otherwise compromised hosts, exposure via raw/under cooked shellfish; wound/skin infection if same hosts exposed via inoculation w/affected water→ walking in surf w/exposed wounds in endemic area; Sx: acute n, v, f, cramps, diarrhea; extremity pain and swelling if via wound) more from CDC
      • Yersinia enterocolitica (Site: small bowel; Etiology: spread via contaminated food; Sx: f, c, cramps, bloody diarrhea; incubation 4-7d; typically self limited to 4-7d) more from CDC
      • Yersinia pestis (plague) (Site: respiratory tract; Rf/Etiology: passed from rodents to humans by fleas, direct contact w/feces, or respiratory droplets; Sx: rapid onset f, c, sepsis, pneumonia) more from CDC
    • Gram negative cocci
      • Neisseria meningitidis (Site: meninges, bacteremia; Rfs: often in outbreaks amongst young adults living in close quarters→ college dorms, barracks; unvaccinated; Sx: f, c, ha, n, v, sepsis; PE: very ill, ha, f, neck pain/stiffness, purpura) more from CDC
      • Neisseria gonorrhea (Site: urethra, cervix, uterus, fallopian tubes, testes, pharynx, ano-rectal, joints; Rfs: sexual activity; PE: penile d/c, cervical d/c, cervical pain and uterine pain if PID; pharyngeal inflammation; anorectal d/c; if disseminated→ pustules, infectious arthritis) more from CDC
      • Moraxella (Sites: otitis media; bronchitis in copd exacerbation; pneumonia in COPD; Sx: cough, sob, f, sputum)

      Aerobes: GPC & GPR

    • Gram positive cocci
      • Staph aureus: coag + (Sites/Sx: skin infection, abscess, wound infection; osteomyelitis via direct extension; arthritis; bacteremia, with seeding of abnormal or artificial valves, joints or devices; virulent w/rapid destruction valves/death w/in hours/days; toxic shock; pneumonia following viral infection; toxin based food poisoning→ n/v hours after exposure, others affected who ate same; PE: cellulitis→ redness, warmth, induration, skin abscess→ focal redness and fluctuance)
      • Staph aureus: coag - (Sites: skin infection, abscess, wound infection; bacteremia, w/seeding of abnormal or artificial valves, joints or devices; overall less virulent than coag +; PE: cellulitis, skin abscess)
      • Methicillin Resistant Saph Aureus (MRSA) (Sites: skin infection, abscess; bacteremia, w/seeding of abnormal or artificial valves, joints or devices, can be hospital or community acquired; healthcare assoc pna; PE: cellulitis, skin abscess) more from CDC
      • Streptococcus: Group A (strep pyogenes) (Sites: cellulitis/lymphangitis; skin abscess; erysipelas; impetigo, throat infections→ acute pain, f, adenopathy; scarlet fever → high temp, rash, palatal petchiae, throat sx; necrotizing fasciits; PE: strep throat→ pharyngeal erythema, d/c, adenop, necrotizing fasciitis, red streaking from lymphangitis) more from CDC
      • Streptococcus: Group B (strep agalactiae) (Sites: endometritis, meningitis, bacteremia, neonatal infection) more from CDC
      • Streptococcus: Group D (enterococcus) (Sites: urinary tract infection, pelvic/abd abscess, wound/other infxn in chronically ill/hospitalized patients)
      • Streptococcus Viridans (Etiology: mouth flora, bacteremia via dental procedure; Sites and Sx: endocarditis→ subacute w/sx f, c, malaise x weeks)
      • Streptococcus Pneumoniae (pneumococcus)(Sites: pneumonia, upper respiratory infections, meningitis; bacteremia if severe; Rfs: s/p splenectomy or fxnl asplenia, eldery and very young, any chronic medical condition→ copd, liver or renal dz, chf, cancer, diabetes, HIV, or otherwise immunocompromised; also csf leaks, cochlear implants; decreased risk if vaccinated) more from CDC
      • Streptococcus Bovis (non-enterococcal Group D) (Etiology: associated w/colon cancer, which may be otherwise unknown at time of infection; Sites: bacteremia, endocarditis)
      • Vancomycin resistant eterococcus (VRE) (Sites and Rfs: hospital acquired infection, affecting those w/multi-system illness; can cause wound, urinary, respiratory infections) more from CDC
    • Gram positive rods
      • Anthrax (Etiology: acquired from animal exposure or biological weapon; Sx: inhalation: cough, f, c, pneumonia sepsis; cutaneous: ulcer to eshcar w/surrounding edema) more from CDC
      • Diptheria (Site: upper respiratory tract; Sx: cough, f, sore throat, uncommon now w/vax; PE: pseudo-membrane w/airway obstruction) more from CDC
      • Listeria (Site: bacteremia, CNS; Etiology: contaminated food; RFs: older persons, newborns, pregnant, immunocompromised; Sx: f, c, d, n, aches; ha, neck stiffness→ meningitis) more from CDC

      Anaerobes

      Anaerobes (GN or GP) (Often associated with mixed/complex infections/abscesses of abdomen, pelvis, lung, mouth)
      • Bacteroides fragilis (GNR) (Sites: along w/GNRs→ contributes to abdominal/pelvic, lung abscesses)
      • Clostridium Perfringes (GPR) (Etiology: most common cause food born diarrhea→ undercooked meat, other who ate same ill simultaneously, resolves in 24h; can contribute to nec fasciitis; Sx: cramps, diarrhea, 6-18h after ingestion, contribute to abd/pv abscess; NEC in neonates; PE: deep tissue infection from necrotizing faciitis) more from CDC
      • Clostridium Difficile (GPR) (Etiology: antibiotic associated colitis; toxin based; Rfs: can occur after any abx, also passed to patients in houspital via healthcare workers; Sx: cramps, diarrhea, severe pain and sepsis if advanced) more from CDC
      • Clostridium Tetani (GPR) (Etiology: exposure via contaminated wounds; toxin mediated; vaccination markedly decreases incidence dz w/50 cases/y US; Sx: ~1w incubation, increased tone in jaw muscles, dysphagia, diffuse musle pain/spasms, sweating, airway compromise; PE: fever, tachycardia, elevated bp, lock jaw, severe muscle spasm) more from CDC
      • Clostridium Botulinum (GPR) (Etiology: food/wound born toxin, black tar heroin; Sx: incubation 1-2d, rapid descending symmetric paralysis starting w/cranial nerves, dizziness, dry mouth, double vision, blurred vision, no sensory deficits, agitation, resp failure, death) more from CDC
      • Peptostreptococus (GPC) (Sites: lives in mouth, contributes to mixed oral/lung infxns/abscess)

      Other bacteria

      • Actinomyces (Sites: oral/neck/face, other organ systems Sx: slow growing abscess, often w/sinus tract development)
      • Chlamydia trachomatis (sti) (Sites: urethra, cervix, uterus, fallopian tubes, testes; Etiology: urethritis, epididymo-orchitis, cervicitis, PID; Sx: cervical or urethral d/c, vaginal bleeding; PID→ lower abd pain, f; women often asx; PE: cervicitis→ purulent cervical d/c, friable cervix; PID→ cervical d/c, cervical motion tenderness, adnexal pain, uterine pain; men→ urethral d/c, testicular/epididymal swelling & pain if testic involvement) more from CDC
      • Chlamydia trachomatis (lymphogranuloma venereum) (Site: Genital region; Etiology: spread by sexual contact, rare in US, Rfs: same as for HIV; Sx: incubation 1-3 weeks, painless papule or ulcer on penis/vagina/rectal area, then painful adenopathy) more from CDC
      • Chlamydia trachomatis (trachoma) (Site: eye; Etiology: spread thru poor hand hygiene, sharing towels, or via flies, endemic in poor/developing countries, a leading cause blindeness world-wide; Sx: chronic, purulent conjunctivitis, can lead to scarring of lid→ inward turned lashes→ scarring of cornea→ blindness) more from CDC
      • Chlamydia pneumoniae (Site: upper resp tract and lung→ atypical cmnty acquired pna; Sx: sore throat, fever, non-productive cough) more from CDC
      • Chlamydia psittaci (psitacosis) (Site: lung; Etiology: spread by exposure to parrots & sometimes other birds Sx: 1-2 week incubation; fever, cough, severe HA; other organ systems as well) more from CDC
      • Mycoplasma pneumoniae (Etiology: common cause CAP; also upper resp tract infxn; Sx: acute f, c, cough, upper resp sx; not usually severe) more from CDC
      • Nocardia (Sites: lung, skin; Etiology: lives in soil, inhaled or via open wound; Sx: subacute cough, f, abscess, cellulitis, lymphangitis if direct inoculation) more from CDC

      Viruses

    • Respiratory
      • Adeno (Etiology/Site: cause of upper respiratory infxn→ common cold, conjunctivitis, otitis media; Sx: cough, nasal congestion, sore throat, ear pain, conjunctival inflamation PE: throat redness, conjunctivitis, anterior auricular adenopathy) more from CDC
      • Enterovirus (non-polio) (Etiology: passed fecal-oral, close contact, ingesting infected water; Site: brain→ meningitis & encephalitis, oral mucosa and skin→ hand/foot/mouth dz, heart→ myocarditis and pericarditis; conjunctiva→ conjunctivitits; upper resp tract; Sx: most have mild illness; w/more severe dz→ fever, ha, cough, runny nose, muscle aches, confusion) more from CDC
      • Hanta (Etiology: rodent exposure, incubation 3-4d; Sx: f, myalgias, HA, n, v, abd pain; then rapidly progressive resp sx) more from CDC
      • Influenza (Etiology: common cause upper and lower respiratory infection; Rfs: seasonal in North America Oct to April, increase risk amongst old, young, pregnant, chronic lung disease, any chronic illness, no vaccination; Sx: abrupt onset of myalgias, arthralgias, fever, chills) more from CDC
      • Measels (rubeola) (Etiology: spread thru resp droplets, highly contagious; Rfs: too young to be vaccinated (<1y), or never vaccinated; winter/spring in US; Sx: incubation 7-14d; cough, high f, malaise; rash 4-5d after sx onset; PE: conjunctivitis, runny nose, then white (Koplick's) spots on oral mucosa, then rash; complications include encephalitis, pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Middle Eastern Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) (Etiology: coronavirus; Rfs: travel to or close contact in past 14d w/someone from Middle East; Sx: acute fever, cough, sob; sometimes n/v/d; can be rapidly progressive)
      • Para-influenza (Etiology: upper resp infection/croup, tracheobronchitis) more from CDC
      • Rhino (Etiology: cause of upper respiratory infxn→ common cold, typically self limited; Sx: cough, nasal congestion, sore throat) more from CDC
      • RSV (Sites: upper and lower resp tract→ croup, brochiolitis, pna; Rfs: winter mos, typically affects infants and children; in partic if premature or w/chronic lung or heart dz; Sx: cough, fever, sob) more from CDC
      • SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome) (Etiology: coronavirus; initial outbreak in China→ rapid spread/pandemic Sx: high fever, aches, sometimes cough; then pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Herpes simplex pneumonia (Etiology: can be primary or reactivation; Sites: typically oral, genital or cns; rarely pna; Rfs: passed by sexual or oral contact; Sx/PE: cough, sob, confusion, oral area vesicles)
      • Varicella zoster (chicken pox) (Rfs: rare in kids as vaccine preventable; Sx: f, fatigue, ha, generalized vesicular erruption, duration 5-10d, can still get mild dz if vax, pneumonia in setting severe chicken pox or immunocomp) CDC
    • Liver
      • Hepatitis A (Etiology/Rfs: spread fecal/oral/ingestion contaminated food, can be epidemic, incubation 2-4w; Sx: n, v, RUQ abd pain, puritis, dark urine, light colored stool, f, jaundice, icterus; sx generally resolve w/in 2-4w; very rarely fulminant, not assoc w/chronic infxn; PE: jaundice, icterus, RUQ pain, hepatomegaly)
      • Hepatitis B (RFs: spread via sexual contact, vertical, shared needles, needle sticks in health care workers, unscreened blood transfusion; Sx: many are asx; incubataion is 1-4m; acute infxn assoc w/n, v, jaundice; puritus, icterus, dark urine, light colored stool, malaise; typically self limited, w/resoln sx 2-3m; 5% go on to chronic infxn, w/risk cirrhosis, spread to others, and hcc decades after initial infxn; PE: chronic infxn can lead to icterus, jaudice and other findings of chronic liver dz)
      • Hepatitis C (RFs: spread via needles, unscreened blood transfusion, shared cocaine inhaling tools, needle sticks in health care workers, vertical, sexual; 10-20% resolve spontaneously; long term risk cirrhosis and HCC w/chronic infxn; Sx: most w/acute hep C are asx; those w/sx have RUQ pain, f, malaise, jaudice; can have sx cirrhosis and hcc decades later; PE: most have no findings in acute phase; chronic infxn can lead to icterus, jaudice and other findings of chronic liver dz)
      • Hepatitis D (RFs: occurs as a co-infection w/hep b, uncommon in west, found in Mediterranean and Asian countries; spread via same mechanisms as hep b)
      • Hepatitis E (RFs: uncommon in western nations, though most common cause of acute hep in developing world, can be sporadic or epidemic, water born w/spread similar to hep a; Sx: incubation 3-8w, sx of malaise, n, jaundice x ~ 2w; usually self limited, rarely fulminant, rarely chronic)
        • More on viral hepatitis from CDC
      • EBV→ mononucleosis (incubation 4-6w, pro-drome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias; then f, head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly) more from CDC
      • CMV (Etol/Rfs: retinitis/colitis/disseminated dz in patients w/HIV; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w; Sx: f, c, malaise hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, fatigue x 4-6w; head/neck adenopathy & pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC
    • Small bowel
      • Norovirus (Etiology/Rfs: common cause of acute enteritis in adults, daycare/hospitals/nursing homes; Sx: abrupt onset n, v, diarrhea, low grade f) more from CDC
      • Rotavirus (Etiology/Rfs: common cause of acute enteritis in kids <5; vaccine preventable; Sx: abrupt onset n, v, diarrhea, f) more from CDC
    • Neuro
      • Arbovirus (Organisms: equine, west nile, lacrosse, other; Site: brain→ encephalitis; Etiology: carried by mosquitos; Sx: incubation 2d-2w; f, fatigue, HA, stiff neck, delirium) more from CDC
      • EBV (mononucleosis) (Rfs: spread by direct contact→ kissing, shared drinking glasses, shared toothbrushes, etc; Sites: pharynx, spleen, rarely brain and/or meninges; Sx: incubation 4-6w, prodrome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias, then f, sorethroat; PE: maculo-pap rash after amox or other abx, head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly; confusion, ha, f, deficits if CNS involvement) more from CDC
      • Enterovirus (non-polio: coxsackie, echo, other entero) (Etiology: passed fecal-oral, close contact, ingesting infected water; Site: brain→ meningitis & encephalitis, oral mucosa and skin→ hand/foot/mouth dz, heart→ myocarditis and pericarditis; conjunctiva→ conjunctivitits; upper resp tract; Sx: most have mild illness; w/more severe dz→ fever, ha, cough, runny nose, muscle aches, confusion) more from CDC
      • Herpes simplex encephalitis (Etiology: can be primary or reactivation; RFs: passed by sexual or oral contact; Site: brain→ meningitis & encephalitis; Sx: acute, HA, delirium vesicles)
      • Measels (rubeola) (Etiology: spread thru resp droplets, highly contagious; Rfs: too young to be vaccinated (<1y), or never vaccinated; winter/spring in US; Sx: incubation 7-14d; cough, high f, malaise; rash 4-5d after sx onset; PE: conjunctivitis, runny nose, then white (Koplick's) spots on oral mucosa, then rash; complications include encephalitis, pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Polio - eradicated in US w/vaccine (Etiology: summer mos, most have no sx; Sx: fever, headache, stiff neck/back, limb pain→ a minority of these develop flacid paralysis of legs, respiratory muscles) more from CDC
      • Rabies (Etiology: bite from infected animal→ skunk, bat, squirrel, dog; incubation can be days to mos→ time to travel along pns to cns; Sx: f, ha, myalgias, arthralgias, hydrophobia, intermitent confusion/agitation, sensitivity to sound/light, pain at bite site, autonomic dysfxn; 20% w/progressive flaccid paralysis, starting near bite; sx onset to death avg 4d) more from CDC
      • Varicella zoster (chicken pox & zoster) (Rfs: rare in kids as vaccine preventable; Sites: skin, lung, brain→ meningitis & encephalitis; Sx: f, fatigue, ha, generalized vesicular erruption, duration 5-10d, can still get mild dz if vax, pneumonia in setting severe chicken pox or immunocomp; also ha, stiff neck, confusion if encephalitis and/or meningitis) CDC
      • West Nile (Etiology: incubation 2d-2w; summer/fall in North America; Site: brain→ meningitis & encephalitis; Sx: fever, muscle aches, confusion, ha, stiff neck, rash, confusion) more from CDC
    • Associated w/derm manifestations
      • Coxsackievirus (enterovirus) (Etiology: myocarditis, pericarditis, erruption on palms/soles; Sx: w/cardiac involvement chest pain, sob; in kids f, malaise, vessicles in mouth and hands and soles) More from CDC
      • Herpes simplex oral/genital infxn (Etiology: primary infxn sometimes assoc w/fever; Sites: genital, oral; Rfs: passed by sexual or oral contact; Sx/PE: acute, painful, genital or oral area vesicles, adenopathy) more from CDC
      • HPV (Sites/Sx: painless growth in genital or rectal areas, spread sexually, years later causes cervical cancer, head/neck scc, penile scc; PE: clustered growths, genital warts, peri-anal warts) more from CDC
      • Parvo (Rfs: most common ages 5-19, Sx/PE: slapped cheek rash, also rash on arms, soles, palms; acute arthralgias/arthritis that can mimic RA; can cause acute hypoprolif anemia) CDC
      • Measels (rubeola) (Etiology: spread thru resp droplets, highly contagious; Rfs: too young to be vaccinated (<1y), or never vaccinated; winter/spring in US; Sx: incubation 7-14d; cough, high f, malaise; rash 4-5d after sx onset; PE: conjunctivitis, runny nose, then white (Koplick's) spots on oral mucosa, then rash; complications include encephalitis, pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Rubella (German measels) (Rfs: uncommon w/vaccination, spread via resp droplets; Sx: incubation ~14d; often prodrome 1-4d of malaise, fever, nasal congestion; rash starts on face and spreads; auricular/occipital adenopathy common; can be congenitally acquired)
      • Varicella zoster (chicken pox & zoster) (Rfs: rare in kids as vaccine preventable; Sites: skin, lung, brain→ meningitis & encephalitis; Sx: f, fatigue, ha, generalized vesicular erruption, duration 5-10d, can still get mild dz if vax, pneumonia in setting severe chicken pox or immunocomp; also ha, stiff neck, confusion if encephalitis and/or meningitis) CDC
    • Associated w/MSK manifestations
      • CMV (Sx/PE: retinitis/colitis/disseminated dz in patients w/HIV; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w, then f, c, malaise hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, fatigue x 4-6w; head/neck adenopathy & pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC
      • Chikungunya (RFs: travel to Carribean, mosquitoe bite; Sx: fever, symmetric arthralgia, inflammatory arthritis wrists, fingers, ankles; muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash; onset 3-7d after bite; usually last days to weeks, sometimes mos) more from CDC
      • Dengue (Etiology: spread by aedes aegypti mosquito; RFs: exposure in tropics, SE Asia, Carribean, South America; Sx: incubation 4-7d, abrupt onset high fever, aches, retro-orbital pain, bone/muscle/joint pain, often low back pain, maculo-pap rash; sx resolve in 3-4d; can recur) more from CDC
      • Ebola (Etiology: spread via close human contact, bats as reservoir; RFs: travel to West Africa or exposure to someone at risk, spread via contact w/body fluids of infected person; Sx: incubation of up to 3w; high fever, fatigue, aches→ 0-3d; epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, arthralgias, myalgias, sorethroat, chest pain, headaches, delirium, conjunctival injection→ 3-10d; severe illness, shock, GI hemorrhage or other complications, death or recovery→ 7-12d) more from CDC
      • EBV (mononucleosis) (Rfs: spread by direct contact→ kissing, shared drinking glasses, shared toothbrushes, etc; Sx: incubation 4-6w, prodrome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias, then f, sore throat; PE: maculo-pap rash after amox or other abx, head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly) more from CDC
      • Enterovirus (non-polio) (Etiology: passed fecal-oral, close contact, ingesting infected water; Site: brain→ meningitis & encephalitis, oral mucosa and skin→ hand/foot/mouth dz, heart→ myocarditis and pericarditis; conjunctiva→ conjunctivitits; upper resp tract; Sx: most have mild illness; w/more severe dz→ fever, ha, cough, runny nose, muscle aches, confusion) more from CDC
      • Hep B (acute)(RFs: spread via sexual contact, vertical, shared needles, needle sticks in health care workers, unscreened blood transfusion; Sx: many are asx; incubation is 1-4m; acute infxn assoc w/n, v, jaundice; puritus, icterus, dark urine, light colored stool, malaise; typically self limited, w/resoln sx 2-3m; a minority develop symetric inflammatory arthritis of MCPs, PIP, knees, ankles; resoves in few weeks; PE: jaundice, icterus, RUQ pain, hepatomegaly, symetric inflammatory arthritis)
      • Influenza (Etiology: common cause upper and lower respiratory infection; Rfs: seasonal in North America Oct to April, increase risk amongst old, young, pregnant, chronic lung disease, any chronic illness, no vaccination; Sx: abrupt onset of myalgias, arthralgias, fever, chills) more from CDC
      • Parvo (Sx: acute, febrile illness in ages 5-19, runny nose, headache PE: skin erruption w/slapped cheek appearance, also rash on arms, soles, palms; sometimes symetric inflammatory arthritis can mimic RA; can cause acute hypoprolif anemia) more from CDC
      • West Nile (Etiology: incubation 2d-2w; summer/fall in North America; Site: brain→ meningitis & encephalitis; Sx: fever, muscle aches, confusion, ha, stiff neck, rash, confusion) more from CDC
    • Associated w/f, c, aches, fatigue
      • Chikungunya (RFs: travel to Carribean, mosquitoe bite; Sx: fever, symmetric arthralgia, inflammatory arthritis wrists, fingers, ankles; muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash; onset 3-7d after bite; usually last days to weeks, sometimes mos) more from CDC
      • CMV (Sx/PE: retinitis/colitis/disseminated dz in patients w/HIV; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w, then f, c, malaise hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, fatigue x 4-6w; head/neck adenopathy & pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC
      • Dengue (Etiology: spread by aedes aegypti mosquito; RFs: exposure in tropics, SE Asia, Carribean, South America; Sx: incubation 4-7d, abrupt onset high fever, aches, retro-orbital pain, bone/muscle/joint pain, often low back pain, maculo-pap rash; sx resolve in 3-4d; can recur) more from CDC
      • Ebola (Etiology: spread via close human contact, bats as reservoir; RFs: travel to West Africa or exposure to someone at risk, spread via contact w/body fluids of infected person; Sx: incubation of up to 3w; high fever, fatigue, aches→ 0-3d; epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, arthralgias, myalgias, sorethroat, chest pain, headaches, delirium, conjunctival injection→ 3-10d; severe illness, shock, GI hemorrhage or other complications, death or recovery→ 7-12d) more from CDC
      • EBV (mononucleosis) (Rfs: spread by direct contact→ kissing, shared drinking glasses, shared toothbrushes, etc; Sites: pharynx, spleen, rarely brain and/or meninges; Sx: incubation 4-6w, prodrome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias, then f, sorethroat; PE: maculo-pap rash after amox or other abx, head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly; confusion, ha, f, deficits if CNS involvement) more from CDC
    • Associated w/other organ involvement: parotid, testicular, pericardial/myocardial
      • Coxsackievirus (Sites: myocarditis, pericarditis, palms/soles; Sx: w/cardiac involvement chest pain, sob; in kids f, malaise, vessicles in mouth and hands and soles) More from CDC
      • Mumps (Etiology: uncommon w/vaccination; Sx: f, myalgia, malaise, affects B parotids and testicles) More from CDC

      Systemic Fungal

      • Aspergillus (Rfs: lung dz assoc w/immunocompromised host and/or w/structual lung dz→ e.g. bronchiectasis; Sites: lungs→ can be tissue invasive or chronic (e.g. fungal ball); sinuses, skin, other; Sx: can be indolent or acute; cough, sob, wt loss, cp, fatigue, hemoptysis; facial fullness/pain, nasal d/c→ invasive sinusitis in patients w/DM or otherwise compromised)
      • Candida (Rfs: compromised host→ HIV, chemo, steroids, long term abx w/indwelling lines, TPN use, long ICU stays; Sx: fevers, sytemic sx/sepsis)
      • Coccidioidomycosis (Etiology: south west US, higher risk if immune-compromised Site: lung parenchyma and pleural space, joints, skin; Sx: sub-acute sob also arthritis, PE: inflammatory arthritis, skin nodules, seeding of other sites)
      • Histoplasmosis (Sites; lungs, liver, spleen, mouth, systemic; Rfs: exposure to Mississippi & Ohio river valley, HIV+; Sx: can be asx/mild and resolve spont; often see x-ray evidence prior infection lung, spleen w/o known past infxn; cough, fever; can cause resp/systemic illness, oral ulcers in HIV+)
      • Mucor (Sites: lung→ pneumonia, sinuses→ invasive sinusitis; Rf: DM or otherwise compromised; PE: cough, fever, HA, sinus pain)
      • Pneumocystis jerovecii (Sites: lung; Rfs: HIV + and cd4 < 200, prolonged steroid use; Sx: cough, f, sob pneumonia)
      • Cryptococcus (neoformans) (Sites: cns, lungs, skin; Rfs: assoc w/immunocompromised, CD4 < 50 or untreated HIV; Sx: CNS disease→ sub-acute headache, fever, confusion; pulmonary→ subacute cough, sob, chest pain, f)
      • Cryptococcus (gattii) (Sites: lungs, skin, cns; Rfs: found on West coast/Pacific Northwest; can cause pneumonia in normal hosts; can also infect those w/HIV and advance t-cell deficiencincy states; Sx: subacute cough, sob, chest pain, f; CNS sx of subacute confusion, ha)
      • More on fungi from CDC

      Mycobacteria

      • M Tuberculosis (MTB) (RFs: HIV +, ETOh, chronic kidney, liver, lung dz; dialysis, homeless, immunocompromised for other reason→ steroid, TNF inhibitors, other; though can occur in anyone, reactivating sometimes years after initial exposure; extra-pulm TB increases in HIV+ w/CD4 < 350; Sx: sub-acute, cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, sweats, fatigue; can also infect GI/GU tracts, pericardium, bones, cns, lymph nodes or become widely disseminated) more from CDC
      • Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC)(Rfs: HIV + w/CD4 < 50→ disseminated dz; bronchiectasis for lung sx; Sx: diarrhea in HIV +; persistent/progressive lung infection in patients with bronchiectasis) more from CDC
      • Mycobacterium avium intracellulare (MAI) (Rfs: HIV +, CD4 < 50; Sx: diarrhea, n, v, abdominal pain, f, c, fatigue; can infect liver, spleen, lymph nodes, bone marrow, lung, pericardium→ causing adenopathy or organomegaly, anemia)
      • M Kansii (Rfs: immunocompromised, broanchiectasis or other chronic lung dz; Sx: similar to M Tb w/subacute cough, fever, heomptysis, sob)

      Retrovirus (HIV)

      • HIV (Etiology/Rfs: hiv risk factors→ men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; risks of unusual infection increase as CD4 declines; Sx: acute infection→ fever, chills, sweats, adenopathy, rash, pharyngitis w/in 2-4 weeks - then resolves; latency until sx develop 6-10y after initial infxn (if not treated) related to drop in CD4: generalized sx include f, c, cough, wt loss; other illnesses: mucosal candidiasis; fungal, mtb lung infection; persistent diarrhea; CNS toxo; non hodgkins lymphoma; kaposis sarcoma of skin, adenopathy, etc) more from CDC

      Spirochetes

      • Borrelia burgdorferi (lyme) (Etiology: tick borne, endemic area north east, upper mid west, tick contact x 24-48h; incubation days to weeks; Sx: rash, f, c, aches; then arthralgias, heart block, CNS involvement; later still arthritis; can co-infect w/organisms causing babesiosis and anaplasmosis) more from CDC
      • Borrelia miyamotoi (Etiology: tick borne, endemic area north east, summer mos; Sx: f, c, headache, arthralgias, myalgias, malaise/fatigue; PE: often ill appearing, sometimes faint lacy rash) more from CDC
      • Borrelia - other sp (relapsing fever) (Etiology: tick borne, mountainous US→ West/Southwest, plateau of Mexico, South America; fever x ~3d→ then fever free x 1w→ then recurs; chills, ha, muscle aches, n, photophobia, joint aches, confusion; PE: non-specific; sometimes conj injection, confusion, mac-pap rash)
      • Leptospirosis (Etiology: contract via exposure to rodent/wild animal feces; incubation period several weeks; Sx/PE: mild dz is self limited f, c, ha, n, v, muscle aches, conjunctival injection; severe dz with hepatic and renal involvement, pulmonary hemorrhage, andicterus) CDC
      • Syphillis (Rfs: sexual exposure, Etiology/Sx/PE: primary, secondary and tertiary manifestations; primary infection causes painless genital ulcer, ~3w after exposure → heals 4-6w, regional adenopathy; secondary manifestations weeks to mos later w/non-specific rash, predilection for palms, and soles; condyloma around genital areas, mucous involvement, generalized adenopathy, f, sweats, eyes→ iritis/uveitis; tertiary manifestations yrs later affecting CNS→ numbness, weakness, balance problems, dementia; large blood vessels→ aortitis, aneurysm) More from CDC

      Rickettsiae

      Obligate intracellular gram negative bacteria which are spread by tick, mite, flea, louse, or chiggers.
      • Anaplasmosis (Etiology: tick born, incubation 1-2w, Midwest and Eastern US; can co-infect w/organisms causing Lyme and basesiosis; Sx: f, ha, n, v, myalgias; often causes BM suppression)
      • Human ehrlichiosis (Etiology: tick borne, incubation 1-2w, endemic South Eastern, South Central and Eastern US; similar presentation to anaplasmosis; Sx: f, ha, n, v, myalgias; often causes BM suppression)
      • Rocky Mtn Spotted Fever (Etiology: tick borne, incubation 2d to 2w; can occur in most states in US, Sx: f, c, ha, arthralgias, then generalized rash - though not always, can be severe/fatal)
      • Coxiella Burnetti (Q fever: Rickettsia-like) (Etiology: spread from cattle and sheep, incubation 5d-2w; Sx: fever, chills, severe ha, myalgias, malaise, cough, abd pain; many recover spont; can cause pneumonia, hepatitis, myocarditis)
      • Typhus (various types) (Etiology: spread via flea, louse or tick, reservoirs often rodents squirrels; summer mos, incubation 1-2w, Central/South America, Asia, Central Africa, tropics; Sx: non-specific f, c, ha, malaise, myalgias; PE: non-specific mac-pap rash, sometimes adenopathy)
      • More on Rickettsiae from CDC

      Parasites

      An organism that lives on or in host and gets its food from or @ expense of its host. Liklihood of infection linked to geographic exposure(s).
    • Associated w/diarrhea & GI sx
      • American Trypanosomiasis (chagas dz - t cruzi) (Etiology: Central and South America, via reduviid bug bite; incubation 1-2w; Sx: most have no acute sx; if acute sx present, can include→ f, c, sweats, malaise, ha, n, v, d x weeks; chronic sx in 20-30%, including: lower esophageal dysmotility; cardiomyopathy→ CHF, dysrhythmia; PE: rare acute findings: skin nodule at bite; eyelid edema)
      • Cryptosporidia (Rfs: young/old/immunocomp at greatest risk, spread fecal oral, assoc w/daycare center outbreaks; Sx: n, v, diarrhea, cramps, fever)
      • Entamoeba histolytica→ amebiasis (protozoa) (Etiology: acquired via unclean water/poor sanitation, also anal intercourse; Sx: only 10-20% develop sx; incubation 2-4w; abd pain, bloody diarreha; occas liver abscess)
      • Schistosomiasis (fluke) (Etiology: South America, Middle East, Caribbean, Africa: flukes, invade skin of swimmers, enter blood stream→ live in portal/mesenteric veins; Sx: can cause cirrhosis after years; also f, c, abd pain, diarrhea; can live in bladder → SCC after years)
      • Trichinella (roundworm) (Etiology: rare in US; from eating infected meat; Sx: abd pain, n, v, diarrhea; after 1-2w, f, muscle pain when migrate to muscles, rash, ha, n, v, itching)
    • Assoc w/hepato-biliary sx
      • Entamoeba histolytica→ amebiasis (protozoa) (Etiology: acquired via unclean water/poor sanitation, also anal intercourse; Sx: only 10-20% develop sx; incubation 2-4w; abd pain, bloody diarreha; occas liver abscess)
      • Echinococcus (tapeworm) (Etiology: main host is cattle and dogs; common in US and many other areas; eggs ingested by humans → travel to liver→ Sx: cysts form & can cause RUQ pain→ compress biliary tract → if rupture can cause anaphylaxis)
      • Schistosomiasis (fluke) (Etiology: South America, Middle East, Caribbean, Africa: flukes, invade skin of swimmers, enter blood stream→ live in portal/mesenteric veins; Sx: can cause cirrhosis after years; also f, c, abd pain, diarrhea; can live in bladder → SCC after years)
    • Assoc w/respiratory sx
      • Toxocariasis (aka visceral larva migrans or roundworm) (Etiology: definitive hosts are cats and dogs; humans ingest eggs from dirt→ eggs hatch in intestines→ larvae can travel to lungs, eyes, CNS, liver; Sx: many are asx; can cause cough, f, visual loss, hepatitis)
      • Ascariasis (Etiology: tropics/sub-tropics/SE US, eggs swallowed if contaminated soil ingested (e.g. human feces used as fertilizer)→ eggs hatch in intestines → larvae enter blood stream → migrate lungs → mature & coughed up → swallowed → mature in intestines; Sx: often asx; if heavy worm burden→ cough, f, sob, n, v, abd pain, impaired growth of children, sbo)
      • Strongyloidiasis (Etiology: warm/temperate regions including southeast US, tropics/subtropics including Asia/Southeast Asia; larvae enter thru feet/skin if walk barefoot in soil w/infected feces→ enter skin, where they can cause itching→ travel to lung→ penetrate alveoli and travel up trachea→ cough and then swallowed→ travel to and live in small intestine; Sx: most carry life-long w/o any sx; non-compromised hosts can have vague sx including cough, f, sob, epigastic pain, weakness, watery diarrhea, itching, constipation; can cause life threatening hyper-infxn syndrome w/systemic symptoms if compromised from glucocorticoids, malignancy, HTLV-1 or organ transplant; PE: sometimes serpiginous red erruption from migrating larva under skin)
    • Assoc w/cardiac sx
      • American Trypanosomiasis (chagas dz - t cruzi) (Etiology: Central and South America, via reduviid bug bite; incubation 1-2w; Sx: most have no acute sx; if acute sx present, can include→ f, c, sweats, malaise, ha, n, v, d x weeks; chronic sx in 20-30%, including: lower esophageal dysmotility; cardiomyopathy→ CHF, dysrhythmia; PE: rare acute findings: skin nodule at bite; eyelid edema)
    • Assoc w/f, c, sweats
      • B. microti→ babesiosis (protozoa) (Etiology: tick born, endemic Northeast/Norhtern Mid-west US; can co-infect w/lyme and anaplasmosis; Sx: 1-4 w after infxn; subacute f, c, sweats, HA, muscle aches; in severe cases hemolytic anemia, kidney, liver injury, resp distress)
      • African Trypanosomiasis (t brucei sleeping sickness) (Etiology: Africa, from tsetse fly; Sx: f, c, HA, delirium, muscle and joint aches, death in mos if untreated; PE: chancre→ skin sore at bite site, adenopathy)
      • Leishmaniasis (Kala Azar) (Etiology: spread by sand-fly bite, subtropics; Sx/PE: cutaneous→ sores/ulcers; visceral→ can be silent, or cause fevers, sweats, chills, wt loss, adnenopathy, organomegaly)
      • Malaria (Etiology: spread by anopheles mosquito, tropical climates, in partic Southeast Asia, Africa; variants = P vivax, falciparum, ovale and malariae; Sx: incubation 1-4w; recurrent high fevers, C, HA; mild to life threatening (falciparum))
      • Toxoplasmosis (protozoa) (Etiology: carried in cat feces, healthy hosts not affected, in HIV + causes brain infection cd4 < 200; pregnant women can pass in utero→ congenital abnormalities; Sx: acute f, c, headache, delirium, szr, eye pain and visual loss from retinal involvement)
      • W bancrofti (filariasis) (Rfs/Etiology; tropics/sub-tropics, spread by mosquitoes; Sx: most are asx and wont have sequelae; some will have acute f, c, adenopathy; filaria invade lymphatis, after years→ lymphedema from obstruction of channels; PE: in some, chronic lymphedema)
    • Assoc w/neuro & muscle sx
      • Malaria (Etiology: spread by anopheles mosquito, tropical climates, in partic Southeast Asia, Africa; variants = P vivax, falciparum, ovale and malariae; incubation 1-4w; Sx: recurrent high fevers, C, HA; mild to life threatening (falciparum))
      • Toxoplasmosis (protozoa) (Etiology: carried in cat feces, healthy hosts not affected, in HIV + causes brain infection cd4 < 200; pregnant women can pass in utero→ congenital abnormalities; Sx: acute f, c, headache, delirium, szr)
      • Trichinella (roundworm) (Etiology: rare in US; from eating infected meat; Sx: abd pain, n, v, diarrhea; after 1-2w, f, muscle pain when migrate to muscles, rash, ha, n, v, itching)
    • Assoc w/eye sx
      • Toxoplasmosis (protozoa) (Etiology: carried in cat feces, healthy hosts not affected, in HIV + causes brain infection cd4 < 200; pregnant women can pass in utero→ congenital abnormalities; Sx: acute f, c, headache, delirium, szr, eye pain and visual loss from retinal involvement)
    • Assoc w/lymph edema
      • W bancrofti (filariasis) (Rfs/Etiology; tropics/sub-tropics, spread by mosquitoes; Sx: most are asx and wont have sequelae; some will have acute f, c, adenopathy; filaria invade lymphatics, after years→ lymphedema from obstruction of channels; PE: in some, chronic lymphedema)
    • Assoc w/cutaneous sx
      • Leishmaniasis (Kala Azar) (Etiology: spread by sand-fly bite, subtropics; Sx/PE: cutaneous→ sores/ulcers; visceral→ can be silent, or cause fevers, sweats, chills, wt loss, adnenopathy, organomegaly)
      CDC: parasites

      Infxn by Organ Syst

      Eye

      Ext Structures

      • Blepharitis (Sx/Pe: redness along eye-lid margins, itchy, no visual loss)
      • Hordeolum (stye) (Sx: acute/sub-acute, discomfort, preserved vision; PE: red bump, focal redness)
      • Dacrocystitis (Rfs: much more common in children; Sx/PE: acute pain and redness over medial lower lid where tears drain, acute, no visual loss, unilateral)

      Globe/Periglobe

      • Orbital cellulitis (Rf: infected sinuses→ ethmoid; Sx: acute pain, worse w/eye movement, loss of vision; PE: diffuse redness, proptosis)
      • Pre-septal cellulitis (Sx: acute, red, painful skin, though eye itself w/o pain, preserved vision, full mobility; PE: red, edematous skin around eye)

      Conjunctiva

      • Viral (Etiology: adeno, other; Sx: acute, redness of conjunctiva, URI sx, watery discharge, no visual change, uni- or bilateral, gritty sensation; PE: diffuse redness, often clear d/c)
        • Adeno (Etiology/Site: cause of upper respiratory infxn→ common cold, conjunctivitis, otitis media; Sx: cough, nasal congestion, sore throat, ear pain, conjunctival inflamation; much less commonly pneumonia; PE: throat redness, conjunctivitis, anterior auricular adenopathy) more from CDC
        • Enterovirus (non-polio) (Etiology: passed fecal-oral, close contact, ingesting infected water; Site: brain→ meningitis & encephalitis, oral mucosa and skin→ hand/foot/mouth dz, heart→ myocarditis and pericarditis; conjunctiva→ conjunctivitits; upper resp tract; Sx: most have mild illness; w/more severe dz→ fever, ha, cough, runny nose, muscle aches, confusion) more from CDC
        • Measels (rubeola) (Etiology: spread thru resp droplets, highly contagious; Rfs: too young to be vaccinated (<1y), or never vaccinated; winter/spring in US; Sx: incubation 7-14d; cough, high f, malaise; rash 4-5d after sx onset; PE: conjunctivitis, runny nose, then white (Koplick's) spots on oral mucosa, then rash; complications include encephalitis, pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Bacterial (Etiology: staph, h flu, strep, moraxella, neiserria; Sx: acute, red, opaque d/c, itchy/irritated, no visual change, uni- or bilateral; copious d/c if neisseria in partic; PE: diffuse redness of conjunctiva, pus)
        • Chlamydia trachomatis (trachoma) (Etiology: spread thru poor hand hygiene, sharing towels, or via flies, endemic in poor/developing countries, a leading cause blindness world-wide; Sx: chronic, purulent conjunctivitis, can lead to scarring of lid→ inward turned lashes→ scarring of cornea→ blindness) more from CDC
      • More on conjunctivitis from CDC

      Cornea/Ant/Post Chambers

      Cornea, anterior and posterior chambers
      • Keratitis (Etiology: can be bacterial, viral→ hsv, vzv, fungal or parasitic→ onchocerciasis; also from trauma/fb, chemical exposure, or contact lens use; Sx: acute, painful, unilateral visual loss; PE: diffusely red, other findings of herpes zoster in v1 dermatome if that's the cause)
        • Onchocerciasis (worm - river blindness) (Etiology: causes river blindness, Africa/Central & South America; worm spread by black fly bite; Sx: conjunctivits/keratitis→ vision loss, skin nodules)
      • Endopthalmitis (Rfs/Etiology: infection inside the eye, can be complication of trauma, cataract surgery, or seeding from systemic bacteremia; Sx: acute, pain w/any movement, f, loss of vision; PE: diffuse redness, pus in anterior chamber)
      • Iritis/anterior uveitis (Etiology: assoc w/autoimmune dz→ ankylosing spond, sarcoid, reactive arthritis, behcet's dz, IBD; infxn→ HSV, secondary syphillis, VZV, TB; often idiopathic; Sx: acute pain, photophobia, impaired vision; PE: decreased acuity, irreg appearance of pupil, circumferential redness at cornea-sclera junction, sometimes layered pus in anterior chamber→ hypopyon; other systemic manifestations of the primary disease; can have pan-uveitis)
      • Posterior uveitis (Etiology: assoc w/autoimmune dz→ sarcoid, behcet's dz; malignancy→ lymphoma; infxn→ toxo, CMV, brucellosis, HSV, VZV, secondary syphillis, TB; often idiopathic; Sx: decreased vision, pain, photophobia; PE: decreased acuity, may not have external inflammatory findings unless pan-uveitis; other findings assoc w/underlying dz)

      Retina

      • Retinal infection - often HIV or otherwise immuncomp - CMV, toxoplasmosis, endocarditis (PE: retinal exudates/cotton wool spots)
      • Toxocariasis (parasite - aka visceral larva migrans or roundworm) (Etiology: definitive hosts are cats and dogs; humans ingest eggs from dirt→ eggs hatch in intestines→ larvae can travel to lungs, eyes, CNS, liver; Sx: many are asx; can cause cough, fever, visual loss, hepatitis)
      • Toxoplasmosis (protozoa) (Etiology: carried in cat feces, healthy hosts not affected, in HIV + causes brain infection cd4 < 200; pregnant women can pass in utero→ congenital abnormalities; Sx: acute f, c, headache, delirium, szr, eye pain and visual loss from retinal involvement)
      • CMV (virus) (Sx/PE: retinitis, colitis, disseminated dz in patients w/HIV; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w, then f, c, malaise hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, fatigue x 4-6w; head/neck adenopathy & pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC

      Head and Neck

      Mouth/Throat/Neck

      • Acute Pharyngitis: bacterial and viral
        • Grp A, Beta Hemolytic Strep (Sx: acute, fever, pain, absence of cough; PE: exudate & reddness, palpable LN, palatal petechiae) more from CDC
        • Other bacteria (Etiology: Strep Grp B and G)
        • Neisseria gonorrhea (Site: urethra, cervix, uterus, fallopian tubes, testes, pharynx, ano-rectal, joints; Sx: pharyngeal infection often asx, but can cause sore throat; Rfs: oral sexual activity; PE: penile d/c, cervical d/c, cervical pain and uterine pain if PID; pharyngeal inflammation & exudates; anorectal d/c; if disseminated→ pustules, infectious arthritis) more from CDC
        • Diptheria (Site: upper respiratory tract; Sx: cough, f, sore throat, uncommon now w/vax; PE: pseudo-membrane w/airway obstruction) more from CDC
        • EBV→ mono (Sx: acutely painful sore throat, fever→ sometimes prolonged, fatigue, doesn't respond to abx; PE: pharyngeal redness, exudate, and adenopathy; sometimes splenomegaly) more from CDC
        • Other viral (e.g. influenza) (Sx: abrupt onset, high fever, cough, myalgias; other viruses: rhino, adeno, others; PE: red posterior pharynx) More on upper respiratory infections CDC
      • Peri-tonsilar abscess (Sx: acute pain, worse then simple pharyngitis, localizes to one side, problems/pain swallowing, if severe→ airway compreomise; PE: focal swelling in tonsilar area, uvula deviated away)
      • Retro-pharyngeal abscess (Etiology: spread of infxn from adjacent space; Sx: f, c, acute, difficulty swallowing or handling secretions, difficulty speaking, sob; PE: sitting up, drooling, swelling in post pharynx, neck swelling, stridor)
      • Acute HIV (primary infxn) (Rfs: men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/somone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; Sx/PE: throat pain and redness w/o exudate, fevers, chills, non-specific rash, adenopathy)
      • Candida (Rfs: immuno-supressed→ chemo or hiv, abx exposure, steroids; PE: white exudate on mucosa, bleeds when scraped)
      • HSV (Sx: pain can precede appearance, worse if immunocmop, can be recurrent; PE: clear vessicles on red base, small ulcer after uncovered)
      • Epiglotitis (Sx: acute, f, can't swallow, sob, pain in anterior neck; PE: ill appearing, sitting upright, drooling, "hot potato" voice)
      • Lemierre's synd (septic thrombophlebitis of jugular vein) (Etiology: fusobacterium; Sx: starts as sore throat, may improve over few days, then worsens; pain also lateral neck, f, c, sweats, sob/cp if septic pulm emboli, severe illness; PE: febrile, pharyngeal inflamation, warmth and pain over lateral neck)
      • More on sore throats from CDC
      • Dental infection (Sx: acute pain, localized to affected tooth or adjacent tissue if spreading; PE: gingival swelling; pain reproduced when tooth is tapped)
      • Syphilis (Rfs: men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/somone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's; PE: other findings assoc w/secondary syphillis including: non-specific rash, w/predilection for palms, and soles; hx painless genital ulcer from primary infxn)
      • Histoplasmosis (Sites; lungs, liver, spleen, mouth, systemic; Rfs: exposure to Mississippi & Ohio river valley, HIV+; Sx: can be asx/mild and resolve spont; often see x-ray evidence prior infection lung, spleen w/o known past infxn; cough, fever; can cause resp/systemic illness, oral ulcers in HIV+)
      • Ludwig's Angina (submandibular space infection) (Etiology: typically starts as dental infection, spreads to submandibular space; Sx: acute, neck/submandibular area pain and swelling in submandibular area, f, difficulty swallowing, drooling, airway compromise; PE: f, ill appearing, sitting up, foul breath, diffiuclty opening mouth, acute & painful submandibular swelling, indurated and red skin, sometimes co-existent dental infection)

      Adenop (infxn)

      Adenopathy related to infections
      • Bacterial
        • Staph (Sites: direct skin infection; Sx: fever, pain/swelling at primary as well as affected lymph nodes; PE: redness, warmth, induration, fluctuance)
        • Streptococcus: Group A (Sites: associated w/pharyngitis or direct infection of LN; PE: strep throat→ pharyngeal erythema, d/c, adenop, LNs warm, tender, enlarged) more from CDC
        • Primary dental or other oral infection (Etiology: adenopathy reflects local spread from primary site in mouth/teeth; PE: focus of infection identified in mouth; lymph nodes warm, tender, swollen)
        • Bartonella henslae (cat scratch) (Sites: skin and lymph nodes; Rfs/Etiology: caused by cat scratch; Sx: may see inflamation at innoculation site, then tender regional adenopathy w/in few weeks, fatigue, fever) more from CDC
        • Brucella (Sites: systemic; Etiology: ingestion of raw/uncooked dairy or handling infected animals; Rfs: veterinarians, meat packers, slaughter house workers, farmers; Middle East, Mediterranean, Mexico, Africa; Sx/PE: causes weeks/months of recurrent f, c, sweats, arthritis, adenopathy, orchitis, hepato-splenomegaly) more from CDC
        • Francisella tularensis (tularemia) (Sites: skin, lymph nodes; Etiology/Rfs: passed from dying wild animals to humans via ticks/insects, US Southeast and Rocky Mtns; Sx: f, c, ha, oral or skin ulcers, painful adenopathy, sob, muscle aches) more from CDC
      • Viral and retroviral
        • HIV (Etiology/Rfs: hiv risk factors→ men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; risks of unusual infection increase as CD4 declines; Sx: acute infection→ fever, chills, sweats, adenopathy, rash, pharyngitis w/in 2-4 weeks - then resolves; latency until sx develop 6-10y after initial infxn (if not treated) related to drop in CD4: generalized sx include f, c, cough, wt loss; other illnesses: mucosal candidiasis; fungal, mtb lung infection; persistent diarrhea; CNS toxo; non hodgkins lymphoma; kaposis sarcoma of skin, adenopathy, etc) more from CDC
        • CMV (Sx/PE: retinitis, colitis, disseminated dz in patients w/HIV; systemic infection in patients 1-4m s/p transplant; normal hosts get mono-like symptoms: incubation 3-8 w, then f, c, malaise hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, fatigue x 4-6w; head/neck adenopathy & pharyngitis are rare) more from CDC
        • EBV (mononucleosis) (Rfs: spread by direct contact→ kissing, shared drinking glasses, shared toothbrushes, etc; Sx: incubation 4-6w, prodrome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias, then f, sore thorat; PE: maculo-pap rash after amox or other abx, head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly) more from CDC
        • Herpes simplex oral infxn (Etiology: primary infxn sometimes assoc w/fever; Sites: oral; Rfs: passed by sexual or oral contact; Sx/PE: acute, painful, genital or oral area vesicles, inguinal adenopathy) more from CDC
        • Other viral resp infxn
      • Mycobacterial
        • M tuberculosis (MTB) (RFs: HIV +, steroids, chronic kidney, liver or lung dz; ivdu, from enedemic area, healthcare worker, otherwise immunocomp; extra-pulm TB increases in HIV+ w/CD4 < 350; Sx: sub-acute, cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, sweats, fatigue; can also infect GI/GU tracts; adenopathy most commonly head/neck→ scrofula) more from CDC
      • Fungal
        • Tinea capitis (Sx/PE: scaly, inflamed, raised, well defined patch(es) on scalp, associated w/focal hair loss, adenopathy occipital region of scalp)
      • Spirochete
        • Syphillis (Rfs: sexual exposure, Etiology/Sx/PE: primary, secondary and tertiary manifestations; primary infection causes painless genital ulcer, ~3w after exposure → heals 4-6w, regional adenopathy; secondary manifestations weeks to mos later w/non-specific rash, predilection for palms, and soles; condyloma around genital areas, mucous involvement, generalized adenopathy, f, sweats, eyes→ iritis/uveitis; tertiary manifestations yrs later affecting CNS→ numbness, weakness, balance problems, dementia; large blood vessels→ aortitis, aneurysm) More from CDC

      Ear related

      • Middle ear infection→ otitis media (Etiology: bacterial or viral; Sx: acute ear pain, muffled hearing, other uri sx→ cough, nasal congestion, fever; PE: evidence effusion behind ear drum; favoring bacterial→ drum red, opaque, bulging)
      • OM associated perforation (Sx: pain may lessen after perf, discharge, decrease in hearing on affected side, can taste liquid dripping down throat if use topical ear drops, can hear air moving thru perf if pinch nose & valsalva; PE: perforation of TM)
      • Otitis externa (Sx: acute, painful, d/c; PE: d/c from external canal, swelling of affected area, pain on palpation of tragus)
      • Otitis externa maligna (Etiology: pseudomonal infxn assoc w/poorly controled diabetes; Sx: acute, painful, necrotizing infection of ear, cartilege; can spread to adbjacent bone, mastoids; brain; PE: febrile, ill, diffuse pain, edema, erythema of ear and sometimes adjacent tissues)
      • Ear cellulitis (Rfs: can start from otitis externa or trauma/injury to ear; Sx: acute swelling, pain of ear/surrounding skin, redness/edema of skin)
      • Mastoiditis (Rfs: a site of spread from complicated otitis media; Sx: acute pain, swelling of mastoid→ posterior and inferior to ear; PE: pain on palpation of mastoid, red, warm, induration)

      Nose & Sinuses

      • Viral (Sx: acute, cough, colored d/c, self limited; PE: pain upon precussion of sinuses, post nasal drip evident on pharynx)
      • Bacterial (Sx: acute, cough, persistent, colored d/c, fever, tooth or facial pain; PE: pain upon precussion of sinuses, post nasal drip evident on pharynx, tooth pain if tapped, no transillumination)
      • Fungal (Etiology: mucor or aspergillous; overall uncommon; Sx: persistent facial pain, fever, congestion in compromised hosts→ older, diabetes; can lead to severe illness as these organisms are invasive)
      • More on sinus infxns from CDC

      Pulmonary

      Upper airway

      • Peri-tonsilar abscess (acute pain, worse then simple pharyngitis, localizes to one side, problems/pain swallowing, if severe→ airway compromise; PE: focal swelling in tonsilar area, uvula deviated away)
      • Epiglotitis (Sx: acute, f, can't swallow, sob, pain in anterior neck; Pe: ill appearing. sitting upright, drooling, "hot potato" voice)
      • Pertussis (Bordatella Pertussis) (Etiology: bacterial; Site: upper airwary; Rfs/Etiology: easily spread; vax of kids and re-vax of adults preventive; kids can have airway compromise due to small size; incubation avg 7-10d; Sx: catarrhal stage 1-2w→ cold sx, sometimes low grade T; then paroxysmal stage→ characteristic whooping cough, post-tussive vomiting; then convaslescent stage→ adults present w/persistent cough x 6-10 weeks) more from CDC
      • Other infection of the mouth/neck that can compromise airway

      Pneumonia

      Pneumonia (Common Sx: acute or sub-acute onset, cough, sob, doe, colored sputum production, fever, chest pain, cxr w/infiltrate; PE: rales, ronchi, wheezing or other findings on auscultation, dullness to percussion if pleural effusion or dense parenchymal involvement) Several scoring systems useful to gague severity: CURB 65 and PSI
    • Bacterial
      • Streptococcus Pneumoniae (pneumococcus) (Etiology: common cause of CAP; Sites: pneumonia, upper respiratory infections, meningitis; bacteremia if severe; Rfs: s/p splenectomy or fxnl asplenia, eldery and very young, any chronic medical condition→ copd, liver or renal dz, chf, cancer, diabetes, HIV, or otherwise immunocompromised; also csf leaks, cochlear implants; decreased risk if vaccinated; Sx: abrupt onset cough, sob, f, c, rusty-colored sputum prod) more from CDC
      • Haemophilus influenza (Etiology: common cause of CAP; Sites: upper and lower respiratory tract, cns; RFs: much less common since widespread use of vaccine; increased risk s/p splenectomy; Sites: pneumonia, otitis media, epiglottitis, meningitis) more from CDC
      • Mycoplasma pneumoniae (Etiology: common cause CAP; also upper resp tract infxn; Sx: acute f, c, cough, upper resp sx; not usually severe) more from CDC
      • Legionella (Etiology: common cause of CPA; Rfs: acquired via inhalation; grows in colonized water collection systems, cooling towers, nebs, whirlpools, etc; can be hospital acquired if water contaminated; Site: lung; Sx: acute cough, sputum, f, c, d, confusion) more from CDC
      • Moraxella (Etiology: common cause of CAP w/COPD; Sites: otitis media; conjunctiva; bronchitis in copd exacerbation; lung; Sx: cough, sob, f, sputum)
      • Francisella tularensis (tularemia) (Etiology: uncommon cause CAP, inhaled w/incubation 2-6d; Rfs: passed from dying wild animals to humans via ticks/insects, US Southeast and Rocky Mtns; Sites: skin, lymph nodes, lung→ inhaled w/incucation 2-6d, uncommon cause pna; Sx: f, c, ha, oral or skin ulcers, painful adenopathy, cough, sob, muscle aches) more from CDC
      • Yersinia pestis (plague) (Etiology: uncommon cause CAP; Site: respiratory tract; Rfs: passed from rodents to humans by fleas, direct contact w/feces, or respiratory droplets; Sx: rapid onset f, c, sepsis, pneumonia) more from CDC
      • Chlamydia pneumoniae (Etiology: uncommon cause of CAP; Site: upper resp tract and lung; Sx: sore throat, fever, non-productive cough) more from CDC
      • Chlamydia psittaci (psitacosis) (Etiology: uncommon cause CAP, spread by exposure to parrots & sometimes other birds; Site: lung; Sx: 1-2 week incubation; fever, cough, severe HA; other organ systems as well) more from CDC
      • Staph aureus: coag + (Etiology: uncommon cause CAP; pneumonia following viral infection; can be rapid and necrotizing)
