      • Reactive arthritis (Etiology: occurs weeks following chlamydia GU infection or bacterial gastroenteritis; Sx: low back/SI joint pain, sometimes radiates to buttocks, progressive; PE: asymmetric inflammatory arthritis, typically one or a few joints→ knees, ankles, wrists in partic; lbp/SI area pain w/AM stiffness and muscle aches; eye sx→conjunctivits, iritis; dysuria; oral ulcers; pain at tendon insertions→ enthesitis, digit swelling→ dactylitis)

      Highly morbid causes

      Often associated w/red flags for infxn, fx, cancer, etc: onset sx > 50, unremitting pain, neuro deficits, doesn't improve w/rest, chronic steroid use, hx osteoporosis, fever, trauma, cancer, wt loss, > 6 weeks duration, in particular if progressive, change in quality/severity if chronic LBP
      • Fracture (Sx: trauma/mechanism of injury that could cause fx, hx osteoporosis, hx steroid use, age > 50; PE: pain on palpation over fx site, deficits if nerves/cord affected)
      • Cancer (Etiology: known cancer with prediection for mets to spine→ prostate, lung, breast, hiv+→ aggressive NHL; if not known to have cancer prior, then assess for symptoms suggestive of primary somewhere; Sx: progressive, severe, unremitting pain, wt loss, sx related to primary PE: sometimes pain on palpation, neuro deficits based on structures affected)
      • Infection: osteomyelitis/discitis (Rfs: compromised host, ivdu, dm, esrd, etc; Sx: acute, subacute, or chronic, progressive pain, fever; site of pain based on area of spine affected; spread can lead to epidural or psoas abscess→ thigh pain, worse w/passive extension @ hip; PE: may have pain over affected vertebrae, neuro deficits if cord or roots compromised)
        • Bacterial (Etiology: Staph most common; then e coli; can be the result of hematogenous seeding from bacteremia, endocarditis; or direct extension from superficial skin process, instrumentation, surgery, foley catheter, uti)
        • Mycobacterial (Etiology/Rfs: complication of systemic TB, often compromised host, sometimes known TB elsewhere; Sx: sub-acute/chronic lbp, f, c, chronic, sx related to tb elsewhere→ lungs, GI)
        • Fungal (Etiology: aspergillous, cocci, other; Rfs: compromised host or complication of an injection; Sx: subacute pain, f)
      • Infection: epidural abscess (Rfs: often compromised from dm, etoh, ivdu, other; Etiology: hematogenous seeding from systemic bacteremia, as w/endocarditis; or direct extension from adjacent osteomyelitis, discitis, instrumentation, surgery; Sx: progressive acute/subacute pain, fever, neuro compromise→ numbness, weakness, bowel/bladder sx w/distribution based on area of spine affeceted)
        • Bacterial (Etiology: Staph most common; then e coli; can be the result of hematogenous seeding from bacteremia, endocarditis; or direct extension from superficial skin process, instrumentation, surgery, foley catheter/uti)
        • Mycobacterial (Etiology/Rfs: complication of systemic TB, often compromised host, sometimes known TB elsewhere; Sx: sub-acute/chronic progressive lbp, f, c, numbness, weakness, bowel/bladder sx)
        • Fungal (Etiology: aspergillous, cocci, other; Rfs: compromised host or complication of an injection; Sx: subacute, progressive pain, numbenss, weakness, bowel/bladder sx)
      • Cauda equina (Etiology: occurs secondary to compression from fx, disc herniation, infection, tumor; Sx: acute/sub-acute pain, bowel and/or bladder incontinence; PE: saddle distribution numbness; weakness and numbness of legs, decreased or absent rectal tone, high post void residual)

      Referred pain

      • Abdominal Aneurysm (Rfs: age > 50, C/V RFs, smoker, male; Sx: abd pain w/radiation to back, can be vague; PE: if obese → non-specific abd pain on palpation; if thin, might be able to feel the aneurysm; severe VS abnormality from bleeding and hypovolemia if rupture)
      • Renal stone (Sx: acute, severe, colicky pain, radiates towards abd/pv, can't find comfortable position, hematuria, urinary urgency)
      • Renal infection (pyelonephritis) (Sx: acute low back pain, f, c, n, v; dysuria, urinary frequency/urgency if concomitant cystitis; PE: f, cvat)
      • Posterior duodenal ulcer (Sx: severe, acute, boring/gnawing pain that radiates from epigastrium to back, n; PE: non-specific pain on palpation epigastrium)
      • Pancreatitis (Etiology: ETOH abuse, gall stones; Sx: acute epigastric pain radiating to back, n, v; PE: pain on palpation epgastrium)
      • Endocarditis (Rfs: abnormal/prosthetic valves, IVDU, bacteremia for any reason; Sx: fevers, sweats, feeling poorly)
      • Viral syndromes

      Chronic

      Focal LBP

      • Osteoarthritis/non-specific LBP(Sx: can be slowly progressive with periodic acute exacerbation, qualitatively consistent; precise etiology often hard to pin down→ assoc w/bones/ligaments/muscle of back; no red flags; PE: no specific findings on exam, obesity can exacerbate progression; sometimes hx prior injury or surgery)
      • Spondylolisthesis (slippage of one vert anterior relative to another) (Sx: progressive lbp, more common in adolescents/young adults, pain is focal w/o radiation, sx similar to OA, can contribute to spinal stenosis, worse w/activity and better w/rest; PE: pain sometimes worse on palpation over affected area)
      • Sacro-Iliac arthritis (Etiology: assoc w/spondyloarthopathies, osteoarthritis, trauma; Sx: pain w/wt bearing, better w/rest, slowly progressive, sometimes radiates to buttocks; PE: pain focused over SI area; no deificts or other findings)
      • Spondyloarthroathies (Sx: onset 20s, stiffness worse in AM, better with activity, progressively limited range of motion, PE: sometimes swelling of fingers→ dactylitis, other joint pain, eye findings c/w iritis, pain at tendon insertions→ enthesitis)
        • IBD associated(Rfs: known IBD; Sx: if not known to have IBD, then concomitant GI sx abd pain, diarrhea, cramps, bloody stools, wt loss)
        • Ankylosing Spondylitis (Sx: slow/insidious onset pain, progressive loss of ROM as bones fuse, radiation of pain into buttocks; PE: pain over SI joints, miminal change in distance from one vert spine to adjacent when bend)
        • Psoriatic arthristis assoc (Sx: hx psoriasis, pain and swelling, tendency to affect multiple peripheral joints: PE: red, warm, pain w/movement of joint, skin findings of psoriasis)

      Radiating pain

      • Nerve root irritation (vast majority are L5 or S1) (Etiology; herniated disc, osteophytes or both irritating nerve root; less commonly→ infection, tumor other; Sx: waxes/wanes, typically radiates down one leg below knee)
        • L2 (Sx: radiates from back to upper leg; PE: if sensory deficits→ lateral and anterior upper thigh; if weakness: quadriceps→ knee extension, psoas→ hip flexor)
        • L3 (Sx: radiates from back to upper leg; PE: if sensory deficits→ lower medial thigh; if weakness: quadriceps→ knee extension, psoas→ hip flexor; if reflexes affected→ impaired patellar)
        • L4 (Sx: radiates from back to below knee; PE: if sensory deficits→ medial aspect lower leg; if weakness→ quadriceps→ knee extension; if reflexes affected→ impaired patellar)
        • L5 (Sx: radiates from back to below knee; PE: if disc related: straight leg raise sensitive, crossed leg raise specific; if sensory deficits→ numbness top of foot; if weakness→ foot inversion, great toe extension)
        • S1 (Sx: radiates from back to below knee; PE: if disc related: straight leg raise sensitive, crossed leg raise specific; if sensory deficits→ lateral aspect of foot; if weakness→ impaired plantar flexion; if relex affected→ impaired achilles)
      • Spinal stenosis (Sx: slowly progressive, worse standing, radiates down B legs w/walking, feels better if walk while leaning forward→ e.g. while pushing a shopping cart)
      • Pyriformis syndrome (Etiology: compression of sciatic by pyriformis muscle; Sx: pain in lateral buttocks area radiating to back of thigh; PE: pain exacerbated by internal rotation of hip, deep palpation over pyriformis→ lateral to sacrum)
      • Herpes zoster (Sx: post-herpetic neuralgia following zoster; PE: prior dermatomal, vessicular erruption, w/chronic pain→ skin findings no longer present)

      Highly morbid causes

      • Can cause chronic pain - though dx typically made in acute phase; sx are progressive & severe

      Leg pain?

    • Try to identify whether symptoms further localize: low back, hip, knee, foot, ankle, or other specific area of leg as origin?
    • For bilateral edema, look under 'Cardiovascular' section

      • Acute inflammatory pain

      • Cellulitis (Sx: acute redness, pain, fever; PE: red, tender, focal edema)
      • Necrotizing fasciitis (Etiology: relatively uncommon; assoc w/dm, impaired immunity or perfusion; typically polymicrobial: strep, staph, clostridium, other; Sx: acute pain, swelling, fever, toxic appearing, often rapidly progressive; PE: typically abnl vs consistent w/severe illness, skin findings sometimes subtle→ redness, dusky discoloration, bulla; more profound findings as dz progresses) LRINEC Score
      • Diabetic muscular infarct (Etiology: related to small vessel infarct in leg→ typically patient w/DM; Sx: acute pain, swelling; PE: non-specific→ may have redness)
      • Pyomyositis (Etiology: related to deep muscle infection w/seeding from direct trauma/injury or bacteremia; relatively uncommon, affecting compromised hosts→ DM, HIV; Sx: acute pain, swelling, fevers/systemic illness)
      • Gout or pseudogout (Sx: sometimes inflammation in foot or ankle can be so intense that diffuse edema develops; may have hx gout or pseudogout prior; PE: pain, warmth, redness, decreased range of motion of involved joint)
      • Joint infection (Etiology:trauma w/direct path of infection into joint, or systemic seeding; Sx: infection w/in joint of foot or ankle can be so intense that causes diffuse edema; also fever and systemic sx; PE: fever, redness, edema, focused over dominantly affected joint, pain worse w/any movement)

      Bone pathology

      • Traumatic fracture or injury (Sx: usually a clear hx and mechanism; PE: pain and swelling focused over site of fx; careful exam for nerve or arterial injury)
      • Stress fracture (Etiology: usually from chronic/repetitive injury; Sx: sub-acute, pain focused over affected site, common areas→ foot, ankle, tibia; PE: non-specific pain over affected area, able to walk/bear weight, better w/rest)
      • Pathologic fracture (Etiology: underlying bone abnl→ bone cancer or chronic infxn; Sx: fracture occur w/o expected amount of force; may also have other progressive sx of pain, fever, wt loss)
      • Osteomyelitis (Etiology: in adult, most commonly occurs in distal extremity, assoc w/neuropathy and peripheral arterial dz; can also be from traumatic innoculation of bacteria; also bacteremia→ more common in kids; Sx: if from pad/dm→ typically distal ulcer or sinus tract, non-healing, pain; if traumatic, then suggestive hx, open wound or draining sinus; PE: pain, swelling, redness non-healing ulcer; probe to bone→ clinical osteomyelitis)

      Hydrostatic edema

      Typically non-painful
      • DVT (RFs: hypercoaguable state, immobility, trauma; Sx: acute swelling, localized discomfort; PE: unilateral edema otherwise unexplained, Well's Criteria to quantify liklihood)
      • Lymphatic obstruction
        • Lymphatic injury (Etiology: lymph node dissection, trauma; Sx: chronic, progressive edema, following injury to lymphatics; PE: Lymph edema, doughy, non-pitting)
        • Obstructing cancer (Sx: may relate to primary malignancy; PE: may have palpable inguinal nodes, Lymph edema, doughy, non-pitting)
        • Idiopathic, prior bacterial infections, prior parasitic infection, obesity
      • Venous insufficiency (Etiology: sometimes hx saphenous vein harvest w/CABG or DVT; Sx: chronic edema, worse after standing, better in morning after lying; PE: chronic edema, dark skin discoloration)
      • Massive DVT (phlegmasia cerulea dolens) (Etiology: unusual, massive proximal dvt, assoc w/hypercoag state; Sx: acute welling, pain, evidence arterial insufficiency/ischemia secondary to increased tissue pressure; PE: marked asymmetric edema, diminished pulses, delayed capillary refill, cool, dusky/bluish skin appearance)

      Arterial insufficiency

      • Subacute/chronic (Etiology: from progressive athero; Sx: distal arterial dz causes calf cramps/pain, worse w/activity, better w/rest; proximal dz can cause buttock claudication, errectile dyxfxn; PE: feet progressively cool to touch, pale, hairless, diminished cap refill, ulcers, cool)
      • Acute embolic (Etiology/Sx: sudden pain from abrupt arterial occlusion; emboli from a fib w/o warfarin, or ventricular thrombus if severe lv dysfxn; recent catheterization where plaque disrupted from aorta; PE: pale, diminished pulses if proximal occlusion, blue/hypoperfused toes w/distal emboli, cool)
      • Acute thrombosis in situ (Etiology: related to c/v rfs; sometimes related to prior endothelial injury from trauma, manipulation or xrt; acute thrombosis less common than occurs w/mi; Sx: acute, severe pain distal to site of occlusion; PE: pale, diminished pulses if proximal occlusion; PE: pale, diminished pulses, cool, decreased cap refill)

      Radiating pain

      • Nerve root irritation from disc or DJD → "sciatica" (Sx: waxes/wanes, typically radiates down one leg below knee, vast majority affect L5 or S1 roots, typically pain w/o weakness or deficits unless severe compression; PE: no pain on vertebral/paravertebral palpaion; if disc related: straight leg raise sensitive, crossed leg raise specific; S1: pain/numbness lateral foot; L5 pain/numbness top of foot; L5: weakness in extension of toe, foot inversion; S1: weakness in plantar flexion)
      • Spinal stenosis (Sx: slowly progressive, worse standing, typically radiates down B legs w/walking, feels better if walk while leaning forward→ e.g. while pushing a shopping cart)
      • Pyriformis syndrome (Etiology: compression of sciatic by pyriformis muscle; Sx: pain in lateral buttocks area radiating to back of thigh; PE: pain exacerbated by internal rotation of hip, deep palpation over pyriformis→ lateral to sacrum)

      Ruptured Baker's cyst

        Sx: asx aside from edema, presence of cyst behind knee often not known prior

      Trauma

      • Injury to skin, muscle, ligaments, tendons and bone; Dx based on mechanism and focality of pain
      • Trauma→ compartment syndrome (Etiology: significant LE trauma/crush injury → in partic to lower leg; Sx/PE: severe pain, swelling, numbness, weakness, decreased pulses)

      Toxic/metabolic

      Etiology: hypothyroid, vit d defic, medication effects, hypokalemia, other→ all tend to cause multi-site sx

      Hip pain?

      Hip Exam

      Groin/Inguinal/Ant thigh

      Typical location for pain secondary to intra-articular pathology
      • Osteoarthritis (Rfs: associated with obesity, worse with weight bearing and increased use, sometimes prior trauma; Sx: chronic progressive pain, worse w/walking/weight bearing, better w/rest)
      • Fracture (Etiology: hx fall or other high force injury, osteoporosis, steroid use; PE: cant walk/bear wt, sometimes obvious deformity)
      • Avascular Necrosis (Sx: sub-acute, progressive pain, worse w/weight bearing, hx underlying predisposing condition: ETOH, lupus, trauma, steroid use; PE: pain w/wt bearing; worse w/ROM)
      • Labral injury (Sx: pain in front of hip/groin, worse w/flexing/rotating, sensation of catching/clicking, can be sports related)
      • Infection (Etiology: direct extension from truama/surgery or spread from systemic infection; Sx/PE: acute,pain w/any range of motion, warmth and redness, fever)
      • Neurogenic→ meralgia paresthetica→ compression lateral cutaneous nerve(Rfs: associated w/obesity; Sx: neuropathic pain or numbness over defined patch upper/outer thigh)
      • Hip dislocation (Etiology: typically high force injury, may have hx dislocation, can occur w/native or prothetic hips; Sx: acute, severe pain and inability to walk/bear weigth; PE: acute pain, unable to walk, difficulty manipulating hip, leg appears foreshortened and externally or internally rotated)
      • Muscle/bone/soft tissue injury/strain (Etiology: recent overuse, recent trauma, onset pain linked temporally Sx: worse w/movement or use; PE: provocative testing clearly reproduces sx)
      • Cancer met to hip/pelvis (Rfs: cancer that mets to bone→ e.g. lung, prostate, breast, etc; Sx: progressive, unremitting bone pain; PE: pain on palpation over involved area, findings assoc w/primary cancer)
      • Non-infectious inflammatory
        • RA (Rfs: women > men; age 30-55; Sx: subacute (>6w), persistent/progressive joint pain, worse in AM, fatigue, tendency for bilateral involvement, commonly small and medium sized joints; PE: warth, redness, spongy feeling from synovial inflam, pain w/squeezing of joints, effusion, abnormal appearing if longstanding, MCPs with chronic changes; extra articular findings: episcleritis, pleural/pericardial inflam, rheumatoid nodules)

      Lateral hip

      • Trochanteric bursitis
        • Non-infected (Sx: sub-acute pain, worse w/movement, PE: pain on palpation of trocantor, pain w/resisted abduction of hip, limited warm/redness/swelling, preserved range of motion of hip)
        • Infected (Etiology: uncommon, from direct innoculation or compromised host; Sx: fever, acute pain, worse w/movement PE: pain over trochanter, redness, warmth and swelling)

      Posterior hip/buttocks

      • Lumbar root irritation (Sx: patients will also typically have back pain, with radiating/electric shock type symptoms that travel from low back to below knee; assoc typically w/L5 or S1 root irritation)
      • Pyriformis Syndrome (Etiology: compression of sciatic nerve by pyriformis Sx: radiating neuropathic-type pain to buttocks and leg)
      • Vascular insufficiency (Etiology: known atherosclerosis and/or RFs; Sx: dull ache in buttocks; worse w/activity, better w/rest; associated w/errecile dysfxn; PE: evidence of atherosclerosis affecting lower extremities→ diminished pulses, delayed cap refill, hairless)
      • Sacro-iliac osteo-arthritis (Sx: pain over SI joints, worse w/movement or weight bearing; slowly progressive; PE: pain over SI region)
      • Ankylosing Spondylitis (Sx: slow/insidious onset pain, progressive loss of ROM as bones fuse, radiation of pain into buttocks; PE: pain over SI joints, miminal change in distance from one vert spine to adjacent when bend)

      Knee pain or swelling?

      Knee Exam

      Acute/Sub-acute

      Trauma/Mechanical

      Knowing mechanism of injury is very helpful
      • Fracture (Etiology: direct fall on knee or impact w/hard structure→ dashboard injury w/mva; PE: pain over site, evidence trauma, effusion)
      • Patella dislocation (Sx: acute pain, prior hx dislocation, PE: appears displaced lateral/medial on exam, sometimes patient can re-locate on own/spontaneously)
      • ACL disruption (Etiology: twisting injury, often non-contact; Sx: acute pain, audible pop, acute effusion from blood, sense of instability thereafter; PE: laxity w/anterior drawer, lachmans; acute effusion)
      • PCL disruption (Etiology: foot planted w/direct force on lower leg; Sx: pain and acute swelling; less instability than w/ACL; PE: laxity w/posterior drawer; acute effusion)
      • LCL or MCL Disruption (Etiology: foot planted, acute force from medial to lateral direction→LCL injury; acute force from lateral to medial→MCL injury; Sx: acute pain, swelling, sometimes instability; PE: laxity w/medial or lateral joint stress; acute effusion)
      • Meniscal injury (Etiology: twisting or contact, can occur concomitant w/ligament injury or as isolated problem, in older adults→ degenerative tears common; Sx: acute/sub-acute pain, swelling hours to days later→ slower accumulation blood, chronic/recurrent sx of locking, instability/give-way, pain; PE: joint line pain, + mcMurrays, + grind)

      W/in Joint

      • Infection (Sx: acute pain, worse w/movement, one or few joints, fever, chills; PE: warmth, redness, effusion, pain w/movement)
      • Non-infectious: Gout (Rfs: male, > 50, post-menopausal women, prior hx gout; Sx: acute joint pain, worse w/movement, one or few joints, most commonly great toe→ podagra, often self limited; sometimes renal stones as well; PE: very painful w/any movement, warmth and redness over poin, rarely evidence of tophi)
      • Non-infectious: Pseduogout (Rfs: tendency to affect joints w/established OA/trauma; also assoc w/hyperparathyroidism, hyothyroid, hemochrom; often idiopathic; age > 50 Sx: acute joint pain and inflammation, typically knees & hands, can look like gout, often self limited, recurrent; PE: warmth, redness, effusion and pain w/movement of affected joint)
      • Non-infectious: RA (Rfs: women > men; age 30-55; Sx: subacute (>6w), persistent/progressive joint pain, worse in AM due to gelling→ improves w/use, fatigue, tendency for bilateral involvement, commonly small and medium sized joints; PE: warmth, redness, spongy feeling from synovial inflam, pain w/squeezing of joints, effusion, abnormal appearing if longstanding, MCPs with chronic changes; extra articular findings: episcleritis, pleural/pericardial inflam, rheumatoid nodules) more from CDC
      • Non-infectious: Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC

      Around knee

      • Bursitis: Prepatellar (Etiology: often hx recurrent kneeling; Sx: acute pain, redness, swelling PE: redness, pain and swelling over patellar area)
      • Bursitis: Anserine (Etio; often chronic kneeling; Sx: acute pain, redness and swelling inferio-medial to knee)
      • Cellulitis (Etiology; sometimes break in skin that is portal for infxn; Sx: acute redness, pain, fever PE: redness in skin, not restricted to knee, not worse w/knee flex/extension as would occur w/intra-articular process

      Chronic

      • Osteoarthritis (Rfs: sometimes prior injury, wt bearing joint, obesity; Sx: subacute/chronic, worse w/activity, better w/rest, slowly progressive; PE: sometimes effusion, crepitus w/movement, decreased range of motion as progresses, sometimes bony growths at joint edges/deformity)
      • Patello-femoral pain (Sx: subacute/chronic, anterior pain, worse w/activity, exacerbated going up/down stair/inclines, squatting; PE: increased w/patellar loading)
      • Meniscal injury (Sx: sense of instability/giveway, decrease ROM, locking, swelling; pain medial or lateral, depending on which meniscus affected)
      • Ligamentous insufficiency (Rfs: hx ligament injury; Sx: sense of give-way and pain when stress applied in direction that ligament typically check - eg. twisting; PE: laxity when affected ligament stressed)
      • Ilio-tibial band syndrome (Rfs: assoc w/overuse from running, cycling, etc; Sx: pain lateral knee, worse w/activity; PE: pain elicited palpating lateral knee proximal to jt line, worse w/flexing-extending)
      • Posterior knee pain
        • Baker's cyst (Sx: can sometimes cause popliteal fossa fullness and discomfort; more commonaly asx; PE: sense of fullness in fossa)
        • Posterior meniscal tear (Sx: pain w/weight bearing, may have locking or give-way)
        • Popliteal artery aneurysm (Rfs: may have aneurysmal or atherosclerotic dz elsewhere; Sx: May be asx, or have fossa fullness, distal emboli; PE: pulsatile, aneurysmal structure in fossa)
        • Osteoarthritis (Sx: usually progressive over time, sometimes prior injury, worse w/wt bearing, may have osteoarthritis elsewhere; PE: may have crepitus, joint line pain, joint deformity)
        • Hamstring strain (Sx: pain w/knee flexion, may have antecedent injury; PE: pain localizes to insertion site)

      Vasculitis

      Vasculitis is a disorder of blood vessel inflammation, with the precise driver for this inflammation often unknown. Patients can present with acute and chronic sx, often affecting multiple organ systems. This family of problems is typically organized based on the size of the vessles infolved. In addition, a number of autoimmune disorders (e.g. SLE) may have vasculitis as a contributing feature. There are also variants which remain confined to single organ systems and/or have etiologies as described below.
      • Large Sized Arteries
        • Giant cell/temporal arteritis (Rfs: age > 50, F>M; 20% w/PMR will develop GCA; 50% w/GCA had PMR; Sx: f, ha, jaw claudication, wt loss, scalp pain, muscle aches typically x mos; visual loss abrupt, w/other sx typically first; PE: sometimes scalp/temp art tenderness, edematous optic nerve)
        • Takayasu's arteritis (Rfs: onset 10-30yo, Asian background, women > men; Sx: sub-acute and progressive, fevers, wt loss, fatigue, myalgias arthralgias; target organ sx based on affected vessels: abdominal aorta & branches→ abdominal pain, htn; thoracic aorta & branches→ chest pain, sob, tia/stroke; PE: loss of palpable pulses radial, carotid, lower extremity)
      • Medium Sized Arteries
        • Polyarteritis Nodosa (vasculitis) (Rfs: 40s-50s, men>women, Hep B/C; Sx: more commonly subacute over mos f, s, malaise, wt loss, muscle/joint pain; multiple systems: arthritis, glomerulonephritis, peripheral nerve pain/dysfxn, skin w/ulcers, small, palapable purpura→ don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; abd pain, blood per rectum)
      • Small Sized Arteries
        • Cryogloblulinemia (Etiol: immune complex deposition; Type I monoclonal→ IgM or IgG, related to lymphoprolif d/o→ lymphoma, myeloma; Type II and III, mixed cryos IgM and IgG; related to Hep C (most common), SLE, RA, lymphoma, myeloma, hiv, hep b, other autoimmune; RFs: female > male, ages 40-50; Sx: subacute fatigue, weakness, muscle and joint aches, cough/sob if pulmonary involvement; confusion; symmetric or asymmetric often painful distal neuropathy, painful skin ulcers of extremities, purpuric papules; membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis; PE: palpable purpura of vasculitis, Raynauds, livedo reticularis, distal skin ulcers)
        • Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss) (Etiology: anca assoc, high levels circulating and tissue invasive eosinophils; Rfs: men=women, assoc also w/leukotriene antagonists; Sx: progressive, adult onset asthma, cough & wheezing, nasal stuffiness→ w/resp sx usually ~2-10 y prior to systemic sx assoc w/eosinophilic deposition in target organs and vasculitis; in these later phases→ systemic sx including: sob from parenchymal lung involvement; f, c, muscle aches; hematuria from renal involvement; heart failure, pericarditis and dysrhythmia w/cardiac involvement; peripheral neuropathy; PE: wheezing, skin findings of vasculitis: small, palapable purpura, dont blanch when compress them, can coalesce; hematuria/renal involvement; unexplained peripheral neuropathy)
        • Goodpastures (anti-GBM) (Etiol: immune complex assoc; Sx: persistent cough, sob, hemoptysis, concurrent acute kidney injury from glomerulonephritis)
        • Granulomatosis with poyangiitis (GPA - formerly Wegener's) (Etiology: anca-assoc; Sx: fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, sweats, wt loss; recurrent/progressive nasal congestion, cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; skin ulcers; PE: mucosal erythema, ulcer, nasal septum perf, palpable purpura, skin ulcer/necrosis)
        • Henoch-schoenlein purpura (HSP) (Etiology: immune complex deposition; Sx: acute, n, v, sometimes bloody diarrhea, hematuria, renal impairment; PE: purpuric rash→ in partic abd, legs, buttocks; joint swelling and pain)
        • Microscopic polyangitis (MPA) (Etiology: anca-assoc; Sx: fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, sweats, wt loss; recurrent/progressive cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; less often nasal sx c/w GPA; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; skin ulcers; neuropathy; PE: palpable purpura, skin ulcer/necrosis)
      • Vasculitis associated w/variably sized blood vessel
        • Behcet's Dz (RFs: typically presents 20-30yo; Middle Eastern, Mediterranean or East Asian background; Sx: waxing/waning over weeks/months, painful ulcers in genital region and mouth; pain w/swallowing; fever; e nodosusm or other nodular skin lesions; pathergy→ papule/pustule in response to minor trauma; arthralgias; inflammatory arthritis in one/few med joints; eye sx from iritis; adenopathy; can have neuro involvement; can have arterial/venous thrombosis; PE: apthous ulcer(s) with surrounding erythema in mouth, pustule or ulcers in genital area; irreg appearance of pupil, circumferential redness at cornea-sclera junction, sometimes layered pus in anterior chamber→ hypopyon; inflammatory arthritis; adenopathy)
        • Other
      • Vasculitis associated w/systemic dz
        • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50, vasculitis can occur at any time during dz; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis, skin findings most common manifestation of vasculitis though can affect any organ system; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss; digital ischemia and Raynaud's if vasculitis) more from CDC
        • RA (Rfs for RA vasculitis: typically longstanding/burnt out RA; Sx: new onset f, c, fatigue, serositis, digital ulceration, new sensory or motor sx; PE: evidence longstanding RA such as MCPs with chronic changes, rheumatoid nodules, new digial ischemia/ulcer, new motor or sensory findings) more from CDC
        • Sarcoid, other
      • Vasculitis contained within a single organ system
        • Cutanous Vasculitis (leukocytoclastic vasculitis) (Etiology: limited to the skin, have to r/o other etiologies→ secondary to systemic vasculitis, infection, malignancy, etc; Sx: diffuse eruption, can occur anywhere; PE: small, palapable purpura, don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce)
        • CNS, other
      • Vasculitis assoc w/probable etiology
        • Medication or toxin induced (Rfs: levimasole→ used to cut cocaine; Sx: acute, painful distal extremities, in particular→ fingers, ears, nose; PE: decreased cap refill distally, swelling, pain, distal necrosis)
        • Hepatitis B, cancer, other

      More Info About Musculoskeletal Disorders: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Disorders; Comprehensive Muscuoskeletal Exam

      Back

      Mental Health

      Comprehensive mental status exam

      Known mental health disorder?

      • Mood disorder→ depression, bipolar; anxiety d/o; psychosis→ schizophrenia; personality d/o, etc

      Depressed?

      • Major depression (Sx: PHQ2 screen: little interest or pleasure in doing things; feeling down depressed or hopeless More on PHQ2; Major depression→ persistence of sx, interferes w/life; also impaired sleep, wt loss/gain, decreased or increased eating, low energy, thoughts of harming self) PHQ9 can f/u positive PHQ2
      • Dysthymia (Sx: long term depressive sx (>2y), not disabling but does interfere w/quality of life, @ risk for major depression)
      • Minor depression (Sx: depression for < 2 weeks &/or otherwise doesn't meet criteria for major depression; @ risk for later major depression)
      • Seasonal affective d/o (SAD) (Sx: depression that occurs in winter mos, assoc w/less sun light, resolves when seasons change)
      • Bi-polar d/o (Sx: mood d/o assoc w/episodes that differ from patient's normal mood & behavior; cycling (variable duration & degree) between depression & mania; manic sx: overly happy & outgoing, inpulsivity, participating in risky behavior, racing thoughts, easily distracted, poor performance school/work, not sleeping, unrealistic sense of abilities, increased activity; Depressive sx (not always prominent): feeling sad, hopeless, low energy, suicidality, disturbed sleeping & eating, lack of joy from activities) MOQ: Bipolar screening tool
      • Other mental health problems (Sx: can co-mingle w/depression including: anxiety d/o, substance abuse)
      • Medications (Etiology: interferon, anabolic steroids when cycle off, beta blockers, clonidine, other→ dx based on temporal connection)
      • Medical conditions (Etiology: hypothyroidism, adrenal excess, ETOH or other substance abuse, w/drawl from substances of abuse)
      • Depression co-mingles w/many conditions (Parkinsons, Alzheimers, MS; also w/many medical conditions→ advanced CHF, traumatic brain injury, substance abuse, etc)

      Manic?

      • Bi-polar d/o (Sx: mood d/o assoc w/episodes that differ from patient's normal mood & behaviour; cycling (variable duration & degree) between depression & mania→ manic sx: overly happy & outgoing, inpulsivity, participating in risky behavior, racing thoughts, easily distracted, poor performance school/work, not sleeping, unrealistic sense of abilities, increased activity; Depressive sx (not always prominent): feeling sad, hopeless, low energy, suicidality, disturbed sleeping & eating, lack of joy from activities) MOQ: Bipolar screening tool
      • Medical conditions or meds
        • Substance abuse (Etiology: in particular, stimulating substance like cocaine, crystal; anabolic steroid abuse)
        • Many meds (Etiology: prescribed for mental health or other d/o - eg. steroids, SSRIs, etc)
        • Medical conditions (Etiology: hyperthyroidism, adrenal excess, etc)

      Alcohol/Substance abuse?

      • Alcohol abuse (Rfs: male drinking >14/week or 4 per occasion; women drinking >7/week or 3 per occasion; Sx: craving/strong desire for alcohol, inability to curb use, dependence and withdrawal sx if stop using, development of tolerance, alcohol use occupies significant portion of time→ both drinking and planning, negative impact on life as a whole→ personal relationships, family, work; can abuse other substances as well; multiple screening tests for alcohol abuse including CAGE, AUDIT, T-ACE, NIAA Screen for heavy ETOH use, and AUDIT-C)
      • Substance abuse can co-mingle w/other mental health problems→ depression, thought d/o, personality d/o, etc
        • More from CDC
      National institute of alcohol abuse and alcoholism

      Anxious?

      • Generalized anxiety d/o (Sx: x 6m, feel anxious much of the time, interferes w/life activities, hyperactivity/vigilance, can't relax, easily startled, poor sleep, fatigue, unexplained somatic complaints)
      • Obsessive-compulsive d/o (Sx: repeated thoughts/fears about germs, concerns about safety, intruders, etc; can't control/stop these thoughts; repeated ritualized behaviours that can't stop→ washing hands, checking doors locked/stove off, etc; performing ritual relieves anxiety; rituals/thoughts occupy >1h per day & interfere w/life)
      • Panic d/o (Sx: sudden, repeated & unfounded attacks of fear; feeling out of control when attacks occur, focus on when next episode will occur, avoidance of places where anxiety attacks have occurred in past, physical sx including: palpatations, sweating, sob, dizziness, numbness, chest/abdominal pain, etc)
      • Social phobia/social anxiety d/o (Sx: anxiety when talking w/people even though wish you could, avoidance of people and events attended by others, self conscious around others, fear of being judged, worry for days/weeks prior to an event, hard time making & keeping friends, feel ill/flushed/sweaty when meet people)
      • Substance abuse (Sx: can co-mingle w/anxiety; sedating substances like benzos & etoh used to self treat; stimulating substance like cocaine, crystal can cause anxious sx; concern about finding addl crystal/cocaine can drive anxiety)
      • Depression with anxious features (Sx of both depression & anxiety)
      • Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) (Rfs: following exposure to perceived life-threatening/traumatic event; Sx x 1m from 3 main groups: Re-experiencing→ intrusive thoughts, recollections, nightmares w/significant psychological & physiological stress; avoidance behavior & generalized numbness→ avoids anything that triggers memories of event, feeling detached, losing interest in activities, using etoh/other sedating drugs; hyperarousal→ irritability, outbursts of anger, insomnia, on-edge, difficulty concentrating, hyper-vigillance/safety concerns, easily startled)
      • Medical conditions
        • Hyperthyroidism (Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, wt loss, weakness, infetility, ED, menstrual irreg; PE: sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid, hyper-reflexia, moist skin)
        • Pheochromocytoma (Sx: rare, assoc w/findings related to abrupt increases in sympathetic d/c→ elevated HR, BP, headache, sweating)
        • Many acute medical problems can cause acute anxiety→ PE, MI, SVT, hypoglycemia, etc
        • Withdrawal from meds (Etiology: ETOH, benzos, etc)
      • Many meds: overuse b-agonist inhalers, ADHD-related stimulants, over use of thyroid replacement, over use caffeine, steroids→ anxiety to mania, mental health meds including SSRIs, other

      Personality d/o?

      • Personality d/o (Sx: inflexible, chronic pattern of problematic interpersonal interactions, mis-perception of events & actions of others, lability in responses to others & environment. Reflected in wide range of persistent behaviors over years, w/onset in early adulthood. Results in difficulty w/relationships, work, following thru & adherence/acceptance of medical plans/advice. Need collateral info & multiple visits to dx. These patients pose significant challenges for clinicians.)
        • Cluster A (paranoid, schizoid, schizotypal) (Sx: odd, eccentric, and isolated; uncomfortable & avoid social contact, emotionally distant; avoid medical care; bizarre ideas re etiology of sx/illness; suspicious and untrusting)
        • Cluster B (antisocial, borderline, narcissitic, histrionic) (Sx: dramatic, emotional & manipulative; hx unstable interpersonal relationships; impulsive & chaotic; can be very challenging for clinician & medical staff to deal with→ identified as "difficult" patients; sometimes approachable, other times not; can be demanding; may frequently transfer care)
        • Cluster C (avoidant, dependent, obsessive-compulsive) (Sx: anxious, fearful, & depressed; feelings of inadequacy, dependence, sensitivity to criticism; preoccupation w/order & perfection)
        Personality d/o often co-mingles w/: substance abuse, somatozation d/o; 50% w/hx childhood abuse.
      • Other mental health conditions
        • Bi-polar d/o, schizophrenia, substance abuse, ptsd, anxiety d/o, depression - though none have the persistent sx & behaviours of personality d/o. Also possible to have one of these dx & a personality d/o.
      • Medical conditions
        • hyperthyroidism, structural brain disease→ tumor/other, complex seizures, lupus/other cns vasculitides, neurosyphliis - all have other features, & none w/enduring characteristics of personality d/o

      Memory problems?

      • Dementia: This is often greatest patient & MD concern; Screening tools can help w/Dx: Saint Louis University Mental Status exam or Montreal Cognitive Assessment; Other medical conditions can co-mingle w/dementia & make dx challenging
        • Alzheimer's-type Dementia (Rfs: age > 65, hx Down's syndrome; Sx: progressive over years, loss of short term memory first; as progresses, affects ability to function; ultimately loss of higher level processing → ability to do calculations, engage in high level and then simpler conversations; can have behavioral problems; ultimately loss of long term memory, ability to recognize/interact/live independently) more from CDC
        • Vascular Dementia (Rfs: age > 60 and traditional CV risk factors; Sx: loss of memory and functionality; deficits can relate to areas of infarct; may progress abruptly in concert w/known strokes; or more slowly from chronic ischemia; can co-mingle w/Alzheimers dz)
        • Lewy Body Dementia (Rfs: increases w/age; Sx: declining cognitive fxn, visual/spatial impairment, inattention, hallucinations, fluctuation in sx; most patient will also have sx of Parkisons; can co-mingle w/AD or vascular dementia)
        • Fronto-temporal Dementia(Rfs: increases w/age; Sx: dominant feature is change in personality & behavioural problems→ ranging from withdrawl to aggression; loss of sense of social norms; binge eating; can also experience aphasia)
        • Normal Pressure Hydrocephalous (Rfs: age > 65; Sx: dementia, accompanied by wide-based gait & incontinence)
        • Korsakoff's dementia (Etiology: starts as Wernickes encephalopathy→ thiamine (B1) deficiency; Rfs: while uncommon, seem in alcoholics; Sx/PE: encephalopathy, ataxia from cerebellar dysfxn, opathalmoplegia leading to disconjugate gaze→ double vision, nystagmus; untreated can lead to Korsakoff's dementia→ inability to form new memories)
        • Rarer neruodegenerative d/o w/dementia
          • Huntington's dz (Etiology: autosomal dominant Sx: onset ~ 50s, movement problems, cognitive, memory & other impairments c/w dementia→ progressive & fatal)
          • Progressive supra-nuclear palsy (Sx: rare d/o assoc w/gait & balance problems, impaired eye movements, rigidity; cognitive impairment, behavioural issues, dis-inhibition, lost of executive fxn)
          • Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease (Sx: can affect old & young (<50); rapidly progressive decline in memory, cognition, thinking; onset to death w/in 1y; coordination probs and myoclonus may come first)
      • Major depression (Sx: PHQ2 screen: little interest or pleasure in doing things; feeling down depressed or hopeless; major depression indicated by persistence of sx, which interfere w/life; can also have impaired sleep, wt loss/gain, decreased or increased eating, low energy, thoughts of harming self)
      • Mild cognitive impairment (Rfs: increases w/age; Sx: very subtle loss in short term memory, doesn't affect ability to fxn, preservation of higher cognitive fxn; often, but not always, a precursor to Alzheimers dz)
      • Other conditions can contribute to memory loss & occur commonly in same population suffering from dementia; goal to identify & correct anything that's treatable, then reassess for dementia (medical conditions include→anemia, thyroid d/o, B12 defic syphillis, sleep d/o, chronic kidney/liver dz; brain tumor; Parkinsons Dz; coexisting delirium state)
      • Meds or substances of abuse (narcotics, benzos, others meds that affect cognition, etoh, etc)

      Confusion or Aggitation?

      Can have a broad spectrum of presentations, from mild disorientation to aggitation, hallucinations and psychosis.

      Delirium

      RFs: age > 65, male, impaired hearing or vision, prior hx delirium, dementia, hospitalization, surgery or serious illness, multiple meds, baseline dementia; Sx: acute change from prior behavior, including→ disorganized thinking, impaired short term memory, inattention, disorientation, confusion, delusions, hallucinations, altered sleep patterns, hypo or hyperactivity; sx fluctuate; spectrum from somnolent to very agitated; typically reversible. Delirium is always secondary to something, including:

      Infection (genl)

      • Infection anywhere (Etiology: the greater magnitude infection, the more likely delirium, though frail/elderly/chronically ill can decompensate w/small burdens of infxn; Sx:site of infection identified by localizing sx & findings)

      CNS process

      Infxn/Inflam

      • Meningitis (Etiology: inflammation of layers covering brain; Sx: photphobia, acute neck stiffness, headache, fever, confusion, and generalized illness; PE: f, + Kernigs (specific not sensitive)→ pain with passive knee extension when hip flexed to 90; + Brudzinski (specific not sensitive)→ hip and knee flexion occurs w/passive neck flexion; + jolt (sensitive not specific)→ worsening ha when patient rotates head back & forth; less common to have focal neurological findings and overall less impaired compared w/encephalitis)
        • Viral (Organisms: enteroviruses, herpes simplex, herpes zoster, ebv, west nile, influenza, hiv, measels, mumps; Sx: acute, fever, head ache, neck pain, n, v, delirium)
        • Bacterial (Organisms: strep pneumoniae, n meningiditis→ in particular when living in dormitories/college and not vax; grp b strep; listeria→ in the elderly; Sx: acute, fever, head ache, neck pain, n, v, delirium; rash)
        • Fungal (Rfs: often assoc w/compromised states → hiv, cancer; Organisms: cryptococcus, histoplasmosis, coccidioomycosis, blastomyces; Sx: subacute, fever, feeling poorly in general, sub-acute headache & neck pain, delirium)
        • Myobacterial (Rfs: known TB elsewhere, immuncompromised, otherwise exposed; Sx: subacute f, chills, ha, fatigue, stiff neck, delirium)
        • Parasitic - Cysticercosis (T Solium - tapeworm) (Etiology: ingest eggs via infected beef that's undercooked; Mexico, Africa, Southeast Asia; eggs cross intestines, migrate to host muscles and brain; Sx: ha, seizures, otherwise unexplained muscles aches)
        • Non-infectious: collagen vascular disease→ lupus, cancer involving the meninges, post infectious, medications→ nsaids, IVIG, other
        • More on meningitis from CDC
      • Encephalitis (Etiology: inflammation of diffuse or specifc areas of brain parenchyma; Sx: tend to have focal neuro deficits as compared w/meningitis; acute onset of headache, fever, confusion, irritability, motor and sensory impairment, altered speech; can also have meningoencephalitis)
        • Viral (most common) (Organisms: enteroviruses,, HSV, VZV, EBV, influenza, west nile, other arboviruses (transmitted by mosquitoes); and other viruses w/prevalence varying by season, region of the world)
        • Other uncommon infections (Organisms: Tick borne→ lyme; rabies, fungal, and mycobacteria)
        • Non-infectious (Etiology: collagen vascular disease, para-neoplastic, post infectious, post vaccination)
        • Autoimmune encephalitis (Etiology: antibody mediated→ multiple including anti-nmda; also paraneoplastic; Rfs: women, < 30, teratoma; Sx: acute change in personality, decline in functional status, agitation, confusion, bizarre behavior, autonomic instability, seizures, unusual movements, seziures, other neuro deficits)
        • ADEM (acute demyelinating encephalomyelitis) (Etiology: autoimmune d/o, often triggered by an infection→ URI, EBV; post vaccination, other; dx of exclusion; RFs: overall uncommon, though kids>>adults; Sx: acute, progressive, ha, f, confusion, weakness, ataxia, focal deficits; PE: f, focal deficits, patchy UMN and sensory findings)
      • Bacterial abscess (Etiology: reason for abscess → spread from adjacent site→ dental or sinuses, AVM, PFO, neurosurgery; Sx: acute/subacute, headache, fever, loss of function based on location, progressive, delirium)
      • Mycobacterial abscess (Rfs: known TB elsewhere, immuncompromised, otherwise exposed; Sx: subacute f, chills, ha, fatigue, stiff neck, delirium, loss of function based on location)
      • Fungal abscess (Rfs: often assoc w/compromised states → hiv, cancer, DM; systemic or from local spread; Sx: subacute, fever, feeling poorly in general, sub-acute headache & neck pain, delirium, deficits based on location)
      • Parasitic - Cysticercosis (T Solium - tapeworm) (Etiology: ingest eggs via infected beef that's undercooked; Mexico, Africa, Southeast Asia; eggs cross intestines, migrate to host muscles and brain; Sx:headache, seizures, otherwise unexplained muscles aches)
      • Parasitic - Toxoplasmosis (Rfs: HIV + w/CD4 < 200; Sx: sub-acute, headache, confusion, fever, focal neruo deficits based on location)

      Other CNS

      • Trauma, bleeding, infection, tumor, post-ictal, stroke
      • Non-convulsive status epilepticus (Etiology: related to an array of pathology including tox/met conditions, meds, structural brain dz, other; Sx: waxing and waning level of altertness, confusion, new onset inability to follow commands; much more subtle than generalized seizure; PE: subtle twitching, eye deveiation, blinking, repeating of words, other)
      • Wernicke's encephalopathy (Etiology: thiamine (B1) deficiency; Rfs: alcoholic, others w/severe nutritional deficiency; Sx: delirium, severe balance problems, occulomotor dysfxn leading to double vision or other occular disturbances; most patients wont have all 3 symptoms; resolve w/thiamine, occulmotor most quickly; untreated→ Korsakoff's dementia→ inability to form new memories; PE: profound confusion, severe ataxia→ often unable to stand, occulomotor dysfxn including cranial nerve palsey, vertical or horizontal nystagmus)

      Meds/Drugs/Withdrawl

      • Cocaine, crystal meth, other stimulants or hallucinogens
      • ADHD meds, dopaminergics, SSRIs, steroids
      • Many other meds→ dx based on temporal relationship
      • Withdrawal from alcohol or benzodiazepines
      • Narcotic withdrawl
      • combinations of agents

      Toxins/Toxidomes/OD

      • Stimulants (Etiology: cocaine, crystal meth, other; Sx: aggitated, sweating, restless, very activated; PE: midriasis, tachycardia, sweating, tremor, psycho-motor activation)
      • Opioids (Etiology: heroin, opiods; Sx: sedation to somnolence; PE: hypothermia, sedation/decreased arrousability, slow respiratory rate, miosis, decreased bowel sounds)
      • Sedatives & hypnotics
        • Ethanol (typical drinking alcohol) (Etiology: degree of intoxication based on qty, chronicity of intake, function of metabolic pathways; Sx: excited, socially uninhibited, impaired judgement, aggressive behavior, aggitation; w/spectrum from hallucinations to sedation to somnolence if severe; PE: respiratory suppression if severe, characteristic odor, aggitation to sedation, slurred speech, ataxia)
        • Benzodiazepine (Etiology: degree of sx based on chronicity, quantity consumed, function of metabolic pathways; Sx: sedation to somnolence if severe; can also have aggitation, hallucinations; PE: aggitation/confusion to sedation, slurred speech, ataxia, respiratory suppression)
        • Ethylene glycol (Etiology: used in anti-freeze; colorless, odorless and sweet tasting→ accidental ingestions in kids or purposeful in adults; Sx: lower dose similar to ethanol, higher dose n, v, confusion, kidney/liver dysfxn, death, tachypnea from metaolic acidosis, osmolar gap; PE: euphoria, aggitation, social disinhibition; severe cases w/respiratory depression to coma; ataxia, slurred speech)
        • Methanol (wood alcohol) (Etiology: contained in wind shield wiper fluid, anti-freeze, fuel additives, paint thinners; consumed inadvertently by child or w/intent to harm self/others, very toxic; Sx: initially can appear inebriated; n, v, confusion, resp depression, death; long term neruo deficits, blindness; osmolar gap and later met acidosis; PE: initially inebriated; later can have tachypnea from met acidosis, visual disturbance, then somnolence, multi-sytem failure)
        • Isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) (Etiology: taken w/goal of inoxication; or unintentional or intentional overdose; Sx: similar to ethanol w/aggitation, disinhibition; w/spectrum including sedataion and coma; abd pain, vomiting; osmolar gap w/o sig metaoloic acidosis; PE: characteristic acetone breath odor, spectrum from aggitated to somnolence, respiratory depression if severe; slurred speech, ataxia)
      • Anticholinergics (Etiology: tricyclics, anihistamines, other; can be intential overdose; Sx: rapid onset < 12h after exposure, aggitated confusion, hallucinations, inability to urinate, blurred vision; PE: fever to > 38.8, flushed, tachycardic, aggitated delirium, dry mucous membranes, urinary retention, ileus, dry, red& warm skin, normal reflexes)
      • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (Etiologloy: exposure to haldol, chlorpomazine, other typical or atypical neruoleptics; more common w/high dose or soon after rx/dose change, but also idiosyncratic→ occurring after years of rx; sx progress over several d; Sx: autonomic instability w/HTN, tachycardia, tachypnea, temp can be > 41.1c, pale, sweaty, fluctuating delirium→ aggitated or stupor/alert mutism to coma, cramps, generalized lead-pipe type muscular rigidity, decreased reflexes)
      • Cholinergic agents (Etiology: organophosphate insecticide overdose or exposure; Sx: sedation, confusion, sweating, shortness of breath; PE: salivation, wheezing, lacrimation, bronchorrea, emesis, diarrhea, urination)
      • Serotonin syndrome (Etiology: SSRIs, MAOIs, anti-epileptics, others; rapid onset sx ususally following rx initiation or dose change, though can occur if received rx w/in 5w; sometimes med combinations precipitate syndrome; intential overdose; Sx: aggiation/easily startled, sweating, shivering, diarrhea; PE: spectrum→ htn, tachycardia, tachypnea, hyperthermia to > 41c, flushed & sweaty skin, tremor, confusion/aggitation to coma, increased bowel sounds, clonus, muscular hyperactivity/stiffness, hyper-reflexia)
      • In the setting of an over dose, multiple ingestions can occur simultaneously

      Acute Medical Cond

      Many acute medical conditions can cause and/or contribute to delirium.
      • Pulmonary
        • Hypoxemia
        • Hypercarbia
        • Pneumonia
        • Pulmonary embolism
      • Cardiac
        • Heart failure
        • Heart attack
        • Hypotension
        • Hypertensive encephalopathy
      • GI
        • Hepatic encephalopathy (Etiology: assoc w/chronic liver dz, most commonly hep b, c, etoh, other; acute infxn, meds, gi bleeding, other leads to decompensation; Sx: confusion to stupor in patient w/underlying dz; PE: findings of chronic liver dz, delirium, asterixis)
      • Renal
        • Uremia
        • Hypovolemia
      • Heme-Oncology
        • Malignancy, including para-neoplastic syndromes
        • Anemia
      • Endocrine
        • Hyper/hyponatremia
        • Hypercalcemia
        • Hyper/hypoglycemia
        • Hypo/hyperthyroidism
      • Neuro and Infections - see under main Delirium categories
      • Above is not exhaustive list - can have other significant target organ system disease contributing. Multi-system organ dysfunction possible too.

      Pain

      • Severe pain, in particular if coupled w/any of above

      Unfavorable environs

      • Hospitalization, disruption of normal sleep wake cycle, ICU stay, procedures, restraints, foley catheter
      Combinations of the above often contribute synergystically

      Dementia

      Rfs: age > 65; Sx: progressive, memory deficits, slowly progressive - define w/ comprehensive exam, collateral reports, Saint Louis University Mental Status (SLUMS) exam or Montreal Cognitive Assessment; note that delirium can be superimposed on dementia
      • Alzheimer's-type Dementia (Rfs: age > 65, hx Down's syndrome; Sx: progressive over years, loss of short term memory first; as progresses, affects ability to function; ultimately loss of higher level processing → ability to do calculations, engage in high level and then simpler conversations; can have behavioral problems; ultimately loss of long term memory, ability to recognize/interact/live independently) more from CDC
      • Vascular Dementia (Rfs: age > 60 and traditional CV risk factors; Sx: loss of memory and functionality; deficits can relate to areas of infarct; may progress abruptly in concert w/known strokes; or more slowly from chronic ischemia; can co-mingle w/Alzheimers dz)
      • Lewy Body Dementia (Rfs: increases w/age; Sx: declining cognitive fxn, visual/spatial impairment, inattention, hallucinations, fluctuation in sx; most patient will also have sx of Parkisons; can co-mingle w/AD or vascular dementia)
      • Fronto-temporal Dementia(Rfs: increases w/age; Sx: dominant feature is change in personality & behavioural problems→ ranging from withdrawl to aggression; loss of sense of social norms; binge eating; can also experience aphasia)
      • Normal Pressure Hydrocephalous (Rfs: age > 65; Sx: dementia, accompanied by wide-based gait & incontinence)
      • Korsakoff's dementia (Etiology: starts as Wernickes encephalopathy→ thiamine (B1) deficiency; Rfs: while uncommon, seem in alcoholics; Sx/PE: encephalopathy, ataxia from cerebellar dysfxn, opathalmoplegia leading to disconjugate gaze→ double vision, nystagmus; untreated can lead to Korsakoff's dementia→ inability to form new memories)
      • Rarer neruodegenerative d/o w/dementia
        • Huntington's dz (Etiology: autosomal dominant Sx: onset ~ 50s, movement problems, cognitive, memory & other impairments c/w dementia→ progressive & fatal)
        • Progressive supra-nuclear palsy (Sx: rare d/o assoc w/gait & balance problems, impaired eye movements, rigidity; cognitive impairment, behavioural issues, dis-inhibition, lost of executive fxn)
        • Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease (Sx: can affect old & young (<50); rapidly progressive decline in memory, cognition, thinking; onset to death w/in 1y; coordination probs and myoclonus may come first)

      Medical conditions

      • Acute Intermitent Porphyria (Etiology: uncommon, inherited d/o; often triggered by starvation, etoh, smoking, infection, or meds; also cutaneous variants; Sx: episodic bouts of unexplained severe abd pain, agitation/confusion, n, v, limb pain, motor and sonsory neuropathy, seizure; PE: episodic htn, tachycardia, generalized muscle weakness, dark urine)
      • Adrenal excess (Sx: central wt gain→ neck/face/thorax/abd, htn, glucose intol/dm; PE: striae, easy bruising, buffalo hump, moon face, hyperpigment in mouth/sun exposed areas if acth depen)
      • Adrenal insufficiency (Sx: feeling poorly in general, n, v, orthostatic sx)
      • B12 deficiency (Etiology: pernicious anemia, s/p gastrectomy, crohn's dz, rarely diet related; Sx: progressive, legs more common then arms, can be painful, impaired dorsal columns function, gait problems, tongue can be smooth and swollen if severe, s/s anemia if severe, rarely confusion)
      • HIV (RFs: men having sex w/men, sex w/prostitutes, IVDU, transfusion w/o screening, sexually active, past STI, TB, sex w/anyone w/HIV RFs, sex for money; Sx: wt loss, fatigue, f, sweats, delirium, infections typical of t-cell dysfxn→ fungal, mycobacterial, other)
      • Hyperthyroidism (Sx: irritability, diarrhea, palpatations, tremor, heat intolerance, wt loss, weakness, infetility, ED, menstrual irreg; PE: sometimes proptosis, tremor, tachycardia, lid lag, palpable thyroid, hyper-reflexia, moist skin)
      • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
      • Progressive Multi-focal Leukoencephalopathy (PML) (Etiology: JC virus; RFs: HIV or immuncompromised meds; Sx: lethargy, apathy, hallucinations, inattentiveness, perservation, & other manifestations of confusional state that's progressive over months, unrelenting→ leading to disability and death)
      • Wilson's dz (Sx: initially present w/signs and sx of liver dz that's otherwise unexplained; neuro sx include dysarthria, dysphagia, tremor, dystonia, ataxia. fine motor issues; some will experience otherwise unexplained psychosis, personality changes, bizarre behavior)

      Primary psych d/o

      Psychosis defined by hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that aren't actually there), delusions (beliefs that aren't true), generalized agitation. Having collateral info from someone that knows the patient critical in determining prior behavior, timing onset, etc
      • Bi-polar d/o (Sx: mood d/o assoc w/episodes that differ from patient's normal mood & behaviour; cycling (variable duration & degree) between depression & mania→ manic sx: overly happy & outgoing, inpulsivity, participating in risky behavior, racing thoughts, easily distracted, poor performance school/work, not sleeping, unrealistic sense of abilities, increased activity; Depressive sx (not always prominent): feeling sad, hopeless, low energy, suicidality, disturbed sleeping & eating, lack of joy from activities) MOQ: Bipolar screening tool
      • Schizophrenia (Sx: age onset teens-30s; symptoms are positive, negative & cognitive; positive sx: losing touch w/reality→ delusions, hallucinations, disordered or dysfunctional thinking, agitation; negative sx: lack of interest in anything, inability to follow thru w/plan, flat affect, speaking little, social withdrawal; cognitive sx: impaired ability to understand & use info, impaired ability to make immediate use of learned info, impaired ability to focus/concentrate)
      • Schizoaffective (Sx: chronic psychotic sx including delusions & hallucinations similar to schizophrenia; however, also sustained affective sx including depression, mania or mixed)
      • Depression w/psychotic features (Sx: depressive sx commingled w/delusion, hallucinations)

      More Info About Mental Health: National Institute of Mental Health, Comprehensive mental status exam

      Back

      Skin and Hair

      Known disease?

      • cancer, psoriasis, alopecia, acne, etc

      Dermatology terminology

      Dermatologic conditions are most accurately described using a words that are specific and precise. This terminology includes the following:
      • Macule: Flat area (not identifiable if you palpate it with you eyes closed) of different color than normal skin. Can be any shape. Example: small nevi
      • Patch: Same as a macule, but bigger. Example: larger nevi.
      • Papule: Small (< 1 cm), solid, raised area. Example: Warts.
      • Nodule: Larger (>1 cm), solid, raised area. Example: Basal cell skin cancer.
      • Vessicle: Small (<1 cm), fluid filled structures. Exmaple: Coxsackie Virus - hand, foot and mouth dz
      • Bullae: Larger (> 1 cm), fluid filled structures. Example: Pemphigus.
      • Pustule: Vessicles or blullae that are filled with pus (inflammatory cells - may or may not be infected). Example: herpes zoster.
      • Plaques: Solid, elevated areas. Example: Psoriatic plaques.
      • Wheals: Raised areas, erythematous or same color as surrounding skin, papules or plaques, lasting < 24h. Example: urticaria.
      • Cysts: Large, isolated, structures; contain fluid and sometimes solid material. Example: Sebaceous cyst.
      Other secondary descriptors:
      • Scale: Flaky outer layer of dead epidermis, which sheds daily. Example: Psoriasis.
      • Crusts: Dried serum and proteinaceous exudate, secreted on top of the primary problem. Example: Impetigo.
      • Erosions: Areas of shallow loss of superficial (epidermal) tissue. Example: Apthous ulcers.
      • Ulcers: Deeper tissue loss, reaching into the dermis. Example: Venous stasis ulcers.
      • Fissures: Linear, often painful, cracks in the skin. Example: atopic dermatits between the fingers, angular chelitis.
      • Excoriations: Often linear eroisions caused by scratching. Example: scratches associated with poison ivy, scabies, other puritic processes.
      • Pigmentation (colored) or hypopigmentation (absence of color).

      Hair Loss

      Without scarring

      • Andro-genetic
        • Men (Sx: bi-temporal &/or posterior, progressive)
        • Female → diffuse
      • Hereditary (Rf: family hx)
      • Alopecia areata (Rfs: male or female, 20-50 yo, can be spontaneous or following systemic stress; if all hair lost→ alopecia totalis; PE: circumscribed patches or generalized, sometimes spontaneously re-grows)
      • Telogen effluvium → diffuse loss (Etiology: occurs w/severe systemic dz, chemo or other meds, hiv, pregnancy; generally regrows after insult resolves)
      • Local trauma → chronic pulling
      • Local fungal infection (Etiology: tinea capitis; Sx: tends to be focal; gradual or abrupt; PE: patches, w/scale)
      • Malnutrition

      With scarring

      • Hereditary or developmental d/o
      • Necrotizing Infection - bacterial, fungal
      • Cancer of the skin or mets
      • Exposures
        • Burns, XRT, caustic agents, severe trauma
      • Dermatoses
        • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
        • Sarcoid (Etiology: idiopathic systemic illness; Rfs: age usually <40, blacks >> other racial groups; Sx: recurrent/progressive cough, fever, fatigue, sob, wt loss, wheezing, joint pain, neuro sx, eye and skin complaints, chf from infiltrative cardiac dz, syncope/sudden death; often delays in dx as rx for asthma/other; PE: wheezing, other systemic findings including: uveitis, arthritis, erythema nodosum, purplish-skin plaques/nodules on face, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, CN7 palsey, PNS & CNS involvement, adnopathy, other organ infiltration)
        • other auto-immune

      Skin Infections

      Fungal

      • Blastomycosis dermatidis (RFs: lives in soil, most commonly found Great Lakes, Mississippi & Ohio river valleys, SE US; typically inhaled; hosts usually of normal health; Sites: lungs, skin if disseminated or as primary problem; Sx: many are asymptomatic; sometimes flu-like illness; others w/sub acute cough, fever, sob; skin nodules or ulcers) more from CDC
      • Candida ballanitis (Sites: head of penis, in partic if uncircumcised; Rfs: worse if immunocompromised→ DM, HIV, chronic steroids; PE: bright red erruption, sometimes w/white d/c)
      • Coccidiomycosis (Etiology: south west US, higher risk if immune-compromised Site: lung parenchyma and pleural space, joints, skin; Sx: sub-acute sob, cough, f, also arthritis, skin nodules, seeding of other sites) more from CDC
      • Onychomycosis (Site: nails; Sx: common, chronic, nail infection; more common in toes than fingers; PE: nail appears thickened, opaque and deformed/ragged; non tender; can cause onycholysis→ separation of nail from bed)
      • Sporothrichosis(Rfs: lives in soil, infection via cut when handling dirg, vegetation; Sx: painless skin nodule at site of innoculation; develops over 1 to 12 weeks; increases in size and can ulcerate; sometimes local adenpathy)
      • Tinea cruris ("jock itch") (Site: inguinal crease, genitals; Sx/PE: puritic, scaly, red leading edge)
      • Tinea pedis ("athlete's foot") (Site: feet; Sx:can itch, pain if cracking; can be portal for secondary bacterial infxn; can sometimes blister; PE: scaly, predilection for sides/soles, macerated appearance in web spaces)
      • Tinea veriscolor (Sites; back, chest: Sx: multiple hypopigmented patches; sometimes puritic; PE: well circumscribed, hypopigmented patches, w/light scale)
      • Tinea capitis ("ring worm") (Site: scalp; PE: scaly, inflamed, raised, well defined patch(es) on scalp, associated w/focal hair loss)
      • Tinea corporis ("ring worm") (Site: skin - anywhere; PE/Sx: well circumscribed, scaly, patch on skin, sometimes puritic, central clearing w/active border)
      • Inframammary & diaper area candida (Site: below breasts, diaper distribution w/babies; Rfs: candida has predilection for moist spaces, also worse if immunocompromised→ DM, HIV, chronic steroids, itchy and sometimes painful PE: bright red eruption)
    • More on fungal infections from CDC

      • Bacterial

      • Cellulitis (Etiology: strep, staph, mrsa; Sx/PE: acute, painful, redness, fever; most commonly strep, though can be staph as well; focal swelling if associated with skin abscess - tend to be staph)
      • Erysipelas (Etiology: Streptococcus: Group A; Sites: often face; acute, red, f, pain PE: bright red, indurated, tender, well demarcated border, sometime oraange-peel consistency) more from CDC
      • Impetigo Streptococcus: Group A (Etiology: Streptococcus: Group A; Sites: often face; in particular kids; Sx: acute, crusted groups of lesions, often w/serous dc, not ill PE: honey crusted lesions, often around face, w/discharge) more from CDC
      • Erythrasma (corynebacterium) (Sx: chronic infection, groin, underarm, under skin folds, commonly mistaken for tinea, more common in diabetics & obese patients; otherwise, diptheroids not typically pathogenic; PE: reddish patch, sometimes scaly, sometimes itchy, sharp borders)
      • Folliculitis (Etiology: acute inflammatory process that starts around hair follicle, typically bacterial (staph, pseudomonas w/hot tubs); Sx: acute, painful, red, itchy; PE: tender, erythematous pustules)
      • Lympangitis (Sx: rapidly ascending red streak, assoc w/strep or staph, fever, tender; PE: ascending red streak, sometimes tender nodes)
      • Anthrax (Etiology: acquired from animal exposure or biological weapon; Sx: cutaneous ulcer to eshcar w/surrounding edema; if not inhalational, then no resp sx) more from CDC
      • Actinomyces (Sites: oral/neck/face, other organ systems Sx: slow growing abscess, often w/sinus tract development)
      • Nocardia (Sites: lung, skin; Etiology: lives in soil, inhaled or via open wound; Sx: w/pneumonia→ subacute cough, sob; f, abscess, cellulitis, lymphangitis if direct inoculation) more from CDC
      • Necrotizing fasciitis (Etiology: relatively uncommon; assoc w/dm, impaired immunity or perfusion; typically polymicrobial: strep, staph, clostridium, other; Sx: acute pain, swelling, fever, toxic appearing, often rapidly progressive; PE: typically abnl vs consistent w/severe illness, skin findings sometimes subtle→ redness, dusky discoloration, bulla; more profound findings as dz progresses)

      Viral

      • Herpes Zoster (Sx: acute vessicular erruption, pain a few days prior to skin lesions, neuropathic/burning type pain, PE: vessicles in a dermatomal distribution) more from CDC
      • Herpes simplex (Etiology/Rfs: past by sexual or oral contact; genital or oral herpes, encephalitis; Sx: fever or pain prior to appears vesicles ; resolves spont; can recur, can be congenitally acquired; rare cause pneumonia) more from CDC
      • HPV (Sx/Rfs: painless growths, can be single/grouped/or in multiple clusters, painless, acquired via sexual contact, travel w/other STIs; PE: single or clustered growths) more from CDC
      • Molluscum Contagiosum (Sx: acute papular erruption, assoc w/viral infection; PE: papules) more from CDC

      Mycobacterial

      • M Mariunum (Rfs: local infection, often of hand, related to exposure to fish tanks/cleaning; local papules to nodules, can ulcerate)

      Parasites

      • Leishmaniasis (Kala Azar) (Etiology: spread by sand-fly bite, widespread throughout subtropics→ Africa, Central & South America, India, Mediterranean basin, Asia, Middle East; Sx/PE: cutaneous: papule→ nodule→ painless raised & indurated ulcers that don't heal over weeks to mos; visceral→ can be silent, or cause fevers, sweats, chills, wt loss, adnenopathy, organomegaly)
      • Cutaneous larva migrans (hookworm) (Etiology: typical hosts are cats and dogs; larvae shed in tool, enter humans thru bare feet; Sx: migrate thru the skin, causing itchiness and red lines; die after a few weeks w/resolution of sx)
      • Schistosomiasis (fluke) (Etiology: South America, Middle East, Caribbean, Africa: flukes, invade skin of swimmers, enter blood stream→ live in portal/mesenteric veins; Sx: itching and erruption during first few days @ site where enters skin; can cause portal htn after years; also f, c, abd pain, diarrhea; can live in bladder → SCC after years)
      • Strongyloidiasis (Etiology: warm/temperate regions including southeast US, tropics/subtropics including Asia/Southeast Asia; larvae enter thru feet/skin if walk barefoot in soil w/infected feces→ enter skin, where they can cause itching→ travel to lung→ penetrate alveoli and travel up trachea→ cough and then swallowed→ travel to and live in small intestine; Sx: most carry life-long w/o any sx; non-compromised hosts can have vague sx including cough, epigastic pain, weakness, watery diarrhea, itching, constipation; can cause life threatening hyper-infxn syndrome w/systemic symptoms if compromised from glucocorticoids, malignancy, HTLV-1 or organ transplant; PE: sometimes serpiginous red erruption from migrating larva under skin)
      • Lice (Sx: itching in hair, often occurs in outbreaks amongst kids; PE: can sometimes see moving lice on scalp; nits on hair shaft) more from CDC
      • Scabies (Sx: can be acute or chronic, intense itching→in particular at night, predilection for web spaces/hands/arms though can be anywhere, sometimes burrows visible, but often just papules and excoriations seen; spread person to person, including via sexual contact) more from CDC

      Derm w/Systemic Infxn

      Bacterial

      • Disseminated gonorrhea (Etiology/Rfs: sexual activity w/at risk groups, relatively uncommon; Sx: acute, tender pustules; can also present w/tenosynovitis, arthritis; PE: painful pustules) more from CDC
      • Endocarditis (Rfs: + risk factors for acquiring→ IVDU, abnormal or prosthetic valve; Sx: acute or subacute fever, chills, sweats; PE: relatively are skin findings include Janeway lesions→flat, painless, erythematous lesions on hands, and Osler's nodes→ painful nodules on fingers) Duke criteria for endocarditis
      • Ecthyma gangrenosa (Etiology: assoc w/pseudomonal bacteremia; often in compromised host; Sx: acute redness, induration, fever; initially painless; one or multiple; evolve rapidly (<24h), macule--> pustules/bullae--> ulcer w/gangrenous tissue; PE: redness, induaration, bualle, central eschar/ulcer)
      • Neisseria meningitidis (Site: meninges, bacteremia; Rfs: often in outbreaks amongst young adults living in close quarters→ college dorms, barracks; unvaccinated; Sx: f, c, ha, n, v, sepsis; PE: very ill, ha, f, neck pain/stiffness, purpura) more from CDC
      • Toxic Shock Syndrome (Etiology: toxin mediated, related to staph or strep, first noted w/hyperabsorbent tampons; Site: w/staph, often dont find primary infxn; step assoc w/primary skin infection or other often necrotizing site; Sx: severe illness w/fever, hypotension, confusion, target organ dysfxn; PE: ill appearing, abnormal vitals, rapid deterioration often skin primary site if step, sometimes macular rash, desquamation 1-2w after onset) more from CDC Staph or CDC Strep
      • Vasculitis (Rfs: can occur secondary to many processes including: infection, rheum d/o, malignancy, etc; Sx: diffuse erruption, can occur anywhere; PE: small, palapable purpura, dont blanch when compress them, can coalesce)
      • Salmonella typhi (typhoid fever) (Site: small bowel, systemic infxn; Etiology: related to poor sanitation→ outbreaks, travel to endemic areas, spread by contaminated/unwashed food, poor sanitation, unclean water; gall bladder can act as reservoir; Rfs: from endemic area or travel; Sx/PE: relapsing daily fever x weeks, malaise, ha, chills, abd pain, diarrhea, maculop-pap rash→ rose spots, relative brady; aside from fever, sx quite variable)
      • In compromised hosts, any severe systemic infxn (bacterial or fungal) can metastasize to skin

      Viral

      • EBV (mononucleosis) (Sx: incubation 4-6w, pro-drome 1-2w of fatigue and myalgias, then f, sore throat; PE: head/neck adenopathy, pharyngitis, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, maculo-pap rash after amox/other abx) more from CDC
      • Erythema multiforme (Sx/Etiology: acute, erythematous erruption, assoc with allergic reaction to meds, viral infections, auto-immune, idiopathic; usually self limited; PE: erythematous eruption, often w/central clearing)
      • Erythema nodosum (Etiology: acute, nodular erruption associated with infection, sarcoid, IBD, Bechets dz, other inflammatory/autoimmune conditions; PE: erythematous, painful nodules; often on legs)
      • Fifths disease (parvo virus) (Sx: acute, febrile illness in ages 5-19, runny nose, headache PE: skin erruption w/slapped cheek appearance, also rash on arms, soles, palms; sometimes symmetric inflammatory arthritis can mimic RA; can cause acute hypoprolif anemia) more from CDC
      • Hand, foot and mouth dz (coxsackievirus) (Sx: acute febrile illness, common in children, self limited, irritable/cranky, sometimes wont eat/drink due to oral invovelement, vessicles appear 1-2d after fever onset; PE: vessicles on soles of feet, palms and in mouth, also genitals, buttocks, elbows, knees) more from CDC
      • Measels (Etiology: uncommon w/vaccination, winter/spring in US, complications include encephalitis, pneumonia; Sx: cough, f, malaise, PE: conjunctivitis, runny nose, then rash, white spots on oral mucosa) more from CDC
      • Pityriasis rosea (Etiology: thought to be viral assoc; Sx: initial erruption is 2-5cm scaly "herald patch" on trunk, neck or legs; scaly w/central clearing; followed w/in days to weeks by wider spread erruption→ trunk, neck, back, legs→ many oval, scaly, pathces; can have "Christmas tree" distribution; variably puritic; lasts 6-8w, then resolves spont)
      • Roseola (herpes-6) (Sx: acute febrile illness, children typically < 3; PE: high fever, maculo-papular pink erruption, starts on trunk→ spreads to arms, legs; eyelid swelling)
      • Rubella (German measels) (Etiology: uncommon w/vaccination Sx: rash starts on face, fever, adenopathy; can be congenitally acquired) more from CDC
      • Varicella zoster (chicken pox) (Etiology: rare in kids as vaccine preventable; Sx: f, fatigue, ha, generalized vesicular erruption , duration 5-10d, can still get mild dz if vax, pneumonia in setting severe chicken pox or immunocomp) more from CDC

      Fungal
