      • Blastomycosis dermatidis (RFs: lives in soil, most commonly found Great Lakes, Mississippi & Ohio river valleys, SE US; typically inhaled; hosts usually of normal health; Sites: lungs, skin if disseminated or as primary problem; Sx: many are asymptomatic; sometimes flu-like illness; others w/sub acute cough, fever, sob; skin nodules or ulcers) more from CDC
      • Coccidiomycosis (Etiology: south west US, higher risk if immune-compromised; Site: lung parenchyma and pleural space, joints, skin; Sx: sub-acute sob, cough, f, also arthritis, skin nodules, seeding of other sites) more from CDC
      • In compromised hosts, any severe systemic infxn (bacterial or fungal) can metastasize to skin

      Rickettsial

      • Rocky Mtn Spotted Fever (Etiology: tick borne, incubation 2d to 2w; can occur in most states in US, Sx: f, c, ha, arthralgias, then generalized rash; can be severe/fatal) more from CDC
      • Typhus (various types) (Etiology: spread via flea, louse or tick, reservoirs often rodents squirrels; summer mos, incubation 1-2w, Central/South America, Asia, Central Africa, tropics; Sx: non-specific f, c, ha, malaise, myalgias; PE: non-specific mac-pap rash, sometimes adenopathy)

      HIV

      The following are skin disorders most commonly associated w/HIV. They tend to track w/CD4 counts, though it's important to recognize that patient's w/HIV can still suffer from disorders that occur in the general population.

      Acute retroviral infection

      • Acute HIV (Rfs: men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/somone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, health care worker's w/needle stick injury; Sx/PE: throat pain and redness w/o exudate, fevers, chills, non-specific rash, adenopathy)

      Bacterial

      • Bacillary angiomatosis (bartonella sp) (Site: skin; Rfs: occurs in HIV infected or otherwise compromised pts; Sx: fevers, sweats, wt loss; PE: nodules on skin, resemble Kaposis Sarcoma) more from CDC
      • Cellulitis (Rfs: common bacterial infxn w/HIV +; Etiology: strep, staph, mrsa; Sx/PE: acute, painful, redness, fever; most commonly strep, though can be staph as well; focal swelling if associated with skin abscess - tend to be staph)
      • Folliculitis (Etiology: acute inflammatory process that starts around hair follicle, typically bacterial (staph, pseudomonas w/hot tubs); Sx: acute, painful, red; PE: tender, erythematous pustules)

      Fungal

      • Oral candidiasis (thrush) (Rfs: lower CD4 counts associated w/peristence and/or recurrence; PE: white discharge, bleeds when scraped)
      • Vaginal candidiasis (Rfs: lower CD4 counts associated w/peristence and/or recurrence; PE: cottage-cheese type discharge, itchy, bleeds when scraped)
      • Histoplasmosis (Sites; lungs, liver, spleen, mouth, systemic; Rfs: exposure to Mississippi & Ohio river valley, HIV+; Sx: can be asx/mild and resolve spont; often see x-ray evidence prior infection lung, spleen w/o known past infxn; cough, fever; can cause resp/systemic illness, oral ulcers in HIV+)
      • Blastomycosis dermatidis (RFs: lives in soil, most commonly found Great Lakes, Mississippi & Ohio river valleys, SE US; typically inhaled; hosts usually of normal health; Sites: lungs, skin if disseminated or as primary problem; Sx: many are asymptomatic; sometimes flu-like illness; others w/sub acute cough, fever, sob; skin nodules or ulcers) more from CDC
      • Coccidiomycosis (Etiology: south west US, higher risk if immune-compromised Site: lung parenchyma and pleural space, joints, skin; Sx: sub-acute sob, cough, f, also arthritis, skin nodules, seeding of other sites) more from CDC

      Viral

      • Herpes Simplex Virus (Sx: acute, painful, vessicles; pain often present before lesions appear, regress spontaneously 1-3w; w/low CD4 counts, may recur or persist)
      • HIV related apthous ulcers (Rfs: men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/somone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's, hx needle stick injury from infected person; PE: painful ulcer(s) w/surrounding erythema)
      • Herpes Zoster (Rfs: increased incidence and recurrence rates as CD4 drops; Sx: acute vessicular erruption, pain a few days prior to skin lesions, neuropathic/burning type pain, PE: vessicles in a dermatomal distribution) more from CDC
      • HPV (Rfs: Low CD4; Sx: painless growths, can be single/grouped/or in multiple clusters, painless, acquired via sexual contact, travel w/other STIs; PE: single or clustered growths) more from CDC
      • Molluscum Contagiosum (Etiology: w/CD4 < 200→ molluscum more numerous & less likely resolved spont; Sx: acute papular erruption, assoc w/viral infection; PE: papules) more from CDC
      • Varicella zoster (chicken pox) (Etiology: if first infxn, can be severe and disseminated w/HIV+; Sx: f, fatigue, ha, generalized vesicular erruption, can still get mild dz if vax, pneumonia in setting severe chicken pox or immunocomp) more from CDC

      Spirochete

      • Syphilis (Rfs: men who have sex w/men, unprotected intercourse, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/somone known hiv +, ivdu, transfusion w/unscreened blood, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's; PE: other findings assoc w/secondary syphillis including: non-specific rash, w/predilection for palms, and soles; hx painless genital ulcer from primary infxn)

      Parasitic

      • Scabies (Rfs: lower CD4 assoc w/crusted (Norwegian)scabies; Sx: can be acute or chronic, intense itching→ in particular at night, predilection for web spaces/hands/arms though can be anywhere, sometimes burrows visible, but often just papules and excoriations seen; spread person to person, including via sexual contact) more from CDC

      Cancer

      • Kaposis sarcoma (RFs: most commonly assoc w/advanced HIV, though can occur in elderly/others; Sx: purplish/red/brown nodules that can occur anywhere on skin; can affect any organ system including: intestines, liver, lung, etc→ sx related to degree of organ dysfxn; PE: purplish/red/brown nodules)
      • Non-Hodgkins (Etiology: 90% of lymphomas; many different types (B & T cell), significant variability in how aggressive they may be; Rfs: age > 60, hx hiv + confers markedly increased risk aggressive NHL; EBV→ Burkitts; h pylori→ stomach MALT; Sx: f, c, sweats, fatigue, wt loss; PE: progressive, painless, generalized adenopathy; splenomegaly; extra-nodal dz can involve almost any organ system)
      • Basal cell cancer (Etiology: more common w/HIV +; Rfs: chronic sun expossure, fair skin, prior bcc, immuncompromised; Sx: Non-healing, ulcerated, bleeding on a sun exposed region PE: rolled edges, growing, non-healing, central depression, pearly, w/telangiectasias)
      • Squamous cell cancer (Etiology: more common w/HIV +; Rfs: chronic sun expossure, fair skin, prior scc, immuncompromised; Sx: Non-healing, ulcerated, bleeding on a sun exposed region PE: non-healing, growing, crusted, firm, sun exposed areas)

      Autoimmune/Inflam/Drug Rxn

      • Atopic dermatitis/eczema (Rfs: CD4< 200; Sx: chronic, waxes/wanes, hands/arms/face, itchy; PE: cracked, sometime peeling, puritic, erythematous skin)
      • Seborrheic dermatitis (Etiology: often more pronounced and severe in setting HIV +; Sx: persistent/recurrent scaly, red patches, affecting face, scalp, behind ears, body folds; PE scaly, red, flaky)
      • Psoriasis (Etiology: often more pronounced and severe in setting CDS < 200; Sx: plaques and scale; predilection for knees, elbows, behind ears, umbillicus, gluteal cleft, hands PE: raised plaques & scale on ertheymatous base, pitting of nails) more from CDC
      • HIV Lipodystrophy (Etiology: assoc w/HAART; Sx: abnormal deposition of fat in abd, back of neck, breasts, trunk; loss of sub cu fat in face, extremities, buttocks; assoc w/insulin resistance)
      • Generalized allergic reaction (Etiology: more common w/HIV +; Sx: occurs w/in a week of exposure to a med, itchy, can be local or generalized, morbilliform (measels-like); PE: erythematous, macular, often areas of coalescence)
      More on HIV from CDC

      Spirochete

      • Secondary syphillis (Rfs: unprotected intercourse, men who have sex w/men, sex w/prostitutes, sex w/someone known hiv +, ivdu, drug/etoh abuse, hx other sti's; Sx: secondary manifestations weeks after primary chancre heals; include: condyloma lata→ moist, frond-like growth in genital area; non-specific rash, w/predilection for palms, and soles, mucosal involvement, adenopathy, alopecia) more from CDC
      • Lyme (Rfs: hx living in area endemic w/Lyme→ Northeast, WI/MN, Northern Calif, occurs secondary to tick bite; Sx: bull's eye type rash→ erythema migrans, f, c, adenopathy, arthralgias; joint inflammation mos to yrs later, large joints, can wax/wane; PE: erythema migrans rash, joint pain, swelling, effusion) more from CDC

      Parasitic

      • Cutaneous larva migrans (hookworm) (Etiology: typical hosts are cats and dogs; larvae shed in tool, enter humans thru bare feet; Sx: migrate thru the skin, causing itchiness and red lines; die after a few weeks w/resolution of sx)
      • Leishmaniasis (Kala Azar) (Etiology: spread by sand-fly bite, widespread throughout subtropics→ Africa, Central & South America, India, Mediterranean basin, Asia, Middle East; Sx/PE: cutaneous: papule→ nodule→ painless raised & indurated ulcers that don't heal over weeks to mos; visceral→ can be silent, or cause fevers, sweats, chills, wt loss, adnenopathy, organomegaly)
      • Lice (Sx: itching in hair, often occurs in outbreaks amongst kids; PE: can sometimes see moving lice on scalp; nits on hair shaft) more from CDC
      • Loa Loa (Etiology: from bite of deerfly; central and west Africa; Sx: diffue or local itching; transient, painless, red swellings; tendency for arms, legs, near joints; transient blurriness if crawl across eye; many are asx; takes mos after bite for sx to develop in those that get them; PE: transient, painless, red swelling; sometimes see worms moving under skin) more from CDC
      • Scabies (Sx: can be acute or chronic, intense itching→in particular at night, predilection for web spaces/hands/arms though can be anywhere, sometimes burrows visible, but often just papules and excoriations seen; spread person to person, including via sexual contact) more from CDC
      • Schistosomiasis (fluke) (Etiology: South America, Middle East, Caribbean, Africa: flukes, invade skin of swimmers, enter blood stream→ live in portal/mesenteric veins; Sx: itching and erruption during first few days @ site where enters skin; can cause portal htn after years; also f, c, abd pain, diarrhea; can live in bladder → SCC after years)
      • Strongyloidiasis (Etiology: warm/temperate regions including southeast US, tropics/subtropics including Asia/Southeast Asia; larvae enter thru feet/skin if walk barefoot in soil w/infected feces→ enter skin, where they can cause itching→ travel to lung→ penetrate alveoli and travel up trachea→ cough and then swallowed→ travel to and live in small intestine; Sx: most carry life-long w/o any sx; non-compromised hosts can have vague sx including cough, epigastic pain, weakness, watery diarrhea, itching, constipation; can cause life threatening hyper-infxn syndrome w/systemic symptoms if compromised from glucocorticoids, malignancy, HTLV-1 or organ transplant; PE: sometimes serpiginous red erruption from migrating larva under skin)

      Autoimmune/Inflammatory

      • Acne (Sx/Etiology: common condition in teens/young adult; primary event→ plugging up of ducts of sebaceous follicles; infection is often superimposed; PE: spectrum disease: comedones→ papules→ pustules→nodules/cysts)
      • Atopic dermatitis/eczema (Sx: chronic, waxes/wanes, hands/arms/face, itchy; PE: cracked, sometime peeling, puritic, erythematous skin)
      • Ichthyosis (Sx: diffuse, chronic, generalized scaly/flaking skin, worse in dry weather; an inherited d/o, so often present from childhood; PE: generalized scaling/flaking)
      • Pemphigus vulgaris (Sx/Etiology: diffuse, painful, blisters that affect oral mucosa→ unroof→ become ulcers; secondary to malignancy, meds, genetics, and idiopathic; PE: cutaneous blisters)
      • Psoriasis (Sx: plaques and scale; predilection for knees, elbows, behind ears, umbillicus, gluteal cleft, hands PE: raised plaques & scale on ertheymatous base, pitting of nails) more from CDC
      • Rosacea (Etiology: idiopathic inflammatory condition; Rfs: age > 30, women > men, light skinned; Sx/PE: waxing and waning red patches, typically involving cheeks, nose, chin fore head; acne-like and can have pustules; eye dryness; sometimes if untreated and advanced→ can lead to bumpy disfiguration of nose called rhinophyma)
      • Seborrheic dermatitis (Sx: persistent/recurrent scaly, red patches, affecting face, scalp, behind ears, body folds; PE scaly, red, flaky)
      • Subacute cutaneous lupus (Rfs: can occur w/o SLE; photosensitive; can also be triggered by meds; PE: papular to diffuse skin involvement, often of sun exposed areas)

      Drug reactions

      • Angioedema (Sx: acute, focal swelling of lips, upper airway→ acute sob, sometimes intestines→ abd pain; can occur w/first exposure to meds, or months/years after started; common meds include ace-inhibitors, though many others PE: diffuse swelling of lips if this is primary site)
      • DRESS (drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic signs) (Sx: severe systemic and cutaneous reaction to a medication, erruption ocurs 2-8w after exposure; f, c, malaise, adenopathy; PE: erythematous patches & paules, that become confluent, can affect large areas of the body)
      • Erythema multiforme (Sx/Etiology: acute, erythematous erruption, assoc with allergic reaction to meds, viral infections, auto-immune, idiopathic; usually self limited; PE: erythematous erruption, often w/central clearing)
      • Erythema nodosum (Etiology: acute, nodular erruption associated with infection, sarcoid, IBD, Bechets dz, other inflammatory/autoimmune conditions, meds; PE: erythematous, painful nodules; often on legs)
      • Generalized allergic reaction (Sx: occurs w/in a week of exposure to a med, itchy, can be local or generalized, morbilliform (measels-like); PE: erythematous, macular, often areas of coalescence)
      • Pemphigus vulgaris (Sx/Etiology: Diffuse, painful, blisters that affect oral mucosa→ unroof→ become ulcers; secondary to malignancy, meds, genetics, and idiopathic; PE: cutaneous blisters)
      • Steroid induced skin atrophy (Sx/Etiology: response to chronic topical application of steroid, loss of sub-cutaneous tissue; findings limited to area of exposure, puritic; PE: focal area of thin skin)
      • Stevens Johnson Syndrome→ Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN) (Sx/Etiology: a severe form of erythema multiforme; acute, painful, blistering erruption that affects skin and mucous membranes; spectrum d/o, where SJS mild→ TEN severe w/systemic effects; typically a reaction to a med; PE: painful, erythematous patches to bullae and epidermonecrosis; affects eyes and musosal surfaces)
      • Urticaria (hives) (Etiology: related to meds, cold weather, allergies to food, infxn, stings/bites, environmental exposures, latex, vasculitis, other; Sx: erythematous erruption w/raised wheals, very itchy, vary in size, any location; acute resolves w/in 24h, can also be chronic; can be assoc w/angioedmea and/or anaphylaxis)
      • Vasculitis (Sx: diffuse erruption, can occur anywhere, Rfs: can occur secondary to many processes including: infection, systemic vasculitis, meds, malignancy, etc; PE: small, palapable purpura, don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce)

      Derm Findings w/System Dz

      • Acanthosis nigricans (Etiology/Rfs: assoc w/insulin resistance/obesity/DM; can also occur w/malignancies; PE: most commonly on back of neck, under arms, velvety brown, maculo-pap)
      • Adult Still's Disease (Etiology: febrile illness of unknown etiology; Sx: f and other sx are persistent, sub-acute; evaluation of f does not reveal other etiology; also arhtritis & arthralgias of larger joints; salmon colored, maculo-pap non-puritic skin erruption; myalgias, adenopathy, sore throat, pericarditis and pleuritis; PE: erruption is light salmon colored mac/pap, pharyngitis, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy)
      • Cryogloblulinemia (Etiology: medium-vessel vasculitis caused by antigen-antibody complex deposition; Type I monoclonal→ IgM or IgG, related to lymphoprolif d/o→ lymphoma, myeloma; Type II and III, mixed cryos IgM and IgG; related to Hep C (most common), SLE, RA, lymphoma, myeloma, hiv, hep b, other autoimmune; RFs: female > male, ages 40-50; Sx: subacute fatigue, weakness, muscle and joint aches, cough/sob if pulmonary involvement; confusion; symmetric or asymmetric often painful distal neuropathy, painful skin ulcers of extremities, purpuric papules; membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis; PE: palpable purpura of vasculitis, Raynauds, livedo reticularis, distal skin ulcers)
      • Cutaneous t-cell lymphoma (Rf: age >50; Sx: persistent and progressive itching over mos, sometimes systemic sx of feeling poorly, sweats, wt loss; skin findings only→ mycosis fungoides; w/adenopathy→ Sezary syndrome; PE: progressive, red, scaly patches and plaques, sometimes adenopathy)
      • Erythema multiforme (Sx/Etiology: acute, erythematous erruption, assoc with allergic reaction to meds, viral infections, auto-immune, idiopathic; usually self limited; PE: erythematous eruption, often w/central clearing)
      • Erythema nodosum (Etiology: acute, nodular eruption associated with infection: TB, histo; sarcoid, IBD, Bechets dz; other inflammatory, autoimmune or granulomatous conditions; PE: erythematous, painful nodules; often on legs)
      • Kaposis sarcoma (RFs: most commonly assoc w/advanced HIV, though can occur in elderly/others; Sx: purplish/red/brown nodules that can occur anywhere on skin; can affect any organ system including: intestines, liver, lung, etc→ sx related to degree of organ dysfxn; PE: purplish/red/brown nodules)
      • Leukemic infiltrate (Sx/Etiology: leukemic cells can infiltrate skin; not specific for leukemia; dx based on hx and bx; PE: appear red, indurated, can have bullae)
      • Lupus (Etiol: idiopathic/autoimmune, drug induced→ hydralazine, procainamide, INH, others; Rfs: female > male, black>white, age onset 15-50; Sx: sub-acute onset, fever and feeling poorly in general, photosenstive, rash on face, discoid erruption on body, multi-system involvement including: confusion if CNS involvement, kidney involvement, muscle aches, pain and inflamation of 2 or more peripheral joints→ can be migratory, SOB w/pleural or parenchymal disease, CP if pericarditis; PE: painless oral ulcers, malar and nasal bridge erruption sparing naso-labial folds, discoid erruption on body, pleural rub or findings of effusion, pericardial rub, inflammatory arthritis, adenopathy, scarring hair loss) more from CDC
      • Mixed connective tissue d/o (Etiology: rare d/o, cross over between lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis; Sx: fatigue, muscle and joint aches, finger pain after exposure to cold; PE: raynauds → fingers blanch/hurt when exposed to cold temp, sausage-type thickening of fingers)
      • Niacin deificiency (Etiology: nutritional deficiency; Sx: chronic, prgressive, symmetric, erythematous erruption, puritic, can resemble sunburn, often V-area of neck, skin is often dry & rough appearing; diarrhea; irritability, anxiety, delusions, apathy; symmetric, painful peripheral sensory and motor neuropathy, arms and legs)
      • Porphyria (Etiology: a family of uncommon d/o assoc w/abnormalities in heme biosynthesis→ accumulation of precursor proteins; porphyria cutanea tarda assoc w/hep c; Sx: episodic acute otherwise unexplained abd pain w/n, v; weakness; episodic unexplained bizarre behavior, often mis-dx as primary mental health d/o; attacks triggered by meds, smoking, stress, drugs, etoh, other; skin findings in sun exposed areas; PE: excess hair growth on face/sun exposed areas; bullae, pigmentation, fragile/slow healing skin)
      • RA (Rfs: women > men; age 30-55; Sx: subacute (>6w), persistent/progressive joint pain, worse in AM due to gelling→ improves w/use, fatigue, tendency for bilateral involvement, commonly small and medium sized joints; PE: warmth, redness, spongy feeling from synovial inflam, pain w/squeezing of joints, effusion, abnormal appearing if longstanding, MCPs with chronic changes; extra articular findings: episcleritis, pleural/pericardial inflam, rheumatoid nodules) more from CDC
      • Sarcoid (Etiology: idiopathic systemic illness; Rfs: age usually <40, blacks >> other racial groups; Sx: recurrent/progressive cough, fever, fatigue, sob, wt loss, wheezing, joint pain, neuro sx, eye and skin complaints, chf from infiltrative cardiac dz, syncope/sudden death; often delays in dx as rx for asthma/other; PE: wheezing, other systemic findings including: uveitis, arthritis, erythema nodosum, purplish-skin plaques/nodules on face, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, CN7 palsey, PNS & CNS involvement, adnopathy, other organ infiltration)
      • Scleroderma (Rfs: age onset < 50, women > men; Sx: can be localized to skin or cause systemic dz; local skin; local disease causes focal skin thickening, skin pigmentation; greater involvement can include: GERD, skin tightening/thickened fingers, telangiectasias, raynauds→ finger hypoperfusion and pain in cold, calcium deposits in sub-cu; w/systemic sclerosis, wide spread dz affecting skin, lungs→ sob from pulm htn and interstitial lung dz; joints→ athralgias & myalgias,; kidneys→ scleroderma crisis; pericardium→ pericarditis; gi→ GERD; PE: raynauds → fingers blanch/hurt when exposed to cold temp, skin thickening/tightness, hyperpigmentation)
      • Urticaria (hives) (Etiology: related to meds, cold weather, allergies to food, infxn, stings/bites, environmental exposures, latex, vasculitis, other; Sx: erythematous erruption w/raised wheals, very itchy, vary in size, any location; acute resolves w/in 24h, can also be chronic; can be assoc w/angioedmea and/or anaphylaxis)
      • Vasculitis (Rfs: can occur secondary to many processes including: infection, systemic vasculitis, malignancy, can be limited to the skin or idiopathic; Sx: diffuse eruption, can occur anywhere; PE: small, palapable purpura, don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce)

      Skin Cancer & Growths

      Benign

      • Actinic keratosis (AKs) (Sx: small scaly/roughened patches on sun exposed areas, risk of becoming bcc or scc; PE: rough, scaly patches )
      • Cherry angioma (PE: small, raised, proliferation of blood vessels)
      • Cutaneous horn (PE: raised, keratinized, can harbor SCC at base)
      • Dermatofibroma (Sx: asx, non-tender, non-progrssive; PE: raised, non-tender nodule)
      • Epidermal cyst (slow growing, feel fluid filled on palpation, non-tender unless infected; PE: non-tender, small fluid filled cyst, when infected can increase rapidly in size, red tender)
      • Keratocanthoma (Sx: rapidly growing, raised, predilection for sun exposed area, can harbor SCC; PE: "errupting volcano" appearance)
      • Lipoma (Sx: very slow growing, non-tender, often subtle, mass below the skin; PE: homogeneous, squishy feel on palpation, non-tender, no skin changes)
      • Neurofibroma (Sx: can be isolated, in which case asx; if many→ consider neurofibromatosis→ sx related to involvement w/cns, pns, other structures; PE: multiple, raised, flesh colored nodules or papules, neurofibromatosis is assoc w/ cafe au lait macules)
      • Pyogenic granuloma (Etiology: benign vascular tumor; PE: grows rapidly, bleeds easily, sometimes triggered by trauma)
      • Seborrheic keratoses (SKs) (Sx: raised, warty/stuck on appearance, increase in frequency w/aging, sometimes referred to as "barnacles on the ship of life"; PE: raised, waxy, stuck on appearing)
      • Skin tags (Rfs: common in patients w/DM, obesity; Sx: small fleshy growths, often w/a stalk, tend to grow @ points of friction→ under arms, around neck, eyelids, groin)

      Malignant

      • Basal cell cancer (Rfs: chronic sun expossure, fair skin, prior bcc, immuncompromised; Sx: Non-healing, ulcerated, bleeding on a sun exposed region PE: rolled edges, growing, non-healing, central depression, pearly, w/telangiectasias)
      • Melanoma (Rfs: fair skin, fair hair, prior melanoma, dysplastic moles, family hx, hx blistering sun burns, immunocompromised; PE: Asymmetric, irregular Borders, non-homogeneous Color, Diameter > 6mm, Evolves over time, bleeds, non-healing)
      • Squamous cell cancer (Rfs: chronic sun expossure, fair skin, prior scc, immuncompromised; Sx: Non-healing, ulcerated, bleeding on a sun exposed region PE: non-healing, growing, crusted, firm, sun exposed areas)

      Non-Healing Wounds or Ulcers

      • Cancer
        • Basal cell cancer (Rfs: chronic sun expossure, fair skin, prior bcc, immuncompromised; Sx: Non-healing, ulcerated, bleeding on a sun exposed region PE: telangiectasias, pearly w/rolled edges, growing, non-healing, central depression)
        • Melanoma (Rfs: fair skin, fair hair, prior melanoma, dysplastic moles, family hx, hx blistering sun burns, immunocompromised; PE: Asymmetric, irregular Borders, non-homogeneous Color, Diameter > 6mm, Evolves over time, bleeds, non-healing)
        • Squamous cell cancer (Rfs: chronic sun expossure, fair skin, prior scc, immuncompromised; Sx: Non-healing, ulcerated, bleeding on a sun exposed region PE:non-healing, growing, crusted, firm, sun exposed areas)
        • Skin met from primary elsewhere→ uncommon
      • Compromised healing from: poor nutritional state, chronic advanced illness (kidney, liver, hiv), meds (prednisone, chemotherapy)
      • Diabetes (Etiology: neuropathy→ impaired sensation so can't feel wound; PAD→ can't heal once wound develops/infxn sets-in)
      • Infection (Sx: redness, d/c, fever; can be superimposed on wound that is slow healing due to PAD, DM, osteomyelitis, foreign body, other process)
        • Bacteria (Etiology: typically Staph or strep; Rfs: trauma, PAD, DM; or can can a secondary infection if primary ulcer from vasculitis/other; Sx: pain, redness, swelling, d/c; PE: induration, redness, d/c)
        • Francisella tularensis (bact: tularemia) (Sites: skin, lymph nodes, lung; Etiology/Rfs: passed from dying wild animals to humans via ticks/insects, US Southeast and Rocky Mtns; Sx: f, c, ha, oral or skin ulcers, painful adenopathy, sob, muscle aches) more from CDC
        • M Marinum (mycobact) (Rfs: exposure via fish tanks; Sx: sub-acute skin infection; PE: sub-acute, progressive skin infxn, not repsonsive to typical rx)
        • Sporothrichosis (fungus) (Rfs: lives in soil, infection via cut when handling dirt, vegetation; Sx: painless skin nodule at site of innoculation; develops over 1 to 12 weeks; increases in size and can ulcerate; sometimes local adenpathy)
        • Anthrax (bact) (Etiology: acquired from animal exposure or biological weapon; Sx: cutaneous ulcer to eshcar w/surrounding edema; if not inhalational, then no resp sx) more from CDC
        • Blastomycosis dermatidis (fungus) (RFs: lives in soil, most commonly found Great Lakes, Mississippi & Ohio river valleys, SE US; typically inhaled; hosts usually of normal health; Sites: lungs, skin if disseminated or as primary problem; Sx: many are asymptomatic; sometimes flu-like illness; others w/sub acute cough, fever, sob; skin nodules or ulcers) more from CDC
        • Leishmaniasis (parasite: Kala Azar) (Etiology: spread by sand-fly bite, widespread throughout subtropics→ Africa, Central & South America, India, Mediterranean basin, Asia, Middle East; Sx/PE: cutaneous: papule→ nodule→ painless raised & indurated ulcers that don't heal over weeks to mos; visceral→ can be silent, or cause fevers, sweats, chills, wt loss, adnenopathy, organomegaly)
      • Neuropathic wound (Etiology: impaired sensation can lead to wounds that go unnoticed and grow, anything that causes neuropathy can contribute→ diabetes in partic PE: if very neglected and/or co-existent other wound healing problems→ neuropathic ulcer)
      • Pressure ulcer (Etiology: persistent lying on an area of body, w/local ischemia and skin breakdown; RFs: Paralysis, severe motor impairment, profound weakness, advanced dementia, poor nutrition; PE: ranges from mild erythema to deep tissue loss w/exposed bone)
      • Peripheral Arterial Disease - PAD (Etiology: C/V RFs; Sx: progressive ulcers, aching in legs that's worse w/activity and better w/rest; if severe→ better w/dangling legs; relatively easily infected; PE: lost of pulses, decreased cap refill, feet cool to touch, sometimes shallow ulcers first, deep ulcers/infxn/gangrene if advanced)
      • Trauma
      • Vasculitis - relatively uncommon cause of non-healing wounds - small or medium vessels
        • Buerger's Dz (thromboangiitis obliterans) (Sx: smoker, non-healing, painful ulcers of hands, feet; PE: progressive ulcers, can become gangresnous)
        • Pyoderma gangrenosa (Sx/Rfs: wounds associated w/IBD, cancer; wounds grow in unusual places and w/o clear explanation; non-responsive to typical wound care; PE: can be beefy red, sometimes surrounding erythema, sometimes eschar)
        • Polyarteritis Nodosa (Rfs: 40s-50s, men>women, Hep B/C; Sx: more commonly subacute over mos f, s, malaise, wt loss, muscle/joint pain; multiple systems: arthritis, glomerulonephritis, peripheral nerve pain/dysfxn, abd pain; PE: skin w/ulcers, small, palapable purpura→ don't blanch when compress them, can coalesce; abd pain, blood per rectum)
        • Medication or toxin induced vasculitis (Rfs: levimasole→ used to cut cocaine; Sx: acute, painful distal extremities, in particular→ fingers, ears, nose; PE: decreased cap refill distally, swelling, pain, distal necrosis)
        • Granulomatosis with poyangiitis (GPA) (Sx: fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, sweats, wt loss; recurrent/progressive nasal congestion, cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; skin ulcers; PE: mucosal erythema, ulcer, nasal septum perf, palpable purpura, skin ulcer/necrosis)
        • Microscopic polyangitis (MPA) (Sx: fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, sweats, wt loss; recurrent/progressive cough, f, c, wheezing, hemoptysis; less often nasal sx c/w GPA; lab evidence glomerulonepthritis; often delays in dx as rx for more common infxn/inflam processes; skin ulcers; PE: mucosal erythema, ulcer, palpable purpura, skin ulcer/necrosis)
        • Cryoglobulinemia (Rfs: hepatitis C - though can occur without; Sx: fatigue, sob, arthralgias, skin ulcers, gross hematuria, neuropathic pain; PE: palpable purpura, digital ulcers/gangrene, sensory and motor neuropathy)
        • Raynauds (secondary) (Etiology: distal vasospasm assoc w/an underlying d/o such as scleroderma, SLE, cryoglobulinemia, cancer; Sx: related to underlying dz; in fingers, vasospam can be severe and disabling, leading to ischemia and necrosis and finger loss; spasm often triggered by cold temp; PE: other findings of scleroderma or underlying dz; fingers w/ischemic changes, ulcers, pain, secondary infection)
          • Scleroderma (Rfs: age onset < 50, women > men; Sx: can be localized to skin or cause systemic dz; local skin; local disease causes focal skin thickening, skin pigmentation; greater involvement can include: GERD, skin tightening/thickened fingers, telangiectasias, raynauds→ finger hypoperfusion and pain in cold, calcium deposits in sub-cu; w/systemic sclerosis, wide spread dz affecting skin, lungs→ sob from pulm htn and interstitial lung dz; joints→ athralgias & myalgias, kidneys→ scleroderma crisis; pericardium→ pericarditis; gi→ GERD; PE: raynauds → fingers blanch/hurt when exposed to cold temp, skin thickening/tightness, hyperpigmentation)
        • Other vasculitides - can be assoc w/cancer, other rheumatologic d/o
      • Venous insufficiency (Sx: chronic swelling, worse at end of day, PE: long standing stasis can lead to bluish discoloration and ulcers→ medial lower leg common site, chronic edema)

      Itching?

      Skin D/O

      • Atopic dermatitis/eczema (Sx: chronic, waxes/wanes, hands/arms/face, itchy; PE: cracked, sometime peeling, puritic, erythematous skin)
      • Bullous pemphigoid (Rf: Older adults; Sx: puritic urticarial lesions, that later become blisters, oten in intertriginous areas)
      • Contact dermatitis (Sx: acute, erythematous, itchy, following contact w/something; PE: appearance on skin follows pattern of contact)
      • Cutaneous t-cell lymphoma (Rf: age >50; Sx: persistent and progressive itching over mos, sometimes systemic sx of feeling poorly, sweats, wt loss; skin findings only→ mycosis fungoides; w/adenopathy→ Sezary syndrome; PE: progressive, red, scaly patches and plaques, sometimes adenopathy)
      • Dematophyte infections (Etiology: fungal infections any place on the body can itch, predilection for moist areas, PE: red w/scale and defined leading edge, e.g.: Tinea cruris, tinea pedis, inframammary area candida)
      • Folliculitis (Etiology: acute inflammatory process that starts around hair follicle, typically bacterial (staph, pseudomonas w/hot tubs); Sx: acute, painful, red, itchy; PE: tender, erythematous pustules)
      • Lice (Sx: itching in hair, often occurs in outbreaks amongst kids; PE: can sometimes see moving lice on scalp; nits on hair shaft) more from CDC
      • Lichen simplex chronicus (Etiology: the underlying problems is the chronic itching itself; Sx: self perpetuating cycle of ithcing, occurs in patches; PE: lichenifiied, red, sometimes scaly, puritic patches)
      • Parasitic infections (Etiology: strongyloidiasis, cutaneous larva migrans, loa loa, others; Rfs: travel to an endemic area)
      • Psoriasis (Sx: plaques and scale; predilection for knees, elbows, behind ears, umbillicus, gluteal cleft, hands PE: raised plaques & scale on ertheymatous base)
      • Scabies (Sx: can be acute or chronic, intense itching→ in particular at night, predilection for web spaces/hands/arms though can be anywhere, sometimes burrows visible, but often just papules and excoriations seen; spread person to person, including via sexual contact) more from CDC
      • Urticaria (hives) (Etiology: related to meds, cold weather, allergies to food, infxn, idiopathic; Sx: erythematous erruption w/raised wheals, very itchy, vary in size, any location; acute resolves w/in 24h, can also be chronic; can be assoc w/angioedmea if severe)
      • Xerosis→ dry skin (Sx: chronic condition, typically affect extremities; PE: itchy, dry, cracked, scale, lichenified)

      Systemic D/O

      Often see excoriations/signs of scratching, but no primary skin erruption
      • Any disease or meds assoc w/cholestasis (advanced liver disease; PE: findings typically include jaundice)
      • Metabolic d/o
        • Chronic renal dz/Uremia
        • Hyperthyroidism
        • Hypothyroidism
      • Hematologic/Oncologic D/O
        • Polycythemia Verra→ itchiness exacerbated by warm shower/tub
        • Mastocytosis
        • Hodgkins Lymphoma
        • Leukemia
        • Paraneoplastic assoc w/some solid tumors
        • Multiple Myeloma
        • Carcinoid tumors
      • Pregnanacy associated
      • Infections
        • HIV assoc
        • Parasistic dz: giardia, shistosomiasis, ascariasis, onchocerciasis
      • Post herpetic neuralgia assoc

      Medications

      • Many oral meds: temporal link to onset itching w/initiation Rx
      • Many topical meds (Etiology: typically local effect, itching temporally related to initiation of med, skin findings may be persistent or transient; PE: may have local rxn, excoriations if no skin findings; chronic topical steroids causes itching when rx stopped and atrophy)

      Psychogenic

      • Manifestation of obsessive-compulsive d/o, delusions, substance abuse

      More Info About Skin Disorders:
      National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Disorders

      Back
